name: Preşedinte. –
text: The first item on the agenda today is the debate on the report of Mrs Giulia Moi and Mrs Renate Sommer, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety and the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the cloning of bovine animals, swine, sheep, goats and equidae reared and reproduced for agricultural purposes (COM(2013)0892 - C7-0002/2014 - 2013/0433(COD)) (A8-0216/2015).

name: Renate Sommer
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, I would like to thank my co-rapporteur, Giulia Moi. We have worked very well together and are united in what we are now presenting to Parliament for a vote at first reading. We want to turn two proposals for directives from the European Commission into a single regulation that applies equally in all Member States. This is particularly important on an issue as fundamental as cloning. All Member States must act equally. This is what the common internal market requires. Our proposal is very consistent. We want to ban cloning in principle, because cloning is animal cruelty. The success rate is exceptionally low: ten percent, says EFSA. This varies according to animal species, but ultimately a minimal success. Why is that? Cloning technology has not matured, and in the last twelve years there has been no progress at all on this technique. The mortality rate remains the same. Live-born animals – the few born alive – suffer to a large extent from deformities, malformations of internal organs or external extremities, they suffer from immunodeficiency and, for example, from problems of the respiratory tract. As a result, many of these live-born animals die in the first few weeks, before they are put down. And they die agonizingly. Can we allow this to happen? Is it not also our job to ensure the welfare of animals? As I said, this technique is used even though it does not work. Yes, it is not applied directly in the European Union, but in third countries – in North America, I think perhaps also in South America, in China, for example – and we benefit from it, because we can import so far. We can import reproductive material or the descendants of cloned animals. Is that right? Is it right that we say: yes, we have nothing to do with cloning technology, it is not used in Europe, but we would like to have the propagating material. That is a sham! We wash our hands of innocence and let others do the dirty work, but we want to profit from the success. And is the success really so great? As I said, mortality is extremely high. And in our opinion, the progress of breeding is extremely limited. Because there are biological limits in animals. At some point, the body of a farm animal is exhausted, and everything else – still more production increase, more muscle packs still put on an animal, still more milk on the animal – is ultimately animal cruelty in livestock farming. After all, cloning impoverishes the gene pool of our farm animals worldwide. Can we allow this to happen? Incidentally, it is not only the cloned animals themselves that survive, but also the mothers who suffer. This, too, must be taken into account. The removal and re-insertion of the oocytes is not harmless and there are a high number of caesarean sections. At the end of the day, there is something that moves us here, and the European Parliament has always moved, just as it worries our citizens in the European Union: it is a fact that every reproductive technique developed for farm animals has ultimately reached humans. And it is precisely this concern that is driving people in the European Union around. That is another reason why they are against cloning. They do not want this, because it is precisely this fear that cloning will eventually be applied to humans, once it works properly. So: Defend the beginnings! It actually touches the roots of our own, our human existence. Nor do our citizens want to have the meat of cloned animals on their plates. But they may already be cheered on. That is why we want to ban everything. We want to ban not only the use of cloning technology in the European Union, but also the import of reproductive material, the import ation of clones and their descendants. And we want, in principle, a labelling requirement for what may have already landed on our market. Is that unrealistic? We think: No. Traceability is possible, as experience with GMOs has shown. In the case of animal feed and food, it was easy to introduce a traceability system for third countries worldwide. And if the European Commission now says' 'Oh, but this is not possible with farm animals', then we do not think that is true. Especially in farm animals there are breeding books. Farm animals are therefore even more traceable according to their origin. That is our view, and we think that all is feasible. I would therefore ask the European Commission to: to reconsider the whole thing. Above all, I would ask my fellow Members in this House to give massive support to our joint report , the report by Giulia Moi and myself. You are doing something for animal welfare, and you are also doing something for the European Union's community of values. We have a responsibility here as Members of the European Parliament. Sometimes politics has to set limits, and today it is. Please help us to draw this line! Thank you very much!

name: Giulia Moi relatrice. –
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Parliament now has the opportunity to take on a great responsibility: to make our trading partners and competitors understand, across the Atlantic or in deeper Asia, that we are not prepared to trade the health of our citizens, our families and future generations, in exchange for food of dubious origin and quality! We are well aware that the directive deals with farm animals and that our farmers are now facing strong foreign competition, due to under-controlled practices such as cloning; But we also know that Europe bases its value on the quality of its products and not on quantity alone. The production and marketing within the European Union of products derived from cloned animals is a matter of concern to us and to which we must pay due sensitivity, but without underestimating the health and welfare of animals, offspring and what unsead DNA can cause in human health.  Known are the cases of premature death of clones, mutilation in the offspring, intoxication of surrogate mothers, subjected to strong hormonal and antibiotic treatments. But if all this is known to us, there remains doubts as to the nutritional intake that a cloned food, or rather a food that derives from the offspring of a clone – which is what we then import from third countries – can give, and what consequences the human being can be subjected to after its continuous administration. We are therefore called upon to protect the well-being of our citizens, to take responsibility for marketing, importing or using these foods. Are we ready to turn our families and future generations into experiment guinea pigs?  Today we are living in a time when the food system already lends itself to paradoxes such as overnonutrition or malnutrition, we cannot continue to aggravate it with products that are not scientifically proven. We have therefore decided in the text of the report to exclude this practice within the Union, to label products derived from clone offspring, knowing that in the past the European Commission has already prepared a system for this. We have also decided not to allow this practice to be used for profit and gaming purposes, as is unfortunately already the case for racehorses. We should make this Europe better, not make it worse, venturing into roads from which it would then be difficult to go back.  I hope that the sensitivity shown by myself and my colleagues in dealing with this issue and in working on this report will match the same sensitivity that will guide your vote today. Ladies and gentlemen, I beg you, there are no certain studies on the use and administration of foods obtained from the offspring of cloned animals. Today you have a great responsibility, especially towards your children, your families, their future. You can vote today on whether to have sick children in the future and whether your children will be the lab guinea pigs of a few companies that will make a profit on your skin.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, first let me thank the two rapporteurs, Renate Sommer and Giulia Moi, for the report we have in front of us today. I very much appreciate your hard work and commitment. I am also pleased to see that Ms Sommer and Ms Moi fully support the ban on cloning which has been proposed. I also agree that any measures taken now would need to be reviewed at a later stage. These points aside, I am sorry to have to recognise that the amendments would leave little of the initial Commission proposals. Let me remind you that the Commission had proposed to ban the use of the cloning technique in the European Union for five species, as well as the import of live clones from third countries. I must reiterate my support for these initial proposals. I am confident that they protect the health and welfare of animals, allow for innovation where desirable and take account of citizens’ concerns. The report that we are discussing today seeks to enlarge significantly this reasonable ban, to include descendants of clones as well as food and feed from descendants of clones. It also seeks to enlarge the ban to include all animal species and their products. Mr President, honourable Members, last February we discussed all aspects of cloning. I remember that on that occasion I explained that the proposal was shaped in the light of comprehensive analysis of the legal powers available, rigorous impact assessment and consideration of the principle of proportionality. The current Commission has upheld these proposals because they are well balanced and respect the legal framework within which we all must operate. Unfortunately, I am afraid that many of the amendments in the report which we are discussing are legally impossible or disproportionate. Allow me to explain some of the Commission’s reservations. The report seeks to enlarge the scope to include descendants of cloned animals. However, descendants of clones are conceived through conventional methods and therefore give rise to neither food safety nor animal welfare concerns. It follows that all measures proposed regarding descendants of clones, and food or feed obtained from such descendants, can be justified only with reference to ethical presumed concerns. To support the view that such extended ethical concerns exist, the report points to the 2008 Eurobarometer study. It can, indeed, be inferred from this study that a majority of European Union citizens disapprove of cloning. However, if we look closer, it reveals that half of those interviewed thought incorrectly that animal cloning involved genetic modification. If half of the interviewees formed their opinion on incorrect presumptions then the outcome of the study has to be treated with a great deal of caution. Indeed, the results have insufficient credibility to justify far-reaching measures with a significant impact for our agriculture. In addition, the line of argument to justify measures on descendants appears to be that even if animal welfare is not compromised in cloned descendants, their very existence is an animal welfare concern for ethical reasons. Allow me to express the Commission’s doubts as to using this distant link to animal welfare concerns as a justification for such a wide ban. The Commission, as guardian of the Treaty, has an explicit obligation to respect the legal limits of the Treaty. In the case of cloning, the Treaties do not provide specific powers to address the ethical concerns that are the motivation for most of the amendments proposed in the report. Measures that are motivated essentially by ethical concerns can be proposed only under Article 352 of the Treaty – the flexibility clause. The flexibility clause allows the Union to act beyond the power of action conferred upon it by the Treaties if the objective pursued so requires. For that reason, any proposal based on Article 352 must be adopted separately under different legislative procedures. Mr President, honourable Members, I recognise that the idea of manipulating animals as if they were mere objects creates resentment and is perceived as morally wrong. At the same time, however, I firmly believe that the Commission has proposed sound and justified measures that represent a balanced workable approach to address the issues of animal cloning and to reconcile science and ethics. Therefore we should proceed on this basis.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. – Mr President, millions across Europe are saying that they will not accept global trade any more if it means trading away the rules and standards we hold dearly. In showing that we can still decide for ourselves and keep – or even strengthen – the protections that we deem necessary, while of course respecting our international commitments, this legislation demonstrates that we can regulate globalisation for the benefit of people and the planet. In the Committee on International Trade we reviewed this proposal to ensure that it was absolutely compatible with WTO rules. We even found that we could go further than the Commission had initially proposed and ban not just the cloned animals, but also their offspring. This is an important piece of legislation and it bears witness to the crucial role that the EU plays and must play to protect our citizens in our rapidly changing world.

name: Pilar Ayuso
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, cloning is the latest technique of reproduction and animal improvement that science has put at our disposal. Personally, I think it is a perfectly expendable technique, except for the conservation of some endangered species, but there we have it, and the European Union needs legislation on this. This is a great report, and in this House we agree to ban the technique of cloning for animal welfare reasons and for the negative position of public opinion on this technique. However, we should point out that the scientific reports of the Food Safety Agency indicate that there are no food safety problems with products from cloned animals – meat or other products – and that there is currently no distinction between the meat of a cloned animal and that of an animal that has not been cloned, since there is no genetic modification and there is currently no valid analytical methodology , accredited and harmonised to differentiate them.  However, the legislation applicable in the European Union must also apply to the products we import, because we cannot subject our farmers to conditions other than those of third-country farmers. For all this, and although we think this is a great report, in the Committee on Agriculture the members of my political group differ by two points. In particular, we believe that the importation of genetic reproduction material from cloned animals or their offspring should be allowed by administrative authorisation. At the same time, the importation of the first and second generation of cloned animals, descendants of cloned animals or their products should also be authorised by appropriate labelling and import certificate. Finally, I think we have a big problem, but in any case we must approximate our positions and come to legislation that is coherent, because it is of no use legislating if this legislation cannot then be applied or cannot be verified to be applied. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank the Madam President, you were right to say that the consumption of meat from animals that have been cloned does not pose any health risks. Their two arguments against cloning were, firstly, animal welfare considerations and, secondly, the public image of cloning. I believe that we should agree that the image is not a sufficient reason to ban an innovative technology in principle.  Animal welfare, on the other hand, can be guaranteed by animal welfare legislation in cases where cloning actually leads to a burden on animals. But banning all technology – just because the image is bad – seems questionable to me. How do you feel about this?

name: Pilar Ayuso (PPE)
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Lucke, I agree with you that the image should not be that, but we are Members, representatives of the Europeans who vote for us, and there is a rejection in public opinion - let us not deny it – to this technique of cloning. I believe that in the European Union we can ban the technique of cloning. It would not be good for our scientists and our scientific system, because we will not allow them to move forward in this area. But it's public opinion. The issue of animal welfare also arises: citizens are very against this cloning. But the importation of genetic material and meat or products derived from cloned animals or their descendants should not prohibit it.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu
text: on behalf of the S&D group – Mr President, today we are again faced with a test: are we or are we not on the side of citizens on a matter of major interest to their lives? The problem is the cloning of animals for food, and we've been at the same point in the past mandate. At that time, the institutional deadlock could not be overcome and we were unable to regulate the issue of cloning, because each institution supported a different point of view. But we have to start from what people want.  It is clear that Europeans do not want to consume food from cloned animals. 70% of Europeans believe that the production of food from cloned animals should not be encouraged and only 15% of europeans feel the opposite, according to the latest Eurobarometer on the subject.  Unfortunately, the Council and the Commission seem to have set out to introduce the cloning process into the food chain without taking into account this desire and despite the fact that we cannot anticipate the long-term consequences of this decision. We are called upon to decide on an issue that will impact many generations and we are not allowed to play with their future. It is not enough to prohibit cloning, we must also prohibit the import of these foods. We do not need cloning to provide the European Union's food needs. To do so, it is enough to encourage a fair agricultural policy and to support producers.  I call on Parliament, the Council and the Commission to take into account not the interests of the food industry, but the health and safety of citizens and future generations.

name: James Nicholson
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, while there is support in Parliament for a ban, there is much disagreement about how long that ban should last and how far it will go. When it comes to EU policy—making our core guiding principles should be quite simple: follow the science. Evidence-based policy—making should be at the heart of what we do. For example, we have to take into account the impact of a ban if it were to include germinal products of cloned animals – their descendants – and embryo clones. That could have serious consequences for animal breeders and scientific research in Europe. In 2008, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) found no indication of any differences in food safety between food products from healthy cloned animals compared to those from conventionally—bred animals. A ban on the import of these products would be challenged according to the existing WTO rules. This is a very sensitive issue, I am aware of that, and there are legitimate concerns about animal welfare. However, I feel that this report very much extends the scope of the Commission’s original proposal, it is legally unenforceable and quite frankly a piece of legislation we could do without.

name: Ulrike Müller
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner! Colleagues! Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Sommer and Mrs Moi, I would like to thank the rapporteurs for their work on We all agree in this House that we do not want animal cloning in Europe, nor do we need it. Our breeders are able to maintain genetic diversity and produce high-quality breeding material in the traditional way. We also all want a ban on the placing on the market of cloned animals and clone disused embryos, just as we do not want to have food from cloned animals!  The Commission wants to achieve the objective with two directives and wants to oblige the Member States not to bring imported animals and goods into our countries. I agree with the rapporteurs' proposal to turn these two directives into a regulation. The merging of the texts is important and necessary. However, I now have to pour a little water into the wine: the report by the two rapporteurs, Sommer and Moi, is well overthe mark. And there is no additional approach to targeted problem solving!  We know that cloning technology is already being used in many countries, and the semen of cloned animals is already being used in EU countries. Do we really need to see the mandatory introduction of a labelling system and traceability of cloned animals and their offspring in all generations? I don't think so! The labelling in the breeding books must suffice, as the obligation to provide proof is currently not possible.  We cannot distinguish between the cloned animal and the origin at e-animal. We should install a system that does not incur significant additional costs for farmers and processors and, above all, does not deceive consumers. For me, the approval of the Sommer/Moi report means a ban on imports of all products from countries where cloning technology is used. Thank you very much.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: n/a
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. Thank you very much, Mr. President. I am glad that you and your group argue that there is no need to have animal cloning in Europe, but I was surprised by your assertion that you feel that labelling is not necessary in the light of costs. These discussions we have had before in Parliament. What do you think: Is it more important that we have a cost of labelling or the health and knowledge of the buyer? I am on the Consumer Protection Committee and I am making a case for that.

name: Ulrike Müller (ALDE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Dear Commissioner, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is very I am quite sure that we are not really making any progress with this proposal in the report by Mrs Sommer and Mrs Moi on labelling. Because I'm a realist. If I can distinguish something and the scientific method is available, then I am happy to introduce it and to clearly label the products. However, if we do not have a basis at the moment for differentiating products, then I wonder why we want to introduce a system where we already know full well that the proof cannot be provided.

name: Anja Hazekamp
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – The birth of the sheep Dolly, the first cloned animal in the world, caused a great wave of reactions in the world in 1997. It led to horror, disbelief and outrage.  And that makes it a very special subject, because it is one of the few issues on which both the European Parliament and the People of Europe are in agreement. It's morally reprehensible and it should be banned. European citizens do not want it, consumers do not want it. The farmers don't need it and the animals pay the price. That's what cloning is about. First of all, consumers. They reject it en masse and want a free choice to refuse it. So if it's already on the market, they want good labelling. It will lead to many problems in the agricultural sector, much more than we already have, because it will lead to the demise of small farmers. Moreover, there is immeasurable animal cruelty. Because the only goal is to create offspring of highly productive animals. Even after three decades of research, no progress has been made, when it comes to animal welfare, in terms of effectiveness and efficiency. A vast majority of animals still die at birth and only a small percentage make it through the first year of life, suffering from diseases and abnormalities. Many surrogate mothers suffer unbearably, they suffer from the procedure themselves and they all have to undergo a caesarean section. This is not solved by these two proposals, because there are many issues between the two proposals, such as materials, species, applications and generations.  The Party for Animals calls for a total ban without exception. A ban on animal cloning and a ban on imports. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Bart Staes
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – This piece of food legislation has a very long history. An earlier third reading in the novel food dossier simply failed because of the Commission's rigid attitude in this matter. The Commission - let us be honest - has waited far too long for these proposals, which are far too late and, moreover, split into two pieces, two directives whose second directive was actually tabled with a legal basis which we can only call scandalous. All we could do was agree and the Member States had to decide unanimously.  We know that some in the Barroso Commission actually wanted to come up with a stronger proposal. Tonio Borg also wanted this, but that has been prevented by a number of Commissioners, including the Belgian Commissioner for Trade, under pressure from the TTIP context. I am very pleased with the proposal that is now before us. I think we are sending a very clear signal to the Member States and to the European Commission. It is very good that we are making these two proposals for a directive into a single regulation. Parliament wants a clear ban on the cloning of animals for food production. We also do not want the import or sale of cloned animals, and perhaps the most important message is that this Parliament wants a ban on the marketing of food from cloned animals and indeed, Mr Andriukaitis, of their descendants.  What are the reasons for that? They have already been mentioned in the debate. Cloning has a disastrous effect on animal welfare, leads to greater mortality, more risk of disease, genetic abnormalities. Moreover, in the long term, cloning poses a risk to genetic diversity, and as has been said, European consumers do not want to know about this kind of food either. So I hope for a very convincing majority later. I think democracy here should be based on short-term interests. Democracy must prevail over commercial interests. Democracy must take precedation of animal cruelty.  I hope that Parliament will approve this proposal by a very large majority, so that we can conclude the negotiations with the Member States in a clear and strong way with many assets in hand. [The speaker responds to a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)]

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: question ("blue card"). I feel the commitment in your speech, but the question is whether you do not go too far in your speech. What we know will come out of this debate is that there will be a large majority in favour of a total ban on cloning – and one goes even further, including offspring. But what will be the effect when the institutions then sit down and negotiate? Will we have legislation on the table? Probably not. I therefore support the Commissioner's position on this issue, which will allow us to move forward and have a temporary ban on cloning. However, with your line, the institutions will stand against each other, and the effect is that we will not have any legislation at all.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: "blue card" answer. I believe that if we are going to deal with a dossier at first reading and try to take a stand as a group of rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs, we should always indicate the best possible starting position. That is what we are trying to do in this House at the moment. It has always been the conviction of my group that a total ban, not only on animal cloning, but also on the marketing of meat, and on the food of cloned animals and their descendants, is the best approach to reassuring consumers and preventing animal cruelty.  [The speaker responds to a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)]

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, like you, I agree with this text which seeks to combat the consumption of cloned animals for the reasons you have mentioned: human health, animal welfare and, more fundamentally, for ethical reasons, since I am personally against cloning. You also mentioned TTIP, the famous transatlantic treaty project, which is very interesting. Do you not think that, in preparation for the negotiation of this partnership, the Brussels Commission will not torpedo this report?

name: n/a
text: "blue card" answer. It is true that, against the background of this dossier, the TTIP negotiations are at play. This was proven when the previous Commission, the Barroso Commission, prepared this dossier, and out of good winds who explained to us the creation of that piece of legislation, we know that Commissioner Borg actually wanted to go far beyond the proposals that were finally put forward.  It is indeed Commissioner De Gucht, the Belgian Commissioner for Trade, who intervened with a number of other Commissioners in the meeting of the 28 Commissioners. In this way, we have come to a weaker piece of legislation. I believe that, with a strong attitude here in this Parliament, we can ensure that the Commission will eventually have to give in to democracy.

name: John Stuart Agnew
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, as a UKIP MEP I really do not want to see any more EU legislation on anything at all. We do not need EU legislation on what British farmers can do and on what British consumers can eat – but ‘British’ consumers is the key word: it is up to them. If British consumers do not want to eat clones and the products of clones, they can make their wishes known to the retailers, as they did about battery chickens 40 or 50 years ago. The retailers can then incorporate non-cloning into their assurance schemes and this will guarantee that there are more British products on British supermarket shelves. That is the way to approach it. In any case, I do not think cloning is going to catch on to any great degree for two reasons. The first is that it assumes perfection – that you have ‘got there’ – when in fact there is always somebody somewhere who will produce something better, and the clone becomes redundant. The second reason I do not think it will catch on is because of the difficulties involved. We have heard about the deformities and mortality. These represent costs, and it is quite likely these costs will outweigh any benefit of cloning. Finally, I would like to say that we should never dismiss a technology out of hand. I can visualize a scenario where cloning might be quite useful. Imagine a livestock disease sweeps across Europe from Asia, most of European livestock are naive to the infection, but a few will survive it. These can be cloned and thus you can protect the species.

name: Sylvie Goddyn
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the issue of cloning food-related animals is important. It is about our sovereignty, our food security, but also our agricultural model and our values. I therefore draw the attention of this House to an essential point, namely the essential traceability, because the citizens have shown their great hostility to this technique.  I would remind you that countries that practice animal cloning have never kept a record of which animal is derived from a clone or not. As the text is presented and amended by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety and by the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, we will not be able to ensure that products from cloned animals or their descendants do not reach our plates. It is therefore clear that the declaration provided by this text is not sufficient to provide this guarantee because, in the absence of a lineage register, exporters may be mistaken in good faith.  Let's be clear and dare to tell consumers the truth. To date, there is no technology to verify whether or not a product is from a cloned animal. The only way to assure citizens of the absence of clone products is to suspend imports of the affected products from the countries that allow their trade, including under the TTIP under negotiation. So I tabled an amendment for the ENF group to protect consumers. Any elected official of common sense or rejecting the TTIP should support him.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – Animal cloning is such an intervention in the natural order created that ethically based rejection rightly arises. Cloning also reduces genetic diversity and is objectionable from an animal welfare point of view. Cloning techniques are characteristic of high mortality rates. Information is limited in several areas, it is necessary to examine how the consumption of meat and milk from cloned animals and their offspring affects the immune system of humans. The legislation tabled by the Commission cannot be adopted and is quite rightly rewritten by the rapporteurs' amendments on fundamental issues. The ban on cloning will be extended, expanding the range of farm animals named by the Commission. The amendment would prohibit not only the cloning of animals, but also the import of reproductive material from third countries and the marketing of food from animal clones and their offspring. This is linked to the planned EU-US Free Trade Agreement. Quite rightly, the ban would not only be introduced temporarily and would be a regulation instead of a directive, closing loopholes in transposition. Only 18% of the European population agrees with animal cloning. If we here are constantly boasting that the European Parliament is the only directly elected institution of the Union and that we represent the interests of the public, then we must accept the amendments made by the rapporteurs.

name: Peter Liese (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats supports the report by Mr Sommer and Mr Moi. Personally, I also very much support this report. Cloned animals suffer. And it is a requirement – it is not private ethics, it is a commandment – of the treaties that we take animal welfare into account. That is why it is also legally imperative that we do something about this. Now, of course, it can be argued that at some point this technique may be improved and is more "effective". But let me be very clear: this is the direct route to the cloned person. Because everything that works in animals without problems is done in humans. I don't think anyone wants to pave the way for the cloned person here. The question arises: how can we control legislation? This is important. I have already dealt with genetics scientifically in my doctoral thesis, and I am currently legislating for medical diagnostics, which also includes DNA diagnostics. My shadow rapporteur, Mrs Boszan, is sitting there, as are many other Members. I have therefore asked the companies dealing with DNA diagnostics: if we pass such a law, can you bring a test? "Yes, we'll have the test in three to four months." So those, the Commission or some colleagues who say that it is not demonstrable, should really talk to the experts. I would like to say one thing to you, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen: it is, in any case, ten times easier than to detect feed or food that has been modified by means of genetic engineering. This is much easier. And, with all due respect, Commissioner – as you know that I personally appreciate you – to make a proposal for a national ban on the marketing of genetically modified feed and, at the same time, to say that what we are asking for here is undetectable, that is absurd. In other words, we will adopt the Sommer/Moi report by a large majority, we will be willing to compromise. But if you have decency, Commissioner, and if you remain true to the line that you followed in the hearing, then you are also willing to compromise in the Commission, and I call on you to do so!

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to say, first of all, that we need European legislation for cloning. Although so far it is a very little used technique in Europe, it is in other countries with which we have trades: with the United States, Canada, Brazil or Argentina. I would like to point out that the cloning technique applies to select animals and that their aim is not to enter the food chain, but to produce genetic material, especially to improve livestock production — let us all remember that, since sometimes it seems that there is a great production of cloning to enter the food chain and this is not the case. The fundamental issue on which this prohibition is based — on which the Social Democratic Group and I personally agree – is animal welfare, as it is not a refined technique. Also, of course, as politicians we take public opinion into account, although more information must be given. Public opinion is mostly against it, because it believes it is a genetic modification. We support the legislative instrument; it is a bad example that we have set with GMOs. We therefore support the Regulation in favour of the abolition of all species, but I have to say that I do not agree on the extent, because it affects farmers and researchers.

name: Janusz Wojciechowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Cloning animals is a bad practice and it is very good that in the European Union we are introducing a directive prohibiting this practice for breeding purposes – when using animals for economic purposes. However, I am in favour of this being an unconditional ban, not just a temporary one. Any ban of its very nature is temporary until it is repealed, but it is a clear signal that the European Union is the opposite of cloning practice. And it is not only for ethical reasons – the Commissioner has reflected on the treaty grounds and ethical considerations – I think that economic considerations also speak unequivocally for this, because the future of European agriculture should be based on natural production methods. Cloning is part of such a vision of agriculture, animal husbandry, agriculture transformed into food factories – into meat factories. Absolutely bad concept for Europe! We should defend natural methods.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would like to begin by thanking the Commissioner for doing a very good job, which is balanced and in line with research. I would also like to be clear that we in the ALDE Group are in favour of a temporary ban on cloning. The difference today in the debate is very much about whether there should be an eternal and total ban, or whether we should have a temporary ban. In the nature of the temporary ban, when technology may develop with the future and we make scientific progress, we must, of course, make a balance and see if we need to change our legislation. In this respect, I think that the Commissioner has struck a much better balance than our two rapporteurs-general in the European Parliament. The most problematic thing for me is when we make the great extension of the concept to include offspring of cloned animals. Here we see that there is quite a large part of European agricultural production today, where we import genetic material into our own meat production or milk production. This means that you certainly eat cheese on a daily basis or drink milk derived from the offspring of a cloned animal. There is a scientific fear as soon as we look at our agricultural sector. However, if we are to be able to feed more mouths on this earth, we must continuously develop our methods and ensure that European agriculture is also more efficient in the future. However, this must not be at the expense of animal welfare. That is why we are in favour of the temporary ban, but not an eternal and long-term ban, which, in my view, is not based on any type of scientific ity but is only driven by people's fear of science in agricultural production. Since the day we started domesticating animals, having domestic animals, we have been trying to breed and increase production, get more meat from our meat animals, get more milk from our dairy animals. Even when it comes to our crops, we have ensured that they have become better and more viable. We have refined them continuously. We must be able to continue to do so in the future. That is why we support the Commissioner's line. (The speaker agreed to answer a question ("blue card") in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" question. My colleague is calling for a temporary ban, not a permanent ban, but we heard very clearly during the hearing that there have actually been no efficiencies in recent decades, that the technology has made little progress and that it is actually as bad as it was 30 years ago. Do not you believe that it would be much better to keep a permanent ban and you also pointed out that there are mainly ethical concerns, but those ethical concerns are present throughout the European Union. Would a special procedure, as outlined by the Commissioner, not simply legitimise it here?

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: answer ("blue card"). Thank you very much for the question, which is justified in several ways. However, I would like to ask a counter-question. We have not produced any effective antibiotics in 20 years, almost 30 years. Does that mean we should stop research on antibiotics? Absolutely not! But we must constantly evaluate what research comes up with and be prepared to adapt to it. Before the antibiotics were invented, wouldn't you have done research on it then because there had been no progress centuries before? No, certainly not, but we must constantly research and constantly evaluate.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we are going to vote in favour of this directive because we are strongly opposed to cloning animals for food purposes. In addition, we would like to take this opportunity to go a little further.  What really concerns us is the extension of highly technified agriculture and livestock that are based on large capital investments and which involve energy costs that only mean irreparable mistreatment of our land. The use of animal cloning for food or the use of GMOs as animal feed poses a danger, especially since they give greater power to large corporations and leave farmers who care for and respect the land helpless.  In the face of this, we are committed to a living rural world that is based on those farmers and ranchers who generate decent employment, who are able to give us high quality products, who understand that what is really important is respect for natural cycles and who also generate a rich and sustainable economic sector over time.

name: José Bové (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate the two rapporteurs, Mrs Sommer and Mrs Moi, for the work they have done to prevent the use of cloning very clearly, but also the imports of clone descendants, and I believe that this work is remarkable. It comes at a time when the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) believes that global genetic concentration and impoverishment pose a threat.  Today, farms are often dominated by a single variety: the Leghorn hen is present in all countries of the world, the Large White pig is present in 117 countries and the Holstein cow is present in 128 countries. As a result, diversity and livestock are now at a threat. On the other hand, we have a genetic concentration by companies. Today, two genetic companies control laying hens and two companies control broilers. It's a danger! And it is in this context that cloning arrives, because companies want to impose a modified genetics, that is, we are inventing, with clones, transgenic animals only for the purpose of patenting for these companies.  European consumers do not want this technology. They don't want these products. If the Commission is re-introducing this text today, no one can imagine that it is simply for the beauty of scientific work; it is obviously to give a gift to businesses in the context of the international negotiation of the transatlantic treaty. It's obvious! The consistency of time, at the time it was decided, makes this clear. I hope that the European Parliament will follow the recommendations and in particular that everyone will vote on Amendment 38, which prohibits the consumption of animals from cloning.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the proposal for a directive we are debating illustrates the sneaky technique of globalism: first we destroy all the protections of our economies, then we lower the standards by introducing new techniques that flourish at the whim of free trade and, all of a sudden, the technocratic proposal proposes a text whose aim is to establish global rules , an additional piece to the global edifice of ultra-liberalism.  The substance of this directive on the cloning of animals raised for agricultural purposes is also very worrying. Ultimately, one of the major risks is the uniformity of species and patent control by an oligopoly of companies and laboratories that will hold cloned genetic models and cloning techniques.  When parliament decides on techniques that lead to structural changes in our economy and agriculture, it is necessary, on the one hand, to broaden the reflection to the legal framework, in this case the patents for cloning and, on the other hand, to apply the precautionary principles because we must be vigilant in the face of the serious excesses of the manipulation of life.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: Mr President, today we are discussing an extremely important issue, which will affect future generations and which will certainly be discussed again in the future. I am pleased in principle that this report prohibits the cloning of animals for use for agricultural purposes, but that is the only positive element of it. Firstly, the ban is temporary and the commitment to its future lifting leaves no doubt as to the real aims of the European institutions in this regard. Subsequently, the definition of the concept of 'descendant of cloned animals' is very limited, which will have the direct effect of eventually ending up descendants of cloned animals in the food chain. Nor should we escape the fact that, with the agreement of the TTIR, we are leaving Europe unseed to import food from cloned animals, the reproduction of which in the Usa is free and uncontrolled. Obviously you haven't learned anything from spongiform encephalopathy. When we intervene so violently in nature, it is at least naïve to think that we will avoid the consequences. Our firm position is a complete and irrevocable ban on animal cloning for any reason.

name: Herbert Dorfmann (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I agree with many of my fellow Members here who believe that our agriculture does not really need animal cloning. Our agriculture copes well with the sexual reproduction of animals, and it is only there that there is finally a breeding progress. Nevertheless, we must take note of the fact that this technology is being used and accepted elsewhere in the world.  It is not up to us to decide whether this is right or whether it is wrong. Commissioner, I am very grateful to you for questioning Eurobarometer surveys here – and I have rarely heard this. It is sometimes a bit difficult when you ask people about topics they have no idea about. There is therefore no doubt that we want to ban the use of cloning in European agriculture and that we do not want to have products from cloned animals on our plates. But animals are not cloned so that you get cows for milk production, nor are they cloned so that you can get fattening cattle.  Animals are cloned elsewhere in the world to produce seeds. That is why traceability has limits – and I do not agree with some of the previous speakers on this. It is clear that we can identify cloned animals and probably also the successors of the first generation But the third and fifth generation? And if we have a piece of cheese in the European Union and then want to see if perhaps the great-great-grandfather or the great-great-grandmother of a cow was a cloned animal? So I am in favour of us being honest with the consumer. Thank you very much.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to reiterate my full and strong support, as already expressed in the ENVI Committee, for the work of synthesis and amendment to the Commission proposal by the rapporteurs, Mr Sommer and Mr Moi, which affirms the European Parliament's clear opposition to animal cloning for agricultural and food purposes throughout the Territory of the Union.  In Europe, we are not prepared to be guinea pigs, we do not need ineffective techniques to date. The precautionary principle applies! These techniques do not offer safety and quality standards to ensure our food supply. Cloning does not protect animal welfare, as well as, as a matter of priority, the health of citizens and consumers, as has been repeatedly confirmed by the European Food Safety Agency.  Banning cloning, beyond any legal sophisma or quibble, is also a major issue of ethical values and principles. We are in agreement with many of our citizens, who overwhelmingly are opposed to these techniques. It is important that the proposed ban should be extended to all farmed animals, including not only clones, but also the import and placing on the European market of the offspring of animal settlers, the germ material of all the food products derived from them. Mandatory traceability is fundamental to this. Finally, the proposal for a regulation rather than a directive is a good one.  (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Julie Girling (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I personally do not object to animal cloning in principle – unlike most of my colleagues it seems. But I do believe that the disproportionate call for a permanent ban could be damaging, because there is this big assumption that cloning can only lead to bad things. What about the possibilities that cloning and scientific advance can lead to an improvement in animal welfare? Now, that has not happened yet, I fully admit. But that does not mean to say it will not happen; what is the sense of closing the door entirely with a permanent ban when we could go down the road of a temporary ban – which is what I will be supporting in the amendments – which would have to be reviewed on a regular basis, would give the opportunity for industry to go forward and start working without the possibility that they will never be able to bring any of their advances to market.  I do not understand why this House wants to be so absolute without looking to the future with open minds.

name: Jan Huitema (ALDE).
text: – Farmers across Europe are currently struggling, but the market orientation of agricultural policy is what we have been betting on for decades and a great asset. I support the European Commission in this. This is the future. But farmers must be able to move from a level playing field. Equal monks, equal hoods. The control pressure must also be reduced. Agricultural policy is too complicated and hinders farmers from doing business. A good example are the rigid greening requirements. We must remain competitive on the world market. This should be the commitment of European policy makers, but they still too often live in a paper reality.  The European Parliament's proposal to trace descendants of cloned animals and their products is just such an unworkable proposal. It is completely unfeasible to ban the products of offspring of cloned animals, such as milk and meat. The products of cloned animals are indistinguishable from un-cloned animals. Cloning of animals is prohibited in the European Union and rightly so. I believe that this should continue to be the case until it has been proven that cloning does not adversely affect the health and well-being of the animal. The European Commission has made a balanced proposal based on scientific advice from the European food watchdog. The proposal is based on facts. The European Parliament's proposal, on the other hand, is based on scaremongering. I will therefore also vote against the European Parliament's proposal.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, cloning increases the already great danger of how we produce food today and moves agriculture in an absolutely unnatural direction. The cloning process makes cattle and pigs more likely to have miscarriages and an increased incidence of abnormal and severe births. It has no environmental, social or health benefits and therefore, fortunately, animal cloning for farming purposes is not currently used in the EU. However, it is used in some third countries, such as the USA. It is not only in the case of ready-made food that European standards, which are currently threatened by TTIP, must be defended, because animal cloning in the US has reached gigantic numbers and therefore threatens to export them to the EU. I therefore strongly ask the Commission to take this into account in the negotiating process, together with the negative opinion of citizens on cloning.  I will vote in favour of the proposed restrictive report, and I will hear the voices of many people and civil society organisations who have approached me in recent weeks. I hope that this Parliament will not return to this issue under the cloak of TTIP.

name: Martin Häusling (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The question arises: do we really have to do everything that is technically possible, or are there not also ethical limits? For me, cloning technology is an ethical issue. Moreover, we do not need them in European agriculture. We live on diversity. We must strengthen these, not restrict them by means of cloning technology. I am grateful to the rapporteurs and also to the majority if we have a clear, unequivocal position in the European Parliament here and thus also follow the majority opinion of the citizens. What I am simply asking the Commission to do now is to abandon its stubborn attitude. We cannot continue to accept the import of sperm on the European market, for example, unless it is clearly labelled. The Commission must also dare to conflict with the United States. Why not? We are not the driving force, but we should set standards here in the global markets for technology that we do not want. We simply cannot accept cloning technology for animal welfare reasons. Cloning is a dead end, not progress.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF).
text: Mr President, the issue of authorising the cloning of animals raised for food is unacceptable in more ways than one. Apart from the desire of some to play sorcerer's apprentices, this technique is not supported at all by our breeders. It also raises ethical questions related to animal welfare. During gestation, as you know, females suffer from fat calf syndrome, which is responsible for one-third of post-natal deaths, causes very high height and weight and causes the appearance of enlarged organs. One of the dangers lies in the loss of genetic diversity and this may of course not only benefit speculative interests because the technique is very expensive, so reserved for the richest. The other danger could be the accelerated disappearance of the already well-in-crisis breeder's profession. In addition, cloning has a bad image in the population, which obviously risks alienating consumers from these products. Therefore, this project is of absolutely no interest.  This proposal is also dishonest because it is only a matter of preparing for the release of the cloned products that will come to us from the United States because of your disastrous transatlantic treaty.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Mr President, despite the contrary, the cloning of farm animals does not serve the food needs of a country's population, but is done purely for the sake of speculation by multinational meat cartels and other livestock products. Cloning animals is a painful technique for animals and endangers their health because it is done by methods that violate nature. And you know very well that when nature is violated, it avenges us. In this case, revenge of nature consists of the dangers faced by people consuming products derived from cloned animals. Above all, however, cloning directly affects the principles, values, customs and customs of the European peoples. That is why we, as MEPs, have a huge responsibility not only to the present generation, but especially to future generations, not to allow the cloning of animals, either for nutritional purposes, for research purposes or for medicinal purposes. Finally, we must focus on devising a method of identifying and labelling cloned products originating mainly from third countries.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I should like to begin by thanking Mrs Sommer and Mrs Moi for their efforts in this difficult work on such a sensitive issue as the cloning of animals, which at first sight seems to involve only scientific aspects, but in reality has profound ethical implications and clearly has a strong impact on the public that has debated and continues to debate it.  There are basically two main arguments on which our opposition to animal cloning and its use for agricultural purposes is based: firstly, the protection of animal welfare and concerns about the high mortality rate of animals subjected to cloning techniques at all stages of the same. EFSA stated in 2008 – and has repeatedly taken up its positions – on the grounds that there are serious health risks to cloned animals that often lead to their deaths. In fact, there are success rates between 6 and 15% in cattle, experiences of births difficult for offspring, neonatal death. Unfortunately, the technological progress of recent years has not allowed the improvements that we all expected.  Secondly, we cannot fail to listen to the opinion of our European citizens: surveys have recently found that more than 80% of European citizens have declared themselves against animal cloning and just as high percentages of consumers have declared themselves against the consumption of food from animal clones. Of course there are parts that could be modified. Our position – but I believe that voting as a whole is Parliament's position – should be supported.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would first like to congratulate our two rapporteurs, Mrs Giulia Moi, from the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, and Mrs Renate Sommer, from the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Security, for this remarkable work on this issue of cloning.  The report you have prepared reinforces the clear application of the precautionary principle to which we are attached. This breeding technique, which is not used in agriculture in Europe, is in fact only a problem. Citizens, as has been said, are legitimately concerned about these modes of production. We must be vigilant to protect human health, the environment, animal welfare and the heritage of genetic diversity.  I fully support the lines of the report proposed to us, which prohibits not only cloning in livestock and for food purposes, but also imports of live animals and groan and food products from cloned animals, as well as all products that may come from their offspring. You also require traceability of cloning products in order to prevent their entry into European territory. I agree with that requirement. The search for economic profitability cannot in any way be free from respect for these principles and that is why we must say 'no' collectively, here in Parliament, to cloning in agriculture and food.

name: Bolesław G. Piecha (ECR).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. At the outset, I would like to say that this issue needs to be regulated, and it is good that the European Commission and the European Parliament have dealt with this issue. I would like to say that I fully support the report put forward by the rapporteur for two reasons. I omit ethical matters, I omit moral matters – two pieces of legislation that apply must be dealt with. The first issue is animal welfare. There is no doubt that animal welfare has nothing to do with cloning – but that is a great suffering for animals. And the second point, perhaps more sensitive, is food safety, and food safety is always part of a huge area of public health. Scientific research and scientific evidence on the safety of food derived from meat of cloned animals is very small or small. For this reason, cloning should not be allowed to provoke other scientific research. We don't know much, we probably won't know any more. And the question arises – why should we know more? As for the identification of meat, preparations that come from cloned animals – the matter for geneticists, for scientists is quite simple. And here, as the ers said, it takes a moment to provoke such tests.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE).
text: Mr President, this plenary debate will have been no different, it is clear, from those that preceded it and which I attended in the Committee on International Trade, the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Security, and the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. It is really a head-on clash between our Parliament and the Commission, which is, in a way, standing up against the public.  I will vote on Mrs Sommer's report and I will vote on the report, although I differ on some points. The rapporteurs go a little too far in my view, in terms of, for example, questioning the temporary and renewable nature of the cloning ban, which seems to me to ignore the possibilities of research. On this point, I agree with Mrs Girling's argument. Having said that, the real question today is how we will, in a trilogue, break this deadlock and dodge this shock, because, I am a little sorry to tell you, Commissioner, the Commission is largely responsible for the situation we find ourselves in today. Nothing or almost nothing has been done since the failure of new foods in 2011. In 2010, however, the Commission considered, I quote, "appropriate" the establishment of traceability measures, which are required not only by us, the citizens, but also by the Council. What has been done in the last five years and what do you intend to do now to save, in a way, this legislation that is essential to the citizens?

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, Congratulations to the two rapporteurs in this report. Society, to feed, does not need the cloning of animals. People who raise cattle also don't need expensive laboratory techniques to provide the food. Cloning attacks the welfare and health of animals. Cloning will only serve to create more dependence on the agro-chemical and pharmaceutical business and patents and will contribute to greater food insecurity. The European institutions often make very negative decisions for farmers, farmers and food. Today, the thousands of dairy farmers who are mobilising in my country are reminding us. Therefore, we must do the right thing, we must have zero tolerance for cloning, not authorizing cloning, not authorizing, prohibiting, the marketing of reproductive material and also food.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner and colleagues for this report. We have discussed the public opinion on cloning here in the plenary, but let me just recount a story: earlier this year in Ireland, we had a report of a famous show-jumping stallion called Cruising who passed away, but whose owner had kept genetic material and created two colt foals from this wonderful show-jumping horse. The public reaction was very positive, because they liked and appreciated the skills and attributes of that fine animal and that they had been preserved through cloning. It is an expensive technique: it cost over EUR 100,000.  I bring that to your attention to say that sometimes the public have different views on the one issue, depending on the species. I share Mr Federley’s earlier comments. We have a concern in agriculture, which is ‘how do you trace back’? Do you close off an avenue for genetic potential, mindful – and I am very mindful where there are animal welfare concerns – that we cannot allow animals to suffer.  So let us be very careful about bans. We can call for them, and it might sound good, but can we effectively implement them when we are trading? Commissioner, that is something that you might address in your concluding remarks – is it physically, technically and scientifically possible?

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the issue of animal cloning is not a neutral issue, far from it. It has many aspects, first ethically, of course, concerning animal health and animal welfare, but also on issues of human health and biodiversity. European citizens are legitimately concerned about these modes of production that do not conform to their vision of our societies.  I therefore support this report which draws the red lines in this area, by banning the importation of cloning products and by calling for the strict traceability of cloning products in order to prevent their entry into European territory. In terms of animal reproduction and improved animal characteristics, there are other methods. We have ways to build on: genomic research, for example, which helps to reinforce, in a natural and diverse way, the quality and characteristics of different animal breeds.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR).
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa The European Commission's proposal on animal cloning as it stands is not sufficient. It is necessary to adopt a regulation, not a directive. Scientific research clearly shows that cloning techniques do not currently meet animal welfare standards. Therefore, a total permanent ban on cloning should be introduced. I would like to point out that, to date, no third country has created viable labelling systems and systems for identifying and registering imports of clone offspring or food derived from them. Meat and milk from offspring and clones themselves have already started to appear in the food supply chain, and it is therefore necessary to adopt appropriate regulation on this matter. Citizens of the European Union do not want food from cloned animals on their tables and have the right to know where the products they buy come from. Thank you very much.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, in the fundamental case we follow the content of this report, thus appealing to the prevalence of the precautionary principle with regard to asexual reproduction or cloning of domestic animals. We also believe that this principle should be strengthened through control and surveillance mechanisms to prohibit the marketing and consumption of food from cloned animals. The cloning procedure applied to agricultural production is a reflection of a production model based on the unbridled demand for productivity and profit at any price, and it is this competitive framework of liberalised markets that underlies this problem. Therefore, our support for this report against the cloning of domestic animals is also a wake-up call in defence of small and medium-sized family farming, in defence of a production model based on biodiversity and respect for social and environmental standards.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – Mr President, animal cloning has been a major concern for the field of research. At the same time, food safety and security, but also animal health, have been objectives for the European Union whose consolidation has been desired and is constantly desired.  It is not irrelevant, however, that some countries around the world use cloning of animals for agricultural purposes, so this regulation is absolutely necessary. Research and studies carried out today show that more than 80% of the population of the European Union does not want to consume food from cloned animals. In those circumstances, the traceability of foodstuffs, as well as germination material arriving on the internal market of the European Union, must contain all import licences to ensure that they do not come from animals or descendants resulting from this process.  On the other hand, animal cloning is practically not only a new technology, which is not well known, but also a welcome method of research, even if we stop only on the conservation of endangered animal breeds, the production of medicines, and not only.  That is why I believe that we must continue to support research at European level in the field of animal cloning, as well as a much more in-depth analysis of its long-term effects. It is therefore necessary to re-evaluate and revise in a reasonable time to take account of all technical and scientific progress in this area, not least the perception of public opinion.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D).
text: Mr President! I warmly support the Report of the Committee on the Environment on cloning. We should ban products from cloned animals and their descendants in the European Union. The technology is far from being fully developed and the European Food Agency also says that we simply do not have enough knowledge to guarantee that food safety is in order for these products. Nor is there any doubt that the animal welfare of cloned animals and their descendants is highly endangered. All reports of this.  I think we should listen to the citizens of Europe and their concerns. They do not want products from cloned animals and their descendants. I do not want that either, and that is why I support the report and say no thanks to cloning.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! Cloning animals raises legitimate doubts. It not only has a negative impact on animal welfare, disrupts natural biodiversity, but also exposes surrogate mothers to suffering. This process is characterized by a high mortality rate of both embryos and cloned animals, a large part of which dies early in life. So I am firmly in favour of a total ban on animal cloning. Let us promote healthy, natural food. I hope that Parliament will vote to ban the sale of food derived from animal clones. The health safety of citizens depends on food safety, and healthy food is food produced according to nature. Thank you.

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE).
text: – In Parliament, we are thinking about the future.  Fortunately, because that is sorely needed, especially when we are talking about cloning animals. But at the end of the day, it's about man. Now, however, we must ensure that we get the facts straight. Only in this way can we take a decision that takes account of the real situation. And that situation is that there are a lot of cloned animal products in circulation on the European market for a long time now. Which brings me to the traceability of cloned animals. We stand for a Europe with fewer rules. Are we going to argue now that cloned animals should be traceable to the third generation? I wonder if this is feasible and I am sure that this is not possible. Look at the milk of all the farmers that ends up in one tank. Even in non-cloned animals, it is already difficult to guarantee data on breed and quality. If we can't do that now, why do we want to start with cloned animals? Not to mention products from cloned animals from third countries. In short, let us remain reasonable in this discussion. Only in this way can we create policies that are really looking to the future.

name: Paolo De Castro (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Andriukaitis, after years of legislative vacuum, partly due to a lack of agreement between the co-legislators, we are here to legislate on the issue of animal cloning for agricultural purposes. So, first of all, thank you to the rapporteurs for the work they have done.  Although there is scientific evidence showing that cloned animals comply with food safety standards and do not pose a danger to human health, resistance and objections to animal welfare and ethical considerations remain. That is why there is a great deal of consensus in this House in imposing a ban on the cloning of animals for agricultural purposes on European territory and on their marketing, as proposed by the European Commission. On the other hand, doubts remain as to the technical feasibility of traceability of offspring, particularly with regard to animals imported from third countries. That is why, Commissioner, I hope that this aspect can be better and more concretely defined between the Council and the Commission.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: – The European ban on the cloning of animals for agricultural purposes must remain in place. A large majority agrees on this. Negative effects on animal welfare and uncertainty about the long-term effects are decisive.  Based on the current state of science, the disadvantages of cloning outweigh any benefits. The question is how do you want to put this ban on cloning into practice? Well, it is essential that we do this in a realistic way. Legislation must be based on scientific facts, practical, verifiable and WTO-compatible. The Commission's proposal seems to meet those criteria. Unfortunately, the European Parliament's is not that, because it is not feasible, it is not verifiable. I will follow the realistic guidance in the vote. I am convinced that this is the only way to address the legitimate concerns of European citizens. Creating expectations that you can't redeem is counterproductive.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would also like to thank the rapporteurs of this proposal, because I consider the report presented to be of very good quality. In my opinion, a ban on animal cloning is appropriate because it is in the interests of protecting human health and animal welfare. The expert findings of the European Food Safety Authority showing the negative effects of animal cloning on animal welfare in the form of severe and fatal damage cannot be ignored. In view of the lack of convincing studies on the safety of food produced from cloned animals, I am also in favour of banning food from cloned animals and their offspring. On the other hand, I believe that the ban on cloning goes too far when it also applies to the import and marketing of germ products from the offspring of cloned animals. Such a long-formulated ban can lead to the loss of valuable genetic material and thus contribute to reducing the competitiveness of European farmers. I do not consider this to be desirable, especially at a time when European agriculture is facing serious problems and needs impetus to increase efficiency. The questions raised in this report follow a number, be it traceability of products, genetic modification. These are all questions that European consumers are asking. And I also ask: What do we want to gain from the animal? And was that God's purpose? Don't we open pandora's box?

name: Paul Brannen (S&D).
text: – Madam President, there is deep unease amongst the British public at the idea of cloned animals and this unease is shared by the wider European public. We have seen that reflected in the Chamber today in the comments made by colleagues from across the European Union. It is not only a concern about the food that we eat, it is also a concern about the potential wider impact on nature of cloned animals and their offspring – and we have heard from colleagues this morning how cloned animals do indeed suffer.  A growing world population does indeed present challenges for food supply, but cloning animals is not the answer. Rather, a move to a more sustainable approach to the entire food chain would benefit the customer, the farmer and the environment – a sustainable future, yes; a cloned future, no.

name: Christofer Fjellner (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Certainly there are challenges with cloning. The early technique created suffering for the animals. We need a broad gene base to meet the challenges of the future. It is sensitive, because public opinion is sceptical, as is so often the case with new technologies. I therefore understand the Commission's cautious approach to this issue. However, as the European Parliament is now doing, calling for a total ban on all-time food from clones and also their offspring of all generations is directly irresponsible. I will give three reasons why: firstly, it is unscientific and anti-technology because technology is evolving and progressing. To say that there has been no development in this area for 30 years is downright disingenuous. If that were the case, we would not have had this debate here today. Secondly, it is impossible to control, because we do not eat what are clones, except possibly their offspring. How could we know if an animal's ancestor's ancestor was a clone? It's as impossible as knowing if someone's great-grandfather was a identical twin. My third reason is that, in practice, this only means a ban on imports of food from more and more countries in the world. Protectionists may think that is a good thing, but do not forget that we are net exporters of food. Our bans on them will be answered by their ban on us. I am concerned that this risks being the first step towards a monumental failure as the EU's GMO policy – a hard, populist, unscientific battle in the air, which will be led by many other debates and many new problems.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I support the co-rapporteurs' proposal for a total ban on cloning all species of animals for agricultural purposes. Scientific observations have shown so far that cloning has a disproportionately small success rate and the whole process carries a number of dangers for both offs and surrogate mothers involved in the process.  In addition to animal health, however, we here, being directly elected by European citizens, must listen to their voice and attitudes. The majority of Europeans oppose this kind of reproduction and we have a duty to betray their will.
