An effective ban on imports of cloned animals and their products is a step in the right direction for negotiations on an international agreement such as TTIP. Production must not be allowed on the European market, which will undermine the confidence of our citizens in the quality of European agricultural production.  The cloning of farm animals and imports of their products must be explicitly included as ineligible for import into the European Union during these negotiations.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – First of all, my sincere congratulations to Mrs Sommer and Mrs Moi for the report prepared, which I would also be happy to support in the vote itself. Cloning, as we hear, is the first issue of animal welfare. We know that in these methods mortality is very high, that the success of this method is only five to fifteen percent, and because there is no real progress, it is right to limit ourselves and build on this method. Another very important aspect is the ethical aspect: the question of what Kind of Europe we want to live in. Can we keep doing this on animals? Is it his turn to pass a successful method on animals then also cloning on humans? This is a very big question and if anyone already wants successful cloning in animals, I do not know who wants successful cloning in humans and this as some public method. The next question, which has been very clear, to which we have been given a very clear answer, is for consumers, with Europeans rejecting, on the one hand, the method of cloning, on the other hand, the use of products, products, that is to say, cloning meat, and requiring clear labelling of these products. Here, I think that what we are going to adopt today is also a very clear signal to the negotiators in adopting the transatlantic trade-investment agreement. And if we have put responsibility on countries and countries can be identified in the case of GMOs, it is right that we give a single signal from Europe when cloning.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D).
text: – Madam President, cloning is a technology that has great potential in medicine and science, but its use in livestock farming and food production in Europe should be unequivocally prohibited. The vast majority of European Union citizens do not want to eat any meat grown by cloning. That is why a Proposal from the European Commission prohibiting cloned but allowing meat from the offspring of cloned animals is unacceptable. Such food should also be prohibited or, at the very least, unequivocally labelled. In addition, currently available cloning technology often causes fetal deformities, uterine damage, painful problems in animals, which is ethically unacceptable. The European consumer knows well what he wants and what he does not want. He supports cloning research for the purposes of medicine and science, but does not want such meat on his desk. That is why I support this directive and call on the European Commission to listen to the voice of its citizens.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – I would like to draw Parliament's attention to the fact that, in this case, it is our job to signal the problems. The various problems will be examined by the European Commission and, hopefully, proposals for solutions will be made. I believe that we are going to raise a number of real problems in this Parliament, such as the reduction of genetic diversity due to cloning, the problem of various genetic impediers, technological dependencies and, in particular, ethical issues – which is also not the last issue. So this report that we are discussing is, I think, fulfilling its role, even if there are other opinions on some points as to whether it is possible to verify the clones of the descendants, or what we even call cloning. I think, Honourable Parliament, let us see what solutions the Commission is making, which is why, at this point, I urge everyone to support this report in this way. That's not our final word, although there's clearly a will that we don't want cloning.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I support the prohibition of cloning of animals held and bred for agricultural production purposes and I am sorry that the European Parliament was not so in agreement when it came to some other controversial procedures and methods used in agricultural production today. Existing animal cloning techniques cause unnecessary animal suffering, and cloning techniques have not progressed in the past ten years and there is no scientific justification for their widespread use and use in animal breeding. The only motive for the application of such controversial techniques is profit, supposed competitiveness and unnecessary efficiency gains, especially when agricultural production is sufficient in the Europ Union and results in vast surpluses resulting, unfortunately, in food waste. Animals are thus reduced to ordinary machines, not living things worthy of our care. I also note that I am also against any importation of cloned animals and reproductive material from third countries or encouraging the use of such techniques in third countries.

name: Bas Belder (ECR).
text: I am in favour of a total ban on cloning and we support this report. My party has ethical objections to cloning, as it goes against the order of creation. It is also accompanied by a lot of suffering and high mortality among cloned animals. A tracing system must be put in place as soon as possible so that clone products from third countries are banned at the border.  I strongly call for the EU to support a global ban on cloning in international forums. Third countries must also stop, first of all for ethical reasons, and agreement is also needed for a level playing field.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Madam President, let me be absolutely clear at the outset. I am against any cloning of animals and for the simple reason that this is unacceptable from an ethical point of view. It is not clear what meat consumption means for the human body, for our organism, and I also want to be absolutely clear that this is really something that conflicts with animal welfare. It is clear that past experience that has already lasted more than a decade shows that there are no significant developments and significant results. Because of the high animal mortality, the high burdens and suffering of animals, I think we really need to be absolutely clear in this Parliament and be against putting meat on the market from cloned animals because the citizens of Europe simply do not want it. Likewise, imports of such products, in my deep belief, should be prohibited.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, over the last century, human activity has led to the greatest disruption of the ecological balance that has occurred on planet Earth over the last 65 million years. In less than 100 years, we humans have managed to wipe out almost half of biodiversity and not only are we continuing this devastating path towards desolation today, but, moreover, we are on the verge of further skewering the natural balance and evolution through the cloning of animals, and possibly not just animals. In other words, we operate as apprentice magicians, unleashing forces that we will not be able to control. The European Union must assume its responsibilities as one of the most important players on the world stage and be at the forefront of the fight for nature protection. We need a strict cloning ban for every commercial purpose.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: – Dear Commissioner, colleagues, let us think about the problems of cloning farm animals in agriculture in the European Union. Food shortages? No, we have a bigger problem– food waste. Animal welfare lift? Nor do we know that the cloning consequence of animals is even more suffering for animals than it has been up to now. Food quality? Hardly. It is claimed that cloned animals have problems with the immune system and are susceptible to many diseases, so food produced from them can be infected with disease vectors more than usual. Therefore, I do not understand the need for cloning farm animals. It is very good that we are debating this issue, which has not yet been regulated at European Union level, and so far the only acceptable regulation is the ban on activities such as that proposed by the rapporteurs and the ENVI and agri-committees.

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, livestock farming in my constituency, the West Midlands, is valued at GBP 1.16 billion, with 2% of the West Midlands workforce employed in the agriculture sector. Accordingly, this contentious issue has the ability to directly affect the livelihood of many of my constituents who live in rural communities across the West Midlands, from the Staffordshire moorlands to the Vale of Evesham and the Welsh Marches. This debate must always be driven and informed by science and the knowledge and best practice that our agriculture sector has, and certainly not profit-driven by multinational corporations looking to decrease production costs, potentially at the expense and health of the consumer. We must be very careful on this path, and if cloned meat is to be used in meats and animal products, it should always be clearly labelled so that the consumer can always make a proper and informed choice on what they decide to eat. I have received over 1 000 emails from my constituents on this issue, making clear how this issue directly concerns the British electorate. Accordingly, it should be debated and voted on in the British Parliament, whose members are elected and accountable – unlike the European Commissioner. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to say once again that I have listened to Members’ views on all aspects of the cloning debate and they have heard my detailed explanations as to why I believe the Commission approach is the correct path to follow. I would like to respond only on a few things. Some Members mentioned issues related to descendants. I reiterate once again: descendants are conceived through conventional methods and therefore create neither food safety nor animal welfare concerns.  Of course we must draw the distinction that we are talking about cloning and not about GMOs, they are absolutely different and are not the same thing. Cloning is absolutely not the same as genetically modifying products.  Some of you mentioned TTIP. I would like to say that the negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership had no influence on the shape of the cloning proposal – no influence. The proposals are the product of a serious analysis of the available powers conferred by the Treaties, the result of the impact assessment and respect for the principle of proportionality. They are not about TTIP; that is absolutely not true. Some Members mentioned the system of traceability, but of course tracing requires documentation through the food and animal production chain. This creates a bureaucracy that is bound to collapse under its own weight and will not provide consumers with any true advantage. On the contrary, such a burdensome, extensive system will most probably only lead to higher food prices for average consumers.  I would like to say that I see very different views and different approaches. Clearly we have a difficult task ahead of us to reconcile our differences. Nevertheless, I am optimistic that, as with other difficult topics, we can work towards finding a common position, finding compromises and common positions on cloning.

name: Giulia Moi
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am literally disgusted by your use of science. And you, Commissioner, but how do you allow yourself to question a survey that has been carried out throughout Europe, where European citizens have said with more than 80% of a percentage that they do not want cloned food, do not want cloning? How can you question how much the citizens of Europe want? Based on what? Science, as you have so named it, you have appointed only two lines of EFSA. Why didn't you read all the reports they made from 2008 until 2012? They say that they do not have enough data to 100% certify the safety of cloned animals that will become food, they do not have the safety even on the offspring, because the offspring, although it will be produced with sexous and normal techniques, will unfortunately have cloned parents and EFSA itself says that cloning leads to genetic modification, but not in the structure of DNA, but epigenetics. So externally, in the reprogramming phase, a very delicate phase that is subject to external factors such as cloning technique can lead.  We do not have reliable scientific data that these foods obtained from genetic animals are safe. You have no right to use us as guinea pigs! Today we cannot afford to put health and safety on our children's shoulders, just for your economic interests and your profits! Who does he owe favors to? Why do you not listen to the citizens? We here in Parliament are here to bring their voice, not your economic interests.

name: Renate Sommer
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Thank you very much! I would like to thank the vast majority of this House who support our joint report. Thank you very much, ladies and gentlemen. Let us send a strong signal with our vote this lunchtime, to the European Commission and to the Council of Ministers.  We want the Member States to finally take a stand with their citizens, with the citizens who do not want cloning. We want each Member State to explain to its citizens how it feels about this? Is it on the side of the citizens, or is it not on their side? We have heard once again today that the European Commission is not on the side of the citizens! Polls are simply being called into question. If it doesn't fit, then the poll has been done wrong.  Commissioner, I am very disappointed in you and your House. I know that you personally are very committed to animal welfare. Just call your officials to order! Of course, it is possible to do what we have proposed here! The European Commission must finally move a little, it cannot say: Oh help, help! But the third countries will be angry with us. That is actually what is behind it, behind your opposition to our report.  They are afraid – the European Commission is afraid of this – that third countries will sue us before the World Trade Organisation. We, the European Parliament, do not have this fear! We represent our citizens and we represent the fundamental values that are important for coexistence in the European Union as well. We are against animal cruelty. If you come here with technical trickery, try to cast doubt on the legal basis again, then I can only tell you that the European Court of Justice is on our side. The European Court of Justice has already ruled in the past that Article 43 of the general EU Treaty is the right legal basis for all legislation relating to the production and marketing of agricultural products. And our report is exactly one such thing. I therefore ask the European Commission to move away from its rigid position and move towards the European Parliament, and we expect this to be the same from the Member States. Thank you.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place shortly. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. – I propose to support all points in the report on the prohibition of cloning. As a representative of Hungarian farmers recognised in food production and a member of the Committee on Agriculture, it is of the utmost importance to me that Hungarian and European consumers have access to safe and high-quality food. Cloning is a completely new technique in food production. Due to the lack of conclusive scientific evidence, we do not actually know whether eating food from cloned animals can cause serious health problems. We must therefore touch on one of the fundamental principles of the European Union, the principle of prevention. So we must ban all techniques and food that we cannot prove to be 100% safe. Furthermore, I agree with fellow Members that cloning can also result in unnecessary suffering and pain in farmed animals, which should be avoided. This is clearly required by EU animal welfare legislation.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. – The issue of food safety and the protection of public health and consumers is crucial. And I have stressed this repeatedly in this Chamber. Cloning for agricultural purposes is rightly prohibited within the EU. But the EU imports food products from the US - Canada, Argentina and Brazil where cloning is allowed. Therefore, the EU closes its eyes and lets them do the dirty work. Since cloning is harmful to humans and animals, the Commission should therefore include specific provisions prohibiting the import of food produced by the offspring of cloned animals, as regards clone reproductive material and its offspring, as well as meat and milk from clone offspring which are now beginning to enter the food chain. In addition, the Commission must take immediate account of the fact that the cloning technique does not meet animal welfare standards.

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen (PPE)
text: Written. "Animal cloning is a technique that most of us are weaned on in Europe. In the United States, the technology is unlimited – cloning can be used not only by the best strawberries, but also by your beloved pet dog.  Cloning raises a lot of ethical issues and also causes suffering to animals – animals born from cloned cells suffer significantly more malformations and premature deaths.  The European Union wants to ban the use of cloning technology in food production. However, there is disagreement about the technical implementation of the ban. Member States and the Commission believe that the ban on the use of an animal born with clone technology in food is driving the issue. However, clone animals themselves are expensive ingredients for Italian lettuce, and the use of cloning in food production is based precisely on offspring production. It is important that we in this House also call for the ban to be extended to generations of descendants.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ENF)
text: in writing. – First of all, I would like to mention that there is no information on the quantity of cloned animals that has already reached the European market. For this reason, since there is no record of such data, the European citizen is deprived of the right to opt for or against the purchase of such animals. The consumer is also deprived of the right to opt for or against the consumption of products from cloned animals. With regard to the process of cloning animals, there is currently insufficient information to prove that products from cloned animals are 100 % safe and do not in any way endanger the health of the population. More scientific studies and in-depth tests are therefore needed to verify whether or not the products harm human health. Thus, at this time, lacking proper information and careful analysis with regard to the cloning of cattle, pigs, sheep, goats and equidae reared and reproduced for agricultural purposes, I call for respect for the point of view of European citizens and their rights to take this decision at European level!

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – Parliament's role is to represent the population, and with a positive vote of this report we will do so. Consumers are scared of the possible side effects of cloning on food, but also of the implications of cloning in animal welfare. We do not disclaim the potential role of cloning in the conservation of endangered animal species, but we have no reason, nor encouraging scientific evidence, to support this technique for food production. The European Union must take all necessary measures to prevent the production and import of clones and descendants of clones, food products obtained from them and the importation of germination material from clones or offspring of cloned animals.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. – I welcome the report on the approval of the Directive on the cloning of animals for agricultural purposes, because the EP once again takes the firm position that it does not support the technique of cloning farm animals. The future of European livestock farming should be based on traditional breeding and selection methods in order to preserve animal health and strengthen consumer confidence in the quality of animal products. I support the ban on the cloning of farm animals and the placing on the market of cloned animals and embryos, as well as the proposal by both EP committees to extend the prohibition to the inclusion of offspring of cloned animals, germinal products, as well as food originating from cloned animals and their offspring. With its position, the EP responds to European citizens' concerns about animal welfare and strengthens consumer confidence about the origin of the food they consume. Compliance with the cloning ban should be ensured by introducing a traceability and control system for imports of animals and animal products from third countries, especially with regard to countries applying the cloning technique. I support the adoption of special import conditions to ensure that import certificates contain the necessary traceability information.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the recommendation for second reading from the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection on the correct application of the law on customs and agricultural matters (08257/3/2015 – C8—0159/2015 – 2013/0410(COD)) (Liisa Jaakonsaari) (A8-0234/2015).

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, parliament is now dealing with rules aimed at preventing customs fraud more effectively. I believe that this is an important part of the work against the shadow economy. Although this document seems a little technical, it does have great meanings of principle.  Olaf, the European Anti-Fraud Office, has estimated that the European Union and its Member States are losing a couple of hundred million euros in tax revenue every year due to cigarette smuggling alone. This is a lot of money and it is important to get to grips with this, not only because of the civic morale, but also because of the economy. How do we get to the smugglers? Firstly, a common EU database and a modern container movements monitoring system will now be created. Digital technology will help in this. It is possible to monitor the movements of containers and that is important. As I said at the beginning, it is tobacco, alcohol and energy products that are usually linked to fraud. However, the challenge was to ensure the security of sensitive export data and then to open this export data in a common database. We reached a compromise. We came to the end that the export data stored in the registers would be limited to excise goods, in other words tobacco and alcohol, which are essential. We also accelerated the investigation into fraud. Member States must provide immediate information and documents in suspected cases of fraud within four weeks. These data protection rules were also aligned in accordance with EU regulations. We included an inspection clause, according to which it will be possible to assess this whole in a couple of years' time. As a whole, this will provide olaf, the European Anti-Fraud Office, with a modern tool for combating fraud and will enhance the effectiveness of investigations. This is a positive example of new regulation, which, if implemented, will bring a significant amount of euros into the EU and Member States' budgets.  I am pleased that we have succeeded in achieving good legislation that prevents fraud and protects sensitive export data. Thank you to the shadow rapporteurs and to the Commission and the Council for their very constructive cooperation.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to say that I am pleased to be addressing Parliament today on an issue relating to the fight against customs fraud. The Commission has always appreciated the strong support from Parliament to protect the European economy and European taxpayers’ money from fraud and this is now a shared commitment for both the Commission and Parliament.  Customs-related fraud is a cross-border phenomenon which needs to be tackled centrally. Therefore, it is important that the relevant customs authorities of the Member States be equipped with the right tools to cooperate between themselves and with the Commission and to pursue fraudsters effectively at European level. It was against this background that, in 2013, the Commission proposed a number of improvements to our basic regulation governing the cooperation of customs authorities in the fight against fraud. This regulation came into being almost 20 years ago and it is important that we keep it up to date with modern technologies.  Information sharing is a key element in that respect. The lack of available information on, in particular, container movements, can lead to customs fraud detrimental to national and European budgets and cause serious damage to the European economy. Our proposals will enable us to curb this fraud and strengthen both the detection and investigation of fraudulent activities in the area of customs. The Commission has paid particular attention to striking a careful balance between the necessity to have a fraud-proof system on the one hand and avoiding overburdening businesses on the other.  We are grateful for the support from Parliament and the Member States for the Commission’s proposal. I would also like to take this opportunity to commend the diligent work of Parliament’s previous and current rapporteurs on tax, especially Ms Liisa Jaakonsaari. The constructive attitude of Parliament, but also of the Council, has allowed for a swift negotiation and conclusion of the legislative process. I hope that Parliament will continue to support our efforts in the field of the fight against customs fraud.

name: Ivan Štefanec
text: for the PPE Group. – Common European practices and practices are always most effective against unfair practices. The adoption of this Regulation on mutual assistance between the administrative authorities of the Member States and of the European Commission is intended to contribute to the proper application of the rules on customs and agricultural matters. The main objective of the Regulation is to improve the detection and investigation of customs fraud and thus to combat customs fraud effectively throughout the European Union. Greater emphasis should also be placed on preventing and intensifying the exchange of information and available evidence between Member States. It is important to improve the availability of data on imports, exports and transit, as well as data on container movements at national level. As customs workers currently have no possibility of verifying whether the declared origin of the goods coincides with the container route, stepping up cooperation between member states' administrations would reduce the abuse of the transit system and allow for better exchange of information that could serve as evidence in criminal and administrative proceedings in the Member States. This Regulation shall also avoid delays and unnecessary time losses at the investigation stage. It will also ensure that legislation is brought into line with the Treaty of Lisbon as regards the protection of personal data, in particular in the area of procedures and time limits. I firmly believe that the adoption of this regulation will bring deeper cooperation between the administrations in the field of customs, thus reducing the amount of customs fraud throughout the European Union. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Congressman, I'm sorry. I am very pleased to hear that you are queering up countless versions of joint European action, including prevention and punishment. However, I ask you whether, in the spirit of the common agricultural policy, could you accept the European Union moving towards fiscal union in relation to agricultural products?

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – I think that, as I said at the beginning, common European procedures will best help us against fraud prevention, but we overwhelmingly have rules, especially with regard to fiscal union, which we need to respect. As far as fiscal union is concerned, I do not think that we need new rules, but rather strict adherence to the current ones.

name: Evelyne Gebhardt
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We certainly need a fiscal union, otherwise the European Union will not be able to continue. But that is not the issue we have today. On behalf of the Socialist Group, I would like to thank Mrs Jaakonsaari for the truly excellent work she has done. You have just said that it is a technical report, but it is also a highly sensitive and highly political report. It is also a question of ensuring that customs fraud can be tackled and that the Member States work better together to combat this customs fraud. This is not just a trivial matter, but very important. You have just said that there are the biggest problems, particularly in the area of alcohol, tobacco. This must also be addressed. The compromise that has now been reached between granting data protection and respecting trade secrets – which is also important, of course, and ensuring that such trade secrets cannot be taken to facilitate this fraud – to find this compromise, that balance, that was precisely the feat that has been achieved here. I would really like to thank you for that, which is why we can fully agree with it, and that is also a good thing. In a globalised world in which we are today, ensuring that controls are good and better is the key to development, and it is about ensuring the safety of citizens. For some products are not just about the fiscal sector, but also about product safety, which must be guaranteed. Thank you again for the good work!

name: Daniel Dalton
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteur for their work on finding a sensible agreement with the Council on this one. The revision to the regulation will help close loopholes, for example those allowing false declarations of transported goods. Detected fraud in the EU was over EUR 107 million in 2011, and the true losses for Member States are likely to be much, much more. The changes agreed here should also reduce unnecessary bureaucracy and speed up mechanisms in place for tackling customs fraud. They also safeguard national competences, giving Member States two weeks to get the information from operators who are subject to investigations before the Commission can get involved. The report also includes data protection and data confidentiality parts.  In line with the ECR commitment to better regulation, I am glad to see the two-year revision clause included in this regulation. This will require the Commission to assess if the data exchange provisions are sufficient, and that is a good basis for us to work from. So, from the ECR our side, we can support this.

name: Kaja Kallas
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the customs union is an important achievement of the European Union and also the backbone of the single market. A functioning customs union not only encourages and facilitates the flow of goods in and out of Europe but also brings legal certainty to businesses and protects our financial interests. But it cannot function properly if we do not have the proper means for it to do so. National customs authorities should talk to each other and should also exchange information with the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF). That is why I welcome the setting up of the two databases at European level. However, in order to fight fraud effectively, information exchange also needs to take place as quickly as possible. This does not happen if it takes six months before the information comes to the table for the Anti-Fraud Office to start the investigation. I am therefore happy that shorter deadlines are included in this package. Estonia is very efficient in dealing with mutual assistance requests because we have an electronic customs system. If Member States have electronic, rather than paper-based, customs systems they should be able to transfer information more quickly – in just a few clicks. So I hope therefore that this new law will not only help to fight against fraud but will also speed up the development of electronic customs, as that can only make customs authorities more effective.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, detecting and preventing customs fraud is important to avoid loss and greater damage to the European peasant. But, as important or more important than this is the regulation itself. The decisions to liberalise, to deregulate that this Commission, the majority of Parliament and the Council itself have taken lately are highlighting the seriousness of the losses that are being caused in the agricultural sector in our European Union. We must say that today the dairy sector is highlighting this situation with its mobilizations. That is why we think it is very important to implement new regulations, a new agricultural and food policy that gives priority to the domestic market over exports and to the international market and free trade agreements. That is essential and also, of how not, preventing and preventing fraud.

name: Igor Šoltes
text: Mr President, commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. – I believe that strengthening and harmonising cooperation and mutual assistance between the administrative authorities of the Member States is very important, especially in order to better and more effectively combat fraud. This Regulation brings improvements as it aims to simplify and speed up the processes in the review of goods used by consumers in the European Union. At the same time, it is trying to reduce or remove unnecessary bureaucracy, which often presents obstacles and problems at customs. Until now, customs officials have had difficulties in determining whether the declaration of origin of the goods corresponds to the actual course of the container route. Despite the inspection of the documents and also the visual inspection of the goods, the checks were of a limited nature. Many cases of falsified declarations, as well as poor, limited supervision, have left the European Union and its members with quite a few financial consequences due to financial losses, which of course also has a significant impact on budgets. I believe that the inclusion of 'export data' in the regulation is a very important provision, as this will make it easier for Member States to combat fraud. OLAF has identified clear and irrefutable information that some of the products exported, such as tobacco transhipped to and back to third countries, have been back in the EU. Which allowed for tax avoidance. And as a member of the Greens Group, I have advocated the inclusion of 'export data' in the regulation, as this reduces the possibility of fraud. In such cases, of course, transparency is needed and, above all, transparency is ensured, which we also wanted to achieve through the regulation. For this reason, I think that, of course, this regulation must also be supported, because we have managed to reach a compromise that more satisfies all parties. I am thinking here, in particular, of including 'export data for sensitive goods', such as tobacco, alcohol and minerals, in so-called directories, which, with the establishment of this regulation, will be more, easier to control and the competent authorities will have access to it.

name: Margot Parker
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, for this proposal at second reading we have tabled a complete rejection of the whole idea. This is for two reasons.  The first is because we, the elected members of this Parliament, have the duty to be held accountable to our electorate who democratically elected us here to represent them. I firmly believe that we owe it to our constituents to see how their representatives have voted. Sadly, due to the democratic process in the EU, this can only be achieved by tabling a complete rejection of the proposal.  The second reason for rejecting the proposal is because we are opposed to this over-reaction to customs fraud, and to the centralisation of powers and delegation to the Commission that this report brings. Do not get me wrong: I am absolutely in support of combating customs-related fraud, but I am wholly against this proposal, which serves only to plaster over the cracks and does not address the origins of the customs-related fraud. To deal with customs-related fraud issues is not to add bureaucracy and burdens for Member States, but to question the fundamental pillars of the single market, the free movement of goods, persons, services and capital between Member States by establishing and maintaining a database that will contain detailed information on imports, exports and transit of goods, including those within a Member State.  The EU is raising great data protection concerns for businesses, to say nothing of the additional costs that come as a result of starting up a project like this. We are, as sovereign nations should of course be, encouraging greater mutual assistance and cooperation in the second fight against fraud but I say it once again: this does not require a centralised EU database to be established.  The whole approach to combating customs-related fraud feels awfully similar to the idea of using a sledgehammer to crack a nut. Once again this is just another example of the EU using an economic problem as an excuse to increase harmonisation, and this is not something that I can support.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega
text: on behalf of the ENF group. – Madam President, Commissioner, we appreciate the Commission's efforts to ensure fair customs and agricultural legislation, but at the same time we must not forget the principle of subsidiarity, according to which the Member States are best aware of the problems they face. That is why I ask you, Commissioner, to take into account what the Member States are telling you through the relevant ministries. We have a duty to both producers and consumers to make every effort to combat evasion of agricultural products and thus contribute to the objective of the internal market to have safe products with authentic certificates of origin. I reiterate that we must take realistic account, and not only at the declarative level, of the recommendations made by the Member States, given that they are best aware of the problems they face. I believe that more and more consideration should be given to carrying out on-the-spot checks that can lead to future strategies for effective control in order to reduce the risk of evasion. It is also welcome to speed up the customs investigation through the Commission, following the request of a Member State, and to introduce the obligation for public or private sector operators whose activities are linked to the international supply chain to transmit to the Commission data on the movement of containers.

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which First of all, I would like to thank Mrs Jaakonsaari very much for the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, because she has represented Parliament very well with her tough attitude towards the Council and the Commission and has made it clear that, in all efforts to combat fraud, the child must not be thrown out with the bathwater. Commissioner, I would also like to make this very clear to you: of course, it would be practical for fraud control if all companies were to register their consignments of goods first, so that we can check somewhere in the administration whether these things are correct. But that is not our image of the European internal market. We really need to focus controls on the priority areas of fraud. Thanks in part to the work of our shadow rapporteurs, this was ultimately achieved in the proposal. But I would also like to make it quite clear to you that if Parliament had not remained so this point, some of it would have become imbalanced. That is why I am pleased that, in the end, we have reached this compromise together and that the concentration of controls has focused very much on tobacco, alcohol and diesel fuel. Mrs Gebhardt has seen data protection and trade secrets as a difficult element. The concept of trade secrets is often viewed ominously here in this House. Let me be very clear: individual companies would have had to disclose all their export figures, all their recipients of products and services, in the Commission's original proposal, which attracted a great deal of interest in the Council. It is the case that we in Europe work very well together. But there are also competitive situations. And if the individual competitors can then get to know the supply flows from each other, through accidental publications or other, then of course these are massive interventions in their business activities. This has been prevented, and in this respect I believe that we have been able to reach a good compromise here in the end. I was particularly pleased that the EFDD Group suddenly spoke here of the fundamental principle of freedom of movement that they want to defend. They should do the same elsewhere.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, from the outset I would like to stress the importance of this report on mutual assistance between the administrative authorities of the Member States and the cooperation between them and the Commission in order to correctly apply customs legislation. You've said it before, dear colleagues. Of course, there is a very large evasion and the figures – we do not have them at their true value! But I want to emphasise that, in addition to these financial deficits created in the Member States, erroneously completed customs declarations are also very damaging to consumers, because a lot of counterfeit goods are entering and also affecting fair competition in the internal market – particularly in the case of SMEs. I believe that the team that worked on the changes, in particular Mrs Jaakonsaari and the shadow rapporteurs, have taken these things into account and have come to balanced changes. I also think that a much more rigorous control is needed! We don't have a regulation if there's no rigorous scrutiny! I am pleased that, in the text, there is an amendment requiring the Commission to report annually on the results of these checks and controls in order to be able to achieve the reduction, if not the total elimination, of customs evasion, particularly with regard to agriculture and alcohol.  I congratulate the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs and I hope that, through application and cooperation between the administrations of the Member States, we will be able to achieve fair competition, consumer protection and, why not, sME growth and trade defence against non-European products.

name: Vicky Ford (ECR).
text: – Madam President, before the customs union existed, businesses trading within Europe faced a mountain of paperwork and different levies at every border. The single market, through its common customs code, has removed costs, which has helped to boost trade and drive economic growth. However, a breach at customs in one country, especially false or fake goods, can have repercussions across all 28 Member States – and that affects consumers.  This report updates a framework which was first set in 1997. It will make it easier for those in our ports and airports to check that goods really are what they claim to be. Parliament’s approach has been to simplify and speed up mechanisms for combating customs fraud without adding unnecessary and repetitive bureaucracy. Member States remain responsible for initial investigations, and it is only when that fails that the Commission comes in. On that basis, I support this report. However, a common approach to customs code is not an indication that I would support common taxation on other matters. Taxation is, and should remain, a Member State competency.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the tragic events of the day show that national borders are no longer the limits of a single state, but constitute the external border of the whole of the European Union. This is particularly true of trade. Take the case of xylella, for example. The epidemic that is now spreading in the south of Italy, in Puglia, has spread from plants imported into Europe at the port of Rotterdam. What does that mean? That decisions taken by a single port, in a single gate, can have repercussions throughout Europe: false declarations about the origin of the imported goods; fallacious designations of the typology; abuses of the transitional regime. These are all illegal practices by which low-quality products are introduced into the Union. Low-quality products that circumvent security controls and measures, deceptive products that compete with local products on the shelves of our stores, counterfeit products that penetrate through stretch marks of our customs network.  We have a duty to protect real products, local products, because they represent quality, history, traditions, jobs and social well-being. It is true that the rules for protecting us are there, but they must be applied in a serious, effective and, above all, uniform manner. So these instruments are welcome, enabling the various national authorities responsible for monitoring and verifying what is coming to Europe, to exchange information and good practice more effectively. This will give a great boost to ensuring that Community rules are interpreted without any doubt and uncertainty, and will help us to ensure that the borders of the European Union are a real wall for all those who would like to do illegal business.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF).
text: Madam President, Customs is a key tool in the intelligent economic protection of a territory and in the defence of a country's sovereignty and strategic independence.  Any fair and coherent economic plan cannot be built without reactive and effective customs. The Commission once again wants to replace the Member States and position itself as a champion of surveillance, control and prevention of customs fraud, but the terrible news we are experiencing today proves otherwise.  How is it possible to believe for a moment that the Commission will be able to effectively control the flow of goods when it is unable to control human flows?  How can it claim to be able to regulate an economic space, a space it has already methodically deregulated? Open your eyes and don't be naïve anymore. Stop promising more to the Europeans. It is urgent for the member countries, and in particular for France, to regain control of their borders and national sovereignty.

name: Lara Comi (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this regulation is the result of important work on a fundamental issue which is the strengthening of the European internal market on which we are fighting every day. These rules will in fact improve the detection, investigation and prevention of customs fraud by increasing the exchange of information and the available evidence, making the system even more effective in my opinion.  In my opinion, two aspects deserve to be highlighted: firstly, this regulation provides customs agents with new means of checking whether the declared origin of the goods is consistent with the path actually taken inside the container, because this is not the case many times. This is no small point, both for the proper functioning of the free movement of goods and for the protection of European consumers.  Secondly, The Member States must be able to provide the Commission with the data necessary for the verification of potential fraud; this was not the case before, since the documentation was carried out only by economic operators. The negotiations have been long and complex, but I believe that today we can all be satisfied with the work produced by this legislation, so I congratulate all those who have worked on this objective because the result has been achieved.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking Mrs Jaakonsaari for her excellent work, for the complex and difficult subject to deal with, there were many resistances, but the conclusion is an important conclusion, for the many reasons that have already been mentioned in the debate.  I would like to return briefly to three aspects which seem to me to be the most significant. The first, of course, concerns certainty for consumers: the control guarantees those who will use those products that they do not have in front of them in disguise products that have been altered, counterfeited and therefore different from those that are perceived or how they are presented.  The second issue also concerns competition between companies, all counterfeiting has the immediate, almost automatic effect of altering relations between companies, between those who behave loyally, produce according to the rules, respect them and those who, instead, by placing second-level products on the market, do so through alteration processes that lead to negative consequences, both on people who then consume , but also on the economic relations between companies.  Finally, there is one aspect that I would not like to be forgotten, and that is the fight against crime: where there is counterfeiting there is normally an illegal activity that stimulates crime. Therefore, everything that is transparent, everything that responds to the rules, also helps the fight against crime.

name: Ева Паунова (PPE).
text: – Effective public administration is a process comparable to open innovation. Any interested party may contribute to its development with expertise, experience and ideas. The process is limitless, but this should not affect the motivation for success of the participants in it. Effective administration is also one of the most visible and firm signals of stable governance of a country. Optimizing systems is really a lengthy and complex process. I am very happy to state that I come from a country I know best - Bulgaria. We boldly continue to take steps in the right direction towards building e-government. It is indeed important that civil society, business and the public sector cooperate to give businesses a chance to operate successfully and beyond the union's borders. This really can't happen without a well-functioning administration providing information about what it does for citizens and businesses. In order to save time and money, we need electronic working institutions and customs whose successes are tangible. We should not be a passive player in the eGovernment process because it is important to be active participants and take advantage of its services. It is important and necessary to be open to the changes that are already happening in order to be more prepared for those who are coming and are truly unpredictable at the moment. Innovation moves our world forward and brings us closer to the future.  Public administration and customs can therefore, when effective, become the driver of europe's new digital economic model.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the amendments to Regulation No 515 of 1997 are only apparently technical, but they are of significant political importance in the current international economic and social context. Fraud and abuse of customs regulations are constantly on the increase and are putting a quality production system such as the European one in crisis every day.  All this requires greater attention and control on the part of Europe, in order to guarantee consumers safe products and businesses fair and fair competition, as we are being asked, even at this time, by the agricultural world. In order to achieve these objectives, we need to strengthen the mechanisms for combating fraud, making them more effective, more transparent, making full use of the new opportunities of digital ing, thus ensuring maximum traceability of goods. The amendments to this regulation can be a useful piece in the context of a broader strategy for combating the many unfair practices of European and international trade.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the fight against breaches of customs regulations entails the exchange of information in the context of cooperation between Member States and the Commission, and I encourage those parties to deal more closely with violators. When importing and exporting various goods, inaccurate and incomplete data are often presented, which we in Croatia have witnessed when importing meat and meat products, as well as other food products. I strongly advocate that this be put to an end and more strictly control the movement of goods from starting point to finish, i.e. from the starting point to the finish line. specifically to us final consumers. In my view, it is necessary to create the conditions for an improved fight against customs fraud relating to an incorrect declaration of origin of the goods, an incorrect description of the goods and the abuse of the transit system. I have personally repeatedly advocated transparent labeling of the origin of products on labels, as well as the entire course of traceability, including the date of slaughter when it comes to the mess. In that case, I believe they would put an end to the sale of frozen meat that comes from imports to the Croatian market.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – Crime often happens precisely in the area we are talking about today, that is, on the one hand, the tobacco sector, on the other, the area of oil, alcohol. I therefore support that institutions be entensified at the level of the European Community, as well as providing the means to make this control stronger and to minimise this crime in the future. Many times, not only criminal groups but even people who are very close to politics, and in many, including the transitional country, are involved in such links, so the development of democracy itself, and also the introduction of the principles of modern parliamentary democracy, has major problems. I therefore think it is right that we support measures to combat precisely such necky business, which are based primarily on the exploitation of other people and on criminal association.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, the proper functioning and control of customs authorities is an important factor for the smooth functioning of a State but also for the proper functioning of the internal market. However, there are not a few times in which we have seen various products being "baptized" domestically and circulating in the internal markets. In my country Greece, there have been many cases of illegal "Greekizations" of products, which, as they cross the border, are "baptized" Greek, so that greek farmers already impoverished by the memorandum see their own products rot. The "Greekizations" of lambs from Skopje are known every year, as well as it is known that oil from Tunisia is "baptized" Greek. For this reason, the European Union must do its duty and combat fraud in the customs field, thereby contributing to the achievement of the objective of the internal market for the disposal of safe products with genuine certificates of origin.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, in that one minute I would like to focus on only two aspects of the problem under consideration. And that is the question, firstly, how to protect local markets effectively, because that is something that I think is very important for the European Union. To protect those who bring employment and not only employment at the level of the European area, but also, for example, to protect the landscape.  I am a member of the AGRI Committee and I am aware that it is many farmers, many producers, who are very affected by this illegal activity. I think that the security of supply chains is also mentioned in the Commission's specific proposal, and this is something that we really should pay close attention to.  And the second question, which relates to the coordination of procedures at the level of the EU institutions, and I think that OLAF's activities have a large margin. The Commission itself notes significant problems with the delay, delay in the procedures. And I think we should sort this out for ourselves by sweeping it in front of our own court.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the European Parliament once again for its continued support on this important legislative file. I also felt encouraged by the remarks of Parliament’s rapporteur, Ms Liisa Jaakonsaari, who, when emphasising the importance of this legislative proposal, also mentioned tobacco and alcohol issues, because it is not only about internal markets but also about public health.  I wish to stress that the proposed amendment is not only designed to strengthen the position and analytical capabilities of the European Commission in the fight against fraud. More importantly, the proposal is designed to better equip Member States to protect their own tax base, and it is a good example, speaking about subsidiary issues. I strongly believe that the compromise text, as tabled for the vote, encompasses the joint efforts of the core legislators to improve the framework which governs the detection and investigation of customs fraud. I trust that this initiative constitutes an important milestone in our common efforts to combat fraud at EU and national levels, and I hope that we will be able to successfully finalise this initiative, which is so important for improving the fight against customs-related fraud.

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would also like to thank Parliament for its broad support and the Commission for its cooperation.  Mr Parker of the EFDD Group said there was no need for such centralised systems. On the other hand, I think that this is a good example of how no country alone can prevent customs offences, but that we need very good tools and strong cooperation and commitment to this. I was already wondering about the efdd group's comments, because I did not see any time during the whole process the shadow rapporteur for your group, who could have expressed his concerns about possible problems during the negotiations.  There are indeed two new things here in some ways. First of all, the fact that it is very important to always take data security into account in all presentations. In this proposal, the information security of business secrets in particular was central and we reached a good compromise. As Mr Kallas said when member states adopt and have to introduce this electronic system, it will speed up the investigation of these crimes, possible suspicions and crimes, which is very important. In other words, the digital revolution and the world will also be helpful in combating the shadow economy and crime if we want to, if the Member States want to, and if, for example, this proposal comes to fruition. Thank you, everyone.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. Vote: 8 September 2015. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. – False declaration fraud increased in 2011 to an annual loss of EUR 100 million. Member States reported 1 905 cases of recorded fraud and other irregularities linked to the miscalculation of goods, representing a loss of EUR 107,7 million. This amount concerns only the loss found by the Member States and the Commission. As information on around 30 000 cases of suspected fraud is not available, the actual scale of the problem is considerably greater. This system urgently needed reform because it became clear that the introduction of e-customs in 2011, in which the background documents on imports and exports are no longer left by customs administrations but by economic operators, has led to delays in investigations conducted by the European Anti-Fraud Office in the customs field, because in order to obtain these documents, OLAF needs the mediation assistance of customs administrations. Moreover, the three-year limitation period applied to customs documents held by the administrative authority constituted additional obstacles to the successful conduct of investigations. Although consumer protection is at a very high level in the European Union, it is very important that work is constantly being made to improve it and make it more effective. It is the Union's duty to combat customs fraud.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is voting time. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (GUE/NGL).
text: Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to put forward an amendment to Article 29 and specifically to the second paragraph, to the point where it says 'so that the situation can be compared', with the addition of the words 'needs', and I would like to make a second addition, then to the same proposal 'of different sizes', from which its proportional support will be judged. Thanks.

name: Lynn Boylan
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I just have said to the Tabling Committee that we want to put forward an oral amendment for paragraph 92. The oral amendment is: ‘calls on the Member States to introduce, in accordance with World Health Organisation guidelines, a pricing policy by the application of a progressive charge that safeguards people’s right to access a minimum quantity of water for living and reduces waste’.

name: Presidente. –
text: That concludes voting time.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it reinforces international commitments to combat forced labour, which affects 21 million people worldwide. But we must not forget that slave labour has not disappeared in the EU, where the ILO estimates that 880 000 people work hard: many of them women victims of sexual exploitation; so a greater effort is needed from EU states and institutions, including within their own economies.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This legislative resolution authorizes member states to ratify the protocol established by the International Labour Organization (ILO) in 2014. This protocol relates to the C29 Convention on Forced Labour, adopted in 1930 by the ILO and ratified by France in 1937. Convention C29 called on signatory countries to prohibit forced labour, on the understanding that this did not include certain forms of compulsory labour (the one required of the military, civic obligations, work of general interest following a conviction, etc.). It encouraged member countries to take appropriate measures to ensure that workers receive fair pay, guaranteeing them free and dignified living conditions.  The new 2014 protocol finds that the convention is not respected by all signatory states. It therefore reminds them of their obligations to combat forced labour and calls on them to cooperate judicially to be more effective.   In these times of economic crisis, it seems to me useful that France should be allowed to ratify this new protocol. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Of course, Member States should be allowed to sign up to this Convention. I want the United Kingdom to sign up to it. However, I reject the notion that this is an exclusive EU competence; it is not, and the House of Commons’ position is that it is not. Consent is not required, and I abstained therefore on technical grounds.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to ratify the Convention on Forced Labour. The Convention calls on governments to take action to better protect workers, especially migrant workers, against abuse and fraud in hiring. I agree with the importance of holding a European-wide debate on the risks identified in the ILO's latest report on forced labour, forcing people to take up forced labour, i.e. reduced income and poverty or belonging to vulnerable groups (women, migrant children). It is also important that the European Strategy against Poverty is aimed at more than just coordinating national action, which should set binding poverty reduction targets.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation, which calls for compliance with the International Labour Organization Convention on Forced Labour: it dates back to 1930 and it is clear that it is still not respected in too many countries. Our economies are, of course, suffering from this unfair and immoral competition.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted to ratify this protocol, which updates the fight against forced labour and puts it back into current realities, and provides this Convention with a binding legal force, providing for the establishment of redress and redress mechanisms such as compensation and compensation for material and physical damage.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. U2012 I voted in favour because even in the 21st century forced labour affects 21 million people who are victims of exploitation, the most vulnerable being women, children and migrants, and that generates one hundred and fifty billion benefits annually to those who organize and control it. We should end this exploitation with concrete actions and the impetus for legislation and the objective of the 2014 Protocol to the Convention on Forced and Compulsory Labour of the International Labour Organization. That is why I voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The fight against forced labour dates back to a 1930 ILO convention. This convention (not ratified by the United States) calls on countries to abolish forced or compulsory labour altogether. The 2014 protocol follows this convention and states that the need to address the fact that forced labour is still not eradicated everywhere must be addressed.  The Council of the Union this year authorised the Member States to ratify this convention, because the Union, as an entity, cannot do so. Given that some EU Member States, including France, have already signed this convention, it is normal to continue on this path and fight against forced labour in the world.  So I voted for that recommendation.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the ratification of the 2014 ILO Protocol on the 1930 Convention on Forced Labour, which updates this Convention, providing new tools to combat forced labour.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. With this recommendation, Parliament consents to the opening of negotiations by Member States with the International Labour Organization, with the aim of ratifying the 2014 Protocol to the ILO Forced or Compulsory Labour Convention, which updates that Convention by providing it with new tools to combat forced labour and entrusting it with a legally binding nature.  In this way, the Protocol considers "necessary" prevention and protection measures, and the introduction of legal and redress actions, such as compensation and reparation for material and physical damage, and calls for the strengthening of means and cooperation between States in the fight against modern forms of slavery.  Similarly, Parliament's recommendation points to the need to pay particular attention to immigrants, often the first victims of forced labour, particularly women.  For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it expresses Parliament's support for the Council's decision on the EU's accession to the 1930 Protocol 2014 to the International Labour Organisation Convention on Forced or Compulsory Labour. This Protocol updates the 1930 Convention by creating new measures to combat forced labour and giving it a legally binding nature. In the 21st century, 21 million people are forced to work. People. These are victims of exploitation, generating around EUR 150 billion a year. dollars in income for those who organise and manage such work. 880 000 people in the European Union (1.6 million people across the European continent) are doing this new form of forced labour. Men and women who have been offered jobs abroad are caught up in the trap of supposed employers, migrants are trapped by human traffickers, children are vulnerable to loss of roots. The protocol therefore states that, in the event of a change in the context and forms of forced labour, it is necessary to establish prevention and protection measures and mechanisms for redress and redress (such as compensation and compensation for material and physical damage suffered. It also calls for increased resources and cooperation between states in the fight against modern forms of slavery, thus recognising their increasingly international nature. The provisions of the Protocol strengthen measures of international law by imposing an obligation to prevent forced labour and to provide protection for its victims and the ability to defend their rights, such as compensation.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. Forced labour violates human rights and the human dignity of millions of men, women, young girls and boys. The fight against this most violent form of exploitation has played an essential role in many major political and philosophical movements for emancipation. The struggle for emancipation, which was intended to liberate man from political and cultural domination and physical dependencies, has always been an attack on slave labour, which has prevented other entitlements from being enforced. Nevertheless, forced labour in the 21st century still affects 21 million people who are victims of exploitation that generates $150 billion a year in income for the organizers and organizers of this violation. The 2014 Protocol to the ILO Convention on Forced Labour of 1930 updates the Convention by providing it with new instruments and binding legal force to combat forced labour. I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes the EU taking any action on the international stage as it should be elected and accountable national governments that take these decisions. We also agree with a House of Commons note which objects to the EU having sole competence in this area of social policy. However, we do not want to oppose a measure authorising Member States to sign up to the ILO Protocol. We also note that either way the UK will sign up in its own right. For these reasons I abstained. The issue itself is very important and we agree that stronger measures must be taken to combat forced labour, the best of which would be to leave the EU as freedom of movement laws make it easier for criminal gangs to traffic people across Europe.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the phenomenon of forced labour, also and above all in its most recent forms, must be combated effectively and that, therefore, the ratification of the new 2014 protocol added to the 1930 International Convention on Forced Labour is a decisive step in the right direction.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has made a positive recommendation on the Council's draft authorising Member States to ratify, in the interests of the European Union, the 2014 Protocol on the International Labour Organization's 1930 Convention on Labour Force. As a reminder, this convention calls on the signatory countries to abolish forced and compulsory labour as soon as possible with the possibility of establishing a transition period. The 2014 protocol states that forced labour has not yet been eradicated and reminds states of their obligations in this area. Above all, it would be appropriate for the Union to reconsider its policy of cooperation with Qatar, which allows a genuine modern slavery to take place on its territory.  We consider forced labour to be a moral aberration. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Labour law is one of the fundamental pillars of hard work and is the main tool for combating labour exploitation, bearing in mind that forced labour is a violation of human rights and undermines the dignity of millions of women, men, girls and boys.  The 2014 Protocol to the International Labour Organisation Convention aims to update this Convention and to provide new anti-forced labour instruments, making it legally binding. Furthermore, it calls on governments to take steps to better protect workers, especially migrant workers, from abusive practices, and provides an insight into the protection of the human being from forced labour through prevention. I voted in favour of this recommendation, because the policies of the European Union must defend human rights and decent work, while eliminating black work both inside and outside it.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Ratification of the ILO 2014 Protocol on the Convention on Forced Labour updating that Convention, I voted in favour.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is noted that new forms of exploitation based on physical or material constraint are added to classical forms, especially in rich countries, sometimes even despite the existence of a rule of law. I mention that forced labour constitutes a violation of human rights and undermines the dignity of millions of people. The 2014 Protocol to the 1930 ILO Convention on Forced Labour updates this Convention, providing new tools to combat forced labour and making it legally binding. I support the ratification, in the interest of the European Union, of the 2014 Protocol to the 1930 International Labour Organisation Convention on social policy issues.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision authorising Member States to ratify, in the interests of the European Union, the 2014 Protocol to the International Labour Organisation Convention on Forced Labour of 1930 on social policy issues. I voted in favour because forced labour is a violation of human rights and an infringement of the dignity of millions of women, men, girls and boys. The Member States must ratify the new Protocol to the Convention on Forced Labour of the International Labour Organization (ILO). Even today, according to ILO estimates, more than 21 million people are victims of forced labour or compulsory labour. This is a very serious situation which generates 150 billion illegal profits every year. According to ILO research, it is once again women and children who suffer the practice of forced labour. It is necessary to combat this odious form of exploitation, particularly in the context of trafficking in human beings, by improving the protection of victims and by providing access to compensation.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote relates to the EU authorising Member States to sign up to new international (non-EU) rules on forced labour. The EU cannot sign these in their own right, and, as it covers aspects of existing EU law, the EU needs to authorise Member States to sign up. However the UK House of Commons issued a note stating its objection, as it does not agree that the EU has exclusive competence in this area, hence their belief that the EU does not need to ‘authorise’ Member States to do anything. On the one hand I do not recognise the right of the EU to say what we can and cannot do, but I abstained on this matter because I am vehemently opposed to forced labour. Her Majesty’s Government have indicated that they intend to sign up, by their own right. I support such a decision.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Since the EU has already consolidated the principle of a ban on forced labour in its primary legislation, I gave my consent for the authorisation for Member States to ratify the ILO’s Protocol of 2014 in order to prevent forced labour and in the same time provide protection for victims.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Patrick Le Hyaric on the updating of the International Labour Organisation (ILO) protocol on forced labour. The text calls on the governments of the European Union to take measures to better protect workers in this regard. Forced labour is a violation of human rights and an infringement of the dignity of millions of women, men, girls and boys. The ILO's 2014 Protocol to the 1930 Convention on Forced Labour has just updated this Convention, providing new instruments to combat forced labour and giving it a legally binding character: workers' rights are one of the basic foundations of decent work and are the main instrument in the fight against exploitation.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because the fight against forced labour is being organised on the basis of a convention of the International Labour Organization that France has ratified. It would therefore be a matter of continuing on this path in order to combat forced labour around the world.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We agree that forced labour is a violation of human rights and an affront to the dignity of millions of women, men, girls and boys. European Union policies must therefore be implemented to defend human rights and decent work and to eliminate trafficking in human beings, both within and outside their borders. Labour rights are one of the main pillars of decent work and provide the main means of fighting against exploitation through work.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Council decision authorising Member States to ratify, in the interests of the European Union, the 2014 ILO Protocol on the 1930 Convention on Forced Labour. Forced labour is a violation of human rights and, even today, in the EU it involves 880 thousand people and around 1.6 million across the continent. The protocol provides new instruments to combat forced labour and makes the Convention binding. In addition, the provisions of the Protocol lay down the obligation to prevent forced labour and offer victims protection and access to redress mechanisms, such as compensation. The EU and its Member States therefore have a duty to defend human rights and decent work, promote them and combat trafficking in human beings, both within and within their borders.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
