text: in writing. \u2012 I am rather perplexed when it comes to voting on reports of this kind: although I agree with its content, I have the impression that the European Parliament is wasting time and therefore citizens' money if the Council (i.e. the Heads of State or Government) asks Parliament to authorise states, i.e. those represented in the Council itself, to ratify an international treaty. I voted in favour, but my commitment is towards greater concentration towards what is really relevant to people.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP do not believe that the EU needs to authorise any national government activity. Since the UK has said it intends to sign up to this in its own right, the EU’s involvement is unnecessary and irrelevant.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The labour market scenario has undergone profound changes in recent decades due to the exponential growth of migration flows and the exacerbation of the economic crisis.  Often, the most disadvantaged groups such as migrants, women and children suffer treatment that violates the fundamental rights of man: wages at the minimum allowable, violations of working hours and safety and hygiene rules, precarious working conditions and forced employment towards harsh and degrading tasks such as prostitution and begging. I therefore believe that it is appropriate to approve the 2014 ILO Protocol ating the 1930 ILO Convention, adapting it to the current employment context through the integration of the measure with mechanisms to protect the victims of forced labour. In this respect, the Protocol provides for the right of appeal and redress for those who suffer any kind of exploitation or treatment that is affected by dignity, giving these procedures binding value.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it reinforces international commitments to combat forced labour, which affects 21 million people worldwide. But we must not forget that slave labour has not disappeared in the EU, where the ILO estimates that 880 000 people work hard: many of them women victims of sexual exploitation; so a greater effort is needed from EU states and institutions, including within their own economies.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report in question gives the Council Parliament’s consent to authorise Member States to ratify an update of the International Labour Organization’s Forced Labour Convention with regard to social policy. The protocol includes updated measures on how to prevent forced labour and provide support for victims. Hence I have voted in favour of this procedural report.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Labour rights are one of the fundamental pillars of decent work and are the main tool for combating labour exploitation. I agree that there needs to be real reflection at European level on the risk factors for forced labour that push people towards it: loss of income and poverty, vulnerabilities linked to lack of education, illiteracy, vulnerability of certain groups (women, migrant children).  I believe that the European strategy to combat poverty must go much further than the mere coordination of national actions, set binding targets for poverty reduction and include the text of the preamble to this protocol, according to which forced labour 'contributes to the perpetuation of poverty and hinders the achievement of the objective of decent work for all'.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes ratification by member states of the 2014 Protocol to the International Labour Organization's Convention on Forced Labour. This protocol aims to strengthen the international legal framework dating back to 1930 and adds new instruments to prohibit forced labour and provide protection to victims, as well as access to care. Considering that forced labour, which still affects 20 million people worldwide (880,000 in Europe), is an unacceptable reality in the 21st century, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of updating the ILO Convention on Forced Labour, proposed by the Council. Any protocols and actions towards the prevention of forced labour and tougher penalties against forced labour are, of course, welcome.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's legislative resolution on the draft Council decision authorising Member States to ratify the 2014 Protocol to the ILO Forced Labour Convention of 1930 on social policy issues is a fundamental battle that I hope all the European institutions will take forward. In fact, this motion for a resolution combats one of the most infamous phenomena still taking place on our continent and throughout the world: forced labour. 21 million people in the world are still victims of abuses of this phenomenon, which not only violates human rights but denies them dignity. Of these almost 1.6 are located on our continent, most of them are exploited both in their physical and material size. Moreover, women, children and migrants are the fragile groups most affected by this phenomenon, which also deprives them of the possibility of an improvement in their condition in the future. In addition to these violations of rights, physical and psychological violence is often added, leading to fear and isolation of victims. That is why, together with my colleagues, I am voting in a lively manner on this text in order to eliminate this scourge from our continent and in the world.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The report submitted to the vote of MEPs proposes to approve the ratification of the 2014 protocol on the 1930 Convention on Forced Labour, which France had already ratified. I therefore voted in favour of this ratification, which confirms France's commitment against forced labour. However, I think it is essential to add that this position should be reflected in action and particularly in the trade field vis-à-vis partner countries engaged in forced labour. Behind the naïve and joyful web of globalization are very often dramatic situations of exploitation of human beings.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Although forced labour is absolutely reprehensible and reprehensible, this recommendation, instead of focusing on the major problems of European workers, focuses on illegal immigrants and constitutes a "Trojan Horse" aimed at relaxing laws against illegal immigration.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. Forced labour is a violation of human rights and an attack on the dignity of millions of women, men, girls and boys. In the 21st century, forced labour affects 21 million people, victims of an exploitation that generates $150 billion a year in income for the benefit of those who organize and manage it. Although debt slavery no longer officially exists on the European continent, 880 000 people in the European Union and 1.6 million across the continent are affected by these new forms of forced labour. Men and women who have been offered a job abroad are deceived by their would-be employers, just as migrants are by doers, and children are weakened by uprooting. Labour rights are therefore a fundamental pillar of decent work and are the main instrument for combating labour exploitation. The Protocol in question calls on governments to take measures to better protect workers, in particular migrant workers, from abusive and fraudulent recruitment practices.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it aims to combat forced labour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 European Union policies must promote and defend human rights and decent work and effectively combat trafficking in human beings. The main objective of the 2014 International Labour Organisation Protocol is to eradicate new forms of exploitation and trade in slaves. It is estimated that up to 800 000 people in the European Union are exposed to new forms of forced labour. Since 1930, there have been many changes in the context and form of forced or compulsory labour, and it is therefore important that the European Union responds adequately to this problem. The protocol in question should strengthen labour inspection services and the more effective enforcement of labour laws, as the Posting of Workers Directive allows undertakings to de facto break the rules and circumvent existing labour rights practices. The protocol also welcomes the request by the Governments of the Member States to take substantial measures to better protect workers during the difficult recruitment process.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the ratification of the 2014 ILO Protocol on the Convention on Forced Labour.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Although forced labour is absolutely reprehensible and reprehensible, this recommendation, instead of focusing on the major problems of European workers, focuses on illegal immigrants and is a "Trojan Horse" aimed at relaxing laws against illegal immigration. I'm voting against.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Protocol of 2014 on the Forced Labour Convention is a fundamental tool for the defence of human rights. Nevertheless Member States need authorisation from the European Union to open negotiations as well as to ratify international agreements when parts of the agreements fall in areas of EU competence. Hence it is not acceptable that Member States entered negotiations on the Protocol without prior authorisation.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. With today's vote, the European Parliament is giving the green light to accession to this important convention, enabling the European Union to strengthen its role as a global player committed to a fairer and fairer order, starting precisely from a more certain and advanced legal framework to protect labour rights and, in particular, the fight against and prevention of forced labour.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP recommendation on the draft Council decision authorising Member States to ratify, in the interests of the European Union, the 2014 Protocol to the International Labour Organisation's 1930 Convention on Forced Labour on social policy issues, as I believe that the procedures of Community law must be respected. I share Parliament's position of giving its assent to the EU Commission to enter into the negotiations on protocol 2014 to the ILO Forced Labour Convention, approving its request, without, however, implying acceptance of the misconduct of certain States. This is a formal but obligatory step: this is a matter for the EU, and therefore accepting autonomous accession by the States, without a mandate from the Commission, would be a serious vulnus for the European institutions.  On the substance, I agree with the call for a protocol to be applied, which is an important instrument in the fight against forced labour, because it makes the Convention legally binding, calls for more resources to be allocated against forced labour and aims to combat all new forms of slavery.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the International Labour Organisation Convention on Forced or Compulsory Labour on issues relating to social policy, because, as a social policy expert, I welcome the application of minimum international social standards in the EU.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the ILO Convention on Forced Labour. Human rights must be protected throughout Europe and across European borders. We must create working conditions that do not lead to forced labour.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is the 21st century, yet 21 million people are still performing forced labour. They are modern slaves, generating USD 150 billion for the criminal networks that exploit them on an annual basis. This has to end. That is why it voted in favour of the Le Hyaric report and its call for the authorisation of opening negotiations on the ILO’s 2014 Protocol on the Forced Labour Convention. We need new tools and resources for combating forced labour. But most vital will be coordination amongst Member States. If we really want to eradicate slavery, and stop the exploitation of workers that is undercutting the wages of others, Member States simply cannot go at it alone, in spite of best intentions. They can only make a change if they act together, for example by adopting stronger rules across Europe to prevent undercutting, and strengthening the Agency Workers and Posted Workers Directives. I call on Member States to do so, so that we can make slavery history.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is a step in the right direction, highlighting the continuous impact of forced labour on the lives of millions worldwide.  The International Labour Organization (ILO) estimates that there are currently 21 million people being exploited, whether through physical labour, sexual violence or fraudulent recruitment processes.  This report urges governments to help victims of forced labour escape their situation by educating and informing those who are most vulnerable: women, children and migrants.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of ratifying this Protocol on Forced or Compulsory Labour. Forced labour "contributes to perpetuating poverty and is an obstacle to achieving decent work for all." Ratifying the Protocol is a guarantee that we support continuing to combat new and traditional forms of forced labour with more modern tools. New forms of exploitation through forced labour require States to develop new national policies and plans to act more efficiently, as well as to promote the generation of new fighting tools, and mechanisms for the protection and reparation of victims. We are in favour of defending the most vulnerable and this Convention allows us to continue in this line. The Protocol emphasizes that, in order to protect human beings from forced labour, a focus must be placed on prevention and reparation. The Protocol encourages the strengthening of labour inspection services to ensure the implementation of labour legislation. Further inspections are needed that do not leave employers unpunished and that there is a responsibility for the entire outsourcing chain.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour rights are among the main pillars of decent work, and the main instrument for combating exploitation through work. By voting in favour of the report, Labour MEPs called for the authorisation of the Protocol of 2014 on the Forced Labour Convention, 1930, as one of the most important tools for the defence of human rights.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the position of the rapporteur. Human rights must be followed and forced labour directly exploits the most vulnerable people: women, children and migrants. Physical and psychological violence cannot be tolerated, therefore I strongly believe that by securing and updating the ILO’s Protocol of 2014 on the Forced Labour Convention, 1930 we will be able to better protect workers and their rights. Also, we must follow the European anti-poverty strategy, thus only national measures are not enough. Moreover, prevention of forced labour could only be effective if we also approached third-world countries, which breach the ILO Convention of 1930 on forced labour and its 2014 Protocol. Due to these reasons, I voted for this Council proposal.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was very pleased to support this resolution for the ratification of the Protocol of 2014 to the ILO Forced Labour Convention, 1930. This is an important update to the existing Convention which seeks to tackle forced or compulsory labour in all its guises in the modern world. It is estimated that over 20 million people are victims of forced labour globally and it is always vulnerable groups such as women, children and migrants that suffer. In the context of the ongoing refugee crisis I particularly welcome its call to protect persons, particularly migrant workers, from possible abusive and fraudulent practices during the recruitment and placement process and to ensure all victims of forced or compulsory labour, irrespective of their presence or legal status in the national territory, have access to appropriate and effective remedies, such as compensation.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because this updated Protocol strengthens the international legal framework by establishing obligations to prevent forced labour and to provide victims with protection and access to certain remedies. The International Labour Organization’s Protocol of 2014 on the Forced Labour Convention, 1930, updates the Convention, equipping it with new tools for combating forced labour.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my Socialist colleagues, I voted to authorise the ratification of this ILO convention on forced labour. It is a disgrace that 21 million people are performing forced labour today. This is a highly exploitative practice which generates billions of euros for those who manage it. It is therefore important that we, as MEPs, give Member States the go-ahead to ratify this international agreement.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes the EU taking any action on the international stage as it should be for elected and accountable national governments to decide. We also agree with a House of Commons note which objects to the EU having sole competence in this area of social policy. However, we do not want to oppose a measure authorising Member States to sign up to the ILO protocol. We also note that either way the UK will sign up in its own right anyway. For these reasons I abstained. The issue itself is very important and we agree that stronger measures must be taken to combat forced labour, the best of which would be to leave the European Union, as freedom of movement laws make it easier for criminal gangs to traffic people across Europe and force them to work.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Forced labour and human trafficking are massive global problems in the 21st century, and we must work together collectively to eliminate modern day slavery. This Protocol sets out real measures to be taken which will go some way to assist these efforts and I support this report without hesitation.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of ratifying this Convention as forced labour 'contributes to perpetuating poverty and is an obstacle to achieving decent work for all'. Ratifying the 2014 Protocol to the ILO Forced or Compulsory Labour Convention is a guarantee that we support continuing to combat new and traditional forms of forced labour with more modern tools. New modern forms of exploitation through forced labour require States to develop new national policies and plans to act more efficiently, promote new tools of struggle, as well as mechanisms for the protection and reparation of victims.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Vote for. I consider labour rights to be one of the main pillars of decent work and represent the main instrument of combating exploitation at work

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft decision authorisation of Member States to ratify the 2014 Protocol in the interest of the European Union with the ISO Convention on Forced Labour on social policy issues, as I condemn any type of forced labour and consider it necessary to further strengthen the legal framework in question to put an end to such actions and approaches.  I believe that this Protocol strengthens the administratively international legal framework by which signatory states undertake to strengthen the prevention of all types of forced labour and to provide victims with specific safeguards. However, national action plans need to be developed to further contribute to this fight, which is encompassing millions of people around the world. Moreover, the main legal texts of the European Union condemn forced labour, and I therefore consider the ratification of the Protocol to be in line with all European principles and regulations.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This recommendation on the Council's draft decision authorizes Member States to ratify the protocol established by the International Labour Organization (ILO) in 2014. This protocol relates to the C29 Convention on Forced Labour adopted in 1930 by the ILO and ratified by France in 1937.  Convention C29 called on signatory countries to prohibit forced labour, on the understanding that this did not include certain forms of compulsory labour (the one required of the military, civic obligations, work of general interest following a conviction, etc.). It encouraged member countries to take appropriate measures to ensure that workers receive fair pay, thus guaranteeing them free and dignified living conditions The new 2014 protocol finds that the convention is not respected by all signatory states. It therefore reminds them of their obligations to combat forced labour and calls on them to cooperate judicially to be more effective.  In view of the deteriorating working conditions in our country and the threat posed by further deregulation of our economy, I thought it would be useful to vote in favour of this text.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Patrick Le Hyaric's report on the ILO Convention on Forced Labour. The aim of the text is to give Parliament's consent to ratify a 2014 protocol updating the ILO Convention on Forced Labour. The text was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which aimed to ratify the 2014 protocol on the Convention on Forced Labour of the International Labour Organization. It was important to adopt this report in order to effectively combat human trafficking and forced labour.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This is an annex to the 1930 ILO Protocol, the purpose of which is to update the definition of forced labour. Particular emphasis is placed on new forms of forced labour, such as organised begging, bogus self-employment, forced prostitution, work forced by smugglers, or work obligations to pay off debts. It also sets out obligations to be followed by ILO signatories. These include labour inspections, due diligence procedures, and, in principle, measures to combat the roots of forced labour, with forced labour not specified. Although this additional protocol is to be welcomed, I am in agreement because the report broadens the concept of victim and creates a legal vacuum that can be easily exploited for criminal activities.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour rights are among the main pillars of decent work and are the main instrument for combating exploitation through work. I strongly supported the report as it calls for the authorisation of the Protocol of 2014 on the Forced Labour Convention, 1930, as one of the most important tools for the defence of human rights.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour of Mr Le Hyaric's proposal. The ILO's 2014 Protocol on the Convention on Forced Labour updated this convention. The new provisions strengthen the international legal framework by establishing an obligation to prevent forced labour, while also offering victims protection and access to redress mechanisms.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. It is legitimate to fight forced labour around the world. This protocol is a logical continuation of the 1930 Convention on Forced Labour, which France had already ratified. I'm voting for.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it reminds us of the need to abolish forced labour, which still exists in some countries while the ILO has been trying to ban it since 1930.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation by Parliament because it consents to the opening of negotiations by Member States with the International Labour Organization. States had already initiated negotiations prior to this authorization, but the recommendation complies with the legal and jurisdictional terms of the EP. On the basis that 'the context and forms of forced or compulsory labour have changed', the Protocol considers prevention and protection measures and the introduction of legal and redress actions, such as compensation and compensation for damages, 'necessary'.  It calls for a strengthening of the means and cooperation between States in the fight against modern forms of slavery, thus recognizing their increasingly international character. These practices today affect 880,000 Union citizens and 1.6 million across the continent.  Focuses on immigrants, 1st victims of forced labour, especially women, and the criminalization of their legal status if they do not have the roles in order or the activity they are forced to perform ($150,000M of benefits resulting from forced labour, 2/3 come sexual exploitation)

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it reinforces international commitments to combat forced labour, which affects 21 million people worldwide. But we must not forget that slave labour has not disappeared in the EU, where the ILO estimates that 880 000 people work hard: many of them women victims of sexual exploitation; so a greater effort is needed from EU states and institutions, including within their own economies.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 There is no opposition to the request to adopt the Council Decision authorising Member States to ratify the 2014 Protocol to the Convention on Forced or Compulsory Labour of the International Labour Organization (ILO). We are aware that even today forced labour remains a sad reality for many people and, therefore, we cannot be impassive about it. This new ILO Protocol enables us to actively and positively cover and address changing contexts and forms of forced or compulsory labour. I voted in favour of that decision, decided on the need to spare no effort in the fight against this phenomenon. Ensuring the rights of the most vulnerable subjects, stressing children, with regard to forced labour is both a political and moral obligation.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported Mep Le Hyaric's recommendation to give consent and join the appeals of the Commission and the Council for The Member States of the European Union to ratify as soon as possible the International Labour Organisation Convention dealing with social policy and labour standards issues. The Convention aims to strengthen legislative frameworks that protect the employee from forced labour and to provide protection to victims of forced labour. At a time when Europe is facing a huge influx of refugees from war zones, but also economic immigrants in search of a better life, it is important to ensure respect for human rights, prevent trafficking in human beings and provide an opportunity for decent work for all. Among other things, the Convention calls on governments to prescribe greater measures to protect potential employees in the recruitment process, especially refugees.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Paradoxical situation – sometimes forced labour exists in EU countries. It is forbidden because it cannot be considered as a form of slavery. I voted in favour because the implementation of the text will allow the European Union to allow another world to set an example of what the relationship between an employee and an employer really should be. Support!

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Forced labour has various, often hidden forms these days. It affects the most vulnerable sections of the population, especially women and children, but also the long-term unemployed, who are unable to find adequate work. Such persons accept work that they would otherwise never have accepted under properly functioning conditions and with sufficient knowledge. Forced labour goes hand in hand with a lack of education, a lack of awareness and knowledge. For a long time, it is no longer just about prostitution, hard work in unsatisfactory conditions, begging or other degrading work. In the countries of the former Eastern Europe, various loans and loans from private companies are also a form of forced labour, which people often take with the vision of a possible purchase of things they do not even need. Disadvantageous contracts, together with complicated provisions and interest burdens for them, make them modern-day debt slaves who are unable to repay their obligations even in decades. The European Strategy against Poverty must also coordinate and guide the governments of the EU Member States in taking action so that forced labour is lost from the European area. We can only build a democratic Europe if we can guarantee its people a dignified life and work.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the authorisation of Member States to ratify, in the interests of the European Union, the 2014 Protocol to the International Labour Organisation Convention of 1930 on forced or compulsory labour in matters relating to social policy because, on the one hand, this Recommendation condemns the new forms of slave trade and exploitation under which 880,000 people are in the European Union and 1,600,000 on the European continent; , on the other hand, its support will be another lever for the European Union to finally accede to the European Convention on Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this protocol, which follows the 1930 convention. This new protocol is a logical follow-up that encourages signatories to finally eliminate forced labour that has not yet been eradicated. It is therefore normal to go in the direction of this convention, which France has already ratified.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Forced labour breaches human rights and is an affront to the dignity of millions of women, men, girls and boys. That is why I am delighted to vote for this proposal. The ILO’s Protocol of 2014 on the Forced Labour Convention, 1930, updates the convention, equipping it with new tools for combating forced labour and making it legally binding.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision authorising Member States to ratify the 2014 Protocol to the ILO Forced Labour Convention of 1930, with regard to social policy issues. The aim of this protocol is to prevent forced labour and to offer victims protection and access to redress mechanisms, preventive measures and protection. The ban on forced labour, which is a violation of human rights and an infringement of the dignity of victims, is part of EU primary law. It is therefore necessary to take action to defend these rights and decent work and to take measures that can best protect all workers.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2014 Protocol recently updated the 1930 Forced Labour Convention, giving a legally binding character to existing regulatory instruments on combating forced labour. The awareness of the existence of new forms of exploitation, in addition to the 'classical' ones, based on violent and intimidating methods, explains why I have decided to support Mr Le Hyaric's report.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because the Protocol calls on governments to promote the necessary measures to better protect workers, especially migrants, from abusive and fraudulent practices during the recruitment process. However, without strengthening the means and resources to implement it, or without a clear and unequivocal statement that it prevails over free movement or competition law, the Protocol may be nothing more than a dead law.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I believe that we all agree that forced labour is a violation of human rights and undermines the dignity of millions of women, men, girls and children. My support for the ratification from the Member States of the 2014 Protocol to the Convention on Forced or Compulsory Labour of the International Labour Organization, as regards social policy issues, a text which strengthens the international legal framework by establishing obligations to prevent forced labour and to provide victims with protection and access to legal and redress actions.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained in the final vote, although an adjustment to the definition of 'forced labour' is more than necessary, and activities such as organised begging, bogus self-employment, forced prostitution and 'indentured labor' are also taken up and condemned in the report. However, the concept of victim is too broad and many activities of illegal immigrants simply cannot be punished as a result.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Forced labour is a violation of human rights and an attack on the dignity of millions of women, men, girls and young boys. In the 21st century, however, forced labour affects 21 million people, victims of an exploitation that generates $150 billion in income a year for those who organize and supervise it. The International Labour Organization(ILO) Convention on Forced Labour of 1930 prohibits the practice. The 2014 Protocol updates this convention by giving it new tools to combat forced labour and giving it a legally binding character. The text authorizes Member States to ratify this new protocol. I'm voting for.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This legislative resolution authorizes member states to ratify the protocol established by the International Labour Organization (ILO) in 2014. This protocol relates to the C29 Convention on Forced Labour adopted in 1930 by the ILO and ratified by France in 1937.  Convention C29 called on signatory countries to prohibit forced labour, on the understanding that this did not include certain forms of compulsory labour (the one required of the military, civic obligations, work of general interest following a conviction, etc.). It encouraged member countries to take appropriate measures to ensure that workers were not subjected to fair remuneration, thus guaranteeing them free and dignified living conditions The new 2014 protocol finds that the convention is not respected by all signatory states. It therefore reminds signatory states of their obligations to combat forced labour and calls on them to cooperate judicially to be more effective.  I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union (EU) is committed not only to promoting human rights and decent work but also to the eradication of trafficking in human beings, both internally and in its external relations. Hence the importance of the signing of this Protocol by all Member States.  Rights at work are a fundamental pillar of decent work.  By ratifying ILO conventions and related protocols, EU Member States send an important signal on the coherence of EU policy on promoting fundamental principles and rights at work, as well as on improving working conditions around the world. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to vote in favour of this resolution because it provides protection against forced labour and ensures social and economic rights, including remedial actions should these rights be infringed. The resolution also proposes anti-corruption strategies such as transparency, empowerment and initiatives for reducing crime such as human trafficking.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The ILO and the EU share the same commitment to social and economic progress, better living and working conditions, and employment promotion. It is essential that Member States ratify the 2014 protocol on the ILO Convention on Forced Labour. Conventions on freedom of association and collective bargaining, the elimination of forced and compulsory labour, the elimination of discrimination in employment and labour, and the abolition of child labour are reference terms that must become unavoidable. But the real debate here is the role of the state as an impartial public power, the guarantor of equal opportunities and social justice; it is the one on everyone's access to education, justice, administration, health, and culture. This debate will lead to political solutions such as, for example, greater fiscal convergence, which too often encourages, like unframed globalization, the risk of social dumping. I repeat, it is up to the public authorities to play their role as protector and regulator, enabling it to perform the great functions of the regal functions that naturally fall to it.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the social policy on the ILO Forced Labour Convention. The Protocol of 2014 on the Forced Labour Convention, 1930, is an important tool for the defence of human rights. Nevertheless, Member States need authorisation by the Union to open negotiations as well as to ratify international agreements when parts of the agreements fall in areas of EU competence. Hence it is not acceptable that Member States entered negotiations on the Protocol without prior authorisation.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today, new forms of forced labour have spread, including forcing people lured abroad with the promise of job opportunities to work in the most difficult and humiliating jobs through abuse of their vulnerable situation, often through physical violence and constant psychological aggression. The Council's draft decision seeks the EU to urge its Member States to ratify as soon as possible the 2014 Protocol to the 1930 International Labour Organisation Convention on Forced Labour, thereby contributing to the success of the Union's efforts to ensure human rights and decent work for all and to end trafficking in human beings inside and outside the Union. I voted in favour of Parliament giving its consent to this Council decision.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Council of the European Union decided on 10 March 2015 to allow Member States to ratify the additional protocol to the 1930 ILO Convention on Forced Labour, condemning forced labour. The European Union, as an entity, cannot ratify the text, so it will be up to the Member States to do so individually. France had ratified the original Convention. The vote must therefore be favourable, given the objectives pursued by the protocol.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2014 Protocol of the International Labour Organisation on the Convention on Forced Labour of 1930 updated it, guaranteeing it new mechanisms for combating forced labour and giving it a legally binding character. I believe that preventive and protective measures are essential, as well as the establishment of repayment mechanisms, such as compensation and compensation for physical or material damage, such as the measures in the Protocol. I believe that in order to prevent forced labour, Member States should promote people's education and information; ensure that the scope of legislation relating to this matter has the reach of all workers and all sectors of the economy; and that labour inspection services be strengthened. I support the strengthening of the means and cooperation between states in the fight against contemporary forms of slavery, thus recognising their increasingly international character. I think it is important to stress that these measures should always aim at protecting people, especially migrant workers, from possible abusive and fraudulent practices during a possible recruitment and placement process.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the ILO Convention on Forced Labour is part of the ILO Convention's policy to combat forced labour, which began in 1930. This convention (not ratified by the United States) calls on countries to abolish forced or compulsory labour altogether. The 2014 Protocol follows this convention and states that the forced labour that still persists in some countries must be addressed quickly.  The Council of the EU this year authorised member states to ratify the convention because the EU, as a legal entity, cannot ratify it. Although I believe that the EU does not have to interfere in the international affairs of States, which have already signed this convention (including France), it is normal to continue on this path and to fight against forced labour in the world. So I voted for that recommendation.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour rights are among the main pillars of decent work and are the main instrument for combating exploitation through work. Labour MEPs called today for the authorisation of the Protocol of 2014 on the Forced Labour Convention, 1930, as one of the most important tools for the defence of human rights.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which calls on the European Union to fight against forced labour around the world by authorising Member States to ratify the 2014 Protocol to the Convention of the International Labour Organization. Forced labour generates $150 billion in income a year for those who organize it. It is important to combat this human rights violation that undermines the dignity of 21 million adults and children worldwide.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to highlight the 2014 Protocol on the Convention on Forced Labour of the International Labour Organization of 1930. This text updates the previous convention and the team of new and more appropriate instruments to combat new forms of forced labour. This strengthens the international legal framework that establishes obligations to prevent forced labour and allows victims protection and redress. The Union has already banned forced labour, but it remains present on its territory, which cannot be accepted.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We strongly support the draft Council decision authorising Member States to ratify the 2014 Protocol to the Convention on Forced Labour, as we see it as a serious violation of human rights and an infringement of the dignity of millions of women, men, girls and boys. The European Union has always been committed to combating all forms of exploitation. Forced labor affects more than 21 million people and generates $150 billion in revenue a year for those who organize and control it. The most vulnerable populations, women, children and migrants, are those who have the worst tasks and conditions imposed: prostitution, begging, the hardest and most degrading jobs. In addition to the violence of exploitation, there is physical violence, constant psychological aggression, fear and isolation. We are therefore convinced of the need to combat these new forms of trafficking and exploitation through law and increasingly determined actions to enforce it. This is the aim of the 2014 ILO International Labour Organisation Protocol on the 1930 Convention on Forced Labour, which we call on all Member States to ratify as soon as possible.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report that combats the most violent form of exploitation that is an affront to the dignity of millions of women, men, girls and boys.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that modern slavery needs new tools to combat, and in order to determine it, we must not forget, as states, that we are obliged, above all, to respect fundamental human rights and freedoms, including that of being protected against forced labour. It is a condition that the EU as a whole and each country to fight against the illegal exploitation of people.  At the European Parliament, we are often reported with shocking cases of modern slavery, and what is more outrageous is that the victims are often women and children who become 'working tools' of human traffickers. The European Commission and the Member States have an obligation to ensure that the right to human dignity is not infringed by the right to free movement, for example. European citizens have a legitimate right to do decent work and enjoy a fair payment, and the EU must actively fight to ensure that their rights are respected.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. – As far as the ILO agreement on forced and compulsory labour is concerned, my impressions were divided: on the one hand, the Convention goes very far in some parts (e.B. in the area of the remedies now to be introduced), on the other hand, it does not go far enough in others, particularly as regards an effective fight against forced labour in those parts of the world where it is a common phenomenon. I have therefore abstained from voting.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. This convention has been since 1930, but 85 years later forced labour is nevertheless widespread. There are 21 million people in the world who, as victims of forced labour, have to suffer physical and mental violence and endure fear and isolation. Given that forms of forced labour have changed over time, the protocol aims to modernise prevention and protection measures, remedies and redress mechanisms, and states are also called upon to step up their cooperation in combating modern forms of slavery.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I support the recommendation made.  It is essential that in each Member State there are deterrent, imperative and innovative measures to combat forced labour. An appropriate mechanism must be put in place to prevent and criminalise forced labour. We cannot allow people to continue to be victims of forced and compulsory labour. States need to better protect workers from abuse and fraud. In order to prevent forced labour and to provide its victims with protection and the opportunity to defend their rights, it is essential that measures to enforce labour law are actually strengthened. Furthermore, the impact of European social policy on labour law should be considered when ratifying this Convention.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that forced labour is a violation of human rights; that the objective of the ILO Protocol 2014 on the 1930 Convention on Forced Labour is to combat forms of trafficking and exploitation and that this protocol calls on the acceding States to take measures to protect workers' rights, and in view of Article 4 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The 1930 Convention on Forced Labour is one of the founding conventions of the International Labour Organisation, which is made up of international standard work and is considered a human rights instrument. It is still used in practice, but the International Labour Organisation was concerned by information from the early twentieth century when at least 20.9 million people were victims of forced labour.  It is therefore necessary to adopt this Protocol which outlines measures to prevent forced labour in society, as it constitutes a threat to fundamental human rights and offends human dignity. I believe that it is necessary to educate and inform people and to make efforts to implement this Protocol in order to largely eradicate forced labour from the Member States of the European Union and beyond.  People have the right to work and to make live resources, but in a fair and dignified way, and any kind of forced labour that violates human rights and their dignity can be condemned. We should not create and support a society that is more like slavery than democracy, so it is necessary to eradicate all risks that contribute to the survival of forced labour.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The fight against forced labour dates back to a 1930 ILO convention. This convention (not ratified by the United States) calls on countries to abolish forced or compulsory labour altogether. The 2014 protocol follows this convention and states that the need to address the fact that forced labour is still not eradicated everywhere must be addressed.  The Council of the EU this year authorised member states to ratify the convention because the EU, as an entity, cannot ratify it. As EU Member States, including France, have already signed this convention, it is normal to continue on this path to combat forced labour around the world. I therefore voted in favour of this recommendation, which does not infringe on the sovereignty of states.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Devastating and absolutely intolerable is the fact that in the 21st century, when we have already advanced in a number of areas, 21 million people are still victims of forced labour. Such a form of coercion affects men, women and children without exception, whose only desire is to ensure a better future for themselves and loved ones. Just adopting the legislative framework is not enough because forced labor also happens in some of these countries, only in a more subtle way. In the European Union too, 880,000 people are victims of forced labour, while across Europe the number is almost double that. It is time as international actors to act and help stop forced labour, which is why I support this report and the rapporteur's recommendation to give consent to the council's draft decision authorisation of Member States to ratify the 2014 Protocol to the 1930 Convention on Forced Labour in the interest of the European Union. international labour organisation concerning social policy issues.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2014 PROTOCOL of the ILO – International Labour Organization – on the 1930 Convention on Forced Labour, has just updated this convention, providing new tools to combat forced labour and giving it a legally binding character. The provisions of the Protocol strengthen the international legal framework by establishing an obligation to prevent forced labour and to offer victims protection and access to redress mechanisms. Given the crucial importance of combating all forms of forced labour, I believe that the European Parliament must strongly support the action taken by the ILO in this field. I have decided to support this assent by voting in favour.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In the context of promoting human rights and decent working conditions for all, the EU wanted to strengthen the ILO's International Convention on Forced Labour by ratifying the 2014 Protocol. This document has been approved by the European Parliament and complements the convention on social policy issues. I am pleased to have voted in favour of this report. This protocol will then have to be ratified by each Member State.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. – (PT) I voted in favour of considering the ratification by the Member States of the 2014 Protocol on the 1930 Convention on Forced Labour of the International Labour Organisation on issues relating to social policy.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. In the 21st century, forced labour affects 21 million people, victims of an exploitation that generates US$150 billion a year in income for the benefit of those who organize and manage it. Although slavery does not officially exist on the European continent, 880 000 people in the European Union and 1.6 million across the continent are affected by new forms of forced labour. Men and women who have been offered a job abroad are deceived by their would-be employers. The most vulnerable remain the same as ever: women, children and migrants. We must continue to fight for these new forms of trafficking and exploitation to be abolished. This is the objective of the 2014 International Labour Organisation Protocol on the 1930 Convention on Forced Labour and covered by this Recommendation of the European Parliament's Committee on Employment and Social Affairs.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. With this Recommendation, Parliament consents to the opening of negotiations by Member States with the International Labour Organization, with the aim of ratifying the 2014 Protocol to the ILO Forced or Compulsory Labour Convention, 1930, which updates that Convention by providing it with new tools to combat forced labour and entrusting it with a legally binding nature.  In this way, the Protocol considers 'necessary' prevention and protection measures and the introduction of legal and redress actions, such as compensation and reparation for material and physical damage, and calls for the strengthening of means and cooperation between States in the fight against modern forms of slavery.  Similarly, Parliament's Recommendation points to the need to pay particular attention to immigrants, often the first victims of forced labour, particularly women. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Today I voted in favour of the report on the ILO Convention on Labour Force and thus gave my consent to the Council's proposal for a decision. Once adopted, this Council decision will allow Member States to ratify the 2014 Protocol on the International Labour Organization's Convention on Forced Labour on social policy issues. Despite Convention 29 on forced labour in 1930, we must note that this phenomenon is still relevant in our societies. According to the ILO, at least 20.9 million people are victims of forced labour worldwide. This is an issue that we cannot ignore. The 2014 protocol discussed here must address gaps in implementation, strengthen measures to prevent human trafficking for the exploitation of their work, and improve protection and compensation for victims of forced labour. Given all these elements, it seemed inevitable to me to vote in favour of this report.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the legislative resolution on the draft Council decision authorising The Member States to ratify, in the interests of the European Union, the 2014 Protocol on the Convention on Forced Labour of 1930 of the International Labour Organisation, because I believe that it updates the Convention with new tools promoting labour rights, which are the fundamental pillar of decent work and are the main instrument for combating labour exploitation. I also believe that the provisions of the Protocol make the international legal framework possible by establishing obligations to prevent forced labour and to provide victims of such labour abuses with a system of protection and access to redress mechanisms, such as compensation for physical or material damage, as well as greater cooperation between States in the fight against contemporary forms of slavery.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Together with my group, I have decided to vote in favour of the ratification by Member States of the 2014 ILO Protocol on the 1930 Convention on Forced Labour. I agree with strengthening the international legal framework and I am in favour of creating new means of eradicating all illegal forms of work. It is up to the European Union to defend human rights, combat forced labour and put an end to trafficking in human beings.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of ratifying this Convention. Forced labour "contributes to perpetuating poverty and is an obstacle to achieving decent work for all." Ratifying the 2014 Protocol to the ILO Forced or Compulsory Labour Convention is a guarantee that we support continuing to combat new and traditional forms of forced labour with more modern tools. New forms of exploitation through forced labour require States to develop new national policies and plans to act more efficiently, promote new tools for combat, and mechanisms for the protection and reparation of victims.  We are in favour of defending the most vulnerable and this Convention allows us to continue in this line. The Protocol emphasizes that, in order to protect human beings from forced labour, a focus must be placed on prevention and reparation. Article 2 of the Protocol provides for the strengthening of labour inspection services to ensure the implementation of labour legislation. Further inspections are needed that do not leave employers unpunished and that there is a responsibility for the entire outsourcing chain.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is important to defend workers against any form of forced labour, modern slavery and trafficking in human beings. I welcome the adoption of this Protocol as a tool in the fight against these forms of terror and fully support the protocol.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it reinforces international commitments to combat forced labour, which affects 21 million people worldwide. But we must not forget that slave labour has not disappeared in the EU, where the ILO estimates that 880 000 people work hard: many of them women victims of sexual exploitation; so a greater effort is needed from EU states and institutions, including within their own economies.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, the European Parliament voted in favour of the Council decision authorising Member States to ratify, in the interests of the European Union, the 2014 Protocol to the International Labour Organisation's 1930 Convention on Forced Labour on Social Policy Issues. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote as I do not believe this is an EU competency.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the case of a recommendation concerning the EDC Convention on Forced or Compulsory Labour, I voted in favour of this application because I am in favour of combating forced labour. Even in the 21st century, 21 million people carried out forced labour. The ILO Protocol of 2014 to the 1930 Convention on Forced or Compulsory Labour updates this Convention, providing new instruments to combat forced labour and making it legally binding.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution on the ILO Convention on Forced or Compulsory Labour. Labour rights are one of the main pillars of decent work and are a major tool for combating labour exploitation. Although labour law is at a very high level in the EU, we are still faced with forced or compulsory labour today. It is therefore necessary to really reflect on the risk factors that lead people to forced labour, as defined by the ILO in its latest report on forced labour, such as income loss and poverty, vulnerability due to lack of education, illiteracy, vulnerability of specific population groups such as women, children ... That is why individual Member States must take measures to better protect workers, especially migrant workers, from abuse and fraudulent practices during recruitment. EU policies must defend and promote human rights and decent work, as well as eradicate trafficking in human beings, whether within or outside the EU's borders.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Forced labour constitutes a violation of human rights and an attack on the dignity of exploited people. Although much has already been done in this area, in the 21st century there are still 21 million people victims of forced labour exploitation, which generates about $150 billion in revenue annually. In addition to classical forms of exploitation (material or physical coerction), new forms have emerged that are much more delable and insidious and are based on the hope of improving living conditions. The 2014 ILO Protocol on the 1930 Convention on Forced Or Compulsory Labour aims to use remedies to destroy and eradicate all forms of forced labour. New measures are very needed to prevent, protect, establish complaint mechanisms and remedies such as compensation and other compensation. The Protocol is a binding document which includes provisions on the education and information of individuals, the effort to ensure that the scope and implementation of legislation relating to the prevention of forced labour includes all workers and all sectors of the economy, the protection of the most vulnerable persons, support for due diligence to be demonstrated by the public and private sectors and the elimination of root causes that increase the risk of forced labour. As I believe that the measures described above to combat forced labour are absolutely necessary, I supported this recommendation.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this report because the 2014 ILO Protocol is actually an update of the 1930 Forced Labour Convention, which means that new tools to combat forced labour are included in this Protocol. The Protocol advocates strengthening the international legal framework, preventing forced labour and protecting victims with access to certain medicines.  Although the European Union has already included in its primary legislation the principle of prohibition of forced labour, this issue should be addressed and such initiatives should be propagated, as they are human lives and fundamental human rights, and the legislation related to them needs to be constantly supplemented, upgraded and updated.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour rights are among the main pillars of decent work, and the main instrument for combating exploitation through work. The Labour Party in this Parliament called today for authorisation of the Protocol of 2014 on the Forced Labour Convention, 1930, as one of the most important tools for the defence of human rights.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. I support the implementation of the protocol of one of the basic documents on the prevention of labour slavery and adequate protection of workers. The provisions of the protocol strengthen the international and institutional legal framework by improving workers' social security as well as safety during work. This protocol is in line with the times because by developing global world interdependences, we also notice the emergence of some new forms of slavery and different types of exploitation of children and women in work as well as various forms of labour coercion. The Protocol allows for a revision of European social policy as well as greater freedom for workers to perform their duties. This protocol is in line with the European Union's policy on the protection of human rights and is an extremely important aspect of the total eradication of modern slavery.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal as I support the proposed measures to combat forced or compulsory labour.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 This is a Commission recommendation to authorise Member States to ratify the update of the Treaty against Slavery (1930), which defines forced labour.  The update includes, inter alia, measures to educate and inform citizens from ILO member states, prevent against slavery and specifically protect migrant workers. As a Left we have always been and will continue to be against slavery, and in favour of human rights and workers' rights. That is why we also voted in favour of the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Although forced labour is absolutely reprehensible and reprehensible, this recommendation, instead of focusing on the major problems of European workers, focuses on illegal immigrants and constitutes a "Trojan Horse" aimed at relaxing laws against illegal immigration.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because I agree that we must also take action against this form of exploitation. The recommendation describes that forced labour is still present in the 21st century and still affects at least 21 million people globally who are victims of exploitation. It is a regrettable fact that, although debt servitation no longer officially exists on the European continent, 880 000 people in the European Union and 1.6 million people on the whole European continent are languishing in captivity for these new forms of forced labour. These include men and women seduced by foreign job offers, who are actually trapped by their alleged employers, migrants exploited by people smugglers and defenceless children ripped from their homes. I therefore agree that these new forms of trafficking in human beings and exploitation must be eliminated by means of law and by decisive action to enforce legislation. This is the purpose of the 2014 Protocol to the International Labour Organisation (ILO) Convention on Forced Labour of 1930, which was referred to this recommendation by the European Parliament's Committee on Employment and Social Affairs.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The society of the 21st century should not tolerate under any circumstances and in any form the compulsion to work on the free market. I am therefore pleased that the European Parliament has agreed to ratify the Protocol to the 1930 Convention on Forced Or Compulsory Labour by the International Labour Organisation. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ While slavery is a shameful practice belonging to the past, the harsh reality is that approximately 21 million people, in our 21st century, perform forced labour as victims of exploitation and trafficking.  In order to eliminate these practices, the International Labour Organization (ILO) updated its 1930 Forced Labour Convention with the 2014 Protocol, which gives the Convention new tools for combating forced labour. Today’s resolution recommends that Member States ratify the 2014 Protocol, with regard to matters related to social policy. For example, it calls on Member States to consider measures to better protect workers – particularly migrant workers – from abusive and fraudulent practices. It also recommends placing a larger emphasis on risk factors such as a decline in income, a lack of education and illiteracy, which compel individuals to perform forced labour. Lastly, it asks that EU’s foreign and trade policies are more determined in their approaches to third countries which breach the 1930 ILO Convention and its 2014 Protocol.  I voted in favour of the resolution because I believe the EU has an obligation to ensure that the rights of workers, either EU citizens or foreign nationals, are respected and all forms of modern-day slavery are combated.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution authorising Member States to ratify the Protocol of 2014 of the Forced Labour Convention of the International Labour Organization (ILO). This Protocol provides necessary updates for the Convention adopted in 1930 in order to combat forced labour. New forms of slavery with an international dimension have emerged and it is time to increase state cooperation and dedicate more resources to it. The Protocol also includes provision requiring Member States to take specific actions to prevent forced labour and ensure its victims find access to remedies. Such policies are fully consistent with EU objectives and legislation.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the recommendation on a draft Council decision giving Member States, in accordance with the Lisbon Treaty, the power to ratify the complement of the IOC Convention on Forced Labour.  I find this complement to be extremely useful, as it outlines concrete tools and binding measures to combat forced labour that violate human rights and dignity. In the 21st century, as many as 21 million people continued to be victims of exploitation, both traditional forms based on physical or material limitations and debt bondage, and the same has long since taken on an international character.  As the Convention establishes that 'the context and forms of forced or compulsory labour have changed', I believe effective changes are essential to effectively and sustainably counterapel forced labour and implement those provisions.  In defence and promotion of human rights inside and outside the borders of the European Union, it is necessary to constantly educate and inform people, which will be ensured by the application of this Convention.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of ratifying this Protocol on Forced or Compulsory Labour. Forced labour "contributes to perpetuating poverty and is an obstacle to achieving decent work for all." Ratifying the Protocol is a guarantee that we support continuing to combat new and traditional forms of forced labour with more modern tools. New forms of exploitation through forced labour require States to develop new national policies and plans to act more efficiently, promote new tools for combat, and mechanisms for the protection and reparation of victims. We are in favour of defending the most vulnerable and this Convention allows us to continue in this line. The Protocol emphasizes that, in order to protect human beings from forced labour, a focus must be placed on prevention and reparation. The Protocol encourages the strengthening of labour inspection services to ensure the implementation of labour legislation. Further inspections are needed that do not leave employers unpunished and that there is a responsibility for the entire outsourcing chain

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The fight against forced labour is organized on the basis of a 1930 International Labour Organization (ILO) convention (which came into force on 1 May 1932). The Convention (No.29) on forced labour in 1930, ratified by all EU Member States, calls on countries to abolish forced or compulsory labour altogether as soon as possible. It also sets up specific conditions for forced or compulsory labour for the transition period before total abolition (hours, salaries, care, etc.). A review was planned five years after the convention came into force to take stock, in 1937. It should be noted that this convention has not been ratified by the United States.  This protocol is therefore a logical continuation of the 1930 Convention on Forced Labour, which France had already ratified. It is therefore normal to continue on this path. Moreover, it is legitimate to fight forced labour around the world. I voted for it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU entreated in its primary law the prohibition of forced labour by incorporating into the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union the Charter on the Fundamental Social Rights of Workers and the European Social Charter of the Council of Europe. The European Union must seek to protect human rights and fair work through its policies. I voted in favour of the adoption of this recommendation.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of ratifying this Protocol on Forced or Compulsory Labour. Forced labour "contributes to perpetuating poverty and is an obstacle to achieving decent work for all." Ratifying the Protocol is a guarantee that we support continuing to combat new and traditional forms of forced labour with more modern tools. New forms of exploitation through forced labour require States to develop new national policies and plans to act more efficiently, promote new tools for combat, and mechanisms for the protection and reparation of victims. We are in favour of defending the most vulnerable and this Convention allows us to continue in this line. The Protocol emphasizes that, in order to protect human beings from forced labour, a focus must be placed on prevention and reparation. The Protocol encourages the strengthening of labour inspection services to ensure the implementation of labour legislation. Further inspections are needed that do not leave employers unpunished and that there is a responsibility for the entire outsourcing chain.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Member States should ratify (and promote the ratification of) the Protocol as soon as possible. In light of the upcoming Olympic Games and other global sports games, the EU must take a strong stance on the promotion of human rights and decent work for all and on eradicating the trafficking of human beings both inside and outside the Union.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of giving consent to the Council decision authorising Member States to ratify the Protocol of 2014 to the ILO Forced Labour Convention of 1930 with regard to matters related to social policy. The 1930 ILO Forced Labour Convention is one of the ILO’s eight fundamental Conventions that make up the core international labour standards, and it is considered a human rights instrument. In adopting the Convention, the International Labour Conference called upon States to end the use of forced labour within the shortest possible period, and to criminalise the offence. Now, the 2014 Protocol that the Council will ask Member States to ratify seeks to address gaps in implementation and to make progress on preventing trafficking for labour exploitation and protecting and compensating victims of forced labour. I find this of great importance as it is in line with the EU commitment to promoting human rights and decent work and to eradicating trafficking in human beings.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This ILO Convention updates the Forced or Compulsory Labour Convention, which dates back to 1930, and equips it with new tools to combat forced labour. It is therefore necessary to vote in favour of this report in order for the European Parliament to give its approval to the Council's proposal.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Forced labour is an intolerable form of human exploitation that remains a reality. Nearly 21 million people worldwide are now victims of forced labour, including 1.6 million on European soil. The first victims are most often the most vulnerable populations, especially irregular migrants, who often have difficulty asserting their rights and demands. As a result, these people are generally blackmailed by their employers. This failure to respect human law and fundamental rights on European soil is intolerable and that is why it was necessary to finally update the Convention against Forced Labour, which dates back to 1930.  It is essential to strengthen labour law and not to allow it to weaken as recent European policies have tended to do. I therefore voted in favour of this report presented by my colleague Patrick Le Hyaric, which proposes new binding tools to force States to implement plans to combat these illegal forms of forced labour.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The ILO Protocol on the 1930 Convention on Forced Labour updates that Convention by assigning it new tools to combat forced labour and giving it a legally binding character. However, in the 21st century, forced labour affects 21 million people, victims of an exploitation that generates US$150 billion a year in income for the benefit of those who organize and manage it, joining the classical forms of exploitation, based on physical or material coerity, new forms, particularly in rich countries and sometimes despite the existence of a rule of law.  The European strategy to combat poverty can go beyond mere coordination of national actions and set binding poverty reduction targets, as well as to integrate the terms of the preamble to that Protocol, according to which forced labour 'contributes to perpetuating poverty and hinders the achievement of decent work for all'.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained in the final vote, although an adjustment to the definition of 'forced labour' is more than necessary, and activities such as organised begging, bogus self-employment, forced prostitution and 'indentured labor' are also taken up and condemned in the report. However, the concept of victim is too broad and many activities of illegal immigrants simply cannot be punished as a result.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Protocol of 2014 on the Forced Labour Convention of the International Labour Organization with regard to matters related to social policy. The Protocol’s provisions are strongly connected to fundamental rights. Forced labour is, in fact, a significant violation of rights stated in Article 5 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which has a legally binding status since the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon in December 2009. The Protocol introduces new measures that can prove very useful in combating forced labour. One of the most important provisions focuses on making efforts to ensure that enforcement of legislation related to the prevention of labour exploitation applies to all economic sectors. Moreover, the other purpose of the Protocol is to ensure that labour inspection services are strengthened. This is essential for us to minimise the aforementioned problem; however, we must also take steps to help the victims of labour exploitation. This Protocol establishes protection for them together with access to remedies such as compensation. I believe that this Protocol will help us to move forward and hopefully eliminate forced labour from our society.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The Convention on Forced Labour is one of the eight fundamental Conventions of the ILO. The Council adopted a decision authorising Member States to ratify parts of the Protocol to the Convention on Forced Labour falling within the eu's competence. The support for the Council's decision on the matter is linked to doubts raised when some Member States implemented the Convention as to the competence of the Union to negotiate on behalf of the Member States. The legal basis in the Treaty, which allows the Council to approve decisions defining a common position within an international organisation of which the EU is not a member, was also called into question. The Council decision therefore appears worthy of support.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I supported this recommendation of the European Parliament's Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. The text sets out additional mechanisms to strengthen the fight against forced or compulsory labour and updates the relevant convention.  At the same time, the text sets out the prerequisites for supporting and protecting victims of forced labour.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.
