The report concerns the 2014 Protocol to the Convention on Forced Labour of the International Labour Organisation in a 1930 document updating it with new definitions and mechanisms to combat forced labour. On the other hand, the Protocol emphasizes the prevention and compensation of victims. This report and the Protocol to which it relates are positive and reflect progressive positions. It does not denounce, however, that the EU has, as a result of its external policies, contributed to the causes that weaken the social relations that promote these practices; on the other hand, there are also realities within the EU that skim forced labour (or which correspond to this phenomenon), as a consequence of the liberalisation of industrial relations and the weakening of those relations, the little cohesion in its territory, the limitation of its inclusion policies (in the case of migration, for example) and austerity policies. We voted for it.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of the far-right Polish MP Korwin-Mikke, accused of assaulting a Polish official during a meeting. Beyond that I believe that this alleged attack on the physical integrity of a public official should be investigated, I welcome the suspension of Korwin-Mikke's parliamentary immunity given that he must be held accountable for his fascist (the claim that Hitler was not aware of the Holocaust), racist (referring to asylum seekers as "human garbage that does not want to work") or sexist (claiming that the difference between sexual consent and rape is very subtle). Although the procedure for withdrawing parliamentary immunity is not political, since the conviction that the presence of fascist elements such as Korwin-Mikke, which has even made the Nazi salute in the Chamber, is intolerable in a democratic institution, I have certainly voted in favour of the proposal to withdraw its parliamentary immunity.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I am not certain of the grounds on which speeding could be considered as part of fulfilling the  duties of an MEP, especially under the circumstances described to me.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Considering that the alleged offence - speeding in a settlement of Piotrk-w Trybunalski - has no direct or obvious connection to the exercise by Mr. Korwin-Mikke of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament and that in this case Parliament could not establish that there was fumus persecutionis, i.e. a sufficiently serious presumption and specifies that the proceedings were initiated with the intention of harming the political activity of the Member , I did not object to the lifting of his parliamentary immunity.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Convinced that a good administration of justice in a rule of law requires the application of the rules of immunity in accordance with the values of the Union, I voted in favour of the lifting of The parliamentary immunity of Mr Korwin-Mikke, in order to allow the Polish justice system to continue its investigation, which does not seem to have any connection with Mr Korwin-Mikke's status as an MEP.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of suspending Mr Korwin-Mikke's immunity because, according to the above described in the report and taking into account the provisions of the House Regulations, the pleading has been brought for an alleged infringement for exceeding the speed limits and the traffic infringement at issue is punishable by a fine. Moreover, the research carried out has not uncovered any encouragement to cause harm to the politician. Finally, because the alleged infringement and the proceedings are unrelated to his position as An MP. All this, as I mentioned at the beginning of my speech, has made me support the recommendation of the suspension of immunity.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns a request to waive the parliamentary immunity of Janusz Korwin-Mikke, a non-registered Polish MP. The alleged offence against Mr Korwin-Mikke is the speed limit in the town of Piotrk-w Trybunalski of 32km/h. The Prosecutor of the Republic of Poland has requested permission to prosecute Mr Korwin-Mikke.  I voted in favour of lifting immunity, since the alleged offence is not directly related to mr Korwin-Mikke's duties in the European Parliament, it does not concern a political opinion expressed by Mr Korwin-Mikke and the procedure initiated does not seek to interfere with the Member's political activity.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of suspending the immunity of Mr Janusz Korwin-Mikke so that proceedings against him for speeding can be brought. The charges against him do not concern the functions of Member of the European Parliament and there is no evidence of fumus persecutionis, that is to say, a sufficiently strong and precise suspicion that the matter has arisen with the intention of causing political harm to the Member, and parliamentary immunity must therefore be suspended.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this decision, which led the European Parliament to waive the immunity of Janusz Korwin-Mikke. The Prosecutor General of the Republic of Poland referred to the request of the Piqueguard of the City Guard for the prosecution of Janusz Korwin-Mikke, a Member of the European Parliament, for an administrative offence under Article 92a of the Code of Administrative Offences and Article 20(1) of the Road Traffic Rules, since the offence concerned speeding in the village.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report related to the waiver of parliamentary immunity of a Member of the European Parliament. In waiving an immunity defence, Parliament does not formulate any opinion on the probability of guilt or not of the MEP in question. It only looks at applying the Immunity Rules of Procedures (so-called Protocol No 7) to these cases, and when it finds the alleged actions have no direct and obvious connection to the performance of their duties as an MEP, then it decides to waive the immunity, so that court proceedings in the national Member State can begin or continue. If there is suspected political interference or otherwise, then a negative vote may be tabled. However, as there was no such suspicion, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because the criminal offence of which Mr Syod is accused is not the case. Mr Korwin-Mikke cannot be regarded as a contract in the performance of his duties as a Member of Parliament.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Parliament must vote on Janusz Korwin-Mikke's request to lift his parliamentary immunity. He is suspected of having committed an offence for exceeding the maximum speed allowed in the town of Piotrk-w Trybunalski in Poland.  The alleged offence is not directly or obviously related to the exercise of his mandate as a Member of the European Parliament and does not constitute an opinion or vote cast in the course of his duties as a Member of Parliament. As a French politician, mayor and Member of the European Parliament, I have always been of the view that those who perform public office should behave irreproachably. If this is not the case, they must go to court.  I therefore voted in favour of this proposal to waive parliamentary immunity.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report related to the waiver of parliamentary immunity of a Member of the European Parliament. In waiving an immunity defence, Parliament does not formulate any opinion on the probability of guilt or not of the MEP in question. It only looks at applying the Immunity Rules of Procedures (so-called Protocol No 7) to these cases, and when it finds the alleged actions have no direct and obvious connection to the performance of their duties as an MEP, then it decides to waive the immunity, so that court proceedings in the national Member State can continue. If there is suspected political interference or otherwise, then a negative vote may be tabled. However, as there was no such suspicion, I voted in favour of this report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to abstain on this matter, as I believe that this is a matter for the Polish courts, and this intended prosecution has nothing whatsoever to do with this Member’s parliamentary duties.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I agreed with the rapporteur’s position that the circumstance does not cause political damage to the Member, thus it falls within Article 9 of Protocol No 7 under which immunity can be waived if there is no serious damage to the position of Mr Korwin-Mikke.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Rapporteur Evelyn Regner calls on the European Parliament to waive the parliamentary immunity of Polish MEP Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI) following a request from the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland on 13 March 2015. The municipal police claim that Mr Syley is not a member of the Committee on The Korwin-Mikke, driving his car, exceeded the permitted speed limit of 50 km/h by 32 km/h. Since the alleged crime has no direct or obvious connection with the exercise of the duties of a Member of the European Parliament, I voted in favour of waiving parliamentary immunity.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. The alleged offence committed by Mr Korwin-Mikke is not directly related to the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, nor is it an opinion or vote cast in the course of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union. However, I am against interference in the Polish justice system, so I abstained on the lifting of his immunity.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 It is well known that Parliament, in the exercise of its powers relating to privileges and immunities, acts with a view to maintaining its integrity as a democratic legislative assembly and ensuring the independence of its Members in the performance of their duties. Thus, each application is evaluated and, through a specific procedure, immunity is waived and it is for this reason that the decision to waive immunity is taken.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Janusz Korwin-Mikke. On 13 March 2015, the President announced pursuant to Rule 9(1) of the Rules of Procedure that he had received a letter from the Attorney General of Poland requesting the waiver of janusz Korwin-Mikke's parliamentary immunity. Having examined the documents, the Commission decided to submit to the EP the decision to waive immunity, considering that the allegations clearly have no relation to the office of Member of the European Parliament. At the time of the events, Janusz Korwin-Mikke, driving his car in an inhabited area of Piotrków Trybunalski, exceeded the permitted speed limit of 50 km/h by 32 km/h, according to a speed detector located in the area. Furthermore, there is no reason to suppose that there is a fumus persecutionis.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The parliamentary committee responsible for privileges and immunities, after examining the case of the violation of the highway code by the Polish Member, ruled that there was no direct link between the office of Member of Parliament and the offence in question, denying his immunity from the requested judicial procedure. In fact, the action taken by the Member does not constitute a political opinion or a vote expressed in the performance of his duties as a Member of Parliament, but a fact completely unrelated to the exercise of political office. I fully agree with the position of the Audit Committee because the case has been the subject of a thorough and transparent investigative examination which found that there was no specific intention to harm the Member concerned politically. The proceedings brought against him shall be the correct application of national justice.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of the far-right Polish MP Korwin-Mikke, accused of assaulting a Polish official during a meeting. Beyond that I believe that this alleged attack on the physical integrity of a public official should be investigated, I welcome the suspension of Korwin-Mikke's parliamentary immunity given that he must be held accountable for his fascist (the claim that Hitler was not aware of the Holocaust), racist (referring to asylum seekers as "human garbage that does not want to work") or sexist (claiming that the difference between sexual consent and rape is very subtle). Although the procedure for withdrawing parliamentary immunity is not political, since the conviction that the presence of fascist elements such as Korwin-Mikke, which has even made the Nazi salute in the Chamber, is intolerable in a democratic institution, I have certainly voted in favour of the proposal to withdraw its parliamentary immunity.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I can only oppose the lifting of parliamentary immunity if there are obvious political persecutions and cases of repression of intellectual freedom. In this case, Mr Korwin-Mikke is being prosecuted for speeding in Poland, a procedure which is clearly not intended to interfere with his political activity. That is why I voted in favour of lifting his parliamentary immunity.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are against parliamentary privileges that promote discrimination but also that foster two-speed justice. Everyone must be equal in the face of the law.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution so that the Member in question could defend himself before the courts of his country.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are against discriminatory parliamentary privileges that lead to two-speed justice. Everyone must be equal against the law. I am voting in favour of the request for the waiver of Janusz Korwin-Mikke's parliamentary immunity.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Considering the fact that the alleged offence does not have a direct or obvious connection with Mr Korwin-Mikke’s performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, and that in this case Parliament has found no evidence of ‘fumus persecutionis’, I am in favour of waiving the parliamentary immunity of Janusz Korwin-Mikke.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal and agree that the parliamentary immunity of Janusz Korwin-Mikke should be waived.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. The immunity of Members of the European Parliament is limited. It was certainly not created to rid them of the consequences of a breach of the road traffic code. That is why today I am voting in favour of the rapporteur's recommendation to lift immunity in this particular case.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support the Committee on Legal Affairs’ recommendation that Parliament should waive the parliamentary immunity of Mr Janusz Korwin-Mikke.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒I voted for a proposal for a decision by the European Parliament on a request to lift the immunity of Janusz Korwin-Mikke, on the part that this case is an alleged criminal offence which is clearly not related to the performance of the function of a Member of the European Parliament or to the expression of an opinion or a vote in the performance of that office. Accordingly, I support the waiver of immunity and the easy of the initiated legal proceedings.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Parliament is to vote on Janusz Korwin-Mikke's request to lift parliamentary immunity. He is suspected of having committed an offence for exceeding the maximum speed allowed in the town of Piotrk-w Trybunalski in Poland. The alleged offence is not directly or obviously related to the exercise of his mandate as a Member of the European Parliament and does not constitute an opinion or vote cast in the course of his duties as a Member of Parliament. As a French politician, mayor and Member of the European Parliament, I have always been of the view that those who perform public office should behave irreproachably. If this is not the case, they must go to court.  So I voted for this proposal for a decision.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Evelyn Regner's report on Janusz Korwin-Mikke's request for the lifting of parliamentary immunity. This procedure is a formality which, without deciding on the merits of the case, is intended to enable the judicial authorities to carry out their investigative work. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. The Polish Attorney General has requested the lifting of MP Janusz Korwin-Mikke's immunity for a traffic violation. This was not part of his activities as a Member of Parliament and, in order for the Polish judiciary to investigate, I voted in favour of lifting immunity

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of waiving Mr Mikke's immunity so that the authorities can punish a traffic offence. Failure to prosecute could seriously damage Parliament's credibility and integrity.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request as I agree with the reasons in the proposal to waive immunity.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. The alleged offence is the speed limit in an agglomeration. The municipal police claim that on 6 September 2014, while driving his car in Piotrk-w Trybunalski, Mr. Korwin-Mikke exceeded by 32 km/h the maximum speed allowed in an agglomeration, or 50 km/h, as was observed by a radar located in the area in question.  Considering that the alleged offence is not directly or obviously related to Mr Korwin-Mikke's exercise of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, that it does not constitute an opinion or vote cast in the context of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union, that in this case Parliament could not establish that there was fumus persecutionis, that is, a sufficiently serious presumption and specifies that the proceedings were initiated with the intention of harming the member's political activity, we voted to waive his immunity.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted to waive Mr Korwin-Mikke's immunity because it is a matter of prosecuting him for a traffic offence. It has nothing to do with his parliamentary mandate.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report establishing the suspension of the MEP's immunity so that proceedings can be brought against him for speeding. On the other hand, JURI has seen no indication that there is a purpose of causing political harm to the Member.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of the far-right Polish MP Korwin-Mikke, accused of assaulting a Polish official during a meeting. Beyond that I believe that this alleged attack on the physical integrity of a public official should be investigated, I welcome the suspension of Korwin-Mikke's parliamentary immunity given that he must be held accountable for his fascist (the claim that Hitler was not aware of the Holocaust), racist (referring to asylum seekers as "human garbage that does not want to work") or sexist (claiming that the difference between sexual consent and rape is very subtle). Although the procedure for withdrawing parliamentary immunity is not political, since the conviction that the presence of fascist elements such as Korwin-Mikke, which has even made the Nazi salute in the Chamber, is intolerable in a democratic institution, I have certainly voted in favour of the proposal to withdraw its parliamentary immunity.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Mep Janusz Korwin-Mikke is an independent Polish member of the European Parliament and a member of the Committee on Foreign Affairs and a member of the Delegation for Relations with the People's Republic of China. The Deputy Attorney General of the Republic of Poland forwarded a request by the head of the municipal police of piotrków Trybunalski for bringing a case against Representative Korwin-Mikke, for the alleged offence of exceeding the permitted speed in a populated area. I support MP Evelyn Regner's report and the decision based on the Opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs to lift the Immunity of an MP, as there is no doubt that the procedure will harm his political activity in Parliament.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I like the practice of the European Parliament that, if only suspected, a Member must stand before the judicial system. I voted in favour because I'm sure Temid will cope.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on Janusz Korwin-Mikke's request for waiver of immunity, following the positive recommendation of the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this waiver of parliamentary immunity. This is requested so that Mr. Korwin-Mikke can be tried for speeding in his home country. As this offence is unrelated to his exercise as a Member of Parliament, we recognize that he can be prosecuted for this and therefore we ask that he be waived for immunity.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support the Committee on Legal Affairs’ recommendation that Parliament should waive the parliamentary immunity of Mr Janusz Korwin-Mikke.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the request for the waiver of Mr Korwin-Mikke's immunity because I believe that parliamentary immunity is not a personal privilege of a Member but a guarantee of the independence of Parliament and its Members as a super partes institution. I remain convinced that a guarantee line must be followed in these cases, so I will continue to vote against this type of report in defence of the institutional role conferred by this Parliament.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although Members of the European Parliament normally enjoy immunity, it is in any case possible to waive these privileges, at a time when the crime committed is not linked to the performance of the person's public functions. In the present case, I consider it appropriate to bring proceedings against Korwin-Mikke, who is accused of exceeding the legal speed limit, driving his car. That is why I have decided to support this report, which calls for the waiver of his parliamentary immunity.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of waiving Mr Mikke's immunity, as the speeding offence itself is not linked to the political or parliamentary activities of the Member. I cannot judge whether the Prosecutor General of Poland is also addressing other traffic offenders to the same extent.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report calls for the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of Polish far-right MP Janusz Korwin—Mikke. On 6 September 2014, while driving his car in Piotrk-w Trybunalski, Mr. Korwin-Mikke exceeded the maximum speed limit in an agglomeration, 50 km/h, by 32 km/h. This behaviour constitutes an offence within the meaning of Article 92a of the Polish Law of 20 May 1971 establishing the Code of Offences, in connection with Article 20, paragraph 1, of the Polish Law of 20 June 1997 on road traffic. A decision by the European Parliament is needed for the action against Mr Korwin-Mikke to continue. Given that even though Mr Korwin-Mikke was already a Member of the European Parliament at the time of the events, the alleged offence and the subsequent prosecutions are clearly unrelated to his mandate as an MEP, I am voting to lift this immunity.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Parliament must vote on Janusz Korwin-Mikke's request to lift his parliamentary immunity. He is suspected of having committed an offence for exceeding the maximum speed allowed in the town of Piotrk-w Trybunalski in Poland.  The alleged offence is not directly or obviously related to the exercise of his mandate as a Member of the European Parliament and does not constitute an opinion or vote cast in the course of his duties as a Member of Parliament. I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The defence of the independence of the Mandate of the European Parliament is the responsibility of the European Parliament and that independence cannot be called into question. In accordance with Article 8 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, members of the European Parliament may not be sought, detained or persecuted for the opinions or votes cast in the performance of their duties. The Attorney General of the Republic of Poland transmitted an application for authorisation from the Head of the Municipal Police of Piotrków Trybunalski to file a legal action against a Member of the European Parliament, Janusz Korwin-Mikke, for breach of Article 92a of the Law of 20 May 1971, establishing a Code of Offences relating to Article 20(1) of the Road Code of 20 June 1997 , whereas, in particular, the alleged infringement concerns the overtaking of the maximum speed limit allowed in a built-up area.  The alleged acts do not have a direct or obvious link with janusz Korwin-Mikke's performance of the duties of Member of the European Parliament. I therefore voted in favour of the lifting of parliamentary immunity.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report requesting the waiver of the immunity of Janusz Korwin-Mikke, Member of the European Parliament, who exceeded the permitted speed limit of 50 km/h by 32 km/h according to a speed camera located in that area. This conduct constitutes an offence under Article 92a of the Polish Act of 20 May 1971 establishing a Code of Offences in connection with Article 20(1) of the Polish Road Traffic Act of 20 June 1997. At the plenary sitting on 15 April 2015, the President announced, under Rule 9(1) of the Rules of Procedure, that he had received a letter from the Prosecutor-General of the Republic of Poland requesting the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Janusz Korwin-Mikke.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Polish police suspect that Janusz Korwin-Mikke, a Polish Member of the European Parliament, committed an offence by significantly exceeding the maximum speed permitted in a populated area by driving his own car on 6 September 2014. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's consent to the suspension of the Member's immunity in a particular case, thereby allowing the authorities of the Republic of Poland to take legal action against the Member.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. Mr. Korwin-Mikke's request to waive his immunity, which follows a speeding offence, is not related to the Mp's political action. Therefore, the elected representatives of the French delegation of the ENF group voted in favour.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deserves my vote in favour, after all the legal procedures required have elapsed, because the offence in question is in no way related to the performance of the duties of a Member and that there is no evidence or suspicion that, at the origin of the criminal proceedings, the intention to harm the Member concerned is politically impaired.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns the request for the lifting of parliamentary immunity by the non-registered Polish MP Janusz Korwin-Mikke.  The facts alleged against Mr Korwin-Mikke relate to a traffic offence, namely a speeding offence in the town of Piotrk-w Trybunalski of 32km/h. The Prosecutor of the Republic of Poland has requested permission to prosecute Mr Korwin-Mikke.  Noting that the alleged offence is not related to the office and activities of Mr.M Korwin-Mikke as a Member of Parliament, nor with a political opinion expressed by him, I voted to waive immunity.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting Janusz Korwin-Mikke's parliamentary immunity. Any request made to the President of the European Parliament by the authorities of a Member State to waive a Member's immunity is heard by the relevant parliamentary committee. I voted in accordance with the opinion of this committee.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report according to its resolution and analysis.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the Polish State's request for the waiver of immunity.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the request by the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland regarding the waiver of The Honourable Member's parliamentary immunity, i.e. the request by the Public Prosecutor of the Republic of Poland for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Syp/ Janusz Korwin-Mikke, I have analysed Articles 8 and 9 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union; I have also seen the EP Regulation on the waiver of immunity, considering the application of Article 9 on procedures to be of particular importance. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns a request to waive the parliamentary immunity of Janusz Korwin-Mikke, a non-registered Polish MP. The alleged offence against Mr. Korwin-Mikke is the speed limit in the town of Piotrk-w Trybunalski of 32km/h. The Prosecutor of the Republic of Poland has requested permission to prosecute Mr. Korwin-Mikke.  I voted in favour of lifting immunity, since the alleged offence is not directly related to Mr Korwin-Mikke's duties in the European Parliament, that this does not concern a political opinion expressed by Mr Korwin-Mikke and that the procedure initiated does not seek to interfere with the political activity of the Member.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I respect the rapporteur's recommendation because, although the offence committed and the legal process are not related to the opinion expressed or the vote to serve as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of the EIA, it is not possible for the rapporteur to be able to do so. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union and the alleged offence is clearly not in any connection with the performance of the duties of colleague Korwin-Mikke as a Member of the European Parliament, there is no reason to assume, i.e. serious and reasonable enough suspicion, that the proceedings were initiated with the intention of causing political harm to the Member concerned (fumus persecutionis).

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 13 March 2015, the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland forwarded to the President of Parliament the request made by the Chief of the Municipal Police of Piotrków Trybunalski, on 9 March 2015, to grant authorisation to initiate legal proceedings against Mr Söderman. Janusz Korwin-Mikke. The reason for this request would be a high speeding while driving a car. Pursuant to Rule 9(3) of the Rules of Procedure, the Committee on Legal Affairs recommends that the European Parliament waive the parliamentary immunity of Mr Sleyn. Janusz Korwin-Mikke. I voted in favour of waiving immunity so that the Polish authorities can proceed with the verification of whether or not the traffic code has been breached.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the request to waive parliamentary immunity in order to allow the police and judicial forces to carry out their respective investigations.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. – (PT) I voted in favour of considering that the statement of reasons justifies the waiver of immunity.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a matter of Polish internal justice, unrelated to the status of Mr Janusz Korwin—Mikke.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of suspending the immunity of Mr Janusz Korwin-Mikke so that proceedings against him for speeding can be brought. The charges against him do not concern the functions of Member of the European Parliament and there is no evidence of fumus persecutionis, that is to say, a sufficiently strong and precise suspicion that the matter has arisen with the intention of causing political harm to the Member, so parliamentary immunity must be suspended

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted to lift Mr Janusz Korwin-Mikke's immunity, so that the Polish justice system can carry out its work, with strict respect for the rights of the defence, considering that the alleged facts - Mr Korwin-Mikke has exceeded by car by 32 km/h the maximum speed allowed in an agglomeration, i.e. 50 km/h - have nothing to do with the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament and are not motivated by the desire to harm the political action of the Member.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. We are facing a request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of a member of the European Parliament, which follows a request from a judicial authority to file a judicial appeal against him in connection with infringements of the Road Code. It has been found that the alleged acts are not directly related to the performance of their parliamentary duties, nor is there even a presumption that the case has been brought for political reasons, which is why I endorse the position sufqued in this decision and voted in favour of the request for the waiver of Janusz Korwin-Mikke's parliamentary immunity.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of the far-right Polish MP Korwin-Mikke, accused of assaulting a Polish official during a meeting. Beyond that I believe that this alleged attack on the physical integrity of a public official should be investigated, I welcome the suspension of Korwin-Mikke's parliamentary immunity given that he must be held accountable for his fascist (the claim that Hitler was not aware of the Holocaust), racist (referring to asylum seekers as "human garbage that does not want to work") or sexist (claiming that the difference between sexual consent and rape is very subtle). Although the procedure for withdrawing parliamentary immunity is not political, since the conviction that the presence of fascist elements such as Korwin-Mikke, which has even made the Nazi salute in the Chamber, is intolerable in a democratic institution, I have certainly voted in favour of the proposal to withdraw its parliamentary immunity.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal because I agree with the decision of the Committee on Legal Affairs on this matter and that Janusz Korwin-Mikke have his parliamentary immunity waived.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support this report because the alleged work is in no way linked to the function of a Member of the European Parliament, and there are no grounds on which it can be assumed that the aim of the procedure is to harm the political activity of members.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Representative Janusz Korwin-Mikke was spotted driving while exceeding the maximum permitted speed on Polish national roads, which was confirmed by conducting a satisfactory police investigation and using recognition techniques. Given that the report clearly underlines the lack of a link between janusz korwin-mikke's parliamentary mandate and that incident, and that there is no reasonable doubt that the proceedings were initiated due to a difference in ideological assumptions or for the purpose of causing irreversible political damage to the Member, I support the report on the waiver of the immunity of Janusz Korwin-Mikke in accordance with the request of the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland and on the orders of the Head of the Municipal Police of piotrkow Tryybunalski.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal as Janusz Korwin-Mikke's actions were not related to the exercise of his mandate as a Member of the European Parliament and should therefore be properly investigated.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 MEPs should be held to account in court when the need to investigate their activities is required, in accordance with existing legal procedures.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request by the Prosecutor-General of Poland to waive the parliamentary immunity of Janusz Korwin-Mikke.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a request to lift the immunity of Polish MEP Janusz Korwin-Mikke who allegedly committed an offence related to exceeding the permitted speed in a populated area.  According to the protocol on the privileges and immunies of the European Union, Members of the European Parliament may not be subject to any form of questioning, detention or judicial proceedings due to expressed opinions or voting in the performance of their duties, and on the territory of their state they must enjoy immunity recognised by members of parliament of that State and only the European Parliament can decide whether their immunity will be lifted in that case.  Since the alleged offence is not directly or manifestly linked to the performance of the duties of a Member of the European Parliament, I consider that there is no reason to assume that the proceedings were initiated with the intention of causing political harm to the Member concerned.  In addition, municipal police allege that the camera recorded that the Representative of Korwin-Mikka on September 6, 2014 exceeded a limited speed of 50 km/h with his vehicle and was driving at 82 km/h.  In my view, those claims are sufficient to lift the member's immunity and to allow him or her a fair and impartial trial.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 On the basis of all the documents of the Committee on Legal Affairs, I supported the report on the request for waiver of the immunity of Janusz Korwin-Mikke.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of waiving the immunity as the alleged offence refers to exceeding the permitted speed limit in a built-up area and does not constitute an opinion expressed or a vote cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. 'Mr Janusz Korwin-Mikke is accused of driving a speeding vehicle in a residential area in Piotrków Trybunalski on 6 September 2014. According to police records, it was driving at 82 km/h when the permitted speed is 50 km/h. Such conduct constitutes an infringement under Article 92a of Polish law. In addition to the vehicle being registered in the name of the Deputy, the police allege that the facial image of the driver, visible in the photograph recorded by the speed recording camera, corresponds to the facial image of the Member. The alleged acts do not have a direct or obvious link with the exercise of the duties of a Member of the EP, nor do they constitute opinions or votes expressed in the performance of their duties as a Member of the EP. We voted in favour of lifting parliamentary immunity.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of waiving Mr Mikke's immunity, as the speeding offence itself is not linked to the political or parliamentary activities of the Member. I cannot judge whether the Prosecutor General of Poland is also addressing other traffic offenders to the same extent.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report focuses on the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Janusz Korwin-Mikke transmitted by the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland to the European Parliament on 13 March 2015. The deputy is accused of driving a speeding vehicle in a residential area in Piotrków Trybunalski on 6 September 2014. According to police records, it was driving at 82 km/h when the permitted speed is 50 km/h. Such conduct constitutes an infringement under Article 92a of Polish law. In addition to the vehicle being registered in the name of the Deputy, the police allege that the facial image of the driver, visible in the photograph recorded by the speed recording camera, corresponds to the facial image of the Member. The alleged acts do not have a direct or obvious link with the exercise of the duties of a Member of the EP, nor do they constitute opinions or votes expressed in the performance of their duties as a Member of the EP. We voted in favour of lifting parliamentary immunity.

name: Morten Messerschmidt (ECR).
text: Mr President! The fact that all Member States comply with the rules is a fundamental requirement for any cooperation, not least as integrated cooperation as the European Union. We just have to note that, particularly in the area of agricultural policy, things are going really, really badly. We are seeing a massive level of fraud, non-compliance, non-compliance with controls, resulting in a huge waste of European, including Danish, tax dollars. It is not only a pity, it is scandalous, especially when it takes place in the very largest budgetary area we have in the EU system, which unfortunately is agricultural aid.  That is why a proper call must be sent out to the Member States – especially those who do not comply with the rules, do not implement on time – and it is made clear that this must have a consequence. It's no good that some countries act as dukse and others as villains. Those who act as dukse might have to rethink their role.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to use my explanation of vote to call on the EU institutions to do more precisely to protect the internal market, of course its free and equal competition, which is often distorted by the import of counterfeit products, goods that are of poor quality and which clearly infringe the right to equal competition. This is undoubtedly the case, but it must be remembered that, in order to protect consumers, it is also important to prosecute those frauds that are linked to this illegal smuggling of goods, and here it is necessary to be cleared to some extent on its own doorstep. This is a question of the functioning of OLAF, which has very long delays in its investigation. I think that significant shifts are needed in this regard and it is important that the next further initiatives are better targeted at the functioning of the EU institutions.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. •u2012 Detecting and preventing customs fraud is important to avoid losses and greater damage to the European peasant. But, as important or more important than this is the regulation itself. The decisions to liberalise, to deregulate, which this Commission, the majority of Parliament and the Council itself have taken lately are highlighting the seriousness of the losses that are being caused in the agricultural sector in our European Union. We must say that today the dairy sector is highlighting this situation with its mobilizations. That is why we think it is very important to implement new regulations, a new agricultural and food policy that gives priority to the domestic market over exports and to the international market and free trade agreements. That is essential and also, of how not, preventing and preventing fraud.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The report, at second reading, believes that the European Commission is the most competent to fight customs fraud effectively. For this reason, the text envisages strengthening the customs union and the internal market, and establishing direct access by EU authorities to information circulating between Member States to enable monitoring of the proper application of customs regulations. Moreover, they would like to regulate the flow of goods to prevent these violations as best they can.  We formally challenge the idea that European bodies are the most effective in combating customs fraud. Since its inception, the internal market has been deregulated and deregulated by free trade advocates. These offences are the result. We consider that the Member States are in the best position to stop these frauds, particularly through customs, whose scope has been extremely limited since the ratification of the Maastricht Treaty.  So I voted for the rejection proposal.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour, in order to reject the Council position and close the procedure.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the Council's position on the correct application of customs and agricultural legislation.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The Internal Market has demonstrated its inability to protect both our producers and consumers, which is why we are calling for the return of national borders and customs regulations, as the nation is the optimal level for rigorous management of goods flows and for an effective fight against customs fraud and infringement. That is why I could not vote in favour of that recommendation.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted to adopt this regulation, which aims to improve the management of customs risks and to strengthen the detection and prevention of customs fraud, so that the internal market is equipped with safe products, accompanied by certificates of authenticity.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Council's position at first reading of the Court of Auditors' opinion and the first-reading position of both Parliament and the Council, as well as the second-reading recommendation of the IMCO Commission in the European Parliament.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This recommendation on the proper application of customs and agricultural regulations should improve the customs union and strengthen the internal market, regulate imports and exports of goods and monitor trade data and claims that the Commission will be more effective in this regard than the Member States.  This vote concerns the amendment to reject the Commission's proposal on this customs union and the centralisation of trade information by a federal body and I therefore voted in favour.  The FN prefers to restore national borders and customs regulations since the EU is now unable to protect its trade or geographical borders.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote on this amendment calling for the Council's position to be rejected because I consider it counterproductive to vote in favour of rejecting the agreement reached between the Council and the European Parliament. For our high-quality production system, the cooperation of the customs authorities of the 28 Member States is very important, especially in sensitive sectors such as agriculture.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation by which Parliament supports the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 515/97 on mutual assistance between the administrative authorities of the Member States in order to improve the identification, investigation and prevention of fraud at customs, by increasing the exchange of information and available data, and by improving the functioning of the established system.  The main development lies in the creation of a new database which will require carriers to provide the Commission with information on the movement of containers to create a central basis for import and export data, and a centralised register for transit-related data.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on Parliament's report amending The 1997 European Parliament and the Council Regulation (EC) No 515/97.  The new regulation introduces improved cooperation between administrative authorities and their cooperation with the Commission in order to ensure the correct application of customs and agricultural legislation throughout the European Union.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the proposed recommendation for second reading amending legislation in the area of mutual assistance between Member States in order to ensure better implementation of customs and agricultural legislation. In my opinion, the amended draft legislation specifically improves the control of the two most exposed areas as regards smuggling, namely tobacco and alcohol. I support the strengthening of institutions at EU level, which must be provided with sufficient resources to effectively enable stronger control, thereby reducing the number of such crimes. This type of action often involved not only criminal groups, but even people who are very close to politics, which, especially in the transitional countries, poses a great danger to the development of democracy. I therefore believe that we must support measures to strengthen the fight against this type of crime, which is based primarily on the exploitation of other people and on criminal association, as it destroys many families as well as leaves major consequences in wider communities.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Since Regulation 515/97 has to change because it shows shortcomings, especially in evading customs duties, I support the course of trilogues so far. The most important element of the dispute - a common database must be carefully interceded. Therefore, I support entering the next round of trilogues.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. The underlying and fully assumed political will to operate the European Union is to establish free trade between the Member States, but also with regard to the rest of the world. This has led capital holders to install production tools in countries with the lowest labour costs and the harshest conditions of employment either within the EU or better outside the EU. Thus they were able to manufacture their products at low cost to sell in developed countries without having the risk of having to pay customs duties. This has led to an acceleration in the industrialization of the BRICS countries and, conversely, an explosion in unemployment in high-cost EU countries. Today, passing on information to the Commission that could make this death system even easier would undoubtedly lead to an increase in unemployment and misery in our countries. That's why I'm voting against it.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The report, at second reading, believes that the European Commission is the most competent to fight customs fraud effectively. For this reason, the text envisages strengthening the customs union and the internal market, and establishing direct access by EU authorities to information circulating between Member States to enable monitoring of the proper application of customs regulations. Moreover, they would like to regulate the flow of goods to prevent these violations as best they can. We formally challenge the idea that European bodies are the most effective in combating customs fraud. Since its inception, the internal market has been deregulated and deregulated by free trade advocates. These offences are the result. We consider that the Member States are in the best position to stop these frauds, particularly through customs, whose scope has been extremely limited since the ratification of the Maastricht Treaty. So I voted for the rejection proposal.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The losses of millions of euros in the EU budget indicate the extent of fraud in the customs system. These losses show us the immediate need for more effective prevention and detection mechanisms at national and European level, precisely in order to reduce the risks of fraud. I believe that we need to focus on simplifying and accelerating anti-fraud mechanisms in a way that avoids unnecessary and repetitive bureaucracy. All this can lead to the strengthening of the internal market and the products circulating within it, thereby guaranteeing consumers a higher level of protection. In order to make actions more efficient, there is also a need for a permanent communication between the customs authorities of each Member State and their communication with the European Commission in order to protect the EU's financial and economic interests. I voted in favour of the Report on the proper application of customs and agricultural legislation, because I believe that the EC initiative to amend this Regulation supports the amendments made by the new Customs Code which aim to simplify and apply customs legislation uniformly and facilitate customs clearance procedures, which will be fully computerised and provide maximum simplifications , as well as improving customs controls.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 For our high-quality production system, customs systems that work together are critical. It would be counterproductive to vote in favour of rejecting the agreement reached between the Council and the EP.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the recommendation for second reading concerning the Council position at first reading with a view to adopting a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 515/97 on mutual assistance between the administrative authorities of the Member States and cooperation between them and the Commission to ensure the correct application of customs and agricultural regulations. I believe that it is vital to facilitate the prevention, detection and repression of the many international operations that violate customs and agricultural regulations. The exchange of information necessary to facilitate joint customs interventions between state administrations and the Commission's Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) must therefore be improved and speeded up.  In this respect, the creation of a new centralised database, accessible by the competent national authorities, is a huge step forward. The database can become an indispensable tool to prevent and combat breaches of customs regulations and to protect the safety of citizens. Therefore, also in the light of the compromise reached between Parliament, the Council and the Commission on the type of data that can be shared, I have decided to vote in favour of the text.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This was a very technical report which was concerned with loopholes in the existing administrative systems for the detection of customs-related fraud of goods and products.  The only roll-call vote in this report was on an amendment put forward by the EFDD. This amendment called for the Council position in the first reading to be rejected. Considering that this is a very draconian action that does more harm than good and does nothing to solve the issue of customs fraud, I voted against this amendment.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal, in order to reject the Council position and close the procedure.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the rejection amendment because I am in favour of the return of national borders and customs regulations which are the effective means for the rigorous management of the flow of goods. Customs remains an effective tool for economic sovereignty and protection, which is now beyond the reach of member states.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Concerns the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the EFDD Group's amendment rejecting the Council's position at first reading and therefore I support this recommendation for second reading. The measure concerns the proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 515/97 with the aim of creating better cooperation between the customs authorities of the Member States and with the European Commission. The main objective is to achieve a more accurate level of transmission of shipping data by economic operators.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because I supported the objective (getting new regulations passed on the detection, investigation and prevention of customs fraud) and the method chosen to achieve it, namely improving the functioning of control systems. I agree, in particular, with the fact that the Commission will be able to request specific data from the Member States to investigate fraud and also with the fact that the report maintains legislation in line with the Treaty of Lisbon on the protection of personal data.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this regulation, which is the result of important work on an issue that is fundamental to strengthening the European internal market. These rules will, in fact, improve the detection, investigation and prevention of customs fraud by increasing the exchange of information and available evidence, making the system more efficient than the current system. This Regulation provides customs agents with new means of verifying whether the declared origin of the goods is consistent with the route taken by the container. Furthermore, The Member States must be able to provide the Commission with the data necessary for the verification of potential fraud, which was not the case before, since the documentation was kept by economic operators. The negotiations have been long and complex, but I believe that today we can be satisfied with the work produced and this legislation, so I congratulate all those who have worked to achieve this result.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. •u2012 Detecting and preventing customs fraud is important to avoid losses and greater damage to the European peasant. But, as important or more important than this is the regulation itself. The decisions to liberalise, to deregulate, which this Commission, the majority of Parliament and the Council itself have taken lately are highlighting the seriousness of the losses that are being caused in the agricultural sector in our European Union. We must say that today the dairy sector is highlighting this situation with its mobilizations. That is why we think it is very important to implement new regulations, a new agricultural and food policy that gives priority to the domestic market over exports and to the international market and free trade agreements. That is essential and also, of how not, preventing and preventing fraud.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the amendment which suggested rejecting the Council position. However I agree with the creation of a new database, which would oblige carriers to supply the Commission with the information on container movements to create a central database for import and export data and to create a centralised repository for transit-related data. I believe in the need to clamp down on customs-related fraud, while safeguarding data protection and trade secrets.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the Commission's proposal on ensuring a balance for the internal market and consumer protection, which aims to simplify and speed up mechanisms to combat customs fraud, thereby avoiding unnecessary and repetitive red tape, with a view to strengthening the security of the internal market, but also of the products circulating within it, thereby guaranteeing a high level of consumer protection.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report aims to strengthen fraud detection and prevention in customs matters by increasing the exchange of information and data between the European Commission and Member States, through a review of the electronic customs system. From now on, the European Commission will be able to request information from Member States for the purposes of a fraud investigation. At the same time, the report strengthens the protection of personal data. Considering that fraud, in general, is an obstacle to the law and that it penalises citizens by reducing the effectiveness of European public policies, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. It is essential to defend the food security of Europeans. That is why I voted in favour of this text, which strengthens customs controls as well as fraud prevention and data exchange at European level. It is essential to engage more at European level to defend our farmers, against fraud, through the proper application of customs regulations.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The proposed report continues the EU's trade and customs logic, which has been in place for several decades. The basic idea of this policy gives a place and efficiency rarely proven however, to the supranational authorities in the control of goods from third countries. However, in addition to the multiple risks of massive imports to the Union and without any real restrictions on domestic and local production, the strengthening of the internal market means the total free movement of goods in the Union. At a time of disturbing innovations such as GMOs or nanotechnology in the food field, such laxity is opposed to the freedom of sovereign nations and their legitimacy in the control of their territory. I therefore voted in favour of the rejection amendment, the only vote proposed.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is customs and agricultural regulations that have created the two-speed EU which is destroying the South for the benefit of the industrialised North. Further deepening these arrangements will 'legitimise' a crime committed against real Europe and Europeans.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the direction of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of the Jaakonsaari report. The European Commission intends to amend Regulation (EC) No 515/97 on customs fraud to make the fight against fraud linked to the payment of duties and taxes more effective by unifying and simplifying the system. The draft significantly accelerates the flow of information between the Commission and the Member States and makes coordinated action against fraud more effective. It also better protects customers' personal data and shortens procedural times and deadlines. The Hungarian Government has already introduced similar measures last year, so it is Hungary positive for the EU to take similar steps.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it is in line with a greater power given to the Commission.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 False declaration fraud increased in 2011 to an annual loss of EUR 100 million. Member States reported 1 905 cases of recorded fraud and other irregularities linked to the miscalculation of goods, representing a loss of EUR 107,7 million. This amount concerns only the loss found by the Member States and the Commission. As information on around 30 000 cases of suspected fraud is not available, the actual scale of the problem is considerably greater. This system urgently needed reform because it became clear that the introduction of e-customs in 2011, in which the background documents on imports and exports are no longer left by customs administrations but by economic operators, has led to delays in investigations conducted by the European Anti-Fraud Office in the customs field, because in order to obtain these documents, OLAF needs the mediation assistance of customs administrations. Although consumer protection is at a very high level in the European Union, it is very important that work is constantly being made to improve it and make it more effective. It is the Union's duty to combat customs fraud. Although it was very difficult to reach an agreement to create a central database for import and export and a centralised repository for data for transit purposes, a compromise was finally reached.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is customs and agricultural regulations that have created the two-speed EU which is destroying the South for the benefit of the industrialised North. Any further deepening of these arrangements will "legitimise" the crime committed against the real Europe and the real Europeans.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Through this report, we will be able to increase the exchange of information and the available evidence, and improve the functioning of the established system. I support the proposal by the Commission to create a new database, which would oblige carriers to supply the Commission with information on container movements, considering the fact that it will include export data, but only of product categories falling under excise duty like tobacco and alcohol, as these are particularly sensitive to fraud. Therefore, it will be in line with our position on data protection and trade secrets.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted against the report on the proper application of customs and agricultural rules. Disclosure of all operational information would be hugely damaging to competition. That would be a step in the wrong direction.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which will ensure a higher level of consumer protection and establish better fraud prevention in the transit system of goods across borders.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. In the fight against infringements of customs legislation, the exchange of information between Member States is essential. Anything that entails improving mutual assistance between the administrative authorities of the Member States and the cooperation between them and the Commission in order to ensure the correct application of customs and agricultural regulations is in favour of me.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the amendment which rejects this report which claims to improve mutual assistance between the administrative authorities of the Member States and between them and the Commission, in order to apply customs and agricultural regulations. This type of assistance cannot replace a return to national borders and customs regulations, which alone would regulate the flow of goods and prevent fraud. In addition, the Commission once again wants to replace member states and claims to be able to fight customs fraud better than they do. It is impossible to believe that the Commission will effectively control the flow of goods, whereas on the contrary it is committed to opening our borders to imports, even when they present social, health and environmental risks.  Customs and agricultural assistance can only be seen in a Europe where Member States have regained control of their borders.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against rejecting the Council's position, since it is a legislative proposal which aims to improve customs management and risk management, strengthen the detection and prevention of fraud related to customs management, simplify and accelerate mechanisms to combat customs fraud and avoid unnecessary and repetitive bureaucracy. While the creation of multiple databases is necessary, the use and security of databases should be guaranteed as is the case in the proposal: "(...) respect and ensure the confidential processing of information." Preventing fraud and combating corruption is one of the axes of Podemos and we therefore support this legislative proposal, which also involves the cooperation of all Member States.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal, as it will ensure a higher level of consumer protection and establish better fraud prevention in combating practices in the transit system of goods across borders.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ During the second reading regarding the correct application of the law on customs and agricultural matters, I voted against the proposal to reject the Council position. If we want to achieve the goal of the single market, then customs union is a necessary attribute. Moreover, national customs authorities should collaborate in order to ensure legal and protected flows of goods in and out of Europe.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ This legislation will help strengthen the security of products circulating within the EU and will contribute to the fight against fraud and tax evasion. I am therefore able to support the outcome.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against rejecting the text, since it is a legislative proposal that aims to improve customs management and risk management, strengthen the detection and prevention of fraud related to customs management, simplify and accelerate mechanisms to combat customs fraud and avoid unnecessary and repetitive bureaucracy. While the creation of multiple databases is necessary, the use and security of databases should be guaranteed as is the case in the proposal: "(...) respect and ensure the confidential processing of information." Preventing fraud and combating corruption is one of the axes of Podemos and we therefore support this legislative proposal, which also involves the cooperation of all Member States.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt a regulation by Parliament and the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 2012/2013; 515/97 on the mutual assistance of Member States' administrative authorities and on the cooperation of the latter with the Commission in order to ensure the proper application of customs and agricultural regulations, as I consider that synergies and better cooperation between Member States' administrative authorities contribute to a more efficient and correct implementation of the rules, especially in sensitive areas such as agriculture and customs issues.  Cooperation with the European Commission further strengthens efficiency and ensures consistency in the application of the rules. I therefore support the acceptance of the Council's position at first reading in order to allow the continuation of the work started on this issue.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The report, at second reading, believes that the European Commission is the most competent to fight customs fraud effectively. For this reason, the text envisages strengthening the customs union and the internal market, and establishing direct access by EU authorities to information circulating between Member States to enable monitoring of the proper application of customs regulations. Moreover, they would like to regulate the flow of goods to prevent these violations as best they can. We formally challenge the idea that European bodies are the most effective in combating customs fraud. Since its inception, the internal market has been deregulated and deregulated by free trade advocates. These offences are the result. We consider that the Member States are in the best position to stop these frauds, particularly through customs, whose scope has been extremely limited since the ratification of the Maastricht Treaty. So I voted for the rejection proposal.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on mutual assistance between the administrative authorities of the Member States and the cooperation between them and the Commission in order to ensure the proper application of customs and agricultural regulations.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of the EFDD's proposal to reject the Council's position, as the original report contains a direct right of action by the Commission against private companies, which amounts to a further curtailment of national competences.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal, as it will ensure a higher level of consumer protection and establish better fraud prevention in combating practices in the transit system of goods across borders.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. The report in this second reading claims: - Improving the Customs Union and strengthening the internal market - Regulating the inflows and exits of goods and preventing infringements and fraud - Establishing direct access by EU authorities to information circulating between Member States to enable monitoring of the proper application of customs regulations - Monitoring trade data on imports and exports and the transit of goods - That the Commission will be more effective than the whole Of Member States anticipating and preventing customs fraud. We call for the return of borders and national customs regulations, which is the optimal level for rigorous management of goods flows and for an effective fight against customs fraud and infringement.  It is worth remembering that the European Union's space is no longer protected at its borders, whether commercial or geographical. The market is deregulated and the territory is wide open.  Customs remains an effective tool of economic sovereignty and protection that is now beyond the control of member states.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal amending Regulation (EC) No 515/97 on mutual assistance between national authorities in order to combat customs fraud, increasing the exchange of information and available data, and improving the functioning of the system.  What is interesting about the proposal is the creation of a new database that will force carriers to provide the Commission with information on the movement of containers and thus create a database and create a centralised register for transit-related data.  The commitment reached also includes export data, but only in the product categories covered by excise taxes, as these are particularly sensitive to fraud. These products include especially tobacco and alcohol.  In addition, the alignment of the terminology of customs legislation and the improvement of competences for OLAF is also interesting.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. •u2012 Detecting and preventing customs fraud is important to avoid losses and greater damage to the European peasant. But, as important or more important than this is the regulation itself. The decisions to liberalise, to deregulate, which this Commission, the majority of Parliament and the Council itself have taken lately are highlighting the seriousness of the losses that are being caused in the agricultural sector in our European Union. We must say that today the dairy sector is highlighting this situation with its mobilizations. That is why we think it is very important to implement new regulations, a new agricultural and food policy that gives priority to the domestic market over exports and to the international market and free trade agreements. That is essential and also, of how not, preventing and preventing fraud.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Incorrect application of legislation or even mistreation of legislation can lead to trade difficulties. The agricultural aspect is particularly important in the context of Russian counter-sanctions, as European and Latvian farmers must look for new markets, including external ones, and cannot allow agricultural farms to go bankrupt. I voted in favour.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Customs fraud linked to the incorrect declaration of the country of origin represents a loss of EUR 100 million per year for the EU. The proposed Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 515/97 on mutual assistance between the administrative authorities of the Member States and on cooperation between the administrative authorities of the Member States and the Commission in ensuring the proper application of the rules on customs and agricultural matters will contribute to the detection of customs fraud, while reducing the bureaucratic complexity to date. The consistent application of these measures by both the EU and the Member States will, in addition to the economic effect, also increase consumer protection.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. this Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly. for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 8/9/2015 and why the European Union must protect Greek farmers and livestock farmers from the Memorandum and fight with determination the great "Greekisations" of oil and lambs from countries such as Tunisia and Skopje respectively.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the amendment to reject this text, which aims to strengthen the internal market of the EEC by strengthening the Commission's powers to manage and anticipate the prevention of customs fraud. Indeed, each country's customs remain the most relevant level to effectively combat fraud and customs offences. It is therefore inconsistent to give more power to the Commission, which is responsible for this deregulated and unprotected market.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. "U2012 My vote in favour of the draft for the amendment of the Regulation regulating mutual assistance between the administrative authorities of the Member States and cooperation between them and the Commission in order to ensure the correct application of customs and agricultural regulations. Unfortunately, we have so far had some precedents, as with imports of tomatoes from Morocco, which tell us that we have to be very vigilant.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. As this report is a long way from the original Council position (a direct right of action by the Commission against private companies and further curtailment of national competences), I voted in favour of this report.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal for mutual assistance between the administrative authorities of the Member States and cooperation between the latter and the Commission to ensure the correct application of the law on customs and agricultural matters.
