name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as the agreement should improve the detection of fraud in fuel laundering and tobacco products which damages Member State budgets.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The purpose of this text is to adapt a 1997 regulation to make the means to combat customs fraud more effective, particularly in the areas of origin and misrepresentation of import or export transactions. However, the stated objective of strengthening anti-fraud means is largely incompatible with the Commission's foreign and customs trade policy. Moreover, the new EU customs code (Customs Programme 2020) continues to place fluidisation and market penetration as the EU's first objectives. This pushes customs to limit the downtime of goods at the border to a minimum (today about 4 minutes, knowing that less than 1% of containers are checked). While the scheme proposes to strengthen the means to combat customs fraud, it fits very well into the liberal logic of the EU. The new means focus on strengthening risk analysis and reserve a very limited place for physical control. This whole text is hypocrisy to justify the sieve state of borders. I abstain so as not to encourage the current situation.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The report, at second reading, believes that the European Commission is the most competent to fight customs fraud effectively. For this reason, the text envisages strengthening the customs union and the internal market, and establishing direct access by EU authorities to information circulating between Member States to enable monitoring of the proper application of customs regulations. Moreover, they would like to regulate the flow of goods to prevent these violations as best they can. We formally challenge the idea that European bodies are the most effective in combating customs fraud. Since its inception, the internal market has been deregulated and deregulated by free trade advocates. These offences are the result. We consider that the Member States are in the best position to stop these frauds, particularly through customs, whose scope has been extremely limited since the ratification of the Maastricht Treaty. I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Action against violations of customs regulations is essential for the protection of the Union's financial interests and the development of customs cooperation. Customs regulations may be infringed by various practices such as misleading description of imported goods, to take advantage of duty reduction, misleading declaration of the origin of goods, to circumvent anti-dumping duties and/or to avoid quantitative limitations or import quotas, or misuse of the transit procedure, where the goods actually imported are declared in transit to avoid the applicable customs duties. We have to avoid these practices; hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this proposal to reject the Council’s position because I support negotiations advancing to a further stage.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of the second reading report on the Commission proposal that amends Regulation (EC) No 515/97 on mutual assistance between national authorities so as to improve the detection, investigation and prevention of customs-related fraud by increasing the exchange of information and the available evidence, and improving the functioning of the established system. The main innovation of the Commission proposal was to create a new database, which would oblige carriers to supply the Commission with information on container movements, to create a central database for import and export data, and to create a centralised repository for transit-related data. The creation of the aforementioned databases proved to be the most controversial point due to data protection and trade secrets concerns on Parliament’s side. In its first reading position, Parliament suggested only that import and transit data should be included in the databases, while the Council and the Commission wanted to include all data. A compromise was found to include export data too, but only of product categories falling under excise duty, as these are particularly sensitive to fraud. These products include especially tobacco and alcohol.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament discussed at second reading the draft Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 515/97. I voted in favour of a proposal for the amendment to enter into force in accordance with the agreed decision of the competent committee of the European Parliament by a large majority.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Currently customs agents do not have mechanisms to ascertain whether the declared origin of the goods is in accordance with the route of the container concerned and there is misuse of the transit procedure which is monitored through documentary and visual controls which have a limited scope.  I would like to highlight that the false declarations of origin represent an annual loss of EUR 100 million for the EU and, as regards the misleading description of the products transported, the losses reported by the Member States in 2011 were around EUR 107.7 million. I stress the importance of speeding up mechanisms to combat customs fraud and to avoid bureaucracy, ensuring that the security of the internal market and the products circulating in it is strengthened, while also ensuring greater protection for consumers.  I would point out that, having been diagnosed with some shortcomings in the e-Customs system, it is essential to change it with a view to a faster and less bureaucratic process.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This recommendation on the proper implementation of customs and agricultural regulations envisages improving the Customs Union and strengthening the internal market, as well as regulating imports and exports of goods and controlling trade data. It concludes that the Commission will be more effective in this regard than the Member States.  However, this vote relates to the amendment to reject the Commission's proposal on the Customs Union and the centralisation of trade information by a federal body. Considering that ENL MEPs prefer to restore national borders and customs regulations since the EU is now unable to protect its trade or geographical borders, I have decided to vote in favour of this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it will ensure a higher level of consumer protection and establish better fraud prevention in combating practices in the transit system of goods across borders.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which strengthens the capacity of the Union and the Member States to combat customs fraud by developing information exchange and focusing on new technologies. This includes modernizing the anti-fraud information system (AFIS) and the procedures for exchanging messages relating to the status of cargo containers. The package of measures voted represents an investment of 60 million euros over the period 2014-2020.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are today giving our whole strong support, having assessed its full compliance, to the Council's position at first reading which, by amending the regulation on mutual assistance between the administrative authorities of the Member States, intends to ensure the necessary and indispensable correct application of customs and agricultural regulations.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this proposal to reject the Council’s position.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report in my vote today because it is in line with the Council's position and thus concludes the legislative codecision procedure whereby customs and agricultural legislation has been changed to meet the new challenges that have arisen at EU level. It is essential that the institutions of the Member States work together and be able to use the evidence obtained by the partner authorities to punish those who commit illegalities in customs transport. The traceability of goods and the control of authorities on products entering and leaving eu territory is an additional tool for combating illegal trafficking and tax evasion. It is also very important that all these procedures provide companies and citizens with the security of the information collected and a bureaucracy as supple as possible.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the proposal to reject the Council's position.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – In order to ensure the correct application of customs and agricultural legislation, particular attention must be paid to assistance between the administrative authorities of the Member States and cooperation between them and the Commission. In addition, it is essential that gaps in existing customs fraud detection systems and delays in OLAF investigations are addressed. Administrative and criminal procedures in cases of criminal offences must continue to be strengthened at EU level. It should be noted that data protection supervision needs to be simplified and the possibility of limiting the visibility of data and the conditions for admissibility of evidence collected through peer-to-peer channels should be clarified. It should be noted that the Commission is empowered to adopt implementing acts, but that Member States should have the same access to the container status notification register as the Commission.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the rapporteur's work and position and thanking him for what he has done, I have decided to vote against it.

name: Ева Паунова (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report on ensuring the correct application of legislation in the field of customs and agricultural matters, as I find the optimisation of systems, the use of innovation and the exchange of information and expertise between Member States' administrations the most correct means in combating smuggling and customs fraud. New technologies are moving our world forward and we need to link our public administrations and customs to them as effectively as possible and be more easily accessible and transparent to European citizens.  Bulgaria's national government has already taken this right direction and I hope the EU will support and facilitate the bringing to an end this much-needed process.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Internal Market and Consumer Protection Committee adopted by a large majority of votes the Recommendation subject to this vote, and when adopting the draft legislative resolution, the Council's position at first reading was also taken into account.  The recommendation for a second reading on the Council's position with a view to adopting a new regulation on mutual assistance of Member States' administrative authorities and their cooperation with the Commission to ensure the proper application of the rules on customs and agricultural matters has taken a step closer to the final adoption of a new regulation which will hopefully avoid situations such as incorrect labelling of the origin of the product, incorrect labelling of the composition of the product or manipulation in its transport.  Unfortunately, we have often witnessed such criminal activities when importing agricultural products into Croatia, especially milk, meat, fruits and vegetables, and this needs to be put to an end. I believe that the new regulation will offer exactly that and I call on all parties involved to adopt it as soon as possible.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This recommendation on the proper application of customs and agricultural regulations should improve the customs union and strengthen the internal market, regulate imports and exports of goods and monitor trade data and claims that the Commission will be more effective in this regard than the Member States.  This vote concerns the amendment to reject the Commission's proposal on this Customs Union and the centralisation of trade information by a federal body and I therefore voted in favour.  The FN prefers to restore national borders and customs regulations since the EU is now unable to protect its trade or geographical borders.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support my colleague Jaakonsaari's report taking into account the Council's position at first reading, the Court of Auditors' opinion of 25 February 2014(1), the position at first reading on the Commission proposal addressed to the European Parliament and the Council, Article 294(7) of the CST. Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, Article 76 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union Rules of Procedure, and a recommendation for a second reading of the Internal Market and Consumer Protection Committee (A8-0234/2015) which accepts the Council's position at first reading. I am pleased that, in the end, a compromise was reached and that Parliament's position was adopted, which will store import data on those products which are particularly susceptible to fraud in a specific database, taking into account the fundamental principles on data protection rights and privacy. We need more effective cooperation between national institutions, OLAF and the European Institutions to stop fraud related to imports of agricultural products into the European Union as much as possible, which this report also underlines correctly.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In the face of the intensity of global and intra-European agricultural trade, it is important to ensure that customs and agricultural regulations are properly enforced and respected. The European Parliament is currently analysing the Council's position and is expected to reach agreement on this text. I voted against the Jaakonsaari report, which rejected the Council's position.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted against it because I disagree with the position taken by the Council.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. With the development of international trade, customs fraud has grown in recent years. Fraud related to misrepresentation of the origin of the products alone represents an annual loss of 100 million euros. This scourge has a considerable negative economic impact on European businesses and the Community budget, and also poses health risks for our consumers. To be effective, the fight against this grey economy must involve the rapid exchange of information. Delays in the investigations of the European Anti-Fraud Office, resulting in large losses, relate to customs debts with prescriptions, show us that the current working method is not fast enough. This new regulation, adopted by a large majority by the European Parliament, aims precisely to give national and European authorities efficient and reliable tools to access and contribute in real time to a secure flow of information. This modernisation of cooperation between Member States will improve the fight against customs fraud but will also speed up the implementation of electronic customs, with its positive impact on the competitiveness of European businesses.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation, by which Parliament supports the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 515/97 on mutual assistance between national authorities in order to improve the identification, investigation and prevention of fraud at customs, by increasing the exchange of information and available data, and by improving the functioning of the established system.  The main development lies in the creation of a new database that will require carriers to provide the Commission with information on the movement of containers to create a central basis for import and export data and to create a centralized register for transit-related data.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation on mutual assistance between the administrative authorities of the Member States, which aims at better collaboration between them to better ensure the proper enforcement of customs and agricultural regulations within the Member States.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission proposes to amend Regulation (EC) No 515/97 with the purpose of improving the detection, investigation and prevention of customs fraud by increasing the exchange of information and available evidence. More cooperation and more action is required in this area, in particular as regards the creation of conditions for a better fight against customs fraud, particularly related to the incorrect declaration of the origin of goods and the abusive practices carried out in the transit system. I believe that the options presented are in line with fundamental rights and will not only allow for a stronger legal framework, but also to increase the exchange of information on container movements and transit, import and export data. That is why i have voted in favour.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 515/97, which considered the cooperation relationship between the customs authorities of the Member States and the European Commission to be unsatisfactory, in particular the proposal considered the modus operandi of the transmission of shipping data by economic operators to the national authorities to be unsatisfactory.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against rejecting the text, since it is a legislative proposal that aims to improve customs management and risk management, strengthen the detection and prevention of fraud related to customs management, simplify and accelerate mechanisms to combat customs fraud and avoid unnecessary and repetitive bureaucracy. While the creation of multiple databases is necessary, the use and security of databases should be guaranteed as is the case in the proposal: "(...) respect and ensure the confidential processing of information." Preventing fraud and combating corruption is one of the axes of Podemos and we therefore support this legislative proposal, which also involves the cooperation of all Member States.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. •u2012 Detecting and preventing customs fraud is important to avoid losses and greater damage to the European peasant. But, as important or more important than this is the regulation itself. The decisions to liberalise, to deregulate, which this Commission, the majority of Parliament and the Council itself have taken lately are highlighting the seriousness of the losses that are being caused in the agricultural sector in our European Union. We must say that today the dairy sector is highlighting this situation with its mobilizations. That is why we think it is very important to implement new regulations, a new agricultural and food policy that gives priority to the domestic market over exports and to the international market and free trade agreements. That is essential and also, of how not, preventing and preventing fraud.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's vote is intended to simplify and speed up the mechanisms for combating customs fraud by lightening the bureaucratic burden. Efforts have been made to improve mutual assistance relations between The Member States and the administrative authorities and also their cooperation with the Commission, so as to ensure the correct application of customs and agricultural regulations. Thanks to the changes made to the current rules in force, I hope that we will be able to combat fraud linked to the false declaration of origin (which results in very high annual losses) and avoid lengthy bureaucratic delays. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of the report.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Every effort shall be made to ensure that control of agricultural products imported from third countries is effective. The effectiveness, in this context, implies the control of the origin of the products so that it is possible to assess their production conditions and compliance with the trade agreements established. This is the starting point for ensuring reciprocity of production standards and the protection of competitive conditions of European agricultural producers.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal as it is a rejection of an EU Council position.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support this report, because the compromise between the European Parliament and the Council of Ministers will ensure a higher level of consumer protection and establish better fraud prevention and combating practices in the transit system of goods across borders.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that strengthening and harmonising cooperation and mutual assistance between member states' administrative authorities is very important, especially in order to better and more effectively combat fraud. This Regulation brings improvements as it aims to simplify and speed up the processes of the examination of goods. At the same time, it is trying to reduce or remove unnecessary bureaucracy, which often presents obstacles and problems at customs. Until now, customs officials have had difficulties in determining whether the declaration of origin of the goods corresponds to the actual course of the container route. Despite the inspection of the documents and also the visual inspection of the goods, the checks were of a limited nature. Many cases of falsified declarations, as well as limited controls, have led the EU and its Member States to financial losses. I believe that the inclusion of 'export data' in the regulation is important, as this will make it easier for Member States to combat fraud. OLAF has identified clear and irrefutable information on the lack of exported products, such as tobacco, transhipped to third countries and then back to the EU, which allowed tax avoidance. I believe that the regulation is good, and I am sure that it will have a positive impact on reducing the bureaucratic burden on customs officers and improve the control of the goods we export, which is why I voted in favour of its adoption and supported it.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. Olaf, the Union's anti-fraud office, regularly notes that both the Member States and the European Commission lose a lot of revenue from smuggling alcohol and cigarettes. For example, they are first exported to third countries and later reintroduced, making tax evasion possible.  In the negotiations with the Council, the EPP in particular opposed the inclusion of export data under the guise of 'trade secrets'. Also, customs agents currently have few tools to determine whether the origin of the goods as indicated actually corresponds to the effective route of containers. Visual checks and the checking of documents are limited. In my opinion, this second reading report provides a solid basis for taking a more stringent approach to this customs-related fraud, with an eye for the protection of privacy. By setting up a registration system for products covered by excise duties in the form of a European database and by improving border surveillance systems, lost tax revenue can be kept to a minimum.  This new legislation will help to improve cooperation between customs services without increasing the administrative burden. At the same time, consumers are better protected by fewer fake products being able to enter Europe. I therefore voted in favour of this regulation.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this report because mutual assistance between the Member States of the European Union is extremely important, it is actually the meaning of the European Union. Therefore, mutual assistance between member states' administrative authorities in the proper application of the customs and agricultural law is essential, as only in this way it is possible to enable quality work for people on the ground.  I supported the report as it proposes to improve the detection, research and prevention of customs fraud by better sharing information, evidence and the functioning of the system between Member States. It is also necessary to increase the powers of workers in these sectors on the ground in order to improve their efficiency and reduce the abuse of the system, but all this while respecting the Lisbon Treaty and protecting individuals' personal data.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which will ensure a higher level of consumer protection and establish better fraud prevention in combating practices in the transit system of goods across borders.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this amendment to the provision as it addresses the aggravating circumstances that are a way of cooperation between Member States and the Commission. The amendment to the regulation allows for the proper application of the provisions relating to customs issues and agricultural goods, which in turn should allow faster transfer of data necessary for the movement of agricultural goods through the customs duties of other countries without administrative difficulties. In order to better apply the law, the European Commission will now be able to request data from Member States in cases of fraud investigation. However, this does not mean that it will have access to protected data, i.e. invade the privacy of individuals, as the provisions of the Lisbon Treaty are respected.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the proposal and support efforts to streamline the system of collecting customs duties, as well as plugging holes that allow today's system to be abused.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on ensuring the proper implementation of customs and agricultural legislation. In the European Union, we are witnessing a number of irregularities in agricultural policy. There are few countries that comply with the rules, so we must demand that all countries comply with the rules. At the same time, we must all work together on a competitive economy and free market, and counterfeiters and smugglers of counterfeit goods must be prosecuted consistently. Olaf must also add his own. That's the only way we're going to make progress.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is customs and agricultural regulations that have created the two-speed EU which is destroying the South for the benefit of the industrialised North. Further deepening these arrangements will 'legitimise' a crime committed against real Europe and Europeans.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 By my vote, I did not support the rapporteur's amendment at second reading, which proposed the rejection of the results achieved so far and the end of the conciliation process.  In my opinion, the compromise reached between the European Parliament and the European Council will help to combat cross-border tax evasion and VAT fraud. I think it is important to develop effective instruments against practices that cause significant disadvantages both to the Member States and to the European Union as a whole. In addition to causing economic disadvantage, these practices also involve health risks (e.g. lack of origin and quality assurance). In my opinion, the level of the various VAT rates, which give way to abuses, for example in the case of agricultural products, is a major obstacle in the work for further harmonisation. Furthermore, I believe that, in addition to prevention and detection, a single union of taxes and levies is needed.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I opposed the proposal to reject the Council position. It is important that a more robust customs fraud prevention and detection system be enabled and cooperation between Member States on these matters be increased. In particular, a single EU database should be put in place to gather all information regarding goods entering or transiting through the EU.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ As the current regulation on mutual assistance by Member States' administrative authorities and on the cooperation of the latter with the Commission to ensure the proper application of customs and agricultural regulations provides scope for abuse in this area, I think it is of utmost importance to adopt changes to simplify and accelerate mechanisms to combat customs and similar fraud.  In addition, the rules adopted by this Regulation need to be clarified and one of them is certainly that Member States and the Commission should have the same level of access to data, for example on the import and export of consignments of sensitive goods. Those documents should be provided by the Member States at the request of the Commission within four weeks, which I consider to be a reasonable time limit for obtaining the data that economic operators should already possess.  In addition, I support an item setting out that the Commission and the Member States should respect the confidentiality of business data and ensure that the business information exchanged remains secret. Given that I believe that these amendments will lead to the proper application of that regulation, I supported these amendments.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I did not support the second reading on mutual assistance between the administrative authorities of the Member States and on cooperation between them and the Commission to ensure the correct application of legislation on customs and agricultural matters, as I support stronger controls against criminal gangs and the exploitation of people.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against rejecting the text, since it is a legislative proposal that aims to improve customs management and risk management, strengthen the detection and prevention of fraud related to customs management, simplify and accelerate mechanisms to combat customs fraud and avoid unnecessary and repetitive bureaucracy. While the creation of multiple databases is necessary, the use and security of databases should be guaranteed as is the case in the proposal: "(...) respect and ensure the confidential processing of information." Preventing fraud and combating corruption is one of the axes of Podemos and we therefore support this legislative proposal, which also involves the cooperation of all Member States.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The report in this second reading claims: - Improving the Customs Union and strengthening the internal market - Regulating the inflows and exits of goods and preventing infringements and fraud - Establishing direct access by EU authorities to information circulating between Member States to enable monitoring of the proper application of customs regulations - Monitoring trade data on imports and exports and the transit of goods - That the Commission will be more effective than the whole Of Member States anticipating and preventing customs fraud. I object to all of the points mentioned above. I therefore voted in favour of the amendment to reject the text.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against rejecting the text, since it is a legislative proposal that aims to improve customs management and risk management, strengthen the detection and prevention of fraud related to customs management, simplify and accelerate mechanisms to combat customs fraud and avoid unnecessary and repetitive bureaucracy. While the creation of multiple databases is necessary, the use and security of databases should be guaranteed as is the case in the proposal: "(...) respect and ensure the confidential processing of information." Preventing fraud and combating corruption is one of the axes of Podemos and we therefore support this legislative proposal, which also involves the cooperation of all Member States.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote was positive because the report contributes both to strengthening the security of products circulating in the EU and to combating fraud and tax avoidance.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which gives approval to the Council to amend Regulation (EC) No 515/97 of 13 March 1997. The regulation lays down the ways in which the administrative authorities responsible for implementation of the legislation on customs and agricultural matters in the Member States are to cooperate with each other and with the Commission in order to ensure compliance with that legislation within the framework of a Community system. To this end, the Regulation states that each Member State shall communicate to the other Member States and the Commission a list of the competent authorities it has appointed for the purposes of applying the Regulation itself.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The fight against fraud in the context of the customs union and the common agricultural policy is at the basis of this Regulation, according to which it requires close cooperation between the administrative authorities entrusted in each Member State with the implementation of the provisions adopted in these two areas. It also requires adequate cooperation between these national authorities and the Commission, which is responsible for ensuring the implementation of the Treaty and the provisions adopted under it, involving effective cooperation in this area, which could strengthen the protection of the Community's financial interests.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. As this report is a long way from the original Council position (a direct right of action by the Commission against private companies and further curtailment of national competences), I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This report is aimed at filling existing loopholes that cause serious problems in the application of customs and agricultural law. This implies abuses of the transit system monitored by documentary and physical checks, which are limited in scope. At present, the losses resulting from false declarations of origin of containers amount to around EUR 100 million in the 27 Member States, and these are only detected offences. The report aims to simplify and speed up mechanisms to combat customs fraud and reduce red tape. I voted in favour of the second reading.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The tragic events of the present situation present us with the fact that the national borders of the EU Member States are no longer the limits of a single state, but constitute the external borders of the whole Union. False declarations about the origin of imported goods, false designations of the type, abuses of the transit system: these are illegal practices by which low-quality products are introduced into the Union, circumventing controls and security measures, and then competing with local products. Products that we declare to protect, because they represent quality, history, tradition, jobs, well-being, but that every day face the challenge of imitations and low-cost counterfeiting that penetrate through the stretch marks of our customs network. The rules to protect us from these commercial aggressions already exist in part, but they must be applied in a serious, effective and uniform manner. I voted in favour of this report, the aim of which is to provide more instruments for the various national authorities responsible for monitoring and verifying what comes to Europe to exchange information and good practice more efficiently: the borders of the Union must be a wall for all those who would like to do business illegally.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, since the EU ban on the trade in seal products in 2009, more than two million seals have been saved from being clubbed or shot and left to bleed to death, but an unnecessary exemption on small-scale hunts has meant that too many seals have still suffered a horrible death without any reason. That is why I voted in favour of the Buşoi report on trade in seal products: so that the EU can help bring an end to this. I applaud the swift negotiations that took place on this issue between the Council, Parliament and the Commission. It shows that when we pull in the same direction the EU can take swift action to uphold the values that matter to our citizens and encourage our national governments and Commission to demonstrate this, the same positivity and decisive action, in many other fields of importance – especially in animal welfare.

name: Bendt Bendtsen (PPE).
text: Mr President! When I have voted in favour of this report, it is because there has now been a demand for an information campaign. The Commission is therefore now obliged to inform the public and raise awareness of the rules governing the circulation of seal products originating from hunter-p veal communities in the Arctic. There is no doubt that the regulation that was made in 2009 has been a disgrace to the people who treat the environment and nature much better than many others, i.e. the Inuit high from the north.  An impact assessment was not even carried out. This meant that more than 135 000 seal skins have accumulated in Norway or in North Greenland. So there is a need for this to be looked at. I am pleased that there is a report on this, because it really shows that the 2009 regulation was a little junk.

name: Morten Messerschmidt (ECR).
text: Mr President! Unlike my good colleague, I do not quite share the view that the way in which wto legislation has been implemented is in Greenland's interest. I think it must be made clear that the ban that was implemented in relation to seal products is more emotional than rational, especially when it comes to Greenland. It is completely impossible to talk about, understand, relate to or get under the skin of Greenlandic history and the Greenlandic people, if one does not understand the relationship with nature, to the hunting, to the seals especially.  It has to be said that, with the way in which the EUROPEAN Union has chosen to deal with WTO requirements, the European Union has completely ignored the interests of the indigenous peoples. The Inuit exception in the regulation is not what we need. I think it is an affront to Greenland. I think it is an affront to a proud prisoners, whom we should protect and cherish, and that is why I am glad I voted against this report.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I just want to point out that this report balances itself to some extent on a certain edge. On the one hand, there is no doubt that there is a demand from many animal protection organisations to reduce seal discharges, where in many cases there is indeed cruelty and brutal violence against these animals. On the other hand, there is a requirement to respect, of course, also national differences, a certain custom, a certain tradition. And in that sense, I think that the report is balanced on a certain edge precisely on respect for Inuit culture and its customs, which, of course, should not be favoured to the detriment of seals. We must respect national customs, but also always protect animal rights. It's very hard to find that border.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 While I am not in favour of any kind of hunting or trade in its derivatives, I understand that in some cases it cannot be prohibited. In this particular case, the proposal provides for the IC (indigenous community) derogation, which is also included in the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples. In other words, it gives the possibility of importing products derived from hunting carried out by indigenous communities in which this practice is an integral part of the culture and identity of the indigenous community itself. In the present case, they are the Inuit, a small population living in the Arctic and basing their livelihood on the consumption and trade of the fruit of their own hunting. The text of the report provides for this derogation, but at the same time lays down clear and precise rules, and also calls on the Commission to carry out studies and controls, in order to prevent the protection of the rights of indigenous peoples from being used as a decoy to cover the import of products resulting from hunting carried out for mainly commercial purposes. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Regulation (EC) No 1007/2009 lays down a general ban on trade in seal products throughout the Union in response to concerns of the market presence of products obtained from animals slaughtered using methods that cause excessive pain, distress, fear and other forms of suffering. However, it provided for two exceptions: seal products hunted by indigenous communities such as the Inuit and seal derivatives hunted not for commercial reasons, but for sustainable management of marine populations and resources. The amendment to Regulation (EC) No 1007/2009, after the trilogue negotiations, it contains positive aspects such as the need for hunting by indigenous communities to take due account of the welfare of animals, which contributes to the subsistence of the community or a limitation of the quantity of seal products marketed to prevent it from being used for products obtained from hunting mainly for commercial purposes. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Trade in seal products is generally prohibited by moral concerns about animal welfare. The only exception is the traditional hunting by indigenous communities such as the Inuit. I welcome these tightened rules on the EU ban on trade in seal products, as they promote animal welfare and take into account the right of self-determination of indigenous communities.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. According to EU regulations - Regulation 1007/2009, trade in seal products is prohibited.  The WTO had prohibited the inclusion of two exemptions in the regulation. One of them allowed the seal trade if the products were made from seals hunted by the Inuit or any other "indigenous community".   The report referred to here wants to lift the WTO ban. It defends the right of Inuit to live according to their traditions and customs, especially since this hunt provides for the livelihood of these communities.  It is regrettable that this report does not reverse the other exemption not granted by the WTO. This was to enable indigenous populations to sustainably regulate overpopulation of seals in some areas that negatively impacted the fishing activity of several indigenous communities, with seals feeding on large quantities of fish.  Even if it is insufficient, this report is a good move. That is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not believe that the Commission should be interfering with the lives of indigenous communities.  However, I support the WTO recommendations.  I therefore abstained on the motion.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to strengthen the EU ban on the marketing of seal products. Since 2009, the EU has banned the marketing of seal-based products such as their meat, leather, fur or oils. This ban was challenged by the World Trade Organisation, which in June 2014 adopted a resolution calling on the European Union to take place in The Hague. justified the EU ban, but ordered the exemptions from this ban to be clarified. The new rules will reduce the number of exemptions that allow seal products to be marketed in the EU. The rules agreed with the Council of the EU provide that these products will continue to be marketed by indigenous communities, as seal hunting is an integral part of their culture and identity. However, the exemption that allowed the marketing of seals hunted by regulating their number of products will be abolished.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which defends the right of Inuit and other indigenous communities to live according to their traditions and therefore, in this case, authorizes the trade in products derived from their hunting under two conditions: on the one hand if this hunting is practiced for the subsistence of those communities and on the other hand provided that animal welfare is given into account. , that is, we do not unnecessarily cause suffering to hunted animals. This derogation, which had been suspended by the WTO, seems to me to be fully justified.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. The objective of this Regulation is to implement the 2009 recommendations and rulings as a result of Canada and Norway's actions on seal products, eliminating the so-called ORM option that enabled the marketing of seal hunting products for the objective of small-scale, non-profit sustainable management. The proposal preserves the exception that allows seal products to be marketed if practiced by the Inuit population and other indigenous populations, if it has traditionally been practiced by that community, if it is used for its subsistence and not mainly for commercial reasons and if certain techniques are used. In addition, the Commission has the competence to take decisions when it sees any irregularity.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The adopted Regulation 1007/2009 prohibits the trade in seal products and imports within the European Union and contains two exemptions. Following a challenge, the WTO banned the seal hunt and rejected both exceptions and this report must redefine the framework of the first exception. This would allow Inuit to market seal products slaughtered for subsistence care alone rather than throwing them into the sea. On the contrary, the second exemption for small-scale hunting is denounced in this report.  I understand the concepts of sovereignty, of defending the local traditions of communities and it is for these reasons that I voted for it. Nevertheless, as a member of the animal defence intergroup, I will remain vigilant on this report and this subject, since I believe that encouraging the marketing of these seal products in the EU (although this was banned from 2009 to today) will encourage the seal hunt.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote on this piece of legislation, which stems from the need to adapt EU rules to certain requirements of the World Trade Organisation - WTO - because it does not seem to balance in a completely balanced way the needs of the Inuit communities that live off these traditional forms of hunting, and the legitimate demands of those who want the commercial killing of the seal to be as limited as possible.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this revision of the regulation on the prohibition of trade in seal products in order to bring it into line with the recommendations and rulings of the WTO Dispute Settlement Body.  In 2009, the EU approved the regulation establishing a general ban on trade in seal products in the EU, both to products produced in the EU and to imported products. This prohibition had 2 exceptions: the Inuit, which allowed trade in products obtained from seals hunted by the Inuit population and other indigenous communities, and the exception for marine resource management that allowed trade in products obtained from hunting practiced for the sole purpose of sustainable management of small-scale and non-profit marine resources. However, the WTO Dispute Settlement Body (DSB) ruled in June 2014 that the GRM exception is discriminatory in nature and must be eliminated and that the Inuit exception should be amended in its formulation, judged arbitrary. European legislation should therefore be amended to implement the decision of the Dispute Settlement Body.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on Parliament's report amending the 2009 Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on trade in seal products. The aim of this legislation is to implement the World Trade Organisation recommendations and regulations relating to the basic 2009 Seal Regulation in order to ensure that seal products hunted for commercial purposes no longer enter the EU market.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 1007/2009 because I believe that it is important for the Union to respect the decisions of the World Trade Organisation's dispute settlement body but, at the same time, to continue to pursue its policy of protecting seals and combating the most painful and destructive hunting practices for the species.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Until now, the law prohibited the trade in seal products with two exceptions. The first was the result of hunting by indigenous communities. The second legalized the practice of hunting to regulate the amount of seals. In the face of challenges from Norway and Canada, the World Trade Organization has taken the decision to outright ban the marketing of seal products. This report denounces the WTO's decision and calls for a review only of the removal of the first Inuit hunting exemption. We consider this demand to be consistent and admissible to the extent that these communities live off the proceeds of their hunts. As this report provides, they will still be able to market seal products whose remains are released at sea for lack of market opportunities. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. 1007/2009 on trade in seal products, as it seeks better regulation in this sector. I believe that seal hunting contributes to a large extent to the subsistence of indigenous communities, which are among the few food sources to which they have access. The report's proposal is a beneficial one because, among other things, it regulates cases where the European Commission can intervene to adopt delegated acts in order to limit the quantity of products obtained from this hunt that can be placed on the market.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained. with this Commission proposal, the entry into the EU of seal products will remain prohibited unless hunting has taken place by traditional methods and mainly contributes to the livelihood of local communities and is mainly carried out for commercial purposes.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1007/2009 on trade in seal products. With this vote, Parliament has strengthened the ban on trade in seal products, restricting the right to hunt seals only to indigenous communities, such as the Inuit, and only for reasons of subsistence. This measure, on the other hand, excludes the possibility of hunting seals to protect fishing stocks, which until now has been permitted.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The background to this resolution is concerned with an EU-ban in 2009 on trade in seal products (mainly fur) which was adopted.  Two exceptions under which seal products can still be imported have come back into play since then. These exceptions have been challenged by the World Trade Organization and so the Commission had to come with a new proposal to adjust the ban on seal products. There are a number of reasons to impose a ban on the killing of seals including public concerns about the animal welfare aspects of the killing of seals and the possible presence on the market of products obtained from animals killed in a way that causes excessive pain, distress, fear and other forms of suffering. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this resolution

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not believe that the Commission should be interfering in the lives of indigenous communities. However, I support the WTO recommendations. I therefore abstained on the motion.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report taking into consideration the Commission proposal as adjusted to meet the recommendations suggested by the WTO regarding the Basic Regulations from 2009 on trade in seal products. According to the Basic Regulations, there are two main exceptions: products from hunts conducted by Inuit or other indigenous communities (the IC exception) and products from hunts conducted for the sole purpose of sustainable management of marine resources on a small scale and non-profit basis (the MRM exception). I agree with the Commission’s proposal to remove the MRM exception and present new considerations for the IC exception.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has banned trade in seal products in response to legitimate concerns about animal welfare. Exceptionally, The Inuit will only be able to sell seal products in the EU if their hunting methods take animal welfare into account.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because for me the seal hunt ensures the survival of indigenous communities and also allows effective regulation of fish quantities by regulating the overpopulation of seals in certain areas.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The rapporteur makes it clear that, on the issue of the marketing of seal products, the decision of the World Trade Organisation can be respected while respecting the compromise reached in 2009 by Parliament and the Council in Regulation 1007/2009 which provided for two exceptions to the ban on seal products . One concerns the right of Inuit and indigenous peoples to self-determination and the use of their resources and the second concerns the management of marine resources in the Baltic Sea.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for an EP and Council regulation amending ec basic Regulation 1007/2009 on trade in seal products. This applies both to seal products originating in the EU and to imported products. The EU has decided on a "total" ban, with only two derogations: products from hunting by the Inuit or other indigenous communities (IC derogation) and products from hunting carried out only on a small scale and not on a profit-making basis for the sole purpose of ensuring sustainable management of marine resources (MRM derogation). The 2009 regulation was challenged in the WTO by Canada and Norway. The purpose of this proposal is therefore to implement the decisions taken in the WTO. The new Regulation amends the criteria for the JV derogation and abolishes the MRM derogation.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a regulation because I shared its spirit: I agree with a European Union that harmonises, breaks down barriers, but I also believe that the EU must not stifle local traditions, inso far as they do not affect the internal market. I congratulate Mr Busoi on his excellent report.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst we do not support the Commission interfering in the livelihoods of the Inuit communities, the report is following WTO recommendations and does, ultimately, increase the protection of seals.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report and shared its content. It is a proposal for a regulation amending a previous regulation of 2009 and accepts the recommendations and decisions of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) on the regulation currently in force. The latter, in fact, opted for a "total" ban, with two main derogations, the IC (products from hunting practiced by the Inuit or other indigenous communities) and the MRM (products from hunting practiced only on a small scale and not on a profit-making basis).

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE)
text: Written. I voted against the proposal because it is bad for Sweden and the Baltic Sea region. This means that shot seals in Sweden will not be able to be marketed in the future. It will reduce incentives for the necessary game management of the Baltic Sea. In the case of fish, there is a ban at EU level on discards, a so-called discard ban. As far as seals are concerned, therefore, it will now instead be a draft compulsion. It doesn't make any sense.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Regulation (EC) No 1007/2009 lays down a general ban on trade in seal products throughout the Union in response to concerns of the market presence of products obtained from animals slaughtered using methods that cause excessive pain, distress, fear and other forms of suffering. However, it provided for two exceptions: seal products hunted by indigenous communities such as the Inuit and seal derivatives hunted not for commercial reasons, but for sustainable management of marine populations and resources. The amendment to Regulation (EC) No 1007/2009, after the trilogue negotiations, it contains positive aspects such as the need for hunting by indigenous communities to take due account of the welfare of animals, which contributes to the subsistence of the community or a limitation of the quantity of seal products marketed to prevent it from being used for products obtained from hunting mainly for commercial purposes. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report further limits the trade in seal products in the European Union; in fact, there will be fewer exemptions to the EU ban on the trade in seal products. The only exception which will stand is the trade of seal products derived from hunting by Inuit. Inuits are culturally similar indigenous peoples inhabiting the Arctic regions of Greenland, Canada and Alaska. I voted in favour of this report as it further protects seals and provides our citizens with further information.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The draft legislative resolution drafted by Mr Sy committee on the commission's proposal for a regulation on the common foreign and security policy Busoi expresses the European Parliament's position on the amendment of Regulation 1007/2009 (EC), which had already established a ban on the placing and presence in the European internal market of products resulting from seal hunting and now aims to bring European rules into line with recent WTO recommendations. I strongly support the strengthening of the general ban on trade in seal products provided for in the regulation approved today, as well as the further clarification of the derogation for the Inuit and other indigenous communities.  The regulation now makes it clear that no product resulting from commercial seal hunting will be allowed on the internal market. This is a necessary measure that protects European consumers and definitively prevents commercial exploitation from seal hunting, thus protecting a fragile species and animal welfare. At the same time, I consider the granting of a specific exception for indigenous communities to be balanced.  Seal hunting, traditionally practiced by inuit and indigenous peoples and not carried out for mainly commercial purposes, is not only an integral part of their cultural fabric and identity, but also an activity necessary for the livelihood of such communities.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report concerns the revision of the exception regime under EU legislation on the seal trade. This report introduces new criteria for the trade in hunting products by Inuit and other local communities and puts a definitive end to the commercialization of products from hunting practiced solely for the sole purpose of sustainable management of marine resources, on a small scale and for a non-profit purpose. Considering that the report is balanced and aims to align with the rules of the World Trade Organization (WTO), I voted in favour.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2009, the European Union banned trade in seal products. The ban, which came into force in 2010, allowed for two exceptions: one for products resulting from the hunting of indigenous tribes and the other for hunting that ensured sustainable "marine resource management." With the amendments to the original text of 2009, the derogation concerning products derived from seal hunting for the protection of fish stocks will be deleted. I have chosen to vote in favour of this measure because it will strengthen the ban on trade in seal products.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Under a 2009 EU regulation, trade in seal products was prohibited throughout the COMMUNITY. However, the Union had maintained two exceptions to this prohibition: the first for Inuit communities, for whom trade in hides or other derivatives is necessary for their livelihood, and a second allowing small-scale marketing of seal products as part of marine resource management.  However, these two exceptions were not acceptable under WTO law, which the dispute resolution body issued in June 2014, invalidating both exceptions.  European legislation therefore had to be adapted accordingly. By amending the exception granted to the Inuit community to better reflect animal welfare considerations and removing the other exception, the Union is bringing itself into compliance with international trade law. However, special provisions for Inuit and Aboriginal communities will be maintained to preserve their traditional ways of life.  However, it is regrettable that, on these Regulations, the Commission has not carried out an impact assessment which would have made it possible to better understand the effects of the removal of these two exceptions.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The preservation of biodiversity is one of the subjects for which I am committed to the European Parliament. Restricting trade in seal products is part of a mechanism that holds states accountable on this issue through trade measures. However, I support the exception in favour of indigenous peoples. Trade in seal-hunting products by local communities is a livelihood for local communities. That is why I have decided to support this report.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This resolution promotes inequality among European Union fishermen as the regulations must apply to everyone. If there are exceptions then there is inequality. This text tolerates animal abuse for the sake of "tradition". Also, the right to self-determination invoked is linked to the right to self-determination, that is, one person, one vote.  The special privileges for a special group of people at the expense of the real natives of Europe are, in our view, a kind of negative discrimination.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the direction of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of the Buşoi report.  The International Trade and Tariff Convention provides for the possibility of banning imports of certain products for animal protection and animal health reasons. The European Union has therefore banned the import of seal products as allowed by GATT rules. Canada and Norway challenged this decision at the World Trade Organisation, but the WTO Dispute Resolution Panel (court) adopted the EU's trade restriction measures. This is a precedent-setting judgment in WTO jurisprudence. The protection of human and animal health and the protection of nature come first than barrier-free trade. Therefore, the European Union can rightly prohibit, for example, imports of cloned animals and foodstuffs made therein and imports of other foodstuffs or materials which are clearly not considered safe by science, on grounds of animal health and welfare.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. I fully support the WTO's decision in the case on seal products, especially since animal welfare considerations have been the basis for the decision. However, it is very unfortunate that the implementation proposed by the Commission does not take account of the special circumstances prevailing in Sweden. The result of this Decision is that meat and skins from the permitted and necessary protection hunt slated for the fishing industry will not be able to be used. It is a waste of natural resources not to be able to use the catch from the protection hunt, and it will have a negative impact on the fishing industry and the archipelago environment. I have therefore chosen to vote against the proposal.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament and the Council adopted in 2009 a Regulation on trade in seal products, which prohibits this practice in the European Union and applies to seal products produced in the EU and imported products. The EU has opted for a 'total' ban, with two main exceptions.  Given that the objective of the new Regulation is to implement the WTO recommendations and decisions with regard to the 2009 basic regulation on trade in seal products, I agree with the deletion of the GMR exception and the proposed amendment with regard to the IC exception, taking into account, in particular, the right to self-determination of Inuit communities or other indigenous communities. I also agree with the proposed amendment to insist that seal hunting is an integral part of the culture and identity of Inuit communities and other indigenous communities, contributing significantly to their livelihood, providing food and income that allows the community to live and ensure their livelihood, perpetuate their traditions and preserve their cultural heritage , which is part of the direct exchange.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation, because I believe that indigenous peoples should be able to live according to their most ancestral traditions.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In 2009, the European Parliament adopted Regulation EC 1007/2009 prohibiting the marketing of seal products in the European Union. However, the regulation in question has been challenged within the framework of the World Trade Organisation by Canada and Norway. It was therefore necessary to await the decision of the World Trade Organisation body, which arrived on 18 June 2014 and confirmed the general ban on seal products. The European Commission subsequently decided on the 16-month period needed to prepare the necessary legislation and bring existing legislation into line with world trade organisation decisions and recommendations.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am against the report because it promotes inequality among fishermen in the European Union. The regulations should apply to everyone. If there are exceptions, then there is inequality. This text tolerates animal abuse for the sake of "tradition". Also, the right to self-determination invoked is linked to the right to self-determination, that is, one person - one vote.  The special privileges for a special group of people at the expense of the real natives of Europe are, in my view, a kind of negative discrimination.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Considering the final rulings of the Dispute Settlement Body of the WTO on 18 June 2014, defining the Inuit and MRM exceptions as ‘arbitrary and unjustifiable discrimination’, we have no choice but to adopt an amendment to the current Regulation on trade in seal products, in order to bring the EU Regulation into compliance with WTO rules. As stated by the WTO, the EU did not address animal welfare in Inuit hunts, given that the overall objective of our Regulation was based on animal welfare concerns, and the ambiguity of some of its conditions could lead to a use of the exception for hunts that should in reality be characterised as primarily undertaken for commercial purposes. I therefore strongly agree with the links made in the proposal between use of the exception and respect for animal welfare and it provides for a mechanism that would help prevent its misuse. I support the agreement reached that makes it obligatory on the Commission to inform public and private authorities of the impact of this Regulation, namely the fact that seal products derived from Inuit hunts can be legally sold.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP's position on the proposal for a regulation of Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1007/2009 on trade in seal products. The total ban on trade in seal products responds to ethical and moral concerns on the part of European citizens. Precisely in order to avoid circumvention of this ban, I agree with the decision to remove the so-called MRM derogation (which concerns the management of marine resources) in relation to small-scale hunting with no profit-making purpose. On the other hand, I agree with the decision to maintain the derogation for the indigenous COMMUNITIES in the INUIT, which feed on seal products and hunt seals not for commercial purposes but for the sake of livelihoods and income production. Precisely in order to protect the originality of this activity, I agree with the decision to allow this community to place products on the market for economic livelihoods, proving that hunting has been respectful of animal welfare, accompanied by information obligations that allow European citizens to know the origin of these products.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1007/2009 on trade in seal products, because, as a member of the Eurogroup for Animals, I warmly welcome a further tightening of the ban on trade in seal products in Europe.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on trade in seal products. It is important that the PPE-DE has succeeded in taking into account the right of self-determination of the Inuit and other indigenous communities in this report.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. I welcome the Commission's proposal to adapt our European legislation to the recommendations issued by the World Trade Organization on trade in seal products. The EU must take into account the opinions issued by international organisations of which it is a member. That is why I vote in favour of this report.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission’s proposal which amends Regulation 1007/2009 brings the EU into compliance with the WTO and thereby enables the European Union to fulfil its international obligations. Given that neither of the revised exemptions have been, or are envisaged to be in operation in the UK, the report does not substantially affect the ban on trade in seal products and therefore does not present any significant difficulties. In fact, since seals are a species that is highly susceptible to pain and distress, the modification of the IC exemption is a welcome and necessary alteration, providing assurance of more humane treatment and practices in relation to seal hunting. As some 900 000 seals are hunted each year across the globe with around one third of world trade in seal products either passing through or ending up in the EU market, EU Member States have a duty to protect against the unnecessary suffering of seals and this report can serve as an example to the rest of world. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. The sale of seal products had been banned in principle since 2009. But two exceptions continued: on the one hand, for products derived from traditional Inuit hunting (CI derogation); on the other hand, for products from hunting for sustainable management, for non-profit and non-commercial purposes (GRM derogation).  Nevertheless, Canada and Norway challenged this ban in the WTO, and in June 2014, the DSB disapproved of both exemptions on the grounds that the exemption in favour of Inuit hunting was "discriminatory, arbitrary and unjustifiable" and that non-commercial hunting could not be distinguished from commercial hunting. The new regulation proposes to remove the non-commercial hunting exemption, but to allow Inuit hunting, by limiting the marketing of hunting products, in order to avoid fraud.  I voted for this report on the trade in seal products because it limits the commercial hunting of seals while allowing Inuit communities to perpetuate their way of life and sustain themselves.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the proposed text, since the Regulation aims to ensure that products from commercially hunted seals can no longer be placed on the EU market. At the same time it also contains an exception, which defends the rights of indigenous peoples, the Inuit, allowing the hunting of seals by these communities as long as it contributes to the subsistence of the community itself, and that is practiced with methods that reduce pain, distress or fear to the animal. In addition, this consensus text follows the recommendations of the WTO and the WTO Dispute Settlement Body itself.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as, since the introduction of the ban in 2009, more than two million seals have been saved from being clubbed to death or shot and left to bleed to death. This vote will reinforce a more stringent EU ban and uphold EU citizens’ values on animal rights.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text. It was important to put in place stricter rules for trade in seal products. The new rules are intended to extend the ban to hunting products to protect fishing stocks.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the regulation which endeavours to ensure that products of commercial seal hunts are not found on the EU market. Due to the deadline of 18 October 2015 given by the WTO, the issue of commercial hunts must be solved by implementing the Seal Regulation. I believe that the addition of the new criteria, which include the exception of seal hunting for integral cultural reasons, as well as for hunting for food, is a reasonable move which ensures the fostering of community traditions and cultural heritage. After numerous debates, we must reach a solution that will comply with the international obligations set by the WTO. Thus, I believe the Seal Regulation is a necessary ban with considerable exceptions.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report supports the deletion of the Maritime Management exception and amends the Commission’s proposal on the indigenous community’s exception taking into account their right to self-determination and ILO Convention No 169. The Convention determines the indigenous peoples’ right to traditional lifestyles, culture and making a living. I supported the new text to this report as it brings the EU into conformity with its international obligations and allows seal products resulting from hunts conducted by Inuit and other indigenous communities to still be placed on the EU market.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe it strikes a fair balance in how the EU regulates trade in seal products. Through this proposal we will have an EU ban on trade in seal products with certain exceptions.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. 'Seal fur is an unnecessary fashion product for which seals are brutally killed. Therefore, the sale and import of seal products in Europe was banned years ago. But there were two exceptions, the hunting of seals in the Baltic Sea and hunting by the indigenous peoples (the Inuit). The World Trade Organisation has spoken out on this issue and, for the first time in history, found animal welfare to be a legitimate reason to restrict trade. The Party for Animals considers that there is no excuse or justification for the hunting of seals. That is why I have proposed that these two exceptions should be removed. 1. The hunting of European seals is completely unnecessary. 2. Inuit hunting in particular does not meet European animal welfare standards. If the Inuit needs seals for their survival, then we should not encourage them to sell seal fur to Europe.  There was no majority in the European Parliament for the removal of the exception for the Inuit. Nevertheless, I agreed with the final proposal, because it further restricts large-scale commercial seal hunting.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. This report implements necessary amendments to the current regulation banning the sale of seal products in the European Union in order to comply with WTO requirements. This concerns, on the one hand, the exemption for imports of seal products originating from seals hunted for the purpose of sustainable management of marine resources (BMR exception) and, on the other hand, the exemption for imports of seal products originating from a hunt traditionally practised by Inuit and other indigenous communities (IG exception). Following a complaint from Canada and Norway, the WTO decided that the BMR exception should be deleted and the IG exception should be specified in order to take a clearer view of the protection of the Inuit tradition. Compliance with WTO recommendations and decisions is of great importance for efficient global trade, and discrimination against individual trading partners is opposed to free trade. Both the Commission's proposal and the committee report implement the WTO decisions. They counteract discriminatory trade rules without being at odds with animal welfare. This report is therefore to be welcomed. I voted in favour. Incidentally , and this is my ceterum censeo – I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ More than two million seals have been saved from being clubbed to death or shot since the introduction of the EU ban on the trade in seal products in 2009. I believe this vote to end the trade in seal products will reinforce a more stringent EU ban and uphold our values on animal welfare. The only way such bans work is through cooperation and international action, and on issues like this the EU has led the way.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the proposed text, since the Regulation aims to ensure that products from commercially hunted seals can no longer be placed on the EU market. At the same time it also contains an exception, which defends the rights of indigenous peoples, the Inuit, allowing the hunting of seals by these communities as long as it contributes to the subsistence of the community itself, and that is practiced with methods that reduce pain, distress or fear to the animal.
