In addition, this consensus text follows the recommendations of the WTO and the WTO Dispute Settlement Body itself.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Vote for. I share the need for restrictions on the importation of seal products, especially due to seal hunting for commercial purposes.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 2012/2013; 1007/2009 on trade in seal products, as I firmly support the fact that it is of particular importance to protect those species of animals that are endangered or disappearing, and there are such situations throughout Europe, including in the Western Balkans.  In this regard, I think it is necessary to distinguish between the traditional life of indigenous communities, that is, in this case the traditional fishing of seals of Inuit communities, and overfishing for commercial and other purposes. Therefore, I believe that it is necessary to sensitize the public and further protect biodiversity, which represents one of the greatest European values.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. According to EU regulations - Regulation 1007/2009, trade in seal products is prohibited. The WTO had prohibited the inclusion of two exemptions in the regulation. One of them allowed trade if the products were made from seals hunted by the Inuit or any other "indigenous community". The report referred to here wants to lift the WTO ban. This report defends the right of Inuit to live according to their traditions and customs, especially since this hunt provides for the livelihoods of these communities. It is regrettable that this report does not reverse the other exemption not granted by the WTO. This was to enable indigenous populations to sustainably regulate overpopulation of seals in some areas that negatively impacted the fishing activity of several indigenous communities, with seals feeding on large quantities of fish. By defending indigenous peoples, this text is going in the right direction and I have therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Cristian-Silviu Busoi's report on the trade in seal products, which aims to implement WTO recommendations and decisions on the subject. To this end, the report amends exceptions to the prohibition in principle of trade in seal products, introducing new criteria and removing one of the exceptions. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which is to bring European legislation in line with THE recommendations and decisions of the WTO. In particular, the WTO has called for one of the two exemptions on the EU embargo on seal products to be lifted. This is the "GRM derogation" which allowed "products from small-scale, non-profit hunts for sustainable management of marine resources."

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. Although I find the report fundamentally worthy of support with regard to the traditional creation of seal products, I abstain from voting because the report does not adequately respond to the concerns of nature conservation and sustainable management of natural resources.

name: Rikke Karlsson (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted against the report 'Trade in seal products' and the proposal to deprive Greenlandic hunters of the opportunity to sell their seal products commercially. It is my opinion that Greenlandic hunters use completely humane and sustainable fishing methods and immediately eut away the adult seal with a rifle shot. Greenlandic fishing methods are being unfairly compared with those of, among other things, Greenland. Canada, where baby seals are eutellers with clubs. Many Greenlandic communities in the Arctic are deeply dependent on being able to live on their catch and their products, so it makes no sense to deprive them of the opportunity to carry out an ancient profession, which is also an immense part of their culture. In the waters around Greenland there are about 12 million seals. Greenlandic hunters shoot about 150 000 seals a year. Independent biologists have established that even if the prisoners were to catch 3 times as many seals, the catch would still be sustainable. From an animal welfare point of view, it has to be said that these seals have lived their whole lives in freedom and have been killed quickly and accurately – unlike many of the animals that we kill every day in large slaughter houses after a lifetime confined in cages and stables.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Since the introduction of the ban in 2009 more than two million seals have been saved from being clubbed to death or shot and left to bleed to death. I strongly supported the report, as it will reinforce a more stringent EU ban and uphold EU citizens’ values on animal rights.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. This report implements necessary amendments to the current regulation banning the sale of seal products in the European Union in order to comply with WTO requirements. This concerns, on the one hand, the exemption for imports of seal products originating from seals hunted for the purpose of sustainable management of marine resources (BMR exception) and, on the other hand, the exemption for imports of seal products originating from a hunt traditionally practised by Inuit and other indigenous communities (IG exception). Following a complaint from Canada and Norway, the WTO decided that the BMR exception should be deleted and the IG exception should be specified in order to take a clearer view of the protection of the Inuit tradition. Compliance with WTO recommendations and decisions is of great importance for efficient global trade, and discrimination against individual trading partners is opposed to free trade. Both the Commission's proposal and the committee report implement the WTO decisions. They counteract discriminatory trade rules without being at odds with animal welfare. This report is therefore to be welcomed. I voted in favour.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to redefine the framework of the first CI exception in order to respect the WTO's conclusions and recommendations and thus enable indigenous peoples to live on the fruits of their hunts and traditions once again within a determined framework.  This would allow them to market products derived from slaughtered seals for the sole need of subsistence, which today are often thrown into the sea for lack of commercial opportunities. The decision of the European Court of Justice of 3 September 2015 has just enshrined this right of 'indigenous communities'.  On the other hand, this report denounces the second "GRM" exemption made to allow small-scale seal hunting to ensure sustainable management of these resources.  "Indigenous communities" must be able to continue to live according to their traditions and customs. Especially since this hunt provides the livelihood of these communities.  It is regrettable that the WTO's ban on allowing indigenous peoples to regulate the overpopulation of seals in certain areas in a sustainable manner, which has a negative impact on the fishing activity of some communities (seals feeding on very large quantities of fish).  Vote for

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it defends the right of Inuit to live according to their traditions, and allows trade in products derived from their hunting while striving to avoid possible abuses.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. This proposal amends Regulation (EC) No 1007/2009 on the prohibition of trade in seal products. The purpose is to bring it into agreement with the recommendations and rulings of the WTO Dispute Settlement Body (DSB). The Regulation ensures that products from commercially hunted seals cannot be placed on the EU market and is applicable to both seal products produced in the EU and imported products. It provided for two exceptions, the first, inuit, allows trade in products obtained from seals hunted by the Inuit population and other indigenous communities. The second exception, Marine Resource Management, allowed trade in products obtained from hunting practiced with the sole objective of sustainable management of marine resources on a small scale and without profit. This second exception has been removed. I voted in favour because the agreement maintains the total ban on trade in seal products, eliminates the GRM exception and reinforces the Inuit exception for Inuit communities, as seal hunting is an integral part of the culture and identity of Inuit and other indigenous communities and contributes to their livelihood.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Regulation (EC) No 1007/2009 lays down a general ban on trade in seal products throughout the Union in response to concerns of the market presence of products obtained from animals slaughtered using methods that cause excessive pain, distress, fear and other forms of suffering. However, it provided for two exceptions: seal products hunted by indigenous communities such as the Inuit and seal derivatives hunted not for commercial reasons, but for sustainable management of marine populations and resources. The amendment to Regulation (EC) No 1007/2009, after the trilogue negotiations, it contains positive aspects such as the need for hunting by indigenous communities to take due account of the welfare of animals, which contributes to the subsistence of the community or a limitation of the quantity of seal products marketed to prevent it from being used for products obtained from hunting mainly for commercial purposes. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. This report implements necessary amendments to the current regulation banning the sale of seal products in the European Union in order to comply with WTO requirements. This concerns, on the one hand, the exemption for imports of seal products originating from seals hunted for the purpose of sustainable management of marine resources (BMR exception) and, on the other hand, the exemption for imports of seal products originating from a hunt traditionally practised by Inuit and other indigenous communities (IG exception). Following a complaint from Canada and Norway, the WTO decided that the BMR exception should be deleted and the IG exception should be specified in order to take a clearer view of the protection of the Inuit tradition. Compliance with WTO recommendations and decisions is of great importance for efficient global trade, and discrimination against individual trading partners is opposed to free trade. Both the Commission's proposal and the committee report implement the WTO decisions.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. In 2009, the European Union completely banned the trade in seal products, with two exceptions. The first exception is products from hunting by the Inuit community (Eskimos) or other native communities, the so-called IC exception, and the second is made up of hunting products solely for the purpose of maintaining marine resources and non-profit functions, the so-called MRM exception.  The Commission's proposal completely rejects the MRM exception to the Provision and constitutes a new criterion for IC exclusion. As there are nevertheless several members of the Baltic and Nordic countries who support amendments to restore the modified MRM exception, this may cause legal problems with the World Trade Organisation. Bearing in mind that the MRM exemption represents a further step towards the declining exploitation and killing of endangered species, I support the proposal for amendments. We can compare a similar situation with the Adriatic Sea, which abounds in protected species of fish. Overfishing of endangered fish and fish products would mean violation of native fauna and poaching in the Croatian underwater world.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 There is a certain kind of duplicity here – seals can be killed, but products and food can not be traded. If we save nature, seal hunting must also be banned— if we cannot trade, why kill them? The text as a whole was balanced, but much remains to be done in this regard.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The legislative proposal tabled modifies, in line with WTO recommendations, the existing derogations for seal hunting and trade in their products for indigenous peoples, for whom hunting is both a traditional mode of suburitisation and a part of cultural heritage. Hunting must traditionally be carried out by Inuit or other indigenous communities, contribute to the subsoition of the community, must not be carried out mainly for commercial purposes and must be carried out in such a way as to reduce as far as possible the pain, anxiety, distress or other forms of suffering of the animals hunted. The need to raise awareness in EU countries of the origin and legality of seal products is underlined.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. 1007/2009 on trade in seal products, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 7/9/2015.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted FOR this report, which re-enters the two derogations from Regulation 1007/2009 on the trade in seal products.  The first "GRM" (Marine Resource Management) exemption allowed small-scale hunting to regulate marine resources. It had been repealed as too restrictive and too difficult to measure. This regulation maintains this repeal and does not wish to put it back in place. The second "CI" (indigenous community) exemption permitted trade in seal products hunted by Inuit or any other "indigenous community." It, too, had been repealed by the WTO. This regulation wants to put it back in place so that Inuit can continue to live according to their traditions and customs.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal to bring our regulation banning the sale of seal products into line with WTO rules. I am delighted that in its ruling the WTO made it clear that ‘the protection of public morality’ can be a legitimate reason for restricting trade. The mass slaughter of seals in Canada clearly does offend European public morality.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In favour of the adoption of the text strengthening the European ban on trade in seal products. With today's vote, the European Union is removing the derogation on products derived from seal hunting so that there is full and effective protection and protection of animal welfare.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Buşoi's report deals with the topic of trading seal products. It should be remembered that seal hunting is an integral part of the socio-economic life, nutrition, culture and identity of Inuit and other indigenous communities and makes a significant contribution to their development, providing them with food and continuing the traditional existence of the community. At the same time, however, due regard for animal welfare must be respected. The report shall aim to limit seal hunts to those which contribute to the livelihood of indigenous communities under the strict supervision of the Commission, provided that the Member States concerned regularly inform the Commission of compliance with all measures. As I consider the report to be more than balanced, I voted in favour of it.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report is in itself in order, but does not take sufficient account of the concerns of nature conservation and sustainable management of natural resources. That is why I abstained.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In 2009, the European Parliament and the Council adopted Regulation 1007/2009, which prohibits the trade in seal products in the European Union. However, two exceptions remain: products from Inuit hunting (CI derogation) and products from hunts for the sole purpose of sustainable management of marine resources, on a small scale and for a non-profit purpose (GRM exemption). Norway and Canada, both exporters of seal products, challenged the decision at the World Trade Organization (WTO).  The WTO Dispute Resolution Body (DSB) has ruled in upholding the general ban on seal products, but rejects both exceptions under the obstruction of free competition. In order to comply with the DSB's decision, the proposed text removes the "GRM" exemption and specifies the conditions for the application of the "CI" exemption. I denounce the use of private justice, which allows us to arbitrate between the human general interest in the protection of biodiversity and the interests of seal merchants. Nevertheless, the proposed text maintains the seal preservation measures while allowing the Inuit to hunt them, I vote For.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. According to EU regulations - Regulation 1007/2009, trade in seal products is prohibited. The WTO had prohibited the inclusion of two exemptions in the regulation. One of them allowed trade if the products were made from seals hunted by the Inuit or any other "indigenous community".  The report referred to here wants to lift the WTO ban.  This report defends the right of Inuit to live according to their traditions and customs, especially since this hunt provides for the livelihoods of these communities. It is regrettable that this report does not reverse the other exemption not granted by the WTO. This was to enable indigenous populations to sustainably regulate overpopulation of seals in some areas that negatively impacted the fishing activity of several indigenous communities, with seals feeding on large quantities of fish. Even if it is insufficient, this report is a good move.  I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this legislative proposal is to implement the recommendations and decisions of the DSM in relation to the basic Regulation. It also lays down the legal basis for the co-membership of Regulation (EU) No 737/2010 with those decisions. Reservations for the GRM exception are met by eliminating it from the basic regulation. In the case of the CI exception, reservations as to its design and application are met by amending it, in particular by articulating its use with respect for animal welfare and providing for a limit on the placing on the market of seal products if the scale of hunting or other circumstances indicate stems from primarily commercial purposes. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support the proposal because it protects native wildlife by implementing further bans on the trade of seal products, the only exception being for indigenous communities under strict criteria.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption by the European Parliament of the report to amend the regulation on trade in seal products to ensure compliance with the decision of the WTO dispute settlement body. The latter had considered that the two exemptions to the ban on the importation of seal products on the European market under the European regulation were not justified. Both exemptions related to traditional subsistence hunting and hunting for sustainable management of marine resources. The EU thus strictly supervises the possibilities for the introduction of seal products on the European market. Only products from traditional hunts, practised for subsistence purposes and with respect for animal welfare, must be able to enter the European market. The regulation amended today was adopted in 2009 in response to public demands that seals be killed. The Union had thus implemented in a concrete way the principle of animal welfare dear to citizens and had thus provided an answer to their ethical concerns.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on trade in seal products, which amends Commission Regulation No 1007/2009 concerning the ban of trade in seal products, in order to comply with a WTO ruling. Regulation 1007/2009 introduced a general ban on placing seal products on the European Union’s market. The ban included two exceptions, the so called Inuit exception and the so called MRM-exception (Maritime Resource Management), which allowed seal products to be placed on the market if they originated from seals hunted by Inuit or as a result of maritime resource management. The MRM-exception has been mainly used by the Member States located in the Baltic Sea.  Canada and Norway challenged the ban and its exceptions in the WTO, arguing that they are discriminatory. The WTO dispute settlement body ruled that while the ban itself does not violate WTO regulations, the MRM exception is indeed of a discriminatory nature. Concerning the Inuit exception, the WTO ruled that while in principle it is justified, the specific formulation was arbitrary and should thus be changed. The decision has to be implemented by 18 October 2015.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Joint Regulation (EC) No 1007/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council banned trade in seal products in the European Union with two exceptions. The regulation was challenged by Canada and Norway before the World Trade Organization. The two exceptions to the Regulation were rejected by the competent wto bodies. The proposal for amending the Regulation, presented by the Commission, is intended to bring the Regulation into line with wto recommendations and decisions on this matter. I supported the motion.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. Regulation 1007/2009 prohibits trade in seal products and imports within the European Union. It makes two exemptions: the exemption for indigenous communities, which authorizes this trade if it is done by the Inuit or any other "indigenous community";  the Marine Resource Management Exemption, which allows products from hunts for the sole purpose of sustainable management of marine resources. Following Norway and Canada's complaint to the WTO, the WTO suspended the second exception, forcing the European Union to review its regulations. It is therefore proposed to retain only the exception that applies to indigenous communities, which is a bad thing, but is nevertheless preferable to a total absence of derogation. As a result the vote may be favourable.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the trade in seal products should be prohibited in its entirety, except for the two situations presented: a) "CI Exception" - seal products hunted by Inuit communities or other indigenous communities;  (b) "GMR Exception" means game products practised with the sole purpose of ensuring the sustainable management of small-scale, non-profit marine resources. With regard to the first exception, my position is justified by the fact that seal hunting is a cultural tradition of Inuit communities and other indigenous communities, contributing to their livelihood, providing food and income. With regard to the second exception, given the difficulty in differentiating commercial hunting from gmr hunting, I argue that it can only be carried out in very specific circumstances, allowing this exception for the management of marine resources to fulfil its objective of promoting the protection of natural biodiversity. For the foregoing, this report has voted in favour.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on trade in seal products relates to Regulation 1007/2009, which prohibits trade in seal products and imports within the EU and includes two exemptions. However, following a conflict, the WTO banned the seal hunt and rejected both exceptions. The purpose of this report is therefore to redefine the framework of the first exception. The report defends the exemption for Inuit who could market seal products slaughtered for subsistence alone rather than throwing them into the sea. On the other hand, he denounces the second exemption for a small-scale hunt.  I voted for this text because I defend local traditions and the sovereignty of peoples, but being a member of the animal defence intergroup, I will remain vigilant on this report and this subject since I believe that encouraging the marketing of these seal products in the EU (although this has been banned since 2009) will encourage the seal hunt.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Since the introduction of the ban in 2009 more than two million seals have been saved from being clubbed to death or shot and left to bleed to death. This vote will reinforce a more stringent EU ban and uphold EU citizens’ values on animal rights.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the proposal to amend the European Union regulation on trade in seal products. Since 2009, this trade has been banned in the European Union, with the exception of products from hunting by Inuit or other indigenous communities ("CI derogation") and products from hunts carried out solely for the sole purpose of sustainable management of marine resources, on a small scale and for a non-profit purpose ("GRM derogation"). This report proposes that the Commission be able to adopt measures to limit these exceptions if it is established that the seal hunt is primarily for commercial purposes, not for subsistence purposes. The aim is to bring the Union into line with the recommendations and decisions of the World Trade Organization in this area.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament already in 2009 spoke out against trade in seal products, both those made in EU and imported countries, opting for a "total" ban, with two main derogations for products from hunting by the Inuit or other indigenous communities and those from hunting carried out only on a small scale and not on a profit-making basis. , for the sole purpose of ensuring sustainable management of marine resources. With the regulation that we are approving today, we want to reaffirm our commitment and ensure that products derived from seals hunted for commercial purposes are no longer present on the European market, amending some of the derogations initially provided for. Furthermore, where there is relevant evidence to indicate that the number of seals hunted or the quantity of products placed on the market is such as to confirm that hunting was mainly carried out for commercial purposes, we consider it necessary to give the Commission the power to adopt delegated acts in order to limit the quantity of products resulting from this form of hunting that can be placed on the European market.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report that will instate a prohibition on placing seal products on the market.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Did not support the disposal of products from seals caught in the permitted quantity. This directly affects some regions of Estonia.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – It is to be welcomed that an agreement has been reached and the regulation on trade in seal products will be brought into line with World Trade Organisation rules. In order to prevent possible discriminatory cases, it is appropriate to withdraw the exemption provided for in the Regulation for seal products hunted in small quantities and not for profit solely for the purpose of sustainable management of marine resources. It should be noted that such hunting cannot be distinguished from commercial hunting, therefore the prohibition of the latter is considered discriminatory. In addition, it is essential that the impact of this legislation on the essential and social interests of Inuit and other indigenous communities be assessed and that the right to self-determination of these communities is taken into account. I support the proposal that citizens be duly informed that seal products placed on the EU market, hunted down by Inuit and other indigenous communities, are legal.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the work done by the rapporteur and thanking him, given the need to tighten penalties for trade in seal products in order to safeguard animal welfare, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Ева Паунова (PPE)
text: in writing. – I supported the report on trade in seal products because it prohibits the commercial killing of seals, thereby protecting their population and reducing the cruelty caused to these animals by an extinct species. I appreciate the fact that a alignment has been reached between European and EU provisions, with which the EU fulfils its international obligations. I agree with the compromise reached with the Inuit community and find it fair because I do not believe it is within our power to eradicate a millennial tradition and seize the basic livelihoods of Indigenous people when we are absolutely aware that their goals are non-commercial.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Seal hunting is an integral part of the culture and identity of the Inuit and other indigenous communities. As such, it makes a great contribution to their survival and is not carried out for commercial reasons. Taking into account the traditional way of life and survival in the community, the way in which hunting is carried out reduces pain, suffering, fear and other forms of animal suffering and takes into account animal welfare.  As regards imports of seal products, the quantity of such goods shall not indicate that they are imports for commercial reasons. In view of the protection of the Lifestyle of the Inuit on the one hand, and the misuse of seal products used for commercial purposes on the other, I support this report prohibiting such exploitation.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The adopted Regulation 1007/2009 prohibits the trade in seal products and imports within the European Union and contains two exemptions. Following a challenge, the WTO banned the seal hunt and rejected both exceptions and this report must redefine the framework of the first exception. This would allow Inuit to market seal products if the animals were slaughtered for subsistence alone rather than throwing them into the sea. On the contrary, the second exemption, for a small-scale hunt, is denounced in this report.  I support sovereignty as well as the defence of local traditions and it is for these reasons that I voted for it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Seal hunting is an integral part of the culture and identity of Inuit and other indigenous communities that contributes to their livelihood, provides food and a source of income necessary for life, and does not constitute a wild party or hobby. For these reasons, seal hunting traditionally carried out by Inuit and other indigenous communities does not raise the same moral public concerns as hunting carried out primarily for commercial purposes or entertainment.  The social interests of inuit and other indigenous communities should not be jeopardised, which is in line with the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples and other relevant international instruments, which is why Regulation (EC) No 1007/2009 exceptionally allows seal products to be marketed as a result of hunting traditionally and sustainably carried out by Inuit and other indigenous communities. I support the rapporteur's proposal that the Commission should consider developing appropriate measures to combat the potential negative effects that the application of Regulation (EC) No 1007/2009 can have on Inuit and other indigenous communities, as long as the restriction would apply to hunting that contributes exclusively to the necessary living needs of the communities that depend on it.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2009, the European Union opted for a "total" ban on trade in seal products with two main exceptions: for products resulting from hunting by the Inuit and other indigenous communities (the so-called IC exceptions) and for products resulting from hunting for the sole purpose of sustainable management of marine resources on a small scale and non-profit (the so-called MRM exception). The proposal presented by the Commission completely removes the MRM exception from the regulation but maintains, by introducing new criteria, the IC exception. I believe it is of fundamental importance to ensure respect for traditional hunting practices because they are a valuable asset for European culture. However, the marketing of products resulting from this type of hunting activity must be placed within an international regulatory framework, in order to ensure greater respect for the environment and the life cycles of fauna. The rapporteur has supported the Commission's line and a cross-party consensus has been reached between the various political groups. That is why I have decided to support the resolution.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. We have adopted legislation amending the EU regulation banning trade in seal products within the EU, for products manufactured in the EU but also imported. The new proposal is consistent with WTO conclusions and recommendations and meticulously specifies the conditions under which the marketing of seal products from the hunt is permitted. I am pleased to have voted in favour of this text.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. – (PT) I voted in favour of considering that the position that the regulation on trade in seal products should be considered correct.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. At noon, MEPs at the plenary session overwhelmingly supported the Busoi report on the sensitive issue of trade in seal products. These are meat, oil or seal fur mainly used in the clothing and cosmetics industry, in traditional cooking and furniture manufacturing. In practice, a new regulation is needed to bring existing legislation in line with WTO decisions and recommendations. Indeed, since 2010, the European Union has imposed an embargo on seal products invoking the amoral nature of this hunt, and at the same time provides for two exemptions for: - products from hunts practiced by Inuit or other indigenous communities ("CI derogation") - products from small-scale hunts, for non-profit and aimed at sustainable management of marine resources ("DErogation"). However, the WTO concluded in 2014 that the latter derogation was not justified. That's why it was important to adapt the legislation, to put the cursor in the right place, taking into account animal welfare standards in the 21st century while integrating the ancient hunting traditions of the Inuit.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this revision of the regulation on the prohibition of trade in seal products in order to bring it into line with the recommendations and rulings of the WTO Dispute Settlement Body.  In 2009, the EU approved the regulation establishing a general ban on trade in seal products in the EU, both to products produced in the EU and to imported products. This prohibition had 2 exceptions: the Inuit, which allowed trade in products obtained from seals hunted by the Inuit population and other indigenous communities, and the exception for marine resource management that allowed trade in products obtained from hunting practiced for the sole purpose of sustainable management of small-scale and non-profit marine resources. However, the WTO Dispute Settlement Body (DSB) ruled in June 2014 that the GRM exception is discriminatory in nature and must be eliminated and that the Inuit exception should be amended in its formulation, judged arbitrary. European legislation should therefore be amended to implement the decision of the Dispute Settlement Body.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted yesterday in favour of this report which calls for a ban on the sale of seal products in the EU by ending a ban on products from hunts to protect fishing stocks. Since 2009, the EU has banned the trade in everything produced from seals, both clothing and food, in an effort to protect the welfare of these animals. Europe, however, had so far granted two exemptions allowing the Inuit community to continue to sell these products and allowing trade in hunting products when it was intended to protect fishing stocks. It is with this second exception that the vote that took place yesterday ends. As a reminder, the EU's ban on trade in seal products had been challenged in the World Trade Organization by Norway and Canada, leading the WTO to ask Europe in 2014 to clarify its exemptions. The text adopted on Tuesday therefore confirmed the exemption granted to the Inuit community, specifying its conditions. These new, stricter rules will apply from mid-October 2015.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of this legislative proposal is to implement wto recommendations and decisions and decisions established last year in July on the 2009 base regulation on trade in seal products.  The Regulation provided for a total ban on trade, with the exception of seal products hunted by Inuit communities or other indigenous communities (except IC) and hunting products practised with the sole objective of ensuring the sustainable management of small-scale and non-profit marine resources (GMR exception). In the current Commission proposal, some amendments have been made to the CI exception and the GMR exception has been deleted. Despite the fact that this latter decision is somewhat controversial, I endorse the rapporteur's position that he intends to implement wto recommendations and decisions in order to ensure that products derived from seals hunted for commercial purposes are no longer available on the EU market and strive for adequate control of the limits applicable to imports of seal products , hunted by inuit communities, recalling in this context that the historical 'rights' of inuit communities to this hunt are the dignity and rights of animals. For that reason, I voted in favour.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of the resolution on the basic regulation on trade in seal products. I believe that we can respect both compliance with the WTO decision and the compromise reached by Parliament and the Council introducing two derogations from the ban on seal products: the IC derogation, which concerns the right of the Inuit and indigenous peoples to self-determination and the use of their resources, and the MRM derogation, which establishes the management of marine resources in the Baltic Sea. I believe it is necessary to promote the protection of natural biodiversity and bioeconomic sustainability and at the same time to respect the traditions and culture of certain countries.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the proposed text, since the Regulation aims to ensure that products from commercially hunted seals can no longer be placed on the EU market. At the same time it also contains an exception, which defends the rights of indigenous peoples, the Inuit, allowing the hunting of seals by these communities as long as it contributes to the subsistence of the community itself, and that is practiced with methods that reduce pain, distress or fear to the animal. In addition, this consensus text follows the recommendations of the WTO and the WTO Dispute Settlement Body itself.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the revision of the Regulation on trade in seal products because it adapts legislation to recommendations and a binding WTO decision on trade in seal products. The text abolishes the existing exception concerning the management of marine resources, as these hunts cannot be distinguished from commercial hunts. The report further amends the proposal on the exemption relating to indigenous communities, in particular taking into account the right of inuit or other indigenous communities to self-determination. I consider it important to consider a provision referring to the right of citizens to be properly informed that seal products placed on the EU market and derived from hunts organised by Inuit and other indigenous communities have legal origin. Moreover, if the numbers of seals caught under the so-called Inuit exemption prove to correspond to commercial hunting, the quantities of products derived from such hunts which may be placed on the market may be reduced.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Regulation (EC) No 1007/2009 lays down a general ban on trade in seal products throughout the Union in response to concerns of the market presence of products obtained from animals slaughtered using methods that cause excessive pain, distress, fear and other forms of suffering. However, it provided for two exceptions: seal products hunted by indigenous communities such as the Inuit and seal derivatives hunted not for commercial reasons, but for sustainable management of marine populations and resources. The amendment to Regulation (EC) No 1007/2009, after the trilogue negotiations, it contains positive aspects such as the need for hunting by indigenous communities to take due account of the welfare of animals, which contributes to the subsistence of the community or a limitation of the quantity of seal products marketed to prevent it from being used for products obtained from hunting mainly for commercial purposes. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. It is necessary to emphasize that Portuguese citizens do not agree with the hunting of wild mammals. The capture and death of pinipedes is far from consensual.  European values include tolerance and respect for difference. With other subsistence cultures that have secularly hunted and used seal products in a sustainable way, it will be up to the informed consumer to decide and choose which products seem most appropriate to them.  One thing is the capture of some animals, in a geographical and social context in which man is part of the ecosystem of these same animals and another, completely different, is the mass, unsustainable and culturally unjustified capture of cetaceans by industrial fleets or by the simple practice of bloody rituals. European citizens know the difference and this Parliament must mirror that difference. For this reason, I voted positively for this resolution.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote as I do not believe this is an EU competency.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report because I want to see more protection given to these endangered creatures. Already, we have seen the extinction of the Caribbean Monk Seal in the middle of the 20th Century, the overhunting into extinction of the Japanese Sea Lion in the 1970s. Many more species of seal are now critically endangered. However, since the introduction of the ban in 2009, more than 2 million seals have been saved from being clubbed to death or shot and left to bleed to death. I believe that this vote will further reinforce protection for the rights of this creature.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Seal hunting is an integral part of the culture and identity of the Inuit and other indigenous communities and makes a significant contribution to their subservient life, provides food and income to support the life and sustainable livelihoods of the community, preserves the traditional existence of the community and cultural heritage of the exchange trade and allows them to continue. It was therefore necessary to add a derogation in this case in order to allow seal products to be placed on the market under well-defined conditions. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The Regulation prohibiting the sale of seal products is very important for the Greens/EFA Group, as its primary and primary purpose from the outset is to protect the animals for which we are actively committed. Following two main exceptions in the regulation, which are briefly referred to as the IC exception and the MRM exception, Canada and Norway challenged the Seal Regulation and its implementing act in the World Trade Organisation. The general ban on the sale of seal products, justified by moral reservations in animal welfare, was supported and the exceptions were rejected. I believe that the mrm exception was the most problematic in the existing regulation, which is why I also advocated that it be deleted. During the negotiations, we successfully agreed to delete from the definitions some other words that could potentially soften the regulation and thus shake it. I believe that the changes in the regulation are good and balanced. It should now comply with the WTO and its requirements. We have all worked hard to find a compromise acceptable to everyone as soon as possible, and I think we have been successful in doing so. Both I and the Green/EFA Group are pleased with the final outcome and the amended regulation, which is why I supported the regulation.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. 'Although some Nordic Member States have tried to obtain an exception to the ban on trade in seals(s), I am pleased that Parliament has today made the legislation watertight by a large majority. The changes that have been made came at the insistence of the World Trade Organisation.  It made it clear that the distinction between commercial catch and catch in the context of overpopulation (Marine Resource Management) was too vague. In addition, mrm catches could still be on the market.  By removing the Marine Resource Management aspect from the legislation, that problem is off the table. However, an exception remains for the Inuit community, which is still allowed to hunt seals for a limited time, but cannot bring the derived products to the European market. I voted in favour of the report, which in the past has already received very broad support from the People of Europe.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. This report implements necessary amendments to the current regulation banning the sale of seal products in the European Union in order to comply with WTO requirements. This concerns, on the one hand, the exemption for imports of seal products originating from seals hunted for the purpose of sustainable management of marine resources (BMR exception) and, on the other hand, the exemption for imports of seal products originating from a hunt traditionally practised by Inuit and other indigenous communities (IG exception). Following a complaint from Canada and Norway, the WTO decided that the BMR exception should be deleted and the IG exception should be specified in order to take a clearer view of the protection of the Inuit tradition. Compliance with WTO recommendations and decisions is of great importance for efficient global trade, and discrimination against individual trading partners is opposed to free trade. Both the Commission's proposal and the committee report implement the WTO decisions. They counteract discriminatory trade rules without being at odds with animal welfare. This report is therefore to be welcomed. I voted in favour.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this report as the rules in the store need to be adjusted and attempted to be leveled across the system. The report implements WTO recommendations and rules when it comes to products made from seals. The measures introduced and recommended by the WTO have been well and deeply processed and adopted and are in line with the principles of free but regulated trade.  Regulation of products coming from seals will achieve a regulated market and thus consumers, in the bottom line, will be protected and well informed about these not so well-known and widespread products. For the sake of quality regulation, there need to be certain limitations and ultimately they result in only the best and highest quality products coming into consumers' hands.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support this report. It strengthens the original legislation put in place in 2009 which has saved more than two million seals from being clubbed to death or shot and left to bleed to death. This vote will reinforce a more stringent EU ban and uphold EU citizens’ values on animal rights.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the initiative to once again thoroughly consider all items and amendments to Regulation (EC) No 2012/2013. 1007/2009 to find a solution that will suit all indigenous communities and Inuit, but we must also look out for the conservation of the species and avoid any form of discrimination between Member States.  Seal hunting is an integral part of the culture and identity of Inuit and other indigenous communities and greatly contributes to their existence. When making decisions like this, we need to think in advance about whether quotas and legislation threaten the livelihoods of these communities. In line with the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples and other relevant international instruments, the fundamental and social interests of the Inuit and other indigenous communities should not be jeopardised.  Also, all conditions and exceptions of the resolution must be clearly defined so as not to discriminate between member states. All determinants and legislative acts must be equal and implemented in the legislation of each Member State.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Given that the proposal only specifies certain provisions and aligns EU legislation with world trade organisation requirements, I supported the proposal.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on trade in seal products. On the one hand, we are seeing a number of organisations which have been calling for restrictions on the import of seal products for many years in order to protect seals, and on the other hand we must also respect the national traditions of indigenous people for which seal hunting is survival. I think that the report on trade in seal products has moved closer to a balance with the exception clause on imports of products obtained by hunting these communities. But it will be crucial to control it so that there is no abuse.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This resolution promotes inequality among European Union fishermen as the regulations must apply to everyone. If there are exceptions then there is inequality. This text tolerates animal abuse for the sake of "tradition". Also, the right to self-determination invoked is linked to the right to self-determination, that is, one person, one vote.  The special privileges for a special group of people at the expense of the real natives of Europe are, in our view, a kind of negative discrimination.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because I believe it is important to regulate trade in endangered species and products thereof. I believe that we can only be effective on such issues in a uniform way. The proposal does not prohibit indigenous communities from pursuing seal hunting in a sustainable manner in order to sustain life support , in accordance with the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples and other relevant international agreements. However, even in this case, due attention must be paid to the welfare of animals. Under the proposal, indigenous communities will not be allowed to engage in commercial activities, and calls on the European Commission to lay down detailed rules on the placing on the market of seal products.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 There are many species of animals living in wild conditions, the economic use of which by man should be banned or very severely restricted. Seals undoubtedly belong to this catalogue, which is why I voted with conviction in favour of tightening the rules on trade in seal products.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Around one third of the world trade in seal products either passes through or ends up on the EU market. To answer animal welfare concerns, the EU banned trade in seal products in 2009. However, it allowed two exceptions for seal products from hunting by Inuit and other indigenous communities, and for small-scale hunts to ensure the ‘sustainable management of marine resources’ (MRM exception).  In June 2014, a WTO ruling challenged these exceptions, arguing that they could have discriminatory effects. As a reaction to that, the Commission tabled a proposed update of the EU rules which align them with the WTO ruling by renouncing the MRM exception and clarifying the Inuit one.  The current reports backs the Commission report and provides further improvements, asking the Commission: 1) to report on the impacts of this Regulation, and to assess deletion of the MRM-exception, and 2) to inform the public of the impacts of this Regulation, namely the fact that seal products derived from Inuit hunts can legally be sold.  Adoption of this report sets a stronger EU ban on the trade in seal products and helps to ensure fewer seals are hunted for their fur.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposed regulation on trade in seal products. This regulation intends to comply with WTO recommendations as regards exceptions to the ban on trade in seal products. Until now the EU authorised an exception as regards maritime resource management (MRM); such exception is no longer needed. The second exception concerns the trade in seals conducted by Inuits: seal hunting is a long-term tradition and is still today essential for their community. In accordance with the right to self-determination and the indigenous peoples’ right to traditional life styles, such an exception may remain and these products may be placed on the EU market, provided animal welfare is respected and limits are set out on the number of seal products which can be put on the EU market.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the necessary changes to the existing Regulation prohibiting the trading of seal products in the European Union, which allows for two exemptions: the maritime resources management exemption and the exemption relating to the sale of these products by Eskimos and other indigenous communities.  As the World Trade Organisation has found that these exemptions discriminate against Norwegian and Canadian seal products and requires that the maritime resource management exemption be abolished and the exemption relating to the Eskimo exception amended, these amendments will ensure that it relates to maintaining their traditional way of life and living conditions without being exploited for commercial purposes.  I consider the provision of these amendments to be a very important requirement obliging the Commission to study the effects of these changes to the original Regulation in order to actually implement these balanced provisions supporting the European Union's approach to animal welfare. In my view, the European Union shows that an engaged and responsible member of the World Trade Organisation respects communities for whom seal hunting is part of the traditional way of life.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The legislative proposal on trade in seal products, which I supported, aims to implement the WTO recommendations and decisions presented in July 2014, in accordance with the basic 2009 regulation on trade in seal products. The regulation prohibiting trade in seal products in the European Union was considered a sensitive subject, voted for removal despite opposition from the Baltic and Nordic countries.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the proposed text, since the Regulation aims to ensure that products from commercially hunted seals can no longer be placed on the EU market. At the same time it also contains an exception, which defends the rights of indigenous peoples, the Inuit, allowing the hunting of seals by these communities as long as it contributes to the subsistence of the community itself, and that is practiced with methods that reduce pain, distress or fear to the animal. In addition, this consensus text follows the recommendations of the WTO and the WTO Dispute Settlement Body itself.

name: Nils Torvalds (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The proposal to remove the MRM exception is unfortunate. Not taking care of the products of authorised and necessary protection hunting is not reasonable and a waste of natural resources. At the same time, it is important that the necessary protection hunt takes place, and the ban on trade in products reduces the incentives for hunters to carry out the protection hunt. I have therefore voted against the proposal.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The adopted Regulation 1007/2009 prohibits the trade in seal products and imports within the European Union. This regulation has two exemptions: - The CI (indigenous community) exemption allowing trade in seal products if they have been hunted by the Inuit or any other "indigenous community". - The GRM (Marine Resource Management) exemption authorizing products from hunts carried out for the sole purpose of sustainable management of marine resources. The WTO ruled in favour of a total ban on seal hunting and rejected the two exceptions defined as unjustified in light of moral concerns about animal welfare and the difficulty of distinguishing between individuals slaughtered for the livelihood of "indigenous communities" from those slaughtered for commercial logic.  This report only wishes to redefine the framework of the first CI exception in order to respect the conclusions and recommendations of the WTO "indigenous communities" must be able to continue to live according to their traditions and customs. Especially since this hunt provides the livelihood of these communities.  The WTO's ban on allowing indigenous peoples to regulate seal overpopulation in a sustainable way is regrettable. So I voted for this text.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Seal hunting is an integral part of Inuit culture. This provides a source of subsistence that fully corresponds to the traditional lifestyle of the community, preserving its identity and thus guaranteeing its permanence. I therefore welcome the Commission's decision to preserve the IC exception in the context of the amendment of Regulation No 17. 1007/2009 on trade in seal products, but strengthened it by imposing strict conditions. Furthermore, I agree with the abolition of the exception concerning products derived from hunting carried out for the sustainable management of marine resources, as it risks being interpreted broadly and thus leading to abuses. The report inparticular innovates with the proposal to adequately inform consumers about the provenance of seal products from indigenous communities. Moreover, the report calls on the Commission to carry out an impact study of the new regulation on the Inuit community by the end of 2019. Convinced that such strict but extremely useful measures will have a positive effect on the Inuit community, while ensuring animal welfare, I voted in favour of the Report on trade in seal products.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the proposed text, since the Regulation aims to ensure that products from commercially hunted seals can no longer be placed on the EU market. At the same time it also contains an exception, which defends the rights of indigenous peoples, the Inuit, allowing the hunting of seals by these communities as long as it contributes to the subsistence of the community itself, and that is practiced with methods that reduce pain, distress or fear to the animal. In addition, this consensus text follows the recommendations of the WTO and the WTO Dispute Settlement Body itself.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I am in favour of a ban on seal hunting and commercialisation of seal products. Therefore I consider the Commission proposal was generally good because it would allow compliance with the WTO ruling and therefore preserve the general ban.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of strengthening the ban on EU trade in seal products, which will result, among other things, in fewer seals being hunted for trading purposes. A significant change is that the ban will also be extended to products resulting from hunts aimed at protecting fishing stocks. Understandably, the only exemption from this ban will continue to be granted to Inuit and other indigenous communities, which rely on seal products for their living, although the sale of seal products in the EU will only be permitted if their hunting methods 1) are compatible with animal welfare principles 2) are a part of their tradition and 3) contribute to the subsistence of their communities.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a legislative proposal that aims to implement the recommendations established by the WTO in seal products and to remove some exceptions that European regulation had in this regard. I therefore consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I was proud to vote in favour of the report by the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) which strengthens the EU’s stance on the sale of seal products. By calling for the removal of the marine resources management (MRM) exception, we are not only making our legislation more efficient, we are also preventing further challenges to our ban from non-EU countries in the World Trade Organization. In so doing, we are placing our relationship with our international partners on surer foundations. I also voted to strengthen the protection on the hunting practices of the Inuit peoples, to aid in the preservation of their unique way of life. Since the introduction of the EU-wide ban in 2009 more than two million seals have been saved from an inhumane death. It is an honour to reinforce this ban and uphold the values of EU citizens.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'With regard to trade in seal products, I voted in favour of the report because, firstly, it is not desirable that it should be allowed to trade on The European markets. This should ensure that fewer and fewer seals die a gruesome and useless death. In this way, we are also adapting European legislation to WTO regulations. It is to the credit of the European Parliament that it is aware of the fate of the Inuit and allows the thousands of skins left in stock to be sold. There must be a balance between the economic and traditional necessity of seal products for the Inuit on the one hand and a ban on the cruel slaughter of these seals for global consumption on the other.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Since 2009, and due to the threat to the species and hunting in particular, trade in seal products has been banned in the European Union. Some states, including Canada and Norway, have requested exemptions from international legislation at the WTO to allow certain communities, such as the Inuit, to continue hunting, but also to maintain fisheries stocks that would be threatened by the increase in the number of seals.  If Inuit and other Aboriginal communities are to be able to continue hunting and selling seal products, is the threat that seals could pose to fishing stocks not scientifically demonstrated, which is why the European Parliament has removed this exception. The European Parliament has remained cautious in accepting only part of the exemptions now accepted by the WTO allowing Inuit and indigenous communities to sell seal products as part of the adaptation of European law, provided that hunting methods take into account the welfare of the animal and are part of the community's traditions and contribute to its livelihood.  This position seems to me to be balanced, so I voted for this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is at issue is the implementing of the WTO recommendations and decisions on the 2009 basic regulation. The rapporteur agreed to the exception of the import of hunted seal products with the sole objective of ensuring the sustainable management of marine resources, not for profit and not for commercial reasons. Furthermore, the rapporteur amended the Commission's proposal for the CI exception (2012) exception that exists for seal products hunted by traditional methods of Inuit communities and other indigenous communities and which contribute to their subsistence by considering, in particular, the right to self-determination of Inuit communities or other indigenous communities. The proposal was amended by the rapporteur so that in the new Regulation the idea that seal hunting is an integral part of the culture and identity of Inuit communities and other indigenous communities, which contributes significantly to their livelihood, through the provision of food and income that allow the community to live, perpetuate their traditions and preserve their cultural heritage , which is part of the direct exchange. We voted for it.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report is in itself in order, but does not take sufficient account of the concerns of nature conservation and sustainable management of natural resources. That is why I abstained.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. Together with my group, the ECR, I voted in favour of this report. The report implements the necessary amendments to the current regulation banning the sale of seal products in the European Union. The ECR considers that this is a balanced agreement. It complies with EU animal welfare standards and reflects the EU's position as a committed and responsible member of the WTO (World Trade Organisation). In addition, this report also respects those communities for which seal hunting is part of their traditional way of life.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU banned trade in seal products in 2009 as the result of animal welfare concerns. Labour MEPs voted for this report to strengthen the 2009 ban, aligning it with World Trade Organisation (WTO) standards by removing exemptions for small-scale hunts. Since the existing EU ban came into force in 2009, two million seals have been saved from being clubbed to death or shot and left to bleed to death. Millions more seals will continue to be saved from this gruesome practice by a reinforced EU ban. The only way a ban can work is through cooperation and international action, and on issues like this the EU has led the way, reflecting EU citizens’ concerns for animal rights.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report. This report aligns EU standards for trade in seal products with WTO requirements. Trade conducted by the Innuites, resulting from their traditional way of life and the need to live in difficult conditions rather than the desire to commercialise the use of seal products, remains excluded from the ban. However, it is to be carried out in a way that does not offend the population of these animals, saves pain, undue suffering and takes into account their well-being.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has launched the above-mentioned legislative proposal to implement wto recommendations and decisions on the 2009 basic regulation. The rapporteur agreed to the exception of the import of hunted seal products with the sole objective of ensuring the sustainable management of marine resources, not for profit and not for commercial reasons. Furthermore, the rapporteur amended the Commission's proposal for the CI exception (2012) exception that exists for seal products hunted by traditional methods of Inuit communities and other indigenous communities and which contribute to their subsistence by considering, in particular, the right to self-determination of Inuit communities or other indigenous communities. The proposal was amended by the rapporteur so that in the new Regulation the idea that seal hunting is an integral part of the culture and identity of Inuit communities and other indigenous communities, which contributes significantly to their livelihood, through the provision of food and income that allow the community to live, perpetuate their traditions and preserve their cultural heritage , which is part of the direct exchange. We voted for it.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The ban on the marketing of seal products was introduced a few years ago in the European Union, with the only limited exceptions resulting from the management of maritime resources and the need for livelihoods by the Inuit populations. Seal hunting is a barbaric practice which the EU is rightly trying to put an end to. However, the World Trade Organisation has accepted the complaints of certain countries such as Canada and Norway, which questioned the legality of this ban as it would constitute an undue restriction on freedom of trade. A revision of the legislation was therefore necessary, on the one hand to confirm the ban and, on the other, to ensure that it is finally unattagable. Without this revision, the legislation would have lost its effectiveness and we could have seen seal products again on the European market. I am therefore voting in favour of this report, which reflects the difficult work we have done in the Committee on the Internal Market and with the Council to find a solution that will allow the ban to remain in force, in the knowledge that the common feeling of European citizens is in line with this battle of civilisation.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I fully support the Moi-Sommer report on cloning of animals, and I do this with the overwhelming backing of hundreds of my constituents, who are deeply concerned at the consequences of cloning for animal welfare and the sustainability of our food production. That is why I urge the Commission to go much further than its initial proposal and completely ban the use of animal cloning in farms. I also call on our Member States to ensure that cloned animals, their offspring and products derived from them cannot be imported into our market. Rather than hurting farmers and consumers, these measures will benefit them, given that they reassert to the world our leading animal welfare and food standards. Thanks to the single market, the EU has the opportunity to answer citizens’ concerns, protect biodiversity and promote high global standards.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I support the ban on animal cloning. I'm a big opponent of that. I'm not so much interested in economic parameters, it's a purely ethical problem for me. The animal is simply not a thing, and it is clearly demonstrated that when cloned animals animals suffer extremely. I think that the European Union should go further in this matter, that we should really support a total ban on cloning and a total ban on imports of products from cloned animals. If we do not accept the ethical level that an animal is not a thing, that it cannot be arbitrarily disposed of, and if we do not treat animals decently, then I believe that we can hardly defend the concept of an advanced modern legal Europe. On the contrary, we should be addressing how to improve animal welfare in the future, how to treat animals better, rather than inventing ways to benefit more from them against nature. So I support further tightening of the rules in the future.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, I abstained in this vote on the basis that the Commission proposal and the proposed amendments do not reflect an adequate response to the issues around the cloning of animals. There are a wide range of concerns relating to animal welfare, scientific evidence, public perception, and the purpose of animal cloning, all of which need real and meaningful solutions. These must be based on science, labelling and public awareness, while ensuring that all imports reach EU standards and respect a level playing field for our farmers.  It is fair to say that this is a very emotive issue and we should continue to form an adequate solution. Europe has yet to strike a balance between public concern and science on a wide range of issues, not just animal cloning.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, honourable colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. I have also just voted in favour of such an important document, this report, because I believe that cloning is a subject where no answers have been given to all the questions. What seems to me to be the most dangerous aspect of this sector is that we must now stop, as the report says, the import of clones into the European Union and the import of technologies that allow the production of clones. Why do we have to do this, colleagues? Because we cannot risk the lives of our citizens of the European Union, and until scientists have given complete answers to all the questions, we cannot continue to move in this area without the scientific opinions. But, overall, I supported this report and believe that it is timely and extremely important for the European Union. Thank you!

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, we have just voted on the cloning of agricultural animals. Cloning technology has been invented, so the EU must have a response through legislation on this issue.  Since the question concerns highly developed creatures, animals, it requires very careful reflection and ethical and moral reflection. I want to give cloning technology a chance, but I do not want to cause animals suffering, so we need to think carefully about how to proceed. I voted in favour of a rather difficult compromise, as we all do, and this must be monitored in such a way as to guarantee animal welfare.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I, of course, also supported this report, because the ban on animal cloning is, in my view, entirely appropriate. If there are no convincing studies on the safety of food produced from cloned animals, then we must undoubtedly protect human health and animal welfare. However, I did not support an unconditional ban on cloning as regards valuable genetic material. I believe that, in this case, this prohibition may lead to problems in the agricultural sector, which may become uncompetitive, inefficient. And I think that European agriculture needs fundamental impetus for its further development. As regards the import and marketing of germ products from the descendants of animal clones, I think that we are too bound by our vision of a simple ban on animal cloning.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. Today, the European Parliament voted on a negotiating mandate on the cloning of animals. Cloning is a complex issue and, fundamentally, I believe that cloning should not occur on the European market. On the other hand, the legislative procedure needs to be done with caution and detailed analysis of possible consequences. The Commission has proposed temporary legislation with an evaluation mechanism, which is basically a good idea. However, the report before Parliament had been deleted and replaced by a call for the introduction of permanent legislation. The report also proposed the introduction of a ban on trade in meat from clones' offspring. Since the offspring of a clone do not differ dna-wise from a 'normal' animal, it would be a ban that becomes difficult to implement and could result in undesirable effects for third countries. I chose to vote against these problematic points and also the report as a whole, because the line I advocate was voted down. I would like to stress that this should not be interpreted as aid for the cloning of animals.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 A clear and decisive position had to be taken against the cloning of animals for agricultural purposes and this report allowed us to do so. Specifically, it is highlighted that several studies consider the consumption of food from cloned animals to be dangerous to human health. This is also in view of the fact that the long-term effects of prolonged human consumption are not known, since this is a relatively new practice and given the limited data to which reference can be made. I do not therefore believe that it is appropriate for european citizens to be the guinea pigs for experimentation. The report also highlights how, on the basis of EFSA's studies of cloned animals, the health and well-being of a significant proportion of clones has been compromised, often seriously and with lethal results. In addition, there is certainly the fact that the majority of EU citizens do not approve of cloning for agricultural purposes. This is, among other things, for animal welfare and ethical considerations. For these reasons and because of the strong 'no' to cloning that the Movement has always expressed, I voted in favour.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 I support the prohibition of the technique of cloning animals for livestock purposes, proposed by the European Commission, which includes animal clones and embryo clones. The European Parliament's report has some positive aspects, such as extending the ban to all farm species. However, it goes too far in a whole series of demands, which are very difficult to implement, the immediate consequence of which will be the blocking of negotiations with the Commission and the Council.  For this reason, I have decided that the meaning of my vote, at this first reading of the European Parliament, was abstention.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. At the moment, cloning is not being used for agricultural purposes in the EU. However, it is used in certain third countries, such as the United States, Canada, Argentina, Brazil and Australia. Cloning techniques call into question animal welfare. In addition, they pose ethical problems and give more power to large breeding industries in the face of conventional animal husbandling. This report by Parliament strengthens the Commission's proposal by taking a broader approach in all aspects related to cloning animals for breeding purposes. The objective is to address concerns about animal health and its well-being and the perception of consumers and ethical considerations regarding cloning techniques. The proposed amendments aim to implement effective and coherent regulation that responds to the legitimate concerns of the agricultural sector and European citizenship in general. That is why I voted in favour of this report

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The cloning of animals must be strictly prohibited due to moral concerns, as well as the effects on animal health and possible consequences for human health.
