Accordingly, I also voted in favour of a comprehensive ban on cloning, that is to say, a ban on the cloning of animals, the breeding material of cloned animals, their offspring and products, and the import of reproductive material, and supported the text put to the vote.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Commission recently proposed a directive temporarily banning the marketing of cloned animals and the products that come from them. This text has been extensively amended by the joint COMMITTEE AGRI-ENVI to broaden its scope and secure consumers.   It is a positive text. It transforms the directive into regulations, prohibits the importation of products from clones and their descendants, requires a certificate from exporters ensuring that their food products are in compliance with EU rules and sets up a traceability system. It also curbs the scope of TTIP by de facto blocking imports from the United States where cloning technology is permitted.  However, it has a major weakness: to date, there is no technical means to control whether a product is from a clone or not. To address this, our group proposed in plenary an amendment to ban all imports of products potentially affected by this opacity, because they come from herds raised in countries where cloning is exploited without any particular traceability.  Since the amendment did not obtain the required majority as we had hoped, I abstained on the whole text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report, as a matter of conscience on cloning.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to ban the cloning of animals and the marketing of their products. The new rules would prohibit the cloning, marketing and importation into the EU of animals kept for economic purposes. Cloning technology is characterised by high mortality, which raises animal welfare and ethical concerns, and I therefore support the proposal to tighten the ban and also apply it to the offspring of cloned animals. Given that some third countries allow the cloning of animals for farm purposes, the new rules would prohibit the import and marketing of these animals, their genetic material, offspring and food and feed produced from them. In its 2008 opinion on the cloning of animals, the European Food Safety Authority noted that the health and welfare of many cloned animals had a negative impact, which was often serious and had fatal consequences.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. As the amendments that our group had tabled were rejected, we consider that this text is insufficient and could not be supported as it stands. However, it can still be useful for restricting the trade in cloned animals, provided that exporters put in place a reliable traceability system. That is why I finally decided to abstain.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. This proposal for a regulation on the cloning of animals bred and reproduced for livestock purposes is aimed, inter alia, at ensuring the application of the same conditions to all those involved in the reproduction and distribution of animals and animal products throughout the Union. The outcome of the vote on the amendments prohibits third countries from importing animal clones among other restrictions by arguing, among other ethical reasons. Even if I agree on some point in the report, I voted against it because the restrictions do not live up to European needs and progress.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the cloning of animals raised and bred for agricultural purposes is intended to prohibit the marketing of products from the breeding of certain animals. This text is a step in the right direction and is a hindrance to imports from the United States. However, to date, there is no technical way to control whether a product is from a clone. Our ENF MEPs have amended the text to ensure the safety of European citizens and, in the absence of technical checks, it is preferable to suspend imports of products from countries that authorise the trade in cloned products.   I voted against this text because even if it puts some brakes on imports, there is still no real traceability of cloned products (certificates are guaranteed only on the good faith of breeders and there is no evidence that the products are not descendants of cloned animals). Our Amendment 56 was also not adopted on this point.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this text which, in relation to the Commission's proposal, makes the ban on cloning permanent, applies it to all species and also extends it to offspring and germ material, including imports from third countries by introducing a special traceability system.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 I support the prohibition of the technique of cloning animals for livestock purposes, proposed by the European Commission, which includes animal clones and embryo clones. The European Parliament's report has some positive aspects, such as extending the ban to all farm species. However, it goes too far in a whole series of demands, which are very difficult to implement, the immediate consequence of which will be the blocking of negotiations with the Commission and the Council.  For this reason, I have decided that the meaning of my vote, at this first reading of the European Parliament, was abstention.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it is against the cloning of bovine animals, swine, sheep, goats and equidae kept and bred for farm purposes. The European Commission has presented two legislative proposals on the cloning of animals for food. These proposals suspend the use of cloning technology for EU farm animals, the placing on the market of clones of live animals and embryo clones, as well as the marketing of foodstuffs (e.g. meat or milk) made from animal clones. Scientific studies have produced indisputable evidence that cloning animals pose a risk to animal welfare and is therefore currently prohibited for economic purposes in the European Union.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I was pleased to support the proposed report, as I believe that cloning of animals for agricultural purposes is controversial both for moral and ethical reasons and from the point of view of animal health and product safety. In addition, European consumers are also opposed to cloning. The European consumer knows very well what kind of food he wants on his plate; to know its origin and quality. In any event, it does not want food produced from cloned animals or their descendants, which this report takes full account of. I wonder what Kind of Europe we want to live in. If we're talking about animal cloning today, are we going to discuss cloning people tomorrow? This is a very important question! What we have adopted today is also a very clear signal to the negotiators in adopting the TTIP transatlantic investment agreement. And if, in the case of GMOs, we have given responsibility to countries for their own to be able to identify themselves, we need to give a single signal from Europe when cloning. Today's debate confirmed the European position, which is a negative attitude towards cloning animals for agricultural purposes. And this position follows the one adopted by the European Parliament with the recent amendment of the Directive on the restriction or prohibition of the cultivation of genetically modified organisms. Therefore, EU negotiators must also take this position actively and substantively into account when negotiating the TTIP agreement.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this directive because the vast majority of EU citizens do not want to eat any meat grown with cloning technology. That is why a Proposal from the European Commission prohibiting cloned but allowing meat from the offspring of cloned animals is unacceptable. Such food should also be prohibited or, at the very least, clearly and unequivocally labelled. The European consumer knows what he wants, but also what he does not want, and that is why I call on the European Commission to listen to the voice of its citizens.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. With regard to this report, I abstained on the final vote of this text. Indeed, traceability is not sufficient for consumer protection.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which contained a number of important provisions, specifically in relation to the substantial animal welfare concerns with cloning. The resolution was seeking to extend a ban on animal cloning to include the cloning of all farm animals, their descendants and products derived from them. The ban will include any imported animal products derived from cloning methods. This cloning ban is very important because cloning leads to cruelty to animals and moreover, there are general ethical issues surrounding cloning methods. Moreover, a majority of EU citizens strongly oppose the consumption of food from animal clones. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I am convinced that the cloning technique presents many critical issues and, in general, that its use does not bring sufficient benefits to compensate for them. In particular, the low success rate of the procedure and the ethical dilemma of its use are the two most important obstacles to its introduction into the single market.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The animal cloning techniques currently in use are not mature enough to allow industrial use of the technique. The high costs, the high number of birth deaths, the large size of foetuses and the consequent difficulties in the parts, together with the numerous physical anomalies and frequent health problems of cloned animals are a sign of the difficulty of mastering the cloning technique. Furthermore, animal cloning frequently causes unnecessary suffering to the animals themselves and raises doubts about its complete safety for human food use. Instead, the Eu ropean Union must protect the health of its citizens and animals and promote a culture of healthy and high-quality food. Parliament – having also taken note of the opposition to human cloning of 80% of European citizens (Source Eurobarometer) – must, loudly and unanimously, protect the right to research and safeguard endangered species, but ban animal cloning for food purposes and prevent trade in products from cloned animals or their offspring.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The proposed directive put to the vote of the European Parliament aims to ban the marketing of products from the breeding of animals reproduced using cloning technology. Faced with the scientific information available (animal welfare, food safety or the interest of technology), the Commission has proposed to "temporarily" ban the marketing of cloned animals and the products derived from them. Although I am in favour of the Commission's initiative because it can potentially put a brake on imports from the United States, where cloning technology has been used for a few years, I find that European consumers do not have sufficient guarantees on the origin of the product: there are currently no technical means to control whether a product is cloning. However, this perspective offers little security.  That's why I abstained.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour: the proposal voted on makes the ban permanent, applies it to all species and also extends it to offspring and germ material, including imports from third countries by introducing a specific traceability system.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 I support the prohibition of the technique of cloning animals for livestock purposes, proposed by the European Commission, which includes animal clones and embryo clones. The European Parliament's report has some positive aspects, such as extending the ban to all farm species. However, it goes too far in a whole series of demands, which are very difficult to implement, the immediate consequence of which will be the blocking of negotiations with the Commission and the Council.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I am opposed to cloning for food in the European Union. As things stand, scientific research in this area does not allow us to be persuaded of the results of cloning. With this text, Parliament adopts a strong position against cloning and thus reinforces the Commission's proposal to do so. Cloned animals, their descendants and breeding materials will not be allowed on European soil. Of course, to ensure this, a realistic and reliable traceability system will have to be put in place. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of strengthening the Commission's initial proposal to ban animal cloning, including the cloning of all farm animals, their descendants and products derived from them, including imports into the European Union. We must take into account the impact on animal health, but also on human health. This vote sends a message to our trading partners that we are not prepared to put our health, the health of our families and future generations at stake, using products of dubious quality of this kind. The cloning technique is not fully mature and no further progress has in fact been made. The mortality rate remains just as high. Many of the animals that are born alive, die in the first weeks, and die painfully. I do not therefore think it is appropriate to allow this. The majority of EU citizens are strongly opposed to the consumption of food derived from cloned animals or their offspring, and disapprove of the use of cloning for agricultural purposes, due to considerations on animal welfare and general ethical standards. The concerns of European citizens must therefore be taken seriously.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which contained a number of important provisions, specifically in relation to the substantial animal welfare concerns with cloning. The resolution was seeking to extend a ban on animal cloning to include the cloning of all farm animals, their descendants and products derived from them. The ban will include any imported animal products derived from cloning methods. This cloning ban is very important because cloning leads to cruelty to animals and moreover, there are general ethical issues surrounding cloning methods. Moreover, a majority of EU citizens strongly oppose the consumption of food from animal clones. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report, as a matter of conscience on cloning.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agreed with and voted in favour of the report by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) and the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (AGRI) on the Commission proposal, which shows that people are still uncomfortable with consuming food resulting from cloned animals.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Giulia Moi's report because the parliamentary text reinforces the European Commission's initial proposal to ban animal cloning, including the cloning of all farm animals, their descendants and products derived from them, including imports into the European Union. The health of all European citizens and the preservation of environmental diversity must be protected by private financial interests.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which makes the Commission's proposal a good way, in particular by strengthening the ban on the cloning technique of animals for consumption in Europe.  I consider that the suspension of the cloning technique for food purposes benefits consumers and contributes to animal welfare. At present, no one can know its consequences on human health, while much scientific research has indicated the suffering it causes in animals.  In this context, an extension of the ban on the marketing of foodstuffs from descendants of cloned animals seems to me to be sensible.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this legislation because I do not believe it will help animal welfare, but instead will only limit research while adding costs for our farmers. Currently, there is no cloned animal meat being sold and this is not likely in the near future. We do not want to make our farmers, who are already in crisis, now have to pay for the introduction of an unworkable traceability system for a problem that does not exist. This is just a waste of money and more red tape without increasing animal welfare.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote because, on the one hand, this text slows down the flow of imports from the United States, which is a brake on the extent of TTIP.  However, to date, there is no technical way to control whether a product is from a clone.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 With this report the message is clear. We have no intention of endangering the health of our families and subsequent generations by consuming products of questionable quality. It is well known that the cloning technique has not been fully developed and no progress has been made in this area, and mortality rates remain very high. The report therefore rightly lists the concerns and calls on the Commission to take the necessary measures.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal concerning the cloning of animals reared and reproduced for agricultural purposes. Cloning is a form of asexual reproduction carried out in the laboratory in which animals are generated using the genetic heritage of another animal's cell. The animal clone therefore shares the same genetic heritage as the donor. Cloning for breeding purposes, which is not used in the European Union, is in use in countries such as the USA, Canada, Argentina, Brazil and Australia. This proposal suspends the use of cloning for agricultural purposes, the placing on the market of clones of living animals and the marketing of food, such as milk and meat, from cloned animals.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this proposal for a directive because I found it too restrictive. I believe, in fact, that certain innovations with a strong ethical impact must be used cum grano salis, and not stop at all so as not to return to the Middle Ages. And, above all, that practical sense should guide political choices: I do not believe that the work of farmers should be weighed down by the mandatory keeping of additional registers to certify that there are no cloned elements in each animal's genealogical line. Progress cannot be stopped, but it must be governed in order to use it for good and not to increase bureaucracy.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I am not prepared to jeopardise our own health, the health of our families and that of future generations by allowing products whose consequences we do not know! Animal cruelty must be put to an end. And it is our job to respect the will of consumers who are strongly opposed to cloning and the consumption of food derived from cloned animals and their offspring.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is an attempt to impose a blanket prohibition by means of an EU regulation on 500 million people which will have an impact on long-term competitiveness at a time when people need productivity and jobs.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of a total ban on the marketing of animal clones, embryonic clones and foodstuffs intended for human consumption from animal clones and their offspring. It is a question of precaution, as well as concern about possible ethical implications, but also of compliance with animal health and welfare rules. The cloning technique is also aggravated by the fact that none of the third countries has set up reliable traceability and labelling or identification and registration systems for importation with regard to clone offspring or the food they produce. Furthermore, there are no international standards for sanitary and phytosanitary measures in relation to cloning, let alone scientific studies on the effects on human health of prolonged consumption of food resulting from animal cloning. Finally, I can only reiterate the importance of taking due account of public opinion which is opposed to animal cloning and the consumption of food from cloned animals.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE)
text: Written. This week, the European Parliament voted on a negotiating mandate on the cloning of animals for livestock production. Cloning is a complex issue. It is important not to disregard animal welfare. However, the proposal voted on by the European Parliament contains major problems concerning WTO agreements and other trade-related aspects. Furthermore, solving the traceability problem technically is not possible given that cloned animals have identical DNA to the original animal. Mr M. therefore chose to vote against, as the proposal is not feasible and risks leading to major trade policy implications.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. At the moment, cloning is not being used for agricultural purposes in the EU. However, it is used in certain third countries, such as the United States, Canada, Argentina, Brazil and Australia. Cloning techniques call into question animal welfare. In addition, they pose ethical problems and give more power to large breeding industries in the face of conventional animal husbandling. This report by Parliament strengthens the Commission's proposal by taking a broader approach in all aspects related to cloning animals for breeding purposes. The objective is to address concerns about animal health and its well-being and the perception of consumers and ethical considerations regarding cloning techniques. The proposed amendments aim to implement effective and coherent regulation that responds to the legitimate concerns of the agricultural sector and European citizenship in general. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the People's Party position, I supported with my vote a parliamentary report on the prohibition of cloning animals kept and propagated for agricultural purposes. The EP report welcomes the Commission's proposal for a directive on the prohibition of cloning of farm animals, but makes further additions to it. The subject of cloning is of great concern to EU citizens and cloning technology itself raises a number of issues, including animal health and ethical issues.  That is why parliament's report is important, as it proposes stricter and more transparent rules not only for cloned animals, but also for meat and other food products from the offspring of cloned animals. Parliament's text extends the cloning ban, unlike the Commission's proposal, not only to bovine animals, domestic pig breeds, ovine and caprine animals and equidae, but also to all farm animals. Parliament intends to respond to the concerns expressed by EU citizens about cloning techniques with these proposals.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which deals with the prohibition on cloning animals for farming purposes in the EU and also the prohibition on the import of cloned animals from outside the EU. I am not in favour of products from the cloning of animals or their descendants, and this applies also to imports. As I support banning the cloning of all animals, their descendants, and products from them, including imports, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes a ban on the marketing of animals, their germ products and foodstuffs from these animals within the European Union. This ban also applies to imports to the European Union, with the introduction of a traceability system. I fully support the principle of this strict and definitive ban, which nevertheless allows an exemption for basic research in this area and for rare or endangered breeds. Nevertheless, I would like to express reservations about extending the ban to the descendants of cloned animals, their germ products and the foodstuffs from those animals. Indeed, I am convinced that such a traceability system, particularly with regard to the exports of descendants and their products, will be extremely difficult to implement and will be subject to fraud by third countries. Despite this reservation, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. By this vote, Parliament confirmed its desire to ban the cloning of animals raised and reproduced for agricultural purposes. In order to ensure the best protection for European consumers, we do not want cloning to be used for food purposes. We must ensure maximum transparency and traceability on the origin of the meat consumed in our territory. I welcome this decision to ban the marketing of food from clone animals. It benefits European citizens and protects animal welfare.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Science develops at a fast rate. Not so long ago an IVF procedure was a risky issue and the success rate was very low. Due to continually deepening and improving our scientific knowledge, we have managed to significantly improve this technique, helping many parents that have fertility problems. I voted against this report because I believe we need to be able to develop our science. In addition, the evidence that we have at the moment does not show a significant adversely impact on health. Low efficiency rates are exactly a reason to develop our science, rather than to tie its hands.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) has repeatedly pointed out that the health and well-being of a significant proportion of animal clones has often been seriously and fatally compromised. In particular, abnormalities in clones and unusually large dimensions of cloned fetuses cause difficult parts and deaths at birth. I voted in favour of this measure banning the cloning of animals for food purposes in the European Union because I believe it is essential that European consumers should not risk having food from a cloned animal or its descendants on their plates.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. This text aims to ban cloning for the purpose of raising and supplying food to farm animals and thus marketing them on the territory of the European Union. It reinforces the European Commission's initial proposal by extending the marketing ban to offspring of farm animals and by-products. The technique of cloning has not yet been proven and its effects on human and animal health remain poorly evaluated. It was therefore legitimate for our parliament to be in compliance with the precautionary principle and to ban these products on its soil.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution, which sends a strong signal. Indeed, we voted in favour of a ban on cloning for food purposes. This is only the first step, we are now entering into negotiations with the Council. We know that today European citizens do not want to consume cloned animals and the cloning techniques that are still too poorly controlled have caused unnecessary suffering for animals. However, I would like to draw attention to traceability throughout the chain, which remains problematic. Indeed, labelling remains complicated to implement from a technical and scientific point of view. It is now difficult beyond the second generation to determine with certainty whether the meat is originally a clone or not. So let us be careful not to put in place a legislative system that is too cumbersome that we will not be able to bear.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of banning the cloning of animals raised and bred for agricultural purposes in the European Union. This ban applies to possible imports of milk and meat from cloned animals since the European Union does not market this type of product on its territory. On the other hand, it imports 300,000 tonnes of beef per year and in the absence of a traceability system in countries where cloning technology is permitted, it is impossible to know the share of cloning in imported products. The Commission wants to limit the marketing ban to the cloned animal itself. I believe that we need to go further and extend the ban to the descendants of cloned animals, germ products (embryos and semen) and products derived from them such as meat or milk. By voting for this ban by a large majority, Parliament sends the signal that consumer protection must take precedence over the financial interests of certain producers.

name: Jørn Dohrmann (ECR)
text: Written. Research shows that cloning techniques are still at a technological stage where in several cases the animals involved suffer physical cargo during the processes themselves, with many of the clones being created with abnormalities and too many animals involved in the processes. In addition, cloning gives rise to ethical issues. I believe that technology helps to objectualise animals, which is reduced more to things rather than being regarded as the living creatures of nature. It cannot be a human duty to contribute to such manipulation of nature in favour of trade and occupation. Finally, we still know very little about how cloned foods and foods derived from the offspring of clones affect human health.     The proposal provides for a sufficient distancing for cloning in commercial agriculture, while still allowing room for this technology in research contexts that may prove useful in the future of science. This is a good political balancing act, which I am happy to support.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The trade in cloned animals is not desirable. As I pointed out in the plenary debate, the technique of cloning animals raised for agricultural purposes is a significant risk to the independence of our agriculture and to biodiversity. The genetic models of these animals will eventually be owned by a small number of companies whose very small species will invade the market. The consequence will therefore be the homogenization of our species bovine, swine, sheep, goats and equines. The "best of worlds" also has an agricultural translation, that of the total loss of contact with nature, reality and biodiversity. The proposed report supports the directive of Parliament and the Council which goes in the direction of restricting the cloning of animals. However, traceability and trade restrictions are not satisfactory, which is why I abstained.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against, because this report only superficially turns against cloning, leaves too many windows and has deliberate omissions so that, in the end, food derived from cloned animals ends up on the market.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of parliament's report on the draft legislation on the prohibition of cloning. As a Hungarian MEP, it is of the utmost importance to me that Hungarian and European consumers eat safe and high-quality food. Cloning, as it is a completely new technique in food production, can also pose serious health risks, as the scientific findings that guarantee safety are so far less knowledgeable, which we know is not sufficiently convincing. On the other hand, I agree with my fellow Members that cloning leads to unnecessary suffering and pain on farmed animals, which must be avoided. This is clearly required by EU animal welfare legislation. I agree with the further restrictions contained in the parliamentary report. In addition to the placing on the market of clones, the use and import for agricultural purposes of propagating material (semen, ova, zygote) from the first generation of offspring and the placing on the market of food derived from these animals within the EU should be prohibited. It is a great success for me that the extension of the ban to feeds made up of cloned animals has also been adopted.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this regulation because it prohibits the use and marketing of cloned animals and their offspring. With our vote, we have allowed the ban on the use of cloning for the production of animals for agricultural purposes to become permanent, and not transitional as proposed by the European Commission, by means of a review clause to be used in the event that advances in scientific research require an update of EU legislation. To date, in fact, the success rate of experiments is only 10%, while the mortality rate is high and many animals are born with malformations or immune problems, only to die early. We have also decided that the ban should apply to the marketing of products from cloned animals or their offspring and that the EU should provide for clear labelling in this regard, in order to ensure the traceability of products. For these purposes, we have chosen the regulation as a legislative instrument, not a directive, so as to ensure that in such a sensitive area there are equal rules in all Member States.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. I fully support the Commission's proposal to ban the cloning of animals and the sale of products from cloned animals on the European market. There are clear animal health problems with the procedure, and until these problems are resolved, a ban should apply. It is very problematic, as the rapporteurs would like to extend the ban to the progeny of cloned animals. There are already a number of offspring of cloned animals in Europe, and there are no health problems in these animals. The proposal also poses major problems for imports from third countries. The rapporteurs have adopted a position that is very far removed from the Council's position and, moreover, far from what is practicable. This will make further discussions very problematic and risk halting the whole legislative process. The likely outcome of Parliament's decision is that the area remains completely unregulated. As a negotiator for the Liberal Group, I pursued a line that was a return to the Commission's proposal, and I have also chosen in the final vote to vote against the proposal.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report proposes new rules to prohibit cloning of all species of animals for agricultural purposes and the importation of food and other products, such as semen and embryos, from those animals or their descendants. The aim is to address concerns related to animal health and welfare, consumer perceptions and ethical considerations regarding the cloning technique. I would argue that these rules should apply to all species of animals kept and reproduced for agricultural purposes, and not only to cattle, pigs, sheep, goats and equidae, as provided for in the Commission proposal.

name: Christofer Fjellner (PPE)
text: Written. This week, the European Parliament voted on a negotiating mandate on the cloning of animals for livestock production. Cloning is a complex issue. It is important not to disregard animal welfare. However, the proposal voted on by the European Parliament contains major problems concerning WTO agreements and other trade-related aspects. Furthermore, solving the traceability problem technically is not possible given that cloned animals have identical DNA to the original animal. Mr M. therefore chose to vote against, as the proposal is not feasible and risks leading to major trade policy implications.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Cloning animals bred and reproduced for farming purposes is a very sensitive subject for the European Union. In several surveys, the inhabitants of the Member States have expressed their opposition to cloning, because they do not see any positive benefits in this mode of reproduction that it brings and consider it dangerous. Although cloning is currently not used in the European Union, it is used in some other countries, such as the USA, Canada, Brazil or Australia. The European Commission must respond to the concerns of the citizens of the Member States and suspend the use of cloning techniques in the European Union for livestock and the placing on the market of live clones. Meat and milk from animal clones must not reach consumers. The european Commission's proposal presented seeks progress, but avoids specific and specific provisions for food produced from descendants of cloned animals.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the changes which fortunately the ENVI Committee brings to the Commission's text. Make the ban on cloning permanent, apply it to all species and extend it to offspring as well.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the cloning of animals reared and bred for agricultural purposes. This report only superficially turns against cloning, leaves too many windows open and its omissions are deliberate, so that food derived from cloned animals will eventually end up on the market.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We all know that animal cloning is a hazard for animal welfare. It leads to placental and foetal abnormalities resulting in poor welfare for offspring and dams used for cloning, and often substantial pain for the latter. Cloning treats animals as commodities, not as sentient beings, and is associated with great animal suffering at all stages of the process. The negative effects of cloning, inter alia on animal welfare and on food security, greatly outweigh any possible positive effects: thus, the use of descendants of clones is simply not acceptable. Therefore, I strongly support the prohibition of cloning of animals in the EU and I believe that the use of cloning and the placing on the market of the corresponding products should be prohibited until further scientific progress is made.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Currently, cloning is not used for agricultural purposes in the European Union. However, certain third countries make use of this possibility, including the United States, Canada, Argentina, Brazil and Australia. Cloning may be used, for example, for the reproduction of breeding animals with excellent characteristics. A wealth of scientific studies have shown that animal cloning is risky for animal welfare.  Cloning is an issue that is of great concern to European citizens: a Eurobarometer survey carried out in 2010 showed that, according to European public opinion, animal cloning offers no benefits, is unsafe, fairly and is of concern, and only 18% of respondents supported this technique. In line with the rapporteurs' views, I am also of the opinion that the negative consequences of cloning, inter alia, on animal welfare are incomparably greater than any possible positive impact. I therefore welcome the ban put forward by the Commission on cloning techniques, but I believe that the proposal has failed to adequately respond to the legitimate concerns expressed once again by citizens and the European Parliament.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 I support the prohibition of the technique of cloning animals for livestock purposes, proposed by the European Commission, which includes animal clones and embryo clones. The European Parliament's report has some positive aspects, such as extending the ban to all farm species. However, it goes too far in a whole series of demands, which are very difficult to implement, the immediate consequence of which will be the blocking of negotiations with the Commission and the Council.  For this reason, I have decided that the meaning of my vote, at this first reading of the European Parliament, was abstention.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I have decided that the meaning of my vote, at this first reading of the European Parliament, was abstention because, although I support the European Parliament's ban on the technique of cloning animals for livestock purposes proposed by the European Commission, which includes clones of animals and clones of embryos, the European Parliament's report has some positive aspects (such as extending the ban to all farm species) , but however, it goes too far in a whole series of demands, which are very difficult to implement, the immediate consequence of which will be the blocking of negotiations with the Commission and the Council.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's vote represents an important step in the long battle that, as Italians, we have been carrying on for years. We are determined to defend European food safety standards. With this text, we have shown that we do not want to compromise, dismissing the idea of less restrictive measures, such as labelling or the extension of the provisional moratorium. We must, however, remain extremely vigilant so that the important measures taken today are not diluted during the next steps.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I agree with the considerations represented in the draft joint report by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy on animal cloning for agricultural purposes. Europe protects European food safety standards, the health of its citizens and the welfare of animals themselves, renewing with its vote today its clear ban on the cloning of farm animals and the importation of products derived from cloned livestock within the EU by third countries.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP's position on the Parliament and Council directive on the ban on the cloning of bovine, pig, sheep, goat and equine animals reared and reproduced for agricultural purposes. I believe, in fact, that the technique of animal cloning for agricultural reproduction, used in the United States and other third countries, must be categorically banned in Europe. This is demanded by our citizens, who are concerned about their nutrition and the quality of our products, as demonstrated by the 2010 Eurobarometer survey. This is demanded by farmers in those territories who conduct their activities by combining quality and tradition. Finally, the animals themselves are asking for this, given the scientific evidence showing that this technique generates placental and foetal abnormalities that involve poor well-being and pain for mothers used for cloning or offspring. In its position, Parliament affirms its firm support for animal cloning for agricultural purposes, which extends to imports of cloned animals, germ production or products from cloned animals. We call on the Commission to present, within the framework of the legislation on official controls, labelling measures and control procedures to prevent imports of these products and to ensure compulsory traceability.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the cloning of animals that are held and reproduced for agricultural purposes because, for bioethical and moral reasons, as well as respect for creation, I am strongly opposed to the technique of cloning and expressly welcome a large-scale, indefinite ban on cloning in the EU.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I am clearly against animal cloning. I also reject the import of cloned animals and their descendants. Clear limits must be set here.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. The subject of cloning is a scientific topic on which I am not an expert. Therefore, I would rather trust them than pass legislation based on "ethical" reasons that rather seem religious. According to the European Food Safety Authority and the European Commission, an institution that brings together expert professionals in the areas on which it proposes legislative initiatives, animal cloning poses problems because of the pain inflicted on the animal, but not for food security reasons. We have therefore decided in the Liberal group to vote against Parliament's report because we prefer the scientific approach present in the Commission's original proposal, which leads to a ban on both cloning and importing cloned animals, but does not extend this prohibition beyond what is scientifically reasonable, as the report we voted on today does.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I personally do not object to animal cloning in principle. I do believe however, that the disproportionate call for a permanent ban could be damaging, since this is based on a big, overarching assumption that cloning can only lead to bad things. What about the possibilities that cloning and scientific advance can lead to an improvement in animal welfare?  This report not only disregards evidence-based decision-making in several fundamental aspects; a principle I strongly believe should be at the heart of all EU policymaking, but given the current animal welfare issues identified in the European Food Safety Authority’s 2008 opinion, this report also fails to account for the fact that these animal welfare issues could be significantly alleviated in the future.  Moreover, as an impact assessment of the proposed traceability system is yet to be conducted, it remains very unclear whether such a mechanism can even be effective. I therefore view this report as legally unenforceable and subsequently wholly ineffective as a piece of legislation.  I am consequently disappointed that my fellow elected representatives have been so absolute in the opinions and it is for these reasons that I voted against.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report because we want to make it clear that we are strongly opposed to cloning animals for food purposes. In addition, we would like to take the opportunity of this debate to go a little further and highlight another aspect that we find even more momentous. Because if there is one thing that really concerns us, it is the extension of highly technified agriculture and livestock, which is based on large capital investments and which entails energy costs that only mean irreparable mistreatment of our land. The use of animal cloning for food purposes or the use of GMOs as animal feed poses a danger, especially since they give greater power to large corporations and leave farmers who care for and respect the land helpless. In the face of this, we are committed to a living rural world, which is based on those farmers and ranchers who generate decent employment, who are able to give us high quality products, who understand that what is really important is respect for natural cycles and who also generate a rich and sustainable economic sector over time.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on cloning of animals kept and reproduced for farming purposes, because a regulation is necessary on an issue so important for public health and animal welfare, not a directive. The European Commission's proposal is not sufficient. I supported the report by Mrs Moi and Mr Sommer because I consider it necessary to introduce a permanent ban and to extend its scope to include the offspring of cloned animals, food and feed derived from them and biological material used for the reproduction of clones and their offspring. Most citizens in my country do not want food from cloned products on their tables. That is why, as a member Polish, I voted in favour of this report, which, in my opinion, proposes better solutions than the Commission's proposal.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs stand firmly against the use of cloning, cloned animals and their offspring. I voted in favour of the report which will in effect benefit EU farmers, food producers and consumers by reinforcing the global outreach of Europe’s leading animal welfare and food standards. Furthermore, by pursuing a requirement of traceability and labelling, the EU would be able to inflict significant pressure on our partners in any trade negotiations, including TTIP.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report because it must close the door to cloning for food in Europe. Most European citizens do not want cloned animals on their plates. Moreover, the technique of cloning is still poorly controlled, it causes a lot of suffering for animals, and its consequences on human health remain unknown. There is therefore no argument for animal cloning for food purposes. That is why I am very pleased with this decision by the European Parliament, which reinforces the Commission's ban. It provides for a ban not only on the marketing of foodstuffs from cloned animals, but also on food products from the descendants of these animals. The importation of cloned animals and meat derived from these animals will also be prohibited, as will the importation of food from their descendants.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 I support the prohibition of the technique of cloning animals for livestock purposes, proposed by the European Commission, which includes animal clones and embryo clones. The European Parliament's report has some positive aspects, such as extending the ban to all farm species. However, it goes too far in a whole series of demands, which are very difficult to implement, the immediate consequence of which will be the blocking of negotiations with the Commission and the Council.  For this reason, I have decided that the meaning of my vote, at this first reading of the European Parliament, was abstention.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted to ban all forms of food products from cloning in Europe, which means that all imports will be banned. In this case, it was a question of expressing my concerns about food security, and saying no to the animal suffering caused by cloning techniques and not to the excessive artificialization of livestock. As a Socialist and a Democrat, listening to European citizens, it is indeed essential for me to fight for the protection of human health, the environment, the welfare of animals as well as genetic diversity. That is why, with this vote, I supported the measures to call on eu trading partners to put in place instruments for traceability of cloning products in order to prevent their entry into Europe.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the proposal for a directive to ban the cloning of animals which are kept and reproduced for farming purposes. I believe that the cloning ban might be the reason for the stagnation in the progress of science and it might also threaten the improvement in animal welfare. Moreover, according to the report of the European Food Safety Authority, there is absolutely no evidence to justify food safety concerns – food from cloned animals is exactly the same as food from conventionally bred animals. Therefore, the question is whether the extensive ban would or would not harm the businesses. Hence, the cloning ban might even force many small businesses into providing extensive documentation and could threaten the import of meat and dairy products from countries that allow cloning for agricultural purposes in general. These are the main arguments which gave me the grounds to vote against this proposal.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 I support the prohibition of the technique of cloning animals for livestock purposes, proposed by the European Commission, which includes animal clones and embryo clones. The European Parliament's report has some positive aspects, such as extending the ban to all farm species. However, it goes too far in a whole series of demands, which are very difficult to implement, the immediate consequence of which will be the blocking of negotiations with the Commission and the Council.  For this reason, I have decided that the meaning of my vote, at this first reading of the European Parliament, was abstention.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The report aims at a complete ban on the cloning of animals for agricultural purposes within the EU and at a corresponding ban on imports. There are differing opinions within the EU, so this issue should be discussed and decided at national level. The report goes so far as to call for a regulation instead of a directive. I reject the report on the grounds of subsidiarity and believe that we should not put obstacles in the way of this innovative technology. Incidentally , and this is my ceterum censeo – I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report because I believe the proposal made by the Commission should go much further and completely ban the use of cloning in animal production for farm purposes. I believe it should take the form of a regulation.  Such a prohibition is necessary and in line with the expectations of the public and their concerns about animal welfare conditions and threats to biodiversity. We are demanding that all animals imported into the EU are proven not to be clones or descendants of cloned animals. We need to be confident that no food or germinal products derived from clones are imported into the EU.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. These proposals aim to suspend the use of cloning technology for livestock on EU territory, the marketing of cloned animals or live cloned embryos and the marketing of food from cloned animals.  I share the conviction that we must continue to ban the importation of cloned animals and meat products derived from these animals and destined for food. This is a strong demand from our citizens and we hear them.  Indeed, the lack of necessary recoil on the effects of cloning requires the utmost vigilance. We have already seen, for example, that cloning techniques are often poorly controlled and affect animal welfare. It is for these reasons that I have decided to support the resolution. However, I would urge caution with regard to the traceability of cloned animals, which is becoming difficult beyond the second generation. Apart from the risk of legislative inflation that is often blamed on the EU, how can we actually ensure that the milk in cheese imported from Argentina does not come from a cloned cow?

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome today’s vote, which hugely adds to the Commission's original proposal. There are huge consumer concerns with regard to the cloning process and it is right that experiments in this technology are kept well away from the food chain.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report because we want to make it clear that we are strongly opposed to cloning animals for food purposes. In addition, we would like to take the opportunity of this debate to go a little further and highlight another aspect that we find even more momentous. Because if there is one thing that really concerns us, it is the extension of highly technified agriculture and livestock, which is based on large capital investments and which entails energy costs that only mean irreparable mistreatment of our land. The use of animal cloning for food purposes or the use of GMOs as animal feed poses a danger, especially since they give greater power to large corporations and leave farmers who care for and respect the land helpless. In the face of this, we are committed to a living rural world, which is based on those farmers and ranchers who generate decent employment, who are able to give us high quality products, who understand that what is really important is respect for natural cycles and who also generate a rich and sustainable economic sector over time.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a directive from Parliament and the Council on cloning cattle, pigs, sheep, goats and equines held and bred for production purposes, as I oppose any type of animal cloning for a number of reasons. First of all, it is still not known what are the consequences of consuming this type of meat for the human body, and such procedures are unacceptable and on the ethical side.  In addition, there are still no significant developments in animal welfare, as animal cloning has been shown to cause a large range of health problems.  In addition, I also support a ban on imports of cloned animal products.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Commission recently proposed a directive temporarily banning the marketing of cloned animals and the products that come from them. This text has been extensively amended by the joint COMMITTEE AGRI-ENVI to broaden its scope and secure consumers.  It is a positive text. It transforms the directive into regulations, prohibits the importation of products from clones and their descendants, requires a certificate from exporters ensuring that their food products are in compliance with EU rules and sets up a traceability system. It also curbs the scope of TTIP by de facto blocking imports from the United States where cloning technology is permitted. However, it has a major weakness: to date, there is no technical means to control whether a product is from a clone or not. To address this, our group proposed in plenary an amendment to ban all imports of potentially affected products, as they come from herds raised in countries where cloning is exploited without any particular traceability. Since the amendment did not obtain the required majority as we had hoped, I abstained on the whole text.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the cloning of animals raised and bred for agricultural purposes. This vote must definitely close the door to cloning for food in Europe, which I welcome. Indeed, the technique is still poorly controlled, its consequences on human health remain poorly known and it raises questions in terms of animal suffering. However, I believe that the question of traceability throughout the chain must remain open, remaining realistic and pragmatic in light of current techniques and the state of science.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which strictly prohibits the marketing of cloned animals, their germs and foodstuffs from those animals, as well as those from foodstuffs from the descendants of these animals. As the consequences on human health are unknown, it is important to protect the consumer and ensure animal welfare.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: in writing. – As we have already agreed in the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, cloning basically should be prohibited in the European market. Scientific studies showed that cloning leads to malformations of the animal’s uterus and foetus. We cannot know for certain whether food from cloned species will be dangerous to human health or not. Moreover, the question of traceability poses serious technical difficulties, especially to farmers, who would certainly need to bear additional costs for keeping track of cloned animals’ descendants. That is a heavy burden, both financially and administratively. Other doubts are raised in connection with ethics and religious beliefs: cloning interferes in animal welfare and rises moral questions. Animals should be treated as sentient beings, not a commodity. Our task, as politicians, is to represent our citizens. European consumers do not like the idea of cloning, and, what is more, the idea of producing food from cloned animals. Therefore, we reject the proposal.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of the report as it raises many criticisms and represents an improvement on the current legal situation. These include the inclusion of a ban on cloned meat in future free trade agreements, the obligation to trace cloned animals, a permanent ban on cloned meat and a ban on imports from third countries if the origin is not clearly established.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Cloning animals raises concerns and question among European citizens: up to 80% of them, out of ethical, moral and animal welfare considerations, do not support animal cloning. Scientific research does not take enough account of the ethical considerations and problems. Animal cloning is not only cruel treatment of animals; it could also pose a risk for future generations that we cannot predict today. I am in favour of banning all animal cloning, but especially animal cloning for agricultural purposes. It is our duty to guarantee fully not only animal welfare but also food security, and to avoid any harm to human health.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully supported the report and very much welcome its adoption in the European Parliament. I am pleased that Parliament has gone further than the initial proposal by the Commission. I believe that such a prohibition is necessary. It is in line with concerns about the welfare conditions of cloned animals, threats to biodiversity and the current situation in the European agricultural sector, which does not need to resort to cloning in animal reproduction. It will also benefit EU farmers, food producers and consumers by reinforcing the global outreach of Europe’s leading animal welfare and food standards. The Commission and the authorities of the Member States must now enforce this ban, which should apply to the entire EU market.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The Summer/Moi report aims at a complete ban on the cloning of animals for agricultural purposes within the EU, as well as a ban on imports. I do share the concerns about cloning for agriculture for animal health reasons at the current state of research. However, consumers in the EU Member States are different in their attitude to these products, so we are calling for regulation at a deeper organisational level. The certification of products produced without the use of clones would give consumers the choice. The Commission itself doubts its competence. This can be seen from the fact that it is based only on the 'rubber paragraph 352' TFEU in the grounds of the proposal. The Moi Sommer report goes even further by calling for a regulation instead of a directive. In this way, the report is further shifting responsibility towards the European level. I therefore reject the report on grounds of subsidiarity.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because it means a clear 'no' to cloning and the placing on the market of food from cloned animals. We do not need cloning technology in Europe! Our agricultural production, our breeding methods and the food supply function sufficiently. We do not need disease-prone gene copies!

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the draft directive on the ban on the marketing of products from cloned animals in Europe. European citizens are overwhelmingly in favour of this ban, while the consequences of the consumption of this type of product on humans are still unknown and cloning techniques cause significant suffering for animals. That is why the EPP Group voted in favour of this ban, which was the position of a majority of MEPs in Strasbourg. We cannot afford to compromise on the quality of food for European citizens.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. The cloning of animals had caused the "new food" regulation to fail for the first time. It was therefore agreed to return to it in a specific text. The Commission proposes to "temporarily" ban the marketing of cloned animals and the products derived from them.  This text is welcome because it will put a de facto brake on imports from the United States, so it is a blow to the extent of TTIP. As originally presented by the Commission, the proposal was a benefit to US livestock (banning technology in the EU but not imports).  However, there is a major problem: to date, there is no technical way to control whether a product is from a clone. We can only "bet" on the good faith of exporters. However, there is little legal certainty in this perspective.  Cloning has been exploited for several years without any particular traceability, the American herd (but also Argentinian, Australian, Japanese ...) is today "contaminated" immeasurably.  We abstain because our amendments to ensure the safety of European citizens have not accepted: without a technical check, we prefer to suspend imports of products. Vote abstention

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text because the amendment of our ENF group (on the restriction of trade with countries authorising cloning) was rejected. Nevertheless, the final text has the merit of trying to ban the consumption in Europe of meat from cloned animals or descended from clones.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported this report because it has been scientifically proven that cloning can pose a threat to the welfare of farm animals, which raises the question of its ethical aspect. Cloning can have long-term negative effects that have not yet been scientifically investigated. A ban on the use and placing on the market of related products should be introduced until further progress is made in this area. I support a total ban on cloning livestock within the EU and a ban on the import and sale of products from cloned animals, which is crucial for ensuring food safety in Europe.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 I support the prohibition of the technique of cloning animals for livestock purposes, proposed by the European Commission, which includes animal clones and embryo clones. The European Parliament's report has some positive aspects, such as extending the ban to all farm species. However, it goes too far in a whole series of demands, which are very difficult to implement, the immediate consequence of which will be the blocking of negotiations with the Commission and the Council.  For this reason, I have decided that the meaning of my vote, at this first reading of the European Parliament, was abstention.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. At the moment, cloning is not being used for agricultural purposes in the EU. However, it is used in certain third countries, such as the United States, Canada, Argentina, Brazil and Australia. Cloning techniques call into question animal welfare. In addition, they pose ethical problems and give more power to large breeding industries in the face of conventional animal husbandling. This report by Parliament strengthens the Commission's proposal by taking a broader approach in all aspects related to cloning animals for breeding purposes. The objective is to address concerns about animal health and its well-being and the perception of consumers and ethical considerations regarding cloning techniques. The proposed amendments aim to implement effective and coherent regulation that responds to the legitimate concerns of the agricultural sector and European citizenship in general. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The issue of cloning animals bred and reproduced for livestock purposes is the cause and recipient of significant interest and concern on the part of most European citizens. This sensitive subject is subject to extensive discussion in both the scientific and moral field and should therefore not be addressed carelessly. Within the EU we have always dealt with this issue with absolute seriousness and that is why we are determined to work towards an effective and coherent Regulation that precisely satisfies and addresses the legitimate concerns of the agricultural sector and European citizenship.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The Summer/Moi report aims at a complete ban on the cloning of animals for agricultural purposes within the EU, as well as a ban on imports. However, there is no evidence that the consumption of cloned meat is of health concern. To the extent that certain cloning techniques affect the welfare of animals, this must be prevented by the application of animal welfare laws. However, this does not require a general ban on cloning. To the extent that the cloning of animals is rejected by consumers, a labelling requirement for meat from cloned animals is sufficient. There is therefore no reason to ban an innovative technology in principle. In addition, it is not possible to track the biological offspring of cloned animals. In this respect, the prohibition on the use of such animals cannot be enforced at all.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this proposal because it goes beyond Directive 98/58/EC and, contrary to the principle of subsidiarity, regulates an area that member states can easily regulate.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. Although animal cloning can be considered a major step towards the development of medicine, bioengineering and biotechnology, the moral-ethical aspect of cloning is one that is being questioned. The only countries in the world that allow animal cloning are the United States, Canada, Argentina, Brazil and Australia.  The European Union does not allow cloning for breeding purposes. The Commission's proposals prohibit the use of animal cloning techniques in agriculture, placing live clones on the market and selling food such as eggs and milk from animal clones. Scientific studies have shown that cloning is detrimental to animal welfare, and Eurobarometer research has shown that union citizens find cloning unsafe and worrying. In my view, the cloning of animals for the purpose of breeding and instigation of cloned animals and their products from third countries should be prohibited. Like most EU citizens, I find cloning ethically and morally questionable and have supported the moi and sommer report.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposed directive temporarily prohibits the cloning of animals in livestock production for farming purposes in the European Union. This takes into account the fact that the majority of the Population of the Union opposes the use of animal cloning for farming purposes. This is due to general ethical concerns, the maintenance of animal welfare and opposition to the consumption of meat and products of cloned animals. Cloning is one of the farming and livestock production method in third countries, in particular the USA, Canada, Brazil, Argentina, Australia, which import food products into EU countries. It is therefore necessary for the Commission to propose measures as soon as possible which prohibit and make it impossible to import food derived from cloned animals and their descendants, also in view of their difficult traceability and experience in practice.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the cloning of bovine animals, swine, sheep, goats and equidae reared and reproduced for agricultural purposes, because it rightly calls for a ban on the technique of cloning animals.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against allowing cloned animals into the food chain both on health and animal welfare grounds.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Commission's initial proposal to ban animal cloning, including the cloning of all farm animals and their products. This cloning will not, however, be prohibited for purposes such as the research and production of pharmaceutical products and medical devices. The aim of this report is to ban the practice of all farm animals in order to protect the impact on animal health and human health.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Reproductive cloning of animals is currently an assisted reproduction technique that is still developing. This is a subject of enormous public interest, evidenced by the plethora of dissenting emails I have received from interested citizens, who in 100% of cases have expressed their opposition to the legalisation of this technique within the EU. The European Food Safety Authority has repeatedly stated in its opinions that there are currently health problems surrounding this technique, not to mention the ethical issue with this technique. I therefore voted against the legalisation of this technique.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because, in addition to all ethical issues, I understand that there is no need to use animal cloning for food purposes. Rather, we need to think about a sustainable approach to agriculture and not to leave our food delivered to the interests of multinationals and large industry. The use of clones for agricultural purposes not only calls into question food security, as well as animal health and welfare, but will have incalculable environmental and biodiversity consequences. We cannot allow these products to enter the market and reach consumers.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. Invited to vote on a proposal for a european Commission directive on codecision, the European Parliament had the opportunity, by voting for the Moi et Sommer report, to outright ban the marketing of cloning products in Europe. As until now only the production of these foods was prohibited, the challenge was to extend this ban to the importation of meat from cloned animals or offspring of cloned animals, and to ensure a real traceability of these products outside the EU.  I had already mobilized in the INTA committee (seized for opinion on this text) so that the precautionary principle prevails in the field of cloning. I therefore welcome the fact that the Moi et Sommer report is behind the reasonable advice of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), which has repeatedly expressed concern about the impact of cloning on human health or the environment. It also seems to me that the reservations expressed by the text of the European Parliament faithfully reflect the ethical concerns of the citizens, who have been consulted on the subject several times. Finally, since I believe in a virtuous and quality-based European agricultural model, I voted for this text.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. I supported this report, as criticisms that have been voiced so far have been received and subsequently an improvement in the current legal situation is presented.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report, which calls for a ban on the cloning of animals, but I do not think a total ban is feasible, especially for the offspring of cloned animals. In terms of global trade such a ban would also be problematic.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Cloning is a form of asexual reproduction, carried out in the laboratory, which generates animals using the genetic material of a cell of another animal. In 2008 the European Parliament voted against the cloning of animals for agricultural purposes. However, it is allowed in some third countries, including the United States, Canada, Argentina, Brazil or Australia. In 2013, the Commission strengthened the EU's position by proposing a suspension on EU territory of the use of cloning technology for livestock, the marketing of cloned animals or live cloned embryos and the marketing of foodstuffs from cloned animals. The report before us details and reinforces the Commission's proposal. It also proposes to ban the importation and marketing of the offspring of cloned animals. I am voting for this text that protects consumers and farmers alike.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Commission recently proposed a directive temporarily banning the marketing of cloned animals and the products that come from them. This text has been extensively amended by the joint COMMITTEE AGRI-ENVI to broaden its scope and secure consumers.  It is a positive text. It transforms the directive into regulations, prohibits the importation of products from clones and their descendants, requires a certificate from exporters ensuring that their food products are in compliance with EU rules and sets up a traceability system. It also curbs the scope of TTIP by de facto blocking imports from the United States where cloning technology is permitted. However, it has a major weakness: to date, there is no technical means to control whether a product is from a clone or not. To address this, our group proposed in plenary an amendment to ban all imports of potentially affected products, as they come from herds raised in countries where cloning is exploited without any particular traceability. Since the amendment did not obtain the required majority as we had hoped, the Member abstained on the whole text.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of this proposal is to ensure uniform production conditions for farmers while protecting animal health and welfare.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the mandate because I do not support the cloning of animals as a food-production technique.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption by the European Parliament of the report on the cloning of animals raised and reproduced for agricultural purposes. Parliament has just voted for a much stronger line than the one originally proposed by the Commission. Parliament the for example calls for a comprehensive and total ban not only on the technique of cloning and marketing cloned animals and foodstuffs from cloned animals, but also on the importation of offspring of cloned animals, foodstuffs from their descendants and germ products from cloned animals. Parliament is also calling for a traceability system so that these bans can be effectively implemented. Parliament has thus adopted a position without appeal of categorical rejection of cloning, a position largely in line with public concerns in this regard. It was public health concerns and ethical animal welfare concerns that guided the majority of MEPs to vote in favour of this ambitious report.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As regards the cloning of animals for farming purposes, I take a clearly negative stance in view of the number of risks and legitimate concerns associated with their consumption. I am therefore pleased that today the European Parliament has extended the ban to the sale and import of germ products from cloned animals and their descendants, as well as the placing on the EU market of food and feed from livestock clones or their offspring from third countries.  This prohibition takes into account concerns about the possible long-term effects of food consumption, such as meat or milk from descendants of animal clones.
