In view of the studies available and experience in practice, it would be indisccreting to risk human health by consuming and using products of dubious quality.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which calls for a ban on the cloning of farm animals. Cloning has major consequences for animal welfare and raises serious concerns about the long-term effects on food safety, consumer protection and ethical issues. I therefore oppose the cloning of animals and voted to ban the cloning of farm animals in Europe, and I would introduce a number of other restrictions, such as banning embryos and semen from clones and their descendants.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council tabled by the Commission seeks, for animal welfare and ethical reasons, to suspend the use of cloning techniques in the EU, the placing on the market of live animal clones and embryo clones, and the commercial marketing of food from animal clones, including meat and milk. The report, in agreement with the basis and purpose of the Commission proposal, intends to put in place significant restrictions compared to the Commission proposal. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The report proposes to ban the importation of cloned animals in the context of agricultural activities in any form.  However, it does not put in place an effective system to ensure compliance with the rule.  In the case of imported animals or meats, the assurance that they are not cloned animals is based on the certification given by the supplier.  Traceability therefore stops at the good faith of the parties and the reliability of traceability in the country of origin.  This is clearly a significant risk.  The only option is to ban all animal importation from countries where cloning is not prohibited.  This proposal from the ENL group was rejected, resulting in abstention on this report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I would like to point out that the negative effects of cloning, in particular on animal welfare, outweigh any possible positive effects.  Currently, cloning of animals for agricultural purposes does not occur in the European Union. The Commission has proposed bans on the placing on the market of animal clones and the marketing of feed from animal clones, but these were in line with our reality, as the cloning technique is quite expensive, with a low success rate and unprofitable in food production. I would like the rapporteurs to support the main concerns related to cloning, namely the production of germinal products (semen, oocytes and embryos) from clones, to be used in the reproduction of animals through conventional breeding techniques. I would point out that the cloning technique is allowed in some third countries, such as the USA, Canada, Argentina, Brazil and Australia. It would be contradictory to ban the cloning technique in the EU for scientific and ethical reasons and continue to allow the import of the main products for which this technique is essentially used, such as germinal products from clones and foods from descendants of clones.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the cloning of animals raised and bred for agricultural purposes aims to prohibit the marketing of products from the rearing of certain animals. This text is a step in the right direction and is a brake on imports from the United States. However, to date, there is no technical means to control whether a product is cloned. Our ENL MEPs have amended the text to ensure the safety of European citizens and without being able to verify technically, it is preferable to suspend imports of products from countries that authorise the trade in cloned products.  Although it puts some brakes on imports, there is still no real traceability of cloned products (certificates are guaranteed solely on the good faith of breeders and there is no evidence that the products are not descendants of cloned animals). Moreover, our Amendment 56 was also not adopted on this point. I have therefore decided to vote against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs stand firmly against the use of cloning, cloned animals and their offspring. I voted in favour of the report, which will in effect benefit EU farmers, food producers and consumers by reinforcing the global outreach of Europe’s leading animal welfare and food standards. Furthermore, by pursuing a requirement of traceability and labelling, the EU would be able to put significant pressure on our partners in any trade negotiations, including TTIP.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text which calls for a strict ban on the marketing in the EU of cloned animals, their descendants and the foodstuffs that come from them. The aim is to protect European consumers from these products which are authorised in certain third countries and whose traceability is not yet satisfactory.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Report Cloning Animals of Cattle Species, swine, sheep, goats and equines bred and reproduced for agricultural purposes because it is necessary to retain the principle of establishing a strict ban on the marketing of cloned animals, their germ products and foodstuffs from said animals, but with some concrete exceptions to be put in place with the agreement of the competent authority (research , production of medicines, conservation of threatened species or rare breeds).

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The debated issue of animal cloning for agricultural purposes has always raised not only strong concerns about health, animal welfare and consumer choice, but also ethical problems, as well as representing, in the long term, a regulatory challenge. Although cloning of animals for food production purposes is not permitted in the European Union, commercial agricultural cloning takes place in several countries including Argentina, Australia, Brazil, Canada and the United States and can also be carried out in Chile, China, New Zealand and Uruguay. The increasing increase in trade with these countries therefore calls for new and increasingly stringent regulations due to the lack of reliable traceability and labelling systems, or identification and registration, for import purposes. Also taking into account the recent conclusions and recommendations of the European Food Safety Authority, which have recognised the existence of risks to animal health and welfare, we are today approving this proposal for a directive which aims to ensure regulatory coherence with the WTO framework, as well as a level playing field within the framework of the internationally regulated system.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Italian delegation of Forza Italia says no to cloning farm animals for food production including their derivatives. Not only is it important to protect the integrity of animals, but above all we need to protect the food safety of European citizens. In view of a lack of scientific studies on the safety of cloning, it is also necessary to prohibit the import of such animals from third countries where such a practice is permitted, such as the United States, Brazil, Argentina, China, Chile, etc. We reiterate our opposition to this practice on animals and we agree on regulation in all Member States.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which will better regulate animal cloning for farming purposes.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the basis that it is our duty, those who make decisions today, to establish certain firm principles in the field of animal cloning for the future. Still at the early stage from the point of view of scientific studies, I believe that it is essential at this time to ensure that, regardless of the decisions of the States, European citizens will continue to consume safe, healthy food products and their lives will not be put at risk by these products either in the next year or ten years from now.  Unfortunately, as this report also shows, in the case of products from cloned animals or their descendants, there is not enough data and analysis on possible genetic mutations and their implications for citizens. I believe that the legislative vacuum in this area must be properly filled, I believe that we must start from the idea that, regardless of the food needs of the population, we cannot allow these products to reach the tables of European citizens until we ensure that the advantages of using products from cloned animals outweigh the disadvantages, including in the long term.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained on the Moi/Sommer report. This is because I do not agree with the tightening of the Commission's proposal to which the EP has acceded. Cloning raises concerns, but it also offers options that need to be explored in a laboratory. A permanent and permanent ban binds this research considerably, since a hard and unlimited ban underwters interest in this research. The Commission's proposal, meanwhile, was balanced and sufficient when it limited itself to temporarily suspending the use of cloning for food production purposes and marketing live clones (animal clones). This provisional prohibition was to be followed by a review based on the development of knowledge on cloning and progress in the use of this technique in areas beyond economic use. Cloning carried out in the framework of research for the conservation of rare breeds or endangered species and for the manufacture of medicinal products and medical devices should be excluded from the prohibition. I regret that the EP has chosen a radical vision of this problem and has decided not to go down a reasonable path.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because it absorbed all the criticisms I have made so far and now, among other things, provides for a ban on cloning across all generations and comprehensive rules on traceability in the case of international agreements. Furthermore, there is no longer any talk of a temporary ban.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In 2008, the European Parliament voted against the cloning of animals for agricultural purposes in the European Union. To ensure this concrete ban, the European Commission proposes to ban the marketing of cloned animals or live cloned embryos from third states in which cloning is permitted. In its resolution, the European Parliament proposes to strengthen the effectiveness of this proposal by extending the ban on the trade in meat and animal products whose ascendants are derived from cloning. Being deeply opposed to any kind of cloning for commercial or agricultural purposes, I have of course voted in favour of this report.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – Cloning of animals kept for farm purposes and propaving must be prohibited, as must any cloning technology. Such a prohibition shall be of a permanent nature, based on human health, ethics and animal welfare requirements. It should be noted that sufficient data on the consequences of cloning animals is not collected. Cloning animals can adversely affect animal welfare, reduce the genetic diversity of animal populations and increase the risk of diseases, while also producing negative consequences for human welfare and health. In this context, I consider it appropriate to prohibit imports of animals, germinal products or foodstuffs of animal origin intended for human consumption or animal feed from countries where animal clones or products thereof are authorised. The impact of cloning of animals on food and consumer health can be extremely negative. It can also have a negative impact on livestock farming and European agriculture.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the work done and thanking the rapporteur, given the uncertainty of the results of cloning animals for agricultural use and taking into account the possible dangers to human health that may result, I thought I voted in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the report on the prohibition of cloning of all species of animals reared for agricultural purposes. I am opposed to the cloning of animals for agricultural purposes, mainly from an ethical point of view, because of animal welfare and the clear opposition of citizens to the cloning of animals for food purposes. I also support greater traceability of the origin of live animals, germinal products and food imported into the EU from third countries, as consumers have the right to be well informed about the food they see on the trade shelves.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The aim of this Directive is to suspend the use of animal clone technique and marketing for breeding and to ensure that all EU farmers and breeders are subject to the same conditions and adequately care for the protection of animal welfare. I am absolutely against cloning because it is about inducing ethical principles and taking powers that have not been given to us by natural law.  Directive 98/58/EC on the protection of animals reared sets very minimum animal welfare standards for the animals we use in agriculture. This does not apply to cloning, but calls on member states to avoid unnecessary pain, suffering or injury to domestic animals. The Cloning Directive will temporarily ban the use of cloning techniques in the production of five types of domestic animals and the placing on the market of embryo and animal clones.  The suspension of the technique of cloning and importing animal clones for production purposes strikes a fair balance between animal welfare, citizens' concerns and the interests of farmers, breeders and other stakeholders involved, so I supported the adoption of such a proposal.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the cloning of animals raised and bred for agricultural purposes is intended to prohibit the marketing of products from the breeding of certain animals. This text is a step in the right direction and is a hindrance to imports from the United States. However, to date, there is no technical way to control whether a product is from a clone. Our ENF MEPs have amended the text to ensure the safety of European citizens and, in the absence of technical checks, it is preferable to suspend imports of products from countries that authorise the trade in cloned products.   I abstained on this text because even if it puts some brakes on imports, there is still no real traceability of cloned products (certificates are guaranteed only on the good faith of breeders and there is no evidence that the products are not indirectly derived from cloned animals). Our Amendment 56 was also not adopted on this point.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ When implementing Union policy and taking into account the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, a high level of protection of human health and consumer protection should be ensured, as well as a high level of animal welfare and environmental protection. Animal cloning does not comply with Council Directive 98/58/EC14, which sets out general minimum animal welfare conditions for animals reared or kept for production purposes. The Agriculture Committee of the Croatian Parliament also spoke out last year against the cloning of domestic animals, namely cattle, pigs, sheep, goats and horses, and against the use of clones in human diets.  Cloning animals for food production put at risk the basic characteristics of the European production model based on product quality, food safety, consumer health, taking into account the objectives of the Union Common Agricultural Policy, the results of EFSA scientific assessments based on available studies, the animal welfare requirement referred to in Article 13 of the TFEU and consumer concerns, it is appropriate to prohibit animal cloning for production purposes and the marketing of animals and products resulting from the use of cloning techniques with strict animal welfare rules and the application of environmentally friendly methods.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. – I support my colleagues Rebecca Sommer and Giulia Moi's report on the proposal for a directive from the European Parliament and the Council on the cloning of cattle, pigs, sheep, goats and equines held and bred for production purposes. The European Food Safety Agency (EFSA) considers cloning primarily a danger to animal welfare associated with the low efficiency of the technique.  EFSA has seen animal welfare issues related to the health of surrogate mothers and clones alone. Surrogate mothers especially suffer from placenta disorders, which contributes to increased levels of miscarriage. This contributes, inter alia, to the low effectiveness of the technique (6-15 % for cattle and 6% for pigs) and the need to implant clone embryos in several females to obtain a single clone. Likewise, two Eurobarometer surveys from 2008 (in particular the cloning survey) and 2010 (on bio-technology with specific questions on cloning) resulted in a negative perception by Union citizens of the use of the technique cloned for production purposes.  I therefore agree with the proposal for this directive, which provides for the suspension of the use of cloning techniques for the purpose of food production and the marketing of live animal clones. This will limit temporary bans on production techniques, which cause suffering in animals, to areas where they appear to be of particular benefit.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft report proposing a tightening of the Commission's original proposals to stop animal cloning. The Commission has proposed to suspend the use of cloning techniques in the EU for the economic purposes of placing live cloned animals and embryos on the market and marketing of food from cloned animals (meat, milk, etc.). Parliament has not only refused to clone animals, but is also calling for a ban on the import of cloned animals, which is not the commission's original proposal, offering only a half-hearted solution. Cloning is, in itself, primarily an ethical problem. On the one hand, while it makes it possible to work more effectively with quality animal cuts, on the other hand, a very negative impact on donors and, above all, recipients of cloned eggs is shown, mainly in the form of an increase in health problems and frequent high soreness. In addition to animal cloning, the EP report proposes a ban on the production of germ products (semen, oocytes and embryos) from clones for the purpose of procreation of animals (descendants of clones) by traditional reproductive techniques. There is scientific evidence that cloning practices also cause poor living conditions for breeding females and clone offspring in the case of farmed fish and poultry, albeit less significantly than in mammals. That is why the EP has pushed for an amendment to apply the measures to all animals kept and therefore not only to cattle, pigs, sheep, goats and equidae, as proposed by the Commission.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report aims to suspend the cloning of farm animals, the introduction into the market of embryo clones and the sale of products derived from cloned animals in all EU territories. I voted in favour of this report in order to avoid what I consider to be a potentially dangerous and harmful practice of the food safety of European citizens.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report by Mrs Moi and Sommer because of the harmfulness of cloning not only to humans, but also to the animals themselves. Cloning exposes animals to great suffering, and there is very little scientific research into the safety of food derived from cloned animal meat. There is also a lack of appropriate labelling of products from offspring and clones themselves that are already on the market. Consumers have the right to know the origin of the products they buy, so it is necessary to implement not only a labelling system but, above all, the registration of food products made from meat of cloned animals. The European Union should decisively change its direction in terms of food safety and ensure the health of its citizens. This will not be possible when the market is flooded with genetically modified or meat-derived products of cloned animals.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has called for a large majority to ban the cloning and marketing of cloned animals, and products derived from and from their descendants, within the Union. This decision should put a definitive end to the marketing of cloned products and protect consumers in Europe. The practice of cloning is still poorly controlled and not all side effects on humans are known. I'm happy with that. However, I reiterated by my vote that we must refrain from imposing heavy and unnecessary constraints on our companies in the sector.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. – – I voted in favour of agreeing that cloning animals for agricultural purposes is a negative process for several titles.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. Animal cloning is a technique that involves reproducing animals from stem cells. In addition to the many ethical constraints, these practices have raised scientific questions.  It has been shown that animal cloning generates a loss of welfare for cloned animals and that their mortality rate after birth is considerably higher than for animals born naturally.  So I voted for this text which aims to ban the consumption of cloned animals and their offspring in the European Union, a ban which includes production, breeding and importation. Similarly, this text aims to increase the traceability of meat, embryos and seeds in the European Union, which would prevent further food scandals.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. MEPs today confirmed the june 2015 vote in THE AGRI and ENVI committees on a total ban on cloning in food and the use of clones, or their descendants, in food production. Parliament has considerably strengthened the text proposed by the European Commission from an upgrade of a moratorium to an outright ban. Parliamentarians have ensured that this ban will apply not only to meat and milk obtained from clones but also to their descendants, where the real threat lies. Citizens are waiting for strong European rules to address very serious concerns about animal welfare, risks to biodiversity and health. Cloning, through the artificialization of livestock, is incompatible with the agricultural model carried by environmentalists. To ensure that the chosen rules are properly applied, MEPs also voted to introduce provisions on the traceability of these foods, including in the event of importation.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported the European Parliament's legislative resolution on animal cloning in the European Union. This report reinforces the Commission's initial proposal, extending the temporary ban on cloning technology for animals raised and reproduced for agricultural purposes for the importation and marketing of the offspring of cloned animals, germ products (sperm, eggs and embryos) of cloned animals and food from cloned animals or their descendants.  Several arguments in favour of this reinforcement: scientific studies show that cloning is a risk to animal welfare, the impact of consumption of cloned food on human health is uncertain, cloning is not currently used for agricultural purposes in the European Union and European consumers are largely opposed to it. Finally, the enlargement envisaged by the report concerns the main products for which cloning is used, so it was important to take them into account.  I have also supported the establishment of traceability systems at EU level in order to enforce the prohibitions in the regulation.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The European Parliament today adopted rules prohibiting cloning of all species of animals for agricultural purposes and the importation of food and other products from those animals or their descendants. The efficiency of cloning practices is yet to be proven, while the suffering caused in animals is more than documented. If cloning is not used for agricultural purposes in the European Union, the concern relates to imports from some third countries, such as the USA, Canada, Argentina, Brazil and Australia. Like most MEPs, I argue that this text should take the form of a regulation to be directly applicable in the Member States rather than a directive, as proposed by the Commission, which would have to be transposed into national legislation.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 I support the prohibition of the technique of cloning animals for livestock purposes, proposed by the European Commission, which includes animal clones and embryo clones. The European Parliament's report has some positive aspects, such as extending the ban to all farm species. However, it goes too far in a whole series of demands, which are very difficult to implement, the immediate consequence of which will be the blocking of negotiations with the Commission and the Council.  For this reason, I have decided that the meaning of my vote, at this first reading of the European Parliament, was abstention.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has categorically opposed animal cloning, the marketing of cloned animals or live cloned embryos, the marketing of products such as milk or meat from cloned animals, but also the importation into the EU of products from the offspring of cloned animals and foodstuffs from the offspring of these clones. I am pleased that Parliament has voted in favour of a general ban on cloning for human or animal feed, in the interests of human health, animal health and welfare and the environment. Respecting 80% of European citizens who do not want to hear about the food of cloned animals on their plates. The report voted yesterday asks the EU to legislate by regulation and impose a certification system on exporters of products derived from cloned animals to the EU to ensure traceability of these foods and thus ensure the implementation of the regulation.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In December 2013, the Commission published two legislative proposals on cloning animals for food purposes which is under way and a proposal to monitor the Directive on the placing on the market of food from animal clones. Both aim to suspend the use of the EU cloning technique for farmed animals, the placing on the market of clones of live animals and clones in the embryo phase and the marketing of food, such as meat and milk, from animal clones. I endorse the rapporteurs' position on the negative effects of cloning and am in favour of the Commission's proposal. However, there are a number of concerns expressed by the citizens and the European Parliament which have not been welcomed, in particular with regard to food from descendants of cloned animals and the breeding material of clones and their descendants. Corroboro, therefore, the amendments tabled by the rapporteurs to strengthen the Commission's proposal to create a coherent and effective regulation that responds to the legitimate concerns of the agricultural sector and European citizens in general and which is compatible with the WTO regulatory framework.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which allows a ban on cloning for food; At the same time, the text reinforces the commission's ban on not only the marketing of foodstuffs from cloned animals but also those from foodstuffs from the descendants of these animals.  This text takes into account the problems that cloning creates in terms of animal welfare.  Finally, with regard to traceability, we must ensure that it is concretely applicable.  I welcome the adoption of this text, which sends a strong signal and reminds us that we remain vigilant and uncompromising about the health of European citizens.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, because I am opposed both to cloning farm animals and to the marketing of food from cloned animals. I do not believe it is necessary to introduce clones of animal embryos into the market. It has been shown by scientific experts that asexual production causes malaise for animals, in fact, this breeding technique causes placental and foetal dysfunctions for animals used for reproductive purposes.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe it is necessary to avoid the use of cloned animals or their descendants for food purposes in order to protect the health of citizens.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report because we want to make it clear that we are strongly opposed to cloning animals for food purposes. In addition, we would like to take the opportunity of this debate to go a little further and highlight another aspect that we find even more momentous. Because if there is one thing that really concerns us, it is the extension of highly technified agriculture and livestock, which is based on large capital investments and which entails energy costs that only mean irreparable mistreatment of our land. The use of animal cloning for food purposes or the use of GMOs as animal feed poses a danger, especially since they give greater power to large corporations and leave farmers who care for and respect the land helpless. In the face of this, we are committed to a living rural world, that is based on those farmers and ranchers who generate decent employment, who are able to give us high quality products, who understand that what is really important is respect for natural cycles and that, in addition, generate a rich and sustainable economic sector over time

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Parliament’s decisive vote today makes it clear that the European Commission’s proposal is not comprehensive enough. The weak legislation proposed by the Commission would create generations of EU farm animals coming from animals cloned in third countries. Research shows that people do not want cloning to be used in food production, and the European Parliament is the only EU institution standing up for citizens’ views and opposing the use of cloning in the food chain. The cross-party support for this position reflects the clear message from public opinion polls on this issue, and I urge the Council to take note of this when responding to Parliament’s report.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the proposal for a directive on animal cloning and reproduction for farming purposes, as it builds on the European Parliament's consistent, long-term opposition to the issue of cloning, and expresses serious objections to the placing on the EU market of animal clones, their descendants and products there of them. The issue of cloning is very sensitive for European citizens, for example, the use of clones in the food industry is unequivocally rejected by most consumers. Legislation must therefore respond effectively to these concerns.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. At the moment, cloning is not being used for agricultural purposes in the EU. However, it is used in certain third countries, such as the United States, Canada, Argentina, Brazil and Australia. Cloning techniques call into question animal welfare. In addition, they pose ethical problems and give more power to large breeding industries in the face of conventional animal husbandling. This report by Parliament strengthens the Commission's proposal by taking a broader approach in all aspects related to cloning animals for breeding purposes. The objective is to address concerns about animal health and its well-being and the perception of consumers and ethical considerations regarding cloning techniques. The proposed amendments aim to implement effective and coherent regulation that responds to the legitimate concerns of the agricultural sector and European citizenship in general. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Science must serve humanity, but within ethical parameters. Cloning for food production purposes poses too many animal welfare problems so that such a practice can be justifiable in our day. For this reason, this must deserve our full opposition. While it is also true that this practice does not represent economic advantages, there are countries where animals descended from cloned animals enter the food chain. On the other hand, it is also common to use cloned reproductive material for animal breeding purposes. It is important to establish an absolutely strict and reliable traceability system for the import into the European Union of animals descended from cloned animals and cloned genetic material.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because I believe a blanket prohibition via regulation will affect competitiveness in the long term.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Because of the negative effects of cloning on animal welfare, which, amongst other things, greatly outweighs any immediate positive gains, I supported the report because we should prohibit the use of cloning and a ban on the placing of the market of the corresponding products should be put in place until more scientific research and technological progress has been made.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 No one can say plausiably today what negative consequences for human health animal cloning could have for economic purposes, not to mention the moral level of such a dangerous game of life, even if they are animals. Overall, up to 84% of EU citizens oppose the technique of any cloning. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the ban on cloning cattle, pigs, sheep, goats and horses bred and reproduced for farming purposes.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ First of all, I would like to note that animal cloning does not comply with Council Directive 98/58/EC, which sets out general minimum conditions for the welfare of animals reared or kept for production purposes. Currently, cloning is not used for breeding purposes in the European Union. However, I would like to pay attention to how cloning is used in third countries. Eurobarometer surveys from 2010 show citizens' support for cloning of only 18%, suggesting little chance of changing the attitude of European citizens in the near future.   In plenary, I supported amendments aimed at amending the status of the legal act in the directive to a regulation in order to improve legal certainty and ensure rationality and consistency in implementation, respecting the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. The amendments proposed in this draft report aim to establish an effective and coherent regulation addressing the legitimate concerns of the agricultural sector and European citizens as a whole.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although there has not yet been clear evidence that eating meat and milk from cloned animals would be at risk for humans, I personally see it as quite risky. I regret that, despite warnings from experts, animals are still allowed to clone animals for food production purposes, as well as to import and sell such food in the consumer network. I believe that the consumer should be able to decide whether or not he wants to consume the food produced in this way. Unfortunately, by not having to label food from cloned animals, the consumer has no chance of ascertaining whether the food comes from a cloned animal or its descendants. I supported the report because I believe that much more attention needs to be paid to this issue than before and to involve as wide a range of stakeholders and institutions as possible in the debate on this subject. I am convinced that if we cannot cope with the current problems, we will be pulling the shorter end on the world market in the future and in this area.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. There is no legislation in the EU that regulates cloning alone, and cloning for agricultural purposes is not applicable in EU Member States. Scientific studies have shown that cloning poses a risk to animal welfare, and the European public believes that animal cloning does not benefit, is not safe, is unfair and worrying. The report cites the legitimate concerns of citizens and the EP by reminding the Commission that it did not include in its proposals food provisions from the descendants of cloned animals and measures relating to reproductive material of cloned animals and their offspring. I join the view that the Commission's proposal should be strengthened by adopting a more integrated approach to all aspects relating to the cloning of animals for agricultural purposes – an effective and consistent regulation should be developed that takes into account the legitimate concerns of the agricultural sector and European citizens. In general, I believe that the negative effects of cloning largely outweigh any potential positive effect, and I am so strongly in favour of banning cloning, banning the placing on the market of live animal clones, their germs and their offspring and banning the marketing of food from animal clones, which is why I also voted in favour of the report.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The Summer/Moi report aims at a complete ban on the cloning of animals for agricultural purposes within the EU, as well as a ban on imports. I do share the concerns about cloning for agriculture for animal health reasons at the current state of research.  However, consumers in the EU Member States are different in their attitude to these products, so we are calling for regulation at a deeper organisational level. The certification of products produced without the use of clones would give consumers the choice. The Commission itself doubts its competence. This can be seen from the fact that it is based only on the 'rubber paragraph 352' TFEU in the grounds of the proposal. The Moi/Sommer report goes even further by calling for a regulation instead of a directive. In this way, the report is further shifting responsibility towards the European level. I therefore reject the report on grounds of subsidiarity.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained on the Moi/Sommer report. The issue of cloning can be viewed from different points of view and there is certainly no need for its black and white vision. Unfortunately, it was the black-and-white vision chosen by the majority in the EP when it categorically defined against cloning and all other procedures related to it. In cloning research, we are still at the beginning and do not know the answers to many of the questions that accompany it. However, we will not get answers to these questions if we ban cloning in its entirety. Instead, we should open up a space for research to focus on the cloning concerns involved and, at the same time, the opportunities it can bring. While the Commission's proposal was factual and unbiased, it was packed into the EP by the prejudices of opponents of cloning and thus devalued it. I find it wrong that the EP's vote has created obstacles so that the issue of cloning can be thoroughly researched and mapped, thus preventing it from being competently decided in the EU.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this report because it is inadmissible for animals used as food for humans to be cloned. While this is a practice in some countries outside the European Union, such as the USA, Canada, Argentina, Brazil and Australia, I believe that food made from cloned animals should remain prohibited for European markets.  Consequently, food that comes from animals that are descendants of cloned animals should also be prohibited because, among other things, its quality is questionable and how healthy it is at all. Therefore, food imported from other countries to Europe should be certified as not of origin from clones, their descendants or not processed from various embryos, embryos, clones or their descendants.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ A ban on the use of cloning in animal production for farm purposes of all animal species should be introduced. A ban should be created on placing on the market food products derived from animal clones or their descendants, embryo clones and germinal products of animal clones. Moreover, EU Member States should ensure that all animals imported into the EU are proven not to be clones or descendants thereof, and that no food or germinal products derived from clones or their offspring are imported into the EU. This should apply to the entire EU single market, and that is why I support this report. The prohibition of placing on the EU market of cloned animals, their offspring and products derived from them would entail a requirement for the EU’s trading partners to introduce traceability and labelling requirements akin to those long implemented in the EU. This will in effect benefit EU farmers, food producers and consumers by reinforcing the global outreach of Europe’s leading animal welfare and food standards.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this report because it highlights primarily health issues. It is important to protect people who may possibly consume unverified meat products, but also animal health and welfare, as cloning techniques are insufficiently developed and in many cases involve animal abuse.  The problem should be explicitly put to an end and cut in the root, so the report highlights the ban on meat imports for the first generation of cloned animals and the ban on imports of meat from third countries without proper certification and the presented import licence.  The report is a compromise between rationality and emotionality in the use of animals and is a clear sign of solidarity in decision-making within the EU institutions. The voice of citizens who are explicitly against meat products of cloned animals as well as all forms of products derived from them has been heeded.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal because I do not agree with the arguments put forward in favour of an almost total ban on animal cloning and other related bans that the proposal comes up with or supports. As stated in its opinion by the European Food Safety Authority, cloning has no impact on the safety of meat and milk obtained from clones. The only backbone of this proposal is therefore moral arguments. However, as I do not agree with people being forced into moral behaviour, I had to reject the proposal. It is up to everyone's personal decision whether or not to support products derived from cloned animals through their purchase. Especially when cloned animals do not necessarily live worse than other animals that have not been cloned.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the EP and of the Council on cloning bovine, porcine, ovine, caprine and equidae reared and reproduced for agricultural purposes. I am opposed to the cloning of animals for agricultural purposes, as this is controversial in several respects: ethical, human health and animal welfare. We need to go one step further and achieve a total ban on cloning and importing cloned products. By adopting the report, we are once again demonstrating that we want to continue to have the highest food standards in the world in the European Union.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported today's legislative resolution of the European Parliament calling for a ban on animal cloning. I welcome the fact that the Plenary has been unequivocal on this ethical issue and has thus heard the majority opinion of EU citizens. It is now necessary to wait for the Member States in the Council to take up their position.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ A provisional ban on cloning animals and placing food from cloned animals on the market is an appropriate step and one that I can support. However, I consider calls to make this ban permanent and widen its scope to cover all species kept and reproduced for farming purposes to be disproportionate. Furthermore, I have concerns about the implications of extending the ban to include imports of food produced from the descendants of cloned animals and calls to establish a traceability system at European Union level. In my opinion, the report adopted by the Committees strays too far from the principle of scientific evidence-based policy-making. I believe any moves to introduce a permanent ban should be based on a full impact assessment of scientific evidence.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report focuses superficially against cloning, leaves too many windows and has deliberate omissions so that, in the end, food derived from cloned animals ends up on the market.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the issue of cloning should also be addressed because of the development of science and the ethical implications of practice. According to consumer surveys, European citizens strongly object to the consumption of food made from cloned animals, and the majority also disapprove of cloning for agricultural purposes on the basis of animal welfare and general ethical considerations. The issue is therefore also the subject of intense debate among the general public, while the definition of cloning is not always clear, as it is often confused with genetically modified organisms (GMOs). During the debate, I drew attention to the fact that we are facing a serious issue and that the role of the European Parliament is to signal the problem and to provide political guidance. This problem needs to be examined by the Commission from a further scientific and practical point of view and to propose solutions. Furthermore, I underlined that the report raises a real problem, from a decrease in genetic diversity due to cloning, to an increase in technological dependence, to serious ethical issues. I therefore supported the fact that cloning of animals kept for agricultural purposes and products made from the offspring of cloned animals and their imports should not be possible at this point. In my opinion, the report fulfils its role, even if there are other opinions on some points, such as whether it is possible to verify the clone of descendants or what we really call cloning.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report which prohibits animal cloning and which, above all, prevents the entry into the food chain of descendants of cloned animals. That is the crux of the matter.  Cloning is a very expensive technique; it is absurd to use it to get an animal to milk or slaughter. It is convenient instead to clone a particularly productive animal to commercially exploit its offspring. Banning cloned animals from entering the European food chain without dealing with their descendants would be pointless and, above all, hypocritical towards European public opinion, which is largely opposed to cloning. This practice poses three problems. Firstly, the suffering of animals. Pregnancy and childbirth of "surrogate mothers" are subject to complications; many clones fail to reach adulthood. The second problem is that cloning encourages an anthropocentric view of the relationship between mankind and other living beings, since it leads us to regard farm animals as a mere productive machine. Finally, the third and most serious problem. Placing an expensive laboratory technique, such as cloning, at the basis of the reproduction of farm animals and at the basis of the production of our food means making us even more dependent on the large companies operating in the field of agri-bio-technology.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I opposed the report on the cloning of animals kept and reproduced for farming purposes because some of its provisions are technically non-feasible. I support a provisional ban on the use of a cloning technique which does not prevent research and scientific progress. On the contrary I am not in favour of extending the ban to descendants of clones and food products because the traceability requirements would impose an excessive burden on farmers. Similarly, the trade and import of these products is already happening and banning it is unfeasible unless we end all trade in animals or in animal products with countries authorising it, which would not be beneficial for the European consumers.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. While the importation of productions from cloned animals or their offspring is not yet prohibited in Europe, I have taken the decision to support the Moi and Sommer report, which opposes cloning and aims to strengthen the precautionary principle in current legislation.   While EU law already prohibits production from this process of genetic modification, there are currently no regulations prohibiting the importation of such products. With this report, the European Parliament reaffirms its opposition to cloning and takes a further step towards food security and the protection of our citizens. Traceability mechanisms will have to be respected by our trading partners and it will now be impossible to import products from cloned animals or their derivatives. In addition to food safety and consumer protection, the concern for animal welfare is also mentioned in this report, because according to the data we have, cloned animals experience exceptional mortality. Finally, as in the case of any genetically modified organism, the report points to the real risk that cloning causes to our genetic diversity.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I approve and hold justified both proposals contained in this directive - a temporary ban on cloning of traditionally bred species and a ban on imports of animals and clone embryos, since it excludes cloning carried out for scientific purposes, one carried out to preserve rare and endangered species, for sporting and cultural events, and for the production of medical devices and devices. I consider it a proper change in the form of the Commission's legislative proposal proposed by the report - from directive to regulation, as this will allow the temporary ban to become permanent and significantly expand the scope of the ban so that it can cover species reproduced for breeding purposes, descendants of cloned animals, food and animal feed derived from the descendants of cloned animals. I also strongly support the statement contained in the report, which states that it is extremely difficult to follow the trace of food obtained from the descendants of cloned animals, and the resulting proposal for certificates in exports and for the creation of monitoring systems at eu level.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft legislative resolution on the cloning of animals — bovine animals, pigs, sheep, goats and equidae— requires for agricultural purposes that imports of cloned animals as well as semen and articles from animal clones should be prohibited. Imports must be marked with a certificate stating that the product is not a clone or descendant of an animal clone. Because, like the vast majority of Europeans, I do not support cloning as a food-raising technique for moral and ethical reasons and for animal welfare, I supported the report.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report because we want to make it clear that we are strongly opposed to cloning animals for food purposes. In addition, we would like to take the opportunity of this debate to go a little further and highlight another aspect that we find even more momentous. Because if there is one thing that really concerns us, it is the extension of highly technified agriculture and livestock, which is based on large capital investments and which entails energy costs that only mean irreparable mistreatment of our land. The use of animal cloning for food purposes or the use of GMOs as animal feed poses a danger, especially since they give greater power to large corporations and leave farmers who care for and respect the land helpless. In the face of this, we are committed to a living rural world, which is based on those farmers and ranchers who generate decent employment, who are able to give us high quality products, who understand that what is really important is respect for natural cycles and who also generate a rich and sustainable economic sector over time.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 When I voted on my colleague Sommer's report, I voted against the adoption of another ban on the logging. In my opinion, the current Council Directive No 98/58/EC adequately treats the whole process of assisted reproduction techniques. Moreover, the scientific evidence does not support the arguments used in the report. I therefore voted in accordance with the Czech position issued on this material.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is welcome because it will de facto curb imports from the United States, so it is a blow to the extent of TTIP. But there is still a major problem because there is currently no technical way to control whether a product is from a clone. Of course, we can rely on the good faith of exporters who, if they do not have any traceability in doubt, will certainly refuse to establish a certificate and will forego exporting to the EU. However, there is little legal certainty in this perspective.  Cloning has been exploited for several years without any particular traceability, the American herd is now "contaminated" immeasurably.  The ENF Group amended the text submitted in plenary to ensure the safety of European citizens: in the absence of technical verification, we prefer to suspend imports of products that may be affected from countries where trade in cloned products is allowed. We also propose to better define "clone descendants. Since our amendment was rejected, I voted for the abstaining.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report because we want to make it clear that we are strongly opposed to cloning animals for food purposes. In addition, we would like to take the opportunity of this debate to go a little further and highlight another aspect that we find even more momentous. Because if there is one thing that really concerns us, it is the extension of highly technified agriculture and livestock, which is based on large capital investments and which entails energy costs that only mean irreparable mistreatment of our land. The use of animal cloning for food purposes or the use of GMOs as animal feed poses a danger, especially since they give greater power to large corporations and leave farmers who care for and respect the land helpless. In the face of this, we are committed to a living rural world, which is based on those farmers and ranchers who generate decent employment, who are able to give us high quality products, who understand that what is really important is respect for natural cycles and who also generate a rich and sustainable economic sector over time.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution because it gives a very clear message: we do not want food of cloned origin in the food market.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In this controversial vote I expressed myself in favour of extending the ban on animal cloning to include their descendants, the products that derive from them, and any import into the EU in general. Unfortunately I could not follow my Group’s line, which rejected the extension of the ban to clone-derived descendants and products. Scientific progress has not advanced much in this field and cloning techniques are not yet mature: many animals subject to cloning experiments die painfully after a week, and this should not be allowed to happen. At the same time, human beings’ health is also at stake, because the effects and consequences of meat and products derived from cloned animals are still not well known.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which advocates the banning of cloned animals and their descendants from sale for consumption in our single market for the next 5 years, as well as completely suspending the use of cloning on farm animals within the EU. This is important, not only to protect consumer standards within the EU but also to offer an incentive to our trading partners to move away from this intensification of the farming process. With the scientific consensus suggesting high health risks for the animals involved, it is crucial that we move to protect animal welfare and preserve the standards of our Union. Cloning was an awe-inspiring scientific advance, but we must be cautious about its effect on our farming techniques and our health.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I have decided for various reasons to vote against animal cloning for agricultural purposes. First of all, many of the cloned animals die after several weeks under severe pain. Secondly, cloning in the European Union is not yet on the verge of collapse and the European market is in danger of being flooded with Asian cloned products. This resolution remedys this distortion. Thirdly, the majority of the population is not (yet) willing to accept cloning in its food chain.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Ethical and moral questions about animal cloning are numerous, both for ethical and moral reasons and for reasons concerning the health and welfare of animals. European citizens are overwhelmingly opposed to it. There is still no evidence that these practices are not dangerous to the health of consumers, the environment or animal welfare. Thus, this report ensures compliance with the precautionary principle concerning the public health of European citizens.   This report proposes the suspension of the use of cloning to produce food and the traceability of the descendants of cloned animals to avoid the marketing of food from clones and/or their descendants.  This traceability is particularly important, as while cloning for agricultural purposes is not allowed in the EU, it is allowed in some third countries. I therefore welcome the adoption of this proposal for a regulation which aims to better guarantee the food safety and health of European citizens and I am voting in support.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In fundamental, we follow the content of this report, thus appealing to the prevalence of the precautionary principle with regard to asexual reproduction or cloning of domestic animals. We also believe that this principle should be strengthened through control and surveillance mechanisms to prohibit the marketing and consumption of food from cloned animals. The cloning procedure applied to agricultural production is a reflection of a production model based on the unbridled demand for productivity and profit at any price. This competitive framework of liberalised markets is at the basis of this problem. Therefore, our support for this report against cloning of domestic animals is also a wake-up call in defence of small and medium-sized family farming. In defense of a production model based on biodiversity and respect for social and environmental standards. The only one capable of ensuring a balanced planning of our territory, the sustainability of our rural world and a healthy food production for our people.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I supported this report, as criticisms that have been voiced so far have been received and subsequently an improvement in the current legal situation is presented.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE)
text: Written. I fully support the Commission's proposal to ban the cloning of animals and the sale of products from cloned animals on the European market. There are clear animal health problems with the procedure, and until these problems are resolved, a ban should apply. It is very problematic, as the rapporteurs would like to extend the ban to the progeny of cloned animals. There are already a number of offspring of cloned animals in Europe, and there are no health problems in these animals. The proposal also poses major problems for imports from third countries. The rapporteurs have adopted a position that is very far removed from the Council's position and, moreover, far from what is practicable. This will make further discussions very problematic and risk halting the whole legislative process. The likely outcome of Parliament's decision is that the area remains completely unregulated.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted for this report, which calls for a ban on the cloning of farm animals in Europe. Labour MEPs believe in making decisions based on facts and, in this case, animal welfare concerns. Cloning farm animals might be a scientific advancement, but it has no environmental, social or health benefits. There is substantial evidence that cloned animals and the surrogate mothers who carry them can suffer health and welfare problems. Cloning animals for farming purposes takes animal husbandry in entirely the wrong direction, merely making intensive farming even more intensive.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – Scientific studies have shown overwhelming evidence that animal cloning poses a danger to animal welfare. That is why I voted on the Report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the cloning of bovine animals, pigs, sheep, goats and equidae reared and reproduced for agricultural purposes. This report enshrines a ban on the cloning of farm animals throughout the EU. Because, in third countries such as the USA, Canada, Argentina, Brazil and Australia the cloning of farm animals is used, this report suspends the placing on the market of live animals resulting from cloning and embryos resulting from cloning and marketing of foodstuffs, such as meat and milk, from animals resulting from cloning.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider animal cloning for farming purposes to be wrong. On the one hand, the level of scientific progress achieved cannot rule out the risk of suffering to animals that are conceived in this way, serious deformations caused by the non-development of organs, limbs and so on. On the other hand, science cannot guarantee 100% food safety from clones or their descendants whose genetic code may be damaged. I therefore supported Parliament's comments aimed at effectively banning the cloning of animals on EU territory and, at the same time, banning the import and sale of such animals, their descendants and their products in the common European market.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The EP rightly places stricter restrictions on the European Commission's original proposal to ban the cloning of animals, extending the ban to all animals reared for agricultural purposes, their offspring and products derived from them, as well as to imports of such products into the EU. We have no right to endanger the health of European citizens, but also of future generations by consuming products of questionable quality.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Animal cloning for agricultural purposes raises not only issues related to animal health and animal welfare and consumer choice, but also ethical problems, as well as posing a regulatory challenge. Cloning is currently mainly used to obtain breeding animals; food potentially marketed in the EU would only come from clone offspring. Although the cloning of animals for food production purposes does not take place in the EU, agricultural cloning for commercial purposes takes place in several countries including Argentina, Australia, Brazil, Canada and the United States and can also be carried out in Chile, China, New Zealand and Uruguay, countries in which cloning companies are active. As meat and milk obtained from the offspring of clones and clones themselves begin to enter the food chain, it is imperative to ensure far-sighted legislation and a level playing field in this area. It is important to note that none of the third countries has established reliable traceability and labelling systems, or identification and registration systems; this package, with regard to animal cloning, takes into account animal welfare concerns and ethical implications, with a view to giving greater legal certainty to the sector concerned by 2016.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The topic of cloning animals kept and reproduced for farming purposes included deciding on the two directives proposed by the European Commission in relation to the prohibition of cloning and the ban on their imports from other countries. The second proposal for a directive worked with the prohibition of products from cloned animals, as well as the prohibition of products derived from the descendants of these animals. However, I abstained in the vote on this subject. Animals, in my opinion, are not a thing that we can reproduce. In this area, we should respect the laws of nature and not try to change them artificially.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The production of safe and healthy food should be based on natural methods. Only then can we be guaranteed that the products that hit our tables will not be a delayed ignition bomb. The use of cloning for animal husbandry purposes is therefore unacceptable to all those who have at heart both the welfare of humans and the breeding animals themselves. The fact that we do not currently have much evidence of the impact of eating food for which cloning or genetic modification has been used is evidence of how difficult such authoritative studies are difficult to carry out. In this situation, we consumers will act as guinea-rabbits and will bear the long-term effects of the launch of such products. Europe is able to produce enough food using natural methods and it is unreasonable to look for artificial methods to increase its supply, including economically, as this will hit its producers. I therefore fully support the permanent ban on cloning animals and the extension of the scope of this ban.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the cloning of animals kept and reproduced for agricultural purposes, because I believe that the negative effects of cloning outweigh any possible positive effects and should continue to be banned in the European Union. Cloning is a danger to animal welfare, according to scientific studies, in addition to the ethical issues it raises. To this end, this report maintains a firm stance against animal cloning, both in production and import, and the proposed amendments are intended to create an effective and coherent regulation capable of addressing the legitimate concerns of the agricultural sector and European citizens in general.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The cloning procedure applied to agricultural production, prohibited in the EU, not aimed at eliminating any shortage of agricultural production, is rather the reflection of a production model based on the unbridled demand for productivity and profit at any price, be it animal suffering, food security or even the livelihood of small farmers.  In the fundamental case, we follow the content of this report, thus appealing to the prevalence of the precautionary principle with regard to asexual reproduction or cloning of animals. We really believe that this principle should be strengthened through control and surveillance mechanisms to prohibit the marketing and consumption of food from these animals. This report goes further than the European Commission in its communication, increasing the spectrum of products to be banned from cloned animals, and some products have gone the way, such as all products from descendants of cloned animals or reproductive materials from these animals. Our support for this report is therefore also a wake-up call in defence of small and medium-sized family farming, in defence of a production model based on biodiversity and respect for social and environmental standards.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. Animal cloning is a controversial issue, affecting both animal health and welfare and consumer safety. Science has not yet been able to give certain answers to these problems, which will allay doubts and perplexities. Indeed, the European Food Safety Authority has recognised the existence of animal health risks due to high mortality rates associated with cloning technology. Although cloning animals for food production purposes does not take place in the EU, this practice takes place in countries such as Argentina, Australia, Brazil, Canada and the United States, mainly to obtain breeding animals from which to obtain animals for slaughter. As a result, meat and milk obtained from the offspring of clones and clones themselves are beginning to enter the food chain, and it is therefore necessary that we guarantee legislation that regulates a new sector and that is currently subject to the general rules relating to the marketing of new food products and ingredients, which takes into account the specific characteristics of cloning. I voted in favour of this proposal because the package takes due account of the concerns that have been raised in many quarters, prohibiting the introduction of reproductive material from cloned animals as well as milk and meat derived from them.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the sommer and Moi report on the cloning of animals reared and reproduced for agricultural purposes.  Animal cloning is controversial for a number of reasons. First, there are moral concerns, because animal cloning can be followed by cloning humans. Then there is the suffering of the animals, the high mortality rate of clones at all stages of development, congenital anomalies and abnormally large offspring that cause the difficult births and deaths of newborns. Last but not least, the mass upbringing of clones could harm the diversity of the animal world in the long term.  Around 80% of EU citizens oppose cloning for agricultural purposes, and so is the position of my political group, the EPP. Unfortunately, we do not yet have the right rules in this area and third countries can import meat and milk from cloned animals to us. The European Commission's proposal is good because it prohibits the cloning of animals for agricultural purposes, as well as the breeding and sale of their offspring, germs and products such as meat and milk.  However, it would not make sense to ban cloning in the EU, while promoting it in third countries by importing these animals or their products. I therefore supported the position of the ENVI Committee, which requires that all animals, germs and food imported into the EU have confirmed that they do not come from cloned animals.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it pains me to see that, in a union that was born out of the firm will to stand up for democracy and human rights after the Second World War, today we find ourselves treading on the rights of those who are fleeing wars instead. It pains me to see that one third of the petitions from citizens received by Parliament relate to breaches of fundamental rights. It angers me to learn that many of these revolve around unemployment, precarious work practices and inequality in many of the Member States.  That is why I supported the Ferreira report, and I would urge the Commission to adopt an internal strategy and action plan on fundamental rights, put in place an EU mechanism to monitor democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Member States and, vitally, carry out an urgent assessment of the impact of austerity measures on fundamental rights. It is crucial that Member States pull together and allow the EU to carry out the role it was created for, namely tackling these injustices.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, it is certainly necessary to continue to promote and strengthen the protection and full development of fundamental rights in accordance with the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. We are all aware that high levels of poverty and social exclusion, especially children, have been recorded in recent years. Over 26 million children across the European Union are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. In addition, the situation in Syria, Korea, Iran and also in our neighbourhood, Belarus and Ukraine is worrying, and I would like to highlight Crimea in particular here. However, I have always supported and insist that citizens of the European Union should enjoy the rights enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights, without discriminating against gender, religion and skin colour. Unfortunately, some points of this resolution are here for the sole purpose of cheap political points and therefore I voted against this resolution. I fully support the European mechanism for monitoring basic rights in the Member States as well as strengthening the protection of children's rights, the rights of persons with disabilities, roma rights and migrants' rights.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – (The first part of the opposition was not recorded due to a technical problem.) ... on the fundamental rights of the European Union. Given that, in the context of mass illegal immigration, migrants are granted almost unlimited rights by this report. At the same time, it forgets that there are human rights for the European communities, nations and people concerned. This is where I proudly hold in my hand the dramatic statement of the National Legal Protection Service. This was the Hungarian organisation that stood up for the human rights of Hungarians in 2006, even during the time of eye shots and mass human rights violations, and stood by the victims. It is entitled 'Immigration crisis: Hungarians have rights'. And it offers professional legal assistance to individuals who have been in breach, e.g. violations related to the destruction of their crops, destruction of their farmland, violations that come to the fore in connection with the threat to public safety, violations of public transport, and so on. I encourage my fellow lawyers across Europe to do the same, to stand up for the human rights of their compatriots.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: " Mr. President, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms is the foundation of everything. Freedom of expression, freedom of religion, equality and non-discrimination, promotion of children's rights, persons with disabilities, protection of migrants. All these rights must be protected through effective mechanisms and measures, with the safety and dignity of people having to come first. Unfortunately, this report does not provide this and I could not support it. In fact, it even goes beyond the borders accepted by the basic Treaty on European Union and enters the competence of the Member States. I believe that we should put the promotion and effective mechanisms of protection of human rights first so that we do not witness serious violations of fundamental human rights and freedoms, discrimination or hatred on any basis in the future. Human rights must not be manipulated and should not, under the guise of protecting human rights, try to change the image of family and society and impose some new ideologies, which is what this report is trying to do, and that is why I did not support it.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, the events of recent days in Hungary and on the shores of southern Europe have highlighted the fact that the plight of those fleeing war-torn communities in Syria and elsewhere must not be compared with the ambitions of those economic migrants to whom freedom of movement is not a saviour but an opportunity. The image of a young boy whose body was found on a beach will have left an indelible scar upon even the sternest of minds, and it is right that governments across the EU take action to alleviate what is a humanitarian crisis. In this situation, the right to life must form the core of our response, and I am pleased that the UK Prime Minister has committed to resettling 20 000 Syrian refugees by 2020, many of whom are the most vulnerable that we can imagine. Our Government is also correct when it stresses that the wider solution to this influx of refugees can come only from aiding peace and stability and upholding the basic rights in societies where the current threat is real. I want to see Christians and other religious minorities in these communities empowered by the assurance that they do not have to leave their ancestral homes, and that the international community will support their right to life and freedom of conscience and expression.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ (PPE).
text: Thank you, Mr. President. I cannot support a report on fundamental rights which contains positions which distort the nature of the issue and serve political purposes; a report which states that the austerity imposed on the Member States by means of a budgetary adjustment programme is the sole responsibility of the institutions, and we all know that the Member States are also involved in leaving the crisis; a report which does not recognise the control mechanisms in the Member States and proposes a new Mechanism, concealing or serving purposes. For these reasons I have tabled a stand-by, comprehensive, alternative motion for a resolution which reflects respect for fundamental rights and the right of access to them for all citizens and residents of the European Union, without exceptions. Thank you very much.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, honourable colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. We know that human rights are a cornerstone for the European Union. The European Charter of Fundamental Rights must become the 'bible' of the European Union. I am pleased that the document that I supported talks about sanctions against countries that are Members of the European Union and which grossly violate human rights. Because what happens at this moment? As a member of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, I know that we, Parliament, often show other countries human rights violations, and at the same time other countries are saying to us, 'And what is happening to you in the European Union?'. There is, in fact, no control mechanism or an impact mechanism, as a Member State of the European Union could, if you wish, be compelled to fulfil human rights.
