I am extremely sorry that the majority of Members did not support paragraph 167, which states on the right to vote for people without citizenship, because this is an absolutely topical issue for my country, Latvia. It is about non-citizens, but it is still to come. Thank you!

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I have just voted against a proposal on human rights put forward in this place. The whole reason for it was simply that the UK does not need to be told about human rights by the EU. Over many years, the UK has saved people in Europe and the wider world from abuses of human rights. We do not need to be dictated to on this subject. One of the insane proposals that was put forward in this latest idea was to give votes to illegal immigrants. This is the kind of proposal that comes from the EU. This is why the UK does not need the EU and this is why – hopefully very, very soon – in our referendum the UK will leave the EU to these crazy fantasies and crazy ideas and get back to being a beacon of true democracy and true human rights.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I also want to say that I did not support this report. In my opinion, promoting one's own vision of the world and human rights in such a well-intentioned form is not happy. For this reason, I think that a number of my colleagues, and not just within the PPE faction, have not supported this report.  I would also like to point out that if the European Union wanted to enforce its vision of fundamental rights and freedoms in this way on the outside world, I think it could come across to some extent. What I accept is that fundamental rights in that category are kind of insiparable, those completely natural rights, such as the right to freedom, to life, to human treatment without torture. These are indeed rights that we can continue to enforce around the world. But further vision of economic, social, cultural and other rights can be very important, and for this reason I am also calling for prudence in promoting this vision of the world towards our neighbours.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. "Today the European Parliament voted on a report on fundamental rights in the EU, prepared by Laura Ferrara of the Italian Five Star Movement. I chose to vote for an alternative proposal put forward by my group, the EPP. Unfortunately, the EPP proposal fell in the vote, and I chose to vote against the Ferrara report.  The reason is that the report is contrary to the principle of subsidiarity. Everything from a federal definition of marriage to legislation on quotas of company boards and the issue of abortion is addressed in the text. These are issues to be decided at national level and not in the European institutions.  On the issue of abortion, the Christian Democrats believe that in pregnancy there are two individuals worthy of protection and that it is therefore in society's interest to keep down the number of abortions. That perspective is completely lacking in Mrs Ferrara's report.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The protection of fundamental rights in the European Union within the Member States, although enshrined in the Treaties which are the primary source of European law of a universal nature, remains highly controversial at present and a source of contradictions and inequalities. Mrs Ferrara's report highlights a panorama of constant violations of the rights of ethnic minorities, discrimination based on racial, xenophobic and religious intolerances. A framework is highlighted in which the European Union appears to be oriented towards a prospect of economic development and growth, but which increasingly ignores phenomena of exclusion, poverty and social hardship; phenomena that contradict values and principles, such as those of solidarity and democracy, on which the EU is founded. I voted in favour of this report because, in view of this situation, the report contains the proposal for more concrete and stringent action to ensure that the existing regulatory instruments are fully and correctly applied. It also calls for a coordination strategy to be stimulated between the European institutions to ensure that serious violations of fundamental rights are effectively prevented, starting with objective investigations and assessments of the goodness of the Member States' actions, leading to infringement proceedings in the event of well-founded reasons.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it deals with the situation of fundamental rights in the EU in a weighted way. The report proposes a dynamic evaluation mechanism of an annual nature which, on the basis of common and homologable criteria, makes it possible to know the state of democratic quality, the proper functioning of the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights in the Member States.  I also value the fact that the report on this occasion places particular emphasis on fundamental rights in relation to migration, asylum and refuge and that the need to ensure fundamental rights in detention centres and during procedures for the reception and return of migrants at the border is emphasized.  In turn, it is important to denounce the report the impact of austerity on economic, social and cultural rights and its call for the budgetary policy of each Member State to ensure sufficient levels of enjoyment of these rights. Finally, I value the report's in-depth address of the rights of women, the LGBT group and the EU's ethnic and religious minorities.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU because, among other elements, I consider it positive that it reflects the setback in the fulfilment of these rights as a result of austerity policies and cuts in public spending implemented by governments and advocated by the European Commission. I think it is very positive that the report is in need of the European Commission urgently implementing a specific strategy to achieve and ensure compliance with fundamental rights so that they cease to be mere wet paper.  I also share the criticisms it gathers about the systemic discrimination suffered today in the EU by groups such as migrants or Roma people, and I also consider it positive that it challenges the current asylum system and migrant regulations and how they directly and negatively affect the fundamental rights of these people.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it provides a comprehensive overview of the current situation of fundamental rights in the EU. It is particularly strong on calls for enhancing the rights of LGBTI citizens and I welcome the calls for a greater understanding of Transgender issues. The report is also strong on the rights of women and children. The report calls for ‘life-saving abortion’ to be provided as a right. Sinn Féin believe that in the case of rape, sexual abuse or incest or where a women’s life is in danger, or in the case of fatal foetal abnormality the option of termination should be available. Sexual and reproductive health and rights cannot be reduced to mean abortion. Reproductive rights can refer to a range of services covering maternal, post natal, menopausal, reproductive cancers and fertility treatments. It is my party’s and my own view that women should not be denied access to such services.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The Charter of Fundamental Rights guarantees the same personal, civil, political, economic and social rights to all citizens of the European Union and residents of the European Union. I therefore welcome the European Commission's proposal to establish a mechanism for a regular stocktaking of the situation of fundamental rights in each Member State, so that possible violations of these fundamental rights can be prevented.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report discusses institutional issues and analyses the status of specific fundamental rights. In particular, it calls for the strengthening of the role of the FRG, the agency for fundamental rights, which continues to advocate for a considerable expansion of the scope of fundamental rights.   In addition, an important part of the text is devoted to "the rights of migrants".   The text is also concerned about the "increasing phenomenon of rapid expulsion"; it condemns Member States that build "walls and barbed wire to protect their borders"; Roma are systematically portrayed as victims of discrimination.  This text is not just an immigrationist. It is deeply destructive in its unqualified support for the unrelenting demands of LGBTI groups such as the pseudo-right of transgender people to change sex or the so-called right of same-sex couples to marry.   Thus, this very politically correct report is in many ways unacceptable. Because of the repeated attacks on the sovereignty of states and the freedom of opinion of the individuals contained in this motion for a resolution, I voted against its adoption.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Sadly, I could not support this report as too much suggested that matters best decided at Member State level should be determined by the European Union.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: in writing. The severe economic and financial crisis that has affected the EU in recent years has also led to a serious social crisis that has deteriorated the living conditions of millions of Europeans. As a country originating in a country which has requested a financial assistance programme, I would like, with my vote, to recall the insufficient democratic control of the measures implemented in that context, as regards respect for the principle of subsidiarity. The programmes have often been implemented by the shiver of the fundamental values and rights enshrined in the Treaties and eu legislation, which in turn undermined their confidence in their representatives, including MEPs. I fully acknowledge the call made in this report for the Commission to take its role in overlooking the full and correct application of laws in order to protect fundamental rights, and that, together with the Council and the Member States, it should ensure that citizens' fundamental principles and rights are respected in economic and social matters and with regard to , among others, equality and non-discrimination, freedom of expression, religion and conscience, the protection of minorities and the rights of migrants and applicants for international protection.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to support and strengthen the protection of fundamental human rights. It proposes the creation of a comprehensive EU internal strategy on fundamental rights covering all EU bodies active in the area of respect for fundamental rights. I agree with the importance of ensuring that this strategy is consistent with the strategic framework for external relations in the field of human rights and democracy. It is important to carefully check member states' compliance with fundamental rights and the rule of law, not only before accession, but also after accession. I support the proposal to establish a mechanism with sufficient deterrents to prevent and eliminate violations of fundamental rights in the Member States. Priority areas include freedom of expression, the need to strike the right balance between respect for fundamental rights and collective security, the impact of austerity policies and corruption on fundamental rights and the situation in prisons.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Foreigners' right to vote, "LGBTI" propaganda, promotion of "Diversity", fight against "far-right" parties, immigrationism, non-borderism, EU enlargement, etc. It goes without saying that I could not endorse Mrs Ferrara's report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The report adopted by Parliament on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union highlights essential elements related to respect for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. It addresses, in a progressive way, such essential areas as equality and non-discrimination, the rights of children, migrants, LGBTI people, people with disabilities, violence against women, protection of minorities,... I would like to highlight a particular point in the report.  Namely, the need for a permanent mechanism to monitor the respect of fundamental rights and the rule of law by each Member State. This is obviously fundamental for the protection of all European citizens. I can only welcome the fact that a majority of Parliament has supported this report, which reminds us of the importance of Member States' respect for human dignity, freedom, non-discrimination, diversity and the fundamental principles of democracy. These are all values that underpin the construction of Europe and must therefore be respected at all times by each Member State.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU proposes to give a greater role to the Agency for Fundamental Rights (FRA), which wants a considerable extension of the scope of fundamental rights. This leads her, in any document, to consider that Roma are systematically discriminated against. In addition, a large part of the text is devoted to the rights of migrants and asylum seekers, and the text is moved by the rapid deportation procedures or the construction of walls to protect our borders. This report is indicative of the EU's ideology about immigration. So I voted against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this absolutely partisan text, which deals mainly with the rights of migrants and LGBTI without analysing the situation of the rights of European citizens too often ignored and trampled underfoot.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it deals with the situation of fundamental rights in the EU in a weighted way. The report proposes a dynamic evaluation mechanism of an annual nature which, on the basis of common and homologable criteria, makes it possible to know the state of democratic quality, the proper functioning of the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights in the Member States.  I also value the fact that the report on this occasion places particular emphasis on fundamental rights in relation to migration, asylum and refuge and that the need to ensure fundamental rights in detention centres and during procedures for the reception and return of migrants at the border is emphasized.  In turn, it is important to denounce the report the impact of austerity on economic, social and cultural rights and its call for the budgetary policy of each Member State to ensure sufficient levels of enjoyment of these rights. Finally, I value the report's in-depth address of the rights of women, the LGBT group and the EU's ethnic and religious minorities.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report by the European Parliament because it deals with the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union. This report calls on Member States to ensure that all EU legislation, including economic and financial adjustment programmes, is implemented in accordance with the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the European Social Charter (Article 151 TFEU). This Communication is the first attempt to remedy existing shortcomings in preventing and eliminating violations of fundamental rights and the rule of law in the Member States, and draws attention to the Commission's intention to regularly inform the European Parliament and the Council of the progress made at each stage.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I was unable to vote in favour of the Ferrara report because, under the guise of fundamental rights, it takes a position on a number of issues that not only extend beyond the competences of the Union, but are quite controversial among European citizens. The report proposes a new rule of law mechanism, which we do not see as necessary, because there is already a procedure in place to examine the fundamental legal situation in the Member States.  As has been demonstrated in recent years, left-wing factions use fundamental rights for political prevailing, first and fore for political purposes, first and fore in the face of Hungary-led Member States. In a similar way, a new rule of law mechanism would be used for political purposes.

name: David Borrelli (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Ferrara report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union 2013-2014 because the proposals put forward in the report, in addition to ensuring greater control and interaction with citizens, provide the means to ensure full respect for personal, civil, political, economic and social rights. The report we have voted on today presents the right strategy for involving the Union's bodies active in the field of fundamental rights, for combating those situations in the Member States where these rights are being disregarded and, finally, for Europe to stop dealing with these issues with the same indolence and short-sightedness that has always distinguished it up to now. It is important for the European Union to be vigilant and for its reaction to the many violations of fundamental rights in the Member States to be firm and resolute. The establishment of a new mechanism at European level to ensure respect for fundamental rights certainly goes in this direction.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this report by a fellow MEP on the state of fundamental human rights in the EU. I agree that the human rights strategy should be accompanied by an action plan, in co-operation with civil organisations. I consider particularly good the part of the report looking at thematic issues such as equality, the implementation of the anti-discrimination directive and 'Solidarity in Crisis'.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the status of fundamental rights in the EU. This report calls for a greater role for the FRA, the agency for fundamental rights, which wants a much greater scope of fundamental rights. Much of the text is devoted to "the rights of migrants and applicants for international protection." Another example, in the "citizenship" section, the report argues for the granting of municipal and European voting rights for non-European foreigners.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I am convinced that the protection of fundamental rights is one of the cornerstones of the Union's mission. I agree, in particular, with the rapporteurs' view that the rule of law needs to be strengthened, which is a first attempt to overcome the current shortcomings in the prevention and resolution of cases of violation of fundamental rights and the principles of the rule of law in the Member States.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. In the report proposed by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, member states' actions to curb growing insecurity in Europe are seen as an abuse of fundamental rights. Instead of focusing on the real challenges facing Europeans, such as the degradation of security that directly threatens the lives of our compatriots, the European Parliament prefers to condemn the legitimate means used by governments to strengthen the security of citizens. Worse still, the institution promotes openness in the face of the massive influx of migrants. In addition, Parliament has recently made a point of criticising Member States for their ineffectiveness in integrating Roma populations. They are unaware, however, that no social inclusion programme will be effective in the absence of a willingness on their part to better integrate and to better respect the rules and customs of the Member States. So I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The fundamentals of the European Union are to respect and promote human rights, fundamental freedoms, democracy and values enshrined in the instruments guaranteeing its functioning and in the international treaties to which the Union is a signatory.  I believe that the Member States have a particular responsibility for the implementation of the provisions contained in the Treaties which defend the rights and freedoms of citizens and underpin democracy and the rule of law. The treatment of the wave of migrants currently crossing Europe by the authorities of some Member States raises serious questions about respect for fundamental rights and freedoms in the EU. We are facing a number of major problems, which need an urgent and concrete response, with a view to eradicating poverty and social marginalisation, reducing unemployment and providing equal treatment and opportunities to all its citizens, regardless of the country in which they are. I welcome, in this regard, the importance of this report, at such a difficult time for Europe, when I am convinced that mutual trust and shared responsibility should take precedence, in order to counter the danger that President Juncker highlighted in the State of the Union debate: 'an absence of Europe in the European Union and a lack of union in this European Union'.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against, the text is absolutely partisan, it does not speak at 360 degrees about fundamental rights but above all about the rights of migrants and LGBTI. the rights violated today are quite different.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it deals with the situation of fundamental rights in the EU in a weighted way. The report proposes a dynamic evaluation mechanism of an annual nature which, on the basis of common and homologable criteria, makes it possible to know the state of democratic quality, the proper functioning of the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights in the Member States.  I also value the fact that the report on this occasion places particular emphasis on fundamental rights in relation to migration, asylum and refuge and that the need to ensure fundamental rights in detention centres and during procedures for the reception and return of migrants at the border is emphasized.  In turn, it is important to denounce the report the impact of austerity on economic, social and cultural rights and its call for the budgetary policy of each Member State to ensure sufficient levels of enjoyment of these rights. Finally, I value the report's in-depth address of women's rights, the LGBT group and the EU's ethnic and religious minorities

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Charter of Human Rights is an integral part of the european Union's legislative body. It is therefore imperative that these fundamental rights are respected in all Member States. Unfortunately, this is not always the case. However, we must show the rest of the world that we have built our project around unconditional values and that respect for fundamental rights is the cornerstone. We have already made enormous progress in this area and the European Union is a great example for many. We must continue to do so at all costs. However, I abstained in that vote. Although I fully agree with the principle of this report, which is to establish an overview of the situation of fundamental rights in the Union, I am not in line with all the provisions in the text.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union (2013-2014) on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union (2013-2014). There are still many violations of fundamental rights in Europe, as is also evident from the judgments of the European Court of Human Rights. I am thinking of violence against women, which is the most widespread violation of fundamental rights in the EU. But even the condition of minors, according to the WHO, are at least 850 under the age of 15 who die every year in Europe as a result of ill-treatment. It is also necessary not to suspend the fundamental rights that form the backbone of the Union, censoring barbed-wire walls and the horrific practice of marking human beings.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ With regret, as this report was prepared by a colleague from another delegation, I voted against this report as too much emphasis was placed on the suggestion that matters best decided at Member State level should be determined by the European Union.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report, which is designed to give an overview of the situation of fundamental rights in 2012 and 2013, was also an opportunity to stress the importance of observing and promoting the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. The rights it contains should be guaranteed to all citizens without distinction of sex, religion, sexual orientation and skin colour, while institutional actors and non-governmental organisations report alarming examples of violation. My colleague Laura Ferrara has done an excellent job and I voted strongly in favour of it.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Laura Ferrara's report. In particular, I welcome his desire to set up a European mechanism for the evaluation and control of democracy.  The European Union needs instruments to protect the values of the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights. It is necessary to strike a balance between legislative instruments that are too weak or non-existent and the nuclear option provided for in Article 7 of the Treaty of the European Union - suspension of a Member State's voting rights in the event of a serious and persistent violation of the Union's values. The democratic model defended and disseminated by the European Union is now being shaken. Once their integration into the Union is finalised, too many Member States become obedr butted off the democratic principles they had committed to implement during the accession process. This report has the merit of highlighting these shortcomings through an almost exhaustive list of rights and freedoms sometimes threatened in some Member States - from freedom of expression to children's rights to LGBTI rights.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, purely federalist and immigrationist, against which the ENL Group has tabled several amendments.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The report on the state of fundamental rights of the EU in 2013 and 2014 is indeed part of an institutional framework particularly sensitive to the issue of respect for the fundamental rights of the European Union today. The Charter of Fundamental Rights recognises to EU citizens a number of individual, civil, political, economic and social rights. Nevertheless, there are important issues that remain open and need to be reviewed in the report as well.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote against the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU (2013-2014). In the first part of the report, it is proposed to establish an internal strategy of the Union's fundamental rights, while in the second part the report deals in detail with a number of violations. The GROUP of the European People's Party, which also voted against the report in committee, considered the content of this report to be insufficient and not in line with its prerogatives.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 If you look at the content of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, the report is undoubtedly correct in many respects: in focusing on preventing the violation of fundamental rights in the Member States, freedom of expression, data protection, the impact of the economic crisis on fundamental rights or the situation of prisons. Nevertheless, I voted against the Ferrara report because I believe that my political group's alternative proposal was more balanced and practical. I think that the rapporteur has carried out her task with commitment and I congratulate her, but at the same time I believe that a greater search for compromises would have helped to broaden support. There is never a dictatorship of the majority in this Parliament, but a broadest possible representation of the interests at stake.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Ferrara report focuses on fundamental rights which are the deepest basis of the ideals and values on which the European Union is based. This exercise that the European Parliament does every year is only useful if it provides us with a picture of reality that allows us to identify our focuses of action.   But fundamental rights in this house must unite and not divide. The Ferrara Report goes too far. It is lengthened in debatable censorship considerations and often goes beyond the scope of the Union's competences. And it proposes a mechanism that should certainly not be discussed here. Changing the nature of the EU and the distinction between what is European and what is national is a matter for the Treaties. For all this, I abstained in the final vote, although I agree with many points that the report contains.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ While UKIP believes in fundamental rights, it does not believe that this should lead to increased federalism and power to the EU which in itself is anti democratic.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. I agree that fundamental rights, human rights and equal opportunities must be guaranteed to all European citizens, but also to people belonging to national and linguistic minorities. And in order to adequately protect rights, it is necessary to strengthen cooperation between the institutions and to take measures to monitor their implementation. In spite of this, I am obliged to vote against it, because this report introduces content that we cannot support with regard to the priorities and interpretation of certain fundamental human rights.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The report calls for recognition of abortion in life-saving circumstances.  I have voted against these calls as I remain in favour of the right to life. Furthermore, issues surrounding abortion reflect social, cultural, as well as personal beliefs and values. For this purpose they fall outside EU competence. The report does contain valid proposals for the protection of human rights in the EU such as freedom of expression, protection of children from abuse, rights of persons with disabilities, fighting corruption and prison conditions. These represent fundamental principles in a modern democracy and emanate from the value of respect for the person.   The report proposes a new mechanism for protection of human rights in the EU.  I do not believe this is necessary. The EU institutions must however not shy away from using the mechanism available to them. While I remain against abortion and voted against the proposals in this regard, I am not against the protection of children or persons with disabilities from abuse, am in favour of fighting corruption and of freedom of the media and other rights which this report seeks to strengthen. Consequently, I have abstained on the final vote on the report as a whole.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE)
text: Written. I stand up for full respect for fundamental rights. I supported many parts of the report, particularly those relating to children's rights, sexual and reproductive rights, the fight against violence against women and LGTBI rights. I abstained in the final vote, because many other elements should be dealt with at national level, such as the maternity leave directive. Nor do I support the new mechanism for monitoring respect for fundamental rights. It is the Commission's task as guardian of the Treaties to assess whether the Member States are living up to their obligations. The European Parliament should not become a court of law. Fundamental rights should never be politicised.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU because, among other elements, I consider it positive that it reflects the setback in the fulfilment of these rights as a result of austerity policies and cuts in public spending implemented by governments and advocated by the European Commission. I think it is very positive that the report is in need of the European Commission urgently implementing a specific strategy to achieve and ensure compliance with fundamental rights so that they cease to be mere wet paper.  I also share the criticisms it gathers about the systemic discrimination suffered today in the EU by groups such as migrants or Roma people, and I also consider it positive that it challenges the current asylum system and migrant regulations and how they directly and negatively affect the fundamental rights of these people.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because I believe that fundamental rights are an aggregating element of all EU citizens, as well as a fundamental element in the construction of Europe. I therefore support the actions mentioned in the resolution, such as: 1) strengthening actions and programmes to raise awareness of education and training in fundamental rights; 2) actions to monitor respect for fundamental rights in the EU; 3) ex ante and ex post audits aimed at assessing the impact of European policies on fundamental rights.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the report on the protection of fundamental rights. The main reason for my abstention is that, in agreement with my fellow Members of the People's Party, I believe that the protection of fundamental human rights must take a very important place within the activities of the European Union, but the report adopted abuses the possibilities of this subject on certain issues. As a minority member, I appreciate as a positive that the text of the report includes condemnation of all forms of discrimination and recognition of the protection of national minorities. In particular, the EP report calls for the EU institutions to better protect the linguistic, cultural and educational rights of these minorities. It calls on the Member States to implement effectively the minority protection documents of the Council of Europe and the OSCE. The report calls on the Commission to develop a comprehensive EU system to ensure equal treatment of indigenous minorities.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report assesses the situation of fundamental rights in the EU between 2013 and 2014. The resolution raises concerns about the impact of austerity measures on fundamental rights in the EU, and comments on the rights of children, LGBTI people, religious and ethnic minorities and homeless people; it also addresses the issues of freedom of speech, media freedom, anti-terrorism measures and hate speech. I voted in favour of the report as a whole as I believe that it is crucial to analyse the state of fundamental rights in the European Union, especially if our continent still wants to be a global leader in the fight for human dignity. As always I did not vote in favour of the paragraphs related to abortion.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that coordination between EU institutions and agencies and civil society organisations needs to be improved and also enhanced cooperation between THE EU institutions and the Member States, including between the European Parliament and national parliaments, in order to raise awareness of the need to promote a culture of respect and tolerance, to put an end to all forms of discrimination against women and to ensure the implementation of national strategies for respect for and protection of sexual rights and health, and reproductive use of women. I believe that the role of the Union in raising awareness of society and promoting good practice in this area must be stressed, given that health is a fundamental right essential to the exercise of other human rights.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report proposes the development of an internal strategy on fundamental rights based on the article. 2 of the Treaty on the European Union. The report addresses a range of violations, which have taken place in Europe, in the areas of freedom of expression, data protection, the impact of the economic crisis, corruption and the situation in prisons. It also deals with matters of European competence such as the fight against discrimination and the protection of the rights of migrants and refugees. The rapporteur also proposes the introduction of a rather unrealistic deterrent instrument to prevent violations of fundamental rights in states, a 'European Semester of Fundamental Rights', which is de facto intended to replace the intervention of the European Commission with the traditional action of the Court of Justice in this area. Considering this proposal, among others, more ideological than realistic, the EPP Group had tabled an alternative resolution reaffirming the commitment of its members to fundamental rights in Europe and addressing the same issues in a more balanced approach. As this alternative resolution was rejected, as well as part of our amendments on the main resolution in plenary, I decided to abstain.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. It is deplorable that once again the left is using the pretext of fundamental rights to get the European Parliament to adopt many unrealistic provisions that are not within its competence. Our party is firmly committed to the protection of fundamental rights in the European Union, which is too often undermined. We then voted in favour of a resolution that treats this situation with pragmatism and realism. However, I have not been able to support the resolution adopted by the left. It also contrasts the strengthening of security with the protection of fundamental rights, which are two complementary principles that are essential to the protection of European citizens; but it also flouts the principle of subsidiarity in Europe, especially with regard to the family. That's why I abstained.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is very important that we keep a close watch to the state of our Union, and its fundamental values. We have to keep a mirror to ourselves and to the Member States when it comes to our rights and freedoms. Rights of the LGBTI community, asylum seekers, immigrants and other vulnerable groups have to be respected. I fully support the call for effective action against violence against women, hate crime and hate speech. This report is a good reflection document on the state of our fundamental rights.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union was given the same legal effect as the Treaties. The Charter recognises a number of personal, civil, political, economic and social rights for all citizens residing in Europe. Despite this, there are still a large number of violations of rights that take place on the territory of the Member States of the European Union. All this is unacceptable, european institutions and Member States must be firm and resolute in preventing and putting an end to these violations. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that all EU citizens and residents should be able to enjoy the fundamental rights contained in the Charter without distinction of sex, religion, sexual orientation and skin colour.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The economic crisis, the effects of which are still very much present throughout Europe, has increased the precariousness and vulnerability of many European citizens, who are no longer able to fully benefit from their civil, economic, cultural and social rights. There is also the unprecedented migration crisis that Europe is facing with the arrival of many refugees, which requires us to rethink our migration policy in a spirit of solidarity.  Refugees must be welcomed in decent conditions in all Member States and the means of action of the European coastguard must be strengthened. In the long term, a common, effective and realistic European migration and asylum policy Will be necessary The protection of fundamental rights is the dual responsibility of the Member States and the EU institutions, but it is at the Community level that the situation can be best assessed. Thus, the establishment of a Commission-controlled scoreboard with common and objective criteria across the Union would allow for a better assessment of the situation at EU level.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I abstained on the vote on this resolution. Despite my commitment to fundamental rights in Europe, I have also supported the EPP's alternative resolution, I find the Ferrara report 'catch-all' and proposing unrealistic ideological proposals. Furtherover, I deplore the unrealistic call for all Member States to assess any national measures to combat terrorism (development of training programmes and good practice platforms and the exchange of information between law enforcement authorities and Member States and Europol). Finally, the issue of LGBTI marriage is the responsibility of the Member States.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I was unable to vote in favour of the Ferrara report because, under the guise of fundamental rights, it takes a position on a number of issues that not only extend beyond the competences of the Union, but are quite controversial among European citizens. The report proposes a new rule of law mechanism, which we do not see as necessary, because there is already a mechanism in place to examine the fundamental legal situation in the Member States.  As has been demonstrated in recent years, left-wing factions use fundamental rights for political prevailing, first and fore for political purposes, first and fore in the face of Hungary-led Member States. In a similar way, a new rule of law mechanism would be used for political purposes.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this ambitious report, which aims to assess how Member States respected fundamental rights in 2013-14. This type of report is essential as it is clear that even within the EU, fundamental rights are applied according to differing interpretations. The text covers the rights of women and children, LGBTI people, religious and ethnic minorities, the homeless, etc. It addresses topics such as freedom of expression, media freedom, counter-terrorism measures, privacy violations, surveillance and hate speech. It does not avoid the dramatic current issue of the situation of migrants and asylum seekers and urges that solidarity and respect for the fundamental rights of migrants and asylum seekers be placed at the heart of European migration policies. A request to which I can only associate myself with conviction.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I was unable to vote in favour of the Ferrara report because, under the guise of fundamental rights, it takes a position on a number of issues that not only extend beyond the competences of the Union, but are quite controversial among European citizens. The report proposes a new rule of law mechanism, which we do not see as necessary, because there is already a mechanism in place to examine the fundamental legal situation in the Member States.  As has been demonstrated in recent years, left-wing factions use fundamental rights for political prevailing, first and fore for political purposes, first and fore in the face of Hungary-led Member States. In a similar way, a new rule of law mechanism would be used for political purposes.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Under its very general title, the report presented to us is built on a series of politically correct elements. According to the rapporteur and some amendments of the radical left, fundamental rights would thus bring together the rights of sexual minorities, same-sex marriage and the recognition of transgender identities. Added to this are the stigmatization of popular movements and some realistic euro opinions as well as calls for mass immigration. Faced with such a misappropriation of a strong legal concept and in the face of the diversion of common European ideas for ideological purposes, I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is regrettable that while the EP legislates on the basis of the defence of human rights and fundamental freedoms and calls for respect for civil and political rights, despite repeated complaints by Golden Dawn MEPs about the illegal and statutory persecution of the parliamentary group and its officials by the Greek Government, it has not even formally examined these complaints.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I was unable to vote in favour of the Ferrara report because, under the guise of fundamental rights, it takes a position on a number of issues that not only extend beyond the competences of the Union, but are quite controversial among European citizens. The report proposes a new rule of law mechanism, which we do not see as necessary, because there is already a mechanism in place to examine the fundamental legal situation in the Member States.  As has been demonstrated in recent years, left-wing factions use fundamental rights for political prevailing, first and fore for political purposes, first and fore in the face of Hungary-led Member States. In a similar way, a new rule of law mechanism would be used for political purposes.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Respect for fundamental rights for the years 2013/2014 is highlighted by this report which indicates the way forward to improve compliance in the coming years. The Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union brings together in a single text all the personal, civic, political, economic and social rights enjoyed by people in the EU. The EU institutions are required to respect the rights enshrined in the Charter and, in October 2010, the Commission adopted a strategy for the effective implementation of the Charter which aims to ensure the absolute correctness of EU actions in support of fundamental rights.  Unfortunately, there are still many violations of fundamental rights in all Member States and, consequently, I believe that there must be a prompt and effective reaction from both the European institutions and the Member States so that we can put an end to these violations. In particular, I welcome the reference to the increase in cases of cross-border abduction by parents and, in this regard, I stress the importance of the role of the European Parliament Ombudsman for children who are victims of cross-border abduction by parents. Finally, I welcome the inclusion of the monitoring mechanism proposed by Mrs Ferrara, which has passed despite the Commission's opposition. I voted in favour.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The document addresses issues such as the impact of austerity measures on economic, civil, social and cultural rights, the rights of refugees, children and LGBTI people, discrimination, corruption and violations of press freedom. I therefore advocate the existence of a mechanism for the permanent monitoring of respect for fundamental rights by all EU countries. The report addresses a number of violations which I consider to be a priority in the light of the current political situation, such as freedom of expression, the need to ensure a fair balance between respect for fundamental rights and the guarantee of collective security and the impact of austerity policies and corruption on fundamental rights.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it advocates the right to vote in local elections for non-European nationals.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The human rights situation is given greater weight following the emergence of the new Commission and positive developments can therefore be expected in the coming years, as new legislation has also been adopted in this regard and the First Vice-President of the Commission must also fulfil the role of guarantor of the protection of fundamental rights in the European Union. Despite this positive statement, there are still many violations of fundamental rights in Europe on the territory of the Member States of the European Union. The European institutions must make even greater efforts to make similar cases happen less frequently. In the near future, the European Commission should focus on developing an internal strategy for fundamental rights.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I would like to draw attention first of all to the provision on the development of anti-Semitism in Europe, which has the consequence of exodus the Jewish community from Europe to Israel.  Last year, more than 26,000 migrants came from France, and more than four thousand came from war-torn Ukraine and Putin's Russia. The rise of anti-Semitism and violence against the Jewish community in Western European countries is a fact.  Poland is a contrast to this situation. This is despite a wave of deceitful propaganda about alleged Polish camps, defining German Nazi concentration camps (UNESCO nomenclature) – Polish, only because they were located in the territory of the German-occupied Polish. Jews see Poland as a friendly country. We are dealing with a renaissance of Jewish culture. I hope that the world will finally see the reality around us.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Of course my vote is negative because I find it regrettable that, on the one hand, the EP legislates on the basis of the defence of human rights and fundamental freedoms and calls for respect for civil and political rights and, on the other hand, ignores the repeated complaints made by golden dawn MEPs about the illegal and statutory persecution of the parliamentary group and its officials by the Greek Government and does not even formally examine these complaints.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We must find a way to deal properly with breaches of the rule of law and fundamental rights in EU Member States. An EU strategy should be accompanied by an action plan and include cooperation with civil society and the Fundamental Rights Agency. It should be accompanied by a European Union mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, as a tool for compliance with and enforcement of the Charter and Treaties as signed by all Member States. I strongly support the inclusion of equality, the call to implement the Anti-Discrimination Directive and ‘Solidarity in the crisis’, the highlight on the negative impact on economic, civil, social and cultural rights of the financial and economic and sovereign debt crisis, resulting in increasing unemployment, poverty, precarious working and living conditions, as well as social exclusion and isolation. We must stand firm on our positions and remain a driving force for concerted and proactive EU action on human rights and the rule of law, especially in these very challenging times for Europe.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Given the recent start of a new parliamentary term and the recent taking up of office by the new Commission, in which respect for the Charter of Fundamental Rights plays a prominent role, given the mandate of the First Vice-President and his important role as Commissioner for the Protection of Fundamental Rights in the Union, our priority should be to review the situation of fundamental human rights. Unfortunately, according to reports from institutional actors and NGOs, there are alarmingly high numbers of violations of fundamental rights in eu Member States. I find this situation unacceptable. The European institutions and the Member States must act decisively and resolutely to prevent and stop such infringements. Consistency with the strategic framework on human rights and democracy already in place in the EU's external relations should be ensured and the so-called 'Copenhagen dilemma', i.e. respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law should be thoroughly monitored not only before and after accession to the Union. Furthermore, in order for the strategy to be truly effective, a mechanism should be established which is indeed a deterrent to preventing and resolving violations of fundamental rights by Member States.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. The Union is facing socially enormous challenges, so Member States must allow coordination mechanisms at European level to be used to ensure that a fundamental pillar of the Union, human rights, prevails at all times in the face of these challenges. We agree on this: our priorities are today and will continue to be individuals and families in the future. We therefore regret that, faced with the opportunity to make a proposal for improvement, this report has been used to maintain populist principles in search only of the benefit of certain acronyms and not, as our action guide should be, to seek the benefit of all European citizenship. That is why I voted against the Ferrara report.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it deals with the situation of fundamental rights in the EU in a weighted way. The report proposes a dynamic evaluation mechanism of an annual nature which, on the basis of common and homologable criteria, makes it possible to know the state of democratic quality, the proper functioning of the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights in the Member States.  I also value the fact that the report on this occasion places particular emphasis on fundamental rights in relation to migration, asylum and refuge and that the need to ensure fundamental rights in detention centres and during procedures for the reception and return of migrants at the border is emphasized.  In turn, it is important to denounce the report the impact of austerity on economic, social and cultural rights and its call for the budgetary policy of each Member State to ensure sufficient levels of enjoyment of these rights. Finally, I value the report's in-depth address of the rights of women, the LGBT group and the EU's ethnic and religious minorities.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it places particular emphasis on fundamental rights in relation to migration, asylum and shelter and stresses the need to ensure fundamental rights in detention centres and during procedures for the reception and return of migrants at the border.  In turn, it is important to denounce the report the impact of austerity on economic, social and cultural rights and its call for the budgetary policy of each Member State to ensure sufficient levels of enjoyment of these rights. Finally, I value the report's in-depth address of the rights of women, the LGTBI collective and the EU's ethnic and religious minorities.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. As has already been said in the past, we are against discrimination, but even today we have been forced to vote against this report because it clearly violates the principle of subsidiarity and interferes with issues of absolutely national competence. This is frankly unacceptable and we must be clear about this, in order to counter the risk of these violations becoming ever greater over time.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2013 and 2014 because I believe that for a just, fair and supportive society we cannot ignore respect for the most basic human rights. The European Union is founded on the promotion of human rights, democracy and equal opportunities for all its citizens and therefore has a duty to oblige all Member States to respect these values.  According to surveys carried out by EU bodies and the numerous initiatives of European citizens through the institution of the petition, the main violations of human rights are against women, children, LGBTI people, the disabled and ethnic minorities, especially the Roma. In this sense, the Commission communication on the new EU framework for strengthening the rule of law can be a fundamental tool for preventing and resolving cases of breaches of fundamental rights, and I hope that this communication can be put into practice and refined in accordance with the suggestions made by the European Parliament.  I fully agree with the need for a shared approach to solving the migrant issue and for a harmonised system for the distribution of asylum seekers between Member States.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union (2013-2014) today because in many passages false conclusions are drawn and central demands violate the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Charter of Fundamental Rights recognises the civil, economic and social rights of citizens of the European Union. Therefore, I welcome this report as it puts the spotlight on whether the situation of these fundamental rights in the EU has been upheld in a respectful way during the last two years. We have much work to do at EU level to reduce discrimination but with this report and initiatives of the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights, I believe that we are on the right path.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. This report on human rights in the European Union is surreal. It develops the most extravagant innovations, contrary to natural law, as well as to the genius of Europe: exaltation of all sexual deviations, hedonism without borders, generalized indifferentiation, etc. On the other hand, nothing about the proliferation in many European countries of liberticidal laws restricting freedom of expression, once one of the essential achievements of our societies. In France, there have been numerous laws restricting this freedom, in history, in politics, in morals: Pleven law, Gayssot law, Perben law, Taubira law. In Germany, there are hundreds of prosecutions, each more odious than the other. Here, there and elsewhere, we exclude, we ruin, we imprison: academics, lawyers, political figures, simple and honest citizens.... These facts are known, and we are careful not to mention them.  And this in the 21st century! The only echoes that you pass on tend to reinforce or generalize this repression. All this testifies to the fundamental hypocrisy of the vast majority of European political elites today.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU. The Report takes over the 2013-2014 axis. Much of the fundamental amendments to the EGUE were incorporated as commitments. The text critically takes care of many rights elements, including advocacy of LGTBI people, disability, minorities, refugees and other victims of structural violence. The report could still be tougher in pointing out what is structural about such violence, although this exercise could result in some loss of consensus around it. Still, we consider the whole text positive and hope that it will delve into a path of shielding fundamental rights.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it covers a range of areas of fundamental rights for a wide number of groups such as children, the LGBTI community, religious and ethnic minorities and homeless people. It also addresses issues such as freedom of speech, media freedom, anti-terrorism measures, privacy violations, surveillance and hate speech. In addition, the report includes proposals to revise the Dublin Regulation particularly in light of the migrant crisis that is occurring in the European Union. The report also calls for an assessment of the impact on austerity measures on fundamental rights.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it deals with the situation of fundamental rights in the EU in a weighted way. The report proposes a dynamic evaluation mechanism of an annual nature which, on the basis of common and homologable criteria, makes it possible to know the state of democratic quality, the proper functioning of the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights in the Member States.  I also value the fact that the report on this occasion places particular emphasis on fundamental rights in relation to migration, asylum and refuge and that the need to ensure fundamental rights in detention centres and during procedures for the reception and return of migrants at the border is emphasized.  In turn, it is important to denounce the report the impact of austerity on economic, social and cultural rights and its call for the budgetary policy of each Member State to ensure sufficient levels of enjoyment of these rights. Finally, I value the report's in-depth address of the rights of women, the LGBT group and the EU's ethnic and religious minorities.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. It is with strength and conviction that I supported this Parliament's report on the situation of fundamental rights in 2012 and 2013. It is indeed necessary to present objectively the failures that can be identified in either Member State in terms of respect for fundamental rights. I therefore welcome the adoption of this report, which allows for a frank and courageous analysis of the situation. I regret, however, that on this subject, progressive political groups have not been able to present a common front. In addition to a particularly archaic view of society, which here and there is cutting back on such fundamental rights as freedom of expression and the media, migrant rights, equality between women and men and the rights of people with disabilities, the conservative right has refused to see an effective monitoring mechanism in place to monitor respect for fundamental rights in the Union. Unfortunately, the findings on human rights violations in the EU still persist. This alarming finding can only make the case for the European institutions to have the necessary tools.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully agree with the rapporteur, therefore I voted for this report which addresses the importance of the fundamental rights in the EU. Primarily, all the EU citizens should have the same rights despite their age, sex, sexual orientation, race or religion. It is necessary to ensure consistency with the Strategic Framework on Human Rights and Democracy in the context of foreign relations and to verify thoroughly that there is respect for fundamental rights and the Rule of Law not only in those countries applying for membership of the EU but also in States that are already members. The EU has the duty to secure its citizens with the most important rights, hence, in order to avoid its violations, the mechanism is absolutely necessary.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it deals with the situation of fundamental rights in the EU in a weighted way. The report proposes a dynamic evaluation mechanism of an annual nature which, on the basis of common and homologable criteria, makes it possible to know the state of democratic quality, the proper functioning of the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights in the Member States.  I also value the fact that the report on this occasion places particular emphasis on fundamental rights in relation to migration, asylum and refuge and that the need to ensure fundamental rights in detention centres and during procedures for the reception and return of migrants at the border is emphasized.  In turn, it is important to denounce the report the impact of austerity on economic, social and cultural rights and its call for the budgetary policy of each Member State to ensure sufficient levels of enjoyment of these rights. Finally, I value the report's in-depth address of the rights of women, the LGBT group and the EU's ethnic and religious minorities.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The Charter of Fundamental Rights recognises to EU citizens and residents a range of individual, civil, political, economic and social rights, without discrimination on grounds of sex, religion, sexual orientation or colour. However, violations of these rights taking place on EU territory have not been contained. On the contrary, the crisis and austerity are sweeping and eroding the level of fundamental rights enjoyed by the people while cultivating the ground for the rise of racism and the far right.  The report reflects in a relatively comprehensive way the reality, which contradicts the promises and declarations of the European leadership on prosperity and human rights. It turns out, once again, that the European Union, before taking lessons in democracy and freedoms to the rest of the world, must first look inside its own home.  This situation will certainly not change with the granting of new super powers to the Brussels directory which will allow it to impose sanctions on the Member States at its discretion, a crisis which has repeatedly proved to be ulterior motives. Fundamental changes are needed in Europe, a new socio-economic path that will guarantee, not only on paper but also in practice, fundamental rights as an integral part of the daily lives of all the inhabitants of our continent.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union for the period 2013-2014. Europe is quick to call for fundamental rights to be upheld around the world, but our Member States must also look inward and continue to protect and enforce the European values and fundamental rights enshrined in the Treaties and the Charter. I voted in favour of Amendments 5 and 8 on the rights of asylum-seekers and the principle of solidarity and for paragraphs supporting issues such as freedom of religion and belief, violence against women, LGBTI rights and rights of people with disabilities. I also supported the call for an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights and to grant the FRA wider powers and greater resources, so that it can monitor the situation in Member States and publish an annual monitoring report containing a detailed evaluation of each Member State’s performance.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The report by MEP Laura Ferrara (EFDD) analyses the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union (2013-2014) and refers to the main international agreements. These include the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union (2000), the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) (1950) and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (1948). While supporting the basic orientation of the methodically soundly drafted Ferrara report, there are, on the other hand, considerable shortcomings: the report is excessive and far too long, contains a number of political demands which do not belong to fundamental rights in the strict sense, and in doing so repeatedly violates the principle of subsidiarity. Only the alternative report presented by the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, which was ultimately not adopted, had almost completely eliminated these shortcomings and was therefore supported by me. Incidentally , and this is my ceterum censeo – I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I did not support the Ferrara report. Using the theme of fundamental rights, the document takes a position on a number of issues that not only extend beyond the competences of the Union, but which are highly controversial among European citizens. The report proposes a new rule of law mechanism, which we do not see as necessary, because there is already a mechanism in place to examine the fundamental legal situation in the Member States.  As has been demonstrated in recent years, left-wing factions are using fundamental rights for political purposes, first and fore fore most against Member States led by the People's Party, Hungary opposition. In a similar way, a new rule of law mechanism would be used for political purposes.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report comes at a critical moment when the fundamental rights in the Union face a number of challenges. I support, in full, measures to monitor democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Member States. It is imperative that we uphold the rights enshrined in the Treaties. As a member of the Women’s Rights and Gender Equality Committee, I supported the inclusion of a number of proposals to strengthen women’s rights, including action to tackle violence against women.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. This report by a member of the 5-Star Movement proposes a strategy on fundamental rights in the EU that is completely unobtrusive. Here we have a report which sets out a series of slogans aimed at an already acquired electorate rather than an analysis of the real situation of fundamental rights in Europe. This report thus requires the introduction of a mechanism for monitoring Member States by an unelected EU agency, which amounts to denying the sovereignty of states and the role of their institutions.  Moreover, without minimizing the situation of LGBTI people who are subject to real discrimination in some States, I believe that using this report to make the case for marriage for all is still a negation of the debates taking place in some European countries. It is not for the European Parliament to trample on the cultural traditions of these countries by imposing its dogma on them in defiance of the principle of subsidiarity. Finally, I see a tendency of members on the left to bring the intelligence services into disrepute, which are essential links in the security of our fellow citizens. The obsession with transparency is a danger to our societies and a green light for the enemies of democracies.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Paragraph 42 is fairly straightforward in condemning the rising anti-Semitism in Europe and attacks on Jewish people. Paragraph 43 is similarly straightforward in its condemnation of attacks on Europe’s Islamic communities. What is shocking is that a large number of the ECR Group chose to vote against these paragraphs. These votes underline the problem of racism in Europe and it is shameful that the UK Conservative Party allies itself with these racists.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the state of fundamental rights in the EU in 2013 and 2014 is particularly important as it represents another small step in ensuring the rule of law, equality, respect for fundamental rights, including the rights of minorities, which are unfortunately not equally protected in all countries.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU. The Report takes over the 2013-2014 axis. Much of the fundamental amendments to the EGUE were incorporated as commitments. The text critically takes care of many rights elements, including advocacy of LGTBI people, disability, minorities, refugees and other victims of structural violence. The report could still be tougher in pointing out what is structural about such violence, although this exercise could result in some loss of consensus around it. Still, we consider the whole text positive and hope that it will delve into a path of shielding fundamental rights.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the state of fundamental rights in the European Union (2013-2014), as I consider it inadmissible that cases of serious human rights violations are still being recorded across the European Union and its Member States. The answer to such situations must be reassessed and strong to prevent them from appearing, regardless of gender, sexual orientation, religion or color of people's skin.  The current state of respect for fundamental human rights is of course not satisfactory on the world level either, and therefore a comprehensive approach is needed to help find a common solution. In this context, I support the creation of an internal fundamental rights strategy in the European Union to ensure consistency of European legal documents and principles.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report discusses institutional issues and analyses the status of specific fundamental rights. In particular, it calls for the strengthening of the role of the FRG, the agency for fundamental rights, which continues to advocate for a considerable expansion of the scope of fundamental rights.  In addition, an important part of the text is devoted to "the rights of migrants".  The text is also concerned about the "increasing phenomenon of rapid expulsion"; it condemns Member States that build "walls and barbed wire to protect their borders"; Roma are systematically portrayed as victims of discrimination. This text is not just an immigrationist. It is deeply destructive in its unqualified support for the unrelenting demands of LGBTI groups such as the pseudo-right of transgender people to change sex or the so-called right of same-sex couples to marry.  Thus, this very politically correct report is in many ways unacceptable. Because of the repeated attacks on the sovereignty of states and the freedom of opinion of the individuals contained in this motion for a resolution, I voted against its adoption.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ While the Ferrara report had a number of elements with which I wholeheartedly agree, such as the condemnation of rising anti-Semitism and trivialisation of racist and xenophobic acts, I remain of the belief that the overall EU approach to the migration crisis is not the right one. Therefore, I was unable to vote in favour of this report in the end.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I abstained on the Ferrara report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union (2013-2014). The report put to the vote was indeed a "catch-all" containing many ideological and unrealistic proposals, blurring the clear and strong message that the European Parliament must convey on the issue of fundamental rights. For this reason, however, I have supported the alternative resolution of my political group, the EPP, which recalls our group's commitment to fundamental rights and common European values. This much clearer and more balanced text calls on Member States to ensure that all European policies are in line with the Charter of Fundamental Rights.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. The Ferrara report is unfortunately tinged with a lot of ideology, which is why the EPP Group had proposed an alternative report, which in my opinion was more consensual but which was not accepted. Nevertheless it is important to defend fundamental rights within the EU, which is why I have decided to abstain on the original report and not to vote against it.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I rejected this report because it does not offer realistic allying approaches.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. – I voted against the resolution on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg. The text of the resolution is, in my view, unacceptable for a number of reasons, but the main one was the call for non-citizens to be allowed to vote in elections. I find it unacceptable that Parliament's left-flank strategy is to make a huge amount of recommendations for a text that, in essence, does not need to be in such a resolution. As a result, almost half of the members present were forced to vote against such an important report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the adoption of the resolution. It includes a mechanism to monitor and measure infringements of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in EU Member States. We have long called for such a mechanism, backed up by increased powers for the Commission to issue formal warnings and corrective measures for persistent offenders.

name: Timothy Kirkhope (ECR)
text: in writing. – Whereas the ECR Group fully supports fundamental rights, equality and the fight against discrimination for all, there are however, many areas within this report which are not competences of the EU, such as education, prisons, national intelligence services, and a number of issues of conscience. There are also a large number of issues within the report which do not fall within the scope of this report, such as austerity and immigration.  The report also calls for the EU to create a new Fundamental Rights Scoreboard and a new infringement procedure mechanism for breaches of fundamental rights, as well as proposing introducing country-by-country monitoring of fundamental rights, which the ECR Group does not feel is the most effective way of dealing with fundamental rights breaches within the Union.  Whilst the ECR supports a number of the aims contained within this report, it believes that tackling a large number of these issues is best pursued by the Member States.  Therefore, the ECR group could not vote in favour of this report.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The report by MEP Laura Ferrara (EFDD) analyses the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union (2013-2014) and refers to the main international agreements. These include the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union (2000), the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) (1950) and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (1948). While supporting the basic orientation of the methodically soundly drafted Ferrara report, there are, on the other hand, considerable shortcomings: the report is excessive and far too long, contains a number of political demands which do not belong to fundamental rights in the strict sense, and in doing so repeatedly violates the principle of subsidiarity. The alternative report presented by the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats and ultimately not adopted it had almost completely eliminated these shortcomings and was therefore supported by me.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
