text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I was unable to vote in favour of the Ferrara report because, under the guise of fundamental rights, it takes a position on a number of issues that not only extend beyond the competences of the Union, but are quite controversial among European citizens. The report proposes a new rule of law mechanism, which we do not see as necessary, because there is already a mechanism in place to examine the fundamental legal situation in the Member States.  As has been demonstrated in recent years, left-wing factions use fundamental rights for political prevailing, first and fore for political purposes, first and fore in the face of Hungary-led Member States. In a similar way, a new rule of law mechanism would be used for political purposes.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The protection of human and fundamental rights must be the focus of European immigration policies. Today's vote is further confirmation of this. We need more solidarity. Firstly, in the search and rescue of those who, every day, fleeing conflict, hunger and persecution, risk their lives to reach Europe. But also in the EU's internal and external policies. The right of asylum is a fundamental right and, with today's vote, we strongly condemn all acts of refoulement at the EU's borders, which are contrary to international law and conventions.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union. The report prepared by Laura Ferrara is a veritable three Swiss catalogue of political correctness, communitarianism and immigrationism. In particular, it aims to further encourage legal immigration, and advocates the granting of the right to vote in local and European elections to third-country nationals. Paragraph 165 "condemns the fact that more than 15 million nationals of third countries and 500,000 stateless persons in the European Union are victims of the discriminatory refusal to recognise their citizenship; demands respect for the fundamental right to citizenship by the European Union and its Member States." We see what an inflation of the concept of fundamental rights can lead to. Although some points have not been accepted, this report goes against common sense.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it uses human rights to justify more interference by the European Union in the internal affairs of the Member States. He also denounced the rise of "xenophobic parties", which appears to be an insulting and unacceptable attack on the National Front.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because, on the one hand, it addresses the European Parliament developing a strategy on fundamental rights in the EU on the basis of Article 2 of the Treaty, which should be accompanied by an action plan including cooperation with civil society and the European Agency for Fundamental Rights. Moreover, the report contains a second part addressing the various issues raised in the EU in terms of fundamental rights: the implementation of the Anti-Discrimination Directive (blocked in the Council for several years) and the impact of the economic and financial crisis on the enjoyment of fundamental rights, with particular emphasis on unemployment , poverty, precarious work and social exclusion.  In addition, the report contains references to women's rights, including sexual and reproductive health issues, and LGBT people who pose an important divide between progressives and conservatives.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it deals with the situation of fundamental rights in the EU in a weighted way. The report proposes a dynamic evaluation mechanism of an annual nature which, on the basis of common and homologable criteria, makes it possible to know the state of democratic quality, the proper functioning of the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights in the Member States.  I also value the fact that the report on this occasion places particular emphasis on fundamental rights in relation to migration, asylum and refuge and that the need to ensure fundamental rights in detention centres and during procedures for the reception and return of migrants at the border is emphasized.  In turn, it is important to denounce the report the impact of austerity on economic, social and cultural rights and its call for the budgetary policy of each Member State to ensure sufficient levels of enjoyment of these rights. Finally, I value the report's in-depth address of the rights of women, the LGBT group and the EU's ethnic and religious minorities.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU because, among other elements, I consider it positive that it reflects the setback in the fulfilment of these rights as a result of austerity policies and cuts in public spending implemented by governments and advocated by the European Commission. I think it is very positive that the report is in need of the European Commission urgently implementing a specific strategy to achieve and ensure compliance with fundamental rights so that they cease to be mere wet paper.  I also share the criticisms it gathers about the systemic discrimination suffered today in the EU by groups such as migrants or Roma people, and I also consider it positive that it challenges the current asylum system and migrant regulations and how they directly and negatively affect the fundamental rights of these people.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The report by MEP Laura Ferrara (EFDD) analyses the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union (2013-2014) and refers to the main international agreements. These include the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union (2000), the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) (1950) and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (1948). While supporting the basic orientation of the methodically soundly drafted Ferrara report, there are, on the other hand, considerable shortcomings: the report is excessive and far too long, contains a number of political demands which do not belong to fundamental rights in the strict sense, and in doing so repeatedly violates the principle of subsidiarity. The alternative report presented by the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats and ultimately not adopted it had almost completely eliminated these shortcomings and was therefore supported by me.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I find it nonsensical to call for "EU Member States to support trade unions and employers' organisations in their efforts to adopt a diversity and non-discrimination strategy with particular regard to LGBTI people." I do not agree with the statement that 'strongly condemns the security protection of the European Union's borders' and the building of fences on the border of the Schengen area.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The foundations on which the European Union was founded are the desire for a democratic society, the rule of law and respect for human rights and freedoms. Neighbourhood events, including in The Member States, have increasingly affected Union citizens in recent years and these foundations are under threat.  Terrorist attacks result in increasing intolerance and discrimination, violence in all forms persists, and the pressing problem of migration from war zones poses a major threat, but also responsibility to all Member States. However, I did not support Ferrara's report because they are incompatible with the beliefs of the European People's Party Group and certain positions are incompatible with the promotion of the protection of fundamental human rights.  The decisions we make must always take into account respect for human rights and freedoms enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights, such as media freedom, religion or minority. Citizens should be given security and equality, protected from all forms of discrimination and violence, and Member States should be encouraged to strengthen institutional transparency and implement strategies.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 What has been happening recently in the countries of the European Union is a clear signal that respect for and respect for fundamental rights takes various forms. The lack of flexibility and the lack of timeliness in resolving the real problems of the population by the Union and individual Member States, together with insufficient and incomplete awareness, is due to the emergence of undemocratic, fascist, authoritarian and populist groups on the political scene. The report itself notes non-compliance with rights in a number of areas. However, this finding, without taking concrete measures, will not bring about a change or a shift. What Europe will look like in a few years' time, whether it respects rights and is democratic, depends on the steps we are taking right now.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union (2013-2014), for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 7/9/2015. Furthermore, it should be noted that, particularly in Greece, the memorial measures deprived the poor people of the right of access to basic public goods such as health, education and social security. For this reason, the European Union, and in particular the Commission, must also enforce respect for the Charter of Fundamental Rights in Greece. Furthermore, we criticise Commissioner Moscovici's reply to my written question that 'the European Social Charter is not supposedly binding under EU law and does not therefore impose legal obligations on the Union and its Member States within the legal order of the European Union', thus discrediting and insulting my compatriots in the Memorandum.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text, which greatly expanded the role of the FRA (Fundamental Rights Agency). This text, among other things, allows itself to condemn Member States that build walls and barbed wire to protect themselves from illegal entrances, and calls for ever more legal entry routes for migrants. He goes even further by seeing Roma as victims rather than responsible for their own fate; and by granting municipal and European voting rights for non-European foreigners! We are fundamentally against these decisions.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report. I welcome its emphasis this year on tackling violence against women. Violence against women is the most widespread violation of fundamental rights in the EU and throughout the world, and whereas it affects all levels of society, regardless of age, education, income, social position and country of origin or residence, and represents a major barrier to equality between women and men.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am not in favour of the report on the state of the EU's fundamental rights. The text deals with issues and aspects not covered by the EU Treaties or international conventions and, above all, fall within the exclusive competence and discipline of the individual Member States. For these reasons, I did not support my colleague's report.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU, which so often makes recommendations on non-compliance with human rights by third countries, cannot but look at itself and examine whether and to what extent fundamental rights are fulfilled within it.  Situations such as the recent humanitarian crisis of migrants and refugees and the attitude of some Member States, such as Hungary, show how much there is to do. It is essential to have an additional mechanism to increase effective respect for and protection of people's fundamental rights against violations thereof, including the right to effective remedies, and to increase the accountability of the European institutions for their actions or omissions in this regard. I share the concern about the worrying developments in violations of fundamental rights in the EU, in particular in the field of immigration and asylum, discrimination and intolerance against certain populations and the attacks or pressures on NGOs that defend the rights of these groups and populations. I find it regrettable that Member States are reluctant to enforce the fundamental freedoms and rights of Roma, women, LGBTI people, asylum seekers, migrants and other vulnerable populations. For all this, I voted for it.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The EU needs, as noted in the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2013-2014, the EU needs an internal strategy on fundamental rights and to ensure, in external relations, coherence with the strategic framework on human rights and democracy. Moreover, for the proposed strategy to be truly effective, it is necessary to establish a mechanism that is really a sufficient deterrent to prevent and eradicate violations of fundamental rights in the Member States. My vote would be in favour of continuing to work to eradicate human rights violations from the EU on issues relating to freedom of expression, the need to ensure the right balance between respect for fundamental rights and collective security, as well as the situation in prisons, but I cannot accept that they are permanently trying to introduce aspects that clash with subsidiarity or enshrine as rights what are clearly not. For this reason, even if I agree with many aspects of the report, I cannot vote on it in the affirmative.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. As every year, the European Parliament was called, through a resolution, to draw up an overview of the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union. Once again, the Ferrara report looked at a period (2013-2014) marked by significant declines in respect for human and social rights. In my view, it has the merit of pointing out without ambiguity the root causes of these violations, including the persistence of austerity policies that undermine the right to housing, education or health in many Member States. In the same way, I share the disturbing observation made by the resolution: the management of migration flows is too often approached from a repressive perspective, which undermines the rights of migrants. Finally, the Ferrara report is a timely reminder that the implementation of anti-terrorist measures must not call into question the right of European citizens to the protection of their privacy. I therefore wholeheartedly supported the text, and strongly rejected the amendments of the European conservatives who, loyal to their mentor Viktor Orban, simply sought to remove the chapter on press freedom from the resolution.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report must be rejected in its full terms, as it advocates the legal immigration of asylum seekers, but does not contain any solutions as to how to proceed. Moreover, if we also call for both the right to vote in European elections for third-country nationals and the citizenship of the Union for them, you can only oppose it. In addition, parties and opinions that do not correspond to the "asylum trend" are described as racist, Islamophobic and the like from a purely subjective point of view. Quite apart from the strengthening of the Agency for Fundamental rights and LGBTI rights, which should also be enshrined in law. I therefore reject this request.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Parliament takes stock of the human rights situation in the EU every year. The rapporteur of the Italian 5 Star Movement urges states and the Commission to recognise the consequences of austerity policies and memorandums on citizens' rights: freedom of expression, increasing repression against social and trade union movements, discrimination against Roma, migrants, etc. It has been a long time since we have seen such firm language in this domesticated chamber. "The Commission and the Member States have reacted weakly to mass espionage practices"; "Responsibilities for the illegal deportation and detention of CIA detainees in European countries should be established." "Secularism and state neutrality are the best guarantors of non-discrimination." "The refusal of abortion to save a woman's life is a serious violation of human rights."  I welcome this serious work and I vote for it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report discusses institutional issues and analyses the status of specific fundamental rights. In particular, it calls for the strengthening of the role of the FRG, the agency for fundamental rights, which continues to advocate for a considerable expansion of the scope of fundamental rights.  In addition, an important part of the text is devoted to "the rights of migrants".  The text is also concerned about the "increasing phenomenon of rapid expulsion"; it condemns Member States that build "walls and barbed wire to protect their borders"; Roma are systematically portrayed as victims of discrimination. This text is not just an immigrationist. It is deeply destructive in its unqualified support for the unrelenting demands of LGBTI groups such as the pseudo-right of transgender people to change sex or the so-called right of same-sex couples to marry. Thus, this very politically correct report is in many ways unacceptable. Because of the repeated attacks on the sovereignty of states and the freedom of opinion of the individuals contained in this motion for a resolution, I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU in 2013 and 2014 is part of a particularly favourable and sensitive institutional context with regard to respect for fundamental rights in the European Union in our day. A new parliamentary term has recently begun and a new Commission has been appointed, in which respect for the Charter of Fundamental Rights plays an important role in the light of the mandate given to the first Vice-President and his role as authority for the protection of fundamental rights in the European Union. All citizens and persons residing in the EU should be able to enjoy the rights enshrined therein, regardless of sex, religion, sexual orientation and skin colour.  Although I agree with the generality of what is reflected in this report, I cannot but note that there are some aspects dealt with here that should be addressed in another context, so I voted against this document.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ While this report contained aspects aimed at ending violations of fundamental rights, the final version of the report contained unacceptable references to sexual and reproductive health and rights, which may be interpreted as the right to abortion. Therefore, I could not support the full text.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The Union is quick to denounce human rights violations around the world, but is cautious about doing so within it. Women, children, LGBTI, disabled people, the elderly, migrants, Roma... all are still victims of violations of their most basic rights, and this, within all Member States. This report sheds light on all of these violations and provides concrete solutions. Today we still lack the Union of our rights. More than ever today we need objective and continuous monitoring of the situation in each Member State, based on common indicators. We must also institutionalise the dialogue and make it systematic in the event of a Member State's violation of the commitments it made when it joined the European Union.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the report on the situation of the fundamental rights in the EU (2013-2014), which includes a section on institutional questions, and states that the Parliament ‘expects to see an internal strategy on fundamental rights based on article 2 of the TFEU adopted in the near future’, and explains that such a strategy should be accompanied by an action plan and include cooperation with civil society and the Fundamental Rights Agency. The report also looks into thematic issues, including equality, calls to implement the Anti-Discrimination Directive and ‘Solidarity in the crisis’, highlighting the negative impact on economic, civil, social and cultural rights of the financial and economic and sovereign debt crisis, resulting in increasing unemployment, poverty, precarious working and living conditions, as well as social exclusion and isolation. Nevertheless, I have never supported and voted against any references to sexual and reproductive health, rights, services and abortion, which in my opinion fall strictly under a competence of the Member States. Therefore, I have voted against Paragraph 68 and Recital AN and abstained on paragraph 69.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Living in a European liberal democracy does not mean that we can take fundamental rights for granted. Because this will be the moment those rights will be seriously at stake. The migration and humanitarian crisis, the situation of minorities, figures on violence against women and the frequent hate speeches are affecting EU citizen’s everyday life. I would like to mention also the terrorism challenge we are facing: The respect of fundamental rights and freedom has to be fully incorporated into the internal security strategy of the EU and this is not negotiable. Therefore, the annual report on fundamental rights is an important assessment and should be considered as the base for our future work. Not only the European Parliament, but also the Commission should act on this and start to use all the existing mechanisms provided by the treaties to ensure that the institutions and the member states fully comply with the charter of fundamental rights when applying EU legislation.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon has given the Charter of Fundamental Rights, which recognises the personal, civil, political, economic and social rights of EU citizens and residents, the same binding legal force as that of the Treaties. Respect for the Charter of Fundamental Rights plays a prominent role in the activities of the new parliamentary term and the new Commission, which has just begun. The report notes that, nevertheless, there are alarmingly high numbers of violations of fundamental rights in the EU Member States, and that the European institutions and the Member States must act decisively and decisively to prevent and stop such infringements. To this end, the report proposes a strategy that would ensure consistency with the strategic framework on human rights and democracy already in place in the EU's external relations and overcome the so-called 'Copenhagen dilemma', by proposing to monitor respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law not only before but also after accession to the Union. It also proposes to establish a mechanism that is sufficiently deterrent to prevent and resolve violations of fundamental rights by Member States.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Union has always been in favour of mass immigration, the guilt of its citizens, responsible for the miseries of the world and obliged, to atone for their fault, to welcome all peoples in search of a better future. This is again the meaning of this report. Roma are, as usual, considered victims of discrimination and are never responsible for their plight. Migrants and applicants for international protection, i.e. mostly illegal economic refugees, should benefit from more legal access routes. States that wish to limit these flows are singled out, the right to vote is required in municipal elections, etc. Such a text is clearly unacceptable, let alone in a context of unprecedented migratory pressure.  The only possible vote is therefore resolutely against it.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Bringing the situation of fundamental rights in the Union annually is a clear way of demonstrating the union's commitment to safeguarding the foundational principles of the Union itself.  However, I believe that this report goes too far and often goes beyond the union's competences. For these reasons I abstained in the final vote, although I agree that this issue must always be on our political agenda.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU proposes to give a greater role for the Agency for Fundamental Rights (FRA), which is constantly advocating for a considerable expansion of the scope of fundamental rights. This arrogant imperialism leads her, as in any document, to consider the Roma as systematically discriminated against. In addition, a large part of the text is devoted to the rights of migrants and asylum seekers, moving on to rapid deportation procedures or the construction of walls to protect borders. This text is indicative of the EU's sclerosis over immigration. So I voted against this immigration report.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it covers a range of areas in fundamental rights of a number of other groups such as children, LGBTI-people, religious and ethnic minorities and homeless. It also addresses issues such as freedom of speech, media freedom, anti-terrorism measures, privacy violations, surveillance and hate speech. In addition, the report includes proposals to revise the Dublin Regulation particularly in light of the migrant crisis that is occurring in the European Union. The report also calls for an assessment of the impact on austerity measures on fundamental rights.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I have supported some of the measures in this text, including those that propose strengthening the rights of women and children in the face of violence and sexual inequalities. On the other hand, I voted against the provisions of the text stating that legal immigration routes in the European Union are insufficient, at a time when our reception capacity is already saturated and the European people are showing great generosity. Finally, I abstained on the final vote because this report calls for a weakening of the EU's external borders at a time when we need protected and effective external borders in return for the free movement of the Schengen area.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the adoption of this report, we intend to reaffirm the fundamental role we recognise in the Charter of Fundamental Rights in detailing a number of personal, civil, political, economic and social rights of EU citizens and residents. With the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, it was then given the same binding legal effect as all the Treaties. We are convinced that all European citizens and residents should be able to enjoy the rights it contains without distinction of sex, religion, sexual orientation and skin colour. Unfortunately, institutional actors and non-governmental organisations are alarmingly reporting on the still very numerous violations of fundamental rights taking place on European territory. We believe that this situation is no longer tolerable and we call on all the European institutions and the Member States to take firm and determined action to prevent such violations. To this end, we hope for the implementation of a genuine internal EU fundamental rights strategy based on the application of Article 2 of the Treaty and involving all the Union bodies active in the field of respect for fundamental rights. It is necessary to be able to ensure greater coherence with the strategic framework on human rights and democracy in all external relations.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The task of the Human Rights Report would be to provide us with a mirror of how we stand in respect for fundamental values and freedoms in our countries. There's still room for progress.  With my amendments to this report, I have drawn attention to the phenomenon of the rise and spread of extreme nationalism, racism, xenophobia and intolerance throughout Europe. The reasons for this include terrorist attacks, but one thing is the cause and the other is the phenomenon itself, which urgently needs to be addressed. Mistrust among citizens is growing, especially towards the unknown or from the majority to other cultures. This not only affects immigrant communities, but also has a particularly negative impact on the situation of indigenous national and ethnic minorities.  I urge you to take concrete steps to stop aggression, including hate speech. We politicians must choose our words with particular care. He plays with the future of Europe, who excites aggression from populism, momentary vote-winning, and deepens mistrust.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Taking into consideration that almost one third of the petitions received by Parliament relate to alleged breaches of fundamental human rights, I have voted for this report with respect for fundamental rights in the European Union today.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on this report because, although it starts from a positive premise, namely it supports and encourages respect for fundamental human rights and the rule of law at EU level, the document also touches on a number of contradictory and very sensitive themes in some European countries, including Romania.  The report presents a number of points, which I support, on respect for fundamental rights in EU Member States such as equal opportunities and combating discrimination on grounds of gender, ethnicity or religion. But at the same time, the proposed text loses sight of the fact that societies and mindsets in each Member State are at different levels of acceptance and evolution, often for religious and cultural reasons. However, to require all companies in the Member States to develop their collective mind at a common level, without distinguishing between the times required for these societies to go down a natural path of accommodation and acceptance, is an artificial forcing of evolution, with possible side effects difficult to predict and much harder to recover afterwards.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I reject this report because, although it advocates legal immigration of asylum seekers, it does not provide any solutions to how another procedure will be carried out. In addition, parties and opinions that do not correspond to the so-called 'asylum trend', but rather try to respond to legitimate fears and concerns of citizens, are described as racist.

name: Artis Pabriks (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This year’s ‘Report on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU’ again was used by political groups on the left side to serve their political objectives, instead of actually assessing fundamental rights situation in the EU MS. Therefore I had no choice than to vote against the Report. In all EU MS there are national and European courts which deal with fundamental rights issues. I am against the idea of creating new fundamental rights mechanisms, another layer of bureaucracy, which would stand above the judicial systems of the EU MS for the sake of political gains. Furthermore, already today there are several mechanisms in place aimed at safeguarding fundamental rights across the Union, which should be used and correctly implemented.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The report highlights today's concerns in the area of fundamental rights in the EU and proposes different ways to address them. I consider it elementary that the EU strives to improve the well-being of people, that there is no discrimination and violence and that everyone has a chance at a decent life.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – Human rights must be protected and guaranteed. The protection of human rights and freedoms is a fundamental value of a harmonious civil society. Fundamental rights can best be guaranteed only in a democratic and free society. I do not support the resolution tabled. You cannot grant exclusive rights or privileges to a particular group of people in other people's respects. Respect for the institute of marriage and family, freedom must be preserved. First of all, the family is based on the marriage of a man and a woman. It is a natural and fundamental unit of society and has the right to be defended by society and the state. The current challenges facing the family must be overcome. We cannot allow the concept of a family to be distorted or devalued. From the point of view of international law, the family is an unthrced universal value that civilised democracies are committed to protecting and defending. We cannot mention its fundamental provisions.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am aware of the binding value of the Charter of Fundamental Rights since the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon. I have seen the rapporteur's report, which highlights the persistence of violations of fundamental rights in the Member States. I have chosen to vote against.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am big supporter of European mechanisms for monitoring and influencing the respect for fundamental rights in Member States, together with the strengthening of the effective protection of children's rights, the rights of persons with disabilities, Roma and the rights of migrants among others. I agree that there should be full use of the existing mechanisms, with objective evaluations and investigations being launched and infringement proceedings being taken out if cases are well-grounded. Other areas, such as corruption should not be neglected and there is a clear opportunity for the EU to deploy effective mechanisms for preventing, combating and sanctioning corruption. I regret that certain political groups are wrongly using the report to promote measures which are not encouraging an effective fight against terrorism. Therefore I have supported the alternative motion for resolution, tabled by the EPP.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU proposes to give a greater role for the Agency for Fundamental Rights (FRA), which is constantly advocating for a considerable expansion of the scope of fundamental rights. This arrogant imperialism leads her, as in any document, to consider the Roma as systematically discriminated against. In addition, a large part of the text is devoted to the rights of migrants and asylum seekers, moving on to rapid deportation procedures or the construction of walls to protect borders. This text is indicative of the EU's sclerosis over immigration. So I voted against this immigration report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union acts on the assumption that Member States respect democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights enshrined in the European Convention on Human Rights and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, in particular as regards the development of the area of freedom, security and justice and the principle of mutual recognition.  As unemployment or living in poverty or at a social margin have a significant impact on access to and exercise of fundamental social rights, it is necessary to highlight in particular the need to ensure that such persons in a difficult position have access to basic services, in particular social and financial services.  I agree that it is fundamental to ensure full respect for common European values and I agree with the proposal that the Commission introduce and further refine this framework for the purpose of inclusion in the internal strategy on fundamental rights, as I consider the rule of law to be a precondition for the protection of fundamental rights in the European Union and its Member States.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report was intended to establish an internal strategy of fundamental rights of the European Union based on the application of Article 2 of the EU Treaty. In addition, it intended to establish a mechanism to provide a sufficient deterrent to prevent and eradicate situations of violations of fundamental rights in the Member States. In particular, in the second part of the proposal, the report dealt with a whole series of violations in the light of the current political situation such as freedom of expression, the need to ensure the right balance between respect for fundamental rights and the guarantee of collective security, the impact of austerity policies and corruption on fundamental rights and the situation in prisons. There were too many aspects in the report that did not guarantee full respect for the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality of EU action, undermining certain competences specific to the Member States. I therefore voted against the Ferrara report by supporting the alternative resolution tabled by the GROUP of the European People's Party.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although I am a clear supporter of human rights and their respect, I had to refrain from this report because the present proposal contains a number of left-wing principles that, when applied, will lead to a weakening of the state's position towards criminals and terrorists, which will, of course, not benefit human rights, but will, on the contrary, lead to their threat. Although I agree with much of the report on respect for fundamental rights in the EU, I could not support it because of those passages.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Democracy, freedom, and respect for human rights are fundamental values of the Union. Parliament regularly monitors the situation of fundamental rights within the Union and issues a report. I abstained this year because some of the aspects dealt with in this report are more within the authority of the Member States and the principle of subsidiarity. I am particularly vigilant about that.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Respect for and promotion of human rights, fundamental freedoms, democracy and the values and principles set out in the EU Treaties and international rights instruments should be at the heart of European construction and its policies. In fact, under Article 2 OF the EU, the Union is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities, values which are common to all Member States. In this regard, while I disagree with some of the formulations contained in this report, I consider it absolutely essential that these rights be guaranteed to all persons living on eu territory, including against abuses and acts of violence by public authorities, and are defended by the EU and each Member State, in all their policies, both internally and externally. , and for this purpose it is necessary to make full use of existing mechanisms to ensure respect, protection and promotion of fundamental rights and values on which the Union is founded.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. While it is essential that the European Union focuses on promoting human rights around the world, it cannot at the same time turn a blind eye to the situation of fundamental rights within its borders. These rights and freedoms that all Member States are obliged to protect and respect in order to ensure the effectiveness of democracy and the rule of law.  I welcome the adoption of this report, which presents a fair and comprehensive analysis of the main problems for fundamental rights in the Union, calling for ambitious and effective solutions to address them. It is damaging that Parliament, because of the conservative right, has not been able to stand together on this essential issue.  In order to avoid a multi-speed Europe of rights, it is essential to have a binding European mechanism for monitoring respect for fundamental rights, while facilitating the implementation of sanctions in cases of abuse.  Whether it affects media freedom, non-discrimination or the rights of migrants, the European institutions and Member States must take their share of responsibility for improving the rights of all EU citizens and residents.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on fundamental rights in the European Union. We have too often observed the lack of respect for democracy and fundamental rights in some European countries, but the European Union does not have the necessary tools to enforce the commitment of all its Member States in this area.   At present, the fundamental rights of asylum seekers and migrants could be particularly at risk, so it is our duty to integrate this aspect into the Union's migration policies and to put in place a harmonised and coherent European policy to respond to this crisis.  Other factors that have a significant impact on economic, civil, social and cultural rights are the measures that have been taken to stem the financial and economic crisis. Before such measures are put in place, an impact assessment on fundamental rights is needed to ensure minimum levels essential for respect for these rights.  For all these reasons, we are today calling on the Commission to set up a European mechanism to assess the situation of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in each Member State of the European Union using common and objective indicators.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Unfortunately, we continue to encounter numerous and alarming violations of fundamental rights recorded on the territory of the Member States of the European Union. This is unacceptable and the European institutions and the Member States must react firmly and forcefully to prevent and end these violations. I am therefore identified with the rapporteur's proposal for the creation of an internal EU strategy for fundamental rights in the Member States, as well as a mechanism for decommissioning and eradicating violations within the EU and its implementation in external relations.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it deals with the situation of fundamental rights in the EU in a weighted way. The report proposes a dynamic evaluation mechanism of an annual nature which, on the basis of common and homologable criteria, makes it possible to know the state of democratic quality, the proper functioning of the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights in the Member States.  I also value the fact that the report on this occasion places particular emphasis on fundamental rights in relation to migration, asylum and refuge and that the need to ensure fundamental rights in detention centres and during procedures for the reception and return of migrants at the border is emphasized.  In turn, it is important to denounce the report the impact of austerity on economic, social and cultural rights and its call for the budgetary policy of each Member State to ensure sufficient levels of enjoyment of these rights. Finally, I value the report's in-depth address of the rights of women, the LGBT group and the EU's ethnic and religious minorities.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The text adopted yesterday and which I supported expressed its concern about the hot deportation procedures, the reception of migrants and their detention in closed centres, as well as negative stereotypes and misinformation against them. The resolution also condemns security measures at THE EU's borders, including the construction of walls and barbed wire, and calling for border controls to be carried out in accordance with fundamental rights. Finally, the voted text calls on the Commission to draw up a scoreboard using 'common and objective' indicators that will 'assess the situation of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights'. This scoreboard should serve as the basis for ongoing monitoring and for an annual national evaluation system, which I welcome.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union. This text takes stock of the main problems identified and proposes solutions to deal with them. It is a courageous and realistic analysis of human rights violations in the Union, carried out with a view to pragmatism and respect for fundamental European values. I welcome the European Parliament's call for a new mechanism to monitor respect for fundamental rights, which is more effective than the existing one. Above all, this report calls for a thorough review of the Dublin Regulation for the establishment of a more humane and supportive migration system. In this sense, it is in line with the positions defended by the Socialists and Democrats.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Charter of Fundamental Rights recognises a range of personal, civil, political, economic and social rights for EU citizens and residents.  This report proposes the formulation of an internal strategy on fundamental rights in the EU, ensuring respect for the European values set out in Article 2 TFEU and the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. To this end, it proposes the formulation of an internal strategy and the introduction of a mechanism capable of preventing and eradicating cases of fundamental rights violations in the Member States. However, there are two fundamental problems: firstly, the fact that the strategy involves the creation of a complementary mechanism for assessing the fulfilment of fundamental rights in Europe, which would require a revision of the Treaties, thus making it manifestly disproportionate and unfeasible; secondly, the disregard of the principle of subsidiarity, denying Member States competence in the field of family law and also in the security issues mentioned in the report, where the Commission has limited rights to intervene, since it is an exclusive competence of the Member States. In view of the above and since it is a legislative resolution on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union, I have decided to abstain in this vote.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe it is essential to defend Christian values, especially the institution of marriage as the prerogative of the natural family composed of a man and a woman. I think that the adoption of the proposal by the rapporteur of the Five Star Movement is a serious defeat for the European Parliament, a damaging measure that certifies the distance of politics from people's lives. Furthermore, I believe that this is a blatant attempt to use the debate from a very serious and important subject such as the protection of fundamental rights and non-discrimination in order to circumvent the legitimate borders of the Treaties, which prevent the EU from intervening in the social policies of the Member States. The rules on marriage are the prerogative of individual states. For these reasons, I voted against this proposal.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against because I consider the text to be unbalanced, i.e. focused solely on the rights of certain specific categories but lacking in relation to wider issues.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU. The Report takes over the 2013-2014 axis. Much of the fundamental amendments to the EGUE were incorporated as commitments. The text critically takes care of many rights elements, including advocacy of LGTBI people, disability, minorities, refugees and other victims of structural violence. The report could still be tougher in pointing out what is structural about such violence, although this exercise could result in some loss of consensus around it. Still, we consider the whole text positive and hope that it will delve into a path of shielding fundamental rights.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal by the rapporteur, Laura Ferrara, calling for greater cooperation between the institutions in the field of fundamental rights, as well as the possibility of sanctioning them for non-compliance. EU citizens must be guaranteed their rights, so the possibility of enforced compliance by the state is necessary.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU because, among other elements, I consider it positive that it reflects the setback in the fulfilment of these rights as a result of austerity policies and cuts in public spending implemented by governments and advocated by the European Commission. I think it is very positive that the report is in need of the European Commission urgently implementing a specific strategy to achieve and ensure compliance with fundamental rights so that they cease to be mere wet paper.  I also share the criticisms it gathers about the systemic discrimination suffered today in the EU by groups such as migrants or Roma people, and I also consider it positive that it challenges the current asylum system and migrant regulations and how they directly and negatively affect the fundamental rights of these people.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as a whole as I believe that it has a pro-federalisation agenda.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support this report because I feel that breaches of the rule of law in EU Member States should be more easily dealt with.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The present report sought a solution to many of our society's burning human rights issues. However, interference with the exclusive competences of the Member States is unacceptable, as is the indoctrination of society by gender ideology or efforts to interfere in the private lives of citizens. We do not wish to reintroduce totalitarian practices or the return of ideologies that lead to freedom, fear and persecution. This threatens the most fundamental values of freedom, democracy and pluralism on which a common Europe was built. I therefore voted against.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. There are still a number of violations of fundamental human rights in the EU and in the Member States, as shown in the judgments of the European Court of Human Rights and as highlighted in the reports of the Commission, the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights, NGOs, the Council of Europe and the UN. Respect for and promotion of human rights, fundamental freedoms, democracy and the values and principles set out in the EU Treaties and international human rights instruments must be an obligation for the Union and the International Instruments in the fields of human rights and therefore at the heart of European integration. I believe that an institutional and legal structure should be established in cases where a Member State infringes fundamental rights or principles of the Union in areas not covered by EU secondary law. However, I am also in favour of a stronger and more accurate formulation of the problems of fundamental rights in various sectors (non-discrimination, minority rights, LGBTI, migration and asylum, transparency, economic and social rights, the fight against terrorism...). The report includes good structural proposals. On the one hand, it touches on the institutional framework (it reflects the Commission communication on a new EU framework for strengthening the rule of law) and, on the other hand, addresses fundamental rights problems in various sectors (freedom and security, equality and non-discrimination, migration, the economic crisis...), which is why I supported the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU (2013-2014).

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The report by MEP Laura Ferrara (EFDD) analyses the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union (2013-2014) and refers to the main international agreements. These include the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union (2000), the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) (1950) and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (1948). While supporting the basic orientation of the methodically soundly drafted Ferrara report, there are, on the other hand, considerable shortcomings: the report is excessive and far too long, contains a number of political demands which do not belong to fundamental rights in the strict sense, and in doing so repeatedly violates the principle of subsidiarity. The alternative report presented by the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats and ultimately not adopted it had almost completely eliminated these shortcomings and was therefore supported by me.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I did not support the report because it infringes the fundamental principle of the functioning of the European Union, namely the principle of subsidiarity, by which each Member State has the right to decide on issues of the definition of marriage and family policy.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU as it sets out proposals to establish an EU mechanism to monitor democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Member States. Furthermore, the resolution calls for an assessment of the impact of austerity measures on fundamental rights and proposes a revision of the Dublin Regulation, which is particularly important in light of the migrant crisis that is occurring across our continent.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the report because I do not agree with some of its conclusions, such as criticism of austerity, attitude towards migrants and so on.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union. The report is not as good as it could be. We can promote fundamental rights in the world, but we cannot impose economic, cultural and social rights. However, I would like to emphasise the situation in Slovenia, which is not satisfactory. The European Court of Human Rights published alarming figures last month showing that Slovenia, with 148 violations per million inhabitants, has come under The European Peak in terms of the number of human rights violations per population. In 2010 Slovenia was convicted three times for human rights violations and 29 times last year. She was convicted in as much as 94 percent of all cases, placing us in the same place as Russia. Last year, a survey of the former constitutional judge dr. Lovra Šturma, who found that in 2004-2014 human rights and fundamental freedoms violated 442 Slovenian courts and at least 1200 judges. All these shocking data remind us that Slovenia still has a lot of work to do in the area of the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms, and we have to deal with the difficulties immediately!

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The Charter of Fundamental Rights recognises to EU citizens and residents a range of individual, civil, political, economic and social rights, without discrimination on grounds of sex, religion, sexual orientation or colour. However, the numerous violations of these rights taking place on EU territory have neither been terminated nor contained. On the contrary, the crisis and austerity are sweeping and eroding the level of fundamental rights enjoyed by our peoples while creating the ground for the rise of racism and the far right.  The resolution reflects in a relatively comprehensive way the reality, which contradicts the promises and declarations of the European leadership on prosperity and human rights. It turns out once again that the European Union, before taking lessons in democracy and freedoms in the rest of the world, must first look at its own home.  Of course, this situation will not change with the granting of new super powers to the Brussels directory in order to impose sanctions on the Member States in his judgment, which has repeatedly proved to be ulterior motives. Fundamental changes are needed in Europe, a new socio-economic path that will guarantee, not only on paper but also in practice, fundamental rights as an integral part of the daily lives of all the inhabitants of our continent.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is regrettable that while the EP legislates on the basis of the defence of human rights and fundamental freedoms and calls for respect for civil and political rights, despite repeated complaints by Golden Dawn MEPs about the illegal and statutory persecution of the parliamentary group and its officials by the Greek Government, it has not even formally examined these complaints.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I was unable to vote in favour of the Ferrara report because, under the guise of fundamental rights, it takes a position on a number of issues that not only extend beyond the competences of the Union, but are quite controversial among European citizens. The report proposes a new rule of law mechanism, which we do not see as necessary, because there is already a mechanism in place to examine the fundamental legal situation in the Member States.  As has been demonstrated in recent years, left-wing factions use fundamental rights for political prevailing, first and fore for political purposes, first and fore in the face of Hungary-led Member States. In a similar way, a new rule of law mechanism would be used for political purposes.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of our report reflecting on the Commission's proposals, which I regard as a long-awaited step forward towards the development of a Community instrument to ensure the democratic functioning and development of the European Union and its Member States. I welcome the fact that, in addition to the general findings, it also foresees the re-enactment of specific instruments in European law. In the case of appropriate and consistent application, I consider the scoreboards of the Member States based on objective indicators and, on that basis, the continuous monitoring of fundamental rights and the prospect of automatic application of Article 7 of the Treaty as such a meaningful instrument. I considered it a virtue of the report to reflect on topicality and to point out the link between the rights of refugees and their reception and treatment, and the overall performance of fundamental rights in the Member State concerned, and that it calls for urgent improvement in this area. As a Hungarian opposition MEMBER, this aspect was particularly important when considering my vote, given that the need for a resolution was mainly triggered by violations by the Hungarian Government, exacerbated by its treatment of refugees. I also think it is important that the report deals with the various minorities of society and the violations affecting the sections of society affected by economic austerity. I trust that the EP's resolution will help the Commission and its First Vice-President to finally be able to take sufficient action against infringements in the Member States in the future.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Human rights, and civil rights in particular, are one of the greatest heritage of European political culture. Whatever the situation on our continent and in the world, we should protect this achievement and promote and promote the implementation of fundamental rights also in non-European countries. However, this must be done rationally, respecting history, traditions, religions and, above all, the mentality of other peoples and communities. Many cases of non-counting of local reality in the countries of Asia, the Middle East or Africa teach humility in proclaiming the superiority of one's views over others.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Laura Ferrara with great satisfaction. This report calls for a mechanism for monitoring respect for fundamental rights in the European Union and its States, as well as the creation of a database by fra (Agency for Fundamental Rights) to collect all the information.  The European Parliament will be able to demand that all rights provided for in the Treaties and in the Charter of Fundamental Rights be protected and may ask the Commission to keep a constant watch on respect for human rights. The method proposed in the report is also a step forward for the protection of rights: by creating greater and better interaction between the European institutions, the Member States and civil society, all stakeholders such as NGOs have been involved from below and citizens have been asked for suggestions through the publication of the online report. Other important elements: the inclusion of austerity measures that have had a negative impact on fundamental rights, organised crime and corruption as factors in the violation of fundamental rights. Finally, the report condemns discrimination and violence on European territory against lesbian, gay, transgender, bisexual and intersex (LGBTI) people.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Human rights are at the core of the EU’s principles and policies. It is one of the Union's most precious foundations. Nevertheless, institutional players and NGO's have been reporting on a high number of violations of fundamental rights within the territory of EU Member States, particularly against ethnic minority groups. I believe that such violations should not be accepted or tolerated and we must come up with remedies to outstanding problems. The current report, which I supported in the plenary vote, offers few insights and recommendations on how to deal with these problems. It calls on Member States to formulate an internal strategy on fundamental rights in the EU based on the enforcement of Article 2 of the EU Treaty. And it looks into thematic issues, including: equality, increasing unemployment, poverty, precarious working and living conditions, as well as social exclusion and isolation. Although these recommendations relate to the period 2013-2014, they are even more valid for today, as flows of migrants and refugees into the EU increase. Now more than ever the EU must ensure a universal respect for fundamental rights regardless to sex, religion, sexual orientation or skin colour.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Ferrara report was a very good report, tackling important issues such as the rising anti-Semitism and trivialisation of racist and xenophobic acts, but I had to vote against it as the approach proposed on migration was in my point of view the wrong one. The EU will not solve this situation with mandatory quotas.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒I voted against the report, as I consider that it also dangerously and completely unnecessarily encroaches on the competences of the Member States of the Union. The report grossly violates the principles of proportionality and subsidiarity by seeking to extend the scope of the Union's competences to immigration, prison and austerity measures. Many of the compromises integrated into the report contain strongly damning statements regarding budget cuts made by individual Member States to overcome the recession. I also oppose the proposals contained in the report, which require the European Union to establish a scale of fundamental human rights, a procedural mechanism for punishing violations against fundamental human rights and monitoring fundamental human rights in each individual Member State of the Union. In my view, these proposals go far beyond what is needed to effectively achieve the desired objective and that they do not seek to solve problems at the lowest level, i.e. where they arise, but through the institutions of the European Union. I am also extremely opposed to the insertion and imposition of certain already well-known concepts in the report on fundamental human rights, such as euthanasia, abortion and sexual and reproductive health and rights. Gender ideology, for god knows what time, is trying to sneak shrewdly under the framework and protection of fundamental human rights, which is scandalous, hypocritical and inadmissible.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union (2013-2014) proposes the development of a genuine internal strategy in the field of fundamental rights in the European Union, based on the enforcement of Article 2 of the EU Treaty, which includes all bodies of the European Union working in the field of respect for fundamental rights. As the report does not achieve my perception of the area of fundamental rights in the EU and because it touches in certain parts areas that do not fall within this report, I voted against it.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The situation of fundamental rights in the EU has somewhat deteriorated in recent years. Among the main reasons are the new threats faced by Member States, including more aggressive right-wing radicalism and irresponsible populism, flourishing against the backdrop of the global economic crisis, armed conflicts and major instability in the neighbouring countries. Eastern Europe – new Member States – demonstrates a low level of ambition for the protection of human rights, as there is no EU policy on political conditionality following enlargement. Therefore, it is necessary to improve the system of monitoring and enforcement of fundamental rights within the EU to ensure full respect for European values.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU. The Report takes over the 2013-2014 axis. Much of the fundamental amendments to the EGUE were incorporated as commitments. The text critically takes care of many rights elements, including advocacy of LGTBI people, disability, minorities, refugees and other victims of structural violence. The report could still be tougher in pointing out what is structural about such violence, although this exercise could result in some loss of consensus around it. Still, we consider the whole text positive and hope that it will delve into a path of shielding fundamental rights.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Respect for fundamental rights is the basis of the European project and must be respected, but not always, I have repeatedly complained to the European Commission. I therefore support this proposal. I urge the Commission and Member States to launch investigations into all allegations of violations of fundamental rights guaranteed by the Charter and to follow up on such complaints if their accuracy is credited. Particularly, I urge the Commission to start infringement proceedings where it is suspected that a Member State has acted in breach of such rights. I regret, therefore, that the Commission alleges lack of competence on numerous responses to petitions alleging possible infringement of fundamental rights; I ask, in this context, the establishment of a mechanism for monitoring, systematic evaluation and issue recommendations to encourage full respect of fundamental values in the Member States.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. In particular, the report calls for a greater role for France, the agency for fundamental rights, which continues to advocate a considerable expansion of the scope of fundamental rights. As in all comparable documents of the European Union, Roma are systematically regarded as victims of discrimination and are never considered responsible for their own fate. A considerable part of the text is devoted to "the rights of migrants and applicants for international protection." It contains unacceptable demands such as 'concern about the growing phenomenon of rapid eviction', condemnation of Member States that build 'walls and barbed wire to protect their borders', etc. The report also condemns "the lack of legal entry routes." In the "citizenship" section, the report argues for the granting of municipal and European voting rights for non-European foreigners. It is a fundamentally federalist, politically correct and immigrationist report, drawn up by an EFDD (Five Star) MP. I am voting against this text.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Convention on Human Rights was, until the Treaty of Lisbon, the legal basis for respect for human rights in the European Union, but since the entry into force of this Treaty, the Charter of Fundamental Rights has been given the same value as the other Treaties, which means that States are obliged to give, first and foremost, a priority to respect for human rights. I believe that this report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union is a way for the latter to become even more involved in the internal affairs of States, since I believe that every state is capable of defending human rights within its borders. Moreover, this report makes the border between the European Union and the Council of Europe, a special organisation for the defence of human rights, disappear more and more.   In my opinion, the European Union should focus more on other sectors, such as economic stability, which is often a cause of numerous violations of fundamental rights. Moreover, it should pay great attention to the refugee crisis, which could lead to increased violations of fundamental rights. I therefore voted against the Report on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU. The Report takes over the 2013-2014 axis. Much of the fundamental amendments to the EGUE were incorporated as commitments. The text critically takes care of many rights elements, including advocacy of LGTBI people, disability, minorities, refugees and other victims of structural violence. The report could still be tougher in pointing out what is structural about such violence, although this exercise could result in some loss of consensus around it. Still, we consider the whole text positive and hope that it will delve into a path of shielding fundamental rights.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote was positive, because the European Parliament is sending a clear message: The EU should deal with all violations of fundamental rights, also those occurring in the Member States without a strict link with the EU secondary law.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this ambitious report on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU in 2013-2014. The report points out its great concern about the repeated violation of the human rights of migrants and asylum seekers in some Member States. Another blow to the human rights of EU citizens has unfortunately come from the negative effects of the economic crisis. The situation in each and every Member State must nonetheless be continuously monitored and it should be done so through common criteria. The text is an important reminder of the constant need of ensuring that the values on which the EU is founded are respected, because Member States must be constantly aware of the solemn commitment they make upon joining the EU.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it deals with the situation of fundamental rights in the EU in a weighted way. The report proposes a dynamic evaluation mechanism of an annual nature which, on the basis of common and homologable criteria, makes it possible to know the state of democratic quality, the proper functioning of the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights in the Member States.  I also value the fact that the report on this occasion places particular emphasis on fundamental rights in relation to migration, asylum and refuge and that the need to ensure fundamental rights in detention centres and during procedures for the reception and return of migrants at the border is emphasized.  In turn, it is important to denounce the report the impact of austerity on economic, social and cultural rights and its call for the budgetary policy of each Member State to ensure sufficient levels of enjoyment of these rights. Finally, I value the report's in-depth address of the rights of women, the LGBT group and the EU's ethnic and religious minorities.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted against the EPP's alternative resolution because I find it shameless that, for the sake of political leaders in its midst such as Mr Orban and Mr Berlusconi, it was trying to water down the resolution before. It is not because a Member State is part of the European Union that it can abandon the efforts it made to become a member. Being a member of the EU is a sustained effort to protect citizens' fundamental rights, especially when it comes to sexual and reproductive health rights.  So I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I am pleased that a strong majority in the European Parliament has supported this report. It highlights the setbacks of the EU and its Member States in terms of human rights, as highlighted by numerous reports by the UN and the Council of Europe.  It is a good report which provides an indictment of the many human rights violations in the Member States, in the name of the fight against insecurity, terrorism, so-called irregular immigration, discrimination and violence suffered by certain populations, particularly the most vulnerable and including because of austere policies, and also condemning the EU's inability to punish Member States violating its principles and values. I welcome the adoption of the chapter of this report condemning the EU and Member States' migration policy, including the many migrants who have died at sea and the inability to stop it, and the strengthening of border security control. I welcome the adoption of amendments that I have tabled on behalf of my GUE/NGL Group, calling for combating all forms of racism and implementing the principle of solidarity between Member States.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report focuses on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU in 2013 and 2014 and is part of a particularly favourable and sensitive institutional context with regard to respect for fundamental rights in the European Union in our day.  Although it points to relevant aspects, and in some cases clearly, it does not point to the social and labour attacks that millions of workers are victims of in countries where austerity policies are making their way. On the other hand, it omits the role of the European Union in the destruction of countries such as Libya, Syria or Iraq, where it seeks to ensure control of raw materials and energy sources. In this sense, the report is a mere exercise of fun and money laundering of the role of the EU and its imperialist and oppressive policy.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report must be rejected in its full terms, as it advocates the legal immigration of asylum seekers, but does not contain any solutions as to how to proceed. Moreover, if we also call for both the right to vote in European elections for third-country nationals and the citizenship of the Union for them, you can only oppose it. In addition, parties and opinions that do not correspond to the "asylum trend" are described as racist, Islamophobic and the like from a purely subjective point of view. Quite apart from the strengthening of the Agency for Fundamental rights and LGBTI rights, which should also be enshrined in law. I therefore reject this request.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. Together with my colleagues from the ECR, I voted against this resolution. The report on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU is an annual report examining the situation in Europe with regard to fundamental rights. The report covers a wide range of issues, including some issues that do not fall within the competence of the EU or the scope of this report. There are important passages in the report that deal with issues such as immigration, detention centres and austerity measures. The report also calls for the EU to draw up a new infringement procedure for violations of fundamental rights. Proposals for the introduction of country-specific monitoring of fundamental rights are also expressed. This is a clear violation of the European Union's principle of subsidiarity and therefore an overstepping of the competence of the European Parliament.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report "State of fundamental rights in the EU" aims to diagnose the level of respect for human rights in the Member States and possible violations. It points to problems that may, in the future, threaten to ensure that every Citizen of the Union has his or her fundamental rights. However, it should not, with its demands, enter into matters which remain within the scope of the independent decisions of the Member States of the Union, touching on the question of personal beliefs, which are conditioned by the tradition of the country concerned. Mr Ferrara's report, in my view, infringes the principle of subsidiarity and is incompatible with the Polish Constitution. It calls for the introduction of partnerships and gay marriage into the national legal systems, the introduction of a controversial sex education programme and the sanctioning of social stigmatisation of LGBT people, and the promotion of reproductive and sexual rights. All these demands are violations of the Polish legal system and an entry into a sphere that is regulated individually by the Member States. These are: violations of freedom of expression, freedom to raise a child in accordance with one's own beliefs and the model of marriage as a union between a man and a woman enshrined in the Polish Constitution. I consider the call for standards of this nature at EU level to be excessive succumbing to a left-wing worldview that is not a common view for all EU citizens, or even for their majority. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the European Parliament, it has already become part of a kind of local folklore that the annual reports on the state of fundamental rights in the European Union go far beyond the competences of this legislature. Mrs Ferrara's report completely submits to this folklore: it ignores both the Treaties and the principle of subsidiarity and sticks its nose at the exclusive competences of the Member States. Whether it is the content of education, the definition of marriage or health care, liberal activism takes precedence over the treaties that hold Europe together.
