However, what I regret most is that the report repeats a familiar lie for the 100th time: abortion is supposedly a fundamental human right. No, it's not. I therefore voted against this report. However, I could also not support an alternative resolution that ignored the division of competences between the EU and the Member States and created a space for restricting freedom of thought and expression.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. The report by Meps Ferrara on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU is like a report that brings controversy every year. Today's report aims to regulate non-such rights and to infringe the EU's principle of subsidiarity. A priori no one would understand why a report on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU is voted against and, indeed, this report presented very positive aspects. But the introduction of 'new fundamental rights' which are not and the distortion of the principle of subsidiarity have made me give a negative vote to it. It is a pity that these reports are used to instrumentalize the confrontation in this House.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Among others, this report refers to the themes of freedom of expression and the media; freedom of religion and conscience; the protection of minorities; violence against women and equality between women and men, including the right to sexual and reproductive health; children's rights; the right of LGBTI people; the rights of migrants and applicants for international protection; solidarity in the economic crisis. Although the report has very positive parts in denouncing austerity policies, it still falls short of the in-depth analysis that needs to be done, to expose and denounce the root of the problems and responsibilities of EU structural policy in creating these problems. We cannot yet agree with federalist views that argue that the EU should monitor and sanction countries that do not comply with fundamental rights – not least because that would be a complete nonsense. On the issue of migration, the report rightly advocates the creation of safe and legal routes for migrants, but at the same time recognises the role of Frontex and the need for greater border control, with which we do not agree. Despite several disagreements with the report, we voted in favour.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it provides an overview of the state of respect for fundamental rights in the EU for the years 2013-2014 and contains institutional proposals and recommendations to ensure that they are fully addressed in the years to come. With the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the Charter of Fundamental Rights - which recognises a number of personal, civil, political, economic and social rights of EU citizens and residents - has been given the same binding legal effect as the Treaties. All EU citizens and residents should be able to enjoy the rights it contains without distinction of sex, religion, sexual orientation and skin colour. In particular, it is proposed to establish a genuine internal strategy of the EU's fundamental rights based on the full application of Article 2 of the EU Treaty and involving all union bodies active in the field of respect for fundamental rights; It also calls for the establishment of a mechanism that can really be a sufficient deterrent to prevent and eradicate situations of violations of fundamental rights in the Member States that institutional actors and non-governmental organisations report alarmingly and which the European institutions and the Member States must stop reacting decisively.

name: Richard Corbett
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I am delighted that my proposals to make an already good procedure still better and more incisive managed to obtain such a wide level of support and a large majority in this Parliament just now. Those who still claim that the European Union is undemocratic should take heed of this. This is yet another little step in improving democratic accountability in the EU. Already we now have a situation where no – or virtually no – legislation can be adopted at European level without the approval of the European Parliament. No budget, no financial framework, no international agreement of any significance can come into force without this Parliament approving it. What is more, no president of the Commission can be chosen without being elected by this Parliament and, as we know, the Commission as a whole requires a vote of confidence from this Parliament.  But what this report was about was that very last point: the vote of confidence. Before that vote of confidence we have a public hearing with rigorous questioning of every candidate Commissioner. I would love to see that applied at national level to ministers when they take office. Imagine if national parliaments required every candidate minister before they took office to be subject to a public grilling for three hours. I think it would be revealing. We do that here with regard to European Commissioners and, on this front at least, we are at the cutting edge of improving democratic accountability.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to point out that, in my opinion, this report is indeed of very good quality, I was happy to support it, and since it did not reach me yesterday as part of the possibility of speaking in the debate, I would like to point out that many of the moments in the report are, in my opinion, to some extent transferable at the national level. If only many candidates for ministers were subjected to such pressure, such questioning, such a public debate However, I would like to point out one question, and that is the question of the progress of time in individual public hearings, because those candidates who are as if at the end of the timeline are already coming at a disadvantage. And for this, because it is tchaiwise between groups, this question of the time limit when someone is at the end and placed at this disadvantage does not give the report a sufficient answer. I myself have no suggestion of how to deal with this. In any case, it might be a good idea to think about it.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Public hearings of Commissioners-designate are essential to enable Parliament and citizens to give an informed opinion on the Commission at the time of the vote of confidence. They are also important for assessing each candidate's political priorities and suitability for the function. Although they have no legal basis, they are an important parliamentary practice. The negative opinion of individual committees on individual Commissioners has sometimes led to changes in the composition of the Commission or in the distribution of portfolios. The report has highlighted a number of specific problems and tried to solve them. With this in mind, it is hoped that a specific section will be set up on Parliament's website in which the curriculum vitae of the Commissioners-designate and their answers to written questions from the relevant parliamentary committees can be consulted before the hearings themselves and in all the official languages of the Union. It is also stipulated that the Committee on Legal Affairs should pay particular attention to the monitoring of declarations of the financial interests of commissioners-designate, in which the interests of family members should be included. Although some of my specific comments have not been accepted, the text is nonetheless a step forward. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report refers to the procedure for the election of European Commissioners following the experience of the election of the last College of Commissioners last year. Unfortunately in this case again the Grand European Coalition (made up of people and socialists) imposes its majority to further cut the rights of other political groups, with the aim of preventing us from questioning the current European orientation.  The change that this report sees is that it ends with the right that until now each political group had to refuse to ratify a Commissioner directly after a hearing and to force the vote of a Commissioner in the plenary of the parliamentary committee. This mechanism, for example, has succeeded in rejecting Italian Rocco Buttiglione's candidacy to join the European Commission for his homophobic statements, as proposed by this report would no longer apply. As a sign of my rejection of the growing cut in democratic rights in the European institutions, I voted against it.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The hearings on the basis of this report were supposed to improve the procedure for appointing European Commissioners.   To vote for these "improvements" would be to recognise the legitimacy of the European Commission. That is why I objected to this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The rapporteur makes some good points, and I support those which will improve the process.  It does not, however, propose the necessary sweeping changes and I therefore abstained.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to discuss the process of hearings in the post of European Commissioners. The hearing process is not provided for in the EU Treaties, a practice developed over the last 20 years at the initiative of the EP. The opinion of the individual committees on individual Members of the Commission has no legal significance. Nevertheless, this, last and last time negative opinion of the committees led to changes in the composition of the Commission or the division of portfolios. The media's interest in listening was high. They are not only interested in traditional media channels, but they have been monitored online, as well as on social media.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report? That States should be even less free to choose their commissioner than they already are, including requiring them to submit a dual male/female candidacy, all so that Eurocrats can choose personalities who are more in line with their harmful ideology.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Since 1994, Parliament has had the power to hear Commissioners-designate ahead of the Commission's collegial approval vote.  This report, which I have endorsed, underlines the importance of this procedure in terms of democracy and transparency. It also mentions the improvements that could be made to these hearings, including an adaptation of the procedure concerning the Commissioner or Commissioners appointed to the vice-presidency, the imposition of a deadline on Member States for the presentation of their candidates, or a review of the financial declarations of interest of the Commissioners-designate. It further underlines the need to increase the number of female commissioners. In this regard, each Member State should present a man and a woman for the post of National Commissioner.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the content of the report which analyses the procedures and practices of the necessary hearings of the Commissioners held in 2014 as well as the improvements proposed by the future. But I would like to stress the need to ensure the equality of men and women that must exist in the Commission, and in this regard recorder the difficulties Juncker had because governments proposed more male candidates. The European institutions must fulfil the Treaties and the objectives that have been set and must set an example and be a leader in equality. It therefore considers it necessary to paragraph 3 which provides that in the future each Member State shall submit at least two candidates, one man and one woman on an equal footing, to the President of the Commission.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the procedures and practices governing the Commissioners' hearings, lessons learned from 2014, takes stock of the Juncker Commission's recruitment procedure and the hearings that took place in Parliament. He still dares to welcome the democratic nature of the approach, since it would bring the citizens of the EU closer to it through the vote of confidence of Parliament... You only have to look at the audience on the latter's website to convince yourself otherwise. Various measures are proposed to improve this process such as a deadline for submitting candidates, better control of declarations of financial interests (including family interests), respect for parity in Member States' proposals (not yet the case, what solutions then?). Finally, it proposes that the refusal or acceptance of the candidate be decided in a meeting of the coordinators when it is obvious that it would be more democratic for all members of the committee concerned to be able to vote on this point ... On the other hand, to vote in favour of this text would be to give credit to this appointment procedure and therefore by extension to the Commission. So I decided to vote against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The institution of hearings is undoubtedly an element of transparency, but europe only uses it sporadically, procuring as a follow-up an activity, that of the European Commission, which is all too often opaque. I therefore abstained in the vote on the text because I believe that discussing how to improve the effectiveness of the hearings of the Commissioners-designate remains a purely dialectical exercise if they then manage their great power in an opaque manner once they have been appointed.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. Although the procedure for public hearings for members of the Commission is not provided for in the Treaty, it is a practice that has been implemented at the request of Parliament and which increases transparency and strengthens the Democratic legitimacy of the Commission. This report proposes changes to improve the effectiveness of this procedure, including, inter- introducing a deadline for Member States to submit their candidates, improving the control of declarations of economic interests, increasing the number of questions that make up the written questionnaire and greater interaction during the debate (double question), etc. The report also calls for the equality between women and men to be reflected in the composition of the European Commission by presenting by the Member States of at least two candidates - one man and one woman, on an equal footing - for consideration by the President-elect of the Commission. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on Parliament's report, which deals with the procedure for hearing members of the Commission. Public hearings by Commissioners-designate are an important opportunity for Parliament and EU citizens to assess the priorities of each candidate and its professional fitness to perform their duties. In Parliament's view, it would be useful to set a deadline by which all Member States should submit their candidates in order to give the President-elect the Commission sufficient time to allocate portfolios. The procedures for monitoring the continued follow-up of the responses given by the Commissioners-designate during the hearing can help to improve control and increase the responsibility of the Commission as a whole, and the European Parliament therefore calls for a periodic review of the priorities set out by the Commissioner-designate.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Hearings of Candidates for European Commissioners are a process that gives Parliament and the union as a whole great deal of attention and visibility. Since we then elect the people who will hold the most responsible jobs in the European Commission for 5 years, we must make sure that they are competent, qualified and that their morality is unquestionable. I am extremely pleased that my proposal to extend the financial interest check to family members of future commissioners is included in the final document. In conclusion, we want each Member State to propose a minimum of two candidates, a man and a woman, next time in order to respect gender equality.  We need to send a clear message that we will no longer accept the mere minimum of women in the Commission. I support this report because I consider that it addresses the lessons learned during the 2014 hearing in a quality manner.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. The Corbett report evaluated the methods and procedures of the Commissioners-designate hearing process in 2014 with a view to improving the process next time. The primary concern with this report was the recommendation to change the system for evaluation of the Commissioners-designate, specifically the deletion of the possibility for a political group to request a vote in committee on the recommendation of the candidate. My group tabled an amendment together with the Greens and the 5* that included the possibility for a political group to request a vote in committee on the recommendation of the candidate in the new evaluation system. As this was not passed, I tabled a negative vote.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the procedure for hearing Commissioners strengthens the democratic legitimacy of the Eu ropean Union institutions by bringing them closer to the citizens of Europe. Nevertheless, some aspects of the process of selecting and confirming Commissioners could be improved. In particular, I believe that, if national governments were required to submit two candidates of different sexes, instead of just one, it would be possible to achieve a better gender balance within the Commission.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution is once again a testament to the Commission's commitment to undue powers.  Parliament asks the Member States to present two people each time for a post of Commissioner, leaving the final choice to the European institutions. This reform of the hearing procedures further strengthens the Commission's discretion in selecting candidates for the position of Commissioner.  That is why I voted against this motion for a resolution.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The practice of public hearings of candidate Commissioners is a very useful exercise for potential members of the European Commission, but especially for the public concerned. Even if these public hearings are not provided for in the Treaty, they were conducted in a democratic and effective manner. They have developed over the past 20 years, at the insistence of the European Parliament, which has asked candidates for the positions of European Commissioners to present their agendas to the Commission and the committees corresponding to their portfolio before Parliament gives its vote of confidence to the Commission. In this context, although the opinions of the committees on each Individual Commissioner have no legal importance, they are taken into account, so, when they have issued negative opinions, they have had the effect of changing the composition of the Commission or redistributing portfolios.  I voted in favour of the Report on procedures and practices related to the hearing of Commissioners, because the results have shown that this process reflects the political balance at Commission level. Moreover, the media has shown particular interest, not only through traditional channels, but especially through social media, which has led to hundreds of thousands of European citizens informing about decision-making processes at EU level.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Abstention vote on own-initiative report on the practices of Commissioners' hearings.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the resolution on procedures and practices for Commissioners' hearings, which provide an excellent opportunity to discover and assess the personality, qualifications and preparation of each candidate. It is no coincidence that, in recent years, the interest aroused by the hearings has grown exponentially among the media and in European public opinion. As a result, it has become increasingly important to focus attention on monitoring the declarations of financial interests of each Commissioner-designate, on the absence of any conflicts of interest and on any other profile that appears to be opaque or inadequate. Furthermore, as the resolution points out, a great deal of attention must be paid to gender balance: it will be necessary to encourage all Member States to propose at least two candidates, so that the President-designate is able to propose a high-quality college composed of the same number of women and men. Therefore, with the intention of easily arriving at a process of reform of procedures, which would make the debate between the Commissioner and the members of the committee responsible for the hearing less rigid and more dynamic, I have decided to vote in favour of the text.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. The Corbett report evaluated the methods and procedures of the Commissioners-designate hearing process in 2014 with a view to improving the process next time. The primary concern with this report was the recommendation to change the system I for evaluation of the Commissioners-designate, specifically the deletion of the possibility for a political group to request a vote in committee on the recommendation of the candidate. I supported an amendment that included the possibility for a political group to request a vote in committee on the recommendation of the candidate in the new evaluation system. As this was not passed, I voted against this report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report did make some good points, some of which I support that will improve the process. It does not, however, propose the necessary sweeping changes and I therefore abstained.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I agreed with the points raised in it on the monitoring of the latest Commissioner hearing process and also propose some considerations in order to change hearing process procedures. Considering public hearing of candidate members of the European Commission gives an opportunity for Parliament and the public to acknowledge each candidate's priority and qualification. I believe improving procedures will certainly increase public hearing process to become more effective.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 My colleague's report introduces important improvements to the procedure for hearing Commissioners, in particular with regard to the request for reform concerning the declarations of the commissioners' financial interests and the extension of the obligation to make such a statement to members of the Commissioners' families as well. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 It is good practice that has been in place since 1994, the established hearings of Commissioners to strengthen the democratic legitimacy of the institutions of the European Union, thus bringing the institutions closer to European citizens. Indeed, the hearing procedure strengthens the democratic legitimacy of the Commission as a whole. Furthermore, we believe that the procedures for monitoring the Commissioners-designate during the hearings could help to improve control and strengthen the responsibility of the Commission as a whole.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution concerning the hearing of Commissioners. The hearings of Commissioners by the European Parliament, although not provided for in the Treaties, have become a well-established practice. The hearing also allows Parliament to assess the personality and qualifications of commissioners. However, the recent hearings in 2014 raised issues. In particular, this proposal considers it useful to set a deadline by which The Member States propose their candidates; requests that the written questionnaire be composed of 7 questions and not 5; considers it preferable to submit 25 questions and requires the application of new guidelines for the evaluation meeting of the coordinators following the hearings. On this last point, it is requested that, in the absence of a clear majority or a majority against a candidate, additional information or a further hearing of one and a half hours or, if a majority has not yet been reached, a vote in committee. Finally, it is considered necessary to make better use of the media and social media and for the control of the commissioners' financial interests to remain the responsibility of the Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I congratulate my colleagues who have worked on this text because I believe they have done a useful and valuable exercise. Personally, however much I approved the overall structure of the report and therefore voted in favour, I believe that the hearings took too long and often turned into unnecessary a priori interrogations. I am used to judging on the basis of what you do, not what you say or, worse, what you say you want to do. In the meantime, legislative activity has stood still while citizens demand answers to the many problems they encounter. Having said that, at constitutional level, However, I find the report a good compromise between the different visions found in the process of preparing the text.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Public hearings of potential members of the European Commission are an exercise of great value. These hearings provide Parliament and the public with an opportunity to assess the personalities, general approach and priorities of each candidate for Commissioner and their qualifications. Although they are not foreseen in the Treaties, they are a practice developed over the last 20 years, at parliament's insistence, which simply required candidates for Commissioners to appear at a hearing before the relevant parliamentary committees before Parliament gives its vote of confidence to the Commission. Although emphasis is given to whether or not a Commissioner has been rejected, this process generates other developments, such as clarifications and political commitments, a better definition of portfolios and some additional clarifications on the issue of relations between vice-presidents and other Commissioners. These hearings increase the democratic legitimacy of the Institutions of the Union by bringing them closer to European citizens.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the public hearing of the Commissioners-designate is an essential procedure for ensuring transparency in the criteria for evaluating candidates. I therefore voted in favour of this measure, which is also a useful example to the institutions at national level, as well as a democratic instrument that enhances individual competences and competences in a fair and equal way.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report seeks to strengthen the process through which Commissioners are appointed by focusing on procedure which leads proposed Commissioners to the oral hearing by Members of Parliament. This procedure is important as it allows Members of Parliament, as democratically elected representatives of the people, a method of scrutiny over what is often a rather political process of appointment. I have thus voted in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report refers to the procedure for the election of European Commissioners following the experience of the election of the last College of Commissioners last year. Unfortunately in this case again the Grand European Coalition (made up of people and socialists) imposes its majority to further cut the rights of other political groups, with the aim of preventing us from questioning the current European orientation.  The change that this report sees is that it ends with the right that until now each political group had to refuse to ratify a Commissioner directly after a hearing and to force the vote of a Commissioner in the plenary of the parliamentary committee. This mechanism, for example, has succeeded in rejecting Italian Rocco Buttiglione's candidacy to join the European Commission for his homophobic statements, as proposed by this report would no longer apply. As a sign of my rejection of the growing cut in democratic rights in the European institutions, I voted against it.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EP report on the hearing of commissioners-designate last year summarises the essential technical and procedural parts of the hearing process. The hearings went smoothly and MePs were helped by written questionnaires answered by commissioners-designate. Proper management of time was perhaps the most mentioned difficulty of the hearings, a problem that atrophy aeded by the simultaneous hearing of candidates by representatives of 2-3 commissions, fragmenting the individual fields of expertise and the questions that could be asked there. The hearings were characterised by a great deal of media interest, and the role of social channels here has increased considerably. Parliament may draw the necessary conclusions on the effectiveness of the hearings through this report, which will serve as a useful preparatory material for the next hearings.  I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This non-legislative report of the Parliament seeks to learn from the experience during the most recent Commission hearing of 2014 and proposes ways by which to improve procedures. Amongst the proposals put forward there is one for the introduction of a clear  deadline for Member States to put forward candidates in order to allow time for the allocation of portfolios and hearings; another suggestion is for each Member State to put forward a female candidate and male candidate of equal footing for consideration.  Having been part of the 2014 hearing process I believe that the deadline and the gender balance proposals make a lot of sense, while further transparency should be also welcomed, hence I voted in favour of this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to draw conclusions from the hearings of the "candidate commissioners" in connection with the appointment of the Juncker Commission. Following the European elections, newly elected MEPs receive the 'candidate Commissioners' in the European Parliament and ask them about the political objectives and principles that will guide their actions over the next five years. This report therefore looks at a few points that could lead to changes in the current procedure. Among the ideas discussed by the rapporteur is the possibility for states to be able to put forward at least two candidates: a man and a woman; a review of the hearings of Vice-Presidents with horizontal responsibilities; or the possibility of asking "horizontal questions" about the composition, structure and working methods of the Commission, which cannot be addressed by a single Commissioner. With the proposed arrangements aimed at strengthening the democratic control of the European Parliament over the appointment of the College of Commissioners, I have spoken in favour of the text.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report. I think the concept of having hearings is a great way of scrutinizing whether the Commissioners-designate are well prepared for the function as Commissioner. It is important to constantly learn lessons from the way this process is being run. Improvements could be made as to the dynamic of the Q&A, with immediate follow-up questions, or by establishing deadlines for Member States to put forward their candidate.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. If the report suggests some improvements, however Begnines, other major proposals are unacceptable. The dual male-female candidacy that the Member States will have to propose is one, this is a democratic and good-feeling façade that heralds a serious drift where States can only suggest several candidates that the European Commission will choose freely. I have therefore voted against this report, which ultimately seeks to establish the position of the European Commission when this institution is reporting a blatant democratic deficiency. The current European supranational system cannot be reformed by remaining rooted in the denial of the sovereignty of the nation states of Europe.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 We consider that any attempt to amend the Regulations on Commissioners' Hearings, which does not involve a truly democratic process but is based on 'elections without representatives' demonstrates the anti-democratic and unpopular mentality that the European Union embraces.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Public hearings of potential members of the European Commission are an exercise of great value.  The procedure for hearings is not provided for in the Treaty. It is a practice developed over the last 20 years, at Parliament's insistence, which simply required the candidates for Commissioner to present themselves at a hearing with the parliamentary committee(s) corresponding to their portfolio, before Parliament gave its vote of confidence to the Commission. Of course, the hearings are not an opportunity to try to change the political composition of the Commission, which reflects the political balance between national governments and not that of Parliament. Any rejected candidate will be replaced by another, appointed by the same government. I agree that there is always room for improvement and that there should be an assessment of procedures and methods and a reflection on the lessons that can be learned to improve the process next time.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because I do not want to endorse the European Commission, its existence and operation in any way.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is important that we learn from last year's selection of candidates for The European Commissioners. Public hearings are a useful procedure. However, there are still doubts as to whether, as it stands, they can sufficiently verify the competence of a particular candidate. There is clearly scope for a stricter and more detailed examination of the competence and managerial skills of future Members of the European Commission, in particular when dealing with possible crisis situations within their portfolio. I also consider it problematic in this context not to clarify the 'Lux Leaks' case concerning tax evasion in Luxembourg. This has had a significant impact on the credibility of President Juncker himself. The European Union is currently facing a large number of challenges and human disasters in the context of the migration crisis. Their handling so far by some Members of the Commission is in many ways a tragedy. In the case of refugees, it is mainly Dimitris Avramopolous, responsible for migration, external border protection and the Common European Asylum System, but also Věra Jourova, whose competence includes justice and the free movement of persons within the European Union. There were some doubts about Commissioner Jourova when she was selected, when, in addition to the hearing itself, she subsequently had to face written questions. Although the refugee crisis is testing the unity of the Union much more strongly than the economic difficulties to date, both have been too slow to make effective proposals on how to deal with the situation.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. – I believe that any attempt to amend the Regulations on Commissioners' Hearings does not involve a truly democratic process but is based on 'elections without representatives', demonstrates the anti-democratic and unpopular mentality that the European Union embraces. My vote is against.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report, which clarifies the procedures and practices for future Commissioner hearings. In particular, I agree on the idea that a deadline should be fixed for member states to put forward candidates and allow time for the allocation of portfolios and hearings; that each Member State should put forward a female candidate and male candidate on equal footing for consideration; that each questionnaire will have the right to an immediate follow-up question; that the Legal Affairs Committee needs to clarify the rules about how to manage commission's declaration of interest.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In my view, public hearings of future members of the European Commission are a very useful exercise. The hearings are an opportunity for Parliament and the public to discover the personality, general approach and priorities of each Commissioner-designate and to assess his qualifications. And if there are problems, it is better to find out before the Commissioner takes office, not after. The question may arise– in the spirit of democracy and transparency – what would happen if a similar procedure were carried out at national level, even before ministers were appointed– a lot would be revealed during the three hours of public interrogation before taking office! Most of all, I consider it a particularly useful innovation that there was considerable media interest in hearings, not only through traditional media channels, but also through the Internet (largely on the European Parliament's website) and social media. The role of the latter has increased enormously since the hearing 5 years earlier and has a very important role to play in making the European Institutions more citizen-like.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I wholeheartedly support the report by the Committee on Constitutional Affairs drawn up by Mr Corbett. This is a very important work, which allows European democracy to move towards more in-depth parliamentary control of candidates for the post of European Commissioner. Last year, at the hearings of the new Barroso Commission, we certainly demonstrated a great democratic exercise, but I believe that we could have defined even more effective and transparent methods and procedures, and Mr Corbett rightly points out some very appropriate measures.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on procedures and practices concerning commissioners' hearings, lessons to be drawn from the 2014 procedure, as I believe that the hearings allow Parliament to make an conscious assessment of the Commission at the time of the vote of confidence. The committees are responsible for monitoring the responses given by the Commissioners-designate during the hearings, and should help to improve the monitoring and increase the responsibility of the Commission as a whole. The hearings of candidates for the European Commission, being public, are an exercise in great utility and political and institutional correctness. The hearings shall ensure that Parliament and the public have the opportunity to know the personalities, general approach and priorities of each candidate and to assess their qualifications. We need to evaluate the current procedures and see what lessons we can learn to improve the process. Considering that the hearings were organised by the Conference of Presidents, and therefore that the chairman and coordinators of each committee have the task of defining the modalities.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I have today voted against the report on the procedures and practices at The Commissioners' hearings – lessons to be learned from the 2014 procedure, because I believe that the text contains false, unsustainable correction proposals and misses a real reform of the procedure.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the proposed procedure and the proposed approach to the consultation of Commissioners.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of this report which clarifies the procedures and practices for future Commissioner hearings.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The public hearings of candidate European Commissioners by the European Parliament is an exercise that is, in my opinion, very worthwhile. This report had my overall support today as it highlighted making an already good procedure stronger, for example, suggesting a specific section of the Parliament’s website where CVs of the Commissioners-designate and responses to written questions are published in advance of the public hearings. We must continue to learn from mistakes of the past and this report offers improvements to an example of democratic accountability in the EU.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I support calls for more flexibility in the hearings of Vice-Presidents with cross-cutting portfolios in order to allow for wider scrutiny from all relevant parliamentary committees. Calls for the re-introduction of follow up questions is also a positive contribution as it should allow MEPs to pursue more inquisitive questioning. However, while greater gender balance in the make-up of the college of commissioners is of course desirable, I do not support calls for Member States to be required to nominate both a male and female commission candidate – with the President designate then deciding which candidates to approve for the final make up the college. Notwithstanding that the key criteria for evaluating prospective candidates must be competence to fulfil their duties, it is a Member State right to select the candidate of its choosing and therefore I do not support any further erosion of sovereignty in this area. Alongside my conservative colleagues, I also do not support calls for further substantive analysis of Commissioner designates’ financial interests – this would go far beyond Parliament's competences as established under the treaties. It is for this reason that I voted against.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. Whatever way it is to audition future Commissioners, this procedure remains a caricature of democracy. The European Commissioners are and will remain appointed civil servants, largely unknown to the general public. Their initial designation as the portfolio assigned to them is a matter of political balance and haggling between Member States. As for the hearings themselves, their organisation, which discriminates against small groups and non-registered Members of Parliament, with rounds of speakers, length and many of the ultra-controlled interventions without replies or follow-up questions, they have mostly been of great formality. An organization is certainly necessary since the overall time of the hearing is by definition limited. But in this case, it gave the exercise an artificial character and prevented any real debate. Finally, the fact that the approval of each Commissioner is first or exclusively validated by the coordinators of the political groups (thus without non-registered Members) is completely undemocratic: it is at a minimum by a vote of all members of the relevant parliamentary committees that this approval should take place. The rapporteur's proposal to allow this approval, for the most controversial candidates, by the EPP and S-D groups alone is, moreover, scandalous. As you will have understood: I voted against this report.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this Report focusing on the operation of Hearings during 2014. We understand that the report does not finally take over the specific position that small groups hold within the parliamentary structure. While the report has some points of fundamental importance to our political position, such as the recommendation to promote gender balance, it is not able to bring small political groups into the constant evaluation logic required by Commissioners. Likewise, the reduction of questions certainly limits the possibilities of intervention of small groups within the Hearings. We understand that the Report points to certain key criteria and we hope that these criteria will be taken into account in order to promote, for example, equality, but the plurality of the plenary must also be reflected.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which includes key recommendations about how future Commissioner hearings should be held. These include each member state putting forward both a female and a male candidate of equal footing for consideration. The report also asks the Commission to review the rules on financial declarations which should also cover financial interests of family members.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with the rapporteur and I have voted for the resolution on procedures and practices regarding Commissioner hearings, lessons to be taken from the 2014 process. First of all, I believe that the cut of the number of questions from 42 to 25 is a reasonable proposal. Furthermore, so far the vote by individual committees on individual Commissioners has no legal consequence. Therefore, the evaluation of the Commissioner within committees should be more important. These and other possible changes are the significant attempts to make the Commission more accountable.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour to review the Commissioner hearing process in order to analyse where improvements could be made on procedures and practices regarding these hearings. Public hearings are vital in order to assess the Commissioner designates on their general competences, European commitment and personal independence. Along with ALDE, I have always called for a gender balanced Commission and feel particularly positive on the proposal that asks Member States from now on to put forward at least two candidates, one female and one male for consideration by the Commissioner President elect.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it is a very important instrument by which we can measure the success of Commissioner hearings. It also gives us the chance to propose some important adjustments to the Commissioner hearings process for the next parliamentary term.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is an excellent report which will enable MEPs to scrutinise candidates for the College of Commissioners in more detail and also looks at the overall balance of the Commission. Currently only a quarter of Commissioners are women and this is totally unacceptable. To claim full democratic legitimacy, all of our institutions need to be representative of European society as a whole. By recommending that Member States nominate at least one woman for Commissioner, this report represents a major step forward.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this Report focusing on the operation of Hearings during 2014. We understand that the report does not finally take over the specific position that small groups hold within the parliamentary structure. While the report has some points of fundamental importance to our political position, such as the recommendation to promote gender balance, it is not able to bring small political groups into the constant evaluation logic required by Commissioners. Likewise, the reduction of questions certainly limits the possibilities of intervention of small groups within the Hearings. We understand that the Report points to certain key criteria and we hope that these criteria will be taken into account in order to promote, for example, equality, but the plurality of the plenary must also be reflected.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Resolution from the European Parliament on the procedures and ways of hearing commissioners-designate, lessons learned from the 2014 procedure, as it is necessary to increase the transparency and democratic legitimacy of all European institutions and the European Union itself. Public hearings of commissioner-designate certainly allow Parliament, as well as citizens, to familiarize itelves with the candidates' political priorities and to assess their professional readiness.  Controls on candidates' declarations of financial interests should also be strengthened and social networks should be used to increase the involvement of all EU citizens in this process. Citizens' involvement in decision-making and full transparency and consistency can certainly contribute to increasing trust in the EU institutions.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report takes its substance from the hearings for the European Commissioners.  To vote for "improvements" to the existing procedure would be to recognise the legitimacy of the European Commission. That is why I objected to this report.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Richard Corbett's report, which draws lessons from the hearings of the European Commissioners which took place in 2014. This informal but constant practice over the last 20 years allows the European Parliament to ensure the competence of the Commissioners-designate and their European commitment ahead of the validation of the composition of the European Commission. The text thereby recommends improving the transparency and clarity of a number of points in the hearing process. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which will allow for greater transparency in the choice of future Commissioners.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am abstaining from voting on this report. It contains some good proposals to improve procedures, but in order to take better account of democratic accountability, it would be compulsory, for example, to require more votes in committees.

name: Rikke Karlsson (ECR)
text: Written. I voted against the report 'Procedures and practices in relation to Commissioner hearings, lessons learned from 2014'. I did so first of all because the democratic legitimacy of the European Union – unlike the author of this report's somewhat smug representations – must not be found in insignificant procedures and institutional corrections, but through a total rethinking and amendment of the Treaties, so as to restore cooperation between equal partners. Furthermore, I would remind you that the votes of the European Parliament and its committees had very little influence on the Commission and its appointed members. Members and citizens have realised that their efforts were superfluous and it is worrying for democracy that the 2014 hearings had absolutely no impact on the final vote.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The aim of the report adopted today is to propose some reflections that could lead to a change in the procedures for hearing Commissioners. The recent renewal of the European Commission has given us the opportunity to reflect on the functioning of the rules in order to ensure that the process is even more effective and transparent. We therefore believe that the Member States should be imposed a deadline within which to propose candidates; each State must submit at least two candidates, one man and one woman; visibility and transparency of letters of approval must be ensured.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. The report takes stock of the Juncker Commission's recruitment process and the hearings that took place in Parliament. He welcomed the "democratic" nature of the approach. It proposes several measures to improve the process: imposing a deadline on the state to submit candidates to facilitate the organization and adequacy between each and its portfolio; better control of financial declarations of interest and include family interests; ask each Member State to nominate two applications: one man and one woman, in order to respect parity. Other technical organisational measures are proposed. The report proposes that the candidate's refusal or acceptance be decided at a meeting of the coordinators. It would seem more democratic that all Members of the Committee should be called upon to vote, especially since the proposed process excludes non-registered people outright. In the measures proposed, some are good, but the dual male/female candidacy is ridiculous and encroaches on the sovereignty of the Member States with the risk of drift (soon, we will want each state to propose several names and the EU therefore to choose the Commissioner that suits it).  Vote against it.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text for two reasons. Firstly, because it fails to sufficiently clarify the procedure for choosing commissioners. Secondly and above all because I refuse to endorse such a procedure, which would be tantamount to recognising the legitimacy of the Brussels Commission.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report and its recommendations. The Commissioner hearings prior to Parliament’s vote of confidence are an opportunity for the MEPs to scrutinise and cross examine each individual candidate, but also to look at the overall balance of the Commission. Europe must apply the principles of gender equality that it preaches and make sure that all EU institutions are truly representative of all EU citizens.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On Tuesday 8. 9. 2015, we voted in plenary on the report on the procedures and practice of hearing Commissioners – experience from the 2014 hearings. I must say that, given that I participated directly in a large part of the hearings of the new Commissioners in 2014 as envi coordinator, and I was also shadow rapporteur for the ENVI sub-report on this document, I have a very specific opinion on this issue from the outset. Already in the ENVI Committee, we have seen the efforts of large political groups to make the process of selecting Commissioners within the European Parliament more transparent and easier for them, as the proposed candidates mostly come from these groups. Throughout the negotiations, I have encountered proposals to reduce the time of "questioning" commissioners by the plenary of the committee, to reduce the number of possible issues that candidates can face, or to ensure that the final opinion of the committee on the candidate is not put to the vote by the entire plenary, but only by the coordinators. On the other hand, several good elements have been incorporated into the report, such as a deeper review of the financial background of individual candidates by the JURI Committee or a proposal that Member States should have to submit at least two candidates, male and female, for gender balance. That is why I finally decided not to vote against this report, but I abstained.

name: Etelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The hearing process of Commissioners is not provided for in the Treaty but it is well-established practice since 1994. However, this process should be improved. I voted against the report for two mainly reasons. Firstly it is important for a political group to have the possibility to request a vote on the Commissioner’s designation and to express a minority opinion. Secondly, the implementation of the ‘institutionalisation model’ of Commissioners’ designation will limit the possibility for political groups to evaluate Commissioners and for smaller political groups to ask questions. For all these reasons, I do not support this report.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The procedure for public hearings for future members of the European Commission is not provided for in the Treaty, but it is very important because it increases transparency and strengthens the Democratic legitimacy of the Commission. The report provides for changes for better effectiveness of procedures such as the introduction of a time limit for Member States to submit their candidates, the improvement of control of the economic interest statements of the proposed Commissioners, the increase in the number of questions that make up the written questionnaire and greater transparency by publishing post-hearing assessments 24 hours later.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report refers to the procedure for the election of European Commissioners following the experience of the election of the last College of Commissioners last year. Unfortunately in this case again the Grand European Coalition (made up of people and socialists) imposes its majority to further cut the rights of other political groups, with the aim of preventing us from questioning the current European orientation.  The change that this report sees is that it ends with the right that until now each political group had to refuse to ratify a Commissioner directly after a hearing and to force the vote of a Commissioner in the plenary of the parliamentary committee. This mechanism, for example, has succeeded in rejecting Italian Rocco Buttiglione's candidacy to join the European Commission for his homophobic statements, as proposed by this report would no longer apply. As a sign of my rejection of the growing cut in democratic rights in the European institutions, I voted against it.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. •u2012 Any improvement and deepening of mechanisms that increase the democratic legitimacy of the European Institutions must be and is welcome. From past experience we have been able to verify the virtues of the Commissioners' Hearings, and it therefore seems logical to continue in the improvement of this tool. Not being able to find anything to criticize this proposal will vote it in favour.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In the context of the hearings of commissioners-designate, I would point out that, in terms of accepting a Commissioner in a given area, the opinion of the relevant parliamentary committee should be crucial. It is unacceptable that a candidate for Commissioner whose candidature has been rejected by the committee responsible remains the Commissioner responsible for the same area. This practice, which took place when the current European Commission was elected, undermines the democratic process, credibility and competences of the Commission as a whole. In this regard, I stress the role of the President of the European Commission, who should distribute the responsibilities of the various Commissioners-designate in such a way that they do not raise substantive objections to their qualifications in a given field. On the other hand, if the Commissioner does not receive the approval of the competent parliamentary committee, his duties should be changed.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The hearings of Candidates for Commissioners of the European Commission are designed to bring institutions closer to citizens and to make it easier for the European Parliament to identify candidates. This procedure also ensures transparency as the information is available to all in order to know and better assess candidates' qualifications. I supported MP Richard Corbett's report which supports the practice of hearings and proposes guidance on how to make hearings even more effective. Some news is that each Member State proposes two candidates – a man and a woman on the basis of equality, greater control of the candidates' declarations of financial interests and due to the high public interest that accompanied the hearings in 2014, and calls for greater transparency to create a specific Parliament website.

name: n/a
text: Writing. — The European Parliament seems to have elected the European Commission for a period of five years after hearing the European Commissioners and then everything. But no. This experience should be used in inter-institutional dialogue and for improving in-house cooperation. I voted in favour.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Hearings of Commissioners-designate are an important tool enabling Members to complete a picture of a person's suitability in terms of general expression, communication skills, qualifications and knowledge of the future department entrusted to them. Experience in recent years has shown that it is possible to change a candidate in this way. However, in the interests of transparency and objectivity, it is desirable to modify the rules so that the hearing process is flexible. At the same time, clearer conditions need to be put in place to demonstrate financial interests.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on procedures and practices relating to Commissioners' hearings, lessons to be learned from the 2014 procedure, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 7/9/2015.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this improvement in the procedure, which gives the Commission more legitimacy. Although some measures are acceptable, we formally oppose the decision to introduce a dual male/female candidacy: we fear a drift where, in the long run, all Member States should submit a list of candidates and the Commission would only have to choose the right person for it.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report. The public hearings of prospective members of the European Commission are an exercise that is well worthwhile. Even if there had been no problems whatsoever with any of the candidate Commissioners, the hearings provide an opportunity for Parliament and the public to discover the personalities, the general approach and the priorities of each candidate Commissioner and assess their qualifications. And when there are problems, it is better that they are discovered prior to the Commissioner taking office, rather than afterwards.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Public hearings of candidates for the European Commission are relevant as they give each candidate the opportunity to make their skills and qualifications known, giving the European Parliament the opportunity to know each candidate's priorities. Member States should be given a deadline within which to propose their candidates and each Member State should be given the opportunity to submit two candidates, one man and one woman. I am in favour of this report.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 I still have experience hearing commissioners-designate in my fresh memory from 2014. The report that we voted on today proposes, in my opinion, a fundamental change in the fact that the candidate would not be voted on by the entire committee after the so-called grilling on the committee, but only by the coordinators of the various political factions. Unfortunately, I cannot agree to this change. At the same time, however, I welcome the efforts to achieve greater gender balance, i.e. that Member States should propose 2 candidates of the opposite sex for the post of Commissioner, and I also positively appreciate the efforts to increase transparency in the financial interests of the candidates. I abstained in the final vote.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The public hearings of the Designated European Commissioners are a crucial moment in that they enable parliamentary committees to know, before the European Parliament expresses its vote of confidence, the personality, political priorities and qualifications of potential Commissioners. In the light of what happened following the 2014 parliamentary elections, during the hearing of the nominees, the report reflects on possible changes to the relevant procedures. These include a time limit within which member states will submit their candidate. I believe that the scope of these established practices should be delimited. That is why I have decided to support this document.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I support the report we voted on in the European Parliament on procedures and practices relating to The Commissioners' hearings in 2014, as I agree that these hearings give the European Parliament and EU citizens a valuable opportunity to assess the priorities of each candidate as well as their professional suitability for the post. Some adjustments need to be made on the proposal for candidates by member states or other procedures that have been set up but, in general, this is a very useful exercise, give Parliament and citizens the opportunity to know the personality, general approach and priorities of each of the proposed candidates, as well as to assess their qualifications.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. In principle, the report contains good proposals for improving the procedures of hearings. However, it would be imperative that more votes be taken in committees. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report welcomes the growing media and public interest in the commissioners appointment process and details measures that could further improve the "procedure". The text proposes, for example, that the questionnaire addressed to future Commissioners should contain 7 questions, instead of 5...  I denounce this charade by which we are led to believe that the process of appointing European Commissioners is a model of democracy and transparency and I vote against

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The hearings on the basis of this report were supposed to improve the procedure for appointing European Commissioners.  To vote for these "improvements" would be to recognise the legitimacy of the European Commission.  I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. The public hearings of commissioners-designate represent an important opportunity for Parliament and EU citizens to assess each candidate's priorities and their ability to do so. In view of the 2014 hearings, some solutions need to be found to improve the process, which I believe is in this report. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report because it encourages transparency and accountability within the European Parliament by proposing improvements to the hearing procedures of European Commissioners.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The process of hearing Commissioners by elected representatives and made public in their entirety strengthens the democratic legitimacy and transparency of the Union's institutions. This type of democratic exercise does not exist anywhere in Europe at the national level. To do so makes it possible to make known men and women who have important responsibilities and a decisive political role for the future of European integration and therefore for European citizens. It's a way to earn their trust. The Treaty on the European Union promotes gender equality. The proposal to submit two candidates (one man and one woman) per state will meet this priority.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on Commissioner hearings, lessons to be taken from the 2014 process, which clarifies the procedures and practices for the future Commissioner hearings.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The practice of publicly hearing prospective members of the European Commission has developed over the last 20 years under pressure from Parliament, which simply required that, before Parliament held a vote of confidence in the Commission, commissioners-designate should appear before a parliamentary committee(s) corresponding to their portfolio. The report notes that this has now become a well-practiced practice. It will also review the results of parliament's vote on the last three Committees in the light of the committee hearings. I agree with the findings of the report and have therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. Public hearings on commissioners-designate, although not provided for in the Treaty, have been a common practice for the past twenty years, reinforcing the democratic legitimacy of the institutions of the European Union. Public hearings of potential members of the European Commission are a valuable element of European democracy, as they allow Parliament to form an informed judgment on the Commission before giving it its vote of confidence to take office and give Parliament and EU citizens the opportunity to assess the personalities, qualifications, degree of preparedness and priorities of candidates , as well as their knowledge of the allocated folder. In favour of defending the vast majority of what was presented in the report, I voted in favour, as it strengthens the legitimacy and transparency of the European Commission. I would also stress the importance shown in the application of the principle of equality between men and women, with each Member State submitting at least two candidates, one male and one female, on an equal footing for consideration by the President-elect of the Commission.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the procedures and practices governing the Commissioners' hearings, lessons learned from 2014, takes stock of the Juncker Commission's recruitment procedure and the hearings that took place in Parliament. He has the audacity to welcome the democratic nature of the approach, since it would bring the citizens of the EU closer to it through the vote of confidence of Parliament... You only have to look at the audience on the latter's website to convince yourself otherwise. Various measures are proposed to improve this process such as a deadline for submitting candidates, better control of declarations of financial interests (including family interests), compliance with parity in Member States' proposals (so should the number of Commissioners be doubled?). Finally, it proposes that the refusal or acceptance of the candidate be decided at a meeting of the coordinators. It seems more democratic that all members of the committee concerned can vote... On the other hand, to vote in favour of this text would be to give a blank appeal to this appointment procedure and ultimately to the Commission. So I decided to vote against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which includes key recommendations about how future Commissioner hearings should be held. These include each Member State putting forward a female candidate and male candidate of equal footing for consideration. The report also asks the Commission to review the rules on financial declarations which should also cover financial interests of family members.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the procedures and practices governing the hearings of commissioners based on the lessons learned from 2014. These public hearings, which are not covered by the treaties, have been in place for some 20 years at the request of Parliament. Candidates for the post of Commissioner must appear before the committee or parliamentary committees corresponding to their responsibilities for a hearing, before Parliament votes in confidence on the Commission. These hearings are particularly useful because they give Parliament and citizens the opportunity to discover the personality, general approach and priorities of each candidate nominated by the Member States, as well as to assess their competences. It should be remembered that the European Parliament has the power to reject a European Commission whose composition would not be satisfactory.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We believe that the public hearings of the Commissioners-designate represent a truly important opportunity for the European Parliament and for all citizens of the European Union to assess each candidate's priorities and suitability for the post, and also to be a valuable instrument and an important exercise in participatory democracy. With the adoption of this report, we intend to make some procedural improvements, which are also the result of past experience. Noting the increased interest in the media and the public, we suggest, for example, that we envisage a new use of social networks to involve the citizens of the European Union more effectively in the process of hearings. Specific public sections could be created on Parliament's website, available in all the official languages of the Union, so that all European citizens can freely assess the curriculum vitae of the Commissioners-designate and their answers to written questions.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will better regulate the Commissioner hearings, a practice developed over the past 20 years at the insistence of the European Parliament.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the procedures and practices of hearings of Commissioners – experience from the hearings in 2014, I consider it a good tradition that the EP in this way reflects the processes that have taken place in the run-up to the election of a new European Commission. Although committees should remain the main arena for hearings, I consider it useful that, in justified cases, hearings should take place in a different format, e.g. as a meeting of the Conference of Presidents or a meeting of the Conference of Committee Chairs. I also welcome suggestions to streamline and streamline hearings, such as allowing interviewers to respond directly to commissioners-designate's responses.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. – In principle, this report contains very good proposals for improving the procedures of hearings. However, it would be imperative that more votes be taken in committees. That is because of this, I abstained from voting.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report provides an overview of the hearing procedure for European Commissioners prior to their appointment. It proposes ways to improve this hearing process. But the proposals made by this report do not include any of the real democratic problems that arise with the holding of these hearings. For example, there are no plans to strengthen the weight of small political groups during the hearings of the Commissioners-candidates. I have therefore voted against this report, which I find insufficient on one of the essential steps in the appointment of our Commissioners.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The report gives an overview of the 2014 hearings of commissioners-designate in the European Parliament, and also proposes some amendments, such as setting a deadline for the submission of a Commissioner-designate, so that there is more time to collect, as well as a proposal that each Member State should put forward two candidates at the same time, one of whom would be male and the other a woman.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I support the report tabled.  In particular, the listening process helps to improve control and increase the responsibility of the Commission as a whole. It is therefore necessary to ensure that they proceed smoothly and constructively. In particular, this is an important opportunity for Parliament and EU citizens to assess the priorities of each candidate and its professional fitness for office. In addition, the hearings of Commissioners increase transparency and strengthen the democratic legitimacy of the Commission as a whole. In order to ensure a more flexible and dynamic process, it would be useful to set a deadline by which all Member States should submit their candidates in order to give the President-elect sufficient time to allocate portfolios. It is also essential that the Member State should submit at least two nominations to the President-elect of the Commission.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have noted the incisive role played by the public hearings of candidates for the Commission, which can be seen from the rapporteur's work. In view of the absence of a rule providing for such a procedure within the TEU and in the hope that this will soon be regulated, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Commissioner-designate hearings have a 20-year history and are a well-established practice. Since 1994, these hearings have increased the democratic legitimacy of the Institutions of the European Union and brought them closer to European citizens. Hearings are necessary for Parliament to be able to make a judgement on the Commission, based on information in a vote of confidence, allowing the Commission to take up its duties.  Of course, the hearing process can always be improved, although it is also very effective at the moment. I agree with suggestions from committee members that it would be useful to set a deadline for all Member States to propose their candidates so that the President-elect of the Commission has sufficient time to allocate portfolios, taking into account the work experience and CV of candidates, and with member states' proposal to take into account the uniform representation of men and women when proposing candidates.  I also support the initiative to improve checks, i.e. control on the financial interests and financial situation of candidates and their family members, as I believe that in their work commissioners must be independent from any external influences and pressures. I also support the technical suggestions of committee members regarding the hearing process and advocate its clear transparency and public availability. Therefore, I support this report on the procedures and ways of hearing commissioners-designate based on the 2014 and 2020

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. In the proposed measures, some are innocuous or even good (such as better control of declarations of financial interests and inclusion of family interests), but the dual male-female candidacy is ridiculous and encroaches on the sovereignty of the Member States with a definite risk of drift (soon, each state will want to propose several names and the EU therefore choose the Commissioner that suits it). In principle, I refuse to agree to the improvement of the procedure because it would be a way of recognising its legitimacy and the legitimacy of the European Commission, which I formally challenge. I therefore vote against this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The Commissioner-designate hearings first held in 1994 are now a well-established practice that enhances the democratic legitimacy of the Institutions of the European Union and brings these institutions closer to European citizens. They are necessary for Parliament to be able to make a judgement on the Commission based on information on the vote of confidence, allowing the Commission to take up its duties.  I support the provisions of this report, which calls for the establishment of deadlines for the appointment of candidates in order to leave sufficient time for the allocation of portfolio responsibilities and preparation of candidates.
