The evaluation of candidates should be made publicly available after no more than 24 hours after the hearing. The principle of gender equality should also be taken into account when appointing candidates. I believe this report represents a good set of guidelines for future hearings and therefore I once again show my support.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The hearing procedure is not provided for in the Treaty of Lisbon. This is a practice developed over the last 20 years which has meant that candidates for the function of Commissioners will appear before the parliamentary committees corresponding to their portfolio, before Parliament's vote of confidence in the Commission. Public hearings of candidates for the European Commission give the European Parliament the opportunity to know each candidate's priorities and to assess their qualifications. If the debate reveals any problems, Parliament could in this way oppose the nomination of the candidate and ask for his replacement. The aim of the report is to draw conclusions from the last round of Commissioners' hearings and to propose some reflections which could lead to a change in procedures. I believe that it is appropriate to impose on the Member States a deadline within which they must propose their candidates; apply clear guidelines for the post-hearing coordinators evaluation meeting and ensure the transparency and visibility of letters of approval. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 When voting on the report dealing with the hearing of commissioners, I did not support it because I do not agree with the recommended institute, according to which Member States should nominate two candidates (male and female) and the Nominated President of the Commission would choose one from them. This would effectively weaken the positions of the Member States, which I do not support. Moreover, I believe that a similar mechanism would not work in practice. Personally, I believe that the quality and competence of the candidate, not his or her gender, is key.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the Commissioners' Hearing and the lessons learned from the 2014 hearings. This report analyses the conditions under which the hearings were conducted in 2014 and improves the conduct of future hearings.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The hearings of commissioners-designate are essential for Members to be able to assess their general competence, their European commitment and their personal independence, before parliament's vote of approval to which the Members of the Commission are collegiately subject.  In this sense, and by contributing the decisive hearings to the increase of transparency and the strengthening of the Democratic legitimacy of the Commission, it is important that such a process be evaluated, so that the improvements to be made are sharpened. On the basis of the experience of 2014, this report proposes a series of measures to improve the effectiveness of hearings, essentially seeking to ensure greater flexibility and dynamism of procedures, to establish clear guidelines for the coordinators' evaluation meeting, to strengthen monitoring of declarations of financial interests, to ensure compliance with gender equality objectives and to provide greater involvement of EU citizens in the process.  Because I agree with the majority of the proposals put forward, I voted in favour.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. Although the procedure for public hearings for members of the Commission is not provided for in the Treaty, it is a practice that has been implemented at the request of Parliament and which increases transparency and strengthens the Democratic legitimacy of the Commission. This report proposes changes to improve the effectiveness of this procedure, including, inter- introducing a deadline for Member States to submit their candidates, improving the control of declarations of economic interests, increasing the number of questions that make up the written questionnaire and greater interaction during the debate (double question), etc. The report also calls for the equality between women and men to be reflected in the composition of the European Commission by presenting by the Member States of at least two candidates - one man and one woman, on an equal footing - for consideration by the President-elect of the Commission. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The public hearings of candidates for the post of Commissioner provide the European Parliament and citizens with an opportunity to discover the priorities of each candidate and assess the candidate's competence. When the debate uncovers problems, it is up to the European Parliament to oppose the appointment of a candidate and ask for his replacement. Once again, the European Parliament is leading the way and is at the forefront of transparency. The aim of the report in question is to draw conclusions from the last process of Hearings of the Commissioners and to advance certain reflections that could lead to a change in procedures. The adopted text calls, for example, for any Member State to nominate at least two candidates for the post of European Commissioner: one man and one woman. The text also notes that the current scope of the Commissioners' declarations of interest is too limited and that the Commission should be asked to revise its rules on this matter as soon as possible.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Public hearings of candidates for members of the European Commission provide an opportunity for Parliament and the public to know the priorities of each candidate for Commissioner and to assess their knowledge and personality. This system strengthens transparency and gives greater democratic legitimacy to the Union's institutions, bringing them even closer to citizens.  When there are problems, revealed by the debate, it is up to the European Parliament to owe itself to the nomination and to ask for the replacement of the candidate. Once again, the European Parliament is at the forefront of defending the best interests of European citizens and transparency.  The process of hearings is not provided for by the Treaty, although it is a practice developed over the last 20 years at the insistence of the European Parliament. To that extent, I agree with the report's proposals to draw conclusions from the hearing process, proposing some considerations that could lead to changes in procedures, including setting a deadline for Member States to communicate candidates for Commissioner, defining a number of questions to be raised, clear guidelines for evaluation meetings and greater transparency and visibility of the selection process. I voted in favour.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider the role played by the European Parliament in the selection of the College of Commissioners to be essential. The new rules for hearing Commissioners will bring greater efficiency and transparency and bring citizens closer to the world of politics. The European Parliament has decided to impose a deadline by which the Member States will have to propose their candidates, which must be at least two, one man and one woman. In addition, the publication of the letters of approval will be guaranteed and the evaluation will be completed within 24 hours.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained because the institution of hearings is undoubtedly an appreciable element of transparency, but unfortunately it is usually followed by an activity of the European Commission that is all too often very opaque.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this Report focusing on the operation of Hearings during 2014. We understand that the report does not finally take over the specific position that small groups hold within the parliamentary structure. While the report has some points of fundamental importance to our political position, such as the recommendation to promote gender balance, it is not able to bring small political groups into the constant evaluation logic required by Commissioners. Likewise, the reduction of questions certainly limits the possibilities of intervention of small groups within the Hearings. We understand that the Report points to certain key criteria and we hope that these criteria will be taken into account in order to promote, for example, equality, but the plurality of the plenary must also be reflected

name: György Schöpflin (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Corbett report contains highly important recommendations for the organisation of Commissioner-designate hearings. For this reason, I decided to vote in favour.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report refers to the procedure for the election of European Commissioners following the experience of the election of the last College of Commissioners last year. Unfortunately in this case again the Grand European Coalition (made up of people and socialists) imposes its majority to further cut the rights of other political groups, with the aim of preventing us from questioning the current European orientation.  The change that this report sees is that it ends with the right that until now each political group had to refuse to ratify a Commissioner directly after a hearing and to force the vote of a Commissioner in the plenary of the parliamentary committee. This mechanism, for example, has succeeded in rejecting Italian Rocco Buttiglione's candidacy to join the European Commission for his homophobic statements, as proposed by this report would no longer apply. As a sign of my rejection of the growing cut in democratic rights in the European institutions, I voted against it.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Public hearings of potential Members of the Commission are an exercise that has contributed to greater knowledge by European citizens of both the programmes to be developed and personalities and political pathpaths. The European Union has gained, from the point of view of the transparent relationship with European citizens, with these hearings. This practice, although not enshrined in the Treaties, already has a history of twenty years of application. It is therefore widespread understanding that this process must now be maintained and improved with the proper lessons of past processes, with a view to a model in line with the challenges to be overcome in the near future. The amendments now proposed embody developments in the existing model, which deserve our support. From the outset, the issue of parity, with the proposal to present two personalities of different gender, in order to ensure an effective adoption of parity in the constitution of future Commissions. It is also important to highlight the extension of the register of financial interests to the family of potential Commissioners, contributing to greater financial transparency. For all these reasons, I congratulate the rapporteur and all those who have contributed to this report and I hope that many of the proposed precepts will be applied quickly.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as it is far too technical and procedural and in matters of transparency does not go far in enough.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report from Richard Corbett, because it clarifies the procedures and practices for future Commissioner hearings. It rightly identifies the aspects of the procedures and practices from the 2014 process; it flags up the lack of deadline for Member States to put forward a candidate; it allows the Legal Affairs Committee to highlight conflicts of interest; it calls for better provisions for gender equality, an issue I am very excited to hear is being addressed; and finally it allows for Members to give a follow-up question to the Commissioners once they have been asked a question.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this report because I believe that a deeper change is needed. The hearings themselves had little significance and subsequent impact. The last hearings seem to have had almost no impact on the final vote of the European Parliament.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Public hearings of Commissioners-designate were first used in 1994 and have so far become an established practice that increases the democratic legitimacy of the EU institutions, and the institutions are approaching European citizens in this way. The presentations are an opportunity for the EP and EU citizens to learn about and assess the personality, qualifications, readiness and their knowledge of the field of work they are competing for. The final report consists of good proposals that strengthen the integrated process of presenting Commissioners-designate. As such, I can mention the proposal to set a deadline by which all Member States should nominate their candidates in order for the President-elect of the Commission to have sufficient time to allocate them the areas of work, and Parliament could also make hearings and evaluations. Furthermore, the report includes the suggestion that each Member State should nominate at least two candidates – a male and a woman on an equal leave. I also believe that one of the more important proposals is to improve the examination of the declarations of financial interests of commissioners by the Committee on Legal Affairs, according to which the absence of a conflict of interest would be an important condition for carrying out the presentation itself. In view of the above proposals contained in the report and the very importance of the public presentation of the EP Commissioners-designate and EU citizens, I supported the report.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the report because transparency is one of the cornerstones of democratic systems. Some findings suggest that there is still much room for improvement in the selection of political officers and commissioners to European political bodies and this needs to continue to be worked on in the coming period, all to improve transparency on the European political scene. In this way, they can be improved and changed for better specific procedures in these elections.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as it sets out clear recommendations that will improve future Commissioner hearings. Amongst the proposed improvements was setting a deadline for member states to propose candidates and allow enough time for the allocation of portfolios and hearings, a request to make each Member State put forward a female candidate and a male candidate of equal footing for consideration, and setting a ceiling for the number of questions and follow-up questions per hearing.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal because I welcome the Commissioners' hearings and consider them to be a step forward towards greater transparency and democraticity. However, much more needs to be done to actually correct the EU's democratic deficit.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Commissioners' presentation: lessons learned from the 2014 procedures. I welcome the great weight that the European Parliament has on the choice of the President of the Commission and the European Commissioners. In the European Parliament, which is the only institution directly elected by EU citizens, we are voting for both the President of the Commission and the Commission as a whole. In addition, Commissioners-designate are also heard and subject to public pressure, which leads to a really high-quality choice of Commissioners. In Slovenia, too, candidates for ministers must pass a hearing before the home committee, which not only represents formality, but provides a better quality choice.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Report on the procedures and practices of hearings of Commissioners – I supported the experience gained during the hearings in 2014, as I believe that it contains a sober assessment of the experience of last year and proposes adjustments to future practice that can contribute to greater efficiency and clarity of the whole process. It must be said that the practice of hearing Commissioners-designate is indeed only an established practice, which is not regulated in the Treaties, and it is therefore necessary to constantly evaluate and improve these customary rules. So this is not a bureaucratic exercise, but a necessary and useful reflection.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 With the new proposal in the report what is being achieved - and what is part of a more general direction and policy pursued in the institutions in recent years within a more general framework of depoliticisation - is as follows: 1) to limit the possibility of voting only to the will of the two major political groups 2) to play down the role of the political groups; since it is up to the majority of MEPs themselves 3) to reduce the possibility of holding a vote and ultimately to reduce the ability of groups and MEPs to express a political position on the Commissioners-designate. As ACPL, we express ourselves politically with our vote in the voting procedure of the President of the Commission and of the Commissioners. We do not judge them as individuals, but we vote against the unpopular neoliberal programme and the memorial policies they announce and follow (the Commission's policies do not differ from who each Commissioner is). Together with our group, we have already ed against the downgrading or even abolition of the voting procedure for Commissioners. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The attempt to amend the Regulations on Commissioners' Hearings, which does not include a truly democratic process but is based on 'elections without representatives', demonstrates the anti-democratic and unpopular culture presented by the European Union.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that it articulates with sufficient precision our lessons on listening to Commissioner-candidates. In 2014, the current MEPs were able to participate in the process of appointing Commissioners through the lucky selection of election and nomination dates. The Hearing of Commissioners in the European Parliament became a practice in 1994; the hearings have since become indispensable for Parliament to be able to judge the Commission with sufficient knowledge in its vote of confidence allowing it to take office.  The report underlines the importance of setting a meetable deadline by which each Member State should nominate its candidate and to make the hearing process more interactive, including the use of social media. In practice, parliament as a whole formally votes on the Commission as a whole, and the opinion of each committee on certain Commissioners has no legal significance, but the composition of the Commission or the division of portfolios may change. It should be added, however, that the hearings are not in an attempt to change the political composition of the Commission. In fact, the same government will nominate another candidate to replace the unsuccessful candidates.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The public hearings of prospective members of the European Commission is a democratic exercise which provides the Parliament and the public an opportunity to discover the personalities, the approach and the priorities of each candidate. The process produces political clarifications and commitments, adjustments to portfolios, and further clarity on the relationships between the Vice—Presidents and other Commissioners. Nevertheless, there is always room for improvement, and few propositions are outlined by the current report. For example, the report asks for a fixed deadline for Member States to put forward candidates and allow time for the allocation of portfolios and hearings. It also asks the EP Legal Affairs Committee to clarify the rules on how to manage designate Commissioners’ declaration of interest and scope of application, to also include cover financial interests of family members. Lastly, a recommendation which I particularly support, is the need to put forward at least two candidates, a male and a female, on an equal footing for consideration by the President-elect. Drawing the lessons of this period, I welcome this report that clarifies the procedures and practices for future Commissioner hearings, while providing inputs on how to improve the process.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which aims at improving the hearings of Commissioners and the overall selection process. From my experience last September I am in favour of reducing the number of questions MEPs can ask to the Commissioner-designate to ensure a more in-depth discussion. If there is no consensus on a candidate, an additional enquire should be conducted through written questions and if necessary through another hearing. The scope of the declaration of interests should also be broaden so that all Commissioners-designate are free of any suspicion.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒Contrary to the rather smug statements of the rapporteur, the democratic legitimacy of the European Union will hardly find its enlightenment in addressing minor procedural or even institutional adjustments. This can only be achieved through the full renegotiation of the Treaties, namely by minimising the importance of supranational bodies and activities that have flared up to worrying levels in recent decades, and by restoring cooperation between individual Member States as sovereign partners. Also, the politicization that has been taking place recently around the Commission selection process is worrying. This is best demonstrated by the fact that the commission's most recent hearing in 2014 had absolutely no impact on the final outcome of the vote - the Commission as a college after the hearing was approved by 423 votes in favour, compared to 422 three months earlier, when Mr Juncker was voted in as President of the Commission. So I voted no.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the hearing of commissioners proposes to improve certain procedures in the public hearings of members of candidates from the European Commission, thus giving an opportunity for Parliament and the public to identify each Commissioner's priorities and assess their competence. This further contributes to transparency, while again putting the European Parliament at the fore of transparency and setting an example for national institutions at the level. It is important that we discuss and learn from the procedures for appointing Commissioners. In particular, due to the case of the self-appointment and candidacy of the former President of the Government of the Republic of Slovenia, I supported the report.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this Report focusing on the operation of Hearings during 2014. We understand that the report does not finally take over the specific position that small groups hold within the parliamentary structure. While the report has some points of fundamental importance to our political position, such as the recommendation to promote gender balance, it is not able to bring small political groups into the constant evaluation logic required by Commissioners. Likewise, the reduction of questions certainly limits the possibilities of intervention of small groups within the Hearings. We understand that the Report points to certain key criteria and we hope that these criteria will be taken into account in order to promote, for example, equality, but the plurality of the plenary must also be reflected.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. In the measures proposed, some are innocuous or even good, but the dual male/female candidacy is ridiculous and encroaches on the sovereignty of the Member States with the risk of drift (soon, we will want each state to propose several names and the EU to choose the Commissioner that suits it). In principle, agreeing to the improvement of the procedure would be a way of recognising its legitimacy and the legitimacy of the European Commission, which we formally challenge. I am voting against this text.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This is an important procedure and a redeserving of practical experience. The hearing process is not laid down in the Treaty. This practice has developed over the last two decades under pressure from Parliament, which simply required that, before Parliament holds a vote of confidence on the Commission (as provided for in Article 17 TSI), commissioner-designate should appear before the parliamentary committee(s) corresponding to their portfolio. It's become a good practice. It is important to discuss experience. The Committee on Transport and Tourism has prepared an opinion on the report. I supported the commission's opinion and the full report with my vote.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this Report focusing on the operation of Hearings during 2014. We understand that the report does not finally take over the specific position that small groups hold within the parliamentary structure. While the report has some points of fundamental importance to our political position, such as the recommendation to promote gender balance, it is not able to bring small political groups into the constant evaluation logic required by Commissioners. Likewise, the reduction of questions certainly limits the possibilities of intervention of small groups within the Hearings. We understand that the Report points to certain key criteria and we hope that these criteria will be taken into account in order to promote, for example, equality, but the plurality of the plenary must also be reflected.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: por escrito. ‒ My vote was positive because the report includes good proposals to enhance the hearings process, in particular with a genuine scrutiny of the declarations of financial interests.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which is an evaluation of the hearings that are held in the European Parliament before appointing members of the Commission. I agree on the fact that this process in useful and gives a chance, although indirectly, to EU citizens to assess the quality of each candidate and their professional suitability for the role. The resolution also puts forward a number of proposals concerning the approval/rejection procedure of the candidate on behalf of the Committee coordinators. An interesting suggestion that the text puts forward is that of having a specific section of Parliament’s website where the CVs of the Commissioners-designate and responses to written questions are made available, in advance of the public hearings. The 2014 hearings generated more interest than in previous years and this would be an even better way to make citizens part of the decision-making process.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This Parliament, through the hearings of the Commissioners, has a great opportunity to be able to listen to their priorities, as well as to evaluate their profiles and formations. This report aims to make certain changes based on the last hearings that were made for the current Commission with the aim of improving the current procedure. That is why I consider it appropriate to vote in favour of that report.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR)
text: Written. 'The N-VA members of the European Parliament abstained in voting on the Corbett report on the hearings with the Commissioners-designate, because this report proposes, on the one hand, a number of positive elements, such as the declaration of family financial interests, but on the other hand we doubt whether it will be enough to counter the political games that the 'grand coalition' of Christian Democrats, Socialists and Liberals raised at the hearings with the Juncker Commission in 2014 to avoid the disent of their save their own weak candidate by putting all the controversial candidates of the traditional parties in one big pocket and thus holding the European Parliament hostage.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of this report. The hearings we organise with commissioners-designate is an important moment for the European Parliament. On the one hand, we can check that the candidates are well prepared for their new job. On the other hand, we can also see (as has been shown in the past) whether the right person would indeed be in the right place. It is also the first time when the European Parliament can give its concerns to the newly created Commission. Of course, we in Parliament must also look at our procedures and learn lessons from previous hearings.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. After the European elections and before their appointment, the European Commissioners had come to appear before the parliamentary committees of their field of competence.   A year later, the European Parliament takes stock of this procedure.  To say the least, this was not conclusive: from conflict of interest to blackmail between political groups, these hearings were caricatured.  To name but a few, the appointment of Arias Caete (EPP), in charge of the energy portfolio and accused of having personal interests in the oil industry, could not be prevented: the European right had threatened to attack Pierre Moscovici (S-D) if its Spanish "champion" was threatened. It is impossible for the majority of Parliament to acknowledge this failure and to draw the consequences.   Therefore, the report welcomes the success of these hearings, and only asks, timidly, for control of possible conflicts of interest. The GUE/NGL, had tabled an amendment to avoid this type of political blackmail. Amendment obviously rejected. I have therefore voted against this report which derives no consequence from the failure of these hearings and refuses to introduce a minimum of transparency in these procedures.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 In this report, which reviews the "selection" process of Commissioners in 2014 and makes recommendations on how the process should take place in the future, it is proposed, among other things, to increase gender balance, improve the verification of the applicants' financial statements, reduce the number of questions posed to the "candidate" during the hearings or institutionalise the format of the "Conference of Presidents".  The position of Commissioner is a position of political trust of the governments of the Member States and, in this sense, must correspond to their political choices. In this sense, the evaluation that Members make of Commissioners should be political and not just technical, as if it were a job interview.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. In principle, the report contains good proposals for improving the procedures of hearings. However, it would be imperative that more votes be taken in committees. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report reviews how the "selection" of Commissioners process in 2014 took place and therefore makes recommendations on how the process should take place in the future. In this sense, the following is proposed, among other things,: to increase gender balance, to improve the verification of the applicants' financial statements, to reduce the number of questions posed to the "candidate" during the hearings and to institutionalise the format of the "Conference of Presidents". The position of Commissioner is a position of political trust of the governments of the Member States and corresponds to their political choices. In this sense, the evaluation that Members make of Commissioners is political, taking into account their political and ideological choices. We do not follow this attempt to give a 'technical' picture (for example by assessing commissioners' competences at those hearings) to what should be a political discussion. Hence our vote against.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, last year Raif Badawi, a Saudi activist, was sentenced to a decade in prison and a thousand lashes for criticising the Saudi clerics online. Sadly, this is just one of many examples of security measures being used as a pretext for clamping down on those who stand up for freedom and democracy. Events in China, Russia and the Middle East and North Africa region have demonstrated that, while digital technology can be a tool for freedom, in the wrong hands it becomes a tool for repression instead. That is why I voted in favour of the Schaake report on human rights and technology in third countries. We need to adopt binding measures that require our companies not to sell technology to repressive regimes, and we need to counter the criminalisation of encryption – a valuable tool for bypassing censorship and protecting our privacy. Digital surveillance will be effective in countering terrorism and keeping us safe only if it does not tread on human rights while doing so.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – I voted in favour of the report on the link between human rights and technology, because I strongly condemn the mass surveillance of citizens by Edward Snowden, among others. At the same time, I am looking for an answer to a fundamental question, and this is this: how can they not use all this knowledge, all this technology, and about redeploy resources to find the smuggling gangs that cause so much suffering, and to expose the Islamic State, ISIS, which is also causing so much suffering. For example, the Islamic State has got its hands on oil wells in Syria and elsewhere. Somewhere this oil is sold, someone buys this oil. I'm not a secret service specialist, but I suppose if the secret services can tell us for sure what any of us had here this morning, they might be able to do some effort to tell us where the Islamic State got its money from, or identify and punish the smuggling gangs. What's missing? I mean, we've got the technology, we've got the resources. It's the political will that's missing. And that is the fundamental problem with the whole issue of mass illegal migration, that the underlying causes do not want to be eliminated – it seems.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE).
text: – Some information and communication technologies produced in Europe are sold and can be used in third countries by persons seeking the mass collection of personal data seeking to locate and listen to persons illegally. It is very serious what is happening and, therefore, we must prohibit European companies from selling such technologies to people who use them precisely to plan attacks against us.  In this context, I call on the European Commission to remove such companies from public tenders and also, when it comes to aid applications to third countries, not to receive aid those states where human rights are trampled and where there are groups of people or individuals using the technologies bought from us precisely for the destruction of , locating and identifying people and destroying, I repeat, democracy.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, honourable colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. I voted today, together with several Members, in favour of the marietje Schaake report. I believe that this is extremely timely and important for the entire European Union. Because what's going on now? Often, after every terrorist act, we hear talk of more authority being given to the special services. Often, the special services themselves require more powers in the national parliament for each Member State. But it is also often the case that special services not only use these powers to protect the citizens of the European Union from terrorists, but also to target the citizens of the European Union. There is no shortage of such examples, and we must fight against it. Unfortunately, my country, Latvia, is very 'sick' of the arbitrariness of the special services, and I think that this report is a very good orientation for a new policy towards the arbitrariness of the special services and, at the same time, with a vector to protect the citizens of the European Union. I voted in favour. Thank you!

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 While not yet at the levels of Orwell's well-known book "1984", you have to keep your guard high. The advances made in the technological-digital field have had a major impact on information and communication services, allowing us to overcome borders that until a few years ago could be considered science fiction. However, since there are still no clear rules, we all too often see a violation of human rights and fundamental freedoms, especially in third countries. Security measures, including counter-terrorism measures, are increasingly being used as a pretext for violating the right to privacy and for countering the legitimate activities of human rights defenders, journalists and political activists. With the report 'Human rights and technology: impact of human rights surveillance and intrusion detection systems in third countries', the European Parliament sends a clear message to the Commission and the Council, calling on them to actively defend the open Internet, multilateral decision-making procedures, net neutrality, digital freedoms and data protection safeguards. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. While this resolution calls for respect for human rights, privacy and the protection of people's data in intrusion and surveillance systems in third countries, the text is far from desirable on this issue in my opinion, since while it calls for an end to mass espionage operations , does not cite the responsibility of the United States in them and does not criticize the implications of TTIP in future cases. Nor does it condemn human rights violations committed on the pretext of the "fight against terrorism" and calls for digital freedom from a free trade approach. Despite some statements of good intentions in the text, the elements already set out make me consider the report to be insufficient and I have not been able to give it my favourable vote.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which was initiative report with a Roll Call Vote on the final vote. The report was concerned with ICTs and their application/usages in surveillance programmes. The report contained some very positive aspects. Primarily, it defended and called for the de-criminalisation of whistle-blowers. Moreover, the report called for caution when exporting ICTs to third countries with poor human rights track records. It was for these reasons that I tabled a positive vote.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Technological developments and access to the Internet are important for freedom of expression, but can be used to violate human rights. I therefore believe that it is important that technologies produced in the EU do not fall into the wrong hands and are misused by oppressive regimes as surveillance systems for spying on their own people or for corporate espionage.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This is a report that gives European standards precedence over state standards. In this case, this report aims to regulate the conduct of Member States on everything related to freedom of information and the use of cryptological systems or services. This is an area that directly concerns the strategic interests of states; they must therefore be preserved independent and kept under the direct control of states. Since the European Union has no legitimacy to intervene in national legislation and practices, particularly when dealing with areas of defence and communications security, I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ It is not for the Commission to interfere in the internet policies of third countries, and I do not believe in the politicisation of trade in this respect.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Union likes to give moral lessons to the world, but what has it done for Julian Assange and Edward Snowden as far as whistleblowers are concerned?

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Technological advances have a growing involvement in the field of human rights and fundamental freedoms. This report, to which I supported, underlines the universality of these rights and freedoms, including in the area of information and communication technologies. While condemning mass surveillance practices contrary to the rule of law, the report requires, among other things, the Commission to promote digital freedom in its policies, particularly external ones, to set up a body to assess the impact of these technologies on human rights and draws the Commission's attention to the complex situation of whistleblowers. It is essential to protect these citizens who denounce, among other things, practices of massive espionage or major tax evasion.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. U2012 Technological advances and uncensored internet access play a key role in ensuring respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms by being an important tool for individuals and social organizations especially in places with authoritarian regimes. But monitoring communications through ICT can jeopardize the rights and freedoms referred to. It is therefore necessary to compromise the Member States, Europol, Eurojust, and the need to fulfil the obligations of the Charter of Fundamental Rights in order to respect international law. All measures are necessary for the protection of these communications, the development of ICT. That's why I voted for it.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report entitled "Human Rights and Technologies in Third Countries" aims to encourage the use of encryption and circumvention tools and the dissemination of tools for anonymous use of the internet. In the area of human rights, the report aims to put EU standards first and also calls for international protection for whistleblowers, activists and journalists, which can sometimes be useful as was the case with Snowden but which must be cautious to avoid the excesses of such a system.  The report will include amendments calling for data encryption in communication or for the Commission to exclude international companies within EU territory from EU procurement procedures ("companies that cooperate with regimes that do not respect human rights"). If at first glance this request seems legitimate, we must not be deceived by the notion of human rights seen through the prism of Brussels technocrats and well-wishers who would gladly classify Russia or Syria in these "regimes" but certainly not Qatar or China...  So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on this report, which deals in an unsethable way with a very sensitive issue such as the defence of whistleblowers and human rights defenders in third countries.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report on the impact of intrusion and surveillance systems on human rights in third countries. Communications surveillance increasingly interferes with the right to privacy and freedom of expression when an adequate legal framework is not respected.  We must demand coherence between the EU's external action and our internal ICT policies, as well as the promotion of democratic development and use of security and intelligence services through the Union's political dialogue with third countries. Security measures, and in particular those aimed at combating terrorism, are increasingly being used as an excuse to commit privacy violations and as a tool to suppress the legitimate actions of HRD advocates, journalists, bloggers, political activists, as this report stresses.  That is why the EU must offer international protection to whistle-blowers, claim the appointment of a United Nations Special Rapporteur for digital freedom and data protection, and recognize internet access to be recognized as a human right.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on the report on the impact of ICT-assisted hacking and surveillance systems on human rights in third countries. As technology systems may not be misused as tools to violate human rights, Parliament calls on the Commission to prohibit companies involved in these activities from participating in EU procurement procedures from providing research and development funding or other financial support. The Council, together with the Commission, is invited to develop an advanced and effective policy to regulate the export of dual-use technologies, thereby addressing the potentially harmful export of ICT products and services at international level.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support a human rights report in third countries. I want to stress that security measures, including counterterrorism measures, cannot be an excuse to violate the right to privacy and to swoop on the legitimate activities of human rights defenders, journalists and political activists. I believe that respect for human rights is an essential element in the fight against terrorism. The EU must promote democratic surveillance of security and intelligence services in political dialogue with third countries.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which was initiative report with a Roll Call Vote on the final vote. The report was concerned with ICTs and their application/usages in surveillance programmes. The report contained some very positive aspects. Primarily, it defended and called for the de-criminalisation of whistle-blowers. Moreover, the report called for caution when exporting ICTs to third countries with poor human rights track records. It was for these reasons that I tabled a positive vote.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In today's globalized and interconnected world, the Internet is a regular experience for billions of people. Being cut off from the Internet means drastically reducing one's ability to communicate, inform, deepen studies, improve one's economic condition, form an autonomous civic and political conscience. The right to access the Internet must be recognised as a human right because today it is an integral part of the right to social inclusion and non-discrimination of every citizen.  The widespread global spread of fast communication systems cannot make us ignore the serious injuries to privacy and freedom of expression that some institutions, both public and private, can carry out by exploiting ICT. Strong and clear action by the Union is needed to protect the security of communications, freedom of expression and information for all ICT users: new technologies must be an instrument for promoting freedom and democracy, never a means of surveillance and mass control. In this sense, the Union is morally obliged to provide its protection to whistleblowers and humanitarian activists who reveal abusive surveillance systems in third countries: freedom and security are not adversaries but must march together, both in Europe and in the rest of the world.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Internet has become a public space and also a developed single market based on the free movement of information and access to information technology. In the 21st century, the Internet represents a revolution in the possibilities of sharing data, information or knowledge of any kind.  At the same time, human rights and fundamental freedoms are universal and must be defended worldwide, regardless of the form in which they are expressed. The supervision of communications shall affect the rights to privacy if it takes place outside an appropriate legal framework. Furthermore, this report wishes to include clauses in all agreements with third countries, which explicitly refer to the promotion, guarantee and respect of digital freedom, uncensored and unrestricted access to the internet, the right to life and data protection. I voted in favour of the report because, in addition to the above, it draws attention to the development of ICT in conflict zones for better security and respect for human rights.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained. it is regrettable that certain information and communication technologies and services are sold and can be used in third countries by companies and private authorities that often violate human rights.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Respect for human rights is a fundamental value of the European Union. The European Charter of Human Rights is a binding element of the European legislative system. It is true that certain technological advances, particularly in surveillance, used by unbebehaving people, can result in the violation of a person's fundamental rights. In these cases, action must be taken to enforce freedom of expression and privacy. Nevertheless, these technologies also have the virtue of protecting citizens and securing their environment. A balance must be struck between respect for fundamental rights and the safety of citizens around the world. I voted against this report. This extremist text carried by the most ideologue fractions of the left condemns the use of new security technologies. We must not deprive ourselves of these effective instruments, which must nevertheless be regulated with lucidity.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reflection and discussion in plenary, I voted today in favour of the report on the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on 'Human rights and technology: impact of human rights surveillance and intrusion detection systems in third countries'. This issue makes clear what I have repeatedly said over the past year - in two of my written statements on the ethics of technological innovation and e-health, as well as in numerous questions - that this is a risk inherent in the very use of these technologies, of the high pervasiveness.  I join the chorus of those who share the need to properly regulate even the simple use for a noble purpose of these technologies. If this does not happen, this lack can make - and indeed makes - each of us more exposed, more vulnerable. I therefore agree with the motion for a resolution and the call for the inclusive and responsible participation of all involved (governments, civil society, the private sector and users).

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which was initiative report with a Roll Call Vote on the final vote. The report was concerned with ICTs and their application/usages in surveillance programmes. The report contained some very positive aspects. Primarily, it defended and called for the de-criminalisation of whistle-blowers. Moreover, the report called for caution when exporting ICTs to third countries with poor human rights track records. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I am opposed to the European Commission’s interference in the internet policies of third countries, and I do not believe in the politicisation of trade in this respect.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report aims to explain how technologies can help enhance human rights. Despite some of the risks that some of the systems that allow surveillance to be carried out, close or interrupt the signal, I voted in favour because the amendments we proposed, especially those to ensure respect for digital freedom, the non-censorship of the network and the promotion of its neutrality, were welcomed and included in the compromises that form part of the final text.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it encourages the use of encryption and censorship circumvention tools, the dissemination of tools for anonymous or pseudonymous use of the internet. Once again the will of the peoples is exceeded, the Union's standards on "human rights" take precedence.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Today, recognising that technological systems can be misused as tools for human rights violations through censorship, monitoring, unauthorised access to devices, interference, interception, detection and detection of information and individuals, we must recognise that fundamental freedoms and human rights are global and must be protected globally. We therefore call for measures to be taken to ensure that the privacy of activists, journalists and citizens is protected throughout the world and that they can be networked over the Internet. We reiterate and support the position that Internet access should be recognised as a human right and call for measures to close the digital divide.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote against the report on human rights and technology in third countries. This measure stresses that the surveillance of communications interferes with the rights to confidentiality, if exercised outside an appropriate legal framework, and regrets that security measures, including counter-terrorism measures, are being used as a pretext for violating the right to confidentiality. The GROUP of the European People's Party considered the content of this report to be insufficient and not in line with its prerogatives.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this own-initiative report because I believe it fully and comprehensively addresses the problems of EU companies carrying out activities that violate human rights through the sale of these technologies in third countries: interference in the affairs of European citizens, mass surveillance, intelligence services and hackers who purchase these technologies created and produced in the EU undermine the credibility of the European Union. We need more transparency and accountability in the markets. A further reason why I voted in favour is the fact that whistleblowers and journalists who reveal abusive surveillance practices in third countries are in a particularly critical situation: they should be considered human rights defenders and should therefore be protected by the EU as such.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The importance of technologies in the functioning of our societies is indisputable today. Technologies empower the individual and empower free communities. In countries still without democracy, this effect is even clearer, as was evident with the Arab Spring. Safe and free access to the Internet and its media are therefore fundamental and we must ensure and protect them. On the other hand, new technologies have also made states more forms of surveillance and control. Used effectively and legally, these are new tools to combat terrorism, corruption or child pornography. However, they are also weapons of censorship, screening or large-scale surveillance. Snowden's revelations have shown us how these new instruments can in fact lead to unimaginable abuse. In society, where new technologies can threaten fundamental freedoms, public authorities are required not to engage in debauend actions by police or secret services without authorisation and judicial control.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this own-initiative report by Parliament because I believe that technologies can have a real and effective impact on the improvement of human rights in third countries. It is also to the advantage of the European Union and the Member States that there are open rules of global use, as well as free and open source cryptographic software and technologies. That is why promotion within EU programmes and policies in favour of third countries must certainly be encouraged.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report aims to explain how technologies can help strengthen human rights. There are new opportunities that can play an important role in promoting democracy, such as freedom of online association, expression and access to information. All these possibilities are envisaged thanks to new technologies. In some areas this has an impact on activists, journalists and all those who defend human rights. The idea is to ensure that these opportunities can be used. The main ideas of our amendments, that of ensuring respect for digital freedom, the uncensored and non-restrictive network and the promotion of net neutrality, were welcomed and included in the compromises that form part of the final text, so I decided to vote in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. While this resolution calls for respect for human rights, privacy and the protection of people's data in intrusion and surveillance systems in third countries, the text is far from desirable on this issue in my opinion, since while it calls for an end to mass espionage operations , does not cite the responsibility of the United States in them and does not criticize the implications of TTIP in future cases. Nor does it condemn human rights violations committed on the pretext of the "fight against terrorism" and calls for digital freedom from a free trade approach. Despite some statements of good intentions in the text, the elements already set out make me consider the report to be insufficient and I have not been able to give it my favourable vote.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that technology systems can be misused as tools for human rights violations through censorship, surveillance, unauthorised access to devices, jamming, interception, tracking and locating information and persons, it is important to implement the conditions, benchmarks and reporting procedures to ensure that EU financial and technical support for the development of new technologies in third countries is not used in a way that violates human rights.  The Commission has a duty to pay particular attention to human rights issues in procurement processes for technological equipment, especially in countries with unsafe practices in this area.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU cannot breach the rights of citizens in third countries when doing surveillance or counter—terrorism work, otherwise it would be contradicting its own policies adopted at home. This is one of the main arguments being put forward by this report. The report includes other requests such as an international protection for whistleblowers as well as national protection laws and the appointment of a UN envoy for digital liberties and data protection. I will keep on pushing for further EU action on counter terrorism but I can never be against measures that safeguard basic rights, be it here at home or in any country in the world. Hence I voted in favour of this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report focuses on the growing impact of detection and surveillance systems on human rights in third countries, which the Rapporteur says undermines existing confidence in information and communication technologies. In particular, the report calls on the EU to include clauses in its agreements with third countries referring to the promotion and guarantee of digital freedoms, net neutrality and uncensored and unrestricted access to the internet. Finally, the report focuses on whistleblowers and their supporters and proposes to treat them as human rights defenders and that the Union protect them from international prosecution and extradition proceedings. This controversial report is marked by a strong ideological logic in that it put net neutrality before national security. Considering that a realistic approach should be taken to strike a balance between security, in the context of the fight against terrorism, and individual freedom, which is clearly not possible in this report, I voted against it.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The use of communication and information technologies has led to strong mobilizations for human rights. The use of social networks by young Syrians, Egyptians or Tunisians to call for more democracy during the "Arab Spring" is a striking example.  Unfortunately, these technologies are used by oppressive regimes to carry out mass surveillance of populations, or to monitor the activities of some of their citizens via mobile phones or other electronic devices.  That is why the use of the EU must be regulated and provided the EU with a regulatory framework.  These include combating the export by European companies of surveillance technologies to authoritarian countries and the mass surveillance perpetrated by certain European intelligence services. Finally, Parliament deplores the growing use of security measures as a pretext for the violation of the right to privacy and reaffirms its deep conviction that national security cannot in any way justify untargeted, secret or mass surveillance programmes.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: Written. I voted against this report because of two concerns.  Firstly, I believe that the report fails to strike a healthy balance between freedom and security. We often talk about national security versus civil liberties. However, assuming this contradiction is a wrong starting point. Citizens do not enjoy their safety if they are not free. But it is also obvious that there is no freedom without security! The European Union needs to think seriously about this, especially in the current climate of terror.  Secondly, I do not think it is possible under any circumstances to stigmatise European companies. The report places responsibility for the legitimate use of software programmes by third countries predominantly with EU exporting companies. This tends towards self-destruction.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported this initiative report. ICT contributes to improving access to information, promoting freedoms of expression and association, documenting and denouncing human rights abuses. But these technologies also allow tracking of individuals, censorship, mass collection of personal data and hacking of electronic devices. As a result, ICTs can easily become dangerous weapons. Control and regulatory measures must be taken. This resolution reminds all European actors that they must respect the obligations of the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Specific criteria must be drawn up to prevent any financial and technical support from the EU aimed at developing and exporting ICT to third countries from also indirectly contributing to human rights violations. These European surveillance technologies and censorship tools cannot be sold and made available to authoritarian regimes that do not apply the rule of law. Finally, responsibility must also be imposed on private companies, which also play an active role.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Mass surveillance under the pretext of the fight against terrorism is a drift of power that I cannot accept. However, Mr Schaake's report is wrong in proposing, for example, to encrypt communications with individuals who are portrayed as human rights defenders. A term that is difficult to define at a time when some governments and the media are distorting geopolitical and political reality to serve certain interests. The text also needs to strengthen the rule of eu law, including the interpretation of human rights by the European institutions. In view of the lack of ambition and the misplacements of this text, I voted against it.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report shows the hypocrisy of the EU which, while promoting the full liberalisation of digital technology networks and the use of information and communication technologies in non-restricted third countries, in the light of human rights, some of its countries use these technologies to intercept and monitor officials and citizens of its Member States.  It is more a wish list of how these technologies should be used, rather than approaching the essence of the problem of their controlled use by countries, organisations, companies or individuals for the purpose of carrying out criminal acts.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote is in favour of this resolution, as it recognises that human rights and fundamental freedoms are universal and must be defended globally in every aspect of their expression; secondly, it calls on the EU to adopt free and open-source software and to encourage other actors to do the same, as such software ensures better security and greater respect for human rights; stresses, moreover, that the surveillance of communications as such interferes with the rights to confidentiality and expression, when exercised outside an appropriate legal framework; regrets the fact that certain information and communication technologies and services produced within the EU are sold and can be used by individuals, businesses and authorities in third countries with the specific intention of violating human rights through censorship, mass surveillance, disturbing activities, interception, control, detection and localisation of citizens and their activities on (mobile) telephone networks and on the Internet; Finally, the resolution expresses concern that some EU-based companies may provide technologies and services that allow such human rights violations.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. Technological developments and unlimited access to the open Internet play an increasingly important role in enabling and ensuring the exercise and full respect of human rights and fundamental freedoms, having a positive effect by expanding the scope of freedom of expression, access to information and the right to privacy and freedom of assembly and association worldwide. The truth is that technological systems can be used incorrectly as tools for the violation of human rights through censorship, surveillance, unauthorized access to devices, obstruction, interception and tracing and locating information and people. I therefore call for the development and dissemination of technologies to contribute to safeguarding human rights and facilitating people's digital rights and freedoms, as well as their security, and to promote appropriate best practices and legislative frameworks, while ensuring the security and integrity of personal data.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it is an incentive to use encryption tools and circumvent censorship, to disseminate tools for anonymous or pseudonymous use of the internet.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union maintains a consistently high standard of protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms, but the participation of some states in the interception and surveillance of citizens and politicians in Europe has seriously undermined and undermined the credibility of the European Union's human rights policy and called into question the contribution of ICT. The institutions of the European Union must ensure that a similar situation does not happen again in the future. We must support, by all possible means, those working to strengthen ICT security and standards of protection. It is very important that we adopt the necessary legislation to prevent the purchase of communication technologies and services by private individuals from third countries, which they then use for illegal eavesdropping and human rights violations.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report because it demonstrates the hypocrisy of the EU which, on the one hand, promotes the full liberalisation of digital technology networks and the unrestricted use of information and communication technologies in third countries in the light of human rights and on the other hand leaves some of its countries to use these technologies for eavesdropping and surveillance of officials and citizens of its Member States.  The report is rather a wish list of how these technologies should be used rather than approaching the substance of the problem which certainly concerns the controlled use of these technologies by countries, organisations, companies or individuals for the purpose of carrying out criminal acts.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ If conducted outside an adequate legal framework surveillance of communications, as such, interferes with the rights to privacy and expression. Security measures, including counter-terrorism measures, cannot be used as pretext for violations of the right of the privacy and for clamping down on the legitimate activities of human rights defenders, journalists and political activists. On the contrary, respect for fundamental rights is an essential element in successful counter-terrorism policies, including the use of digital surveillance technologies.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. The report supports and prioritises the promotion and protection of fundamental human rights and fundamental freedoms in the fight against terrorism. Furthermore, points on the right to freedom of expression and expression deserve particular attention, in particular as regards the exercise of human rights to privacy, freedom of expression and expression in public surveillance of communications. Technological progress and access to the open Internet are gaining ground in all of our lives and this area deserves particular attention in order to promote and ensure respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. In my opinion, technological progress has a positive impact, broadening the scope of freedom of expression, access to information, the right to privacy and freedom of assembly and association worldwide, but regulation and security are of the utmost importance, as technological systems are being used as a tool for human rights violations through censorship, surveillance, unauthorised access to tools, interference, data acquisition, information and the search and monitoring of individuals.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. – High technology and free access to the network offer almost unlimited access to information and an exceptional stimulus for freedom of expression. But technology is likely to prove to be a threat to the individual if the risks associated with its reckless management are not also considered. Phenomena such as bullying or luking of minors or frail people online is unfortunately just one of the dangers to which network and technologies expose those who use them too lightly. Europe is, by its capacity, the guarantor of human rights and as such cannot allow the reckless and uncontrolled sale or export of high-tech products to prove to be a weapon of mass control for dictatorial regimes or an instrument that facilitates unconscious hacking or industrial or terrorist espionage.  For these reasons, I intend to support the request to the Commission to ensure that the market and the export of technologically advanced European products is regulated and monitored with particular care so that Europe is vigilant and not complicit in dramatic violations of human rights, nor towards third countries, let alone for actions that could backfire on its own citizens.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on 'Human rights and technology: impact of human rights intrusion monitoring and detection systems in third countries', because from the outset I supported the installation of Mrs Schaake's report. In my view, technology is an important tool for ensuring respect for human rights but, at the same time and if misused, it can pose a danger to the security and freedom of citizens.  I believe it is necessary for the EU to step up its efforts to support those involved in strengthening security and confidentiality rules in the ICT sector, because of their fundamental role in authoritarian regimes in organising social protests and demonstrations. I therefore express great concern at the unjustified violations of citizens' privacy by governments around the world in the fight against terrorism. Under no circumstances can the legitimate need for national security justify such intrusions. Finally, I agree with the call for the Commission and the Council to work actively with the governments of third countries to ensure freedom of thought and expression, especially of the press, which is all too often subject to intolerable controls and restrictions.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against the report on 'Human rights and technology: the impact of spying and monitoring systems on human rights in third countries' today because, as a human rights politician, it draws me wrong conclusions in key areas and issues.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: In writing. Technological advances and access to information and the knowledge they provide represent an opportunity for the development of democracy, respect for human rights, education and the promotion of peace. However, these same technologies can be a coercive surveillance tool for an authoritarian regime. I have therefore supported this text which calls on the European Union to fight against censorship and to support and train journalists and human rights defenders so that they can protect themselves, as well as their communication, from abusive surveillance.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. The escalation of the terrorist threat over the past 15 years has enabled some states to put in place legislative and technological mechanisms to monitor increasingly intrusive individuals.  These arrangements eventually led to increased censorship and surveillance of political activists, the media, lawyers and foreign governments.  The draft resolution, while it appears to be in line with the protection of digital freedoms, in return calls for further interference in third countries, as the United States does.  In particular, it calls for training and equipping those whom the European Union deems to be human rights defenders or independent journalists with the means to act.  It also proposes to include clauses in favour of digital freedoms in all agreements with third countries, even as most EU Member States are increasingly curtailing these freedoms in their own territories. These freedoms must therefore be restored in our States, without conditioning them by interfering in the affairs of third countries, because this interference constitutes an instrumentalization of human rights, a factor of tension in international relations.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. Ms Schaake's report on human rights and technology attempts to solve the squaring of the circle, or rather the squaring of the net: to preserve the Internet as a neutral space of freedom and information, to guarantee the protection of the personal data of its users, including through encryption, and at the same time not to prevent the legitimate fight against cybercrime or terrorist activities. , not to contribute, through the export of certain technologies, to the strengthening of non-democratic regimes and their control of populations. Laudable intentions. The problem is that the proposed lines of thought are very intrusive and centralising, giving the Commission far too much power in these areas. Moreover, the rapporteur is only scratching the problems of the mass surveillance of Europeans by the services of the very "democratic" United States. The report still proposes sanctions against companies that export to dictatorships, but only technologies that could strengthen them, while with the blessing of the Commission, which negotiates free trade agreements with anyone, we could safely and with great hypocrisy export everything else. Because it asks real questions but gives the wrong answers, I abstained on this text.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, which advocates the need to ensure human rights in the use and impact of new technologies. In today's times, security should not be a pretext for cutting freedom (including digital freedom). It is therefore essential to efficiently regulate ICT standards mainly with third countries that on numerous occasions systematically violate human rights.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which underlines that the surveillance of communications interferes with the rights to privacy and expression, if conducted outside an adequate legal framework. It requests that the Commission ensures coherence between the EU’s external actions and its internal policies related to technology and to promote the democratic oversight of security and intelligence services in its political dialogue with third countries. The report also notes that security measures, including counter-terrorism measures, are increasingly used as pretext for violations of the right of the privacy and for clamping down on the legitimate activities of human rights defenders, journalists and political activists; a point that Labour MEPs have made in relation to the case of Raif Badawi.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ On the resolution on human rights and technology in third countries, my vote was positive. I strongly believe that the concrete ideas presented in the proposal are the crucial in this digital age and the upcoming future. I strongly support the notion on the increase of attention to the importance of developing ICTs in conflict areas to promote peace-building activities. Nevertheless, the EU should train and equip journalists, human rights defenders and with the knowledge and the tools to protect themselves and their communications. Also, it is essential that the EU would counter the criminalisation of the use of encryption, anti-censorship and privacy tools. Despite the digital innovations and its necessity, we must be aware of the issues that are closely related to the human rights violations not only within the EU but also in the third countries.

name: Jytte Guteland Anna Hedh Olle Ludvigsson Jens Nilsson och Marita Ulvskog (S&D)
text: Written. "It goes without saying that information and communication technology (ICT) cannot be abused and contribute to human rights violations is a matter of course for us Swedish Social Democrats. We believe that both the EU and ICT companies operating in the EU should take responsibility for ensuring this in their relations with third countries, which is why we chose to support the report. We believe that the text clearly emphasises the importance of all forms of digital surveillance taking place with respect for fundamental rights and under effective parliamentary control.
