However, we would like to further underline the importance of this, as the technical and digital tools available today can also act as important means in the fight against terrorism and organised crime – provided that it is done in a controlled manner and with respect for people's privacy and digital freedom.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. This report focuses on the controversial area of digital surveillance and the use of surveillance technologies in third countries in relation to human rights violations and the restriction of individual fundamental freedoms. The report is very critical of European companies and some Member States because of the export of technologies that can be used for such purposes. I have warned that parts of the report stigmatise companies too much because they operate in countries that have a poor human rights record. Trade, investment and good economic relations in general can contribute in the long term to improving the human rights situation and promoting democracy in a country. We have proposed a number of amendments to present a balanced approach that combines respect for human rights, public security and parliamentary control. Many of these proposals were not supported. That is why I voted against this report. Incidentally, as i am my ceterum censeo, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst technology has brought huge advances in our everyday lives, there remains a frightening potential for it to be used in the abuse of human rights. This report deals with important issues and I am satisfied that this House has chosen not to water down the committee text.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, which advocates the need to ensure human rights in the use and impact of new technologies. In today's times, security should not be a pretext for cutting freedom (including digital freedom). It is therefore essential to efficiently regulate ICT standards mainly with third countries that on numerous occasions systematically violate human rights.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on "Human rights and technology: the impact of anti-theft and surveillance systems on human rights in third countries" because the report shows the benefits of ICT, but also points to problems that may arise from their use.  I believe that the Internet has opened expanses and a space of freedom that certainly has a positive effect on everyday life and helps protect certain human rights. However, it is clear that there is also a lot of room for misuse of technology by various actors, from the local and all this global level, including by terrorist organizations.  In addition, security measures often invade privacy and create pressures on individual activists operating in various fields, and it is therefore of particular importance to regulate surveillance programmes in a quality and principled way. In this context, when it comes to new technologies, I believe it is necessary to respect the rule of law, prevent illegal acts and ensure democratic principles.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is federalist because it gives European standards precedence over state standards. In this case, this report aims to regulate the conduct of Member States on everything related to freedom of information and the use of cryptological systems or services. This is an area that directly concerns the strategic interests of states; they should be preserved independently and kept under the direct control of states. Since the European Union has no legitimacy to intervene in national legislation and practices, I voted against this report.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against my colleague Marietje Schaake's report on the issue of human rights and technology in third countries. While the report highlights legitimate concerns about mass surveillance issues, it highlighted a set of unrealistic proposals. The text was adopted in spite of everything, which I regret.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because in order to fight terrorism, we may have to decode communications or encrypted systems.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this report. The proposals on the nexus between human rights and technology are forward-looking and offer great opportunities to improve the living conditions of people in third countries in the long term.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Technological developments and access to an open Internet play an increasingly important role in enabling and ensuring the exercise and full respect of human rights and fundamental freedoms, which, as universal, must be guaranteed and protected in every aspect of their expression. At the same time, respect for the right to privacy and personal confidentiality becomes of fundamental importance in a hyper-connected world and deserves the attention of the legislator when it comes to identifying and defining the applicable legislation

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. The Schaake Report (ALDE) highlights the role of technological advances and internet access in "the development and full respect for human rights and freedom of expression."  Thus, he advocates the encryption of communication with "human rights defenders" and "whistleblowers", however, exceeding the definitions of the latter.  The report condemns non-targeted, secret or mass surveillance programmes by justifying this by the good intention of combating terrorism, which is absurd since at the same time the report encourages the use of encryption and circumvention tools and the dissemination of tools enabling the anonymous or pseudonymous use of the Internet.  Once again the report underlines the primacy of EU human rights standards.  Vote against it.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. While this resolution calls for respect for human rights, privacy and the protection of people's data in intrusion and surveillance systems in third countries, the text is far from desirable on this issue in my opinion, since while it calls for an end to mass espionage operations , does not cite the responsibility of the United States in them and does not criticize the implications of TTIP in future cases. Nor does it condemn human rights violations committed on the pretext of the "fight against terrorism" and calls for digital freedom from a free trade approach. Despite some statements of good intentions in the text, the elements already set out make me consider the report to be insufficient and I have not been able to give it my favourable vote.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. In an increasingly digital world, information and communications technology (ICT) inevitably occupies an increasingly fundamental space. The benefits that have emanated from it have undoubtedly been impressive, but at the same time they have created new dangers and new challenges in relation to respect for human rights (HRD). There is a fragile balance between respect for DDFFs, such as the right of expression or privacy, and the adoption of ICTs such as intrusion and surveillance systems for the sake of collective security. This situation has been sadly accentuated by the conflicts and dangers that indistinctly hit most of the globe. Vote in favour of this report because I believe it seeks to consistently and responsiblely promote the right balance between the use of certain ICTs and the guarantee of related HRDs.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. This report focuses on the controversial area of digital surveillance and the use of surveillance technologies in third countries in relation to human rights violations and the restriction of individual fundamental freedoms. The report is very critical of European companies and some Member States because of the export of technologies that can be used for such purposes. Parts of the report prejudge companies for operating in countries with poor human rights records. However, trade, investment and good economic relations can contribute to improving the human rights situation and promoting democracy in a country. ALFA MEPs have proposed a number of amendments to present a balanced approach that combines human rights, public security and parliamentary control. Many of these proposals did not receive a majority. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it underlines that the surveillance of communications interferes with the rights to privacy and expression, if conducted outside an adequate legal framework. It requests that the Commission ensures coherence between the EU’s external actions and its internal policies related to technology and to promote the democratic oversight of security and intelligence services in its political dialogue with third countries.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. This report focuses on the controversial area of digital surveillance and the use of surveillance technologies in third countries in relation to human rights violations and the restriction of individual fundamental freedoms. The report is very critical of European companies and some Member States because of the export of technologies that can be used for such purposes. I have warned that parts of the report stigmatise companies too much because they operate in countries that have a poor human rights record. Trade, investment and good economic relations in general can contribute in the long term to improving the human rights situation and promoting democracy in a country. We, as ALFA MEPs, have proposed a number of amendments to present a balanced approach that combines human rights, public security and parliamentary control. Many of these proposals were not supported. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported my own-initiative report from my colleague Schaake mainly because of two points. Firstly, it calls for clarification of the standards and standards used by private operators to develop their systems. The report points out that private actors play an increasingly important role in the digital field in all spheres of social activity, but there are still no safeguards to prevent them from excessively restricting fundamental rights and freedoms. Moreover, given that private actors therefore play a more active role in assessing the legality of content and in the development of cybersecurity systems and surveillance systems, their activities can have a negative impact on human rights worldwide. Second, the report did not conceal the activities of the US National Security Agency (NSA) brought to light by Edward Snowden. For example, the report notes that the NSA has collected a large number of zero day exploits – vulnerabilities in IT security that the public or product vendor do not yet know about, which weaken encryption protocols and products and thwart global efforts to improve IT security. , revealed by Edward Snowden, has seriously undermined the credibility of EU human rights policy and undermined global confidence in the benefits of information and communication technology.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this resolution, which calls on the Commission to take further action (Sections 16, 38, 44 and others), the creation of expert panels (§ 54) and even the creation of a new fund (Section 8).

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Technological advances in the context of human rights are a double-edged sword, so I did not support MP Schaake's report. This progress has enabled us to better communicate, access information and knowledge and freedom of expression, but it has created danger and easier implementation of human rights and privacy violations. Technology should be used to increase awareness of the human rights situation in the world and to provide an opportunity to help people in need.  It is important to define rules and procedures precisely when using new technologies for the purpose of protecting citizens and their data. The problem of data protection, setting boundaries when collecting and using them should be addressed as soon as possible and take into account that information must be available to certain services so that the safety of citizens does not come into danger, especially at a time when we face numerous threats from outside. We need to know how to discern the line between protecting citizens' data and protecting citizens from danger and that should be our goal.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The development of technological systems and means of communication also poses an increased risk of various forms of illegal surveillance and eavesdropping. This is a gross interference with fundamental rights and personal integrity. On the other hand, current developments in third world countries, coupled with a potential threat to the population of the Union, require monitoring and controlling the activities of those who pose or may cause this threat. In the interests of democracy and the protection of fundamental rights, any intelligence activity must be defined by law and subject to it. It must not be misused; abuse must be punished. Cooperation with the EU institutions and the Member States must be a priority and coordinated one in this area.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on 'Human rights and technology: the impact of intrusion and monitoring systems on human rights in third countries' because, through this report, the European Parliament calls for the active development and dissemination of technologies that help protect human rights and facilitate digital rights and freedoms, as well as the security of citizens promoting best practices and appropriate legislative frameworks , while guaranteeing the security and integrity of personal data.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which is increasingly in favour of the primacy of european union human rights standards. This report, which is particularly incoherent, encourages and condemns in turn the encryption and circumvention of censorship which, according to the paragraph, are tools for protecting freedom of expression or abuse. It also mentions excluding companies actively cooperating with regimes that do not respect human rights from public procurement: a totally subjective concept when one considers that many technologies are dual-use and are therefore "potentially detrimental to fundamental rights".

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report, which calls for the implementation of conditions, benchmarks and reporting procedures so as to ensure that EU financial and technical support to the development of new technologies in third countries is not used in ways that infringe on human rights.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The priority principle of the report is based on security measures, including anti-terrorist measures, which are increasingly being used as a pretext for violating the right to confidentiality. The surveillance of communications, in fact, when used outside a certain context, interferes with the rights to confidentiality and expression. It is extremely important to emphasise that digital security and digital freedom are both priority factors, but they absolutely cannot violate the right to privacy and confidentiality, as key principles of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The report on the impact of intrusion and surveillance systems on human rights in third countries that we have discussed in the European Parliament, which we have approved with my support, highlights the great opportunities that open up technological advances, but also the sometimes misuse of them, to infringe human rights, through censorship , surveillance, unauthorized access to devices, intentional interference and tracking and tracking of information and citizens. For this reason, MEPs are asking for action from the EU to prevent such violations as, despite progress, judicial and democratic controls and guarantees are still underdeveloped. We want European technology not to be used for illicit purposes.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. As the report on human rights and technology in third countries opposes both any illegal surveillance, in particular against mass surveillance, and the transfer of data, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Information and communication technologies are sometimes developed with the aim of carrying out surveillance, particularly in authoritarian regimes but also in the European Union.  Moreover, it is often the companies, not the states, that own these tools. The report calls for protecting whistleblowers such as Edward Snowden. It calls for better "monitoring of THE regulations and sanctions under EU ICT law" and calls for the public exclusion of companies engaged in ICT procurement procedures or funding aid. We have not been able to introduce conditionality clauses in the text that can stop an agreement such as TTIP when the third country conducts mass surveillance against our citizens. Nevertheless, I vote FOR FOR in order to support the good elements introduced, to recall the need to protect whistleblowers and to open the debate on effective sanctions against these companies.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This is a report that gives European standards precedence over state standards. In this case, this report aims to regulate the conduct of Member States on everything related to freedom of information and the use of cryptological systems or services. This is an area that directly concerns the strategic interests of states; they should be preserved independently and kept under the direct control of states.  Since the European Union has no legitimacy to intervene in national legislation and practices, the Member voted AGAINST.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. Technological developments and unlimited access to the open Internet play an increasingly important role in enabling and ensuring the exercise and full respect of human rights and fundamental freedoms, having a positive effect by expanding the scope of freedom of expression, access to information and the right to privacy and freedom of assembly and association worldwide. Human rights and fundamental freedoms are universal and must be defended on a global scale in all dimensions of their expression. Surveillance of communications as such interferes with the rights to privacy and freedom of expression if it is carried out outside an appropriate legal framework.  It is essential to safeguard free access to ICT for all. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – The Internet and social media are powerful weapons in the fight to safeguard human rights and ensure free speech. These communication systems have the advantage that misheedals of human rights violations and restrictions on free speech immediately circulate around the world and help and support can be provided quickly. But this technology can also be used to block news sites, put citizens, bloggers and journalists behind bars or physically abuse them through large-scale surveillance, censorship, interception, and so on.  Access to and use of the Internet is a fundamental human right. It is therefore advisable to take measures, to introduce mechanisms and to design technology that guarantees the right to privacy, to free expression and publications of journalists, activists and citizens, but also the right to education and emancipation by acquiring digital competences and guaranteeing it all over the world.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the digital era, we urgently need consistent protection of the human rights of internet users, yet we are still waiting for it as a miracle, as current technological developments have overtaken us in the area of legislation by mile-long steps.  Today, the Internet is not a safe place, as, in addition to freedom, users are not guaranteed adequate legal protection. However, freedom and security are two sides of the same coin, and the issue of the protection of citizens on the Internet needs to be resolved promptly and in detail.  I am particularly concerned that security measures are increasingly being used as a pretext for violating the right to privacy and for controlling the legal activities of human rights defenders, journalists and political activists. However, under no circumstances can security justify or justify non-targeted, covert or mass surveillance programmes, regardless of whether private individuals or the State are behind them. Finally, I would like to stress that the new legal framework must be based on the principles of necessity, proportionality and must be based on democratic and judicial supervision.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which underlines that the surveillance of communications, as such, interferes with the rights to privacy and expression, if conducted outside an adequate legal framework. It requests, among others, the Commission to ensure coherence between the EU’s external actions and its internal policies related to ICTs and to promote the democratic oversight of security and intelligence services in its political dialogue with third countries. The report also notes the fact that security measures, including counterterrorism measures, are increasingly used as pretext for violations of the right of the privacy and for clamping down on the legitimate activities of human rights defenders, journalists and political activists and underlines, that on the contrary, respect for fundamental rights is an essential element in successful counter-terrorism policies, including the use of digital surveillance technologies. The report includes some requests such as an international protection for whistle-blower's as well as national protection laws and the appointment of a UN envoy for digital liberties and data protection; finally, it requests internet access to be recognised as a human right.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report notes that technological advances and access to the open Internet are increasingly important for human rights and fundamental freedoms and broadens the scope of freedom of expression, access to information, the right to privacy and freedom of assembly and association. At the same time, it draws attention to the use of technological systems as a tool for human rights violations by public and private actors, including governments and law enforcement agencies, as well as criminal organisations and terrorist networks, through censorship, surveillance, unauthorised access to devices, interference, data acquisition, information and the search and monitoring of individuals. It proposes and urges measures to ensure that technological progress contributes to the fulfillment of fundamental freedoms and that human rights violations become increasingly difficult to commit.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. This report deals with how technological advances represent a key role in ensuring respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. I would point out that technology can have a positive effect on human rights by extending the scope of freedom of expression, access to information and the right to privacy and freedom of assembly and association worldwide. On the other hand, it also has a harmful side when used for the violation of human rights through censorship, surveillance, unauthorized access to devices and the location of information and people. I support the concerns expressed in this report, such as the need to ensure coherence between the EU's external actions and its internal ICT-related policies. I also believe that the impact of technologies on improving human rights should be integrated into all EU policies and programmes. I support the promotion of best practices and appropriate legislative frameworks, while ensuring the security and integrity of personal data. I advocate the promotion and use of free and open source software, as well as encryption technologies, and support for the removal of digital barriers to people with disabilities.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on human rights and technologies in third countries aims to encourage the use of encryption and censorship circumvention tools and the dissemination of tools for anonymity on the Internet. The report wants to put EU standards first and it also calls for international protection for whistleblowers, activists and journalists, which can sometimes be useful as was the case with Snowden but which must be cautious to avoid the excesses of such a system.  The report will include amendments calling for the encryption of data in communication or urging the Commission to exclude companies cooperating with regimes that do not respect human rights (vast programme) from EU procurement procedures. However, the Commission tells us that the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights had been "suspended" in Greece. Should we conclude that the EU is part of the 'regimes' that do not respect human rights? I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which underlines that the surveillance of communications interferes with the rights to privacy and expression, if conducted outside an adequate legal framework. It requests that the Commission ensures coherence between the EU’s external actions and its internal policies related to technology and to promote the democratic oversight of security and intelligence services in its political dialogue with third countries. The report also notes the fact that security measures, including counterterrorism measures, are increasingly used as pretext for violations of the right of the privacy and for clamping down on the legitimate activities of human rights defenders, journalists and political activists; a point that Labour MEPs have made in relation to the case of Raif Badawi.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. New information and communication technologies have significantly increased information exchange around the world and developed remote trade. As the report points out, it is "important to ensure that the means of communication are secure for the benefit of their users." However, it is important to keep in mind that the internet is now regularly used for criminal purposes, especially by terrorists. The regulation of the internet must therefore promote both digital freedoms and guarantee the safety of citizens. Certain provisions in the text, aimed at prohibiting the "restriction of the use of encryption within the EU" or calling for "the systematic implementation of end-to-end encryption standards for all communications services in order to make their content more difficult for public authorities, intelligence services and surveillance agencies" were clearly not in this direction and would have made it more difficult for our intelligence services to do so. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We approve this measure made necessary due to the fact that the surveillance of communications may interfere with the rights to privacy and expression, if conducted outside an appropriate legal framework. In this context, it is important for the Commission to ensure consistency between the European Union's external actions and its internal ICT policies and to promote democratic control of the security and intelligence services, in political dialogue with third countries. It is crucial that counter-terrorism measures are not used as a pretext for violations of the right to privacy and for suppressing the legitimate activities of human rights defenders, journalists and political activists. The resolution adopted by all our group also makes an explicit demand that access to the Internet be considered as a human rights issue.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. Digital freedoms and net neutrality are fundamental human rights. Their protection is important, necessary, censorship is impermissible, data protection is an absolute priority. I therefore agree that we should include relevant items in our contracts with third countries.  At the same time, we must also face up to the fact that the digital world has opened up channels of crime that put citizens at particular risk. We must also find a balance that will enable crime in the digital world to be detected. At the moment, criminals can skilfully lavice the online world by exploiting legal uncertainties. It's time for the other side to equip itself.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will assess human rights impact and will make recommendations for adjustments that will increase the protection of human rights.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that fundamental human rights and freedoms are universal and must be defended worldwide, and in this respect the EU can and must be an example. As the document adopted today states, technological developments and access to the internet have become indispensable for the lives of as many people as possible, and their use in an ethical manner, by fully respecting the rights of those who have access to them, is essential for the EU, but also for third countries with which the EU has bilateral relations.  There is a justified fear that insufficient regulation of the use of new communication technologies may, in some states, lead to situations of violation of human freedoms such as surveillance, jamming or interception of citizens without a mandate given by an independent judge. This is one of the reasons why I voted today in favour of this report, which condemns the misuse of technology and which tilts the balance towards the need for respect for freedoms and human rights.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because I also believe that EU technologies must not be used for human rights violations. Today, technology offers unlimited possibilities, but human rights must not be violated and data of people must be documented without their consent. People can be filmed or intercepted with cameras and microphones without being aware of them. The report calls for greater transparency and accountability, which is why I support this report.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report relates to information and communications technologies (ICTs) and their use for the purpose of monitoring the population. It proposes better monitoring of the regulations and sanctions provided by EUROPEAN ICT law, warned the Commission of the dangers of exporting these ICTs to third countries, especially when the laws of these countries are insufficient in this regard. I voted in favour of this report, which, in addition to reminding us of the need to protect whistleblowers, calls us to reflect on effective sanctions against the misuse of these ICTs.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Information technology is increasingly common around the world. It is often an aid to democracy, so digital freedom must be promoted and defended at the same time.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I support the resolution tabled. In particular, the impact of intrusion and surveillance systems on human rights in third countries can have particularly negative consequences. It is therefore essential to ensure that the appropriate tools are used properly and lawfully. I believe that the EU should promote the use of free and open software. This would help to ensure the credibility of the EU's human rights policy and provide greater security. In addition, it is essential to ensure the effective implementation and monitoring of EU regulations and sanctions related to ICT.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 While I believe that the use of the Internet and ICT technology contributes to the effective and effective implementation of human rights, in particular the freedom of expression of which the European Union is a pioneer, and despite the need to identify the limits within which control and surveillance activities can be carried out by each Member State, I voted against it because, in my opinion, the issue has not been dealt with in a comprehensive and satisfactory manner.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support  the fact that digital freedoms, net neutrality, uncensored and unrestricted access to internet, privacy rights and data protection is guaranteed through specific clauses in all agreements with third countries.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Technological developments and internet access play an increasingly important role in enabling and ensuring the realisation and full respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, thanks to the positive impact they exude by expanding the scope of freedom of expression, access to information, the right to privacy of freedom of assembly and association around the world. Technology systems can be misused as a tool for human rights violations, obstruction, and interception and monitoring of an individual.  Public and private entities as well as governments and other bodies, criminal organisations and terrorist networks through technology violate human rights. Human rights and fundamental freedoms are universal and should be protected globally in every dimension. Monitoring communications is a violation of universal privacy rights if it is carried out outside the appropriate legal framework. Member States should promote full democratic oversight of the activities of intelligence services in third countries in order to establish that those services operate in full respect of the rule of law and to do so in light of enhanced cooperation and exchange of information between Member States and third countries. The Commission should ensure coherence between EU external action and its internal policy on ICT.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report entitled "Human Rights and Technologies in Third Countries" aims to encourage the use of encryption and circumvention tools and the dissemination of tools for anonymous use of the internet. In the area of human rights, the report seeks to put EU standards a step a long way to go and also calls for international protection for whistleblowers, activists and journalists, which can sometimes be useful as was the case with Snowden, but which requires a great deal of caution to avoid the excesses of such a system. The report includes amendments calling for data encryption in communication or an incentive for the Commission to exclude international companies within eu territory from EU procurement procedures ("companies that cooperate with regimes that do not respect human rights"). If, at first glance, this request seems legitimate, we must not be deceived by the notion of human rights seen through the prism of Brussels technocrats and well-wishers who would gladly classify Russia or Syria in these "regimes" but certainly not Qatar or China...  So I'm speaking out against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Today, the Internet is a revolution in terms of the opportunities it offers to share data, information and knowledge of all kinds, and since internet filters and surveillance of communications call into question the ability of human rights defenders to exploit the internet and communicate sensitive data, and since they violate several articles of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (UDHR), which guarantees every person's right to privacy and freedom of expression , I emphasise the fact that respect for fundamental rights is an essential element for successful counter-terrorism policies, including the use of digital surveillance technologies.  I agree with the rapporteur that Member States should be encouraged to ensure democratic scrutiny of those services and their activities through appropriate internal, executive, judicial and independent parliamentary scrutiny in the light of enhanced cooperation and information exchange between Member States and third countries, including through the use of digital surveillance.  I agree with the call on the Commission to engage civil society and independent experts, including security researchers, in the field of information and communication technologies in third countries, in order to ensure time-ahead expertise, which should result in policy-making that can respond to future demands and events.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased by the results achieved by the Parliament on the important issue of human rights. The vote on the human rights and technology report shows that the European Union is committed the rights of privacy and access to technology for all. It has become a worrying trend in some countries that the government will monitor and track communications on a mass scale, without any regard for an individual's privacy. These activates operate on the outskirts of the law and can undermine the pillars of democracy. When we stand idly by and let the actions continue, we undermine our own credibility in regards to human rights. In addition, we need to promote and protect those who bring attention to these privacy concerns. Whistle-blowers, journalists and those who defend human rights should have proper protections, so that they have the ability to call attention to injustice, without fear of retribution. The EU must promote unrestricted access to the internet, this includes countering the criminalization of encryption tools, censorship by passing tools, and privacy tools as a whole. The EU has long been a champion of human rights, and it is time that we include digital rights to the equation.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report urges the EU, and in particular the European External Action Service (EEAS), to use encryption in its communications with human rights defenders, to avoid putting defenders at risk and to protect its communications with third parties from surveillance. The report also deplores the fact that security measures, including counter-terrorism measures, are increasingly being used as a pretext for violating the right to confidentiality and for countering the legitimate activities of human rights defenders, journalists and political activists; reiterates its belief that national security can never justify mass surveillance programmes, secret or non-targeted; insists that such measures must be pursued in strict compliance with the rules on the rule of law and human rights, including the right to confidentiality and data protection. Together with the GROUP of the European People's Party( Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I have decided not to support this resolution because, in my opinion, although it affirms certain founding principles of our democracy, counter-terrorism and the way in which national security must be guaranteed must be the subject of autonomous decisions by the Member States.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In view of the increase in trade between the EU and third countries, many European companies are present in third countries. The report presented and adopted by the European Parliament raised the human rights impacts caused by the use of ICT, used by foreign companies. However, this report tends to promote greater control over the use of these NITs, including greater monitoring of encoding and computer encryption systems. Therefore, I voted against this report.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. Technological developments play an important role in ensuring the exercise and respect of human rights and fundamental freedoms. When used incorrectly, technological systems can, however, be tools for the violation of human rights. The right balance between digital freedom and digital security must therefore be struck.  To this end, the report calls on the EU and the Member States to actively promote the global use and creation of open and open source and open source standards, as well as encryption technologies; stresses the need for the surveillance of communications to be the subject of an appropriate legal framework; regrets that some EU technologies and intelligence and communication services are sold in third countries with the intention of violating human rights; and calls for the inclusion of cross-compliance clauses in agreements with third countries, which include the need to guarantee digital freedoms, net neutrality, uncensored internet access and privacy and data protection. Despite the agreement in principle with the objectives and concerns expressed in the report, I believe that some formulations undercompensate the security issues of citizens and institutions in terms that I cannot follow.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Human rights and fundamental freedoms are universal and must be defended on a global scale in all dimensions of their expression. New technologies can enhance our freedoms, but they can also be used to interfere with privacy and expression rights if they are carried out outside the scope of an appropriate legal framework.  Digital freedoms, net neutrality and unlimited internet access must be promoted, guaranteed and respected, but also privacy and data protection (in EU countries and in their relations with third countries). This is where Marietje Schaake's report goes.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report on the impact of intrusion and surveillance systems on human rights in third countries. Communications surveillance increasingly interferes with the right to privacy and freedom of expression when an adequate legal framework is not respected.  We must demand coherence between the EU's external action and our internal ICT policies, as well as the promotion of democratic development and use of security and intelligence services through the Union's political dialogue with third countries. Security measures, and in particular those aimed at combating terrorism, are increasingly being used as an excuse to commit privacy violations and as a tool to suppress the legitimate actions of HRD advocates, journalists, bloggers, political activists, as this report stresses.  That is why the EU must offer international protection to whistle-blowers, claim the appointment of a United Nations Special Rapporteur for digital freedom and data protection, and recognize internet access to be recognized as a human right.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Access to the open internet and technological advances are playing an increasingly important role in enabling and ensuring the development and full respect of human rights and fundamental freedoms. Unfortunately, these technological systems are sometimes hijacked by oppressive governments and regimes or criminal organizations to violate them through censorship, surveillance, information tracing, etc. In its report on the impact of intrusion and surveillance on human rights in third countries (2014/2232(INI)), Parliament calls on the Commission to ensure consistency in the EU's external actions and internal ICT policies. In particular, Parliament believes that measures must be taken to put an end to the surveillance of European citizens by national and foreign intelligence services. Finally, this report also draws attention to the plight of whistleblowers who, when they denounce abusive surveillance practices in third countries, should be regarded as human rights defenders and therefore be entitled to the protection of the Union.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. This own-initiative report expresses very valid concerns about the use of information and communication technologies (ICT) as a pretext for violating the right to privacy and cracking down on legitimate activities by citizens/groups of citizens in third countries, while also stressing the impact this perception could have on citizens' overall confidence in the use of ICT. It also states that some of these ICTs are sold and used in third countries, not only by authorities, but also by individuals or companies that violate the most basic fundamental rights, although there is no concrete data. Although I believe that this report has virtuous ideas, I consider it to be somewhat biased, but not to take on the fundamental matrix of ict security and defence and its help in preventing/early detection of potential terrorist attacks against innocent victims. Moreover, the specific conditioning provided for in paragraph 17 may be misinterpreted by the third countries concerned and confused with 'ex-colonial paternalism', which, for some, is completely unacceptable. Contrary to this idea, I believe that the EU's focus should be on the defence of human rights in general. Moreover, the EPP tried to negotiate a text which it considered more balanced but unsuccessful. For all these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Through technological development and internet access, citizens can constantly receive a wide range of information services and content. These instruments are an expression of human rights and allow the exercise of freedom of expression. To protect and guarantee these rights, it is essential to preserve and protect the right to privacy and personal confidentiality. Against this background, However, I do not agree with some of the parts of the thesis put forward by Mr Beazley. Mr Schaake.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained because the text, although it has some basically acceptable objectives, lacks an overall view of the problem in question.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, which advocates the need to ensure human rights in the use and impact of new technologies. In today's times, security should not be a pretext for cutting freedom (including digital freedom). It is therefore essential to efficiently regulate ICT standards mainly with third countries that on numerous occasions systematically violate human rights.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. While this resolution calls for respect for human rights, privacy and the protection of people's data in intrusion and surveillance systems in third countries, the text is far from desirable on this issue in my opinion, since while it calls for an end to mass espionage operations , does not cite the responsibility of the United States in them and does not criticize the implications of TTIP in future cases. Nor does it condemn human rights violations committed on the pretext of the "fight against terrorism" and calls for digital freedom from a free trade approach. Despite some statements of good intentions in the text, the elements already set out make me consider the report to be insufficient and I have not been able to give it my favourable vote.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. Technological developments and unlimited access to the open Internet play an increasingly important role in enabling and ensuring the exercise and full respect of human rights and fundamental freedoms. There is a positive effect of these technological developments by expanding the scope of freedom of expression, access to information and the right to privacy and freedom of assembly and association worldwide. All these positive aspects, among many others, oblige us, however, to check the limits of the use of these same technologies, namely the impact of human rights surveillance and intrusion systems in third countries. I voted in favour of this report and stressed the need to ensure democratic scrutiny and in accordance with international law on digital surveillance procedures, through appropriate parliamentary, executive and, in particular, judicial supervision. Privacy and individual freedom cannot be pinched, except in extreme cases, duly justified and scrutable by international justice.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as I do not believe this is an EU competency.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In the plenary session today, I voted for this report from Marietje Schaake as it addresses my concern about the lack of coherence between the EU’s external actions and its internal policies relating to ICT. Furthermore, it promotes the democratic oversight of security and intelligence services in its political dialogue with third countries.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against because I share the position of the EKR. On the one hand, human rights-violating regimes must be condemned, but at the same time, the chosen method of tackling it, which would damage the EU economy and firms that bring it high added value, seems unfortunate to me.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider respect for fundamental human rights to be a crucial element of successful policies, so I find it unacceptable that there are still many countries where technology poses certain risks. I would like to say at the outset that I am opposed to any undermining of human rights that takes place anywhere and in any country. Unfortunately, the legislative measures taken in relation to the protection of a person in third countries often appear insufficient and unable to cope with the pace at which new security risks arise. I supported the resolution because it comes with proposals for the active development and dissemination of technologies that can protect human rights in these countries. At the same time, I believe that these measures can become sufficient mechanisms to improve their legal systems and prevent the misuse of technology as a tool for human rights violations.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Technological development and access to the open Internet play an increasingly important role. Information and communication technologies can be a driver of progress or an incentive to violate human rights, and their impact depends to a large extent on the circumstances in which they are created or used. Technology systems can be misused as a tool for human rights violations through censorship, surveillance, unauthorised access to devices, signal interference, interception and tracking and tracking information and individuals. I think it is a good report, because it highlights the negative impact that the ITK may have on human rights and includes strong and practical proposals. It draws attention to important areas of ITK, such as mass surveillance, promotes democratic surveillance of the security and intelligence services, draws attention to the importance of protecting whistleblowers, calls for the use of open source software and opposes the criminalisation of the use of encryption tools. Since digital security and freedom are essential and cannot replace each other, it is essential to promote, guarantee and respect digital freedoms, net neutrality, uncensored and unrestricted internet access, the right to privacy and data protection. Human rights and fundamental freedoms are universal and must be protected throughout the world in all dimensions of their realisation, which is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. This report focuses on the controversial area of digital surveillance and the use of surveillance technologies in third countries in relation to human rights violations and the restriction of individual fundamental freedoms. The report is very critical of European companies and some Member States because of the export of technologies that can be used for such purposes. I have warned that parts of the report stigmatise companies too much because they operate in countries that have a poor human rights record. Trade, investment and good economic relations in general can contribute in the long term to improving the human rights situation and promoting democracy in a country. We, as ALFA MEPs, have proposed a number of amendments to present a balanced approach that combines human rights, public security and parliamentary control. Many of these proposals were not supported. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted against the report because it calls for each individual to be entitled to encryption and that the conditions for using encryption should be created for all users. The report also calls for whistleblowers to be considered defenders of human rights, which we also cannot take as a universal pattern.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which underlines that the surveillance of communications interferes with the rights to privacy and expression, if conducted outside an adequate legal framework. It requests that the Commission ensures coherence between the EU’s external actions and its internal policies related to technology and to promote the democratic oversight of security and intelligence services in its political dialogue with third countries.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the report on "Human Rights and Technology: The Impact of Anti-Theft and Surveillance Systems on Human Rights in Third Countries". Technology and internet access allow people to express themselves freely, however, if they are not used for proper purposes they can also be a tool for human rights violations.  The European Union should be an example and European technology should not help in violation of human rights. Technology and internet access nowadays allow a detailed view of the documentation about everyone. There are systems that are designed to massively monitor citizens and their personal devices without permission. It is necessary to know what kind of technology we use and what data we unknowingly give to others. European legislation must set an example for third countries where there are recorded cases of human rights violations, media manipulation, restriction of freedom of expression. That is why I support greater transparency, more accountability and licensing of tools so as not to sell them to oppressive regimes. Action needs to be taken to ensure that EU technologies are not used against our values and interests, i.e. they are not a tool for terrorist organisations.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the report as it is full of empty phrases, requests to strengthen the powers of the European Union and unjustified empowerment of some companies.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted against the report on human rights and technology in third countries. I believe that when it comes to helping third countries, we should not provide assistance to those countries that violate human rights and to those that exploit information technology. This undermines democracy. We must prevent the misuse of information technology and prevent companies that are reselling it to third countries.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report shows the hypocrisy of the EU which, while promoting the full liberalisation of digital technology networks and the use of information and communication technologies in non-restricted third countries, in the light of human rights, some of its countries use these technologies to intercept and monitor officials and citizens of its Member States.  It is more of a wish list of how these technologies should be used instead of approaching the essence of the problem of their controlled use by countries, organisations, companies or individuals for the purpose of carrying out criminal acts.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "Building prosperity must increase the security of citizens. This goal is difficult to achieve in today's world without the development of modern techniques and technologies. However, care must be taken to ensure that they serve citizens and are not used against them. All action by the European Union and individual Member States, including in the framework of international cooperation with other countries of the world, should go in this direction.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Technology, particularly the new media, has two coins. It can be used as a tool for exercising the freedom of expression. However, it can also be used for violating human rights, particularly with regards to privacy and surveillance. With this current report, the Parliament aims to address the use of technology in human rights violations.  The position expressed in this report underlines that the surveillance of communications, if conducted outside an adequate legal framework, interferes with the rights to privacy and expression. The report requests coherence between the EU’s external actions and internal policies related to ICTs, in order to promote democratic oversight of security and intelligence services, and ensure European technologies do not contribute to human right violations in third countries.  Equally important, the report also notes the fact that security measures are increasingly used as pretext for violating the right to privacy and cracking on legitimate activities of human rights defenders, journalists and political activists.  I strongly believe that technology should serve the voice of the people, not act against them. As a prominent human rights defender the EU has the responsibility to ensure our technologies protect and promote human rights, not the other way around, particularly in third countries.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which tackles an important issue which is a growing concern: the human rights violations through technological systems. Technological developments play an important role in enabling the expression of fundamental freedoms such as access to information, freedom of assembly or right to privacy. However, these same technologies may be misused and result in censorship or surveillance. The report puts forward a list of recommendations for the EU to improve its standards as regards the use and export of ICT systems to third countries. In particular, the EU should better encrypt its communication, seek the extension of international protection for whistle-blowers, conduct a human right  impact assessment on its own ICT policies.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒The topic of this report is highly controversial – digital surveillance and its use as a tool to impose restrictions on third countries and violate the fundamental human rights and freedoms of their citizens. The report it it it is the only one and many amendments incorporated into it that are highly critical of EU companies and some Member States of the Union for their export of technology that can potentially be used for such purposes. I oppose the stigmatisation of EU companies operating in countries that have poor records in respecting human rights. I believe that it is not only important, but also crucial, in this segment to strike the right balance between respect for human rights and the real need to use digital surveillance in situations where it fights terrorism, extremist activities and crime. Despite the 176 amendments tabled, the balance was not successfully struck and instead of a balanced report, it was voted in a form that remains extremely critical of EU companies and european union member states. So I voted abstention.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the reports on human rights and technology in third countries because of the problematic parts of the resolution, which I cannot support in any way.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, which advocates the need to ensure human rights in the use and impact of new technologies. In today's times, security should not be a pretext for cutting freedom (including digital freedom). It is therefore essential to efficiently regulate ICT standards mainly with third countries that on numerous occasions systematically violate human rights

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The report highlights the role of technological advances and internet access in "the development and full respect for human rights and freedom of expression." It advocates communication encryption with "human rights defenders" and "whistleblowers." The report condemns non-targeted, secret or mass surveillance programmes by justifying this by the good intention of combating terrorism, which is absurd since at the same time the report encourages the use of encryption tools and circumvention of censorship. The rapporteur believes that any mass surveillance is contrary to human rights and calls on Member States to promote control of intelligence operations in third countries.  The report highlights the primacy of EU human rights standards. International companies on EU territory should therefore be excluded from EU procurement procedures, thus companies that sell dual-use technologies "potentially detrimental to fundamental rights and actively cooperate with regimes that do not respect human rights" which remains highly subjective. I therefore vote against this report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, which advocates the need to ensure human rights in the use and impact of new technologies. In today's times, security should not be a pretext for cutting freedom (including digital freedom). It is therefore essential to efficiently regulate ICT standards mainly with third countries that on numerous occasions systematically violate human rights.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report drafted by the ALDE colleague Marietje Schaake. The report tackles the sensitive issue of modern technologies for purposes that may violate individual citizens’ rights, such as personal data hacking and mass surveillance. While technology has greatly improved the lives of millions of people, in contexts where democracy is weak or in authoritarian regimes it may lead to intrusive practices comparable to human rights abuses. The report underlines the responsibility of the EU not to sell such types of technologies to Governments or companies that may use them for such distorted purposes. In short, the text calls for more transparency, more accountability and more licensing of what may be potentially dangerous technologies in the hands of oppressive regimes.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report discusses the impact of surveillance technologies on human rights in third countries. The report rightly deplores the fact that violations of the right to privacy are increasing in the name of security and the fight against terrorism, calls for an end to mass surveillance and denounces the use with impunity of technologies specifically designed to violate certain rights by governments. Parliament therefore asks the Commission to put forward proposals to determine how European standards can be used to prevent the harmful effects of exporting these technologies to third countries where the rule of law is not applied. Some legislative avenues are advanced, such as the inclusion of a digital freedom clause in agreements with third countries or the extension of international protection to whistleblowers. This report has the merit of opening the debate on the need for new European legislation in this area, going so far as to propose aggravated sanctions for companies that sell these products on the aware that they are harmful. I therefore voted in favour of this report, which is unfortunately non-legislative, which favours the rights of citizens and not those of business.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report considers that technological developments and unlimited access to the open Internet play an increasingly important role in enabling and ensuring the exercise and full respect of human rights and fundamental freedoms, having a positive effect by expanding the scope of freedom of expression, access to information and the right to privacy and freedom of assembly and association worldwide. It also considers that technological systems can be misused as tools for the violation of human rights through censorship, surveillance, unauthorised access to devices, obstruction, interception and tracing and the location of information and persons. However, it says nothing about the control of these means and the need for this control to be public, as the only way to be able to guarantee the universality of access and prevent such abuses.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. As the report on human rights and technology in third countries opposes both any illegal surveillance, in particular against mass surveillance, and the transfer of data, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. The social management of values and norms by the EU Parliament does not stop at universities either. "Gender stereotypes" is the contemporary key term for creating uncertainty and thus making it easier to manipulate people. By the way, the 'setting of new standards' is explicitly called for in paragraph 24. There will also be a new parliamentary prize: 'Women and Science in Europe'. I expressly invite all women scientists who prove the nonsense of gender mainstreaming to apply! I reject this nonsense, and that is why I voted against the report.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D)
text: Writing. I am very pleased that Mrs Schaake's report has been fully adopted and that we have achieved joint cooperation across group boundaries. The paper underlines our demand that privacy should remain privacy and that state surveillance measures should not restrict freedom of expression and thus a fundamental human right. It is now up to the Commission to strengthen democratic control of intelligence and security services in its dialogue with third countries. The European Parliament is clearly opposed to increasing violations which, under the guise of security and counter-terrorism measures, curtail the right to privacy and limit the scope of human rights organisations. The upholding of fundamental rights is a fundamental part of a successful counter-terrorism strategy. I am particularly pleased that we have been able to agree on the international protection of whistleblowers and that we want to recognise Internet access as a human right. That is why I voted with complete conviction in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This report deals with the relationship between respect for human rights and the development of digital surveillance technologies. It notes that third countries use such digital surveillance technologies to impose restrictions on their citizens, while violating their rights. At the same time, it expresses a critical position towards many companies established in the EU and member states involved in the export of such technologies, which can be used for surveillance. This can stigmatise companies operating in countries with bad reputations. An appropriate balance should therefore be maintained between the use of digital surveillance to combat terrorism, extremism and crime and respect for and respect for human rights. Unfortunately, this report does not have such an imbalance, and I therefore voted against it.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012I voted today in favour of the report on human rights and technology in third countries. I think it is important for the European Parliament to emphasise that the surveillance of communications, if carried out outside an appropriate legislative framework, is a violation of citizens' freedom of expression and arbitrary interference with their private lives. I find the text particularly appropriate where it calls on the Commission to ensure consistency between the Union's external actions and its internal ICT policies so that democratic control of the security and intelligence services in political dialogue with third countries is guaranteed and promoted.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, do you know who receives the most aid from the CAP in Spain? The Mora Figueroa family: 6 million euros of aid, paid by all taxpayers, destined for one of the largest fortunes in Andalusia. It is followed by a few other large fortunes, including 80% of the money that comes in.  Meanwhile, real farmers and ranchers have to over-strengthen in order to face an increasingly hostile market with the products of our land. That is why we have had to vote against this report, because, although it seems to us essential that aid is efficient, there is still one thing that concerns us most. We consider that it is not a receipt that does not focus on this aspect, which is probably one of the most serious surrounding the CAP: the distribution of aid.  Ladies and gentlemen, it is not possible for the richest to receive more public aid than anyone else. What world do we live in? A radical change of focus is needed on the CAP: to support the farmer who respects the times of the climate, produces wealth and who gives quality products. That is the only possible path and that is the future to which we must aspire.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – I voted in favour of this report because I consider it very important to prevent and detect fraud relating to eu area and other agricultural subsidies. The most obvious way to commit such fraud, and unfortunately, my own country is no exception to playing state-owned land into the hands of pals and pals. Either in the form of a season ticket or in the form of a sale, which is about to begin in Hungary. And with eu subsidies for these lands, these cronies, buddies, criminal gangs, so to speak, can easily get rich. The European Union has a very important task to prevent this. This is by insisting that all types of land lease applications or land ownership are made with the utmost publicity and the utmost transparency.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE).
text: – I agree with the reduction of red tape in the application of the common agricultural policy, especially with regard to the simplification of cumbersome and complex legislation governing greening, because this weight, difficulty and complexity of legislation practically prevents farmers from doing their job. Do you know how? The rules are like this: the simpler they are, the easier they are to apply and easier to verify and control. More transparency means more clarity. I therefore agree with the report's requests, namely to reduce red tape in order to reduce the error rate for the instruments to be established to distinguish between error and fraud. The distinction between error and fraud is very important because omissions, as a rule, do not cause damage to taxpayers, and there is also a need for a fair balance between a lower administrative burden for our farmers and effective financial control to ensure that the money is used correctly.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, I supported this report, as it aims to strike a balance between administrative burden and effective financial control of the implementation of the Common Agricultural Policy, which represents one of the most necessary and successful policies of the European Union. So far, this policy has had a positive impact on the lives of many Citizens of the European Union, on the quality of life in rural areas, on food production, but also on the protection of the environment and nature. If we want this to continue in the future, this policy needs to be simplified, the rules understandable and yet retain the necessary level of scrutiny. I believe that simplification must be more communicated with beneficiaries of the agricultural budget, in particular family farms, so that they can consistently comply with the rules for the reasons of their future, for the reasons of their future, their families, thereby reducing the cost of control, which now amounts to as much as €4 billion a year.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report proposes some necessary aspects, such as more effective and efficient controls through the simplification of audit controls, less bureaucracy and performance-based controls. It also differentiates between unintentional omissions and fraud cases. But, on the other hand, it suggests creating a list of Member States with good and bad practices and calls for Member States that achieve the best results in each area to be rewarded with a reduction in Union controls. By not sharing a proposal in this regard, I abstained from voting on this report.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on the vote of the report on the protection of the financial interests of the European Union: towards results-oriented controls for the common agricultural policy. This report calls for a simplification of the CAP and the administrative procedures of farmers. However, under the pretext of combating fraud, it intends to tighten the framework for the use of funds by the Commission, which already has a very authoritarian and cumbersome framework for the use of funds. While there is an urgent need to ease the administrative and legal burden on farmers, it is not desirable to strengthen the European Commission even further in the face of Member States' choices. On the contrary, Member States should have more freedom to carry out their agricultural policy as they wish.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The report discussed here calls for the simplification of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) and the administrative procedures of farmers, including by rewriting part of the current legislation. It also recommends limiting the number of controls on farms and proposes to stop penalizing farmers in case of unintentional error. These measures are, of course, a good thing.  However, reservations must be issued. Indeed, under the pretext of combating fraud, the report aims to strengthen, to the detriment of the Member States, the supervisory powers of the European Commission in the use of European funds allocated to farmers.   While there is an urgent need to ease the administrative and legal burden on farmers, it is not desirable to strengthen the European Commission in the face of Member States' choices. I have, therefore, chosen to abstain on this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The idea of performance-based controls is a positive one. However, I do not support the principle of the common agricultural policy itself. I therefore abstained.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to set up a performance-based control system for the common agricultural policy. According to the Court of Auditors, the arrangements for the use of the common agricultural policy for the period 2014-2020 remain difficult. I support the calls in the proposal for a less bureaucratic CAP in order to reduce the error rate and to introduce measures that make it possible to distinguish between errors and fraud. It is necessary to distinguish between unintentional inaction and fraud, as inaction usually does not cause financial harm to taxpayers. National authorities and farmers need to be given clearer advice in order to reduce the error rate.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Of course, our farmers must be relieved of the heavy administrative and fiscal burdens on their shoulders, but it is not up to the European Union, which has deprived them of Russian opportunities, to remedy this and I refuse to give further scope for the Commission. The National Front has always been committed to protecting the agricultural world, which is essential to our food independence and survival. France will have to abandon the CAP in the benefit of the PAF (French Agricultural Policy) allowing strategic development more precisely divided between small and large agricultural structures. This "nationalisation" of agricultural policy as part of a multi-year programming law implementing a long-term vision of our collective ambitions for French agriculture, will have as its main objective the stabilization of agricultural raw material prices, which will give farmers visibility in the medium term allowing them to make investment decisions. The policy will also aim to promote reasoned agriculture, balanced between techniques and respect for nature, mastering chemical inputs and innovations that have proven to be safe, planning soil improvements and optimizing the management of water resources and needs.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Like the entire group, I support the approach to CAP quality controls rather than an increase in controls.  This report, which I have approved, calls on the Commission to simplify the expenditure arrangements of the Common Agricultural Policy in view of the diversity of European agriculture and avoiding the dismantling of the instruments already in place. Considering that the simplification and rationalisation of the CAP plays a crucial role for the prosperity of the EU's agricultural sector in the future, the draft resolution presented in the report suggests in particular: - reducing administrative constraints on the CAP in order to reduce error rates; - the establishment of instruments to differentiate between error and fraud; - clarifying guidelines to national authorities and farmers; - improving the quality and content of inspections rather than the quantity of controls.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because in the new CAP, its implementation, in order to achieve its objectives, is very complex and costly, and has led to a large number of errors and great difficulties for beneficiaries and paying agencies. I therefore support the need to simplify the MECHANISM's implementation mechanisms to reduce fees and create clear instruments to distinguish between error and fraud. And, in accordance with the Court of Auditors' report, measures should be taken by States to strike an appropriate balance between lower administrative burden and effective control.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which contains the main elements of stimulus needed to discuss the new cap reform.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
