text: Written. I've abstained. The aim of the report is to simplify and make the EU's agricultural policy simplified and more effective, and to combat fraud and fraud. I am a strong supporter of combating fraud and fraud in the EU. However, I am also opposed to the EU's common agricultural policy, which is very expensive and also contributes to environmental degradation and deteriorating conditions for poor farmers in the global South. For these reasons, I choose to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which analyses how controls on the implementation of the common agricultural policy have been addressed and calls for greater simplification and less bureaucracy in it, so that it is more easily interpretable and applicable by farmers. The report calls for streamlining controls; not for nothing are its costs already rising to 4 billion euros per year. It is also fully in favour of improving the quality and coherence of inspections beyond increasing the number of controls in the agriculture sector by all Member States, the Commission and the Court of Auditors. It also emphasizes that it is the beneficiaries themselves who bear the consequences of the risk of involuntary errors due to the complexity of the regulation, and therefore recommends a reasonable, proportionate and effective sanctions policy that avoids, for example, the double penalty for the same error in both the payment system and conditionality and that payments are not interrupted when minor or administrative errors are detected.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on the report in which Parliament advocates the implementation of the protection of the European Union's financial interests and the establishment of a common agricultural policy control system (CAP). After two reforms of the common agricultural policy (CAP), the rules have become more diverse and complex, and more effective and more effective reform is needed to achieve the CAP objectives. Based control can be a useful methodology for addressing this issue, but administrative bodies need to be stable and have a feasibility-enabling approach to increase the trust of final beneficiaries. Parliament calls for a less bureaucratic CAP in order to reduce the error rate and to introduce measures that allow a distinction to be made between errors and fraud, while ensuring that farmers continue to be able to supply the vital food production that is at the heart of this policy. The Commission must encourage the exchange of best practices between States in order to ensure the smoothest possible controls and minimise disadvantages for farmers.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In July 2015, the European Parliament's Committee on Budgets discussed and adopted a report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests and, in particular, on strengthening performance-based control of the common agricultural policy. The operation of the system for monitoring the regularity of agricultural subsidies is becoming increasingly costly, as it has to audit nearly 40 million transactions a year. There is a need for quantification and simplification in this area. The report makes proposals, such as the introduction of control systems based on risk analysis and, inter alia, the elimination of parallel control processes. I supported the proposal in the plenary vote.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒Protecting the financial interests of the European Union is a key element of EU policy, strengthening citizens' trust in its institutions and trusting that citizens' money is spent properly. The Lisbon Treaty has contributed significantly to protecting the EU's financial interests, but what we must all work on together is to gain citizens' trust in how the EU institutions work to benefit them.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that a bureaucratic simplification of the common agricultural policy would bring a great many advantages, allowing a substantial reduction in error rates and, therefore, greater efficiency of the system.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The report recommends simplifying the use of the CAP and the administrative procedures of farmers. It recommends limiting the number of controls on farms and being more lenient with farmers who make unintentional mistakes. Despite these positive points, the text plans to strengthen the European Commission's framework for funds. While they should benefit from greater autonomy in the use of EU funds such as FEADER, Member States will be forced to co-finance projects imposed by the Commission. Of course, it is essential to reduce european bureaucracy and administrative constraints. On the other hand, we are opposed to strengthening the power of the Commission to the detriment of the Member States. That is why I abstained.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. the urgency of simplifying the basic rules is becoming the main reason why cap reform is already being discussed almost two years before the planned natural deadline.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the protection of the European Union's financial interests. It is essential to achieve a more effective and efficient reform of the common agricultural policy (CAP), which is more simplified and with less bureaucracy. In order to achieve this objective, it is necessary to reduce not only the number of controls, but also, and above all, the costs and administrative burdens placed on taxpayers and farmers.  It is clearly understood that a less bureaucratic CAP, which is easily applicable and interpretable, will make it possible to reduce error rates considerably and will therefore allow the development of instruments to distinguish between error and fraud. In addition, through the creation of digitisation programmes on the relationship between administrations and agricultural enterprises, a single farm file could be available for the integrated and synchronous management of crop data, and, by allowing farms to submit only one declaration, with greater efficiency than controls by the administrations themselves. Addressing the complexity of the CAP is the key to attracting new entry into agriculture, and so I decided to vote in favour of the text.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. This report was concerned with streamlining the rules in relation to CAP in order to ensure that its implementation is more efficient. It contained some very positive provisions such as support control throughout the value chain, from the producer, administrative stakeholders, paying agencies up to the institutions.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The idea of performance based controls is a positive one. However, I do not support the principle of the common agricultural policy itself. I therefore abstained.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ In order to prevent the growth of CAP budget, I agree with the need to strike a balance between less administrative burden and effective financial control. I therefore voted in favour of this report

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report presents minor issues, such as the proposal to reduce controls (at the root of high costs) for Member States that are pursuing the best results, but in general the text is very good.  It focuses on the demand for a less bureaucratic CAP in order to reduce costs and errors, and requires the development of instruments to distinguish between inadvertent error and fraud, since the former do not normally cause financial damage to the taxpayer. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote because the report in question calls for a simplification of the CAP and the administrative procedures of farmers, on the other hand, under the pretext of fighting fraud, it proposes to tighten the framework for the use of funds by the European Commission.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The report calls on the Commission to immediately make full use of the process of simplifying the Common Agricultural Policy, in particular with regard to aggravating and complex regulations governing cross-compliance and a proportionate dimension which ultimately affects farmers across Europe. We support the Commission's initiative to simplify the CAP through an immediate review of measures that can be implemented quickly, as this will bring benefits for farmers, paying agencies, EU institutions and taxpayers. We note that the cost of CAP controls amounts to EUR 4 billion per year and that it concerns 50 million operations with a budget for Georgia of around EUR 58 billion. So there is a need to strike a proper balance between less administrative and effective financial control.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the protection of the EU's financial interests with regard to the CAP. The common agricultural policy is a complex policy, because of its heterogeneity. It is therefore considered that more effective and efficient reform of the CAP requires its simplification and less bureaucracy in order to implement its objectives. In particular, the report calls for an improvement in the quality of agricultural controls carried out by the Member States, the Commission and the Court of Auditors, and reliable communication of data by The Member States so as to avoid double checks and achieve a simplification of the CAP.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because my colleague Petri Sarvamaa has rightly focused on finding the right financial control with regard to the CAP. One of my proposals is to try to put into practice a single control scheme with a single inspection chain: all in order to reduce the costs that have been too onerous in the past. I believe, as the rapporteur has said, that simplifying these controls is inevitable and necessary. Then, by analysing the results of the inspection checks carried out, thanks to the data obtained, it will be possible to identify those who do better or worse between Member States, between regions and between sectors, and thus the controls can be adopted accordingly where they are most needed. I believe that the proposed control rules are essential to ensure adequate levels of quality and to accompany all Member States in development, two things that I have always believed in and committed to.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the content of this important own-initiative report which I supported with my vote in favour. In the management of the CAP, the error rate is still too high, but errors must always be kept separate from cases of fraud, as well as red tape and the right balance must be struck between administrative simplification and effective financial control. I hope that the Commission will continue its efforts to improve the CAP and take initiatives in this direction.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report proposes some necessary aspects, such as more effective and efficient controls through the simplification of audit controls, less bureaucracy and performance-based controls. It also differentiates between unintentional omissions and fraud cases. But, on the other hand, it suggests creating a list of Member States with good and bad practices and calls for Member States that achieve the best results in each area to be rewarded with a reduction in Union controls. By not sharing a proposal in this regard, I abstained from voting on this report.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I am convinced that simplification and administrative burden reduction are needed in order for the common agricultural policy to be more effective and to achieve its objectives. It is not acceptable that control costs amount to around EUR 4 billion per year at Member State level, and it is even expected that these will probably even increase as a result of the latest cap reform. We need a less bureaucratic common agricultural policy with the right guarantees, thereby enabling a distinction between error and fraud.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the Common Agricultural Policy of the EU, which implements a system of agricultural subsidies and proposes innovative solutions in the arrangements for the spending of CAP, as at present these are too complex for the managing authorities and for the beneficiaries, especially in the new framework for cross compliance. The two new approaches put forward are: a single audit scheme with only one chain of audits from the final beneficiaries to the European Union institutions, and the setting up of a flexible organisation of checks promoting performance—based controls of Common Agricultural Policy. I agree with this approach and I voted in favour of the report.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the common agricultural policy must be less bureaucratic, in order to reduce the error rate and to establish new instruments, making it possible to distinguish errors in cases of fraud. I welcome the Commission's decision to extend the deadline for direct payment requests by one month, and I believe that this is a step forward in reducing the error rate in the CAP.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. In order to cope with the rising cost of monitoring activities in the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) budget, this initiative report calls on Member States to provide their data on national checks carried out in order to avoid duplication at European level. Building on the new role of the certification agency, this report proposes a simplification of the Community audit system. It also calls for the introduction of a risk assessment system to identify Member States and regions with below-average results and to adapt controls accordingly. Nevertheless, I would like to express my reservations about paragraph 6 of this initiative report which calls on the European Commission to initiate a process of simplification of the CAP by revising the basic acts. I believe that the negotiation of the reform of the CAP has been sufficiently difficult, so it is not appropriate to reopen the basic acts, but the Commission must concentrate on implementation actions. Considering, however, that this report is in the direction of a better application of the CAP budget and a reduction in the administrative millefeuille between the European and national levels, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text. Controls on CAP (Common Agricultural Policy) transactions are necessary to ensure that funding is transparent. Europe with the help of Member States must find better coordination to make controls more effective and less costly.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In July 2015, the European Parliament's Committee on Budgets discussed and adopted a report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests and, in particular, on strengthening performance-based control of the common agricultural policy. The operation of the system for monitoring the regularity of agricultural subsidies is becoming increasingly costly, as it has to audit nearly 40 million transactions a year. There is a need for rationalisation and simplification in this area. The report makes proposals, such as the introduction of control systems based on risk analysis and, inter alia, the elimination of parallel control processes. I supported the proposal of the Finnish edps in the plenary vote.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – In July 2015, the European Parliament's Committee on Budgets discussed and adopted a report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests and, in particular, on strengthening performance-based control of the common agricultural policy. The operation of the system for monitoring the regularity of agricultural subsidies is becoming increasingly costly, as it has to audit nearly 40 million transactions a year. There is a need for quantification and simplification in this area. The report makes proposals, such as the introduction of control systems based on risk analysis and, inter alia, the elimination of parallel control processes. I supported the proposal of the Finnish edps in both the commission vote and the plenary vote.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The fight against European aid fraud and embezzlement of European funds is an essential and indispensable mission for the proper management of money provided by Member States but paid by taxpayers. However, it is clear that this report also seeks and above all to strengthen the powers of the European Commission and to toughen its tools. The Commission's total control over CAP funds and its administrative architecture is a drift towards the centralisation of power around the Union's institutions which I cannot accept, which is why I abstained.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We disagree in principle with the common agricultural policy as we believe that it limits the independence and self-sufficiency of the Member States in order to put them at an unfavourable position with regard to the Union, creating a relationship of dependency. We consider that the CAP has nothing to do with the Union's theory, but also that it is the tombstone of traditional agricultural production. The so-called simplification is intended to cement an already failed policy that in countries such as Greece and Cyprus has annihilated primary production.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the direction of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of the Sarvamaa report. In my opinion, the distinction between intentional misuse and the concept of error in controlling the use of aid should be made clear. In the latter category, serious penalties should not be imposed on farmers.  On the other hand, there will be fewer errors if the European Commission significantly reduces the financial and administrative burden on farmers. I am pleased that my proposal on this has been incorporated into the report.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of this resolution because it calls for a less bureaucratic CAP that can be clearly applied and interpreted with a view to reducing error rates and developing tools to distinguish between error and fraud, while ensuring that farmers continue to be able to produce essential food, which is at the heart of the strategy; I believe that continuing to address the complexity and rationalise the CAP are key elements in attracting new entry into agriculture, holding them back with their competences, in order to ensure a healthy EU agricultural sector in the future; I support the Commission's initiative to simplify the CAP with the immediate examination of measures that can be implemented quickly, as this would benefit farmers, paying agencies, EU institutions and taxpayers; finally, the resolution suggests that, during the mid-term review, proposals for amendments to the basic legislative act should be submitted for reform for the next funding period.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the two phases of the reform of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP), the rules have become more diverse and complex, leading to more errors on the ground.  Given that the objectives of the CAP need to be met and that mutual understanding and trust between all EU institutions and national and regional bodies must be ensured for their effective implementation, more effective and efficient CAP reform requires simplification and less bureaucracy to achieve their objectives. Expenditure on controls and the provision of advice to stakeholders and farmers is currently analysing TO EUR 4 billion per year at Member State level and is likely to increase.  I believe and agree that a less bureaucratic CAP is needed to reduce the error rate and to create instruments to distinguish between error and fraud.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report because it is in the direction of strengthening the power of the European Commission.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The major reform of the common agricultural policy has brought a number of changes for farmers. However, simplification and a lower degree of democracy remain the main objective in meeting the objectives of the CAP. The error rate for collecting the data required from farmers included in their applications remains problematic. The European Union must be able to control the results of the CAP, given how much money it spends on this policy. Europe needs a less bureaucratic CAP and the creation of instruments that will enable controls to detect and distinguish between error and fraud in various applications. It is clear from the experience of the last 2 years that we must constantly work to simplify the application systems and application forms for farmers and to encourage the development of eGovernment, thus gradually eliminating the errors committed by farmers.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the measure which aims to fill the gap in the non-simplification of the CAP.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I recognise the need to deburracrate the common agricultural policy and to spend funds directly related to the work of farmers, not officials.  At the time of the adoption of the reform package in the Polish Parliament, I expressed reservations about many of the proposed mechanisms, pointing out that the planned reform could also have a negative impact on beneficiaries, especially Polish farmers. However, the CAP reform package was adopted in breach of the scrutiny procedure of the competent committee of the Polish Sejm, which was delayed in preventing a fair impact on the legislative process. Today it is criticized, and one of the proposed drugs is to be checks based on the results. In the proposed amendments, I am concerned about the vagueness of the concept of a result management system in all areas of the common agricultural policy. There is no guarantee that, with diversified agriculture in the Member States, it will be a fair method. I also believe that increasing the role of implementing acts, especially delegated acts, does not contribute to increasing transparency and de-bureaucratic functioning of the common agricultural policy. That is why I abstained.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. – I disagree in principle with the common agricultural policy because I believe that it limits the independence and self-sufficiency of the Member States and aims to put them at an unfavourable position with regard to the Union by creating a relationship of dependency. I believe that the CAP has nothing to do with the - in theory - objectives of the Union and I also believe that it is the tombstone of traditional agricultural production. The so-called simplification is intended to cement an already failed policy that, in countries such as Greece and Cyprus, has annihilated primary production.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the Commission’s initiative of simplifying the CAP through measures which can be implemented quickly, as well as the reinforcement and stronger implementation of the single audit through the coordination of the control activities carried out by the various institutions. The complexity of the CAP is due to the diversity of farming in Europe; therefore, simplification must not result in a dismantling of the instruments that have been adopted. The CAP must become less bureaucratic, with efficient instruments to distinguish between error and fraud. I welcome the adoption of this report, which represents a step ahead towards the fulfilment of the CAP’s objectives and its effective implementation. It will ensure more mutual understanding and trust between the EU institutions and national and regional bodies.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In July 2015, the European Parliament's Committee on Budgets discussed and adopted a report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests and, in particular, on strengthening performance-based control of the common agricultural policy. The operation of the system for monitoring the regularity of agricultural subsidies is becoming increasingly costly, as it has to audit nearly 40 million transactions a year. There is a need for quantification and simplification in this area. The report makes proposals, such as the introduction of control systems based on risk analysis and, inter alia, the elimination of parallel control processes. I supported the proposal of the Finnish reporter from the People's Party.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 After two rounds of common agricultural policy (CAP) reforms, the rules have become more diverse and complex and make more mistakes due to more complex rules, and the objectives of the CAP must be met, while ensuring mutual understanding and trust between all EU institutions, national and regional bodies, in order to ensure the effective implementation of the CAP. I believe that a more effective and effective reform of the CAP requires simplification and reduction of administrative burdens in order to achieve the objectives of the CAP. Taking into account users' point of view, it is important not to be hit by a disproportionate number of tests. I also call for a less bureaucratic CAP with a view to reducing the error rate and introducing tools to make it possible to make a distinction between error and fraud. I welcome the proposal that when the findings of audits are used and possible penalties are imposed, a distinction should be made between unintentional omissions and fraud, as failures do not normally cause any financial harm to taxpayers. Against this background, I call for a less bureaucratic CAP, which can be clearly implemented and understood with a view to reducing the error rate and introducing tools to enable a distinction between error and fraud, while ensuring that farmers remain able to produce essential food, which is at the heart of the policy.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. In the first place, I would like to draw attention to the good news that came to us yesterday from the Commission, in accordance with the adoption of an emergency package of EUR 500 million for European agriculture. We must help our farmers to live on their crops, their activity. It's nothing else they ask of us. Mr Sarvamaa's report goes in this direction, which I would like to stress the need for bureaucratic simplification in agriculture, and in particular that adaptation to greening does not have to be covered by European farmers. That is why I voted in favour of the report on the protection of the Financial Interests of the European Union: towards the organisation of results-based controls in the common agricultural policy.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on the protection of the European Union's financial interests, towards results-based controls in relation to the common agricultural policy. I believe it is essential to simplify and reduce the administrative burden of the common agricultural policy, given that the European Court of Auditors itself has stressed that greater complexity does not correspond to better controls and a reduction in fraud. I therefore agree with the call for a less bureaucratic CAP, which makes it possible to distinguish between voluntary omissions, which do not result in losses for taxpayers and real fraud. There is also a desire to focus on the quality of controls rather than the quantity of controls, and the request to the Commission to study and present innovative audit methods that avoid a repetition of multiple controls on the economic operator itself at different times of the year. The idea of a single audit mechanism can be a acceptable solution to relieve European farmers of excessive bureaucracy. The call for greater digitisation of procedures and, in general, greater use of information technology within the CAP is also a good one. In this respect, investing in broadband in rural areas, especially disadvantaged areas, is a fundamental requirement.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the 'Report on the Protection of the European Union's Financial Interests: Towards Performance-Based Controls of the Common Agricultural Policy', as I welcome any reform of the EU's budgetary mechanisms that helps to deal responsibly with taxpayers' money.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The report I drafted in the Committee on Agriculture and Agriculture was adopted by a large majority in plenary. In recent years, more and more rules have been added to EU agricultural policy without reducing existing bureaucracy. That needs to change.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which advocates improving auditing processes by implementing quality controls rather than quantitative ones in order to reduce unnecessary administrative burden and ensure funding is used in the best possible way. I support measures to simplify the CAP and providing clearer guidance to both national authorities and farmers in to reduce error rates.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Agriculture remains one of the main topics affecting Spain today. Farmers are surviving in a sector which faces many struggles where high production costs and low prices challenge their livelihoods. I believe that it is in the interest of all to find ways of easing the administration burden on farmers in Common Agricultural Policy policies. Therefore, this report had my support today.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report because although the lack of effectiveness or diversion of funds is something to be taken into account, they are not the main problems of the CAP, but are others to which this report does not provide solutions. Most CAP aid often ends up in the hands of landowners and large agri-food companies, which is detrimental to small and medium-sized producers, who face constant economic difficulties and lack the same administrative structures to access CAP aid. The current one is a deeply anti-redistributive model that contributes to the creation of inefficient oligopolies and harms the equal opportunity system. That is why we strongly support the allocation of resources aimed at favouring small and medium-sized producers in favour of increasing a more efficient productive model, and especially towards investments for territorial development. Increase redistributed criteria to prevent funds from ending up in the hands of those who do not need them, and thus not harm those who contribute to social and rural development in an efficient and ecological manner.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which advocates improving auditing processes by implementing quality controls rather than quantitative ones in order to reduce unnecessary administrative burden and ensure funding is used in the best possible way. I support measures to simplify the CAP and providing clearer guidance to both national authorities and farmers in to reduce error rates.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the resolution on the Common Agricultural Policy. I strongly believe that the simplification of the common agricultural policy is a way to reduce the number of controls. Not only it would be is easier to implement rules, but also for the farmers it would be simpler to follow them. Not to mention, the monitoring would be improved hence making the whole common EU agricultural policy more accountable to the taxpayers. Furthermore, clearer guidance should be given to both national authorities and farmers in order to reduce the error rate and in that way the CAP would be more effective.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In July 2015, the European Parliament's Committee on Budgets discussed and adopted a report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests and, in particular, on strengthening performance-based control of the common agricultural policy. The operation of the system for monitoring the regularity of agricultural subsidies is becoming increasingly costly, as it has to audit nearly 40 million transactions a year. There is a need for rationalisation and simplification in this area. The report makes proposals, such as the introduction of control systems based on risk analysis and, inter alia, the elimination of parallel control processes. I supported the proposal of the Finnish edps in both the commission vote and the plenary vote.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe we need proper oversight in Parliament of how one of the biggest sections of the EU budget – the common agricultural policy – is implemented. This report proposes some necessary measures which will help to develop an appropriate framework for the CAP in the years to come.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report because although the lack of effectiveness or diversion of funds is something to be taken into account, they are not the main problems of the CAP, but are others to which this report does not provide solutions. Most CAP aid often ends up in the hands of landowners and large agri-food companies, which is detrimental to small and medium-sized producers, who face constant economic difficulties and lack the same administrative structures to access CAP aid. The current one is a deeply anti-redistributive model that contributes to the creation of inefficient oligopolies and harms the equal opportunity system. That is why we strongly support the allocation of resources aimed at favouring small and medium-sized producers in favour of increasing a more efficient productive model, and especially towards investments for territorial development. Increase redistributed criteria to prevent funds from ending up in the hands of those who do not need them, and thus not harm those who contribute to social and rural development in an efficient and ecological manner.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. In favour of a less bureaucratic common agricultural policy, which provides better defined benefits and is more controllable by the relevant bodies.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE)
text: Writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for his very good report, which can make an important contribution to a much-needed de-bureaucratisation of the common agricultural policy. The provisions of the CAP have become much more diverse and complex with the latest reform, despite the Commission's announcements to the contrary. The increasing complexity of controls has not only led to increasing error rates, but also to rising costs. Every year, EUR 4 billion is spent solely on controls on the use of agricultural funds. The legitimate question is whether taxpayers' money is used responsibly and efficiently. In order for our farmers to have to spend less time at their desks and to return to their main task, a significant simplification of the control system is essential. There is an urgent need to reduce the number of on-the-spot checks. More performance-based controls can relieve the burden on farmers who have performed well. In addition, it is important to ensure that a distinction is made between clear fraud and unintentional errors when sanctioning errors. It is unacceptable that a farmer who inadvertently places a cross in the wrong place in an application without causing economic damage should be sanctioned in the same way as a deliberate fraudster.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution to protect the financial interests of the European Union: to meet performance-based controls on the Common Agricultural Policy, as the Common Agricultural Policy needs significant and effective changes to ensure its efficiency, consistency and full transparency.  First of all, it is necessary to provide less red tape and address the complexity of the CAP and to perfect the control system. In this context, a more efficient and consistent control system and inspections ensure the proper use of CAP funding. However, that system must also take into account a reasonable policy of sanctioning, a comprehensive approach, which should be based on the principles of cost-effectiveness and reliability.  I believe that in order to improve cap controls further for the diversity and importance of the European agricultural sector, I believe that exchanges of best practices and the use of new technologies that can certainly help simplify bureaucratic procedures are essential.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The report discussed here calls for the simplification of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) and the administrative procedures of farmers, including by rewriting part of the current legislation. It also recommends limiting the number of controls on farms and proposes to stop penalizing farmers in case of unintentional error. These measures are moving in the right direction. Nevertheless, reservations must be issued; Indeed, under the pretext of combating fraud, the report aims to strengthen, to the detriment of the Member States, the supervisory powers of the European Commission in the use of European funds allocated to farmers.  While there is an urgent need to ease the administrative and legal burden on farmers, it is not desirable to further strengthen the European Commission in the face of Member States' choices. I have, therefore, chosen to abstain on this report.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Petri Sarvamaa's report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests in relation to the common agricultural policy. For the CAP as for cohesion policy, I believe that the right balance must be struck between reducing administrative burdens and effective controls, which means simplifying the system. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which proposes to reduce administrative burdens for our farmers in exchange for better financial control.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The report acknowledges that many errors in current agricultural support are due to the complexity of the system. This is a fact that often makes it difficult to distinguish between mistakes and fraud, and thus risks targeting farmers through no fault of their own. The report avoids putting farmers under general suspicion, stresses the importance of agriculture for Europe's economic well-being, but also points out that controls are important to avoid fraud, simplification is needed so that farmers do not inadvertently make mistakes and best practices are exchanged in the allocation, handling and verification of subsidies. I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour of this proposal. The report stresses the need to strike the right balance between fewer administrative burdens and effective financial control for farmers. We are calling for a less bureaucratic CAP, which can be clearly applied and interpreted with a view to reducing error rates and developing instruments that make it possible to distinguish between error and fraud, making it possible to punish those who commit offences, while at the same time avoiding hindering the activity of those who work in compliance with the rules.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests calls for a simplification of the CAP and the administrative procedures of farmers, in particular by stopping penalising farmers in case of unintentional error.  On the other hand, this report aims to tighten the framework for the use of funds, under the guise of combating tax evasion.  Similarly, the management of FEADER funds is largely locked down by the Commission, as are the projects that the Commission imposes through the Rural Development Plans.  While I want to ease the administrative and legal burden on farmers, I do not think the Commission is in the best position to do so. So I abstained.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text. Certainly, it has the merit of reducing the administrative and legal burden of the CAP on farmers. But it has the disadvantage of further strengthening the powers of the Brussels Commission on agriculture. However, it is the policy of this Commission that is killing French agriculture.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which advocates improving auditing processes by implementing quality controls rather than quantitative ones in order to reduce unnecessary administrative burden and ensure funding is used in the best possible way. I support measures to simplify the CAP and providing clearer guidance to both national authorities and farmers in to reduce error rates.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In July 2015, the European Parliament's Committee on Budgets discussed and adopted a report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests and, in particular, on strengthening performance-based control of the common agricultural policy. The operation of the system for monitoring the regularity of agricultural subsidies is becoming increasingly costly, as it has to audit nearly 40 million transactions a year. There is a need for quantification and simplification in this area. The report makes proposals, such as the introduction of control systems based on risk analysis and, inter alia, the elimination of parallel control processes. I supported the proposal of the Finnish edps in both the commission vote and the plenary vote.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The protection of the EU's financial interest is, beyond any doubt, an extremely important economic, financial and political issue. After all, we have the financial resources from the public – the taxpayers of the Member States. This appropriation is intended to cover the achievement of specific objectives intended to benefit the Union and the beneficiary countries by correctly targeting direct beneficiaries. The rapporteur has fully shown the importance of the issue, which is particularly important, following the efficiency criterion when assessing the reasonableness of the use of funds. The importance of this report is further reinforced by the fact that there is a very high expenditure on agriculture in the Community budget. As a member of the Committee on Budgetary Control, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report proposes some necessary aspects as more effective and efficient controls through the simplification of audit controls, less bureaucracy and performance-based controls. It also differentiates between unintentional omissions and fraud cases. But on the other hand it suggests creating a list of Member States with good and bad practice and calls for Member States that achieve the best results in each area to be rewarded with a reduction in Union controls. By not sharing a proposal in this regard, I abstained from voting on this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) has undergone two cycles of reforms which have led to the increasingly varied and complex rules governing this area. Consequently, the accumulation of these more complex rules results in a greater number of errors caused by excessive complexity and bureaucracy. It is important to ensure that our CAP is organized in the best possible way, ensuring its functionality both at national and supranational level, that there is effective access to it by the actors involved and that the correct use of available resources is ensured. This report aims to address these issues by prioritizing the need to simplify the functioning and bureaucracy of cap without harming or restricting existing instruments. It therefore considers it right to vote favourably.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on this report. I appreciated the criticism of the common agricultural policy and the call for simplification of its rules, but I could not support the calls and requests directed at the Member States (Sections 39-41 and others).

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The last reform of the Common Agricultural Policy in 2013 has led to an even greater complexity of rules and administrative burdens that are a major burden on European farmers and the development of the agricultural sector in the European Union. The ECA found this. It stressed that the costs of consulting interested farmers and other stakeholders and the cost of controlling payments within the Common Agricultural Policy reach a total of €4 billion.  As the annual budget of the Common Agricultural Policy is around €50 billion, €4 billion in costs is a major burden on the budget of the Common Agricultural Policy and thus on the Budget of the European Union. Furthermore, the Court found that the new multiple compliance framework under the Common Agricultural Policy did not lead to a reduction in unnecessary administrative complexity for farmers, which can lead to an increased number of errors, but also fraud in the Common Agricultural Policy.   I supported this report, which calls for a balance between reducing administrative burdens for farmers and controlling costs more efficiently in the Common Agricultural Policy and improving the first level of controls to achieve a minimum burden for farmers. We encourage the European Commission to adopt concrete measures aimed at reducing administrative costs for farmers and protecting the financial interests of the European Union.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour together with my political group with all our amendments.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on "Protecting the European Union's financial interests: introducing performance-based controls within the framework of the common agricultural policy", for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 7/9/2015, and because this report promotes the creation of a two-speed Europe in the agricultural sector by separating the Member States of the European Union, in terms of the management of EU resources, into supposedly good and not.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text. This report makes some very good points: it calls for a simplification of the CAP and a reduction in administrative procedures, both of which we fully support. On the other hand, and that is why we are not in favour of this text, it also suggests tightening the framework for the Commission's use of funds, which is already very demanding and detrimental to the Member States.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report, which supports the Commission’s initiative of simplifying the CAP with immediate examination of measures which can be implemented quickly, as this would benefit farmers, paying agencies, EU institutions and taxpayers; urges also that at the mid-term review, proposals for amendments to the basic legislative act be brought forward for consideration for the reform for the next funding period.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The common agricultural policy has developed a clear regulatory complexity over the last two rounds of reforms. Effective implementation of the CAP should go hand in hand with the removal of persistent bureaucratic obstacles. It is on this basis that I have decided to support Mr Sarvamaa's report, which calls for a fair balance between administrative burdens and financial control.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. My vote in favour of the report discussed in this plenary on the organisation of results-based controls in the Common Agricultural Policy. Increasingly, the rules governing this area are more complex and make mistakes easier. That is why measures must be taken to ensure effective and fair controls, without overloading producers. That is why I am in favour of the Commission's initiative to simplify the CAP by immediately considering measures that can be implemented promptly, while working on a simplification of the CAP, all to ensure that the most efficient use of European funds is made.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report recognises that many errors in current agricultural support are due to the complexity of the system, making it difficult to distinguish between errors and fraud. It avoids putting farmers under general suspicion, stresses the importance of agriculture for Europe's economic well-being, but also points out that controls are important to avoid fraud, simplification is needed so that farmers do not inadvertently make mistakes and best practices are exchanged in the allocation, handling and verification of subsidies. I therefore support this motion.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the importance of cooperation between stakeholders to make CAP controls more efficient, less costly and less bureaucratic.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This text aims to "simplify" the CAP and the controls put in place by the EU.  In fact, it is a question of reducing the number of errors and thus the costs of these controls (4 billion euros out of 58 billion euros for the agricultural budget).  The text recalls that "the expenditure arrangements of the Common Agricultural Policy remain complex"; while ensuring that "simplification must not lead to the dismantling of the instruments in place."  The text proposes "an increase in the quality and content of inspections." And invites us to distinguish between involuntary negligence and fraud. I abstain on this text by stressing that it does not address the main problems posed by the CAP implemented, namely the lack of support for peasant and ecological agriculture.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The report discussed here calls for the simplification of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) and the administrative procedures of farmers, including by rewriting part of the current legislation. It also recommends limiting the number of controls on farms and proposes to stop penalizing farmers in case of unintentional error. These measures are moving in the right direction. However, reservations must be issued. Indeed, under the pretext of combating fraud, the report aims to strengthen, to the detriment of the Member States, the supervisory powers of the European Commission in the use of European funds allocated to farmers.  While there is an urgent need to ease the administrative and legal burden on farmers, it is not desirable to further strengthen the European Commission in the face of Member States' choices. Therefore, I abstained.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the two phases of the reform of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP), the rules have become more diverse and complex.  More complex rules lead to more errors on the ground. A less bureaucratic CAP is needed to reduce the error rate and the creation of instruments to distinguish between error and fraud. This is the only way to effectively safeguard the EU's financial interests. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it calls for a balance between efficiency and accountability. Certain regulations have become overcomplicated and inefficient, and this report’s objective is to develop a single audit scheme that simplifies controls.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. To date, the administrative burden on farmers receiving CAP contributions is far too heavy. It is time to reduce this to allow them to concentrate their field activities. It is a question of finding a good balance between reduced administrative burden and effective financial control. There is a need for clearer guidelines for both Member States and farmers in order to reduce the error rate and to be able to distinguish between what is a mistake and what could be considered fraud. These are essential initiatives to attract young farmers again and ensure the sustainability of the agricultural sector in the EU.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the performance-based controls of the Common Agricultural policy, which is essential for protecting the EU’s financial interests.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report notes that after two rounds of CAP reforms, the rules have become more diverse and complex, causing them to make more mistakes locally. Calls, therefore, for a less bureaucratic CAP with a view to reducing the error rate and introducing tools to make a distinction between error and fraud; urges, furthermore, that national authorities and farmers be given clearer guidance in order to reduce the error rate.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report, under the pretext of combating fraud, tightens the framework for the use of funds by the Commission, which already strictly regulates their use (whether through the counting of hectares, the control of aid to producer organisations or the application of the nitrate directive, for example). Similarly, the management of Feader funds is largely locked down by the European Commission, whereas it should be the sole responsibility of the Member States, which are obliged to co-finance the projects imposed by the Commission via the Rural Development Plans. On the contrary, Member States should have more freedom to carry out their agricultural policy as they wish.  This report increases the administrative burden for farmers while strengthening the Commission's ability to deal with Member States.  It is therefore preferable to abstain.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The reform of the Common Agricultural Policy has made the rules more diverse and complex, resulting in more errors on the ground and increased administrative burdens.  I advocate greater simplification and less bureaucracy for the Common Agricultural Policy, which is an effective and efficient approach.  I believe that the objectives of the CAP need to be met and that mutual understanding and trust between all EU institutions and national and regional bodies must be ensured for their effective implementation. I believe it is essential to reduce the complexity of the systems and forms for submitting applications by farmers. I stress the importance of sharing experience between the best and worst performing Member States, as well as the communication between national and regional authorities and their joint work in an articulated and efficient manner for the good of farmers implementing the policy on the ground. I agree with the rapporteur on the stronger implementation of a single audit by coordinating the control activities carried out by the different institutions, so that farmers are not, in the same year, subject to different visits on different occasions by the competent bodies.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the protection of the financial interests of the European Union calls for a simplification of the CAP and the administrative procedures of farmers, in particular by stopping penalising farmers in case of unintentional error. On the other hand, this report aims to tighten the framework for the use of funds, under the guise of combating tax evasion. Similarly, the management of FEADER funds is largely locked down by the Commission, as are the projects that the Commission imposes through the Rural Development Plans. While I want to ease the administrative and legal burden on farmers, I do not think the Commission is in the best position to do so. So I abstained.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which advocates improving auditing processes by implementing quality controls rather than quantitative ones in order to reduce unnecessary administrative burden and ensure funding is used in the best possible way. I support measures to simplify the CAP and providing clearer guidance to both national authorities and farmers in to reduce error rates.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on results-based controls for the Common Agricultural Policy. This text, which calls for a simplification of the system and a better chain of checks, aims to protect the financial interests of the European Union by finding the right balance between reducing the administrative burden and effective financial control.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the current Eurosceptic public mood, it is crucial for citizens to see that EU funds are spent for sensible purposes and spent correctly and judiciously. The common agricultural policy is a particularly sensitive area. It is important to examine the use of money, but the investigation mechanism itself involves too much cost and work, so it is high time to reform it. It is time for simplification and rationalisation.  I therefore welcome the report.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that calls for further simplification and a reduced number of controls that will cut error rates and improve efficiency, reduce the cost and administrative burden borne by taxpayers and farmers and ensure that the budget will be well spent.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report in support of one of the most necessary common policies of the European Union, namely the common agrarian policy. As, in recent years, as a result of several reforms, the common agrarian policy has turned into an extremely complex and bureaucratic instrument, there have been a number of debates in which it has been shown that the work of European farmers is hampered and the number of errors on the ground has increased. In order to respond to these referrals and to continue with the objectives originally imposed, the report voted on today is beneficial.  The document proposes to reduce the administrative burden and ensure a lean, qualitative and well-structured financial control, rather than multiplying the number of checks. Simplification and rationalisation of the CAP are essential points for involving as many people as possible in the field of agriculture, for their preservation and professionalisation, with the ultimate aim of ensuring quality and affordable agricultural products at Member State level.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. – This report clearly states that many errors in current agricultural support are due to the complexity of the system. Furthermore, it is becoming increasingly difficult to distinguish between errors and fraud. Agriculture is very important for Europe's economic well-being. Another important area is the implementation of controls in order to avoid fraud. Simplification of bureaucracy is also important, so that farmers do not make mistakes unintentionally. On the basis of these demands, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which rightly proposes clarification and simplification of many measures relating to the implementation and control of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP). These measures aim in particular to aim towards a more qualitative than quantitative application of administrative procedures arising from the CAP, with also an improvement of the controls carried out by the institutions, in order to combat fraud and abuse.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported it because it calls for the complex rules of the common agricultural policy to be simplified and clarified.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I support the report tabled. In particular, the performance-based control system of the common agricultural policy must adequately ensure the interests of farmers. Simplification and less bureaucracy are needed to achieve the CAP's objectives in the context of the latest CAP reform. I believe that the Commission should use the process of simplifying the CAP as soon as possible to remove the existing onerous and complex rules. A less bureaucratic CAP will help to reduce the error rate and ensure its more effective implementation. It is therefore necessary to lay down measures enabling errors to be distinguished from fraud. The quality and consistency of inspections need to be improved, not increased. It should be noted that the measures envisaged must be implemented swiftly. They must benefit farmers, paying agencies, EU institutions and taxpayers.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to bring Europe closer to its citizens, I decided to vote in favour of simplifying the procedures provided for in the CAP, including the EU's monitoring and control activities with regard to beneficiaries in order to facilitate their implementation.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the report, which emphasises the need to strike a balance between the administrative burden and effective financial control of farms. There is a need to simplify and reduce the bureaucracy that farmers are dealing with as a result of many changes to the new common agricultural policy. A less bureaucratic policy, which can be clearly implemented and interpreted, is also important for attracting people to the agricultural sector and for preserving farmers and their knowledge and skills, so that we can ensure a successful agricultural sector in the future.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests wants to simplify the CAP and the administrative procedures of farmers but also recommends that farmers should no longer be penalised in case of unintentional error.  On the other hand, by deciding to fight fraud, this report seeks to tighten the framework for the Commission's use of funds. Similarly, the management of FEADER funds is largely locked down by the Commission, as are the projects that the Commission imposes through the Rural Development Plans.  Although I wish to reduce the administrative and legal burden on farmers, I do not think it is necessary to give the Commission more powers over the States, so I abstained.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒In order to protect the financial interests of the European Union, it is necessary to establish a common agricultural policy with less red tape that can be clearly implemented and interpreted with a view to reducing the level of error and establishing instruments to allow for a distinction between error and fraud, while ensuring that farmers can continue to engage in the vital food production at the heart of this policy.  Continuing to address the complexity of the CAP and channelling it is one of the key elements for attracting and retaining new farmers and their skills in order to ensure a thriving Union agricultural sector in the future, and strong actions from better regulation programmes are expected in this regard. Therefore, I support the rapporteur's proposal to seek less cap red tape to reduce the level of error and to introduce instruments to distinguish between error and fraud. Performance-based controls can become a useful methodology and administrative authorities need to provide stability and take an empowering approach to build trust with end-users, which should, after all, be one of the main objectives of all European institutions.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - In recent years, several reforms of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) have been implemented, increasing the complexity of the procedures itself, both for farmers and competent authorities. Increasingly complex rules lead to an increase in errors on the ground. About €4 billion is allocated annually to farmer transaction checks and other accompanying checks.  I believe that the level of error should be reduced to a minimum level, and I also share the OPINION of the ECA that payment mechanisms within the Common Agricultural Policy for the period 2014-2020 remain very complex. Cap red tape needs to be simplified to reduce the level of error, but also to attract and retain new, young farmers who will contribute to the performance of the European Union's agricultural sector.  The problem of depopulation of rural areas is a pronounced problem in a large number of EU Member States, including in the Republic of Croatia. Simplifying the CAP is a necessary step towards solving this problem, so I support colleague Sarvamaaa's report.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report with the aim of improving the efficiency of the CAP, avoiding the waste of valuable economic resources. The report stresses the need to strike the right balance between less administrative burden and effective financial control. The report presented to the House calls for reliable first-level controls and reliable communication of data by Member States in order to avoid double checks and achieve administrative simplification.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) is one of the historical and economic pillars of the Union. It is a very broad policy that encompasses a wide range of activities and includes a complex system of aid. It is important to exercise targeted control over this policy and the results achieved in order to measure the extent of its impact. The European Parliament has adopted a text on the protection of the UNION's financial interests and calling for tighter controls on the results of the CAP. I voted in favour of this report and I stress the need to strike the right balance between reducing the administrative burden and effective financial control. The control system needs to be simplified without losing efficiency.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. – (PT) I voted in favour, because I think it is essential that there is strict financial control of the performance of the CAP.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. Angry European farmers have reminded us in recent days of the precarious situation in which prices in the sector have fallen. Direct payments from the Common Agricultural Policy are supposed to make up for these losses, at least partially. On paper, because in reality the obligation to carry out 100% of the checks before being able to proceed with the payment of the first tranche of payment de facto prevents farmers from receiving these subsidies.  Even though some of these controls are superfluous, just one example of how certain rules of control of the common agricultural policy poison the daily lives of farmers. I voted in favour of the Sarvamaa report because we need to do better, improve the quality of controls, and reduce their costs, EUR 4 billion a year for a budget for agriculture of 58 billion euros, is huge! Making better use of European taxpayers' money, and enabling the agricultural world to have it fully and quickly, is essential in a sector in the midst of a crisis.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which analyses how controls on the implementation of the Common Agricultural Policy have been implemented and calls for greater simplification and less bureaucracy in it, so that it is more easily interpretable and applicable by farmers. The report calls for streamlining controls, not in vain its costs already amount to EUR 4 billion per year. It is also fully in favour of improving the quality and coherence of inspections beyond increasing the number of controls in the agriculture sector by all Member States, the Commission and the Court of Auditors. It also emphasizes that it is the beneficiaries themselves who bear the consequences of the risk of involuntary errors due to the complexity of the regulation, and therefore recommends a reasonable, proportionate and effective sanctions policy, which avoids, for example, the double penalty for the same error in both the payment system and conditionality and that payments are not interrupted when minor or administrative errors are detected.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for the simplification and reduction of the administrative burden, which are, of course, highly desired. Each year, the control of 40 million transactions and other CAP controls cost around 4 billion euros. The text of the report stresses the need to strike the right balance between reduced administrative burden and effective financial control. However, I am of course minding that we must ensure that, under the guise of administrative simplification, decisions lead to the questioning of the CAP, a barely hidden renationalisation or a transfer of administrative burden from the Commission's services to the Member States or, worse, to the beneficiaries. Real administrative simplification must benefit CAP beneficiaries, national/regional administrations and the Commission's services at the same time. I'll see to it.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The verification of 50 million transactions and other CAP controls cost around EUR 4 billion per year. Given that the cap expenditure provisions for the period 2014-2020 remain complex, it is expected that the costs of monitoring the €58 billion CAP budget will grow further if nothing is done.  For this reason, I share the view that a financial balance needs to be found, capable of reducing administrative burdens and ensuring more effective financial control, as well as fully reliable first-level controls and the provision of credible data by Member States so that they do not have to be duplicated at EU level. I am in favour of the objective of implementing the single audit scheme with only one chain of audits, simplifying the process. I also agree with risk-based controls, where the best performing Member States should be rewarded with a reduction in Union controls. I also stress as a positive aspect the sharing and exchange of good practice, in order to ensure more fluid controls and as little as possible disruption of farmers' activity.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Efficient first-level controls and clear and reliable communication from Member States are needed to ensure an adequate balance between administrative burdens and financial controls.  I voted in favour of the proposal put forward by Mr Beazley. Sarvamaa, so that the various difficulties arising from a CAP that is too bureaucratic and cumbersome can be overcome.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, agreeing with the urgent need for a reform with a view to simplifying the CAP.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report because although the lack of effectiveness or diversion of funds is something to be taken into account, they are not the main problems of the CAP, but are others to which this report does not provide solutions. Most CAP aid often ends up in the hands of landowners and large agri-food companies, which is detrimental to small and medium-sized producers, who face constant economic difficulties and lack the same administrative structures to access CAP aid. The current one is a deeply anti-redistributive model that contributes to the creation of inefficient oligopolies and harms the equal opportunity system. That is why we strongly support the allocation of resources aimed at favouring small and medium-sized producers in favour of increasing a more efficient productive model, and especially towards investments for territorial development. Increase redistributed criteria to prevent funds from ending up in the hands of those who do not need them, and thus not harm those who contribute to social and rural development in an efficient and ecological manner.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report proposes some necessary aspects as more effective and efficient controls through the simplification of audit controls, less bureaucracy and performance-based controls. It also differentiates between unintentional omissions and fraud cases. But on the other hand it suggests creating a list of Member States with good and bad practice and calls for Member States that achieve the best results in each area to be rewarded with a reduction in Union controls. By not sharing a proposal in this regard, I abstained from voting on this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's proposal to improve the quality of agricultural controls carried out by The Member States, the Commission and the European Court of Auditors. The reforms of the common agricultural policy (CAP) have increased complexity and bureaucracy for the competent authorities and farmers in recent years. I therefore felt it was essential to express my support for this proposal, the ultimate aim of which is to improve a very complex agricultural system.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Public funding implies a control logic which must be proportionate to the risks of infringement. In turn, the rules inherent in the use of public money must be sufficiently clear and adapted to reality, so that beneficiaries and implementing bodies can contribute to the proper implementation of funding possibilities. This is the only way to implement policy objectives well.  Agricultural funds have had good relative implementation under the Structural Funds and this is an interesting perspective. Farmers are now in the process of implementing the latest reform of the common agricultural policy, with new rules to be applied. The support of european and national authorities is expected to continue to benefit from the support, as well as the flexibility needed to account for this new legislative reality.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as it could lead to more EU spending, which I am against.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This own-initiative report advocates improving the auditing processes of the common agricultural policy by implementing quality controls rather than quantitive ones in order to reduce administrative burden, and ensures that funding is being used in the best possible way. I support any measures which would simply the CAP and provide clearer guidance to both national authorities and farmers in order to reduce the rate of errors. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The current system allowing support from the common agricultural policy (CAP) is too complex for Slovak farmers. In that context, it can also be concluded that economic operators operating in this sector are burdened with a disproportionate number of checks. I therefore voted in favour of adopting the resolution on results-oriented controls in the area of the common agricultural policy, which aimed at simplifying and reducing the bureaucracy of the CAP, as well as improving the CAP control system.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 In the past two reforms of the COMMON AGRICULTURAL POLICY, the rules have become much more complex and, in practice, cause more errors on the ground. As part of the 2013 reform, the requirements for applications and the justification of applications have changed, increasing the risk of errors and, in practice, there is already a higher cost of controls and advice, which currently amount to €4 billion at Member State level. The ECA also found that the 2014-2020 cap spending regime remains complex due to the diversity of European agriculture. The report calls for a future common agricultural policy with less bureaucracy in order to reduce the error rate and for the establishment of instruments that distinguish between errors and fraud. Addressing the complexity and simplification of the policy is a key element in attracting new players to the agricultural sector. I, too, am in favour of eliminating overly complex procedures wherever this can contribute to reducing errors and making more efficient use of European funds. Although the complexity of the simplification of the CAP is welcome, we must be careful not to cause a setback in key areas such as the improvement of social and environmental standards through deregulation measures.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. 'Together with the Greens, I abstained in the vote on the Sarvamaa report on better control over expenditure on the common agricultural policy. As a member of the Committee on Budgetary Control, I have always been in favour of high-performance controls in all policy areas and therefore certainly in the agricultural sector, which receives most of the European budget. All kinds of proposals to improve the quality of controls on agricultural expenditure are good. But this aim must not be abused to introduce an agenda of deregulation under the euphemistic name of better regulation. It should not be used to water down or even delete (controls on) social or environmental rules. Our proposals to improve the report in this area were not supported, so we abstained. Yes, there is certainly room for simpler bureaucratic rules and less paperwork for farmers by the CAP, as the European Court of Auditors also stated. But this complexity also has to do with the great diversity of agriculture in the EU. Moreover, we should not throw away the child with the bathwater: ensuring that agricultural funds are well spent is crucial in order to maintain the support of European citizens for a European agricultural policy.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this report because it is important to ensure that the financial interests of the European Union are protected in absolutely all spheres and political categories. The common objective should be to comply with financial regulation, and a single audit scheme should be established so that control and financial checks are not carried out two or more times more than necessary.  It is therefore of u u importance that all Member States cooperate and provide accurate information. The best Member States should be rewarded and the worst to be better off and strive for it, all accompanied by thorough analyses and controls, as the protection of the financial interests of the European Union should be high on everyone's list of priorities.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
