text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which advocates improving auditing processes by implementing quality controls rather than quantitative ones in order to reduce unnecessary administrative burden and ensure funding is used in the best possible way. I support measures to simplify the CAP and providing clearer guidance to both national authorities and farmers in to reduce error rates.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this report, as it takes into account all parts of the Common Agricultural Policy and shows weaknesses in the introduction of this policy within EU countries. Current innovation within this branch of the holding requires a more agile agricultural policy that EU countries, with minimal consent, can implement in the short term.  While the increasing development of other economic branches often neglects the successes that continue to be achieved in agriculture, we must provide easier regulation for farmers within the European Union, but also ensure that farmers are not swamped with endless paperwork. The Guidelines of the Common Agricultural Policy clearly assume a reduction in control costs, but it becomes apparent from that report that this has not yet been done.  I hope that this report will facilitate the process of controlling and auditing agricultural activities within EU Member States in the future and will be the basis for compensating for shortcomings over the past years.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal because it can lead to better detection of misuse of money under the common agricultural policy. However, the problems of the common agricultural policy are considerably greater, and many of them are factually insoluble, as they necessarily stem from the very essence of the CAP. It would therefore be ideal to abolish the CAP in order to actually improve the position of consumers and to equate farmers.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests: a step closer to the control of the common agricultural policy based on results. When planning the common agricultural policy, we must reduce the excessive bureaucracy that suffocates farmers. The rules need to be more transparent and clearer. When controlling the use of funds, we must be aware of a link between error and fraud. The extensive and complicated documentation has led to a number of errors which, of course, cannot be regarded as fraud. An appropriate balance must be struck between a reduced administrative burden and effective financial control.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The common agricultural policy must not limit the independence and self-sufficiency of the Member States in order to put them at an unfavourable position with regard to the Union by creating a relationship of dependency.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In my opinion, the protection of the European Union's financial interest is key; in general and in this case, this is the guiding position in simplifying the common agricultural policy. I supported the report, which I was involved in drafting as shadow rapporteur, because I believe that the level of bureaucracy and other constraints should be reduced, but in such a way that simplification does not allow for fraud. Simplification of the control system is necessary because, despite repeated simplifications, the system is not yet user-friendly. When looking at the audit, we find an overlapping system element, which, of course, is an unmanageable burden for the beneficiaries: the paying agency, the certifying and central body of the Member States, the tax authorities, the European Commission (at two levels) and the European Court of Auditors all have audit or audit roles. I believe that the common agricultural policy should stimulate agricultural production, ensure a decent standard of living for agricultural communities, stabilise the market and produce affordable food. All these wishes are entrecognised in the Treaty and should not be present as an unfulmountable barrier.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which aims at optimising the use of EU subsidies for the Common Agricultural Policy. The CAP spending scheme is particularly complex because of the diversity of farming scheme throughout the EU and may lead to burdensome control procedures. The cost of the controls on the implementation of the CAP amounts to EUR 4 billion. I think it is urgent to find the right balance between leading an effective financial control and imposing less administrative burden.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I support this report, as it highlights the need to reduce the cost of control of the Common Agricultural Policy and the associated administrative burdens, which leads to the simplification of the CAP.  In fact, I believe that this simplification will greatly help Croatian farmers who, as residents of a country that recently became a member of the European Union, have faced new and complicated provisions, but also farmers in other Member States of the European Union. The amended provisions of the CAP will be clearly implemented and interpreted in this way and there will also be fewer failures in its implementation.  In particular, I support the provisions of this report which call for the distinction between unintentional fraud failures, while at the same time I believe that this objective will contribute more effectively to strongly advocating the quality and consistency of inspections rather than increasing the number of controls in agriculture.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. Report on the protection of the EU's financial interests: Towards supervision based on the effectiveness of the cap, it stresses the need to strike the right balance for less bureaucratic burden and more effective financial supervision. I supported the report because I do not think that we need any duplication of analytical data and the associated increased bureaucratic burden.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report calls for a simplification of the CAP and the administrative procedures of farmers, including by rewriting part of the current legislation. It also recommends limiting the number of controls on farms by grouping them together. It also proposes to stop penalizing farmers in the event of an unintentional error, as is the case today. On the pretext of combating fraud, it intends to tighten the framework for the use of funds by the European Commission, which already regulates the use of funds in a very authoritarian and cumbersome manner. Similarly, the management of Feader funds is largely locked down by the European Commission when it should be the sole responsibility of the Member States. Member States are also obliged to co-finance, on their own funds, the projects imposed by the Commission via the Rural Development Plans. On the contrary, Member States should have more freedom to carry out their agricultural policy as they wish.  While there is an urgent need to ease the administrative and legal burden on farmers, it is not desirable to further strengthen the European Commission in the face of Member States' choices. So I chose the abstension.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report because although the lack of effectiveness or diversion of funds is something to be taken into account, they are not the main problems of the CAP, but are others to which this report does not provide solutions. Most CAP aid often ends up in the hands of landowners and large agri-food companies, which is detrimental to small and medium-sized producers, who face constant economic difficulties and lack the same administrative structures to access CAP aid. The current one is a deeply anti-redistributive model that contributes to the creation of inefficient oligopolies and harms the equal opportunity system. That is why we strongly support the allocation of resources aimed at favouring small and medium-sized producers in favour of increasing a more efficient productive model, and especially towards investments for territorial development. Increase redistributed criteria to prevent funds from ending up in the hands of those who do not need them, and thus not harm those who contribute to social and rural development in an efficient and ecological manner.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for an EP resolution on the protection of the EU's financial interests in the cap area, as I believe that simplification of the CAP should go hand in hand with optimising control policy in agriculture.  A less bureaucratic CAP will lead to a lower error rate in its implementation and thus less financial penalties for farmers. In addition, payments to projects should not be interrupted when minor or technical errors are identified. Digitising the application process as an element of simplification of the CAP, as well as the creation of a 'single farm file' with plantation data, will save errors when submitting applications. Investment in rural broadband networks and consumer training programmes, especially older farmers, is therefore needed.  I support the idea of implementing a single CAP audit within the same year. An integrated approach to the exercise of checks will reduce the administrative and financial burden for farmers by reducing the number of on-the-spot visits and better coordination of control activities by audit authorities. This will save the European taxpayer considerable money, given that the cost of checks reaches EUR 4 billion per year.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The report points to the need to find a balance between reducing administrative burdens and gaining effective financial control as well as implementing a single audit scheme. We are talking about issues of importance on which progress is needed and what I think is necessary to vote in favour of this report.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests: towards results-based controls in relation to the common agricultural policy, because I believe that the current system of controls in the common agricultural policy needs to be reviewed. I would like to remind you that the European Commission's Directorate-General for Agriculture has proposed a 'financial correction' of up to EUR 388 million and EUR 743 thousand, due to the 'serious shortcomings in the management of debts and irregularities' contested by the agency for agricultural disbursements in Italy. During the two rounds of reforms of the common agricultural policy, the rules have become more heterogeneous and complex, with more errors on the ground.  Results-based controls need to be provided for, while stability and a responsible approach on the part of administrative bodies are needed. The costs of controls relating to the common agricultural policy amount to EUR 4 billion per year and involve EUR 50 million in transactions, compared with an agricultural budget of around EUR 58 billion. Simplification is necessary, but it must not in any way lead to the dismantling of the instruments that have been adopted: it is necessary to define a less bureaucratic CAP in order to reduce error rates, and to develop instruments that make it possible to distinguish between error and fraud, in order to fight actively and successfully against fraud.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which advocates improving our auditing processes by implementing quality controls rather than quantitative ones in order to reduce unnecessary administrative burden and to ensure that funding is used in the best possible way. I support measures to simplify the CAP and provide clearer guidance to both national authorities and farmers to reduce error rates. Helping to improve the efficiency of the CAP is a key method of bettering the European Union at all levels as we move our institutions forward.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'As a Liberal Group, we believe it is necessary for the European Commission to urgently work to simplify the common agricultural policy, especially in the case of the complex regulations that cause a great deal of red tape to EU farmers. I am also concerned about the proper control of eu funds paid out, because fraud means less money for the properly functioning farmer and can lead to more controls and more administrative burdens. I voted in favour of this resolution because our farmers can use all the help from Europe in these hard times.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite a supposed simplification of the CAP, the truth is that farmers continue to face an endless mountain of paperwork that needs to be presented, with increasingly complex regulations and control measures. The promotion of performance-based controls may be an answer to some of these questions, and this report insists that the definition of performance in relation to controls should mainly involve the quality of member states' administrative controls and systems, i.e. the efficiency, coherence and reliability of the managing and certification authorities. We agree that, in order to ease the burden on beneficiaries, operators should not be burdened with a disproportionate number of inspections.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report recognises that many errors in current agricultural support are due to the complexity of the system, making it difficult to distinguish between errors and fraud. It avoids putting farmers under general suspicion, stresses the importance of agriculture for Europe's economic well-being, but also points out that controls are important to avoid fraud, simplification is needed so that farmers do not inadvertently make mistakes and best practices are exchanged in the allocation, handling and verification of subsidies. I therefore support this motion.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on 'Protecting the financial interests of the European Union: towards defined benefit controls of the common agricultural policy', together with my group. The report is a step forward towards greater financial and budgetary accountability. It is also about cutting red tape and simplifying processes. Nowhere is this more important than in the case of the common agricultural policy, which has been a nucleus of the EU's rampant growth over the last few decades and has always been a playground for the conflict of national interests. I support everything that clears the thicket in this area.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report relates to improving the quality of checks carried out under the common agricultural policy and increasing its flexibility through a single control system covering all stages from final beneficiaries to EU institutions. At the same time, the change in the system aims to reduce bureaucracy and harmonise procedures in order to avoid abuses and simplify the CAP. All this is intended to attract new workers and hosts to agriculture, to ensure the smooth operation and development of this sector of the economy.  The report also calls for changes in legislative regulation in order to strike the necessary balance between administrative burdens and effective financial control. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The costs of controls relating to the common agricultural policy amount to EUR 4 billion per year and involve 50 million transactions, compared with an agricultural budget of around EUR 58 billion. The complexity of the CAP depends on the diversity and heterogeneity of agriculture in Europe, and the necessary simplification must not, however, lead to the dismantling of the instruments that have been adopted: the report we have voted on today therefore focuses on the demand for a less bureaucratic CAP in order to reduce error rates, as well as the development of instruments that make it possible to distinguish between error and fraud.  With regard to simplification, this report aims to establish a single audit mechanism in order to establish a single chain of controls, from the final beneficiaries to the EU institutions, and calls for an integrated approach to controls so that all obligations on a farm can contain the number of inspections and reduce the concomitant cost and burden in terms of resources and time. It also calls on the Member States to implement digitisation programmes with regard to the relationship between administrations. Although I have some minor critical issues, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Common Agricultural Policy represents a key item in the Union´s budget also because it absorbs an extraordinary part of it. Nevertheless, it has been and continues to be a very complex and not transparent expenditure over which there is a little control that tends to be very costly. This of course leads to a very high error rates, as determined by the Court of Auditors, and invites fraudulent activities. We need to simplify the administrative burden to make the process less bureaucratic but at the same time we need ensure sufficient monitoring over the finances in this area. I therefore support this call for increased quality above quantity with regard to financial controls, which will not cut a significant part of the CAP’s budget, in the form of the Single audit scheme. The controls need be effective as to secure financial interests of the European tax payers and need to be less burdensome and costly for the very same reason. I also believe that the Member States should take responsibility for quality on-the-spot controls that are crucial for ensuring the correct usage of the European budget.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We follow the concerns expressed in both Opinion 1/2012 of the European Court of Auditors on certain proposals for regulations on the Common Agricultural Policy, as in this report, as to the complexity of the supposedly simplified Common Agricultural Policy. What has happened with this supposed simplification of the CAP is that farmers continue to face enormous bureaucracy. We agree that, in order to ease the burden on beneficiaries, and considering that operators should not be burdened with a disproportionate number of inspections, the authorities should aim to organise on-the-spot checks so as not to subject the farmer to multiple annual on-the-spot checks by national authorities, the Commission or the Court of Auditors. We have many reservations about creating a list of good and bad people in relation to a "blacklist" that discriminates against countries where smallfarmers are not able to meet all the controls required by a deeply bureaucratic and complex CAP.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (GUE/NGL).
text: Thank you, Mr. President. As you know, 75%-90% of businesses in the countries of the South are family-friendly and the vast majority of them are small and medium-sized enterprises. As small and medium-sized enterprises, they were the first and most important victims of the economic crisis. It is therefore imperative both to deal directly with the problem at Community and national policy level and to launch a new initiative.  In this context, the report chooses a thorough and balanced approach, with the aim of either addressing all the factors leading to the exclusion of these enterprises from support measures or exempting them from production obligations because, in principle, their specificities have not been analysed and have not been given much attention and because Community and national policies for small and medium-sized enterprises have proved in any case inadequate and ineffective in dealing with the crisis and the phenomenon of de-investment. The absence of a legally binding and statistically acceptable definition at European level of what is a family business therefore results in the inability to collect statistical and comparable data and to quote good practices, the absence of studies focusing on their specific characteristics, the lack of an assessment of the administrative impact of the regulatory framework and, above all, the absence of associations or structures representing their interests. As shadow rapporteur, I have therefore tabled a number of amendments to improve the problematic - in my view - paragraphs, namely those which include points, elements and proposals with a neoliberal sign, which will only cause additional damage to family businesses. Many of them were accepted and incorporated into the text of the report. At the same time, I have tried, with the tabling of an oral amendment that has been voted on, to emphasise that the needs, challenges and problems faced by these companies are directly linked to their size and that, therefore, it is small and medium-sized family businesses that are entitled to and must immediately benefit from a proportionally fair financial institutional support or even relief from unnecessary obligations. In conclusion, Mr President, by voting in favour of the whole report and having completed this comprehensive and consensual effort on the part of the European Parliament, I call on the Commission to proceed immediately with the implementation of the proposed actions. Thank you.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, today we voted in favour of a report aimed at encouraging the Commission to start paying more attention to family businesses. This is worthy of companies representing more than 60% of European companies and between 40% and 50% of private sector jobs.  We need a common definition that allows us to collect and compare data at European level. We must address the problems that are specific to these companies, such as their more difficult-than-normal transmission by the application of inheritance tax. Cooperation between the various national organisations of family businesses must also be strengthened and the exchange of good practices further promoted from the European Union.  Finally, we must ensure that measures designed to improve the activity of all companies, such as the creation of one-stop-shop windows and the promotion of entrepreneurship, also reach family businesses.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, I have supported this report by Mrs. Niebler on family businesses in Europe, as we live in times when the economy needs to be started and thus to reduce the huge number of unemployed among which there are the most young people. This form of economy is an innovative source of employment in the private sector and therefore needs to be encouraged for its development. There are numerous advantages and important roles of such family businesses because they nurture economic activities that have been passed down through generations, which is a contribution to economic growth. However, many Member States do not have regulated legislation and financial instruments to encourage the realisation of new family businesses or help existing ones. Legislation needs to be edied, a favourable administrative climate should be created that would enable such companies to operate successfully and have a more successful national economy. It is necessary to create measures that would strengthen the economic environment and development of family businesses at the level of the European Union, to raise awareness of problems related to family businesses, and in Croatia we also base our programs on family businesses and thus intend to start Croatia.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I was happy to support this report and the spotlight it puts on family businesses across Europe. They form the backbone of our economy, and there is still no clear definition of them, so it does make it difficult to implement necessary legislation. Sixty percent of all enterprises in the EU are family-run and they account for 40-50% of our jobs in the private sector. They generally take a long—term view, because they are owner-owned rather than non-owner owned and so they have an eye on the future and on ensuring that the business passes on to future generations. One of the single biggest issues and questions facing family businesses is that of succession and passing on the business: 450 000 companies each year, employing 2 million people, find themselves in this position and, because of many difficulties, it is estimated that 150 000 businesses are forced to close because of the difficulty in passing on the business. We need to create the right framework, we need to recognize that they are important and we need to do more work in this area, but I compliment the rapporteur Mrs Niebler on producing the report because it is very valuable in highlighting the effect of family businesses.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: – I voted in favour of the report because it initiates procedures to strengthen family businesses in Greece, where the memoranda and policies of mercelial austerity imposed with the support of the European Commission have led to mass unemployment, where unemployment now affects over one and a half million of our fellow citizens.  After five years of austerity, 230,000 small and medium-sized enterprises have closed. Family businesses make up 85% of all European businesses and create 60% of jobs in the private sector, making them strong pillars of the European economy. The European Commission must therefore adopt the definition of family businesses so that they are not excluded from the possibilities of support provided by the European Union. In addition, family businesses should be given direct financing in order to invest in foreign markets as well as direct information on market opportunities. Thanks.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – I voted in favour of the report on family businesses. Family businesses would also play a very important role in the former socialist countries, not only in their economic role, but also in their political role. Why am I saying that? If there were thriving family businesses, those who worked there would be the most independent people. After all, they wouldn't be at the mercy of power. Like all the community workers who either get community service or don't. Depending on how he behaves, whether he's misbehaving, like going to a protest or something, or not. They are also not at the mercy of the workers who earn 50-60 thousand forints and work alongside the ribbon. They would therefore be the ones who could actively participate in public life, both at local level, at municipal level and at national level. Because they could live with dignity, with their heads held high, economically and independently in every way. Well, that's exactly why they don't support them.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, despite the lack of clear and uniform criteria to define ‘family business’ across Europe, and their vast heterogeneity in terms of incorporation form and size, there are various common traits which set them apart, such as a flexible decision-making process, a high degree of creativity and innovation, a longer-term view on investment, and high involvement and responsibility towards their business, customers, employees and their local community.  It is because of such assets that they play a pivotal role in the regional and national economies and account for more than half of jobs in the private sector in Europe. However, various studies conducted recently show that they also face similar difficulties in terms of access to finance, taxation, a stifling regulatory framework, and the challenge of attracting the right people with the right skills. Coming from a region whose economy is overwhelmingly based on family companies I can only salute the drafting of this report and stress the importance for the European Union of taking supportive measures in their regard.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, I supported this report, as family businesses represent more than 60% of all European businesses and account for 40-50% of all jobs in the private sector. A smaller number of family businesses have a large share of the total turnover of all businesses and thus contribute to job creation and growth and economic success of a country. Family businesses often have a significantly higher share of their own capital than non-family businesses. The result is the economic stability of the company and the stability of the entire economy and the scope for further investment in the company. Legal frameworks for the transfer of family business, the development of specific financial instruments for this transfer should be improved, the thus avoiding a liquidity crisis in order to guarantee the further survival of family businesses and prevent their deterioration or forced sale.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, family-owned businesses are the backbone of the Northern Ireland economy, and 97% of all businesses in Northern Ireland, many of them family-owned, can be classed as SMEs. In order to grow the economy, support jobs and invest in public services, we need to support small business, not to saddle it with further regulation and burdens from Europe. In addition to these burdens, in Northern Ireland we now have a case where a family-owned business, Ashers, has had a legal ruling against it for refusing to inscribe a cake because of a deeply-held religious belief. In this world of competing rights, we need to see that a family running a small business is not deprived of the fundamental right of freedom of conscience.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, colleagues, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent work I supported this extremely important document because family businesses need to be supported and this, in my view, is the task of the European Commission No 1 to provide support not only financially, but also informative, so to disseminate information on how to develop family business. In my country, Latvia, family business accounts for a large part of gross domestic product and makes a very important contribution to the fight against unemployment. Of course, the main, if not the most important, problem is financing. Because this path should be made easier for people who want to continue and develop business with their family members, with the whole family engaging in it. And then there must be a single institution in the European Union that would be obliged to provide this information and to be able to turn and learn how to set up this business. And lastly, the family business is a great guarantee for the greatest value—the family, that is, when the father works with his son and all of them —with his wife or mom. This means that not only will the company be prosperous, but the family will also be strong and rich. Thank you!

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite being a necessary boost from Europe's small and medium-sized enterprises, it implies a position in favour of large companies with this type of ownership. Family businesses account for 85% of European businesses and generate 60% of private employment. This fundamental relevance requires supportive measures to sustain our production system. It is because of the important support measures proposed in this report that we have not been able to vote against it. However, there is explicit support that calls for making the large family business a beneficiary of the support measures currently received by SMEs. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on family businesses in Europe because this report is very favourable to this type of business and their long-term development. The report points out that 85% of European companies are family-owned enterprises, which account for 60% of private sector jobs. Several measures are suggested to promote family businesses and transmission, such as simplifying administrative procedures, promoting training activities to develop entrepreneurship and combating labour shortages and youth unemployment. I have spoken in favour of this report because it also reminds us that legislation on direct taxation or inheritance is the responsibility of the Member States.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. In the German-speaking Community and throughout the European Union, family businesses are the basis of the economy. They create the most jobs and often offer long-term growth prospects, but they encounter numerous problems when it comes to investment financing or generational transfer. I therefore support this own-initiative report, which calls on the EU Member States to create more favourable conditions for family businesses.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is positive in many ways. It is very favourable to family businesses, to their long-term development and, above all, to their transmission... while recalling that "legislation on direct taxation and inheritance is the responsibility of the Member States".   So I voted for this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I oppose new EU legislation in this field. However, I support the principle of reducing red tape, as well as greater recognition of the challenges faced by family businesses. As this report includes both, I abstained.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim is to promote family businesses in Europe. Family businesses can play a crucial role in overcoming the financial and economic crisis and revitalising the economy. More than 60% of all businesses in the EU are family businesses and account for 40-50% of jobs in the private sector. The definition of family businesses is not legally binding and is not used at all in the Member States. As a result, family businesses that no longer meet the definition of SMEs cannot benefit from certain opportunities for support. In addition, many family businesses are trying not to exceed the Criteria for SMEs set by the Commission and the consequences are clear: no more workers are employed, profits or turnover growth are prevented, and thus economic growth is automatically achieved. In addition, it is difficult to compare the situation of family businesses in all EU Member States, with more than 90 different definitions of family businesses across the EU. I support the proposals that more data, figures and facts from individual Member States are needed in order to better understand the difficulties and challenges of family businesses and to promote the exchange of best practices.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Despite its imperfections and some regrettable concessions to fashionable ideologies, this report by Mrs Niebler is very favourable to family businesses, their long-term development and, above all, their transmission. I have therefore not hesitated to support it, especially since the rapporteur reminds us that 'legislation on direct taxation and inheritance is the responsibility of the Member States': there is more talk of exchanges of good practices, with a number of recommendations without constraints for the Member States.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The economic crisis in Europe must push us to find innovative solutions to restart growth, increase the number of investments and actively combat rampant unemployment. In fact, 25 million EU citizens are unemployed, including more than five million young people under the age of 25.  It is therefore essential to create an investment-friendly environment for our businesses and, more generally, to develop entrepreneurship throughout the Union. The report, which I approved, stresses that family businesses, in particular, can play a decisive role in addressing the effects of the financial and economic crisis and in revitalising the economy. Family-owned enterprises account for more than 60% of EU businesses and 40%-50% of private sector jobs.  The rapporteur therefore believes that Member States need to provide more data and figures to enable a better understanding of the problems and issues facing family businesses, as well as to promote exchanges of good practice.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. Europe has 25 million unemployed people. Family businesses play an important role in overcoming the economic crisis, because of their ability to create and fix jobs—especially in local communities—quality work. At the moment they account for 60% of the Union's companies but nonetheless have problems with financing, internationalisation and administrative problems from the exodus of burdens. It is therefore necessary to improve the current legislation by analysing their problems in order to solve their difficulties and needs, and to adapt them to European legislation, as well as for different States to ensure adaptation to them and ensure their continuity in the future. That's why I voted for it.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report entitled "Family Enterprises in Europe" recalls that 85% of European companies are family-owned enterprises, representing 60% of private sector jobs. These enterprises are vital to the European economy because they are deeply rooted in their location and are factors in preserving jobs in rural areas and devastated regions, thus contributing to the fight against the ageing of the population and the depopulation of certain regions. Member States are therefore encouraged to encourage the establishment of specific infrastructures, as well as to ensure the viability of companies, especially start-ups. Family businesses are inherently flexible and are excellent for spotting new perspectives and innovations. Noting that the latter have been underfunded since the crisis, the report encourages states to provide specific measures, such as administrative and fiscal simplification, improving the legal framework for the transmission of these companies or promoting training activities... That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this text.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which effectively underlines the very important role of family businesses in the European economy, and also defines the development of a legal framework to support this type of enterprise as a 'priority'.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted against the report. The report calls on the Member States to reschedule their tax policies to benefit family businesses, including the current business tax, inheritance and gift tax. I believe that europe should not interfere in national tax policy, which is why I am voting against. The report also wants increased support for family businesses to increase employment. However, in order to combat mass unemployment in the Member States, it is far more important for the EU to break with austerity policies, and to invest in public green investment for infrastructure and welfare.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. Family businesses account for more than 60% of businesses in the EU and between 40% and 50% of private sector jobs. However, there is not enough data and research to understand your specific needs and structures. The absence of a specific, simple and harmonised definition of a legally binding family business at European level prevents the collection of comparable data in the various Member States. As this report claims, it is necessary to develop a statistically viable definition at European level of the concept of a family business, including, in addition to purely quantitative criteria, qualitative criteria such as company ownership, control and management, risk and social responsibility or employee participation in the management of business activities. It would also be desirable to set up a permanent working group to deal in a special way with the needs and specificities of these enterprises. The Commission and the Member States should also promote the information and exchange of expertise and good practices, in particular with regard to entrepreneurship and training in management and entrepreneurship. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on the report, which assesses the importance and situation of family businesses in Europe.  Parliament notes that small and medium-sized family businesses are constantly feeling the need to innovate and attract new skills and talents, and therefore calls on the Commission and the Member States to offer smaller family businesses incentives to take risks from growth. Family businesses are deeply rooted in a certain place because of their history, creating jobs in both rural and less attractive areas, thus helping to halt the process of ageing and depopulation in many regions of the EU. For this reason, Parliament calls on the Commission and the Member States to develop the economically efficient infrastructure needed to ensure the competitiveness, renewal, growth and sustainability of such enterprises. The Commission and the Member States are encouraged to take action to strengthen digital entrepreneurship and digital skills so that family businesses can take full advantage of digital technologies.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report draws attention to the fact that family farms used to make a significant contribution to the recovery of the European economy and still play a significant role in economic and social development, in reducing unemployment, especially among young people, and in investing in human capital. The report also discusses, inter alia, the importance of policies for family businesses, which can stimulate entrepreneurship and motivate European families to start their own family businesses. The problem is that many family businesses, which no longer fit into the definition of SMEs but are far from being large companies, cannot benefit from certain support opportunities or be exempted from certain administrative obligations. This inevitably leads to unnecessary bureaucracy, which is particularly burdensome for these medium-sized family businesses. In my opinion, the majority of family businesses are SMEs, so it is essential that EU legislation is better adapted to real circumstances and to the needs of these businesses. It is also important to allow them to benefit from aid schemes and facilities for bureaucratic expenditure. As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of Angelika Niebler's report on support for European family businesses.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. More than 60% of all enterprises in the European Union are family businesses, which account for about 40-50% of private sector jobs, while in Slovenia the share of such enterprises is even higher than 60%. Family businesses think longer in the longer term than companies that are not run by owners, as they want to ensure economic success in the next generation. This should be a guarantee of stability, accountability, development and, most importantly, the provision of jobs and their increasing. Unfortunately, apart from the economic situation in the market, the transfer of ownership to the next generation is often the reason for the family business to shut down, causing completely unnecessary job losses. It is therefore very much up to the measures to encourage family businesses, both at EU and Member State level, whether these companies will continue to be the driver of the European economy and that jobs will not be closed due to rigid legislation. Flexible labour and inheritance legislation and incentives to improve the business environment are necessary. I myself am a partner in a family business, we are engaged in apple production, so I am all the more aware of the importance of this kind of entrepreneurship and the responsibility felt by the owner and the remaining family members to the employees and to future generations. I was therefore happy to support the proposed report.

name: David Borrelli (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the good work done by the rapporteur, I voted against this motion for a resolution because I believe that our SMEs have not been adequately protected. In particular, in my view, it is wrong to extend access to all the instruments and funds provided exclusively for SMEs, such as COSME, including mid-caps companies. Furthermore, our main concerns are that family farms are very variable in size, ranging from micro-enterprises to multinationals, but it is clear that the difficulties faced by a micro-enterprise in accessing European instruments and funding are greater.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. Nearly half of private sector jobs are created by family SMEs. Their preservation in times of crisis is of utmost importance. However, as European aid to such companies is conditional on an outdated definition of SMEs, it is necessary to modernise the current system.  The current situation forces a large number of companies not to develop so as not to lose their rights to different grants. I support this report because it proposes to revise the existing definition and opens up the possibility of SMEs becoming more competitive.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I firmly believe in the fundamental importance of family businesses for the European economy. They represent an enormous resource for the whole continent and play an essential social role within the communities to which they are a part. I therefore believe that the Commission should do everything possible to ensure its survival and, even more so, its growth.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Family businesses account for more than 60% of European businesses and provide around 50% of all existing private sector jobs in Europe. Most companies active in the agricultural and fisheries sectors are family businesses, as are many in the craft sector, trade and the production of quality goods and services. They have a longer-term perspective than companies that are not run by the owners because they want the company to be economically sound even in subsequent generations and for this reason they are often strongly rooted in the territory and represent a bulwark against depopulation in rural areas, as well as being an important source of work that is intertwined with local communities , has stability characteristics and is not at risk of relocation. However, due to their particular characteristics, family businesses cannot be fully identified with SMEs. The lack of a single European definition of this type of reality and the excessive bureaucratisation of the business system cause significant damage to family businesses. The EU needs to start up-to-date studies in this area and therefore adapt its regulatory framework to protect them.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This text defends family businesses, which account for 60% of companies and half of jobs in the European Union. This report recognises that these companies have, in the past, always contributed to the economic development of the Member States and that they are sources of innovation and job creators. They thus help to combat youth unemployment and support employment in disadvantaged areas. For all these reasons, there are plans to encourage their financing and thus to ensure that regulation, including financial markets, does not lead to unnecessary constraints. It also encourages Member States to simplify administrative procedures and tax systems and to improve the legal framework governing transmission. Finally, it is appropriate to promote entrepreneurship in educational settings at best. Attached to the defence of SMEs and family businesses, we can only welcome these types of proposals, especially since the rapporteur has repeatedly pointed out that taxation is indeed the responsibility of States. This text therefore does not pose a particular threat to the sovereignty of States. So I voted for it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The financial and economic crisis has had significant consequences. There are still around 25 million unemployed people across the European Union and the number of unemployed young people under the age of 25 is over 5 million.  In these circumstances, the promotion of jobs, growth and investment is the number one priority of the political guidelines for the current European Commission, as presented at the beginning of its mandate in the summer of 2014. In this context, family businesses can play a decisive role in overcoming the financial and economic crisis and in revitalising the economy, and the conclusions reached by the European Commission's expert group in its 2009 report stressed that more than 60% of EU businesses are family businesses, providing around 40-50% of private sector jobs.  I voted in favour of the Report on family businesses in Europe because these businesses have a longer-term vision than those that are not run by their owners, while ensuring that future generations also achieve good economic performance.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. The report stresses the role played by family businesses in the economy and in maintaining jobs even in times of crisis, and calls for a legal framework more suited to this particular form of enterprise.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the resolution on family businesses, which are strongly rooted in the territory of each Member State and can therefore make a huge contribution to Europe's competitiveness and the creation of new jobs.  Although these companies have played such an important role for our economy for many decades, very little political attention is paid to them. On the one hand, it is becoming increasingly difficult for these companies to access instruments of economic support, while on the other hand the bureaucratic burden continues to increase, becoming unsustainable, becoming increasingly difficult, becoming increasingly difficult to increase profits or turnover, and automatically curbing any possibility of growth. It is therefore crucial to better understand the problems and challenges faced by family businesses, and to give them adequate political attention once again. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour of the text.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I am opposed to any new EU legislation in this field, hence I voted against this proposal.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the fact that family run business constitutes more than 60% of all enterprises and up to 50% of private sector jobs in EU, I voted in favour of this report asking the Commission to address the challenges the family run businesses have to face and to introduce the test in the part of the assessment. I believe that they contribute to local communities so they should deserve opportunities to access to business or finances transfer.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Family businesses are an important part (85% in numbers, 60% of private sector jobs) of the European economy, although their presence is uneven in different EU countries. Over and above their economic role, they play an equally essential social role. I believe it is absolutely essential to protect SMEs, so together with the M5S delegation, I voted against mrs Niebler's report.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European entrepreneurial fabric is made up of about 60% small family businesses. It is therefore a very important economic reality to which there has not been proper attention at national and European level. The lack of a legal definition common to all the Member States of the Union has certainly not helped in identifying specific actions against these companies, which have been and are still particularly exposed to the economic crisis. The recovery of the economy must be based precisely on greater attention to this important category of companies and provide, where necessary, assistance that must not only be understood as financial, but also administrative and fiscal, in order to support them in the generational transition that is the most difficult challenge for family businesses. For these reasons, data must be collected in order to arrive at a simple, clear, easily applicable and comparable definition between countries as soon as possible in order to help better understand the phenomenon and the challenges faced by family businesses.  I voted in favour of this report because it has finally brought to political and institutional attention such an important area for job creation and maintenance.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 It is a necessity for the European Commission to promote entrepreneurship across the EU, taking into account the importance of family businesses in the EU economy, and to create the necessary environment conducive to business excellence. We need to strengthen competitiveness and grow the European economy by 2020 by draw up a roadmap of measures that can enhance the economic environment and the development of family businesses in the EU.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure concerning family businesses in Europe. In a Europe of around 25 million unemployed, including 5 million young people under 25, and, as calculated by the Commission, with positive GDP growth margins for the coming years, it is important to turn our attention to family businesses. These account for 60% of EU businesses and provide 40-50% of jobs in the private sector. In addition, many of these are strongly rooted in the territory in which they operate. However, these companies face many difficulties, due to the lack of a shared definition at European level and the lack of political attention they receive. Many family businesses do not fall within the definition of SMEs and therefore do not benefit from special instruments or exemption from specific obligations. It is particularly difficult for these companies to succeed them at the top of the company and every year, as a result of this problem, some 150 000 000 companies are forced to close down. It therefore calls for the introduction of a test for family businesses and a legislative impact assessment.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I think it has the great merit of putting in black and white what a great contribution family businesses make to the European economy. This recognition, however, only makes sense inso far as it becomes a starting point for effectively and financially supporting these companies so that they continue to provide employment and well-being. A shrewd industrial policy on the part of the EU cannot ignore the flourishing of companies which, as the report emphasises, buffer in times of crisis and guarantee labour supply when the cycle improves. Congratulations to the rapporteur.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ As a UKIP MEP I am firmly against and attempt to create new binding legislation in the field of business and employment and specifically against the introduction of an ‘EU family business test’.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. Family businesses account for 60% of EU businesses and provide 40–50% of jobs in the private sector. They are therefore essential to overcome the crisis, promote economic recovery and restore employment balance. In addition, most family businesses are deeply rooted in the territory, thus making a significant contribution to preventing the depopulation of rural areas. However, although they play an important role, little attention is paid to their needs in practice. For example, there is no legally binding and harmonised definition of a 'family business', which means that they are excluded from certain support instruments or certain administrative exemptions. This obstacle, like others, should be promptly removed.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite being a necessary boost from Europe's small and medium-sized enterprises, it implies a position in favour of large companies with this type of ownership. Family businesses account for 85% of European companies and generate 60% of private employment, this fundamental relevance requires support measures to support our production system. It is because of the important support measures proposed in this report that we have not been able to vote against it. However, there is explicit support that calls for making the large family business a beneficiary of the support measures currently received by SMEs. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Family businesses make up an important part of European businesses and, in some European regions, the main source of employment. Given their economic and social importance, I voted in favour of the resolution because I believe that the Commission and the Member States must take specific measures to encourage and support companies that want to invest mainly abroad, simplify administrative and tax procedures and develop training activities that will allow us to maintain a constant update on the most advanced practices at management level.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report because family businesses are decisive for the European economy. Their role is important because highly specialised family businesses often serve as innovators and make a significant contribution to economic growth through their long-term economic activity. This type of enterprise is of decisive importance, as they account for 85% of all European businesses and provide 60% of jobs in the private sector. The report therefore rightly calls on the Member States to pay attention to smaller family businesses, to ensure adequate support and to help them to use digital infrastructure more effectively; simplify their administrative procedures and tax systems and improve the legal framework conditions for the transfer of family businesses.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report since I believe that family businesses are an important player in the European economy. This report deals with the definition of ‘family business’ in Europe and the effect of such definition in terms of funding opportunities and exemptions.  More than 60% of all enterprises in the European Union are family-run, and they account for about 40-50% of jobs in the private sector. However, family businesses that no longer meet the definition of SMEs, but are also far from being major corporations, are ineligible for specific funding opportunities and exemptions. Many family businesses try desperately to remain below recruitment and turnover thresholds set by the Commission criteria for SMEs, thus halting further growth.  The report aims at getting policymakers’ attention to this important group of entrepreneurs and to provide assistance where it is needed. It mentions a ‘family business test’, which would determine whether proposed changes to EU law have an impact on family businesses. I believe that family businesses are a major player which we need to further safeguard.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Family businesses make an essential contribution to the success of vocational training reforms and to the increase in the number of apprenticeships. In this context, I believe that, in the long term, functional vocational training systems can help to combat the shortage of specialists and youth unemployment, and I believe that the Member States and the Commission should promote the exchange of best practices on how vocational training systems can provide family businesses with the best investment environment in apprenticeships.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report aims to improve the situation of family businesses in Europe. Family businesses are at the heart of European entrepreneurial culture, accounting for 60% of businesses and 50% of jobs in Europe. Knowing that family businesses mostly take a long-term view and contribute to the growth and stability of our economy, I voted in favour of this report which addresses the difficulties they face, in terms of access to finance and the transfer of the company to the next generation.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on family businesses in Europe, which are an essential part of the European economy. It is necessary to ensure that every family business has access to the necessary financing, but also to alleviate any excessive bureaucratic constraints that could undermine these job-bearing enterprises.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because I am convinced that we should give careful attention to the family business in Europe. Not only because they are very important for local job creation, but also because they represent 85% of all companies and 60% of all jobs in Europe. This report addresses issues we need to tackle, such as reducing administrative burden and improving the rules for transfer of family business.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Promoting employment, growth and investment are the main political priorities of the current European Commission. Family businesses can play a decisive role in overcoming the economic and financial crisis. These companies, which account for around 60% of businesses in the European Union, have a greater prospect of life than other companies, as owners want them to be economically sound and durable. Although family businesses play an important role in our economy, little political attention is paid to them. I supported this report because they believe it is necessary to better understand the problems and challenges faced by these business realities in order to provide assistance where necessary.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of Angelika Niebler's report on support for European family businesses. The report draws attention to the fact that family farms used to make a significant contribution to the recovery of the European economy and still play a significant role in economic and social development, in reducing unemployment, especially among young people, and in investing in human capital. The report also discusses, inter alia, the importance of policies for family businesses, which can stimulate entrepreneurship and motivate European families to start their own family businesses. The problem is that many family businesses, which no longer fit into the definition of SME but are far from being large companies, cannot benefit from certain support opportunities or be exempted from certain administrative obligations. This inevitably leads to unnecessary bureaucracy, which is particularly burdensome for these medium-sized family businesses. It reminds the Commission that the majority of family businesses are SMEs and that it is therefore essential to apply the 'think small first' principle in order for EU legislation to be better adapted to real circumstances and the needs of these businesses. It is also important to allow them to benefit from aid schemes and facilities for bureaucratic expenditure. It calls on the Commission to examine whether all existing instruments to support SMEs and/or individual enterprises can be extended to medium-sized family businesses.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of Angelika Niebler's report on support for European family businesses. The report draws attention to the fact that family farms used to make a significant contribution to the recovery of the European economy and still play a significant role in economic and social development, in reducing unemployment, especially among young people, and in investing in human capital. The report also discusses, inter alia, the importance of policies for family businesses, which can stimulate entrepreneurship and motivate European families to start their own family businesses. The problem is that many family businesses, which no longer fit into the definition of SME but are far from being large companies, cannot benefit from certain support opportunities or be exempted from certain administrative obligations. This inevitably leads to unnecessary bureaucracy, which is particularly burdensome for these medium-sized family businesses. It reminds the Commission that the majority of family businesses are SMEs and that it is therefore essential to apply the 'think small first' principle in order for EU legislation to be better adapted to real circumstances and the needs of these businesses. It is also important to allow them to benefit from aid schemes and facilities for bureaucratic expenditure. It calls on the Commission to examine whether all existing instruments to support SMEs and/or individual enterprises can be extended to medium-sized family businesses.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report does not attribute to its true extent the delegation of the national sovereign rights of the Member States to the EU by the mandatory application of European legislation.  In addition, the EU requires the transposition of laws into the national law of countries on a case-by-case basis and, in the main, in the areas of interest to control Member States and not to help citizens.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of Angelika Niebler's report on support for European family businesses. The report draws attention to the fact that family farms used to make a significant contribution to the recovery of the European economy and still play a significant role in economic and social development, in reducing unemployment, especially among young people, and in investing in human capital. The report also discusses, inter alia, the importance of policies for family businesses, which can stimulate entrepreneurship and motivate European families to start their own family businesses. The problem is that many family businesses, which no longer fit into the definition of SME but are far from being large companies, cannot benefit from certain support opportunities or be exempted from certain administrative obligations. This inevitably leads to unnecessary bureaucracy, which is particularly burdensome for these medium-sized family businesses. It reminds the Commission that the majority of family businesses are SMEs and that it is therefore essential to apply the 'think small first' principle in order for EU legislation to be better adapted to real circumstances and the needs of these businesses. It is also important to allow them to benefit from aid schemes and facilities for bureaucratic expenditure. It calls on the Commission to examine whether all existing instruments to support SMEs and/or individual enterprises can be extended to medium-sized family businesses.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this resolution, as the family business lacks a legally binding, concrete, simple and harmonised European definition. This lack has significant consequences in terms of industrial policy, since it makes it impossible to collect data on them uniformly, and makes it difficult to make these enterprises the subject of targeted support/promotion actions. The lack of this consolidated definition seriously harms family farms, so it has a very negative impact on Italian companies. Finally, I do not agree with the further delay in the already insufficient instruments for SMEs, which potentially favours large and very large companies to the detriment of real, small and SMEs.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Family businesses make an important contribution to the substantial increase in the European economy and play a significant role both in terms of economic growth and social development, by reducing unemployment, particularly among young people, and in terms of investment in human capital. It should be noted that 85% of all European businesses are family businesses, representing 60% of jobs in the private sector, demonstrating a high degree of social responsibility towards their staff and maintaining a strong connection with where they are, thus creating jobs in rural areas and less attractive regions, and thereby contributing , to stop the ageing and depopulation process affecting vast regions of the European Union. With regard to internationalisation, I believe that it is important and necessary for the Commission and the Member States to provide information and support to family businesses.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. Family businesses in Europe account for more than 60% of businesses and between 40% and 50% of private sector jobs.  I share the necessary implementation of European-level measures to ty up the specific problems of family businesses in order to relaunch their competitiveness. The development of a statistically viable definition at European level of the concept of a family business; broadion of the European definition of SMEs; the creation of a one-stop shop that serves, at European level, family businesses and representative groups of interests of family businesses; support for their internationalization or the specific problems that different laws in tax material represent for succession in the ownership of family businesses are key issues to support the good development of family businesses in Europe.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 European family businesses will play a very important role in boosting the European Union's economy and kick-starting growth, as the European Commission has called for through the so-called 'green economy'. the Juncker Investment Plan, because more than 60% of all businesses in the European Union are family businesses. It is therefore incomprehensible that politicians pay less and less attention to family businesses. As a result of the lack of interest, family businesses have therefore been put in a very difficult situation, because family businesses no longer fall within the definition of small and medium-sized enterprises, but at the same time they are often too small to be defined as large enterprises, which means that they cannot benefit from specific financing opportunities or many other exceptions. Family businesses need specific European legislation, and politicians in this important part of the business sector must pay legitimate attention.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report rightly highlights the role played by family businesses in the economy and in maintaining jobs even at this time of severe economic crisis. That is why it calls for a legal framework that is better suited to this particular form of enterprise.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on family businesses in Europe because, although it understands the vital role of family businesses in development in Europe, it nevertheless fails to propose substantial solutions and remains committed to the ideas that led to the current situation.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ As shadow rapporteur I voted in favour of report on family businesses. I am glad to see this report coming to plenary emphasising that Member States have exclusive competency in taxation matters.  This report highlights the issues facing family businesses and their economic contribution to various constituencies without calling for more Europe.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Family businesses play a significant role for the economic growth and social development, by decreasing the unemployment rate, and for very much needed investments in human capital. Thanks to their transnational dimension and their multi-generational character, they reinforce the stability of the economy. And since not all 28 EU Member States have specific structures to serve their needs, I welcome the initiative to better adjust EU legislation to the reality, assisting the family businesses to benefit from funding programmes and from reduction in red tape (excessive regulation). We indeed require more data, facts and figures from the Member States to better understand their challenges. In respect to the importance of this group of entrepreneurs, we need to provide support where it is needed, by determining if the proposed changes to EU law have effects on family businesses and, if so, to identify them.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of Angelika Niebler's report on support for European family businesses. The report draws attention to the fact that family farms used to make a significant contribution to the recovery of the European economy and still play a significant role in economic and social development, in reducing unemployment, especially among young people, and in investing in human capital. The report also discusses, inter alia, the importance of policies for family businesses, which can stimulate entrepreneurship and motivate European families to start their own family businesses. The problem is that many family businesses, which no longer fit into the definition of SMEs but are far from being large companies, cannot benefit from certain support opportunities or be exempted from certain administrative obligations. This inevitably leads to unnecessary bureaucracy, which is particularly burdensome for these medium-sized family businesses. It reminds the Commission that the majority of family businesses are SMEs and that it is therefore essential to apply the 'think small first' principle in order for EU legislation to be better adapted to real circumstances and the needs of these businesses. It is also important to allow them to benefit from aid schemes and facilities for bureaucratic expenditure. It calls on the Commission to examine whether all existing instruments to support SMEs and/or individual enterprises can be extended to medium-sized family businesses.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With regard to priorities number one, which are clearly support for jobs, growth and investment, I voted positively in favour of this report. Statistics show that the successes of tighter EU economic and fiscal policy management are already being felt, with the European economy slowly recovering from the crisis. In my opinion, however, Europe knows more, and we are far from exhausted. It is important to create a favourable investment climate for our businesses and, overall, to improve entrepreneurship throughout the EU and to play a particularly decisive role in overcoming the financial and economic crisis and re-invigorating the economy, especially our family businesses. However, the concept of a family business as defined by the European Commission in 2009 is not legally binding and is not applied in individual Member States. This means that many family businesses, which no longer fit into the definition of SMEs but are far from being large companies, cannot benefit from certain aid opportunities or be exempted from certain obligations. This inevitably leads to unnecessary bureaucracy, which is particularly burdensome for family businesses. Moreover, many family businesses are compulsively trying to remain within the limits of the criteria set by the Commission for SMEs. The consequences are clear: they do not hire new employees, they prevent an increase in profits or turnover, and thus automatically further growth. Remediation of these problems must be a priority.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I would first like to congratulate Mrs Niebler on the work she has done in her report on family businesses in Europe. It should be said that family businesses are usually the companies that give the best results in assessments on the work environment, quality of the workplace and stability: a model that we must be able to move to the European business model. Today, family businesses account for more than 60% of total enterprises and 50% of private sector jobs. That is why I believe that from this Parliament we must send a clear signal of support to family businesses, to their access to finance and that is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Family businesses, although they are a driving force in the European economy, unfortunately suffer from a number of problems that limit their potential. The report analyses the problems that Europe must be able to tackle without fear in order to give concrete answers, in particular that linked to the bureaucratic and fiscal difficulties in the succession of the same. I therefore strongly voted in favour of the report, in the hope that these words will be followed by effective and appropriate regulatory development.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. Although family businesses in Europe are a fundamental resource of the European economic market, they still suffer from major gaps in the recognition of certain fundamental rights, linked in particular to the classification of women, thus having the limits to the growth and integration of women into the world of work and increasing them in relation to the development potential of the companies themselves. In fact, women often find many walls to real and effective integration, even though they are an integral part of family businesses, and above all to adequate recognition of role and compensation, which unfortunately still stands below 16% compared to men. Investing in family businesses means that Europe is committed to growth and developing the market of the future, and it is essential to do so today, regardless of the recognition and inclusion and training of the female figure.  That is why I agree with Europe's call for a commitment to ensure equal gender opportunities and equal opportunities for training within family businesses and to adopt a single definition of family businesses for all Member States, as a career tool for both genders.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP own-initiative report on family businesses in Europe because I believe that family businesses are a backbone of the European economic fabric. We are talking about a share of almost 60% of companies in the EU, which create almost half of the jobs in the private sector, and which are spread, by different models, in all Member States. I therefore believe it is crucial for the EU to support and help family businesses overcome everyday challenges, such as access to finance, internationalisation, innovation and the quality of the workforce.
