I believe it is essential to support a type of company that is traditionally linked to the territory and offers, especially in rural and disadvantaged areas, a fundamental employment function, giving employment to minorities and disadvantaged people and guaranteeing a kind of territorial welfare. Finally, I agree with the EP's request to the Member States to adapt national tax and civil legislation to this type of economic activity, and the call for greater consideration at EU level of the interests of family businesses and the consequences that Community legislation has on their activities.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on family businesses in Europe today, partly because I managed to win a majority of Parliament to introduce the traditional concept of 'honourable merchant'. Many family entrepreneurs in Europe exemplify this value-oriented form of economic commerce – and we would do well to give the honourable businessman a more European dimension.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Reviving the economy, creating jobs and promoting growth: family businesses in Europe make an important contribution to this. In politics, however, they often receive little attention. I am therefore committed to ensuring that family businesses receive more support at European level in the future.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ More than 60% of all enterprises in the European Union are family-run, and they account for about 40-50% of jobs in the private sector. Family businesses moreover take a longer-term view than non-owner-run businesses given they want to ensure that the success continues in following generations. But despite the importance of these businesses for our economy, they are faced with many challenges: many do not meet the criteria to be considered an SME, meaning that a lot of potential funding is lost, or try to remain below the threshold by limiting recruitment. Many also struggle with ensuring succession at the top, causing 150 000 closures each year at the cost of 600 000 jobs. That is why I supported the Niebler report, which calls for Member States to collect more data and promote exchanges of best practices. That way we can create the right framework on issues like corporate taxation and national taxation on inheritance and gifts so we can offer robust support to these vital motors of our economy.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the text aware of the importance of supporting the small and medium-sized family business, which is very majority in the face of the large family business (which includes multinational companies that enjoy unacceptable tax and legal advantages for which we demand greater co-responsibility). We believe that the amendments introduced by our group improve the initial text, and we think it is positive that this type of business is explicitly recognized and its problems and particularities envisaged in the report.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which addresses the role of family businesses in the financial and economic crisis and how, at an EU level, we can ensure the right framework conditions to prevent job losses.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because family businesses are the most important source of private sector employment in Europe. They represent more than 60% of EU businesses and thus contribute to the continuity, renewal and growth of the European economy. Family businesses have traditionally become more long-term and thus implement sustainable and reasoned management processes. Many family-owned businesses are no longer part of the definition of small and medium-sized enterprises but are far from large enterprises. As a result, they cannot benefit from certain aid schemes or be exempt from certain obligations. The result is unnecessary constraints, which this report aims to resolve.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ On the resolution on family businesses in Europe, I have voted positively. The truth is that family-run businesses consist 60% of all enterprises in the European Union, thus the EU must take care, in order to increase the growth of economy and create the positive environment for the further establishment of family enterprises within the EU. Therefore, to prevent the bankruptcies and other failures that trigger family businesses to shut down, policymakers must create the right framework conditions to prevent these job losses. The EU should provide assistance where it is needed. In my opinion, this resolution is particularly objected towards the improvement of business environment which I am in favour of.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of Angelika Niebler's report on support for European family businesses. The report draws attention to the fact that family farms used to make a significant contribution to the recovery of the European economy and still play a significant role in economic and social development, in reducing unemployment, especially among young people, and in investing in human capital. The report also discusses, inter alia, the importance of policies for family businesses, which can stimulate entrepreneurship and motivate European families to start their own family businesses. The problem is that many family businesses, which no longer fit into the definition of SMEs but are far from being large companies, cannot benefit from certain support opportunities or be exempted from certain administrative obligations. This inevitably leads to unnecessary bureaucracy, which is particularly burdensome for these medium-sized family businesses. It reminds the Commission that the majority of family businesses are SMEs and that it is therefore essential to apply the 'think small first' principle in order for EU legislation to be better adapted to real circumstances and the needs of these businesses. It is also important to allow them to benefit from aid schemes and facilities for bureaucratic expenditure. It calls on the Commission to examine whether all existing instruments to support SMEs and/or individual enterprises can be extended to medium-sized family businesses.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was pleased to vote in favour of this report which specifically looks at the support for family businesses, particularly in the context of SMEs have always been a top policy priority for ALDE. With more than 60% of all enterprises in the EU being family run and accounting for about 45% of jobs in the private sector, family businesses have a crucial role to play in addressing the financial crisis and reviving the economy. With an estimated 150 000 business forced to close every year, we policy-makers need to create the right framework conditions to prevent these losses and provide the necessary cost-efficient infrastructures in order to ensure competitiveness, renewal, growth and sustainability of these family businesses.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because family businesses can play a crucial role in addressing the financial and economic crisis and in reviving the European economy. More than 60% of all enterprises in the EU are family run, and they account for 40-50% of jobs in the private sector. Family businesses take a longer-term view than non-owner-run businesses: they want to ensure that the business is also economically successful in the following generations.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst there are some worthy enough elements in this report, its scope was so wide to render it meaningless. I therefore joined with my group in abstaining on a fairly worthless text.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the text aware of the importance of supporting the small and medium-sized family business, which is very majority in the face of the large family business (which includes multinational companies that enjoy unacceptable tax and legal advantages for which we demand greater co-responsibility). We believe that the amendments introduced by our group improve the initial text, and we think it is positive that this type of business is explicitly recognized and its problems and particularities envisaged in the report.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Vote for. I stress the importance of establishing recognition of family businesses that do not correspond to the definition of SMEs. I also stress the importance that these companies have in the economic core of our current society.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on family businesses in Europe because of the importance family businesses have for starting an economy, as over 60% of businesses in the European Union are family-friendly. I support their intention to be helped by various measures and incentives to survive on the European market, as I believe that growth, investment and job promotion must be one of the key priorities of the European Commission.  I am convinced that this type of enterprise can also be successful in the long term due to the fact that such structures strive for economic performance for future generations. However, a large number of family businesses have serious problems when the issue of inheritance is raised due to various legal-formal but also technical reasons, such as taxation. I therefore believe that the legal framework needs to be adapted to make it easier for them to address the transitional stage of succession and thereby fully unleash their growth potential for the benefit of the union as a whole.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report provides relevant observations about family businesses. It is very favourable to the development of the latter in the long term and, above all, to their transmission... while recalling that "legislation on direct taxation and inheritance is the responsibility of the Member States".  So I voted for this report.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 It has been repeated for decades that the European economy is based on family businesses and that they are its foundation. The recent economic crisis has made very clear the strength of these companies, mainly due to their long-term development strategy and lack of pursuit of rapid profit. Unfortunately, many family businesses face difficulties in accessing finance, with excessive administrative requirements or a tax system. The fact that 150 000 European companies are liquidated every year due to succession difficulties and therefore nearly 600 000 people lose their jobs shows very clearly the scale of this phenomenon. Therefore, measures are needed to protect family businesses. I agree with the rapporteur that the member states have a fundamental role to play in this regard. The Union has little influence here, as it is often about tax policy and internal labour legislation. An attempt to create a single Pan-European definition of a family business could be a good step, but this requires taking into account local specificities in each Member State. The Union should also think about some form of promotion of this business model in countries with a small tradition of family businesses. It is also worth getting involved in preparing family businesses for generational change, so that the number of closed businesses does not increase dramatically in the coming years.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Niebler report on family businesses, which points out that 60% of businesses in Europe are family-owned businesses and that these businesses, which generate many local jobs, often face difficulties in accessing financing or in ensuring their transfer. The report thus underlines the urgency for governments to focus more on this category of businesses, an initiative which I fully share.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which aims to harmonize the definition of family businesses at European level in order to deal more effectively with their specific problems. All the more so since they represent 60% of companies in Europe and are therefore an important source of employment.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. Family businesses are an important backbone of the European economy. The report comprehensively identifies the specific challenges of family businesses and outlines solutions to improve the framework conditions. I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this measure: more than 60% of businesses in the European Union are family businesses, which provide 40-50 % of jobs in the private sector. These numbers alone show us the decisive role that these realities can play in overcoming the financial and economic crisis, promoting European recovery. In the long term, and in relation to companies that are not run by owners, these companies make a decisive contribution to ensuring European competitiveness vis-vis other global players.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission estimates that around 70% of all enterprises in Europe are family businesses, which create between 40% and 60% of jobs in the private sector. Therefore, it is worth a deeper analysis of the specifics of this type of business and possible incentives. Such enterprises are characterised by long-term and social responsibility, strengthen the social dimension of the EU economy, and play an important role in the economic development of more remote and less advanced regions, in particular as regards the self-employment of young people and job creation in rural areas.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. This report entitled "Family Enterprises in Europe" recalls that 85% of European companies are family-owned enterprises, representing 60% of private sector jobs. These enterprises are deeply rooted in their location and are factors in preserving jobs in rural areas and devastated areas, thus contributing to the fight against the ageing of the population and the depopulation of certain regions. Member States are encouraged to encourage the development of specific infrastructure, as well as to ensure the viability of businesses, especially start-ups. The report encourages states to provide specific measures, such as administrative and fiscal simplification, improving the legal framework for the transmission of these enterprises, and promoting training activities. I voted in favour of this text.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because it supports the inheritance of family businesses, and pays tribute to their role in the economic performance of the Member States.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite being a necessary boost from Europe's small and medium-sized enterprises, it implies a position in favour of large companies with this type of ownership. Family businesses account for 85% of European companies and generate 60% of private employment, this fundamental relevance requires support measures to support our production system. It is because of the important support measures proposed in this report that we have not been able to vote against it. However, there is explicit support that calls for making the large family business a beneficiary of the support measures currently received by SMEs. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. I will never tire of recognising and highlighting the importance of family businesses (mostly SMEs) to the European economy. They have always been a very important part of our economy and culture, being creators of vast benefits for all citizens.  That is why I believe that we have an obligation to strive to help them meet the challenges they must face constantly and reduce them as much as possible.  I believe that this report is well on track, as it recognises the value of family businesses, highlights the main challenges they face and proposes a number of measures and ways to alleviate the main financial and administrative pitfalls that exist.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. According to 2009 Commission report 60% of all businesses in the EU are family businesses, accounting for 40-50% of all jobs in the private sector. Family businesses mostly bear a long-term perspective, aimed to last over generations, presenting a different reality than regular non-owner enterprises. This is an added value, we need to foster in the EU. Currently there is no adequate definition on family businesses; some linger between SMEs and bigger businesses whereas they could not be categorized as big corporations. Without clear legal definition, family businesses could face unnecessary red tape and would not be eligible to funds that they actually would be entitled to. One of the core calls of this report is to have more data, facts and figures from the individual Member States in order to better understand the issues and challenges that the family businesses are facing. Proper data would not only allow decision makers on the EU and national level to exchange best practices, but to learn about the situation on the ground and provide best policy to facilitate the sustainability of family businesses.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which addresses the role of family businesses in the financial and economic crisis and how we can prevent at an EU level the right framework conditions to prevent job losses.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 8 September 2015, at a plenary session in Strasbourg, I supported the report on family businesses in Europe. 85% of all European businesses are so-called family businesses, which now also create more than 60% of private sector jobs. Huge differences in the typology and structure of these entities across the EU justify the need for new legislation by the European institutions. Most family businesses have special relations with both the territory in which they operate and their employees. However, it should be noted that not all family businesses always show the aforementioned positive effects. Some family businesses nowadays can be successfully compared with the world's largest corporations. The text of the report calls for support for this type of business through soft law, so I believe that the report could have a positive impact on this type of business. Unfortunately, the report lacks a proper definition of a family business that excludes huge family businesses (the size of corporations) as beneficiaries of these support measures.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of Angelika Niebler's report on support for European family businesses. The report draws attention to the fact that family farms used to make a significant contribution to the recovery of the European economy and still play a significant role in economic and social development, in reducing unemployment, especially among young people, and in investing in human capital. The report also discusses, inter alia, the importance of policies for family businesses, which can stimulate entrepreneurship and motivate European families to start their own family businesses. The problem is that many family businesses, which no longer fit into the definition of SMEs but are far from being large companies, cannot benefit from certain support opportunities or be exempted from certain administrative obligations. This inevitably leads to unnecessary bureaucracy, which is particularly burdensome for these medium-sized family businesses. It reminds the Commission that the majority of family businesses are SMEs and that it is therefore essential to apply the 'think small first' principle in order for EU legislation to be better adapted to real circumstances and the needs of these businesses. It is also important to allow them to benefit from aid schemes and facilities for bureaucratic expenditure. It calls on the Commission to examine whether all existing instruments to support SMEs and/or individual enterprises can be extended to medium-sized family businesses.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this report because I am fundamentally against the EU accepting any legislation in the area of family businesses, for the EU to accept binding definitions of family businesses and against nonsensical, wasteful programmes such as 'Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs'.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. According to the definition, a family business in the European Union is one in which most decision-making rights are owned by the founder or person who bought the company and the closest associates. Analyses show that more than 80 percent of all European companies are family-owned and employ 60 percent of people in the private sector.  I supported The Niebler Mp's report, which highlights the importance and benefits of this form of entrepreneurship, and calls for further steps towards the development of family businesses, especially in the context of financing, i.e. not limiting investment, and creating new jobs.   Since the term is not officially defined in Croatia, there is no accurate data on the number and impact of family businesses, but the same numbers are speculated as at Union level. They often face economic and financial challenges and administrative and legal obstacles. Also, sometimes the problem of private-business relations arises, but this private aspect brings perseverance and commitment to survive in the most difficult moments of the crisis. This is why family businesses are the lifebloods of the economy and can be a key contributor to the Union in reviving it. We need to pay more attention to them, create rules, definitions and legislation so that Member States can compare data more easily and share positive practices. It is important for family businesses to provide quality sources of financing and a positive investment climate.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 More than 60% of all businesses in the Union are family businesses. They represent a relatively stable form of business, which mainly aims to develop the business, provide employment and income to family members and maintain the business for future generations. Taking into account the specificities of family businesses, an appropriate legal and economic environment, these may be one of the most important and stable sources of employment in the coming period. Due to the many difficulties involved in transferring businesses to other family members, around 600 000 jobs a year will be lost. The most common reason is national legislation. It is therefore necessary to adapt legislation which takes into account the sale, inheritance and donation of family businesses, the possibilities of financing undertakings, the provision of various forms of support and the conditions of employment of family members.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The promotion of jobs, growth and investment is the top priority in the political guidelines for the new European Commission unveiled by Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker at the beginning of his term of office in the summer of 2014 - and rightly so: the financial and economic crisis has meant that, throughout the EU, some 25 million people are still unemployed and there are over 5 million young people under 25 years of age without work. GDP has plummeted during the crisis in some EU Member States to double digits. Family businesses can play a crucial role in addressing the financial and economic crisis and in reviving the economy.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on family businesses in Europe. These enterprises play a significant role in the economic growth of social and regional development in terms of employment, knowledge transfer and land organisation. They are in fact the largest source of employment, providing 40/50 % of jobs in the private sector. The report stresses the need to provide assistance to smaller family businesses by promoting alternative forms of lending to them, such as credit unions, and to create special instruments for financing transfers to prevent liquidity problems.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 More than 60% of European businesses are family-run. They provide 40-50% of jobs in the private sector. Unlike other categories of enterprises, family businesses ensure greater competitiveness, since the owner of the business will always set itself the objective of ensuring the economic soundness of his company, for the benefit of subsequent generations. For these reasons, I felt it necessary to support mrs Niebler's report, which points out that family businesses are a good starting point, in the light of a rapid economic recovery.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. Family businesses remain now one of Europe's main economic and social drivers. We need to work so they can continue and increase their activity. That is why I support the report of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, which once again draws attention to this sector and challenges us to take measures that truly help small entrepreneurs maintain and strengthen their activity and continue in line with job creation. We must establish the right conditions so that they can do so and eliminate all the remaining locks that complicate their work.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Family businesses are an important backbone for the European economy, the specific challenges of which are tackled by the report with many proposed solutions. However, it is worth be careful that family entrepreneurship in the classical sense is not taken as a cover for large multinationals in order to collect subsidies, to obtain tax advantages, etc. (e.B: VW, Roche, Arcelor Mittal, which really do not need subsidies). Nevertheless, the benefits outweigh the benefits, and I therefore agree here.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report notes that, like SMEs, family businesses contribute to growth and job creation in Europe. It seeks to develop a definition of this type of business. However, they cover very different realities: agricultural enterprise, mid-sized companies, transnational or even large multinational companies... Ultimately, the aim is Eu-17 legislation for family businesses to remove "unnecessary" constraints. However, the first constraint of a small business, family or not, is its empty order book, a direct consequence of austerity policies on household consumption, when multinationals are saved by export. A harmonization of legislation mixing the needs of family empires and small family businesses will not be for the benefit of the latter.  The rapporteur of the German CSU here confuses aid to family SMEs and aid to family multinationals on the pretext that family management of a company would ipso facto introduce "values" of integrity and social responsibility.  Simply wanting to create a specific category for "family businesses" (including SMEs) is economic nonsense. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. The first priority of the political guidelines of the next European Commission, presented at the beginning of its mandate in the summer of 2014 by Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker, is to promote jobs, growth and investment. The important thing is to create a favourable investment climate for our companies and foster the spirit of entrepreneurship across the EU. Our family businesses, in particular, can play a decisive role in managing the financial and economic crisis and resuming the economy. More than 60% of businesses in the European Union are family businesses, representing 40 to 50% of private sector jobs.  Support for family businesses is therefore essential for a winning strategy for economic growth. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report because it recognises the value of family run businesses as stable contributors to job creation in local economies and addresses specific challenges they face.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. More than 70% of businesses in Europe are family-owned and they account for 60% of private sector jobs. They are an element of growth and stability in the various Member States and symbolize the backbone of the European economy. There is an urgent need to help these companies function and pass on them. That is why I support this report, which provides for a reduction in the administrative burden as a whole and a simplification of the tax procedure. It is by simplifying administrative procedures, reducing transmission costs and creating training programs that we will be able to achieve this goal. Currently, due to the cost and complexity of the procedures, these companies do not easily find successors, prompting entrepreneurs to stop their activities. Such an outcome for companies that have prospered for generations is unacceptable.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In tackling the high number of unemployed across the EU, which is close to 25 million people, with more than 5 million unemployed young people, it is also desirable to focus directly on the businesses that create jobs. These undoubtedly include the so-called family businesses, which are the single largest source of jobs in the private sector. I am one of those who believe that it is family businesses that can play a key role in tackling the financial and economic crisis and in reviving the economy, because they represent more than 60% of all businesses in the European Union and around 40-50% of private sector jobs.  Among the many advantages of family businesses, I would like to highlight the fact that, based on their own history, they are closely linked to a particular location and therefore maintain employment also in regions or rural areas. In addition, family businesses show more social responsibility and respect for their employees in managing resources. I therefore find it sad that, although family businesses play a very important role for our economy, they are given only marginal attention in legislation. So far, there is also no legal definition at EU level.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the Family business in Europe, which states that more than 60% of all enterprises in the European Union are family-run, and they account for about 40-50% of jobs in the private sector. The important point in this report is rather to draw policymakers’ attention to this important group of entrepreneurs and to provide assistance where it is needed. One approach could be (as a transitional measure) to introduce a ‘family business test’, to be performed as part of the impact assessment, in order to determine whether proposed changes to EU law have an impact on family businesses and their structures and, if so, to identify them.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the own-initiative report 'Family businesses in Europe'. With the adoption of this report, we have taken an important step towards improving the framework conditions for family businesses in Europe. More than 60% of all businesses in the EU are family-run and they make an important contribution to revitalising the European economy and creating jobs. They are often more long-term oriented than other companies and are deeply rooted in their location and environment. Nevertheless, family businesses face a number of problems and difficulties, most notably the question of succession at the top of the management board. This is where policy is called for and must create the right framework conditions, especially in the area of inheritance, gift, corporate taxation and transfers of company shares. Today's vote aims to help find sustainable solutions at European level, particularly in this area, without comchanging the sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report notes that family businesses can play a crucial role in overcoming the financial and economic crisis and re-stimulating the economy. More than 60% of all businesses in the European Union are family businesses, providing around 40-50% of jobs in the private economy.  However, many family businesses no longer fit into the definition of SMEs, although they are far from being large companies and therefore cannot benefit from certain aid opportunities or be exempted from certain obligations. This inevitably leads to unnecessary bureaucracy, which is a burden for family businesses. Many family businesses therefore seek to remain within the limits of the criteria set by the Commission for SMEs; they do not hire new employees, prevent profits or turnover from increasing, and thus automatically prevent further growth. The report therefore demands the same attention for family businesses as it has received for SMEs over the past decade.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. Family businesses have made a huge contribution to the substantial growth of the European economy. According to the 2014 Ernst and Young report on family businesses, 85% of all European businesses are family businesses, representing 60% of private sector jobs.  It is important that we move towards the creation of an official European definition of 'family business', which will have to be simple, clear and easy to apply and compare between countries, as it will help to understand their reality and the challenges that these same family businesses face.  I endorse the rapporteur's position, which calls on Member States to promote entrepreneurship education and 'mini-enterprise' projects in schools, as an essential element for the development of more entrepreneurial mindsets. I also call for special attention to be paid to family farms in rural areas of many Member States, where they should promote training specifically for farmers.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report entitled "Family Enterprises in Europe" recalls that 85% of European companies are family-owned enterprises, representing 60% of private sector jobs. These enterprises are deeply rooted in their location and are factors in preserving jobs in rural areas and devastated areas, thus contributing to the fight against the ageing of the population and the depopulation of certain regions. Member States are encouraged to encourage the development of specific infrastructure, as well as to ensure the viability of businesses, especially start-ups. Family businesses are inherently flexible and are excellent for identifying new perspectives and innovations. Constant that the latter are underfunded since the crisis, the report encourages states to provide specific measures, such as administrative and fiscal simplification, improving the legal framework for the transmission of these companies, promoting training activities etc. I have therefore decided to vote in favour of this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which addresses the role of family businesses in the financial and economic crisis and how we can prevent at an EU level the right framework conditions to prevent job losses.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. This report points out that 60% of businesses in Europe are family-owned. These companies often face difficulties in accessing or passing on financing. I voted in favour of this text, which calls on the Commission to examine a definition of these companies at European level, in order to deal with their specific difficulties. The aim is to promote the sustainability of these companies and to preserve local jobs in Europe.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Mrs NIEBLER's report on family businesses in Europe. 60% of businesses in Europe are family-owned. These companies generate many local jobs and often face difficulties in accessing or passing on financing. I support this report which calls on the Commission to examine a european-wide definition of these companies to deal with their specific difficulties. We call on Member States to put in place appropriate conditions to promote their sustainability.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ More than 60% of all enterprises in the European Union are family-run, and they account for about 40-50% of jobs in the private sector. I have voted for this report that will conduct an impact assessment on family businesses that play such an important role in our economy.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report because I believe that family businesses play a significant role in boosting the European Union economy. It has been pointed out in a number of reports that small family businesses have contributed to the recovery of the European economy and have played an important role in favour of economic growth and social development, the reduction of unemployment, especially among young people, and investment in human capital.  Today's report presents the problems and difficulties specific to these small firms, referring in particular to the inequalities between them, and I believe that the problem exists in all European states, including Romania.  In this respect, as the report also proposes, Member States and regional and local authorities must foster, strengthen entrepreneurship, simplify and de-bureaucratise the work of European businesses, provide tax incentives for businesses and other compensation to help women and men working as employees, as self-employed workers or as managers of family businesses to reconcile family and professional life , creating a framework conducive to economic performance.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on family businesses in Europe, which have a significantly higher equity ratio than other enterprises, and it is this high equity ratio that often ensures the economic stability of the business and the stability of the overall economy, while leaving the possibility of further investment in the company. I consider it useful to create a single point of contact for businesses that could act as a contact body for family businesses, particularly in relation to specific issues relating to European legislation and access to EU funds. On the contrary, I consider it unnecessary to set up a permanent working group within the Commission services to carry out administrative work in the form of reporting.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. – Family businesses are an important backbone for the European economy, the specific challenges of which are tackled by the report with many proposed solutions. I believe that family businesses must be promoted, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported, the report calls for the identification of the needs of family businesses for development and for a framework for their better and more profitable operation.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report. In particular, it is necessary to establish a definition of family businesses, which is legally binding and used in all Member States. Legal certainty needs to be ensured, red tape, which is particularly burdensome for family businesses, requires simplification of administrative procedures and tax systems. Family businesses must be able to benefit from certain opportunities for support and must be exempted from certain obligations. Entrepreneurship and start-ups must be promoted at EU level. In order to develop entrepreneurship among more entrepreneurial people, greater promotion in schools and other educational institutions Greater attention must be paid to the long-term existence and promotion of family businesses. The Commission should carry out an impact assessment of the legislation and a feasibility study on the impact on family businesses. In addition, it is essential that the list of beneficiaries of all measures for SMEs and entrepreneurs be extended to include mid-cap family businesses.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. In view of the fact that SMEs make up the majority of the European economic fabric, that the mortality rate of family businesses is high, given the intergenerational transition, and given my continued commitment to SMEs in the Committee on Industry, External Trade, Research and Energy, I felt it was essential to focus on this issue in the hope that the EU would be able to promote the exchange of good practices and provide assistance to businesses to ensure their survival and development.

name: Ева Паунова (PPE)
text: in writing. – Family businesses are the backbone of the European Union's economy and are economic operators that create almost half of private sector jobs. I supported this report because it clearly reflects mine and those of my colleagues in the European People's Party, priorities. Namely – taking measures to improve lending to small businesses, carrying out staff training, promoting innovation and removing administrative and tax barriers. I believe that the European Parliament must be united around taking the family business support measures that the report specifically sets out in order to create a unique ecosystem of prosperous businesses in all EU Member States.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is generally very favourable to family businesses and focuses in particular on the issue of transmission. Moreover, it recalls, for once, the respect of the principle of subsidiarity in one of its recitals. I consider that the economic fabric of small businesses and family businesses is of the u.s m. for the revival of activity and employment in European countries. Similarly, these human-sized companies are best able to develop local development models in short circuits. That is why I support this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ It is well known that small family businesses have contributed greatly to the growth of the European economy and, as such, play an important role in economic recovery, social development, reducing unemployment (especially among young people) and investing in human capital due to the nature of multi-generation family businesses.  Therefore, I support the rapporteur's proposal to propose measures to develop family business models and policies, as there is an idea that family businesses are characterised by high integrity and values that are maintained in their business activities and introduce high standards of corporate social responsibility in relation to employees and the environment, thereby also creating a favourable environment for work-life balance. I see the importance in that policies targeting family businesses could encourage entrepreneurship and motivate European families to start their own family businesses. It is estimated, for example, that 80% of small and medium-sized enterprises in Croatia are family businesses and that more than 60% of private sector employees work there. In addition to the typical problems faced by all entrepreneurs, generational conflicts are common, but definitely the biggest problem is the un timely initiation of the business transfer process, which is why only 30 percent of family businesses survive transfer to another generation.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - In times of recession and economic crisis, job creation, growth and investment are the main policy priorities of the European Union. Particular emphasis has been placed on SMEs and the private sector in general. Family businesses, although neither defined nor legally regulated in most Member States or at European Union level, should be, and are, drivers of the economy.  More than 60 % of the total number of privately owned enterprises in the European Union are family businesses employing 40-50 % of private sector workers. These figures are not negligible, moreover, they speak of the importance of this type of enterprise. The purpose of The Niebler Colleague's report is to encourage the European Commission as well as member states to analyse in more detail their laws for SMEs and to make it mandatory to include family businesses and their specificities in them.  Due to legal regulations and problems of undefinedness, many family businesses, by force of opportunity, try to stay within the framework of small and medium-sized enterprises, resulting in a hampering in the employment of the new workforce and the creation of higher incomes. Therefore, I support Mp Niebler's report and expect a solution to this economically important problem as soon as possible.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased by Parliament’s vote on the family businesses in Europe report. Family businesses are a cornerstone to the EU’s vast economy. They are the single biggest source of employment in the private sector, and have played an enormous role in renewal and growth in the European economy as a whole. In addition, they provide good paying jobs to Europeans across the region and play an important role in encouraging minorities and under-represented groups to participate in local economies. To help support this integral part of the economy, I would like to call on Member States and the Commission to help develop digital entrepreneurship and skills so that family businesses can take complete advantage of emerging and online technologies. I would also urge the Commission to analyse the current legislation which affects family businesses to identify any issues and barriers to growth and success. Family businesses play a crucial role in our economy, and we should do everything in our power to help them thrive.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 More than 60% of businesses in the European Union are family businesses. They provide 40–50 % of jobs in the private sector. Family businesses have a longer-term perspective than companies that are not run by owners, as the latter want the business to be economically sound even in subsequent generations. Family businesses can play a decisive role in overcoming the economic and financial crisis and fostering economic recovery. This type of entrepreneurial activity makes a decisive contribution to ensuring Europe's competitiveness and creating jobs. I have always been in favour of supporting and recognising the economic value of SMEs and, in particular, of family-run micro-enterprises. The latter are in almost all cases very attentive to the socio-economic context of the territory in which they operate and unlike the large industrial groups are much less inclined to relocate their productive activity. For these reasons, too, I have decided to support this proposal by voting in favour of it.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Family businesses now account for more than 60% of total businesses and account for 50% of private sector jobs in the EU. However, these companies often face many obstacles when it comes to changing direction and finding a buyer. The various national laws (taxes, inheritance tax) represent a serious obstacle to the growth of these businesses. For example, the European Parliament adopted an initiative report calling on the European Commission to adopt an integrated policy for family businesses within the Union. I have spoken in favour of this text and I support the importance of such an approach. Family businesses are an important part of the local and regional economy and jobs, it is our duty to promote their interests.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. – (PT) I voted in favour of considering it essential to increase the European Union's support for family businesses, taking into account their weight and importance in national economies.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. Family businesses now account for 60% of European businesses and as many as 50% of jobs. The vast majority are small and medium-sized enterprises made up of two-thirds of private sector employees. As cornerstones of the economic fabric, these structures have been affected in recent years by the effects of the global economic crisis but also by the fiscal inconsistencies put in place by some Member States. That is why I voted in favour of the report 'Family Business in Europe' which aims to provide an institutional, legal and fiscal framework favourable to these companies. This text, supported by the European Parliament, aims in particular to simplify administrative procedures but also to provide theoretical knowledge to business leaders, in order to promote the internationalisation of their activities which constitutes a real source of growth and job creation. The inheritance tax of these companies must also be simplified and adapted so as not to generate liquidity problems when passing on assets.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Family businesses can play a decisive role in managing the financial crisis and resuming the economy. More than 60% of EU companies are family members. They represent 40 to 50% of jobs in the private sector.  Many of these companies are still excluded from funding. However, there is no common definition of family business in the EU (90 definitions), and this should be the first step. We cannot continue to waste the economic potential of this important business sector.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. Family businesses account for more than 60% of businesses in the EU and between 40% and 50% of private sector jobs. However, there is not enough data and research to understand your specific needs and structures. The absence of a specific, simple and harmonised definition of a legally binding family business at European level prevents the collection of comparable data in the various Member States. As this report claims, it is necessary to develop a statistically viable definition at European level of the concept of a family business, including, in addition to purely quantitative criteria, qualitative criteria such as company ownership, control and management, risk and social responsibility or employee participation in the management of business activities. It would also be desirable to set up a permanent working group to deal in a special way with the needs and specificities of these enterprises. The Commission and the Member States should also promote the information and exchange of expertise and good practices, in particular with regard to entrepreneurship and training in management and entrepreneurship. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the difficulties that family businesses in Europe face and underlines the need to change European legislation. The report adopted yesterday puts forward several proposals to the European Commission and the Member States to facilitate the activities of family businesses.  The European Parliament is the request of the Commission to make a legislative proposal to simplify administrative and tax procedures, improve the legal framework governing the transfer of family businesses and introduce specific instruments for the financing of transmission to avoid cash defaults.  To this end, MEPs also called on the Commission to develop a comparative study of the situation of family businesses in the EU and, on this basis, to draw up an inventory of the obstacles to the activities of these companies. Let us not lose sight of the view that family businesses account for almost 85% of European businesses and 60% of private sector jobs.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Family businesses make up 85% of all European businesses, with 60% of private sector jobs. They contribute to the growth of the European economy and contribute to economic growth and social development, generating jobs, especially among young people, and taking an unavoidable role in issues related to regional development.  Most of these companies have a long-term view of their activity, which makes them stable contributors to job creation in their local communities. However, they often face important challenges in accessing finance and transferring business to younger generations.  I therefore agree with the rapporteur's proposals, in particular on the need to create an EU-wide definition to collect comparable data, the importance of introducing the 'family business test' as part of the impact assessment, and the relevance of Member States creating appropriate conditions for the succession of family businesses.  Finally, I welcome the Europe 2020 strategy and its flagship initiatives in this area, which promote the spirit of initiative and entrepreneurship of European citizens, easing them with skills and qualifications that can boost competitiveness and smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. Family businesses in Europe account for more than 60% of businesses and almost 50% of private sector jobs. Despite a long-term vision of growth prospects, these companies often face difficulties in accessing financing or ensuring the transfer of the business to future generations.  I voted in favour of this report which calls on the European Commission to examine ways to collect comparable data, to deal with specific difficulties and to introduce the test for family businesses as provided for in the impact assessment. Finally, it is important that Member States put in place appropriate conditions for the succession of family businesses.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe has been hit by a severe economic and financial crisis. More than 60% of businesses on European soil are family-run and in the private sector 40%-50% of jobs are created by this type of business, which therefore make an essential contribution to ensuring Europe's long-term competitiveness. I am voting in favour, because I am convinced that it is important to consider and protect the added value of this type of enterprise in order to promote economic recovery.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because the report highlights the role played by family businesses in the economy and in maintaining jobs even in times of crisis, and calls for a legal framework more suited to this particular form of enterprise.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the text aware of the importance of supporting the small and medium-sized family business, which is very majority in the face of the large family business (which includes multinational companies that enjoy unacceptable tax and legal advantages for which we demand greater co-responsibility). We believe that the amendments introduced by our group improve the initial text, and we think it is positive that this type of business is explicitly recognized and its problems and particularities envisaged in the report.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite being a necessary boost from Europe's small and medium-sized enterprises, it implies a position in favour of large companies with this type of ownership. Family businesses account for 85% of European companies and generate 60% of private employment, this fundamental relevance requires support measures to support our production system. It is because of the important support measures proposed in this report that we have not been able to vote against it. However, there is explicit support that calls for making the large family business a beneficiary of the support measures currently received by SMEs. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on family businesses given the importance and great socio-economic role they have at both national and European level. Since there is no definition of a family business in terms of turnover, they can be framed both as micro-authorities and as multinationals, and this risks creating uncertainty in the targeted policies to be adopted. I believe that the role played by these companies is of great importance for our economic growth and the reduction of unemployment. The report proposes extending the instruments for SMEs to mid-cap family-run businesses. In addition, it is hoped that the Commission will present a work plan providing for appropriate measures for growth for these enterprises. To this end, I believe it is necessary to make an analysis of the existing rules in order to identify obstacles to their growth and possible internationalisation, allowing family businesses easier access to information on European legislation and funding.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as I am against any attempt to create new EU legislation. I am also against an ‘EU family business test’ in order to provide assistance to family businesses in Europe. This is not a competency of the EU.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which addresses the role of family businesses in the financial and economic crisis and how, at EU level, we can prevent job losses. With the right framework conditions, employment can be better guaranteed, and with more than 60% of all enterprises in the EU being family run – accounting for 40-50% of jobs in the private sector – this report is incredibly important for very many people across Europe.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Family businesses have a unique role to play as they combine the social and economic dimension of entrepreneurship. They are often deeply connected to their place of operation and encourage the development of the local community, for which they bring very significant added value. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am very glad that, more than 6 years after the end of the work of the Commission's group of experts on family businesses, we are once again opening a debate in the EP on this important group of enterprises. I consider this to be particularly important because family businesses account for more than 60% of all European companies and provide between 40% and 50% of all jobs and are an integral part of the economic recovery in the EU. The positive thing about family business is that strong social ties are established within the business and the transfer of knowledge and skills from generation to generation is ensured. But inconsistent legislation across Member States causes many complications in cross-border business, transfers and inheritment of family businesses - 450 000 transfers of family businesses take place every year - with up to 150 000 firms being lost and up to 600 000 jobs lost. The most positive experience of family business within the EU is in the agrarian sector – family farms.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The report here states that family businesses play an important role in economic growth and social development, reducing unemployment and investing in human capital, as the multigenerational nature of family businesses is expected to strengthen the stability of the economy due to their key role in regional development in terms of employment, transfer of know-how and regional planning. I can agree with the written one, but it is necessary to note that there is no universal definition of a family business in the European space at present. Many of the questions raised in the report are not just focused on so-called family businesses, but basically cover any type of entrepreneurship, which I do not agree with. I believe that so-called family businesses are worth more detailed consideration, and I do not approve of the possible intention to reform the definition of 'small and medium-sized enterprises', which would also allow larger 'family businesses' to access funding from EU programmes. The attempt to define a 'family business', which would also require the controversial definition of 'family', is painted in the report with an overly idyllic picture (stabilising economics, high social responsibility towards employees and the environment...). Despite the report's shortcomings, I do not want the problems relating to 'family businesses' to remain intact (e.g. business transfers and forced sales), which is why I abstained.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am pleased that it is the Group of the European People's Party in the EP of which I am a part that has initiated an appeal to the European Commission to report on family business and to set up a special group to assess the state of the family business and to improve the general conditions for this type of business across the EU. Although family businesses do not have such a great tradition in Slovakia, family business is important for the whole EU. I support stronger support for social entrepreneurship and social innovation in the fight against unemployment. It is important that we create a positive environment for the growth of family businesses and, above all, that the level of awareness of the opportunities that arise from this for the employment of young people and women is improved.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the report because it is necessary to set the right and sustainable conditions for the survival and business successes of family farms and businesses, as they account for more than 60% of businesses and almost 50% of private sector jobs across the European Union. Therefore, family farms need to be helped in their development, because it is evident what their impact on the European economy is and how many people they employ.  Furthermore, they are constantly growing, modernizing and their growth trend is positive, so they are a stable collaborator in job creation and employment in their local communities. For all of the above, family farms need to be provided with conditions to help cope with the challenges they face on a daily basis, and since this report is striving for this, I support it.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which addresses the role of family businesses in the financial and economic crisis and how we can prevent at an EU level the right framework conditions to prevent job losses.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal because I do not agree with activities in support of "family businesses". It is an unquestionable fact that family businesses in the European Union are suffering today as a result of the high administrative and tax burden. However, other entrepreneurs in the EU are also suffering. The solution is therefore to reduce the administrative and tax burden for all, and not just for the bureaucrats selected groups of people.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on family businesses in Europe. Family businesses are one of the drivers of economic growth and employment in Slovenia and in the world. In Slovenia they account for between 60 and 80 percent of all enterprises. One of the bigger problems for family businesses remains the transition to the next generation. According to some data, only a third of family businesses know how to successfully solve the succession problem and do business in the second generation, much less manage to move to the third generation. Eu-assisted actions, such as the exchange of experience between countries and support for research projects on the factors of a successful transition, could improve the situation. Of course, stable macroeconomic policy, a well-functioning legal environment for business and flexible labour legislation are extremely important for good business and the development of family businesses.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on family businesses in Europe, as I agree with the assessment of the role of family businesses on which this report is based. Family businesses are an important part of the economy of each Member State. Family businesses focus on the long-term success of their business, bringing much-needed stability to the labour market and contributing to well-functioning local communities. These qualities of family businesses should be highlight and efforts should be made to improve the conditions for their business so as to ensure their long-term existence even in the event of the emergence of a new generation of owners. This is not about undermining the competences of the Member States, but about alerting them to an issue whose solution will certainly benefit the citizens of all Member States.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. It is always a pleasure to visit family businesses in my constituency; they make a significant and vital contribution to economic growth, unemployment reduction and social development. I welcome much of this report, in particular its efforts to identify the challenges and barriers to growth facing family businesses and to seek means to address them.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report is part of a major effort to institutionalise EU support for family businesses that are too large and cannot be considered SMEs. Although the title "family businesses in Europe" misleads by referring to SMEs, this report mainly refers to very large family businesses, even large multinational companies. In particular, Member States are being asked to promote tax facilities, tax exemptions, easy access for large family businesses to various sources of finance, growth incentives, etc., arguing that strengthening large family businesses at the same time strengthens the EU's competitiveness and increases the strength of the European economy.  For us it is clear that it is not large companies and multinational companies that need support but SMEs and workers. Not only do we not support proposals for favourable treatment of large enterprises, but we support tackling unfair competition and preventing monopolistic and oligopolistic phenomena. We are fighting against such unpopular, anti-labour and anti-development economic policies. For the above reasons we abstained in the vote. We did not vote against, as the report includes individual positive reports on SMEs and the need to support them in different ways.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 This report, while understanding the vital role of family businesses in development in Europe, fails to propose meaningful solutions and remains committed to the ideas that led to the current situation.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Family businesses are a special category of enterprises. These are often companies for whom long-term business planning, even for generations, as well as a special perception of the role, tasks and functions of the employee are often more important than immediate profit. These companies are also of great importance for vocational education and for cultivating the traditions and development of work culture and business. For these reasons, the European Union should be an advocate for the interests of family businesses, support them and help them develop them. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the Niebler report on family-owned businesses. This is not because we are against this type of enterprise, but because a paragraph has been passed in the report calling on the Commission to extend the beneficiaries of the funds allocated to SMEs to mid-caps and to make them use of the specific instruments existing for SMEs (which by definition are only those which meet certain budgetary criteria). , turnover and number of employees). It is already very difficult for small businesses to apply for these tools, and the request approved in this report makes the reality of SMEs even more difficult: MID-CAPS have more resources both from an organisational and human resources point of view, while small and medium-sized enterprises are struggling to apply for European funds or funding through programmes such as COSME or Horizon2020. This runs counter to our objective of protecting a fundamental category for our country such as SMEs.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Family run businesses provide a significant financial contribution to the EU’s economy. It is estimated that over 60% of all enterprises in the EU are family-run, accounting for about 40-50% of jobs in the private sector. The current report aims to draw attention to this important group of entrepreneurs by exploring ways to foster their economic contribution while addressing some of the challenges this group is facing. One of the main challenges the report presents is the lack of a formal definition to ‘family business’. With over 90 definitions used by the different Member States, some family businesses find themselves struggling with red tape and restrictions on access to funding. Moreover, in the absence of data, facts and figures on the activity of family businesses in the different Member States we are unable to design policies that could better assess the challenges family businesses are facing, or exchange best case practices. By aiming to tackle these issues, this report sets in place the right conditions for the succession of family business in Europe. Its adoption in plenary demonstrate the Parliament's commitment and support to this important business community.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on family business in Europe. Creation of good conditions for business is one of my key agendas and I hope this report will contribute to this aim. Furthermore, there are certain specifics of family business which should be taken into account while creating a new legislation or rules for business in general.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a report highlighting the contribution of family businesses to the growth of the European economy and social development, as well as reducing unemployment and investing in human capital, as they create and retain jobs in rural and disadvantaged areas, thereby contributing to reducing population ageing and emigration.  I believe it is essential to adapt EUROPEAN Union legislation to the real conditions and needs of family businesses in order to benefit from funding programmes without creating unnecessary burdens on businesses. In addition, I support the call on the Commission and the Member States to provide information on internationalisation opportunities and to ensure the exchange of experience and best practices.  If Member States simplify administrative and taxation procedures and improve the legal framework for the transfer of family businesses, I believe they will prevent forced sales, which will contribute to the development of the whole economy.  In order to adapt businesses to a very rapidly changing environment, I believe that one of the most important items is the training programme for small entrepreneurs, and this will certainly contribute to establishing a one-stop-go-matter for businesses at European level to turn to and get help on specific issues relating to EU legislation and access to finance.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on family businesses in Europe. Family businesses are very important for the economy in Europe, they account for more than 60% of all businesses and contribute to 50% of all jobs in the private sector. In Slovenia, most family businesses are small to medium-sized enterprises and, like others, face heavier access to finance. The transfer of business to the next generation is also extremely important. The State should not hinder these small businesses, which have particularly solid and long-term business because of their family ties, with additional bureaucratic burdens and high taxes. The European Union is also aware of their importance. This is precisely why it has already tried to draw up a single definition that would define more precisely when an undertaking is regarded as a family company. This definition would be linked to various rights which are extremely important for long-term, viability.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the text aware of the importance of supporting the small and medium-sized family business, which is very majority in the face of the large family business (which includes multinational companies that enjoy unacceptable tax and legal advantages for which we demand greater co-responsibility). We believe that the amendments introduced by our group improve the initial text, and we think it is positive that this type of business is explicitly recognized and its problems and particularities envisaged in the report.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Family businesses have strong local ties and, for that reason, create and maintain jobs also in rural and disadvantaged areas, helping to combat the worrying unemployment figure and the process of ageing and depopulation that affects many EU regions; therefore we urge the Commission and Member States, to develop cost-effective infrastructure to ensure competitiveness, renewal, growth and sustainability of these companies, particularly micro-enterprises and emerging companies, and facilitate intersectoral collaboration and border and helping them to grow and internationalize in this borderless Europe. Therefore it is also important to have a fair tax treatment and to study alternative forms of lending for these small family businesses. Equally important is the reduction of administrative burden for these businesses to facilitate entrepreneurship. I support this proposal in order to strengthen and consolidate these businesses in European territory.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The report supports family businesses, their long-term development and, above all, their transmission. The report also points out that 'legislation on direct taxation and inheritance is the responsibility of Member States'.  I therefore vote for this text.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As the European labour market is experiencing a slow recovery period after a long economic and social crisis, I believe that the role of the European Union is to actively support and facilitate the creation and development of family businesses. Family businesses make up 85% of all European businesses, providing 60% of private sector jobs. Moreover, as this report shows, they contribute substantially to the sustainable development of the European economy and to the reduction of unemployment, especially among young people.  Given the importance of these family affairs, I believe that it is more than necessary for the European Union to find sustainable solutions to the administrative, financial and fiscal obstacles faced by family businesses. In my opinion, the Commission should invite the Member States to review their tax policy, given that inheritance and donation taxes are often far too high, often leading to the disappearance of family businesses. Ownership, enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU, must be fully protected. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the Family Business Report in Europe.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The number one priority in the policy guidelines presented by the President of the European Commission is to create jobs, support growth and investment. The role of family businesses in the small and medium-sized enterprises sector is strengthened. The report shall relate to the analysis of specific specific features and make forward-looking proposals. I voted in favour of this initiative.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Family businesses play a very important role for the European economy, but unfortunately the policymakers pay little attention to them. More than 60% of businesses in the European Union are family businesses, providing around 40-50% of private sector jobs. Although the European Commission established a definition of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in 2003, the same cannot be said of family businesses. In 2009, a group of experts from the European Commission tried to follow this example and establish a definition that is not legally binding, however, and in some Member States it does not even apply. It is therefore not possible to collect comparable data from EU Member States in order to draw attention to the particular situation, needs and economic achievements of family businesses.  The European Parliament resolution draws attention to the need for a definition at European level and proposes, inter alia, the creation of a one-stop shop for businesses to serve as a European contact point for family businesses and family business interest groups and to provide assistance on specific issues, in particular with regard to European legislation and access to EU funding.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the text aware of the importance of supporting the small and medium-sized family business, which is very majority in the face of the large family business (which includes multinational companies that enjoy unacceptable tax and legal advantages for which we demand greater co-responsibility). We believe that the amendments introduced by our group improve the initial text, and we think it is positive that this type of business is explicitly recognized and its problems and particularities envisaged in the report.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ My abstention in this report was due to the fact that there is no uniform definition of family businesses (because of different civil law and private company laws in the MS), and that actually 85% of all EU companies are family businesses. They can therefore be small, medium-sized or large, listed or unlisted.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. Family businesses account for more than 60% of businesses and up to 50% of employment in the European Union. Access to finance and business transfer tax issues are very important issues covered in this report and are key to finding solutions and helping these companies continue to thrive and create jobs. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR)
text: Written. The N-VA delegation voted in favour of this report because it recognises the added value of family businesses to the European Union. These companies are an important building block of our economy and it is our job to have an ear for their needs.  In Flanders, too, there are many family-owned companies from small to large that often face specific problems. Unfortunately, there is no clear definition of family businesses to date.
