As a result, these companies are slipping through the cracks of the European network. For European subsidies, too, these companies are often in a grey area. From Europe, therefore, we certainly have to step up, but the Member States also bear responsibility. The fiscal and social aspect remains a competence of the Member States. The report is clear on this and therefore deserves our support.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'It is high time that the European Commission paid special attention to family businesses operating in the European Union. This resolution calls, among other things, for the existing instruments of European aid to be made more accessible to SMEs and, emphatically, to family businesses. Some family-owned enterprises are outside the scope of SMEs and will no longer be eligible for certain European subsidies. The Commission should also pay more attention to this. It is up to Europe to give this target group a little more breathing space, especially given the amount of jobs they create. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The European Parliament today adopted a report on the role of family businesses in the European Union. These companies account for 85% of European companies and 60% of private sector jobs in Europe. They therefore have an essential role, particularly in terms of the resolution of the effects of the financial and economic crisis and the revitalization of the economy. The vast majority of these companies are small and medium-sized enterprises that are facing more international competition than ever before and the lack of financing available to them. So it's time, more than ever, to support them.  Despite their importance, the characteristics and needs of these companies remain poorly understood at European level, as the realities are different. Since 2009, there has been a fairly vague definition that means that Member States continue to apply rules on aid to these companies, which vary considerably from one Member State to another.  This report outlines a number of recommendations for harmonizing these practices. I'm voting for.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The financial and economic crisis has led to around 25 million people across the EU being unemployed, with the number of unemployed young people under the age of more than 25 million. Gross domestic product suffered a double-digit fall in some Member States during the crisis. European family businesses can play a decisive role in managing the financial and economic crisis and resuming the economy. The European Commission's expert group found in its final report in 2009 that more than 60% of EU companies are family businesses, accounting for 40 to 50% of private sector jobs.  However, for lack of a clear definition of this concept, the same group found that there were more than 90 different definitions of family business across the EU. We follow the need to clarify this issue by articulating it with the definition of SME company, but also to give concrete answers to various questions, such as succession.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Family businesses are an important backbone for the European economy, the specific challenges of which are tackled by the report with many proposed solutions. However, it is worth be careful that family entrepreneurship in the classical sense is not taken as a cover for large multinationals in order to collect subsidies, to obtain tax advantages, etc. (e.B: VW, Roche, Arcelor Mittal, which really do not need subsidies). Nevertheless, the benefits outweigh the benefits, and I therefore agree here.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I would like to thank the colleague Anna Zéborska (Slovakia, KDH) for getting this report off the road. After all, it was the long-standing head of the Family Intergroup who initiated the reporting procedure at the beginning of this parliamentary term. I am voting in favour of the report with my ECR Group. My main concern is the removal of unnecessary obstacles through EU legislation, and therefore the strengthening of family businesses. The less EU legislation and the less state regulation, the more personal and corporate ownership is promoted.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – Because family businesses account for more than 60% of EU businesses and provide around 50% of private sector jobs, I welcome my colleague Angelika Niebler's initiative to produce a report focusing on this subject. I voted for this report in view of the fact that family businesses have an extremely important role for the European economy, but the policymakers pay too little attention to them. I agree with the rapporteur's finding that many family businesses are desperately trying to stay below the threshold set by the European Commission's SME criteria, and this has obvious consequences: family businesses stop recruiting to avoid an increase in income or turnover, which stops any growth. I am convinced that family businesses can play a decisive role in overcoming the financial and economic crisis and in revitalising the economy.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 Supporting family businesses is extremely important, their role in the European economy, their reliability, their contribution to social development and the reduction of unemployment are fundamental factors to look out for when analysing their situation. The report calls for the definition of a universal definition of 'family business', which will at the same time take into account the conditions in each Member State, the size and sector of its activities and serve statistical purposes, the inclusion of family businesses in instruments such as COSME, the identification of barriers to the development of family businesses by means of a test modelled on the SME test in order to minimise them. The report points out that such companies have a much greater financial own contribution than others, and therefore calls for changes to allow for more widespread and efficient use of foreign capital and other alternative sources, especially given that, due to the economic crisis, many family farms are underfunded. I believe that such measures will have a positive impact on the situation of these companies. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report which aims to strengthen the family businesses that form the backbone of the economy in most Member States. Especially in times of crisis, we need to strengthen their competitiveness and operational development by facilitating their access to European financial mechanisms. After all, the creation of new jobs, particularly at local and regional level, depends to a large extent on them.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on family farms in Europe today. This type of company is a fundamental component of our social fabric, think that more than 60% of all businesses in the European Union are family-run, and these companies provide about 40-50% of jobs in the private sector. I am absolutely convinced, and here I agree in the text adopted, that the Union must support these businesses, but that this cannot be separated from a full understanding of the problems and challenges faced by family businesses. I will conclude by recalling the need to carry out in-depth impact assessments, such as the 'family business test' in order to determine with certainty the impact of the new EU regulations on family businesses.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this report, which calls for the legislation for family businesses to be simplified so that they can develop their activities and cooperation in other Member States without unnecessary administrative obstacles. Family businesses are an important part of every national economy, as well as european economies. It is these small businesses that provide a large number of jobs and, moreover, their responsibility towards their own employees is at a high level.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft report addressed the importance of family businesses to the European Union. However, despite their undeniable economic and social benefits, family businesses in the European Union face many obstacles resulting, for example, from the absence of a universally recognised definition of family business, due to the fact that family businesses occur in various forms, from small and medium-sized enterprises to large transnational organisations. However, the lack of a uniform definition prevents Member States from developing policies specialised in helping family businesses. The report therefore calls for a uniform definition, but also for simplification of the administrative burden. As I am aware of the importance of family businesses for creating stable jobs, including in rural areas and remote regions, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "The family plays a huge role not only in educating and shaping social attitudes, but is also an important economic link. Family businesses have a very long and glorious tradition. It was thanks to this form of business that modern capitalism was created. Today, when big companies and transnational corporations play a dominant role, we forget the role that family businesses play in growth and reducing unemployment in Europe. Unfortunately, the economic crisis of recent years has left a very strong mark on family businesses. Their functioning today requires special support and inclusion in EU strategies. We need tools to define and support the existence of a family business well, and to create the conditions for it to modernise and meet the demands of the digital economy. I will support any action leading to this objective, including this report, which is the first and much-needed step towards properly highlighting the impact that family businesses have on the European economy.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on family businesses in Europe, because I believe that they contribute greatly to the growth of the European economy and play a significant role in social development. By investing in human capital and in the transmission of knowledge, while playing a key role in regional development and territorial organization, family businesses reinforce the stability of the economy in which they are part, being one of the main sources of employment in the private sector. In this context, the European Union must pay greater attention to the importance of family businesses for the important role they play in our economy.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to information from a group of Experts of the European Commission in its final report of 2009, 60% of companies in the European Union are "family businesses", representing 40 to 50% of jobs in the private sector. Recalls this report that there is no concrete definition of 'family business', and there are even more than 90 different definitions throughout the European Union. The rapporteur therefore considers that family businesses play a significant role in economic growth and social development. It recalls that they have variable dimensions, which "exposes them to different difficulties and problems", which is important to know and frame. It also recalls that "the European Commission already established in 2003 a european-wide definition of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs),despite the fact that "because of this situation, many family businesses are not covered by the Definition of SMEs". The rapporteur is moving forward with proposals to support and finance "family businesses", which make a clear plank of the range of existing companies that can fit this definition, thus creating the conditions for the possibility of large companies competing for the benefit of these measures, to the advantage of the rest, thus creating an unfair, perverse and unacceptable mechanism. From the above, we abstained.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, in these challenging times for the European economy, sea and coast, they are an important driver of the economy, so work needs to be done to innovate in a blue economy that represents huge potential for jobs and economic growth in general. The blue economy covers a wide range of economic sectors from traditional to new, from fisheries to aquaculture, sea transport, inland waterway transport, ports, logistics, tourism, shipbuilding, maritime works and coastal protection, offshore energy sources, etc. The potential for sea resources exploitation is high and focuses on the development of sustainable renewable energy sources and could make a significant contribution to the European Union's energy security strategy by reducing Member States' dependence on energy sources outside the European Union. The development of the blue economy would stimulate economic development and job creation, especially in coastal regions, as Mediterranean countries are most affected by the crisis, i.e. leading the way in the number of unemployed people.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we must look upon the Blue Economy as an asset, providing incredible opportunities for tourism, energy and food, and new applications for therapeutics and technology. It can create jobs, drive investment, innovation and growth, and I welcome any opportunity that we have to discuss this untapped potential of our Blue Economy.  In Ireland at present we are experiencing a significant Blue Growth, with a 9% increase in marine sector growth over the last five years, and the ocean economy is now valued at 1.3% of GDP. In July, a conference was held on harnessing our ocean wealth which Commissioner Vella attended, and I know he is really keen to promote and to support any developments in the Blue Economy area. At that conference we heard from experts that Ireland could create up to 29 000 jobs and contribute an additional EUR 2.7 billion in growth from our Blue Economy by 2020. It is an extremely important untapped potential, and any report that focuses on it and its value is to be welcomed.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a warning to the aggressive proposals for the exploitation of the blue economy submitted by the European institutions, recalling the importance of ensuring the sustainability of productive activity in order to avoid the ecological and social catastrophes that capitalist development has imposed wherever it has spread. I also value the importance of linking the blue economy with the traditional specializations of coastal areas (fishing, construction and repair of ships...) and with technological development, bases without which the blue economy risks becoming a new speculative bubble.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. By putting States at the centre of the issue and giving the EU only a role as a funder of research projects and facilitator of interstate cooperation, this report presents many interesting axes on the development of the marine economy, which is a crucial sector for France.  However, an update on economic and environmental cooperation on the Basins of the Mediterranean Sea and the Black Sea is missing. The optimization of shipping through a carbon tax levied at the border is a track that the report should have looked at in its analysis of this sector.  An amendment was tabled in committee to this effect by ENL MEPs, it was rejected by 26 votes to 25. Our delegation abstained on this report because our recommendations were not taken into account.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Important drivers of the economy, such as fishing, shipping, ports, logistics, tourism, etc., are closely connected with the sea and the coast. In order to better unlock the potential of research and innovation in the blue economy to create jobs and growth, the adopted report proposes initiatives that I support. Among other things, knowledge about the seas and oceans should be increased, the necessary skills to apply new technologies in the marine environment should be improved, and the coordination of marine research should be strengthened. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Among the Member States of the European Union, France has the largest maritime area. We are therefore very concerned about this report, which looks at the potential of research and innovation in the blue economy in terms of job creation and growth.  Several sectors of the maritime economy are covered: from fishing to shipping, shipbuilding and marine research. In terms of energy, the proposals seem relevant. The commission's intervention is clearly limited to a cooperative role, which is obviously very positive. However, we regret that this report does not underline the importance of the private sector in the maritime field.  Another negative point is the recommendation of free access to all data on the maritime areas of the various Member States. The confidentiality of information must be preserved when the economic interest of our country is at stake. Thus, I abstained on this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I opposed this report, which calls for further EU regulation and a common framework for the exploitation of energy sources in Europe. Nevertheless, there were some good ideas in the report. Rejection of the report as a whole should not imply that I do not have sympathy with some of the points contained in it. I believe that tidal power, for example, will eventually be a cost-effective renewable source of energy.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to use research and innovation in the blue economy. It is necessary to combat the evasion of information on research campaigns and projects in the seas and oceans, in particular those financed by public funds. Training, research and development are key aspects of the sustainable development of the blue economy. Emerging sectors, in particular the exploration and exploitation of mineral resources, the exploration and exploitation of energy resources and biotechnology, have very high potential.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Despite some good suggestions about the crucial role of public investment or the need to revive shipbuilding, this report recommends further expanding the powers of a Commission whose dictatorship we are already suffering from.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. If, in recent decades, we have seen a decline in passenger transport by sea, the blue economy has largely developed, as evidenced by the growing importance of leisure activities, the exploration and exploitation of fossil fuel resources, the exploration and prospects of exploitation of existing minerals in the seabed, the prospects for developing the energy potential contained in the waves , tides, currents or biomass for electricity generation, offshore wind generation or the development of sea-related biotechnology. The blue economy is growing, encompassing a wide range of economic sectors and presenting a challenge for the future.  The report, which I approved, stresses in this regard that education and training, research and development are fundamental elements for the sustainable development of the blue economy. It is important to assess the adequacy between existing programmes and measures (including funding) and blue economy development objectives, the interaction between different structures and existing programmes, and their results.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. The blue economy has great potential to innovate and generate quality employment, but as reflected in the initiative it is necessary to allocate the necessary funds to finance research, training, broadband access of transport links and energy interconnectivity. In this sense I share the sectoral approach and, therefore, we cannot forget the fisheries sector in its entirety, which needs to be supported by strengthening the role of fisheries development groups within the framework of the new CFP, providing them with resources and enabling them to achieve their objectives. Finally, I think it is vitally important to bet on the European shipbuilding industry as a strategic industrial sector which needs special aid to innovate and modernise shipbuilding in Europe. On these issues, I voted in favour.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The main positive point of this report on the potential for job creation and growth in research and innovation in the blue economy is to be comprehensive and to address various issues (fishing, transport, energy, shipbuilding, etc.). It takes into account all aspects of each issue such as the added value of public action, the management of fishing stocks, the preservation of the marine ecosystem, the need for support for the shipbuilding sector. Finally, the report highlights the central role of states in the development of the blue economy (point 9), involving the Commission only to promote their cooperation. On the other hand, the report points to an ideological orientation that leads the editor to neglect certain private sector contributions to the economy. Similarly, there is a need to protect the data essential for defending the fundamental economic interests of states, so the emphasis is on the free access of all data and knowledge. Finally, the report ignores the long-term and sustainable development of the tourism industry.  Although this report has some flaws, it also has some interesting points, so I have decided to abstain on this vote.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the concept of a 'blue economy' is rather vague, the report 'supports a specific and integrated definition, covering all sectoral and cross-sectoral activities related to the oceans, seas, coastal ecosystems, connected hinterland and coastal areas, including forms of direct and indirect support'. I voted in favour of this text because if these activities can also bring benefits in terms of well-being and employment, then they deserve to be supported.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report on the effective exploitation of the potential of research and innovation in the blue economy to create jobs and growth. The report also highlights the importance of the shipbuilding industry, the modernization and sustainable development of the fisheries sector, tourism and underwater heritage, among other issues. The amendments tabled by the Spanish Socialists also denounce the negative, short- and long-term impact that cuts in public R&D&I investment are having on national research systems, require greater EU support for measures against the degradation of coastal systems, and researchers are invited to promote open access to data supporting the results of their investigations. I would like to highlight the paragraphs of this report devoted to prospecting activities, which request that the Commission propose and update a non-exhaustive list of maritime activities (marine energy production, mining activity on the seabed, sand and gravel exploitation at sea, etc.) that require prior assessments of environmental impact, but also socio-economic.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on Parliament's report on unlocking the potential of research and innovation in the blue economy for growth and jobs. The potential for exploitation of marine resources to develop sustainable renewable energy sources could make a significant contribution to the EU's energy security strategy by reducing Member States' dependence on non-EU energy sources. The Commission is invited to draw up projects that it has financed in the past and which have been linked to the blue economy and to launch a comprehensive study on the importance and importance of the blue economy. The financial needs of the blue economy must be assessed at national and EU level in order to exploit its potential for sustainable growth and development and job creation, with a particular focus on regions that are highly dependent on fisheries. The Commission should regularly assess the implementation of Horizon 2020 in blue economy sectors and make the results of the evaluation publicly available. Parliament supports the establishment of a dedicated maritime industry partnership under Horizon 2020 and calls for its inclusion in the Horizon 2020 Work Programme 2016-2017.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In Europe, the "blue economy" jobs 5.4 million people and has a gross value added of almost EUR 500 billion per year. In times of economic crisis, it is of the utmost importance that we seize all opportunities for growth and jobs. Europe's seas not only provide an excellent basis for this, but they continue to grow in importance, bearing in mind the scarcity of our resources and the growth of the world's population. Europe's maritime economy, from clean energy production to new sustainable industries, is very broad and therefore has a vital role to play in boosting the European economy. As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposed report on exploiting the potential of research and innovation in the blue economy, as I am convinced that the potential of the world's seas and oceans is largely untapped. Although these areas offer us many opportunities for economic exploitation, from fisheries, tourism, shipbuilding, ports, energy, etc., there are still many opportunities, especially for more sustainable ways of using the resources that science and research can offer us. One such area is, for example, biotechnology. Of course, this kind of exploitation should pay attention to the sensitivities of marine ecosystems. The environmental, ecological and social functions of the seas and oceans therefore require a strong role for states in the sustainable management and conservation of resources in order to prioritise the public good over the interests of individuals. Resources should be used in an appropriate way so that they are not used too quickly. It is therefore necessary to prevent the practice that we are used to from the mainland. The aforementioned biotechnology related to the seas and oceans, e.g. represents a highly diversified sector with immense potential for the creation and use of new knowledge and the creation of new products and processes with high added value – the development of new materials, pharmaceuticals, etc. The EU must therefore, in my view, step further ambitiously on the path of progressive blue economy.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as blue growth is an important lever for the EU's sustainable development. If you look at all the economic activities that depend on the sea, we see that we are facing a 'blue economy' which represents around 5.4 million jobs in Europe. An economy with strong potential for employment growth, just think of the activities linked to sustainable maritime and coastal tourism. This economy will, however, only be able to fully exploit its potential if it succeeds in combining sustainable business development with good ecological status in the coastal and maritime environment.  In Europe, the demand for the use of coastal zones is constantly increasing. Indeed, various sectors such as: maritime transport, fisheries, aquaculture, tourism, the laying of cables and underwater pipelines, the production of offshore wind energy lead to an increase in its use, which is why there is a need for proper coordination between the different operators and subjects, without which there would be a risk of intensifying competition and putting excessive pressure on valuable resources.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support this document because it correctly identifies areas and problems that are holding back the development of a true "blue economy". The idea of a "blue economy" covers a wide range of economic sectors related to the sea and oceans, from traditional, i.e. affirmed, to emerging sectors.  Among the most important are certainly fisheries, mariculture, maritime and river transport, ports and logistics, tourism and recreational navigation and cruises, shipbuilding and ship repair, maritime works and coastal protection, exploration and exploitation of mineral resources in the sea, the exploitation of offshore wind and marine energy energy and bio-technology. All these areas should work in synergy with each other in order to fully exploit the economic potential of the 'blue economy'.  In my view, the blue economy should have a specific and comprehensive definition covering all sectoral and cross-sectoral activities related to oceans, seas, coastal ecosystems, connected inland and coastal areas.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the blue economy represents a great opportunity for growth for the whole continent. Nevertheless, I believe that, in order to exploit the full potential of this sector, it is absolutely necessary to invest in research and innovation, without, however, compromising the projects already underway. The Commission, together with the Member States, should therefore endeavour to find the necessary resources.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. This own-initiative report by the European Parliament is a response to the Commission's Action Plan for Innovation in the 'Blue Economy', which covers a wide range of economic sectors related to the seas and oceans, including fisheries, aquaculture, ports and logistics, tourism, coastal line protection.  We believe that the oceans and seas are a source of growth and can affect the growth of jobs, food and energy, but at the same time it is necessary to protect ecosystems for future generations with responsible and sustainable management. In order to make this possible, more research, knowledge, skills and data on our seas and oceans are essential.  Of course, investment in the blue economy must give priority to ecological innovation, efficiency in the use of resources, the circular economy, nature conservation, the fight against and adaptation to climate change and the sustainable use of resources. It is also essential to launch strategies and measures for the prevention of maritime disasters, including environmental risks and economic activities, by scientifically supporting their management and solution and by determining responsibilities within European and international legislation.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The blue economy represents significant potential in terms of growth, jobs and investment for EU Member States with disappointing macroeconomic performance. This report highlights the issues and issues to be addressed: fishing, shipbuilding, mineral extraction and shipping. The report gives the state a central place in the development of these activities and the Union as a coordinator. The text highlights the importance of taking advantage of these sectors while ensuring the preservation of the environment.  However, it is regrettable that the text does not incorporate the role that private investors have to play in financing these projects, particularly in order to better allocate resources. Furthermore, the rapporteur deals with this issue without addressing the issue of the union for the Mediterranean, an issue that is crucial for the future of the continent. I have therefore chosen to abstain on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The blue economy is a set of economic activities related to the seas and oceans. Under current economic conditions, any alternative to the traditional economy is beneficial and can contribute beneficially to development. I believe that in order to develop the blue economy it is necessary to focus on a number of economic activities that can meet the current needs of present and future generations. This type of economy must be supported by the European institutions and the Member States as it can represent a chance for the development of island countries, as well as coastal and outermost areas. I voted in favour of the Report on the potential of research and innovation in the blue economy to generate jobs and growth because increasing investment in innovation and research in the field of the seas and oceans can be an effective tool to support the objectives of economic, social and territorial cohesion, thereby reducing the development gaps between Member States.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. The concept of a 'blue economy', like the other 'colourful economies', is rather vague and lends itself to misunderstandings, so much so that it has not yet been defined. To this end, the report 'supports a specific and integrated definition, covering all sectoral and cross-sectoral activities related to oceans, seas, coastal ecosystems, connected hinterland and coastal areas, including forms of direct and indirect support'. Beyond that, if this can bring a benefit in terms of well-being and employment, welcome.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for the report by Joel Ferreira on the potential of the blue economy. I have made a significant contribution to the preparation of this report in committee, through amendments tabled jointly with my colleagues from the 'Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas' intergroup. This report proposes a roadmap for the development of sea-related growth, particularly in sectors such as marine energy, shipping, underwater mining and fishing. These are sectors of the future in which the Union, Member States, regional and local authorities and the private sector must invest. There is also a need to develop synergies between marine research and industrial applications.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reflection and debate in plenary, I voted today in favour of the report on the motion for a European Parliament resolution on exploiting the potential of research and innovation in the blue economy to create growth and jobs on the basis of the following considerations: - the issue of the blue economy and its proper exploitation is now an indissoluble global economic dynamic and represents , together with the protection and protection of natural environments, a priority of the political action of the Community and national institutions; - I join the chorus of those who share the need not to neglect traditional sectors as well as to implement scientific knowledge through research and innovation, I agree that - among the thousand resources of "well-being" that the sea can offer - the creation and growth of jobs is of priority importance. I agree with the report and, with it, with the principle that it is a priority to ensure that the common interest, the public good, takes precedence over particular, sectoral and individual interests.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. This report contained some very positive provisions, specifically paragraph 5, which underlined the importance of the ecosystem approach and the precautionary principle, which should be at the core of the blue economy.  Furthermore, it stated that investment in the blue economy should focus on eco-innovation, circular economy and nature conservation (paragraph 30). Finally, the report stressed the importance of social dialogue and considered that all social partners involved in the blue economy should be represented (paragraph 62).  It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as it calls for further EU regulation and a common framework for the exploitation of energy sources in Europe. Nevertheless, there were some good ideas in the report. Rejection of the report as a whole should not imply that I do not have sympathy with some of the points contained in it. I believe that tidal power, for example, will eventually be a cost-effective renewable source of energy.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I agree with the rapporteur requesting for precise objectives and making marine data more accessible. I believe that the sea and the coast tend to drive a positive impact to the economy, thus encouraging research and innovation will certainly increase jobs and growth

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The concept of blue economy refers to a wide range of activities, sectors and issues related to the sea, which is why it is clearly of great importance to our country. My colleague's report, while referring, from the point of view of an integrated European approach that takes account of the different specificities, to the precautionary principle, is inconsistent. In fact, even in the face of scientific evidence, it does not put the necessary brakes on the exploitation of mineral resources, which seriously damage marine ecosystems. My vote was therefore against.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. The "blue growth" strategy, which is a long-term strategy, aims to support sustainable growth in the marine and maritime sectors as a whole. The report recognises that the seas and oceans are engines of the European economy that offer considerable potential for innovation and growth. This report is an appropriate response to the achievement of the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy for smart and sustainable growth. This is a very important contribution to maritime policy for me, which represents a real added value for the future.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote because, although this report presents many interesting points on the development of the marine economy, such as the need for research and training to make full use of the potential of the blue economy. However, this report is too focused on purely European issues, in an area that falls within the regional level. Several points raised by the ENL group are missing from the report, such as the state of economic and environmental cooperation on the Basins of the Mediterranean Sea or the optimization of maritime transport through a carbon tax levied at the border.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The seas and oceans represent a strong potential for growth: they represent a real opportunity to stimulate the economy and create new jobs especially for coastal and island regions. The lack of data on the "health" status of our seas, seabed resources and marine ecosystems has in fact prevented and limited to date the development process that can result from so-called blue growth, which includes a wide range of sectors of economic activity ranging from traditional activities (fishing, aquaculture) to emerging ones, such as renewable energies , or biotechnology.  In order to bring out the inherent potential of the blue economy, we will have to act mainly on two guidelines: on the one hand, by increasing the shortage of qualified professionals in different fields of study and activity, on the other hand by strengthening the investments in research and innovation necessary also to ensure that its development takes place in compliance with environmental sustainability. The protection and conservation of marine ecosystems must remain the central objectives that should guide the European blue growth strategy.  The report i voted on goes in the direction I wanted, namely a fair balance between research, economic growth and the environment. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I believe that the development of the blue economy should focus on sustainable economic activities that meet the needs of current and future generations and create prosperity for society. The development of the blue economy requires a substantial integration of the scientific knowledge that is the basis of research and innovation. We highlight the need to increase citizens' sensitivity to the importance of the sea as an economic, cultural and social resource, and to the role of research and dialogue between stakeholders and citizens in achieving integrated sustainability. We believe that the seas and coasts are valuable resources and should be one of the pillars of EU policy. Nevertheless, there have been changes in the report that raise doubts and distort important essential issues.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure concerning research and innovation in the blue economy. The concept of the blue economy is linked to a wide range of sectors of economic activity related to the seas and oceans, including traditional sectors (e.g. fisheries, aquaculture, tourism, recreational boating) and emerging sectors (e.g. exploitation of offshore mineral resources, biotechnology). Both sectors are important for growth and employment and both have specific problems and sensitivities that need to be addressed. To this end, education, training and research are essential elements for the development of a sustainable economy. This measure stresses the need to assess the conformity of existing programmes and measures (including funding) with the blue economy development objectives, as well as the interaction between the different existing structures and programmes and their results.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I fully agree with the basic plant provided by the Commission. It stresses the importance of development, particularly technological development, in the maritime sector. In this respect, I consider sectors such as fisheries, aquaculture, transport, tourism and many others to be particularly important. I agree with the rapporteur, João Ferreira, when he makes a number of proposals in his report, including the call for data on the marine economy to be made more accessible, in line with the Commission's ideas. 223 amendments have been tabled concerning tourism, the possibility of financing the marine economy through various projects has been presented, including investments in energy. I am pleased that all the political groups have supported this line.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The Blue Economy concept encompasses a wide range of sectors of economic activity linked to the seas, from traditional ones such as fishing and transport, to emerging ones, such as tourism or the exploitation of energy resources. I believe that the development of the Blue Economy should focus on sustainable activities and can strongly boost economic growth and development, as well as job creation. Particular emphasis on the potential for the exploitation of marine resources to develop sustainable renewable energy resources, which can contribute significantly to the European Union's energy security strategy by reducing member states' dependence. I support the need to develop strategic planning of Blue Economy activities, direct funding modes and an action plan to boost this sector by 2020. However, account should always be taken of the recovery and maintenance of ecosystems, biodiversity, resilience and productivity of seas and oceans. Innovation and new technologies are associated with the development of the Blue Economy, while combating the degradation of ecosystems! I therefore support the excellent report by Mr Ferreira, which most reconciles a commitment from all political groups.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. Marine and coastal tourism accounts for a third of all tourism activities in Europe. I have always maintained that we should focus much more on tourism in order to create jobs and to create better conditions for the economic and social development of our territories. I voted in favour of this own-initiative report, which contains the appropriate political guidelines for strengthening the blue economy in Europe.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a warning to the aggressive proposals for the exploitation of the blue economy submitted by the European institutions, recalling the importance of ensuring the sustainability of productive activity in order to avoid the ecological and social catastrophes that capitalist development has imposed wherever it has spread. I also value the importance of linking the blue economy with the traditional specializations of coastal areas (fishing, construction and repair of ships...) and with technological development, bases without which the blue economy risks becoming a new speculative bubble.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Sustainable development of the blue economy can greatly promote economic growth and development and job creation, especially for coastal regions, outermost regions and island countries, while taking into account the specific and different needs of each geographical area. As the marine environment is a fragile one, I voted in favour of this report because I believe that both the EU and the Member States must invest adequate economic resources in research and innovation aimed both at increasing knowledge of the marine environment and its economic potential while fully respecting the sustainable exploitation of resources.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which deals with a new EU-wide effort to tap into the opportunities which the blue economy can offer through the creation of new enterprises and new jobs. I agree with actions related to the collection of data: both scientific data related to the seas and oceans and also data related to all present and potential maritime careers in order to better assess job opportunities. From an environmental standpoint, the report calls for preserving the natural marine environments and biodiversity, decarbonising maritime transport and diversifying energy sources, thus contributing to climate and energy targets via the use of energy potential contained in waves, tides and seaweed. Furthermore, the report calls for an appropriate financial framework for the blue economy and for the relevant agencies to be brought together under one existing agency which can coordinate all efforts. Having been the rapporteur for the S&D Group on the topic, where I have also spearheaded the push for the conglomeration of all blue economy efforts under one agency, I have happily supported the final version of this report.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has developed and proposed a set of programmes and guidelines covering activities and innovation in the blue economy. I believe that this framework must be assessed from the point of view of practical utility to support the efforts of Member States and regional and local authorities to develop the blue economy. I also believe in the important role of new technologies in countering the degradation of marine ecosystems and in the links between the blue and green economies, in particular with regard to innovative methods of cleaning the seas, including cost-effective recycling of polluting plastics.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report presents a series of proposals to realis the potential for job creation and growth in our seas and oceans, echoing the Commission's communication on innovation in the blue economy. The rapporteur calls, among other things, for concrete targets and deadlines to make data on the marine environment more accessible. Supporting these objectives, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The blue economy is a growing sector within the European Union. Creating new jobs while respecting our oceans and the environment is a challenge that Europe can win. That is why I voted in favour of this text. All economic activities that bring jobs such as fishing, transport and tourism must be supported by the European Union.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it is important to realise the innovative potential that our marine sectors have to offer. In times of economic difficulties it is important to look at all sector and see where they can contribute to economic recovery and economic growth. A well-developed strategy should be put in place to fully exploit the growth potential of this sector by 2020. This strategy should encompass new technologies, counter the degradation of marine ecosystems and provide for long term sustainable growth.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. Since ancient times the sea has been considered a source of resources: maritime transport has been an important means of transport for people and goods until the end of the 19th century while fishing has been and remains an important food and economic source for coastal peoples. In the last fifty years, however, the relationship between man and the sea has changed profoundly. Many of the major social challenges facing humanity today can be met through better knowledge of the marine environment and a better ability to use, manage and conserve the resources of our seas, oceans and coastal regions. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that education, training, research and development are essential elements in promoting a sustainable blue economy and making the best use of the marine resources available.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. We must be the leaders of blue growth in Europe by promoting a new programme for research and employment in the maritime sector (seafood, shipbuilding, shipping, tourism, energy, rare metals). Europe is the world's leading maritime domain. There is therefore a need for ocean governance, including sustainable fishing by banning deep-sea fishing and framing aquaculture.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – In Europe, the 'blue economy' jobs 5.4 million people and has a gross value added of almost EUR 500 billion per year. In times of economic crisis, it is of the utmost importance that we seize all opportunities for growth and jobs. Europe's seas not only provide an excellent basis for this, but they continue to grow in importance, bearing in mind the scarcity of our resources and the growth of the world's population. Europe's maritime economy, from clean energy production to new sustainable industries, is very broad and therefore has a vital role to play in boosting the European economy. As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The maritime sector economy linked to the exploitation of the sea's wealth is an area requiring long-term investment, a need that the public sector can partly guarantee. Mr Ferreira's report rightly underlines this and underlines the future prospects of the blue economy. However, these proposals are only articulated within the strictly European and supranational framework, when it is clear that Member States have an important place in that they are both regional and local policy and an international policy involving third countries. As an advocate of subsidiarity and national economic policies, I regret this lack of flexibility, which is why I abstained.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We vote against because there can be no development through grants to NGOs. As long as the Union moves along with this logic, the problems will simply be exacerbated.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In Europe, the "blue economy" jobs 5.4 million people and has a gross value added of almost EUR 500 billion per year. In times of economic crisis, it is of the utmost importance that we seize all opportunities for growth and jobs. Europe's seas not only provide an excellent basis for this, but they continue to grow in importance, bearing in mind the scarcity of our resources and the growth of the world's population. Europe's maritime economy, from clean energy production to new sustainable industries, is very broad and therefore has a vital role to play in boosting the European economy. As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote is against this resolution because it gives rise to the exploitation of mineral resources, to the irreparable detriment of marine ecosystems. It also seriously harms the complex and multidimensional complex of the blue economy – which, on the contrary, the resolution should promote – in order to make it inconsistent, unsustainable, contrary to scientific evidence and the precautionary principle. The resolution authorises mining exploration, oil and natural gas drilling, offshore mining and mining, including those areas of particular environmental interest (EPA), in defiance of the precautionary principle.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 Hardening the potential for research and innovation in the blue economy with a view to creating sustainable jobs and growth is important and something the EU should focus on. Unfortunately, the resolution focuses almost exclusively on public investment, at the expense of private investment as well, and also calls for additional subsidies for sectors that already have access to EU funds. For these reasons, I was unable to support the resolution and chose to abstain in the final vote.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The report advocates a more comprehensive approach to the challenges of innovation and job creation in the diverse set of sectors that make up the blue economy, such as fisheries, tourism, maritime transport, shipbuilding and the exploitation of energy resources. The concept of "blue economy" covers a wide spectrum of sectors of economic activity linked to the seas and oceans, including traditional sectors and emerging sectors such as fisheries, aquaculture, maritime and river transport, ports and logistics, recreational and cruise tourism and nautical, shipbuilding and repair, maritime and coastal defence works , the exploration and exploitation of mineral resources (offshore), the exploration and exploitation of energy resources (offshore) and biotechnology, among others. I agree that many of the great social challenges facing humanity today have a chance to respond to the better knowledge of the marine environment and a better ability to use, manage and conserve the resources of our seas, our oceans and our coastal areas.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report because it does not mention a desirable cooperation on the Mediterranean and the Black Sea.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Sea is a mode of transport and source of raw materials for many Europeans. We must try to get to know and document our seas and oceans better, because they can bring many innovations and jobs. In order for the blue economy to move forward, we must make full use of the potential of emerging sectors such as aquaculture, cruise cruises, mineral extraction, biotechnology and others. At the same time, however, we must not forget to insete traditional sectors that have already built up their tradition in many Member States.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of these proposals which are good and sensible in principle.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on unlocking the research and innovation potential in the blue economy to create jobs and growth because there can be no growth through grants to NGOs. The longer the Union moves along this logic, the longer the problems will be.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Oceans and seas can be source of growth, jobs, food, medicine and energy while protecting ecosystems for generations to come if they are managed in a responsible and sustainable manner. However, in order to make this possible, more research, knowledge, skills and data about our seas and oceans are needed. New technology, for example to counteract the degradation of marine ecosystems, or to capture and store carbon emissions, plays an important role. I support the importance of an integrated and coordinated approach and the need to consider the potential of Carbon Capture and Storage, but in a balanced manner; I believe that the Commission should further analyse how the technology and its accompanying infrastructure to transport the CO2 safely and in a cost effective manner can be applied in an economically viable way.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In Europe, the "blue economy" jobs 5.4 million people and has a gross value added of almost EUR 500 billion per year. In times of economic crisis, it is of the utmost importance that we seize all opportunities for growth and jobs. Europe's seas not only provide an excellent basis for this, but they continue to grow in importance, bearing in mind the scarcity of our resources and the growth of the world's population. Europe's maritime economy, from clean energy production to new sustainable industries, is very broad and therefore has a vital role to play in boosting the European economy. As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mr Ferreira's report to further address the opportunities of the blue economy, even more so in a context of the current crisis. The Union has almost 70,000 kilometres of coastline, and of them creates much of its wealth. But we cannot be left stranded, we must be able to innovate and balance the processes of modernization, innovation and value-added creation with traditional work related to the sea. We must also take advantage of the opportunities that the sea offers us to face the environmental challenges that we have faced in common, in the short, medium and long term.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the 'Report on unlocking the potential of research and innovation in the blue economy to create jobs and growth' because I consider this area of the European economy to be crucial for coastal regions such as my home state of Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania. At the same time, I am pleased that my request to make the fight against plastic waste in the sea an integral part of the blue economy has been taken into account. A visit to the innovative start-up "Biofabrik" in Dresden a few weeks ago showed me that Europe's leading role in this area is possible. We must encourage this.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the exploitation of the potential of our seas and oceans to promote employment and growth. They are important drivers of our economy. Investments in the blue economy should also cover, among other things, nature conservation and the sustainable use of resources and should be incorporated into existing and future programmes.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report given it is crucial we develop a greater ability to use, manage and conserve the resources of our seas, oceans, and coastal areas in a sustainable manner. The EU should take action to create sustainable growth and employment in the marine and maritime economy, and generate growth in areas such as developing offshore renewable energy technologies or supporting research into the blue biotechnology sector.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Despite the mention of positive principles such as the defence of biodiversity, the support to innovation, research and training, which are necessary to develop a sustainable blue economy at the EU level, the report is lacking balance between public and private. We cannot encourage the development of a new industry without the active involvement of the private sector. This is the reason why I decided to abstain.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report, which talks about the potential for growth and job creation in the maritime economy. This potential is based on many activities such as fishing and aquaculture, transport, logistics, tourism, shipbuilding, exploration and marine energy. If the maritime sector directly or indirectly employs 5.6 million people in Europe, it would theoretically be possible to create 1.5 to 2 million more jobs by 2020. Nevertheless, it will be necessary to ensure that human activities do not damage this environment and biodiversity and that new activities do not harm fishermen, especially artisanal ones. We are not taking this direction at the moment and it is to be feared that the blue economy, as it is currently defined, will have the effect of sacrificing fishermen. Finally, the development of certain activities, such as marine energy, can only be done at the cost of significant investments. At the moment, there are no funds specifically dedicated to the blue economy, although Member States can submit projects under the Junker plan.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour because we are in favour of an economy that incorporates R&D&I towards 'eco-innovation', resource efficiency, the circular economy, nature conservation, marine and coastal protection, climate change mitigation and adaptation and, in general, the sustainable use of natural resources from an ecosystem view.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which aims at developing a better scientific knowledge base for our seas & oceans and at a greater ability to use, manage and conserve the resources of our seas, oceans, and coastal areas. Better management of our blue economy is key to several challenges, including developing sustainable energy sources and energy independence. The focus of the EU actions should be on creating sustainable growth and employment in the marine and maritime economy, and generating growth in areas such as developing offshore renewable energy technologies or supporting research into the blue biotechnology sector.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have abstained on the report on the research and innovation in the blue economy. My decision was based on the grounds of the adoption of many amendments calling for increased public funding and state aid, and the lack of any mention of the role of the private sector in developing the blue economy. Nevertheless, the report is calling for the defence of biodiversity, innovation, research, modernisation, and yet generally, I am in favour of the development of the blue economy as the source of job places which has the potential to contribute to the growth of the economy.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In Europe, the "blue economy" jobs 5.4 million people and has a gross value added of almost EUR 500 billion per year. In times of economic crisis, it is of the utmost importance that we seize all opportunities for growth and jobs. Europe's seas not only provide an excellent basis for this, but they continue to grow in importance, bearing in mind the scarcity of our resources and the growth of the world's population. Europe's maritime economy, from clean energy production to new sustainable industries, is very broad and therefore has a vital role to play in boosting the European economy. As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with how action at EU level can tackle the issues of gaps in knowledge, lack of educated and skilled workers and how this can dilute research efforts in marine and maritime science and hinder interdisciplinary learning and the progress of technology in the blue economy. However I along with ALDE voted against the report as the adoption of many of the amendments called for an increase in public funding and state aid and a lack of any mention on the role of the private sector in developing the blue economy.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because research and innovation in sectors regarding our oceans and seas can have a very positive economic impact through the creation of jobs and new sectors within the blue economy. The sea and the coast are important drivers of the economy and we need to recognise this.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. 'Blue growth', i.e. economic growth by using our oceans and seas. This amounts to a further exploitation of natural resources at sea. However, the earth's borders do not allow for further exploitation, and this certainly applies to the EU's already heavily polluted and overfished waters.  The European fishing fleet is already twice as large as fish populations can bear. The ecosystems in our seas have been disrupted by pollution. Our economic activities at sea should not grow, but shrink. This requires a different way of thinking about economics. We must move away from the naïve belief in growth, and take as a starting point the capacity of the earth and the well-being of all its inhabitants. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report highlights a number of important areas where the EU’s maritime nations and regions can cooperate to create jobs and strengthen the blue economy. Importantly, it notes that a one-size-fits-all is not appropriate and it is imperative that the Commission bears this in mind in the future development of policy.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour since we are in favour of an economy that incorporates R&D&I towards 'eco-innovation', resource efficiency, the circular economy, nature conservation, marine and coastal protection, climate change mitigation and adaptation and, in general, the sustainable use of natural resources from an ecosystem view.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Resolution of the European Parliament on exploiting the potential of research and innovation in the blue economy to create jobs and achieve growth, as the blue economy has a special importance for all Member States of the European Union, especially for countries such as Croatia.  The Blue Economy includes a number of sectors that together can contribute strikingly to EU growth on a global scale: fisheries, aquaculture, port development, transport and many others. I would also like to draw attention to the importance of tourism for the overall economy of the European Union, but in particular to the importance of shipbuilding. Shipbuilding has really great potential that needs the support of the European Commission, Member States and regional and local authorities through concrete investments, and through the exploitation of research and innovation.  I therefore believe that the 'ship' can become a European product that will be competitive and recognisable on the global market. However, the blue economy should pay particular attention to the conservation of the marine ecosystem and the environment.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. As France is the Country of the European Union with the largest maritime area, we are very concerned about this report on the potential for job creation and growth of research and innovation in the blue economy.  We are talking about fishing, shipping, shipbuilding and marine research. In terms of energy, the proposals seem relevant. Moreover, the Commission's intervention is clearly limited to a cooperative role. However, we reject the ideological and purely economic approach of this report, which fails to underline the importance of the private sector in this area.  Furthermore, we are against free access to all data on the maritime domains of the various Member States. On the contrary, the confidentiality of information must be preserved in the economic interest of countries. That's why I abstained.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Ferreira report on the potential for job creation and growth of research and innovation in the blue economy. The measures proposed in this report are to promote innovation and job creation in all sectors related to the seas and oceans (from fishing to shipbuilding to the exploitation of mineral and energy resources). Scientists point out that many of the major challenges facing our societies today could be answered by a better understanding of the marine environment. I welcome the adoption of this report and the avenues developed in particular in the direction of improving teaching, training and research.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. This text has a simple objective: to foster innovation in everything related to the oceans, the seas and the blue economy in general. This includes fishing, aquaculture, tourism, cruises and boating. It is a good move. That is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. Although the report highlights the right points, the proposed measures are aimed at giving the Commission more powers of determination, establishing more quotas, spending more European and public money on various projects and exploiting the potential of the Blue Economy through more planning. For these reasons, I am opposed to the report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which aims at developing a better scientific knowledge base for our seas and oceans and at a greater ability to use, manage and conserve the resources of our seas, oceans and coastal areas. A better management of our blue economy is key to several of our society challenges, including developing sustainable energy sources and energy independence. The focus of the EU actions should be on creating sustainable growth and employment in the marine and maritime economy, and generating growth in areas such as developing offshore renewable energy technologies or supporting research into the blue biotechnology sector.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 8 September 2015, we voted on a report on harnessing the potential of research and innovation in the blue economy to create jobs and growth. The text responds to the commission's previous communication entitled 'Innovation in the blue economy: harnessing the potential of our seas and oceans for growth and jobs'. It points out that the original Communication is far from overlapping all the areas that make up the blue economy, and that an ecosystem approach must also be taken into account. The protection and conservation of natural marine environments is, in my opinion, an essential prerequisite for the conservation, promotion and development of the blue economy. Only viable marine ecosystems are a prerequisite for the exploitation of marine and ocean resources. Since the ITRE Committee has managed to prevent the adoption of the worst amendments, such as those relating to public and private sector investment, I have decided to support the report by my factional colleague Ferreira.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In Europe, the "blue economy" jobs 5.4 million people and has a gross value added of almost EUR 500 billion per year. In times of economic crisis, it is of the utmost importance that we seize all opportunities for growth and jobs. Europe's seas not only provide an excellent basis for this, but they continue to grow in importance, bearing in mind the scarcity of our resources and the growth of the world's population. Europe's maritime economy, from clean energy production to new sustainable industries, is very broad and therefore has a vital role to play in boosting the European economy. As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Etelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because the report deplores the short and long-term impact of cuts in public R&D. Investments in public R&D are essential for national research programs; We cannot afford cuts in the budget for the Horizon 2020. Furthermore, in order to have a proper development of the blue economy, it is important to maintain not only European funds but also to incorporate gender perspectives in the blue economy and last but not least to improve ‘eco-innovation’. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have given my consent to this measure. The blue economy concept encompasses a wide range of economic sectors related to the seas and oceans, including traditional or established sectors and emerging sectors. The sustainable development of the blue economy requires more investment in innovation and research and underlines the role of new technologies to combat the degradation of marine ecosystems, as well as the links between the blue economy and the green economy. Investments must give priority to ecological innovation, resource efficiency, nature conservation, marine and coastal protection and climate change mitigation. Finally, it is hoped that more support will be given to the modernisation and sustainable development of the fisheries sector and the processing of fishery products, in order to create highered value.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. This Ferreira report on the potential for job creation and growth of research and innovation in the blue economy sweeps away a broad field of EU competence (fishing, transport, energy, shipbuilding, etc.). It takes into account all aspects of each issue such as the added value of public action, the management of fishing stocks, the preservation of the marine ecosystem, the need for support for the shipbuilding sector. The report highlights the central role of states in the development of the blue economy, involving the Commission only to promote their cooperation. On the other hand, the report reveals an ideological orientation which leads the rapporteur to neglect certain private sector contributions to the economy. Finally, the report ignores the long-term and sustainable development of the tourism industry. I have decided to abstain on this vote.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a warning to the aggressive proposals for the exploitation of the blue economy submitted by the European institutions, recalling the importance of ensuring the sustainability of productive activity in order to avoid the ecological and social catastrophes that capitalist development has imposed wherever it has spread. I also value the importance of linking the blue economy with the traditional specializations of coastal areas (fishing, construction and repair of ships...) and with technological development, bases without which the blue economy risks becoming a new speculative bubble.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. – Blue Economy is the concept we use to address the wide range of economic activities and processes closely linked to our seas and oceans.  Throughout human history we have interacted and harnessed the resources of this medium for multiple reasons (subsistence, transport, economics or simply leisure). Undoubtedly, the way in which we have been related to the seas and oceans has been transformed, adapting to technological changes and social and economic needs. Given the great importance of the blue economy to us, I think it has been important that issues such as traditional activities (fishing) or emerging economic activities (exploitation of marine resources) be addressed in this report. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that sensible assessments and proposals are made.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the proposals to finance the development and support of the blue economy (Sections 9, 31, 33, 37) and I voted against this report as a whole, which, by using the mysterious neologism 'blue economy', seeks to hide the fact that these are further unnecessary and harmful regulations at European level.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The sea has always been one of the basic sources of existence for people living on the coast, it was fishing, tourism, shipbuilding or even the sea as a source of energy. The human attitude towards the sea has changed greatly in the last 50 years - it is adapted to the needs of today's generations, without much thought about the well-being of future ones. The blue economy concept focuses on sustainable economic activities that meet the needs of current and future generations and create prosperity for society. It does not limit the full potential of seas and oceans, on the contrary, preference is given to knowledge and innovation aimed at preserving ecosystems. Accordingly, small and medium-sized enterprises play a very important role in terms of innovation and jobs in the blue economy, which need to facilitate access to lending and improve existing business networks. I supported Representative Ferreira's report. I come from a country that is part of the Strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Region whose primary goal is to steer the entire region towards future sustainable economic and social prosperity. I believe that such strategies are a great way to create new jobs, develop entrepreneurship and revive small environments.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 My colleagues in the European Parliament and I are convinced of the potential of the blue economy to generate growth and development, although we take into account its current problems. That is why we voted for the resolution in favour of a single strategy to promote the blue sector's leadership within the Union. The blue economy must focus on sustainable economic activities that would create jobs and contribute to overcoming asymmetry between european regions. At the same time, however, I strongly oppose the possibility that the focus on the blue economy serves as a pretext for the unsustainable exploitation of our water resources. On the other hand, I am convinced that the existing specific problems can be addressed through more active interstate cooperation, better governance at EU level and a common focus on research and innovation as a way to expand opportunities to exploit blue potential and overcome negative trends towards the deterioration of water resources.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Blue Economy of the European Union has the potential to create and develop jobs. It is followed up and dependent on other sectors, which operate inland and in which thousands of people work. Increasing economic growth and creating sustainable jobs in this sector require the promotion of research and innovation, taking into account the protection of the environment and aquatic ecosystems. That is why the Commission, in cooperation with the Member States, must focus its attention on this area, assess the needs and possibilities for financing research and innovation of the blue economy and specifically focus on regions dependent on the blue economy.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
