text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on unlocking the research and innovation potential in the blue economy to create jobs and growth for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 7/9/2015. I would point out that the blue economy should, above all, be based on innovation and new technologies. This also means support for small and medium-sized enterprises, but also support for quality itself. It means support for renewable energy sources and forms of local cooperation. It means trying to create new jobs and develop new products. It means that we must have support for economic social and territorial cohesion in the European Union. This therefore means additional cooperation between the regions themselves and requires support through the Structural Funds and in particular through the Regional Development Fund itself and through the European Social Fund.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report on the development of the marine economy. The text presents interesting axes by putting States at the centre of the issue and giving the EU only a role as a funder. This text, neglecting the need for private sector input, is too focused on intra-European issues. It does not consider partnerships with countries bordering the Mediterranean to solve economic and environmental problems. Moreover, this text does not address the issues of sustainable development and the tourism industry, which are essential to the blue economy.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The sea has been known to be a source of wealth at least since ancient Greek and Roman times. Ships were the main means of transporting passengers and goods over short, medium, and long distances until the end of the 19th century. Fishing has been, and remains, a major source of food for waterside populations. During the last 50 years there have been significant changes in the nature of humankind’s relationship to the sea, of which the following can serve as examples: the fact that fewer passengers are being carried by sea (and correspondingly more are being carried by air); the growing importance of leisure activities; the prospection for, and exploitation of, fossil energy resources (oil and natural gas, in increasingly deep waters) necessitated by the dearth of resources on land; seabed exploration (still in its infancy) and the prospects for deep-sea mining; the prospects for utilising the energy potential contained in waves, tides, currents, and biomass (seaweed) to generate electricity; offshore wind farms; and the development of marine-related biotechnologies. The answers to many of the major challenges to society being posed to humankind could lie in better marine knowledge and a greater ability to use, manage, and conserve the resources of our seas, oceans, and coastal areas.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The concept of a blue economy encompasses various sectors of economic activity linked to the seas and oceans, which are now a powerful engine of the European economy and a potential for innovation, growth and employment. It is of the utmost importance to propose a definition of a blue economy covering all production and employment at sea, to protect and safeguard marine natural environments in order to support and develop this blue economy. We must prevent the same mistakes made on land in the seas and oceans, avoid methods of exploiting resources that lead to their depletion and unsustainability. Education, training and research must be essential tools for the development of the blue economy. I therefore felt it was right to support my colleague.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The Blue Economy is one of the EU's big bets on this legislature, and we must exploit the potential of creation and innovation in this sector to create jobs and growth, as we have pointed out from the European Parliament in a report I have supported and asked the Commission for more ambition and an integrated and more comprehensive approach to addressing this great challenge. We must have strategic planning of the activities of the blue economy, direct financing modalities, priority selection and an action plan to energize this sector by 2020 that includes specific ideas on mechanisms for cooperation and investment in infrastructure. As the rapporteur has pointed out, education and training, as well as research and development, are essential elements for the sustainable development of the blue economy. It is important to assess the adequacy of existing programmes and measures (including their level of funding) to the development objectives of the blue economy, as well as the interaction between the various existing structures and programmes, together with their results.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Although the report highlights the right points, the proposed measures are aimed at giving the Commission more powers of determination, establishing more quotas, spending more European and public money on a wide range of projects and seeking the salvation of the blue economy in a greater role for the state. I therefore reject this request.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report finally evokes the tremendous potential of the sea. And for once the concept of the blue economy is not presented to us as a new way of developing capitalism. This includes "protecting, restoring and conserving ecosystems, biodiversity, resilience and productivity of the seas and oceans." The report stresses "the importance of developing innovative sources of clean energy, known as 'blue', such as tidal energy, wave energy or osmotic energy", without forgetting to ask that "the results of publicly funded research be in the public domain for non-commercial uses (preserving data that are of strategic importance to Member States)."  Lucid, the text deplores "the sharp deterioration of some more traditional sectors of the economy (such as fishing or shipbuilding and repair)" and "urges the Commission to defend the rights of workers at sea and to ensure safe working conditions". I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. As France is the Country of the European Union with the largest maritime area, we are very concerned about this report on the potential for job creation and growth of research and innovation in the blue economy.  We are talking about fishing, shipping, shipbuilding and marine research. In terms of energy, the proposals seem relevant. Moreover, the Commission's intervention is clearly limited to a cooperative role. However, we reject the ideological and purely economic approach of this report, which fails to underline the importance of the private sector in this area.  Furthermore, we are against free access to all data on the maritime domains of the various Member States. On the contrary, the confidentiality of information must be preserved in the economic interest of countries. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Concept of Blue Economy covers a broad spectrum of sectors of economic activity linked to the seas and oceans, including traditional or established sectors and emerging sectors such as: fisheries, aquaculture, maritime and river transport, ports and logistics, recreational and cruise tourism and nautical, ship building and repair, maritime and coastal defence works, exploration and exploitation of mineral resources (offshore) , exploration and exploitation of offshore and biotechnology and biotechnology, among others. It is necessary to develop strategic planning of the Blue Economy's activities, direct financing modes and an action plan in order to boost this sector by 2020, including specific ideas regarding cooperation mechanisms and infrastructure investments. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it encourages a balanced approach to the development of emerging marine industries. Whilst innovation should be supported, it is essential that our sensitive marine ecosystems are protected to ensure sustainable growth.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – Rediscovering Europe's seas and oceans as a source of new prosperity and economic growth covers a range of traditional and emerging economic sectors. The transition to a new 'blue' economy, in which the riches of our coasts, seas and oceans are developed in a sustainable way, offers many opportunities for new economic growth and employment. In the field of energy extraction, the sea, as an inexhaustible supplier of renewable energy, offers the opportunity to simultaneously meet environmental targets and create thousands of new jobs. Innovations in traditional sectors, such as shipbuilding and fisheries, should ensure the transition to sustainable shipping and fishing.  Heavy investment is needed to tap into the employment potential of the blue economy. The European Union undoubtedly has a special role to play in the development of the blue economy. However, in order to achieve the maximum creation of new employment, it is appropriate to enable optimal partnerships between science and business, and to develop an attractive investment environment for companies and private investors.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The concept of the blue economy covers a wide range of economic sectors linked to the seas and oceans, spanning traditional and emerging sectors including for instance fisheries, aquaculture, ports and logistics, tourism, shipbuilding and ship-repairing, protection of the coastline, prospecting for, and exploitation of, offshore mineral and energy resources, biotechnology. Oceans and seas can be source of growth, jobs, food, medicine and energy while protecting ecosystems for generations to come if they are managed in a responsible and sustainable manner. However, in order to make this possible, more research, knowledge, skills and data about our seas and oceans are needed. Therefore, I have voted in favour of this report on the research and innovation in the blue economy because it is essential for creating jobs and growth.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. Although this report has some flaws, it presents many interesting axes on the development of the marine economy, a sector crucial for France, putting States at the centre of the issue and giving the EU only a role as a funder of research projects and facilitator of interstate cooperation. By emphasizing the need for research and training to make full use of the potential of the blue economy, the report sees right. However, it is a little too focused on European-European issues, in a fundamentally regional and international area. Indeed, the state of economic and environmental cooperation on the Basins of the Mediterranean Sea and the Black Sea is really missing from the report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Parliament today adopted a report on the Economy of the Sea, arguing that sustainable exploitation of the marine environment can contribute to increased wealth and job creation in the European Union. I believe that it is important to develop strategic planning of the Blue Economy's activities at European level, through an action plan and direct funding to boost this new form of sustainable growth, which can create 7 million jobs. Portugal will allocate 400 million Euros of European funds to activities related to the Sea, this being an area that we should all explore efficiently. The Regional Government of Madeira is also delinitating an Integrated Strategy for the Sea, which should fit into the national and European strategies previously defined, and these proposals can be analyzed and consequently integrated if they constitute a strategic added value for the valorization of Madeira's maritime resources. I intend to affirm the Oceans as a vector of sustainable development, and it is necessary to support universities, technology centers and SMEs, as well as startups that are developing activities related to the Sea and that contribute to the generation of wealth.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Ferreira report on the potential for job creation and growth of research and innovation in the blue economy sweeps away a wide range of EU competences (fishing, transport, energy, shipbuilding, etc.). It takes into account all aspects of each issue such as the added value of public action, the management of fishing stocks, the preservation of the marine ecosystem, the need for support for the shipbuilding sector. Finally, the report underlines the central role of States in the development of the blue economy, involving the Commission only to promote their cooperation. On the other hand, the report reveals an ideological orientation which leads the rapporteur to neglect certain private sector contributions to the economy. Finally, the report ignores the long-term and sustainable development of the tourism industry.  Although not defect-free, this report also presents some interesting points. I have therefore decided to abstain on this vote.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which aims at developing a better scientific knowledge base for our seas and oceans and at a greater ability to use, manage and conserve the resources of our seas, oceans and coastal areas. A better management of our blue economy is key to several of our society challenges, including developing sustainable energy sources and energy independence. The focus of the EU actions should be on creating sustainable growth and employment in the marine and maritime economy, and generating growth in areas such as developing offshore renewable energy technologies or supporting research into the blue biotechnology sector.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which encourages Member States to promote innovation in all sectors related to the sea and oceans: fisheries, aquaculture, maritime and river transport, ports and logistics, tourism, boating, cruises, shipbuilding and repair, maritime and coastal defence works , exploration and exploitation of offshore mineral and energy resources and biotechnology. As a member of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, I support these measures, which will create new jobs and generate growth.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the measures proposed by Mr Ferreira on harnessing the potential for job creation and growth in research and innovation in the blue economy. They promote innovation to create new jobs and growth in all sectors related to the sea and oceans: fisheries, aquaculture, maritime and river transport, ports and logistics, tourism, boating, cruises, shipbuilding and repair, maritime and coastal defence works. , exploration and exploitation of offshore mineral and energy resources and biotechnology.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that may be the answer to many of the major challenges to society being posed to humankind could be in the better marine knowledge and greater ability to use, manage and conserve the resources of our seas, oceans and coastal areas.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report on exploiting the potential of research and innovation in the blue economy because I believe it is an objective text that manages to find the right weight between the desire for development and the possible negative effects of overexploitation. It is very clear that the blue economy is one of the great opportunities for development and research worldwide, and the EU, through this report and through the opinions of the other parliamentary committees, through the debates on this issue and through the funds allocated is positioning itself at the forefront of this development.  However, as was also apparent from the opinion of the Committee on Fisheries, in which I worked as rapporteur from the shadows, we must find the balance between the temptation to develop this new economy, with the potential for research, innovation and job creation incredibly high, and its impact on the environment. The text of this report manages to convey exactly this type of approach, between the caution of the possible excess and the EU's desire to be at the forefront of the development of this new type of economy.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. – In principle, the report discusses the right points, but the measures proposed are aimed at giving the Commission more powers of determination, establishing more quotas, spending more European and, more generally, public money on various projects, and seeking the salvation of the economy in a greater role for the State. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution which calls on the Commission to deepen its investment in the blue economy under the Horizon 2020 project. I welcome the fact that this report adopts an environmental, progressive and innovative vision by proposing a sustainable use of the potential of the seas and oceans.  As the blue economy is a promising sector for the future, there is a need to strengthen measures to encourage research and innovation in this sector. I also deplore the cuts in research and development budgets, and support the report's request to consolidate a public database of marine research data.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained because certain areas provided for excessive state aid. It is neither justified nor economic revitalising.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report. The blue economy is of particular importance to Europe. The blue economy has great potential to create jobs and boost economic growth. Europe's oceans, seas and coasts are and will be vital to the European economy. However, sectors of the blue economy are very vulnerable. Therefore, equal treatment cannot be applied. The Commission must support an integrated approach. In order to achieve the objectives set, Member States must play an important role in the sustainable management and conservation of resources and in order to ensure the priority of public goods of general interest. It should be noted that education and training, research and development are key aspects of the sustainable development of the blue economy. Therefore, more investment in knowledge and research is needed to develop the blue economy in a sustainable way. In particular, the Commission should provide a clear and stable framework for support for research, businesses and governments. An appropriate financial framework needs to be established to promote innovation, sustainable development of the blue economy and job creation.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Assuming that the blue economy has always been one of the pillars of the European economy, considering its potential in terms of supporting economic and employment growth within the Member States, I have decided to vote in favour with a view to implementing innovation, research and development in this area.

name: Ева Паунова (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report on unleashing the potential of research and development within the blue economy for job creation and growth. The blue economy is an extremely important part of the European economy and we need to make the most of the huge capacity it offers. It is our duty to manage and protect our natural assets, such as Europe's oceans, seas and coastal areas, and to sustainably develop the potential of the many economic sectors they offer. Innovation is moving our world forward, so I believe that public funding of new technologies and scientific activity is the most adequate tool to promote growth. The report is important to me because the country I represent has such a huge resource – a border with the Black Sea that can be used even more efficiently and sustainably to create more jobs for Bulgarian citizens and open up new opportunities for development in both our national and international economy.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I think it is of great importance to support the potential of the sea and coast economies with a coordinated approach from the EU, pooling resources where possible.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Commission's 'Innovation in the Blue Economy' communiqué underlines the importance of innovation in all sectors of the blue economy with a view to achieving new jobs and boosting economic growth. The blue economy concept covers a wide range of economic activities related to the seas and oceans, such as fishing, maritime and river transport, tourism and recreational navigation and cruises, ship construction and repair, maritime works and coastal protection, exploration and exploitation of energy sources, and more.  The development of the blue economy implies the continuous inclusion of new scientific knowledge and the development of innovation, and can therefore also give a strong impetus to economic development as well as the creation of new jobs, especially in coastal and island regions and regions highly dependent on fisheries. This report is based on the belief that adequate development of the blue economy requires the development of appropriate occupations associated with it and the creation of quality jobs.  Furthermore, with the blue economy traditionally dominated by men, the report highlights that this is the ideal time to attract women to this economic nih. Given the importance of the report, both for job creation and sustainable use of marine resources, I voted to adopt it.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the potential for job creation and growth in research and innovation in the blue economy sweeps away a broad area of EU competence (fishing, transport, energy, shipbuilding, etc.). It takes into account all aspects of each issue such as the added value of public action, the management of fishing stocks, the preservation of the marine ecosystem, the need for support for the shipbuilding sector. Finally, the report underlines the central role of States in the development of the blue economy, involving the Commission only to promote their cooperation. On the other hand, the report reveals an ideological orientation which leads the rapporteur to neglect certain private sector contributions to the economy. Finally, the report ignores the long-term and sustainable development of the tourism industry.  Although not defect-free, this report also presents some interesting points. I have therefore decided to abstain on this vote.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the report on harnessing the potential of research and innovation in the blue economy, primarily to create jobs and deliver growth. Man's approach to ships as the main means of transporting passengers and goods has changed and is now more airborne, which is why our resources at sea, oceans and coastal areas should be better managed.   The blue economy concept covers a wide range of economic sectors related to seas and oceans, including fisheries, aquaculture, marine transport and inland waterway transport, ports, tourism, sailing and cruising pleasure, shipbuilding and overhaul of navigable facilities, maritime and coastal works and protection, mineral and energy resources and biotechnology.  As the report notes, a better understanding of seas and oceans and life in the sea is needed, as well as environmental impact assessments. The report notes that land-based models that will consume resources rapidly should not be repeated, and the sustainable development of the blue economy requires more transparent availability of data and research projects, as well as education and upskilling.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - I support the conclusion of the Protocol on exploiting the potential for research and innovation in the blue economy for job creation and growth opportunities. The blue economy concept includes a wide range of economic sectors related to the seas and oceans, ranging from traditional and new sectors, including fisheries, aquaculture, marine transport and tourism, sailing and cruising, shipbuilding, and many other occupations.  I believe that the sustainable development of the blue economy could strongly boost growth and economic development and job creation in Member States, especially in coastal regions and island countries. I agree that it would also have a positive impact on the problem of unemployment, which Croatia is also struggling with, for example, with as much as 17.5% of the latest surveys from April 2015.  I also agree that innovation and sustainability should be key pillars of the blue economy for creating growth and jobs, meeting the needs of current and future generations of society. It is also important to note that tourism represents 5% of EU GDP, while in Croatia it accounts for 14%, and thus is arguably the most lucrative activity, especially in the coastal part during the summer, which is another important support factor for this report.  At the same time, as a substitute member of the Fisheries Committee, I believe that support for the development of the fisheries sector under the new Common Fisheries Policy should be increased and the necessary measures should be taken to strengthen the role of fisheries development groups and promote interterritorial cooperation.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Thanks to the correct exploitation of the opportunities offered to us by our maritime heritage it will be possible to create jobs and growth, especially in the islands. The blue economy concept encompasses a wide range of sectors of economic activity related to the seas and oceans, including traditional sectors and emerging sectors. Education and training, research and development are essential elements for the sustainable development of the blue economy. I think it is important to assess the conformity of existing programmes and measures (including at the level of funding) with the development objectives of the blue economy, as well as the interaction between the different existing structures and programmes, as well as their results. I have therefore decided to support this motion for a resolution.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The "blue" economy, in the marine and maritime sectors, now accounts for almost 5.4 million jobs in the EU. In order to boost the growth potential of this economy, the EU has put in place a strategy called 'Blue Growth' with the aim of promoting sustainable growth in the marine and maritime sectors.  The European Parliament has adopted a report aimed at reviving the Union's strategy and recalling the strategic importance of the blue economy in terms of job creation and innovation. I have spoken in favour of this report. The blue economy is a key issue for me, particularly as it represents many opportunities in my riding.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. – (PT) I voted in favour because I consider the commitment to the blue economy crucial and for my conviction that the importance of the seas as an economic, cultural and social resource is crucial.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. With a sea front stretching from the Mediterranean to the North Sea, the European Union has a huge pool of growth and jobs that are still under-exploited. However, the so-called blue economy (economic activities related to seas and oceans such as fishing, renewable ocean energy or ports and maritime transport) still accounts for only 3 to 5% of European GDP. That is why I voted for this report to give more resources to vocational training and research on the blue economy. It also encourages the development of eco-responsible and sustainable fisheries and aquaculture practices with the support of Member States. In addition, we have called on the European Commission to support the mobility of researchers or to take into account the role of local artisanal gastronomy and culture in the development of European coastal tourism.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. This report makes a number of recommendations for achieving the potential for sustainable growth, development and job creation in the blue economy, especially in the coastal and outermost regions. It also draws attention to the need to avoid in the seas and oceans some of the mistakes that have been made on land (exhaustion of resources, unsustainability and concentration of benefits in a few).  Despite the constant references to the importance of the blue economy, member states and the Commission need to really assess the possibilities and priority areas for financing the economy and materialise, once and for all, the potential of the seas and oceans.  Portugal is a clear example of the need to move from intentions to acts.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report on the effective exploitation of the potential of research and innovation in the blue economy to create jobs and growth. The report also highlights the importance of the shipbuilding industry, the modernization and sustainable development of the fisheries sector, tourism and underwater heritage, among other issues. The amendments tabled by the Spanish Socialists also denounce the negative, short- and long-term impact that cuts in public R&D&I investment are having on national research systems, require greater EU support for measures against the degradation of coastal systems, and researchers are invited to promote open access to data supporting the results of their investigations. I would like to highlight the paragraphs of this report devoted to prospecting activities, which request that the Commission propose and update a non-exhaustive list of maritime activities (marine energy production, mining activity on the seabed, sand and gravel exploitation at sea, etc.) that require prior assessments of environmental impact, but also socio-economic.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report, for which I voted, highlights the importance of innovation in all sectors of the blue economy in order to create new jobs and promote growth. The sea and the coastline are indeed important engines of the economy. The Blue Economy concept encompasses a wide range of economic sectors related to the seas and oceans, ranging from traditional to emerging sectors, such as fishing, aquaculture, maritime and river transport, ports and logistics, tourism, recreational boating, cruises, shipbuilding and repair, maritime and coastal defence works. , exploration and exploitation of offshore mineral and energy resources and biotechnology. The text of the report as adopted focuses on several proposals including, among other things, a call to set concrete targets and deadlines to make data available on the marine environment, in line with the Commission's communication entitled 'Innovation in the Blue Economy: Realising the potential for job creation and growth in our seas and oceans'.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This own-initiative report marks the limited scope of the Communication presented by the European Commission on 13 May 2014 entitled "Innovation in the Blue Economy (...)", underlining the need for the Commission to take a more comprehensive and integrated approach to the challenges of innovation and job creation, including both traditional sectors such as fisheries and transport , both the most emerging, such as aquaculture, ports and logistics, tourism, among others. I positively highlight the EP's position on the importance of achieving a comprehensive and specific definition of a blue economy, including all sectoral and intersectoral activities related to oceans, seas and coastal ecosystems, the cross-cutting importance of innovation, the focus on research and development of renewable energies, and the need for strategic programme of activities , direct funding methods and an action plan in order to boost this sector in the future. Only in this way will the blue economy be able to achieve the achievement of the Europe 2020 objectives in the long term through the sustainable growth of the marine and maritime sectors, recognising the importance of the seas and oceans as engines of the European economy, with great potential for innovation and growth.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The blue economy is concerned with shaping and fostering a correct strategy that supports sustainable growth in the marine and maritime sectors. Training, education, development and research are key elements in seizing all the opportunities offered by the blue economy. For these reasons, having contributed a number of amendments to the text, I am voting in favour of this proposal.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that the text is acceptable in its aims of creating jobs and growth.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour since we are in favour of an economy that incorporates R&D&I towards 'eco-innovation', resource efficiency, the circular economy, nature conservation, marine and coastal protection, climate change mitigation and adaptation and, in general, the sustainable use of natural resources from an ecosystem view.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The European Commission's proposals to advance the capitalization of natural resources, particularly maritime ones, under the umbrella of what they have called the 'blue economy' (blue capitalism) are an attempt to provide a political, legal and economic framework for the worrying phenomenon of ocean hoarding, denounced by many social organisations. This report, while having critical aspects of the capitalisation of the oceans, does not strongly express its opposition to this strategy of holistic exploitation of natural resources launched by the Commission, which is why I abstained.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Blue Economy covers a wide spectrum of sectors of economic activity linked to the seas and oceans, including traditional or established sectors and emerging sectors such as fisheries, aquaculture, maritime and river transport, ports and logistics, recreational and cruise tourism and nautical, shipbuilding and repair, maritime and coastal landdefence works , the exploration and exploitation of mineral resources, the exploration and exploitation of wind and marine energy resources and biotechnology, among others. As a special stimulus to some of these sectors, the European Commission has created a strategy called "Blue Growth". I am in favour of this report and I would like to welcome aspects such as the rejection of cuts in the Horizon 2020 Research Framework Programme and that special attention should be paid to the outermost regions, as in the case of the Azores and Madeira. I agree with the investment and use of the sea, as long as it is framed by good knowledge and within the limits of environmental sustainability.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Better management of our blue economy is key to many challenges we face in society, including those of energy independence and developing sustainable energy sources. I voted in favour of this report today because it promotes a better scientific knowledge base for our seas and oceans and improved ability to use, manage and conserve the resources of our seas, oceans and coastal areas. The focus of EU action should be on the creation of sustainable growth and employment in the marine and maritime economy, and on generating growth in areas like the emerging offshore renewable energy technologies.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution. The concept of the blue economy covers a wide range of sectors of economic activity related to the seas and oceans, from fishing to maritime transport and tourism to the extraction of mineral resources. I consider this blue economy to be important for future economic growth in the EU.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ The sea has always represented economic development throughout history, especially for Mediterranean countries. Today, the sea does not have to be a precondition for rapid economic development, but it still plays a big role in the economy of countries like Croatia. I would stress that the "blue economy" as a concept covers a wide range of economic sectors related to the sea and oceans.  Traditional and new economic sectors such as fisheries, aquaculture, marine transport, inland waterway transport, ports, tourism, bio-technology and offshore mineral and energy resources belong to the concept. I believe that for Croatia the concept of a "blue economy" is extremely important, because it represents the direction in which innovation would be encouraged, and on the other hand traditional economic sectors, such as shipbuilding, would be preserved. One example is shipbuilding where the specialization of production enables sustainable and competitive operations of shipyards with strong competition in East Asia.  Another sector, also important for Croatia, is fisheries that have a need to fight undeclared and unregulated fishing and develop innovations such as the introduction of less fuel-consuming fishing vessels. The remaining opportunities in the 'blue economy' point to the need for long-term and sustainable development that can only be achieved through education, upskilling and further research.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU is a global leader in the blue economy sector, but if we want this to continue to be the case, we should look for new opportunities for international competition that will ensure sustainable growth for the sector, not only at European level but also at global level. I voted in favour of the current report because I believe that the development of a blue economy with the support of research and innovation can become a powerful tool not only for the growth and development of the economy, but also for supporting SMEs and creating new jobs. I believe that, by exploiting the potential of research and innovation in the blue economy, we can ensure the development of a wide range of sectors of economic activity related to seas and oceans, but I would also point out that we must not forget the areas that have worked as real pillars in the blue economy up to now (e.g. fishing, shipbuilding and ship repair, etc.). I expect coastlines and island communities to be more involved in the development of the blue economy and, in order to overcome existing disparities, coordination and increased cooperation between Member States and between regions in the blue economy sector will be strengthened.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The blue economy concept covers a wide range of economic sectors related to the seas and oceans covering traditional or established and emerging sectors (fisheries, aquaculture, maritime and river shipping, ports and logistics, tourism, shipbuilding and ship repair...). The protection and protection of natural marine environments are the basis for the conservation, support and development of the blue economy, and sustainable ecosystems are a prerequisite for exploiting the resources of the seas and oceans. In this area, there is a serious lack of data, information and knowledge about the seas and oceans, their resources and biodiversity, and their links to human activities and their environmental and cumulative impact. I believe that there is a need to promote marine and ocean research that would allow the development of a blue economy and a sustainable economic activity. The report contains some important points, such as an integrated approach to all sectors based on the principle of stability, an ecosystem approach and a precautionary principle, which, in my opinion, should be at the heart of all activities affecting the marine environment. I am also in favour of the key points of the report in relation to energy, persistent aquaculture and a cautious approach to deep-sea mining, which is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Blue Economy connects R&D capacities with business activities and allows them to be realized in the structure of the local economy. In this way, it helps job creation, ensures food and health security, recycling and other activities. I voted in favour of the current report because I am sure that it is the link between research and innovation in the blue economy that can benefit regions with high unemployment and thus also help small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this report because I believe that in constant research and innovation in the field of science or social activity lies the potential for the progress of society and the common good, in particular job creation and economic growth across the European Union. This potential lies in innovation and research is also present in the "blue economy" which is very important for Croatia from which I come, since one part of the economy relates to tourism.  Therefore, this sector of the economy needs to be invested in, in particular in research and innovation, so that the whole industry and the economic sector can thrive. Tourism today is an important branch of the European economy, and I think it is important to be competitive in this area, so I supported the report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which aims at developing a better scientific knowledge base for our seas and oceans and at a greater ability to use, manage and conserve the resources of our seas, oceans, and coastal areas. A better management of our blue economy is key to several of our society challenges, including developing sustainable energy sources and energy independence. The focus of the EU actions should be on creating sustainable growth and employment in the marine and maritime economy, and generating growth in areas such as developing offshore renewable energy technologies or supporting research into the blue biotechnology sector.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the proposal as it is full of empty phrases without specific proposals and, moreover, it is written in the spirit of highlighting the role of the state (or the EU) in promoting economic development.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on harnessing the potential of research and innovation in the blue economy to create jobs and growth. In this day and age, in which we are facing many challenges, research and innovation in the blue economy is an important factor in providing new and better jobs and higher economic growth. I welcome the report because it also touches on the potential to exploit marine resources for the development of sustainable renewable energy sources, which can make a significant contribution to the European Energy Security Strategy. This would reduce member states' dependence on non-EU energy sources.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. I am a strong supporter of efforts to promote the blue economy and I am proud that my constituency is leading the way in one of its emerging sectors, with plans for a new tidal lagoon, that could deliver both environmental benefits (in the form of clean, sustainable energy) and investment benefits for the surrounding area.  Notwithstanding the enormous potential of such emerging sectors, I am pleased to also see this report picking up on the role of traditional sectors and highlighting the importance of education, training and research, as this will be central to the development of the blue economy, both economically and sustainably.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal to exploit the potential of the EU's seas needs to be improved in many respects, as developed in the EP report. For example, the report calls on the Commission to draw up a financial framework to promote innovation, the sustainable development of the blue economy and the creation of quality jobs. This framework will coordinate and facilitate access to available financial instruments for local authorities, SMEs, non-governmental organisations and public authorities. The report also quite rightly notes dissatisfaction with the impact of cuts to the budget of the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme and on the impact on national research programmes of public investment cuts. Equally important is the mention that public investment plays a key role in promoting growth and making full use of the potential of the blue economy, which is why they must be strengthened immediately. Finally, the Commission is called upon to provide funds for blue growth in order to finance research, vocational training, the creation of new jobs, SMEs, education, and poverty reduction. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 There can be no development through grants to NGOs. As long as the Union moves along with this logic, the problems will simply be exacerbated.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as the concept of a 'blue economy' covers a wide range of economic and environmental activities related to the seas, oceans and (in part) surface waters of land. One might think at first that the main subject of the report does not concern Hungary, but I must say very much: firstly, because of global climate protection, it does not matter what European strategies we define for the seas and oceans, but there is also a further tangible link. The main elements of the report include fisheries, aquaculture, maritime and inland waterway transport, ports and logistics, tourism and pleasure shipping and cruises, shipbuilding and ship repair, structures for the protection of offshore installations and coastal zones, offshore exploration and exploitation of mineral resources, offshore wind and offshore energy exploitation and biotechnology. So you can see that it's a complex task. I agree with one of the report's demands that the Commission adopt a more comprehensive approach so that we can address the challenges of innovation and job creation in an integrated way. This requires analyses and strategies at regional level, both for marine and land areas with surface catchment areas (e.g. for the Danube).

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The knowledge economy is an opportunity for the development of the European Union, but especially for some of its Member States. In order to maintain and strengthen Europe's competitiveness in the global market, the Community should increase its investment and catalogue of instruments to support projects related to the development of the modern economy. This is also important in very difficult maritime sectors, especially given the huge number of people employed in these sectors.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report, despite the fact that there are a number of points on which we agree, including the need to ensure that the exploitation of marine resources is in balance with the regeneration (and safeguarding) rates of ecosystems, ensuring that the precautionary principle and ecosystem approach are at the heart of the blue economy.  However, precisely out of consistency with this principle, it is inconceivable to us that the definition of a blue economy should include the exploration and exploitation of fossil mineral and energy resources offshore. These industrial activities are short-lived, do not lead to the creation of long-term jobs and end up irreversibly destroying the benthnic ecosystems that we say we want to safeguard. For us, there must be, indeed, a moratorium on these activities, in order to encourage the development and use of sustainable renewable energy resources. This is a red line, "not only" for us at the M5S, "but also" to ensure the prosperity of future generations.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The concept of the blue economy covers a wide range of economic sectors linked to the seas and oceans, involving traditional and emerging sectors such as tourism, aquaculture, ports and logistics, shipbuilding and fisheries, to name a few. If properly managed and sustained, blue economy can be a source of growth, jobs, food and energy. However to achieve this goal we need more research, knowledge, skills and data about our seas and oceans. In this context, the current report makes few important recommendations. First, concerns the need to have an integrated and coordinated approach to the blue economy. Second is the need to consider in a balance matter Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS). Third, is the importance to maintain, support and develop natural marine environments and biodiversity. I voted in favour of the report for the opportunities it offers to manage, and conserve the resources of our seas, oceans, and coastal areas.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Research and innovation, creation of growth and jobs are one of the most important agendas the EU is dealing with at the moment. But we have to ensure that creation of jobs and growth will be tackled in reasonable way with contribution of public but more importantly private sector. This key principle however was not observed in the report. Too little space was given to the private finance and market mechanism while the priority was clearly given to the public sector. Given by these facts, I followed the line of the ALDE Group and  abstained for the final vote on the Ferreira report on Blue Economy.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒I voted for a report advocating strategic planning in the blue economy, direct funding methods, prioritization targeting and an action plan to boost the sector. I support the Call on the Commission, in cooperation with Member States, to assess the financing needs of the blue economy with a view to achieving sustainable growth, development and job creation potential, while focusing on fisheries-dependent regions.  That is why I believe that supporting the modernisation and sustainable development of the fisheries and fish products processing sectors, prioritising small fisheries, will be extremely beneficial. I am pleased that the important role of macro-regional strategies, such as the Adriatic and Ionian Region Strategy, has been recognised when responding to common challenges and seizing common opportunities, but also recognising the fact that Europe's oceans and seas are very diverse and that the Commission cannot apply an equal approach for all.  I think it is very important to promote workers' rights and ensure safe working conditions to make the sector attractive to young people, while ensuring the participation of coastal and island communities at all stages of its development. I also agree with the claim that the development of this sector will be driven by a single platform with all European funds for financing activities that can be accessed by citizens, so I supported this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the Report on Research and Innovation in the Blue Economy for Job creation and Growth. The blue economy concept covers a wide range of economic sectors related to the seas and oceans, ranging from traditional to emerging sectors. Including fisheries, aquaculture, maritime transport, inland waterway transport, ports and logistics, tourism, sailing, cruises, shipbuilding, maritime work to coastal protection, research and exploitation at sea of mineral and energy resources and biotechnology. With the fundamental pillars laid correctly and the timeframe, the sea and coastline can push the economy forward with many of these aspects.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour because we are in favour of an economy that incorporates R&D&I towards 'eco-innovation', resource efficiency, the circular economy, nature conservation, marine and coastal protection, climate change mitigation and adaptation and, in general, the sustainable use of natural resources from an ecosystem view.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. Although this report has some flaws, it presents many interesting axes on the development of the marine economy, a sector crucial for France, putting States at the centre of the issue and giving the EU only a role as a funder of research projects and facilitator of interstate cooperation. By emphasizing the need for research and training to make full use of the potential of the blue economy, the report sees right. However, it is a little too focused on European-European issues, in a fundamentally regional and international area. Indeed, the state of economic and environmental cooperation on the Basins of the Mediterranean Sea and the Black Sea is really missing from the report. The optimization of shipping through a carbon tax levied at the border is a track that the report should have looked at in its analysis of this sector. An amendment was tabled in the committee to this effect by the RBM MEPs and was rejected by 26 votes to 25. So I chose abstention.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2011, the Commission adopted a Communication on 'blue growth', which highlights the potential of Europe's coastal areas and seas to be a major source of new jobs and growth, thereby contributing to the achievement of the objectives set out in the Europe 2020 strategy. To develop the potential of the blue economy in Europe, more action is needed at both EU and Member State level to address a number of issues aimed, inter alia: the significant lack of data on seas and oceans, their resources and biodiversity and interactions with human activities, the need for strategic planning of activities in the blue economy , priority-oriented direct funding methods and an action plan to boost the sector by 2020. There is also a need to create an appropriate financial framework to stimulate innovation, ensure the sustainable development of the blue economy and create jobs, a framework that combines, coordinates and facilitates access to various available financial instruments.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour because we are in favour of an economy that incorporates R&D&I towards 'eco-innovation', resource efficiency, the circular economy, nature conservation, marine and coastal protection, climate change mitigation and adaptation and, in general, the sustainable use of natural resources from an ecosystem view.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote was positive, because this report sends a strong message from the Parliament to the Commission concerning further development of the so-called Blue Economy (economic activities related to the European seas), well beyond research and development issues: The Parliament underlines, that an integrated and sustainability based approach should be taken for any development of the related sectors, and it sets clear limits on exploitation for the sake of growth. It notably highlights the limits for deep sea mining, aquaculture and energy exploitation, and further research on the impacts of human activities to marine ecosystems.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. Innovation must be one of the pillars on which Europe consolidates growth in the coming years. All sectors must be involved in the use and development of innovative tools, and seas and oceans should be no exception. The rapporteur's proposals for the report are trying to move forward in this regard, so I think it is necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which aims at developing our scientific knowledge base for the seas, oceans and coastal areas as well as at a greater ability to use, manage and conserve the resources therein. A better management of our blue economy is the key to many of the problems facing our society, including developing sustainable energy sources and energy independence. The focus of the EU actions should be on creating sustainable growth and employment in the marine and maritime economy, and generating growth in areas such as developing offshore renewable energy technologies or supporting research into the blue biotechnology sector. This will not only promote economic growth but also promote the sustainable use of our natural resources wherever they may be.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the initiative report of my GUE/NGL colleague, Joel Ferreira, on the "blue economy", i.e. the economy of the sea. The maritime space is a rapidly developing sector with high potential for job creation. There is no shortage of challenges in developing a sustainable common policy in this area. Ensuring the fundamental balance between economic, social and environmental interests regarding the potential of this space is fundamental.  This report highlights the need for public investment in marine research and innovation to promote sustainable development of the sector. This sustainable development must be achieved above all through support for small-scale fishing, including the illegal fishing and industrial exploitation of fisheries resources, which this report defends. I also welcome the fact that the concept of 'blue energy' is a leitmotif of this report, and that it places wind energy and the energy produced by ocean currents and the promotion of organic aquaculture at the centre of the concerns. It remains to be seen what will happen to all these recommendations in the other EU bodies.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Concept of Blue Economy covers a broad spectrum of sectors of economic activity linked to the seas and oceans, including traditional or established sectors and emerging sectors such as: fisheries, aquaculture, maritime and river transport, ports and logistics, recreational and cruise tourism and nautical, ship building and repair, maritime and coastal defence works, exploration and exploitation of mineral resources (offshore) , exploration and exploitation of offshore and biotechnology and biotechnology, among others. In this sense, the Blue Economy lacks public policies that can transform this set of potentialities into social and economic developments. Any measure to introduce market logic and strategies for privatising or granting public spaces can only give bad results.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Although the report highlights the right points, the proposed measures are aimed at giving the Commission more powers of determination, establishing more quotas, spending more European and public money on a wide range of projects and seeking the salvation of the blue economy in a greater role for the state. I therefore reject this request.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The blue economy is a key tool for the development of European countries bordering the Mediterranean. Many of the social and employment challenges can only be answered by a better understanding of the marine environment and its potential. In recent years, the seabed has increasingly been used for the exploitation of energy resources and in particular for the extraction of mineral resources. However, conscious use of blue resources cannot be separated from respect for sustainable development. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's resolution on unlocking the potential of research and innovation in the blue economy to create jobs and growth. Firstly, the report again throws a lot of dust around nothing, for example when it calls on the Commission to 'create regulatory and legal conditions that encourage investment in renewable energy in the blue economy, and to create a clear, stable framework to support research, businesses and the government, enabling increased investment in innovative projects to develop energy from renewable sources'. This has nothing to do with subsidiarity. I reject calls for the Commission to give it more powers to adopt further rules. Secondly, the reports on the economy do not get better when they are coloured. After the green economy comes the blue one. It is likely that the European Parliament's Gender Committee will soon want to promote the pink economy. This new theory of colour shows a great deal, but above all that the EU does not understand much about the economy.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 Hardening the potential for research and innovation in the blue economy with a view to creating sustainable jobs and growth is important and something the EU should focus on. Unfortunately, the resolution focuses almost exclusively on public investment, at the expense of private investment as well, and also calls for additional subsidies for sectors that already have access to EU funds. For these reasons, I was unable to support the resolution and chose to abstain in the final vote.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report put to the vote raises the situation of the maritime economy. It calls for the development of coastal and coastal areas, better use of hydropower and existing infrastructure. draws attention to the need to develop shipbuilding through the use of increasingly innovative technologies in order to increase the competitiveness of European products in relation to products originating in the Far East, which is a shipbuilding tycoon; The maritime economy is very complex, it consists not only of traditional sectors that need to be invested, but also very modern, with great potential. The use of biotechnological research, the exploitation of mineral and energy resources is becoming increasingly important. All scientific achievements in maritime sectors should be used to improve the quality of blue economy activities.  This report, noting the need for fisheries development, better use of fish stocks and all the abovementioned aspects, is needed from the point of view of Polish, where the maritime sector exists but requires greater interest. I therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on exploiting the potential of Research and Development in the blue economy to create jobs and growth, as I felt that it is necessary to combat opacity in terms of knowledge of campaigns and research projects developed in the seas and oceans, in particular those financed with public funds. Considering that the development of the Blue Economy can strongly boost economic growth and job creation, greater investment in R&D associated with the seas and oceans is an instrument of the greatest importance. Thus, it is important to have an integrated approach to the innovation challenge and an assessment of the suitability of existing financial support to the blue economy's development objectives.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report denounces the "short- and long-term impact that cuts in public investment in research, development and innovation are having" and argues that "public investment plays a decisive role in promoting development and making full use of the potential of the Blue Economy", as is the case with Portugal, the country with the largest Exclusive Economic Zone of the European Union and one of the largest in the world. Among several measures, it advocates "the creation of an appropriate financial framework to stimulate the development of the Blue Economy and the creation of specialised jobs, integrating and articulates the various available financial instruments – the Structural and Investment Funds (EMFF, ERDF, ESF, Cohesion Fund), the research framework programme and others' and stresses, 'the need to promote better adequacy of the various instruments to the needs of various actors – public institutions , companies, in particular SMEs, non-governmental organisations, etc. – and a wide dissemination of existing opportunities." On the other hand, it calls on "states and regional authorities to invest in an ambitious social dimension of blue growth and maritime literacy".  We voted for it.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this report. She was very well prepared by the rapporteur, Shojdra. I find it very important in a situation where we are fighting youth unemployment not just talking about benefits and passive assistance to these people, but this report clearly states how to actively improve young people's ability to do business and thus take care of themselves. I think this active positive approach is important. I welcome the report and i see some important aspects towards the Commission, such as the call for erasmus, erasmus+ programmes to be addressed more in the future to young people's ability to do business, to develop entrepreneurial skills, and I also see it as important that the report clearly states that we should break down borders for young people within european countries and enable them to do business anywhere in Europe. It's important and I think it can help reduce their unemployment.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, I supported this report, because youth entrepreneurship needs to be an important part of the political strategy to help young generations facing high unemployment and the inability to achieve professionally. The problem of youth unemployment generates much bigger problems such as increased poverty and social exclusion. There is also a huge gap between education and training and labour market opportunities and opportunities, which is considered one of the main reasons for youth unemployment. This is why key abilities in young people should be encouraged. Initiative and entrepreneurship are key if young people want to participate in today's economic moment. All levels of education should help practical entrepreneurship skills and motivate young people to feel initiative and feel social responsibility. Member States as well as regional and local authorities have the burden of fostering the development of education and training in order to start start up companies, include incubators and professional mentoring, as well as social entrepreneurship projects in working with local communities.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Mr President, entrepreneurship – the ability to start your own business or to identify an opportunity in the marketplace – is something that can be taught. Yes, it comes naturally to some people, but it can also be taught in our schools, in our universities, and in our colleges. It is something that the report addresses and I would like to see it included in our curricula in schools, because it is very important to give young people the ability and the confidence to think for themselves and not depend on others to give them information, but instead to have confidence that they, too, can be a successful business person and can use their energy to get out there in the marketplace and develop and innovate.  As we know, around five million young people under 25 were unemployed last December in the EU. That unemployment rate is unacceptable, we all agree with that, but what can be done about it? There are a number of facets and one of them is to encourage young people to start their own businesses. In order to give them the confidence to do that we need to provide support, both financial and logistical – to ensure that is in place – and encourage our young people to take up the challenge.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, at a time when youth unemployment has hit red, particularly in the countries of the European South, the promotion of young people's entrepreneurship, through education and training, is crucial, especially for my country, Greece, where the memorandum has failed and the Troika has sent young people into unemployment and foreign affairs. The youth unemployment rate in Greece is the highest in Europe and exceeds 53%. I therefore voted in favour of the report because it proposes actions that help to reduce youth unemployment, such as by integrating financial courses into the teaching programme. Young people will be nurtured by the entrepreneurial culture and incentives and ideas for setting up new companies will be provided. At the same time, young people will be able to acquire skills in the field of media and digital skills. Finally, of particular importance are the programmes that combine education and studies with parallel work in enterprises, since this will give our young people practical experience.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – I strongly support the broadest possible teaching of entrepreneurship and financial knowledge to young people and to people in general. Who would be opposed to people being enlightened and responsible in their financial affairs? Well, there are those who would be against it: endlessly cash-hungry and profit-hungry banks. I would like to remind everyone that such a 'soft' tool is not enough to educate people about responsible behaviour in finance. They need strict prohibition laws. For example, in the face of practices that are carried out at the airport in Hungary: by the time you get from the entrance to your flight, employees of two or three banks will throw themselves at you as hyenens and try tricks and tricks to get people without financial knowledge to sign loan schemes. They do so even after the tragedy of foreign currency lenders. This can only be defended by legislation, not education.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, the general direction of this report is right. Equipping young people with the right skills and attitude to contribute to our economy remains a huge challenge. However, the problems that we now face are surely compounded not only by the financial crash, but also by the economic direction of Europe’s leaders, which has consigned many young people from the Member States represented in this House to unemployment registers for considerable periods of time. In Northern Ireland this was compounded by the effects of years of terrorism and division. I am glad to say that organisations such as East Belfast Enterprise, using money from the European Social Fund, are supporting people not only by helping them enter employment and education, but also by training them to nurture their own business ideas. Surely this is the future. I am disappointed that, in the new round of ESF funding, the Minister responsible in Northern Ireland has limited the input of the voluntary and community sector to level-one qualifications only. This is a situation that Europe must take note of and change.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, encouraging young people to entrepreneurship through changes in the education and training system is extremely important, especially in these moments when in Europe some Member States have unemployment of more than 50%, i.e. every other young person is out of work. Young people testify that they go to various additional forms of education, acquire new knowledge and skills, but are still out of work. That is why these forms of self-employment and encouraging young people to entrepreneurship can significantly help to solve the problem of youth unemployment. Entrepreneurial spirit and a positive atmosphere towards entrepreneurship have been building since they were little. That is why it is necessary to introduce special programs already in kindergartens, elementary and secondary schools, and then on to faculties. On college campuses, of course, through entrepreneurial incubators we need to help young people realize their ideas and start jobs.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I share the view that the gap between education, training and the labour market is one of the main reasons for the high levels of youth unemployment in Europe. In order to combat this anomaly, it is necessary in the first place to provide young people with much-needed skills, such as entrepreneurial spirit, that will help them to develop fully professionally and personally.  We must not forget that entrepreneurship is the backbone of the European economy. It has the potential to create jobs and growth and boost competitiveness. It is therefore vital that we support young people who want to start their own projects but face a number of difficulties along the way.  Entrepreneurship education must be accessible to all, because entrepreneurial spirit and attitude can be developed in everyone. It is our duty to provide an appropriate learning environment that develops the skills and talents of the young.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because, once again, this is a report that burdens responsibility for youth unemployment on the shoulders of young Europeans. Such actions are carried out on the assumption that young Europeans do not find employment because of their aversion to entrepreneurship, which is completely false, considering that the countries with the highest rates of self-employed are those in southern Europe, those with the highest youth unemployment. We believe that promoting entrepreneurship in education and training is nothing more than a cynical exercise to encourage self-exploitation of young people and to avoid taking responsibility for a business system that is unable to generate sufficient work and wealth for new generations. That's why I've decided to vote against it.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Union's interventionism in the policies of the Member States is a real problem that I am fighting against with my colleagues in the National Front. Nevertheless, we are sensitive to actions that promote entrepreneurship among young people, especially through education and information. This report aims to reward entrepreneurial behaviour and to promote the creation of businesses in the educational journey, thanks to tools such as Erasmus. Overall, this report is therefore positive and in line with our programme. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report calls for further EU funding, which is incompatible with my mandate as a UKIP MEP, and sadly I had to vote against it. However, I support the principle of developing youth entrepreneurship.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to establish a strategic, legal and financial framework for the coordination and implementation of education activities in the European Union. Lifelong learning and mobility programmes must be implemented, quality and effectiveness of education and training improved, equal opportunities, social cohesion and active citizenship, and strengthening creativity and innovation, including entrepreneurship, at all levels of education and training. I support the calls for the Commission to develop methodological assistance, namely the establishment of education standards for entrepreneurship education and support for training courses to improve teacher skills. To this end, it is necessary to allocate specific financial instruments under erasmus+ programme, where possible, within this period and to provide a legal and financial framework for the post-2020 period.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft report proposes to reward entrepreneurial behaviour, and to promote the creation of businesses in the educational journey. It focuses on the development of the capacities to be undertaken, including within the Erasmus course. I therefore voted in favour, but remains vigilant about the Commission's temptation to take care of the Member States' educational programmes.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. With nearly 5 million young Europeans unemployed, all relevant levers should be used to reverse this human tragedy. One of these, highlighted in this report, which I approved, is to awaken the entrepreneurial spirit and sense of initiative among young people and to prepare them as best as possible for the knowledge economy and the ways in which today's society operates. In this regard, the rapporteur stresses the need to promote entrepreneurship among young people through education and training.  In concrete terms, Parliament's resolution urges the Commission to: - adopt a systematic approach; - use the available instruments; - develop skills at all levels of education.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because youth entrepreneurship is a strategic issue in the Union. But this requires strengthening and developing innovative pedagogies for teachers and students so that they can acquire skills for social entrepreneurship capable of generating employment that addresses social inclusion and the fight against poverty. Close collaboration between the public-private sector is also needed to implement dual training and foster the culture of entrepreneurial risk. The Commission should therefore promote these issues in concrete initiatives. On the other hand, Member States, with the involvement of local and regional entities, should encourage the exchange of young people to carry out quality practices. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft report on the promotion of entrepreneurship among young people through education and training aims to reward entrepreneurial behaviour and to promote the creation of businesses in the educational journey. It focuses on the development of the capacities to be undertaken, including within the Erasmus course.  It also calls on the Commission to include education and entrepreneurship training in more EU arrangements. As in the CULT committee, where I had tabled several amendments (rejected), I still voted in favour of this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this text, which calls for exchanges between young European entrepreneurs to be stimulated.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the need for youth entrepreneurship to be part of the current political strategy to support young people, as well as the European objectives of growth, employment, education and social inclusion. Thanks to the Socialist amendments, the report has taken a more social approach, betting on the development of standards in business education linked to social responsibility and their integration into national education plans. It also has an impact on the need to provide all young people with computing skills and cross-cutting and business skills to enable them to fully harness the potential of the digital world to help them create new forms of development, transmission and entrepreneurship promotion.
