It also calls on the Council and the Commission to develop methodological tools and support and to make them available to national education systems in the field of education and training for entrepreneurship, including social entrepreneurship, and calls on the latter to increase the amount of support for young entrepreneurs under the Structural and Investment Funds.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it assesses the use of education and training measures to promote entrepreneurship among young people. Entrepreneurial skills and competences should be promoted in order to promote self-employment among young people and give the younger generation a real opportunity to do their own business, as well as to help themselves and society in general. In order to achieve this, it is necessary to develop innovative pedagogical directions that are more based on participation and learners, and to promote the acquisition of universal competences necessary to develop an entrepreneurial mindset. Parliament recommends balancing economic and social aspects in education strategies in order to make entrepreneurship a success through education. The Commission is called upon to develop a strategy to develop universal skills at all levels of education and training and in all types of education and training: critical thinking, problem solving, initiative, cooperation, direction, planning and leadership capacity, as they benefit different professions and sectors.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With the report by Mrs Michaela Sojdrová, the European Parliament adopted a comprehensive and high-quality report on the promotion of young people's entrepreneurship through education and training. The high youth unemployment rate in the European Union remains a pressing problem, with an average of 22% in the EU and more than 50% in each country and region. confidently become part of today's knowledge-based economy and society. Business education at all levels (basic, intermediate and high level) is a very effective tool for motivating young people and making decisions about starting their own businesses and careers and succeeding in this career. In today's Europe, there is a great need for an approach that supports young people, for example in terms of their creativity, risk-taking capacity, failure management and responsible behaviour. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. The report on promoting youth entrepreneurship was very much supported. I believe that educating young people about entrepreneurship, in addition to proper career guidance and a labour-tailored education system, is essential for the stability of the European economy. Entrepreneurship education at all levels is a very effective tool for encouraging young people to make business and career decisions and have a successful career. Today's Europe urgently needs an approach that supports young people, such as their creativity, their ability to overcome risks and failures, and to act responsibly. The high, on average, 22% youth unemployment rate in the EU is a problem, on the one hand, but on the other hand, the challenge of finding the potential of young people who are being forced to do so is a challenge. I believe that the current circumstances also have an impact on the huge rise in so-called start-ups and entrepreneurial initiatives. Young people are proof that it is possible to adapt, but of course it must also be followed by a policy by creating a favourable business environment. Strengthening knowledge and innovation is a key boost to future growth, followed by quality and labour-based education systems that at the same time encourage young people to be entrepreneurial. Entrepreneurship is a talent, but like any talent, it needs to be nurtured and guided. Therefore, Member States need to strengthen entrepreneurial skills for young people through legislation and through a quality apprenticeship and traineeship system.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support my colleague's report on promoting youth entrepreneurship through education and training. In my view, the report is much better balanced than the first draft of the report, and the amendments focused on how youth education and training can only succeed by adding the competences – ability, behaviour and knowledge needed to use skills. Most importantly, youth entrepreneurship must become part of a strategy to support today's generation of young people for employment.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non—legislative and non—binding report because it calls on the EU to promote the reform of national education systems to which it has no competence.  It calls for more EU funding, action and programmes. It calls for more support and funding to Erasmus (which is a glorified, expensive and bureaucratic exchange programme). Only our elected government has the right to legislate and oversee education programmes and definitely not unelected and unaccountable EU Commissioners in Brussels. The EU has no competence to interfere with education policy.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on promoting youth entrepreneurship through education and training, which is a very important issue in Ireland, considering our high youth unemployment levels – which have stagnated at about 20% in the South. Entrepreneurship is an important driver of economic growth and job creation. We need to move towards a situation where enterprise, especially at a community level, is encouraged, facilitated and adequately supported. Access to finance, and the absence of social welfare and tax benefit supports are huge worries for many entrepreneurs. The focus of this report is on our young people and they do face similar obstacles. Our young people are at even more of a disadvantage and it is they who have been hardest hit as a result of the economic crisis. The Youth Employment Initiative has fallen far short of what is required to address this situation, in Ireland, and across Europe. This report presents an opportunity for us to ensure that our young people who have good and innovative ideas for new start-ups are supported and encouraged in the best way possible.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this text because I am convinced that it is essential for the future of Europe to teach our young people the importance of entrepreneurship and encourage them to undertake their own business so that we can make full use of all its positive effects.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Educating young people in entrepreneurship can only be possible if real collaboration with schools is activated: the greater the interdisciplinarity and openness to the outside world of school, the greater the chances of success of entrepreneurial training. Although the number of youth startups that fail before reaching the market is very high, it is documented that an entrepreneur in the second experience has a better chance of success and that experimental entrepreneurship start-up projects carried out in schools have given positive feedback. Therefore, as young people are our future, not only economically understood, it is necessary to support entrepreneurship education and startups through a widespread dissemination of school projects on the subject integrated with the business world and by supporting the EU Microcredit Fund so that young talents seeking capital have a friendly institution to turn to to try to put their ideas into practice.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is primarily a recommendation to states as education falls within their exclusive jurisdiction. At a time when the youth unemployment rate in the EU is over 22% and investment is slowing down, there is a need to promote initiative, risk-taking, entrepreneurial spirit and creativity. This is why the report encourages states to implement programs and activities that promote entrepreneurship throughout schooling.  We believe that entrepreneurship is essential to foster investment, innovation and job creation. The mass unemployment we know will not be stopped solely through these initiatives, but entrepreneurship is closely linked to the emergence of new start-ups that have an increased capacity to find alternatives to traditional financing channels. This is why it is essential to provide entrepreneurship courses and to set up business incubators, especially in business and engineering schools, especially when we know that the majority of graduates work for large groups.  So I voted for this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are 4.85 million young people in the European Union who currently do not have a job.  This phenomenon obliges us not to remain impassive and to act as quickly as possible to reduce this extremely large number of young people who do not work in the labour market. Concrete solutions are needed to support young people and guide them to a profession suitable for their studies. In this regard, the Report on the promotion of entrepreneurship among young people through education and training provides an effective tool to motivate young people to start their own business and career and ultimately succeed in this career.  Strengthening entrepreneurship education in schools, vocational education institutions and universities will have a positive impact on the dynamic nature of entrepreneurship in European economies. I voted in favour of the above-mentioned report because investing in entrepreneurship education is one of the most cost-effective investments the European Union can make.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report calling for exchanges between young entrepreneurs in Europe as well as with the Erasmus programme for Young Entrepreneurs. Despite a fundamentally critical position, I have no hesitation in supporting reports which, at least in content, seek to steer the European Commission's policies in a reasonable direction (in this case the entrepreneurial spirit of young people).

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament wants to contribute to the achievement of common European objectives in the field of youth entrepreneurship by monitoring the quality of education. With today's vote, the EP calls for the rapid dissemination of innovation focused on entrepreneurial skills and underlines the need for methodological and financial support at the level of an EU programme. I support 'Entrepreneurial education' at all levels, because I believe it is an effective tool to motivate young people so that, following a decision-making process, they can start and successfully support their own businesses or careers.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the resolution on promoting the entrepreneurial spirit of youth through education and training. Educating for entrepreneurship can be extremely effective in motivating young people and influencing their decision to embark on an entrepreneurial career path and help them achieve success in that career.  Never before has it become clear that Europe must encourage the creativity and responsible behaviour of young people, helping them to manage their ability to face risks and to believe in their own ideas. Although the spirit of enterprise is undoubtedly a personal gift, recent studies show that entrepreneurial knowledge can be learned through an education and training process: entrepreneurship education has a positive effect on individuals, helping to increase their career ambitions, improving skills, entrepreneurial attitudes and creative thinking, with huge positive effects on the whole economy.  Given that entrepreneurship, and in particular small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), is the backbone of the EU economy and is the most important and main source of new jobs, I have chosen to vote in favour of the text.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on promoting youth entrepreneurship through education and training, which is a very important issue in Ireland, considering our high youth unemployment levels – which have stagnated at about 20% in the South. Entrepreneurship is an important driver of economic growth and job creation. We need to move towards a situation where enterprise, especially at a community level, is encouraged, facilitated and adequately supported. Access to finance, and the absence of social welfare and tax benefit supports are huge worries for many entrepreneurs. The focus of this report is on our young people and they do face similar obstacles. Our young people are at even more of a disadvantage and it is they who have been hardest hit as a result of the economic crisis. The Youth Employment Initiative has fallen far short of what is required to address this situation, in Ireland, and across Europe. This report presents an opportunity for us to ensure that our young people who have good and innovative ideas for new start-ups are supported and encouraged in the best way possible.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report calls for further EU funding, which is incompatible with my mandate as a UKIP MEP, and sadly I had to vote against it. However, I support the principle of developing youth entrepreneurship.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that promoting youth entrepreneurship will be beneficial for citizens especially young people. They can adapt what they have gained from education and training in professional and private lives.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report presents a marked functionalisation of education systems to the teaching of a business model in which there is completely no reference to the awareness that learners must have human rights, the dignity of workers, maximum environmental protection to be put in place in the creation of a business activity. The only reference to corporate social responsibility is used to encourage private funding and greater private participation in the provision of training. I voted against. For these reasons, I voted against the report by the college Michaela Šojdrová.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which contributes to making young European citizens more accessible to the labour market.  This report calls for the transmission of entrepreneurial skills, the development of initiative and a sense of social responsibility at all levels and types of education. By suggesting the consideration of media and digital skills in education and training, this report promotes the adaptation of the skills of young European citizens to current and future labour market needs.  Finally, by encouraging the continuous vocational training of teachers in the field of entrepreneurship and the promotion of relations between schools and businesses, this report offers a pragmatic approach that can boost the professional integration of young Europeans.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it aims to reward entrepreneurial behaviour, and to promote the creation of businesses in the educational journey, with an emphasis on developing the capacity to undertake.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the light of worrying data on youth unemployment in the EU, which in some Member States peak at over 50%, education and education for entrepreneurship are also tools to support employment. Entrepreneurship education – at all levels of education and learning – plays a crucial role, also in promoting the entrepreneurial spirit of young people, promoting their capacity for initiative, creativity and innovation.  Therefore, the inclusion within the national educational provision of educational standards for youth entrepreneurship education, as well as the preparation of training programmes for teachers, can contribute to the creation of new businesses, enabling an increase in employment (in line with the objectives set out in the Europe 2020 Strategy). The resolution also highlights the need for Member States to make effective efforts to use all the financial resources made available by the EU – in particular, under the Erasmus+ and Erasmus programmes for young entrepreneurs – with the aim of strengthening links between businesses and education, sharing best practices, encouraging mobility, thereby creating the conditions for fostering an entrepreneurial culture among young people regardless of their socio-economic status and socio-economic status. Kind. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the promotion of young people's entrepreneurship through education and training, especially today when youth unemployment rates are very high. At the same time, we note that fiscal consolidation in the Member States most affected by the crisis should not be implemented at the expense of the creation of new jobs. We believe that promoting entrepreneurship is an important driver of economic growth that leads to the creation of new jobs, creates new businesses, opens up new markets, strengthens competitiveness and generates wealth, ultimately promoting the prosperity of countries and peoples.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to promote entrepreneurship in young people through education and training. As of February 2015, there were around 5 million young people unemployed in Europe. The average youth unemployment rate in the EU is 22%, but in some Member States and regions it exceeds 50%. In order to combat youth unemployment and educate and train young people for entrepreneurship, the European Parliament calls on the Member States to promote young people's entrepreneurial skills through legislative initiatives aimed at ensuring quality traineeships; calls on the Commission to promote youth policies (Erasmus+) that develop their entrepreneurial skills; calls on the Member States and regional and local authorities to work to promote the implementation of training activities for the start-up and management of start-ups and to make full use of the resources of the EU Structural Funds, and in particular the European Social Fund, in order to promote education and training for entrepreneurship and the development of digital skills as well as the EaSI Funds , COSME, Erasmus for young entrepreneurs and the European Youth Employment Initiative

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report in the hope that it will be only a first step in a broader strategy to stimulate entrepreneurship in Europe. Creatile destruction (to quote Schumpeter), the ability to break patterns to bring new products to the markets or in an innovative way, imagining a different world in which needs are different and new ways to meet them is something that must start from education. It is good to learn what schools already teach, but better still if the education system focuses on creating what is needed most in Europe: work. I congratulate the rapporteur on her excellent work.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Young entrepreneurship should be an important part of today's youth support policy strategy in terms of EU targets for growth, jobs, education and social inclusion, as well as for reducing youth unemployment in the EU. Jobs and growth are a key priority of European policy and an objective for Member States.  I support this report, as I believe it is essential that Member States continue to effectively integrate entrepreneurship education into education programmes and use the available financial instruments, in particular the EU Structural Funds, to this end. I support the need for systematic evaluation and monitoring of the results of current and future activities in the field of entrepreneurship education, as well as their impact on employment and development of SMEs. With this report, the European Parliament wishes to contribute to the achievement of common European objectives in this area by monitoring the quality of education and by inviting the rapid dissemination of innovations focused on entrepreneurial skills, as well as the need for methodological and financial support at eu programme level.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because we need to take much more action across the EU to achieve gender equality at all levels of the education system. Unfortunately, we are still a long way from gender equality. And I supported every initiative so that girls and women would eventually receive the same recognition and reward for their performance.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the latest statistics, in February 2015, young people out of work in the EU-28 amounted to 4.85 million, a figure that was slightly down on the previous year, but certainly unacceptable. Given that youth entrepreneurship must be an important element of the political strategy to support the current generation in terms of growth, employment and social inclusion and to act as a tool to reduce youth unemployment in the European Union, I consider it essential and a priority to promote entrepreneurship in young people through the inclusion of specific initiatives within the training programme and the educational path, which can stimulate entrepreneurship training. I am therefore in favour of this report because I strongly believe in the need to establish specific programmes at all levels of education that progressively develop a strong entrepreneurial culture and that ensure that young people complete their personal background with specific and practical skills and abilities. These skills can only be developed through the introduction of modules related to basic finance, the economy and the business environment and the establishment of activities and accompanying figures, mentoring and professional orientation for students, also favoring the development of ICT skills, which allow young people to fully exploit the potential of the digital world.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against because the report presents a marked functionalisation of education systems to the teaching of a business model in which there is completely no reference to the awareness that learners must have human rights, the dignity of workers, maximum environmental protection to be put in place in the creation of a business activity. All the amendments on this subject in the CULT Committee have been rejected. There is only one reference to corporate social responsibility, but it is used to encourage private funding and greater private participation in the provision of training.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because, once again, this is a report that burdens responsibility for youth unemployment on the shoulders of young Europeans. Such actions are carried out on the assumption that young Europeans do not find employment because of their aversion to entrepreneurship, which is completely false, considering that the countries with the highest rates of self-employed are those in southern Europe, those with the highest youth unemployment. We believe that promoting entrepreneurship in education and training is nothing more than a cynical exercise to encourage self-exploitation of young people and to avoid taking responsibility for a business system that is unable to generate sufficient work and wealth for new generations. That's why I've decided to vote against it.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because I believe that healthy youth entrepreneurship can act as a driving force for economic growth throughout Europe and consequently to reduce the levels of unemployment, especially among young people, that persist in several Member States. I believe that young people need to develop not only an entrepreneurial mindset but also skills and knowledge that are cross-sectoral or specific to the different professions that only an education and training capable of responding (adequate) to current and future challenges can provide. We are experimenting with the experience of the "Youth Guarantee" with not always satisfactory results. The strategy contains important turning points in the approach to entering young people into the labour market, in particular on the concept of self-entrepreneurship. However, a system that prefers welfare aspects still prevails, which rarely succeed in giving positive results in terms of stabilization. We must start from the analysis of the limits of this experience in order to build a roadmap that really makes Europe an added value for the younger generation.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report has an important message, as the youth unemployment rate is still too high in Europe. The only way to reduce the unemployment rate in the long term is to adapt education to the needs of the labour market. For example, it would be important to develop entrepreneurship at all levels of education. I support the fact that the report calls on the Commission to increase the number of quality apprenticeships, as this will help young people learn creative thinking, problem solving, teamwork and ingenuity. Erasmus+ and erasmus for young entrepreneurs are very effective and successful, giving young people the opportunity to study and train abroad. Every way must be made to help young people find their place in the labour market after completing education, and the report provided several ideas for this, which is why I supported the report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which deals with entrepreneurship education, a policy area which I have been personally working on over the last months. Acquiring entrepreneurial skills has proven to have very positive impact on individuals as it helps increasing their career ambitions and equips them with important skills in life. Thus it is very encouraging to see the EU push for further focus on this area.  However the initial report was too business-oriented and the S&D Group proposed changes that heavily improved the report. These included promoting entrepreneurial education at all stages of life and in both formal and informal settings, as opposed to the original proposal that only dealt with primary and secondary years. The final version of the report also calls for development of educational standards for entrepreneurship education and their integration into national curricula. I believe that it is crucial that youth entrepreneurship becomes an integral part of the political strategy to support today’s youth generation in terms of EU goals for growth, employment, education and social inclusion. Hence I supported this important report.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support and agree with the rapporteur that 'Entrepreneurial education' at all levels can be a very effective tool to motivate young people, following a decision-making process, to start their own business and career and also to succeed in this career. I believe that this is an approach that supports young people by developing their creativity, their ability to cope with risks, failure management and responsible behaviour, qualities absolutely necessary in today's Europe.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report focuses on promoting entrepreneurship and entrepreneurial skills among young people at all stages of the school/university journey and through training. The rapporteur proposes a series of measures to be implemented at national and European level, such as highlighting the sense of initiative and responsibilities; The introduction of new learning techniques through theoretical and practical modules; The development of digital skills and media the fight against poverty and the promotion of inclusion through social entrepreneurship; the lifelong improvement and development of teachers' qualifications; the launch of training and start-up programmes by Member States. At a time when unemployment among under-25s exceeds 22% in Europe, I believe there is an urgent need to provide young people with practical skills to meet the demands of the labour market and develop their entrepreneurial spirit. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. Growth and employment are the watchwords of the Juncker Commission. It is essential to support youth employment and any good practice towards reducing unemployment in the various European economic sectors. I find the support of social enterprise projects that work in collaboration with local communities particularly interesting.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I have voted in favour of the initiative report on ‘Promoting youth entrepreneurship through education and training’ because I strongly believe Europe needs to support and encourage its young entrepreneurs to have their own business.  I am convinced that entrepreneurial skills and competences, such as in ICT, as well as transversal competences should be promoted in order to increase the rates of youth self-employment and to provide the young generation with a real opportunity to start their own businesses. With the adoption of this report the European Parliament has asked the European Commission to develop frameworks and support Member States with the use of European Funds (Erasmus and ESIF). We have also asked for Member States cooperation and sharing best practises. This report is important not only for the future of our youth but also for our European economy. We need to invest wisely in our future!

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. Having long led policies for youth employment and vocational training in my home region, I support the meaning of this report on promoting entrepreneurship among younger generations. From experience, I think it is important to be able to build on their creative potential and their enthusiasm to move forward. Better yet, they should not be discouraged. Youth entrepreneurship is a solution for their integration, to combat mass unemployment and the risk of dropping out that threatens an entire generation. It is also an engine of dynamism, economic growth and innovation, particularly in connection with emerging sectors such as new technologies and creative industries. However, it is not a question of sending young people into the wall and the entrepreneurial spirit that I would like to see further developed must be reasoned and documented. It must be part of a project-by-project pedagogical approach where risk-taking is well thought out.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. In view of the economic stagnation experienced by the Member States of the Union, and in particular those of the euro area, for many years, the promotion of the entrepreneurial spirit is a measure, albeit a small one, but essential for economic recovery. I therefore voted in favour of this text, which goes in the direction of defending the freedom of enterprise and the accountability of young people. The best tools for young people to succeed are learning and effort in work, concepts often dismissed today

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report does not take into account that the EU's role in education policies is purely coordinating, as this area falls within the exclusive competence of the Member States.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report outlines a business model in which references to the dignity of work and environmental protection are completely absent. The amendments proposed to this effect in the CULT Committee were rejected. The only reference to corporate social responsibility is used with the aim of encouraging private funding, thus hoping for greater private participation in the provision of training. According to the report, entrepreneurship must be taught at all stages of education, i.e. from primary school to university. It is reiterated that among the learning objectives of students, there must be entrepreneurship and, in this regard, the Commission is invited to use the resources made available by the Juncker Plan and the European Social Fund, supporting partnerships between schools and businesses. Personally, I am opposed to an entrepreneurial model based solely on the triangle of entrepreneurship, financial literacy and speed of work, because I believe that this is a brief vision; Consequently, I voted against.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In February 2015, 4.85 million young people were unemployed in the EU-28, which is an unacceptably high number, and although the youth unemployment rate is falling – it has dropped by 494 000 people compared to February 2014 – the situation is evolving at a very slow pace. There are high rates of youth unemployment, and fiscal consolidation in the Member States most affected by the crisis should not be carried out to the detriment of youth employment.  This report allows compliance with official documents of the Council, the Commission and Parliament establishing a strategic, legislative and financial framework for the coordination and implementation of educational activities in the EU. The essential principle of this framework is lifelong learning, which takes place in all environments – whether it is formal or non-formal or informal learning – and at all levels. The most recent document, adopted by the Council in December 2014, is the Council conclusions on entrepreneurship in education and training. The European Parliament's report also takes into account the findings of a recent European Commission study presenting data from a comparison of 91 examples of entrepreneurship education in 23 countries. The dominant impression is that entrepreneurship education acts as protection against exclusion.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it encourages entrepreneurship and initiative for young Europeans.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union can only reach the pre-crystal level with unequivocal support for young people, because they are among the most numerous groups of unemployed. Young people must be prepared professionally and systematically in order to be prepared for the pitfalls of the business environment. The European Commission must actively seek further instruments to promote and develop entrepreneurship education for young people. The European Parliament is appealing for the creation of a European network to share examples of good practice, of which there are many in this area, including an internationally proven long-established network of national Junior Achievement centres, and I am also appealing in particular to the European Commission to prepare methodological assistance in the form of educational standards for entrepreneurship education and support courses to improve teacher qualifications as methodological assistance to Member States in integrating entrepreneurship education into education programmes, and to allocate specific financial instruments under the ERASMUS+ programme to this end.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting strongly in favour of this report, which calls for exchanges between young entrepreneurs in Europe to be stimulated, as with the Erasmus programme for young entrepreneurs.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on promoting young people's entrepreneurship through education and training because it does not take into account that the EU's role in education policies is purely coordinating and that this area falls within the exclusive competence of the Member States.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the acknowledgement, in the report, of the very positive impact on individuals entrepreneurship, as it helps increasing their career ambitions and chances, equips them with competences such as critical thinking, sense of initiative, creativity, innovation and risk-taking, increases interest in venturing business and even the completion of secondary education. Teaching and learning entrepreneurship is extremely important at all levels of formal education, as well as that non-formal and informal learning is a privileged environment to acquire entrepreneurship competences. I strongly support the call for development of educational standards for entrepreneurship education and their integration into national curricula, including the strong emphasis on teacher training, ensuring necessary finances, enough attention to monitoring and evaluation of results, and their impact on society and economy.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report at a time when youth unemployment is at an historic high level in Europe, because I believe that promoting an entrepreneurial mindset and fostering motivation could be extremely beneficial for our European youth. I am supportive of this document, which contains a set of important political priorities such as promoting better defined learning contents and tools for formal and non-formal education targeted at all students and promoting links between schools and enterprises in order to provide students with practical experience and models. Both the Commission and the Members States have a big role to play in ensuring coherent and effective promotion and coordination in the area of entrepreneurship education in the context of the EU lifelong learning strategy and the Juncker Commission’s plan.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report deals with young people's entrepreneurship and related entrepreneurship as one of the topics selected by the European Parliament in order to be more prominent because of their importance and low recognition and for which it has proposed further action. It summarises the current activities in the field of business education and points to the objectives of education and the need for education to focus on practical application and the employment of young people. According to socio-economic data, the social and economic situation of EU citizens has not improved significantly. In this respect, the main problem is the high youth unemployment rate, which is on average 22% in the EU and exceeds 50% in some countries and regions. In general, education is seen as a key tool for meeting citizens' specific needs and a way of improving their situation.  I fully support the strategic objectives: 1. achieving lifelong learning and mobility; 2. improving the quality and efficiency of education and training; 3. promoting equality, social cohesion and active citizenship; 4. encouraging creativity and innovation, including entrepreneurship, at all levels of education and training.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I would first like to congratulate The Member Oojdrová on the work done with this report. In Catalonia we have a youth stoppage close to 50%, and we have the problem that many students who finish their higher education have not acquired the skills necessary to start a business. I am no longer talking about our traditional entrepreneurial capacity, which says the saying "Els catalans, les pedres en fem pans", but that it is not known what to do with it. That is why I welcome the european Parliament's first term in favour of including in the school curriculums a subject which in the medium term is sure to bring us back to wealth creation and better redistribution of wealth. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the face of a youth unemployment rate approaching 50% in some parts of Europe, it is necessary, among others, to adopt medium- to long-term measures, which affect at different levels. Education is one of those areas which until now has been neglected too often from the point of view of entrepreneurial training. Young people have great potential which must be stimulated and fully realized. I voted strongly against the report, hoping that concrete measures from the Commission could be followed quickly.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. – The dangers of social exclusion and youth extremism are already being combated at school and, indeed, greater attention to training activities and growth opportunities to facilitate the transition from school to work are the best medicine to find out more easily between the choices to be made in the phase of integration into the professional field. Digitalisation, language learning, entrepreneurship education, investment in continuing teacher training, and university pathways directly oriented to the professional market, linked to networks of small and medium-sized enterprises. The Union invests in the future that young people are called upon to build, supporting them with training options that educate them to build an idea of modern, international, open, inclusive and constantly evolving professionalism.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on promoting entrepreneurship in young people through education and training because I am convinced that entrepreneurship must be understood as an ability to turn ideas into concrete actions. The Europe 2020 strategy and related initiatives promote the spirit of initiative and are the backbone of the EU economy. Education and training are the basis of the personal development of each individual, it is necessary to guarantee equal access to students, regardless of their socio-economic status, providing real support that allows the realization of the same.  It is necessary to encourage the development of networks linking the different stages of education and connecting ex-students so that all obstacles are removed, with the sole aim of having as its sole purpose the union, which generates strength, of young people with the old, of men with women, of disabled people with the community. The Council and the Commission must deal with methodology, communication and financial instruments in order to encourage the participation of young people in the business field. I therefore hope for a comprehensive strategy which will create real employment with appropriate training and which will be an expression of the overall European vision that must always characterise the Member States of the Eu ropean Union.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against today the 'Report on the promotion of young people's entrepreneurship through education and training', as it in some areas exceeds the competence of the EU and disregards the principle of subsidiarity. In addition, the text sets the wrong tone that does not really promote the entrepreneurial spirit of young people in Europe.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I am clearly voting in favour of including entrepreneurship in the curricula of our schools, without compromising the sovereignty of the Member States. The teaching of entrepreneurial skills in school education will strengthen the entrepreneurial spirit of young people and thus reduce youth unemployment.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Nearly 750 000 young people are out of job in the UK, meaning youngsters are 3 times more likely to be unemployed than the rest of the population, the largest gap in more than 20 years. Meanwhile, also in my country, the government’s schemes for getting young people back to work are doing anything but that, and their solution is forcing youngsters into community work that offers minimal prospects for the future. Little surprise then, that more than half of the UK’s graduates who are at work are in non-graduate jobs – one of the highest rates in Europe. That is why I supported the Sojdrova report and welcome EU initiatives that step up for our youngsters where the government is failing, by developing education strategies that support Member States in sharing best practices, setting up domestic and cross-border partnerships, increasing mobility and backing SME networks and development agencies. Because we simply cannot accept that the only choice for so many of our young people is between a low paid job or work boot camps, as is the case in the UK.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls on the Commission and the Member States to develop and promote entrepreneurship among young people in training and education programmes. The EU is strong with creative minds, but risk-taking is not encouraged enough among young people. The development of specific skills in school and training programmes will help to strengthen entrepreneurship in Europe and thus help to combat unemployment affecting young people in many European countries.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. Based on the correct observation that entrepreneurship is being neglected by young people, the text proposes to remedy it with an educational approach and incentives for the creation of a business. The text downplays, however, the fact that what young people who could potentially start a business are now fearing is the administrative burden, the tax loophole and unfair competition from countries with low labour costs. However, even if it is a minimalist response, the intention is commendable. It could bring out the entrepreneurial spirit among young people. For this reason, and without giving the European Union moral support for its economic policies that are destructive to European SMEs/PMIs, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the report because, while entrepreneurship is a path of development and job creation, it is a very limited route. The guidance and emphasis placed by the PPE Group on this proposal reveal how the figure of the entrepreneur is entrusted, as if he were a panacea for the dramatic employment problem in Europe, the prognosis of which is hopeless. Entrepreneurship is used as well as a wildcard that allows governments to evade their responsibility to create the necessary conditions to ensure access to employment or resources that guarantee a dignified life for all people. The responsibility of the Administration is transferred to the individual, promoting individual competition ("helping itself") in a market that tends to deregulation and, therefore, abuse. This report clearly prevails the individual entrepreneurship over cooperative, which is reduced to some testimonial statement, despite suggestions made by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs to give it more relevance in the job creation strategy. We believe that the neoliberal individualistic approach leads to atomization and chronicles precariousness, in the face of collective and cooperative resolution of social problems.

name: Γιώργος Γραμματικάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 Financial difficulties are increasingly making access to educational processes increasingly difficult, and their quality is often degraded. It is clear that this situation jeopardises the fight against youth unemployment, increases social exclusion and undermines the EU's economic recovery. Education and training for young people must be an absolute priority for the EU as it is inextricably linked to healthy economies and healthy societies. But we must find ways to support education in practice and not just in words and to ensure the necessary expenditure in the field of education, especially in southern countries such as Greece, where the economic crisis has led to significant cuts. It is only through education and training that we can promote young people's entrepreneurship and reduce shameful unemployment rates.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Entrepreneurship education at all levels can be a highly effective tool for motivating young people, in their decision-making about career development and setting up their own sustainable business ventures. The report promotes an approach that supports young people in their creativity, ability to cope with risk, management of failure and responsible behaviour; key competences that are needed by all individuals for personal fulfilment and development, active citizenship, social inclusion and employment.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which proposes a more ambitious approach to youth entrepreneurship and entrepreneurship awareness. The high youth unemployment rate is a worrying problem, averaging 22% in the EU and in some countries such as Greece and Spain exceeding 50%. This report therefore advocates for entrepreneurial training at all levels, which can be a very effective tool to motivate young people to start their own businesses and succeed on their own. I also support the creation of a European network to share examples of good practice among Member States.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted favourably on the resolution on promoting youth entrepreneurship through education. The youth training and inclusion of the entrepreneurship as a subject matter in education is extremely important, since it directly results in the employment promotion as it has the practical application. The youth unemployment issue has a significant depth: in the EU the average rate is 22%. Thus, the promotion of entrepreneurship is one of the main ways to stop the augmentation of this rate. We must acknowledge the fact that entrepreneurship education has also proven positive impact on individuals that consequently results in the increase of start-ups, development of enterprises. Youth entrepreneurship is the key towards the prospective yet sustainable future and higher employment rates.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on this important topic - youth entrepreneurship through education and training. Although youth unemployment is decreasing slowly, with almost 5 million young people still unemployed through the EU the Commission and Member States must continue to act to combat this situation. It was welcome that we recently voted to speed up the provision of YEI funds to Member States but we can do more. One way to do this is by promoting the opportunities for young entrepreneurs to benefit both themselves and society generally. I welcome the report´s call for Member States to ensure quality traineeships to promote entrepreneurial skills and that practical entrepreneurial skills should be taught at all levels of education including higher education. I was also very pleased to see the acknowledgement that informal and independent learning, including volunteering, can help young people develop entrepreneurial spirit and skills and this should be recognised. Finally I supported the call for the Commission to support partnerships between educational institutions and companies via the use of EFSI and in particular, the European Social Fund, to encourage work-based learning in companies and foster entrepreneurship competences at national and local level.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because education is considered a key instrument for meeting the individual needs of citizens and a way to improve their life situation. The rate of youth unemployment in the EU is on average 22%, and in some countries and regions this figure exceeds 50%. This is far too high. We need innovative solutions, and research shows that promoting entrepreneurship though education has a proven positive impact.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is clear that we need entrepreneurship education at all levels – in both informal and formal educational settings. This type of education can be highly effective in motivating young people and in helping them to make the right decisions about their own career development. We need to support our young people by nurturing their creativity, building their resilience and promoting responsible behaviour. These are all key strengths needed for personal fulfilment, social inclusion and active citizenship.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report because it calls on the EU to promote the reform of national education systems to which it has no competence. It calls for more EU funding, action and programmes. It calls for more support and funding for to Erasmus (Which is a glorified, expensive and bureaucratic exchange programme). Only our elected government has the right to legislate and oversee education programmes and definitely not unelected and unaccountable EU Commissioners in Brussels. The EU has no competence to interfere with education policy.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the report because, while entrepreneurship is a path of development and job creation, it is a very limited route. The guidance and emphasis placed by the PPE Group on this proposal reveal how the figure of the entrepreneur is entrusted, as if he were a panacea for the dramatic employment problem in Europe, the prognosis of which is hopeless. Entrepreneurship is used as well as a wildcard that allows governments to evade their responsibility to create the necessary conditions to ensure access to employment or resources that guarantee a dignified life for all people. The responsibility of the Administration is transferred to the individual, promoting individual competition ("helping itself") in a market that tends to deregulation and, therefore, abuse. This report clearly prevails the individual entrepreneurship over cooperative, which is reduced to some testimonial statement, despite suggestions made by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs to give it more relevance in the job creation strategy. We believe that the neoliberal individualistic approach leads to atomization and chronicles precariousness, in the face of collective and cooperative resolution of social problems.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of the European Parliament's contribution to the achievement of common European objectives in this area by monitoring the quality of education through quality control, a call to accelerate the rapid dissemination of innovations focused on business competences and emphasizing the need for methodological and financial support.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution promoting youth entrepreneurship through education and training, as I believe that investing in education and youth is an investment for the growth and progress of the European Union, and entrepreneurship plays a significant role in this.  We recognise that lifelong learning and upskilling is inevitable and is achieved by increasing the quality of education and training, strengthening social cohesion, fostering mobility, creativity and innovation. In this context, it has been shown that entrepreneurship has enormous potential that increases professional ambitions in young people, their creative thinking and a tendency to work effectively. Therefore, I strongly support improving young people's entrepreneurial skills through the education system to boost jobs and growth.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Although we must be vigilant about the European Union's interventionism in the policies of States, we are in favour of promoting entrepreneurship among young people, particularly through education and information. However, we do not lose sight of the needs of education to train men, not to condition economic agents. As such, the humanities and culture must remain a priority. Overall, this report is a step in the right direction and aims to reward entrepreneurial behaviour and to promote business creation in the educational journey, among other things with the Erasmus programme. These proposals are in line with our programme. The congressman voted for it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Michaela Sojdrova's report on promoting entrepreneurship among young people. This report aims to encourage the learning of skills that empower young people to integrate into the world of business or create their own. In addition to learning these skills, the link between schools and the business world should be strengthened. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. While in some EU countries the youth unemployment rate is close to 50%, it is important to support all actions in favour of education and training. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. Promoting entrepreneurship in training is an important step towards an innovative and competitive Europe, where young entrepreneurs as well as long-established companies have a place and can compete for the best ideas. I support the report.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal. Youth entrepreneurship is an important and integral part of the policy strategy to support the current generation of young people within the framework of the EU's objectives for growth, employment and social inclusion. Unfortunately, the figures achieved by youth unemployment in Europe are high and, in addition to the support and facilitation measures that have been put in place to date, we need to think about structural interventions for a definitive u-turn. The role of lifelong learning and international mobility must be recognised as key measures in europe's response to globalisation and in the transition to knowledge-based economies, and Member States are invited to promote young people's entrepreneurial skills.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Despite economic stabilisation, youth unemployment remains high. In February 2015, 4.85 million people were unemployed in the European Union. young people. The EU has developed strong financial instruments and programmes to tackle youth unemployment. However, a significant part of the responsibility for the use of these instruments lies with the Member States. It is necessary to absorb EU funds efficiently and responsibly in order to find long-term and sustainable solutions to the problem, in particular by bridging the gap between education and training and the labour market, and promoting entrepreneurship among young people. Education is within the competence of the Member States and their increased efforts are needed to introduce entrepreneurship education programmes into national education systems, in cooperation with the private sector and social partners, to create an appropriate environment for self-employment and informal learning for young people.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on promoting entrepreneurship among young people through education and training aims to promote entrepreneurial behaviour and enhance business creation in the educational journey. It focuses on the development of the capacities to be undertaken, including within the Erasmus course.  It calls on the Commission to include entrepreneurship education in more EU arrangements.  I voted in favour of this report, considering that entrepreneurship has little presence in the education and training of future workers.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because it seeks to promote entrepreneurship among young people, which is a very respectable goal. It also pays tribute to the Erasmus programme, which is one of the European Union's few good achievements.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I firmly believe that gender equality is a fundamental principle that children must learn from a young age.  It is important that Member States implement measures to achieve gender equality at all levels of the education system; incorporating a higher degree of awareness of gender issues into the training of teachers and other school staff (doctors, nurses, psychologists, social workers, educators) and that introduce mechanisms that allow the promotion, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of gender equality in all educational institutions and levels.  I also believe that it is essential that age-adapted sex education and student needs be provided that includes raising awareness of LGBT issues.  It is also important that States invest in educational and awareness-raising campaigns that improve career guidance for girls and boys, addressing the stereotypical picture of gender roles, as well as gender stereotypes in different careers, particularly in the field of science and new technologies, to reduce gender segregation in the labour market and strengthen women's position

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because, once again, this is a report that burdens responsibility for youth unemployment on the shoulders of young Europeans. Such actions are carried out on the assumption that young Europeans do not find employment because of their aversion to entrepreneurship, which is completely false, considering that the countries with the highest rates of self-employed are those in southern Europe, those with the highest youth unemployment. We believe that promoting entrepreneurship in education and training is nothing more than a cynical exercise to encourage self-exploitation of young people and to avoid taking responsibility for a business system that is unable to generate sufficient work and wealth for new generations. That's why I've decided to vote against it.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. It is redundant to stress the importance of youth employment for us. Youth unemployment data remain a worrying issue and we therefore still consider it necessary to intervene in this context. This report notes and reiterates that part of a possible solution to this problem is to focus on promoting youth entrepreneurship through education and training. Member States are therefore encouraged to work in this direction, removing locks and facilitating, by all means possible, the development of powers and opportunities for youth entrepreneurship. I voted in favour convinced that the proposals set out here will help to alleviate some of the problem of youth employment.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as it promotes an approach that supports young people in their creativity, ability to cope with risk, management of failure and responsible behaviour – key competences that are needed by all individuals for personal fulfilment and development, active citizenship, social inclusion and employment.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Since 4.85 million young people were unemployed in the EU-28 in February 2015, I very much welcomed the report by my Czech colleague Michaela Šojdrová on promoting youth entrepreneurship through education and training. I appreciated how it did not cover up that fiscal consolidation in those Member States that have been hit hard by the crisis should not be carried out at the expense of jobs occupied by young people, given that this high level of youth unemployment has led to increasing levels of poverty and social exclusion, especially for young people from disadvantaged and vulnerable groups. I was glad that she mentioned the importance of social entrepreneurship, which is an important driver of social cohesion and sustainability, which can support the economy while alleviating hardship, social exclusion and other social problems. I am also glad that it has called on the Member States to promote young people's entrepreneurial skills through legislative measures that aim to improve the quality of traineeships, focus on the quality of learning and adequate working conditions. First of all, I would like the Czech Republic not to participate in non-conceptual cuts in the past, but if we are to rise economically, we need to promote the creation of jobs that will help citizens to live with dignity.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported the report on promoting youth entrepreneurship through education and training. In the context of this report, I would like to draw particular attention to the fact that the development of entrepreneurial skills should accompany young people at all stages of education, from basic to academic. I stress the key role played by scientific staff in this process, whose appropriate qualifications and competences are essential to ensure the effectiveness and authenticity of the teaching process. I would also like to draw attention to the need to strengthen entrepreneurship education, combined with career guidance in activation programmes for disadvantaged groups.  At European level, it is important to gather, support and prepare best practices in entrepreneurship education on the basis of a common, coherent strategy for the development of entrepreneurship as part of a European strategy for lifelong learning.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this report, which calls for more funding for business programmes, business Erasmus and calls for EU intervention in education systems (Section 27).

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that not only should the country create jobs at this moment, but also create the conditions in Europe so that every young person interested can develop a business. This requires that education systems in Europe are accompanied by the latest news and able to adapt quickly to the realities of a fast-changing life. I am convinced that the document will help a number of young people in Europe find their jobs in their company.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tackling youth unemployment, which stands at 22% in the Union and more than 50% in some Member States, is one of the most serious economic and social problems. The way to improve this situation is to increase quality and accessible education, together with the acquisition of practical skills, especially in the field of entrepreneurship education, which must be promoted at all levels and forms of education. The field of education falls within the exclusive competence of the Member States. However, the Union must be an effective and consistent coordinator on this. It has the resources in the form of projects, but also in the form of financial instruments and support.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text, which aims to promote entrepreneurship among young people. It proposes to promote the entrepreneurial behaviour of young people from school and to focus on the development of the capacities to undertake during training.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report, which acknowledges the role of lifelong learning and international mobility as constituting a key measure in Europe’s response to globalisation and the shift to knowledge-based economies; notes, specifically, the importance of the ‘sense of initiative and entrepreneurship’, as included among the eight ‘Key Competences for Lifelong Learning ‒ A European Reference Framework’, considered to be needed by all individuals for personal fulfilment and development, active European citizenship and participation, social inclusion and employment.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report ' Promoting entrepreneurship in young people through education'. Youth entrepreneurship is an important factor in supporting and encouraging the current generation within the framework of the EU's objectives for growth, employment and the reduction of youth unemployment in the European Union. The skills and competences of young entrepreneurs must be supported and encouraged, including through specific programmes, such as business projects, start-ups, formal education aimed also at all students who enable them to learn from experienced entrepreneurs running small businesses, in order to increase the participation and support of entrepreneurship among young people.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 My colleague Šojdrová's report deals with the promotion of young people's entrepreneurship with an emphasis on education and training. Unfortunately, it must be noted that in February 2015, 4.85 million unemployed young people were registered in the EU. One of the identified causes of this alarming number is the mismatch between education and training and the labour market. I fully agree that young people must be given key competences in order to have the chance to participate in the modern economy and society as a whole. I strongly support young people's sense of initiative and entrepreneurship, saying that small and medium-sized enterprises are now the backbone of the EU economy and are also the most important and main source of job creation. Youth unemployment is falling, but unfortunately only very slowly. Of course, I support initiatives that would change this trend, so I voted in favour of the report.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Entrepreneurship, and in particular social entrepreneurship, is a key element for economic recovery, and for social cohesion. The report presented by Mr De Clercq, on behalf of the Committee on The Sojdrova stresses the importance of developing entrepreneurial skills during all stages of education. Sharing the purpose and structure of the document, I decided to support it with my vote.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The high rate of youth unemployment, especially in the Canary Islands, is an issue that continues to concern us, and much, in the European Parliament. That is why the report on promoting youth entrepreneurship through education and training that we have supported in plenary is so important, examining and proposing new measures to help the youth population find a suitable job exit through their own projects. It is important to instill in our children and young people, from an early age, a business culture and facilitate, from the educational field, their path to entrepreneurship.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report calls for increased cooperation between Member States and entrepreneurs to raise awareness of entrepreneurship through a coordinated approach in the education system. It is important in this report that the Erasmus programme should promote young entrepreneurship. In itself, this motion is worthy of support.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Instead of addressing the causes of youth unemployment, the rapporteur proposes a leak forward to entrepreneurship, a panacea that is supposed to save them. The very subject of the report already poses a fundamental ideological problem. The school should teach "entrepreneurship" under a "positive" image and universities should work with companies to "meet the needs of the labour market". Unsurprisingly, the text "invites Member States to encourage the participation of private partners in the teaching of entrepreneurship" and calls for the use of the Juncker Fund to develop partnerships between schools and businesses. All this is, of course, accompanied by broad moral considerations on the benefits of unpaid work, 'fiscal consolidation in the Member States', less 'unnecessary' burdens on start-ups and the reform of education systems. I'm voting against this ridiculous liberal catechism!

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Although we must be vigilant about the European Union's interventionism in the policies of States, we are in favour of promoting entrepreneurship among young people, particularly through education and information. Overall, this report is a step in the right direction and aims to reward entrepreneurial behaviour and to promote business creation in the educational journey, among other things with the Erasmus programme. These proposals are in line with our programme. I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Young entrepreneurship should be an important part of today's youth support policy strategy in terms of EU targets for growth, jobs, education and social inclusion, as well as for reducing youth unemployment in the EU. Young entrepreneurship is very important for economic growth and job creation.  Hence my vote in favour.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – New Zealand is the country where you can start a business the easiest and fastest. The Member States of Europe are limping behind. However, it is small and medium-sized enterprises that form the backbone of the European economy. They actively contribute to innovative and sustainable growth. That is why entrepreneurship must be promoted.  In addition to removing barriers to entrepreneurship, there is a need for greater efforts in education to promote the culture of entrepreneurship among young people. A positive image of entrepreneurship will motivate young people to turn their own creative ideas into concrete business plans. The education of entrepreneurship-oriented skills should be part of the school curriculum. Business can also play a crucial role in entrepreneurship-oriented education. By offering targeted internships, including abroad, and organising exchange projects between the school and the business community, theoretical education in schools is enriched with the economic realities of business.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's own-initiative report on Promoting entrepreneurship among young people through education and training is a step in the right direction that deserves adequate attention from both the institutions and the Member States.  Entrepreneurship education not only develops an entrepreneurial spirit, but is also an effective means of promoting and increasing employment.  Entrepreneurial skills should therefore also find their way into education programmes, which will contribute to increasing interest in entrepreneurship, the overall entrepreneurial culture and creative thinking.  I therefore join the call on the European Commission to prepare methodological assistance in the form of educational standards for entrepreneurship education and support for courses to improve teacher qualifications as methodological assistance to Member States in integrating entrepreneurship education into education programmes, while also allocating specific financial instruments for this purpose as early as 2014-2020.  The development of entrepreneurship and entrepreneurship in the EU will also need to be remembered when preparing a new legislative and financial framework for the post-2020 period.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on promoting youth entrepreneurship through education and training, because it is crucial that youth entrepreneurship becomes an integral part of the political strategy to support today’s youth generation in terms of EU goals for growth, employment, education and social inclusion.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Current socio-economic data show that the social and economic situation of EU citizens has not improved significantly. In this respect, the main problem is the high youth unemployment rate, which is on average 22% in the EU and exceeds 50% in some countries and regions. In general, education is seen as a key tool for meeting citizens' specific needs and a way of improving their situation. Entrepreneurship at all levels is a very effective tool for motivating young people and making decisions about starting their own businesses and careers and succeeding in this career. There is a great need in Europe for an approach that supports young people, for example in terms of their creativity, risk-taking capacity, failure management and responsible behaviour. The report summarises the current activities in the field of business education and points to the objectives of education and the need for education to focus on practical application and youth employment. It focuses on proposals and recommendations on the further development of business education and on support from the European Commission, the Council and the Member States.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. At a time when wage-earning in large groups is seen as the most favourable social situation, we support all initiatives that highlight the spirit of entrepreneurship, the real engine of the economy. With this report focusing on the development of entrepreneurial skills within educational programmes, we obviously support this initiative.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Young entrepreneurship should be an important part of the policy strategy to support youth in terms of EU objectives for growth, jobs, education and social inclusion. I am voting in favour of this report, which emphasises the importance of the entrepreneurial skills and competences that young people need to acquire while they are having their academic and civic training. Even though i know that not all young people are entrepreneurs, I think it is very important to encourage themselves from an early age and to instill the spirit of initiative and business risk, allowing young people to face the future with better preparation. I also believe that the European Union must clearly and decisively support startups that arise across Europe and that they will be key to improving the competitiveness of the global economy.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on promoting entrepreneurship among young people through education and training aims to promote entrepreneurial behaviour, and to promote business creation in the educational journey. It focuses on the development of the capacities to be undertaken, including within the Erasmus course.  It also calls on the Commission to include entrepreneurship education in more EU schemes.  I voted in favour of this report, considering that entrepreneurship has little presence in the education and training of future workers.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Entrepreneurship education at all levels can be a highly effective tool for motivating young people, and in their decision-making re career development and setting up their own sustainable business ventures. The report promotes an approach that supports young people in their creativity, ability to cope with risk, management of failure and responsible behaviour; key competences that are needed by all individuals for personal fulfilment and development, active citizenship, social inclusion and employment.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this text on the promotion of entrepreneurship among young people through education and training. As a former Minister for Vocational Training, I am in favour of this report, which reminds us that entrepreneurship encourages young people to develop qualities that enable them to be more successful in their professional and personal lives.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
