text: in writing. \u2012 Today's Europe needs an approach that supports creativity, the ability to deal with risks as opportunities, failure management and responsible behaviour of young people more than ever. Entrepreneurship education can be a very effective tool and response.  The report that I supported in the CULT Commission and in plenary refers to the development of entrepreneurial skills at all levels of education and distinguishes the specificities of each phase, not forgetting the importance of formal, non-formal or informal lifelong learning, in all contexts and at all levels. It seems to me appropriate to emphasise the strategic objectives to be pursued: achieving lifelong learning and mobility; improving the quality and effectiveness of education and training; promoting equity, social cohesion and active citizenship; creativity and innovation, including, of course, entrepreneurship. I am sure that the European Commission will take action in this regard to identify and develop standards of entrepreneurship education and for their integration into national programmes, with a strong emphasis on teacher training and, with the necessary funding - including through Erasmus+ and Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs - monitoring and evaluation of results in their socio-economic impact.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this motion for a resolution because we believe that an overall strategy should be devised and implemented that promotes entrepreneurship among the youngest through specific training courses. Indeed, we are convinced that the growth of entrepreneurial activity goes hand in hand with a country's potential for innovation and that, both of these elements together, contribute strongly to economic growth and greater prosperity. In particular, we welcome the reference to the importance of lifelong learning and international mobility and consider it essential to introduce lessons aimed at developing entrepreneurial skills, clearly modulated according to the different levels of education, so that these skills are not only the subject of specific training but are, more generally, the widespread and shared heritage of tomorrow's society. Finally, we stress that increasing entrepreneurship can also be a good solution to mitigate the phenomenon of youth unemployment, which in many European countries has now reached more than worrying levels.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will set out the main principles for the support of entrepreneurship education and create a strategic, legislative and financial framework for the coordination and implementation of educational activities in the EU.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report on promoting youth entrepreneurship through education and training, which is a very important issue in Ireland, considering our high youth unemployment levels – which have stagnated at about 20% in the South. Entrepreneurship is an important driver of economic growth and job creation. We need to move towards a situation where enterprise, especially at a community level, is encouraged, facilitated and adequately supported. Access to finance, and the absence of social welfare and tax benefit supports are huge worries for many entrepreneurs. The focus of this report is on our young people and they do face similar obstacles. Our young people are at even more of a disadvantage and it is they who have been hardest hit as a result of the economic crisis. The Youth Employment Initiative has fallen far short of what is required to address this situation, in Ireland, and across Europe. This report presents an opportunity for us to ensure that our young people who have good and innovative ideas for new start-ups are supported and encouraged in the best way possible.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the European Union must respond with one voice to a problem common to all Member States. We need common European legislation on the promotion of entrepreneurship among young people through education and training. As the document adopted today says, encouraging entrepreneurship among young people must be an important integral part of the political strategy to support today's young generation and to achieve the EU's objectives of growth, employment, education and social inclusion, as well as reducing youth unemployment in the European Union.  In this respect, the inclusion of professional counselling services in the Education System in the Education System to promote entrepreneurship as a career option and to encourage the younger generation to set up their own business ideas is the basis of the European economy, as well as the main source of new jobs. However, the entrepreneurial potential of women, which is an under-exploited source of economic growth and job creation, should not be forgotten.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on promoting youth entrepreneurship through education and training, because I share the author's view that the teaching of practical entrepreneurial skills should be ensured at every stage of education or training, and that subjects teaching basic knowledge of finance, economics and entrepreneurship should be included in all school curricula in order to ensure that young people acquire entrepreneurial spirit and acquire entrepreneurial skills. It is for the Council and the Commission, within the limits of their respective competences and in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, to provide methodological support to national education systems and to develop methodological tools for them in terms of entrepreneurship-related education and training, including social entrepreneurship. In order to achieve these objectives, the Commission could increase the amount of support provided to young entrepreneurs from the European Structural and Investment Funds.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I think it makes a lot of sense to support young people and promote entrepreneurship. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The aim of the report is to promote youth entrepreneurship through training, funding and the creation of various programmes.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution. Young entrepreneurs face many challenges and challenges, including the lack of experience, the necessary skills and access to finance and infrastructure. Particular attention must therefore be paid to entrepreneurial skills and competences. As education policy falls within the exclusive competence of the Member States and the EU only has a coordinating function, member states play a key role. In the field of education, they should focus on practical application, youth employment and the improvement of entrepreneurship education, ensuring quality learning and decent working conditions. It should be noted that the Commission should increase funding for support from the European Structural and Investment Funds to young entrepreneurs and help Member States to ensure that young entrepreneurs have access to the funding they need and are supported at each stage.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As you know, I am particularly concerned about development and support for entrepreneurship, for which I work hard in the ITRE Committee of which I am a member. It is therefore with enthusiasm that I have chosen to vote in favour because I believe it is essential to identify a systematic European approach to education for youth entrepreneurship in order to facilitate the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Ева Паунова (PPE)
text: in writing. – The themes of youth entrepreneurship and business-related education are priorities in my work. For Europe to have a prepared and prosperous next generation, critical and innovative thinking, entrepreneurial spirit and business flair, digital and managerial skills must be nurtured in young people from an early age. Promoting youth entrepreneurship is an effective way of addressing the worrying situation, such as youth unemployment in the European Union. I voted in favour of my colleague Šojdrová's excellent report because it is in line with my vision on the issue and I am convinced that the measures it proposes will help to increase the number of young entrepreneurs, which in turn will inevitably reduce the serious youth unemployment rate in the European Union.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ In current times it is of key importance that at all levels and types of education the teaching of practical entrepreneurship skills should provide sense of initiative, readiness and sense of social responsibility. I support the fact that the Commission has the broad opportunity to coordinate with Member States a coherent and effective coordination in the area of entrepreneurship education in the context of its broader EU lifelong learning strategy, the EU’s global strategies and the Juncker Commission’s plan.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I consider this report to be a good background for an in-depth analysis of today's youth employment situation. Between February 2014 and February 2015, the number of unemployed young people decreased by 494,000.  Unfortunately, there are still a number of unemployed young people. In February 2015 it was 4.85 million.  I agree that this decrease is too slow and I think it is necessary, and as this report says, to focus additional efforts to continue to rapidly reduce the number of unemployed young people in the coming period. On several occasions in this Parliament, I have already spoken of the need for the Council and the Commission to develop within their competences the methodological support and tools in the field of entrepreneurial education dedicated to national education systems, which could be used by those systems where appropriate.  This can help Member States to improve their education systems as quickly and as quickly as possible, based on their best experience, and to direct them towards creating personnel who are today or who will be deficital in the labour market in the nearest future.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on promoting entrepreneurship among young people through education and training aims to promote entrepreneurial behaviour and enhance business creation in the educational journey. It focuses on the development of the capacities to be undertaken, including within the Erasmus course.  It also calls on the Commission to include education in entrepreneurship in more EU arrangements.  I voted in favour of this report, considering that entrepreneurship has little presence in the education and training of future workers.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Youth entrepreneurship is an important component of a policy strategy aimed at supporting today's young generation in the context of a European drive to ensure growth, employment, education and social inclusion. In February 2015, 4.85 million young people were unemployed in 28 EU member states, an impermissibly high figure. Although registered youth unemployment is decreasing, i.e. by 494 000 compared to the February 2014 figures, this decrease is too slow.  Therefore, I support the rapporteur's proposal concerning the measures that must be implemented by the institutions of the European Union, but also of the Member States, with a view to stimulating youth entrepreneurship, since in certain countries start-ups are not adequately recognised or understood as a possible career trajectory and that the support provided to future entrepreneurs under the education system is insufficient.  Small and medium-sized entrepreneurs create 44% of Croatia's GDP, employ more than 900,000 workers and participate in more than 40% of direct exports. The National Youth Plan of the Republic of Croatia from 2009 to 2013 states that previous research insights in the world and in Croatia show that the transition of young people to the so-called adult world is increasingly complex and time-consuming. In this regard, the Union must provide additional support.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. – As a representative from the Republic of Croatia, I consider the issue of youth unemployment to be extremely important. Statistics from February 2015 point to the fact that a total of 4.85 million young people were unemployed in the 28 Member States of the European Union, which is about 20%. In the Republic of Croatia, the data is even more devastating.  According to the latest statistics published by Eurostat, the youth unemployment rate in the Republic of Croatia in July 2015 was 43.1%, which is a truly devastating figure compared to other member states. I support this report, which points to the gap between the education system and the labour market, which leads to a large number of unsubted jobs, both in the Republic of Croatia and in other EU countries.  Young people should be taught the key competences that are really needed on the market. As businesses, in particular SMEs, are the backbone of the EU economy and as such are at the very top of EU policy priorities, it is necessary to promote entrepreneurial skills for young people through legislative measures that will thus foster employability of them and break down the barriers faced by young entrepreneurs.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 All too often the European banking system is not able to adequately prepare the new generations for the challenges posed by the world of work. Entrepreneurial activity with all its corollary of interdisciplinarity requires more and more skills. This report emphasises the importance of developing entrepreneurial skills at all levels of education, distinguishing the specificities of each stage, and provides guidance on how to achieve these objectives at both Community and national level. The report sets out a number of political priorities which I consider to be of great importance. Among these, I would like to highlight the proposal to provide, at all levels and in all types of education, for the teaching of practical entrepreneurial skills and to encourage motivation, initiative and availability, as well as a sense of social responsibility. In addition, the resolution refers to media and digital skills which need to be taken more into account in education and training. I have decided to give my wholehearted support to this report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Today, more than 7 million young Europeans between the ages of 15 and 24 are unemployed and not in education or training. The Union must mobilise to stop this phenomenon and encourage Member States to take targeted action. This report outlines several principles and actions aimed at promoting entrepreneurship among young people through education and training. I am pleased to have voted in favour of this text, which aims to bring young people closer to the labour market.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of understanding that the development of entrepreneurial spirit among young people must be a clear focus on entrepreneurship-oriented education and training.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. On Tuesday, the European Parliament voted on a resolution that includes a series of measures aimed at achieving a coherent and effective education policy for young people. This translates into concrete initiatives taken by the European institutions and the coordination of Member States' actions as well as follow-up measures. Valuable coordination when it comes as here to promote entrepreneurship among young people, by mobilizing innovative pedagogies. In 7 years, the unemployment rate for 15-24 year olds in the EU has risen from 15.5% to 22.2%, an intolerable increase, while Belgium is experiencing an increase of more than 4% during the same period. This new legislative tool is timely in a Europe that at the beginning of this year had 4.85 million unemployed young people. As a reminder, this initiative derives its legitimacy from the broader framework of the 'Europe 2020' strategy, which proposes five objectives in the areas of employment, research and development, climate change and sustainable energy, education, the fight against poverty and social exclusion.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution. Faced with unemployment of under-25s of 22.2% in the Union, focusing on the entrepreneurial skills of young people, especially social entrepreneurship, through training during their schooling but also throughout their lives, will bring benefits in terms of economic growth and job creation, but also individual, societal and institutional benefits.   We need to take an ambitious approach to develop entrepreneurship among young people and this approach will have to mobilise all levels of action: public, European, national and local. Youth entrepreneurship is a promise for our economies and the European Union, respecting its competences, must support Member States in this area. This will include the appropriate use of the European Structural and Investment Funds.  Developing entrepreneurship among young men and women from all socio-economic backgrounds is a prerequisite for achieving the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. Our young people are full of ideas. Now we need to make sure that we give them the best opportunities to make them happen.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the economic circumstantialities we have gone through and the recent changes in society, the inclusion of entrepreneurship in education and training is pressing. I see the development of entrepreneurial spirit (business skills) as another tool at our disposal in promoting personal success and social development.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the need for youth entrepreneurship to be part of the current political strategy to support young people, as well as the European objectives of growth, employment, education and social inclusion. Thanks to the Socialist amendments, the report has taken a more social approach, betting on the development of standards in business education linked to social responsibility and their integration into national education plans. It also has an impact on the need to provide all young people with computing skills and cross-cutting and business skills to enable them to fully harness the potential of the digital world to help them create new forms of development, transmission and entrepreneurship promotion. It also calls on the Council and the Commission to develop methodological tools and support and to make them available to national education systems in the field of education and training for entrepreneurship, including social entrepreneurship, and calls on the latter to increase the amount of support for young entrepreneurs under the Structural and Investment Funds.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. In February 2015, 4.85 million young people were unemployed in the EU-28. Although the number of unemployed among young people has fallen by 494,000 compared to February 2014, this is an unacceptable rate. Jobs held by young people are often sacrificed on the altar of fiscal consolidation in the Member States. Once unemployed, young people face poverty and social exclusion. In this context, the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the promotion of entrepreneurship among young people through education and training (2015/2006 (INI)) makes perfect sense and is proving to be a means of supporting employment. Through this proposal, the European Union is committed to strengthening and encouraging the close link between vocational training and school training as a model for success. By acquiring entrepreneurial skills, young people are brought to start their own businesses, to succeed on this path, and thus to actively support job creation in the European Union. So I voted in favour.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 At a time when there are high rates of youth unemployment in Europe, it is crucial that young entrepreneurship is an integral part of the policy strategy to support youth within the framework of the EU's objectives for growth, jobs, education and social inclusion. I therefore find the reference to the Europe 2020 strategy extremely positive, because it is based on a strategic framework for fostering European cooperation in the field of education and training, the essential principle of which is focused on lifelong learning. In this way, the objectives of instilling an entrepreneurial mindset in the younger ones are fulfilled, providing them with solid qualifications and professional skills, as mentioned in the report. This own-initiative report also highlights the need to develop new skills and entrepreneurial skills in schools, using the use of ICT, focus on social entrepreneurship, qualification and professional development of teachers, exchange of practical experiences between schools and companies, launchand management of start-ups, among others.  Europe today urgently needs an approach that supports young people: their creativity, the ability to manage risks, the management of failures and responsible behaviour, so I voted in favour.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because I believe that, both at Community and national level, a well-defined plan should be followed which favours the development of entrepreneurial skills at all levels of education. We must promote an entrepreneurial spirit in young people through education and training, and promote elements such as private initiative and social responsibility. It is important to teach entrepreneurial skills at a practical level and media and digital skills must be developed in each student, so that they can make their contribution to European economic recovery.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the report because, while entrepreneurship is a path of development and job creation, it is a very limited route. The guidance and emphasis placed by the PPE Group on this proposal reveal how the figure of the entrepreneur is entrusted, as if he were a panacea for the dramatic employment problem in Europe, the prognosis of which is hopeless. Entrepreneurship is used as well as a wildcard that allows governments to evade their responsibility to create the necessary conditions to ensure access to employment or resources that guarantee a dignified life for all people. The responsibility of the Administration is transferred to the individual, promoting individual competition ("helping itself") in a market that tends to deregulation and, therefore, abuse. This report clearly prevails the individual entrepreneurship over cooperative, which is reduced to some testimonial statement, despite suggestions made by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs to give it more relevance in the job creation strategy. We believe that the neoliberal individualistic approach leads to atomization and chronicles precariousness, in the face of collective and cooperative resolution of social problems.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report because the education and training system for young people in entrepreneurship can help reduce the serious social problem of youth unemployment, which is on average 20% in EU countries and rises to an alarming 50% in certain regions. However, promoting youth entrepreneurship is only one measure that can respond to this situation, not a solution to unemployment.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because, once again, this is a report that burdens responsibility for youth unemployment on the shoulders of young Europeans. Such actions are carried out on the assumption that young Europeans do not find employment because of their aversion to entrepreneurship, which is completely false, considering that the countries with the highest rates of self-employed are those in southern Europe, those with the highest youth unemployment. We believe that promoting entrepreneurship in education and training is nothing more than a cynical exercise to encourage self-exploitation of young people and to avoid taking responsibility for a business system that is unable to generate sufficient work and wealth for new generations. That's why I've decided to vote against it.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The appetite for entrepreneurship is an issue that is connected to formal and informal education, but also to cultural issues. In Europe, there is still no ingrained tradition of young entrepreneurship. There is a tendency on the part of Europeans to seek stability at the expense of the challenge. There is also a cultural issue: society tends to stigmatize business failure, which makes it difficult to take risks. Nevertheless, significant steps have been taken to increase entrepreneurship.  Entrepreneurship can be a response to youth unemployment, but it is also a factor in business innovation. Persistent, systematic and coordinated work should therefore be carried out at European level in order to enable concrete responses aligned with the needs of European citizens, with a particular focus on young people.  I support the proposed measures. The Commission and the Council should coordinate policies and develop methodologies and tools to support national education systems in the field of entrepreneurship education and training, as well as increase the amount of support for young entrepreneurs.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as it calls for the EU to interfere in education, and it also calls for more EU spending, which I am against.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because, at all levels, entrepreneurship education can be an effective tool for encouraging our younger generation to develop and set up their own sustainable business ventures. The report promotes an approach that supports young people in their creativity, ability to cope with risk, management of failure and responsible behaviour – key competences that are needed by all individuals for personal fulfilment and development, active citizenship, employment and social inclusion.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of adopting the resolution on promoting entrepreneurship among young people through education and training, because I consider the promotion of entrepreneurship in the education process among young people to be an important part of their practical application in the labour market, the creation of added value for the economy and the path of increasing youth employment.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Europe has long been struggling with the problem of declining interest, especially among young people, in entrepreneurship. There are many reasons why this is the case, but among the most common obstacles in the business of young people in Slovakia, where I come from, are the lack of start-up capital, lack of experience, knowledge and professional contacts. There are other barriers, but based on my own experience, I believe that there are many young people who would love to do business but do not have a business idea and do not know what to do. As Europe has been struggling for a long time with the problem of declining interest, especially among young people, in entrepreneurship, I supported the report that has been tabled because it comes up with measures that can stop the process of stagnation. I regret that many young people are currently facing difficulties in finding work because of the mismatch between their education and the demands of the labour market. I therefore consider it extremely important to equip young people's growing workforce with the skills needed to keep up with a changing world. I am glad that many EU countries are starting to measure skills shortages and adapt their education policies and strategies. Unfortunately, there are still many countries that have not aligned education with the demands of the labour market, and therefore young people's entrepreneurship in these countries has not progressed.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The social and economic situation of European citizens has not improved significantly recently, youth unemployment in the EU is on average 22%, and in some countries and regions it exceeds 50%. In February this year, 4.85 million young people were unemployed in the EU, an unacceptably large number. Young people face increased poverty and social exclusion because of the high unemployment rate, and in addition to the much-needed labour market reforms, we must also ask ourselves, in the context of education and training, what can be done to improve their situation. Competitiveness in today's labour market is certainly welcome for competences such as innovation, initiative, risk-taking, self-thinking and recognition of opportunities that can help to integrate young people more confidently into the economy and society. However, we need to be careful when looking for solutions and take into account a number of factors. We can certainly talk about a kind of gap between education and labour market needs, and it is right that future education systems adapt accordingly to changes in the economy. Nevertheless, I would like to point out that an overly one-sided focus on the importance of entrepreneurial attitudes in the long run can also have a negative effect, which is why I abstained in voting on this report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Education and training should prepare young people for the labour market. However, it is not only necessary to create different support mechanisms, the basis for this situation is the improvement of the business environment. Society will help unemployed young people and all those looking for a job the most by improving the overall business environment that creates new jobs. Support mechanisms such as retraining the unemployed, moving from school to work and stimulating job creation are welcome but directly dependent on the quality of the business environment. There is also a need to improve people's training, especially in the field of information technology.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support this report because we are in the post-economic crisis period that has resulted in high youth unemployment, and it is very important to support entrepreneurship and private sector growth, especially among young people. It is important that young people go into entrepreneurship and want to deal with it, as this results in economic growth, employment growth and many other benefits, both for young people and for the whole society, locally and at European level.  In order for the growth of entrepreneurship to occur, entrepreneurial thinking should be encouraged, especially in young people, and this is best and most efficiently done through education and higher education institutions, and therefore it is of utmost importance to promote competences and entrepreneurship and this way of thinking in young people. The development of entrepreneurship is eventually manifested through improving the quality, both work and private life of a large number of people, and therefore I support the report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Entrepreneurship education at all levels can be a highly effective tool for motivating young people, and in their decision-making re career development and setting up their own sustainable business ventures. The report promotes an approach that supports young people in their creativity, ability to cope with risk, management of failure and responsible behaviour; key competences that are needed by all individuals for personal fulfilment and development, active citizenship, social inclusion and employment.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal because I do not agree with its directive approach, which also encroaches on the competences of the Member States. Furthermore, I have doubts as to whether it is sensible to promote entrepreneurship among young people with the money of entrepreneurs themselves, which will ultimately worsen the business environment.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on promoting youth entrepreneurship through education and training. Last December, more than 5 million young people were unemployed in the European Union. In some Member States, even every other young person is unemployed, which is very worrying. Youth entrepreneurship must be an important part of the political strategy to enable young people who are facing unemployment today to realise their ideas and start their own business. Self-employment and other forms of promoting youth entrepreneurship can make a significant contribution to reducing youth unemployment. I also support the inclusion of entrepreneurship in therics.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report does not take into account that the EU's role in education policies is purely coordinating, as this area falls within the exclusive competence of the Member States.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the report. Although the number of young unemployed people is diminishing, 4.85 million is still too high, especially when we see the large number of unfilled vacancies across the Union. Serious changes are needed in our education and training systems to better connect with the demands of the job market. We hear all the time that small and medium-sized enterprises are the backbones of the European economy, they create the most jobs and have a crucial role in strengthening European competitiveness, and yet still no entrepreneurship skills are taught in most of our secondary schools. EU initiatives in this field are very welcome, but as the report also pointed out, education policy is the exclusive competence of the Member States. Therefore, it is their responsibility not only to simplify the regulatory framework for entrepreneurs but also to prepare students with the necessary practical skills. This is the way towards having a strong SME sector that is in fact the driving force of the European economy. Moreover, Europe needs to prepare its youth to create innovative and viable enterprises with solid knowledge and business plans behind them.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 A high level of not only theoretical but also practical education for young people is one of the most important elements of employee competences on the market. The policies of individual Member States, but also of the European Union itself, should take this obvious issue into account and implement in order to facilitate the start-up and functioning of young people on the labour market. The Union's action in this area should be assessed positively, although it is not equally well implemented in all Member States. Further efforts are therefore needed to improve the situation.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Entrepreneurs are at the backbone of our economy. They contribute to job creation, opening up new markets, and nurturing new skills. Young entrepreneurs, in particular, have an important role to play, as their activity contributes to decreasing the high number of youth unemployment across the EU. Support to entrepreneurs through training and educational programmes is one way to promote the activity of existing ones, and encourage new individuals to become entrepreneurs. The current report addresses this issue by highlighting the value of youth entrepreneurship through education and training. It rightly points out to the benefits of making these programmes available. for example: increasing career ambitions and chances of individuals, equipping them with competences such as critical thinking, sense of initiative, creativity, innovation and risk-taking, increasing interest in venturing business. It also calls on emphasizing the standards for entrepreneurship education and their integration into national curricula, including teacher training, while also ensuring necessary finances for programmes. I support the report and the proposals outlined in it as I strongly believe that teaching and learning entrepreneurship in all levels of formal education, as well as that non-formal and informal learning, is a positive step for creating employment and stimulating economic activity.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as youth unemployment is a serious concern which should be urgently tackled. The promotion of entrepreneurship among young people can boost the economy, encourage innovation and raise the competitiveness of the EU. I find particularly regrettable that in many Member States, start-ups are not sufficiently recognises and entrepreneurs struggle only to find little support for their project.  The report lays down recommendations at EU and Member States levels to develop trainings and education schemes promoting entrepreneurship. Ensuring an effective and simplified access to finance for SMEs and start-ups, combined with an appropriate support for all stage of a project, is in my opinion of utmost importance.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ While this report seemingly promotes the economic and social values of entrepreneurial education and highlights the benefits that the inclusion of this aspect of education at all levels would bring, it encroaches on member states' competences and provides guidance on how to achieve these values.  Since the European Union has limited competence in the field of education policy, I consider it inappropriate to induce the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality to call on Member States to change the curriculum. In addition, this report calls on the Commission to promote education policy reforms in the Member States and to monitor the measures taken to support youth entrepreneurship, which is also outside the competences of the European Union.  In my view, this report is more than promoting youth entrepreneurship through education and training aimed at determining to Member States what they have to do in this area, with no account taken of the fact that each country has a different education system as well as the conditions in which young people can start their own businesses. For those reasons, I voted no.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on promoting youth entrepreneurship through education and training. At a time of high youth unemployment, promoting an entrepreneurial mindset has a lot of positive impact on citizens. Especially for young people, both in professional and private life. This report highlights the further development of entrepreneurship, skills and competences at all levels of education and training and provides guidance on how to achieve these objectives both at EU and national level.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the report because, while entrepreneurship is a path of development and job creation, it is a very limited route. The guidance and emphasis placed by the PPE Group on this proposal reveal how the figure of the entrepreneur is entrusted, as if he were a panacea for the dramatic employment problem in Europe, the prognosis of which is hopeless. Entrepreneurship is used as well as a wildcard that allows governments to evade their responsibility to create the necessary conditions to ensure access to employment or resources that guarantee a dignified life for all people. The responsibility of the Administration is transferred to the individual, promoting individual competition ("helping itself") in a market that tends to deregulation and, therefore, abuse. This report clearly prevails the individual entrepreneurship over cooperative, which is reduced to some testimonial statement, despite suggestions made by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs to give it more relevance in the job creation strategy. We believe that the neoliberal individualistic approach leads to atomization and chronicles precariousness, in the face of collective and cooperative resolution of social problems.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Young entrepreneurs face many challenges and difficulties, such as lack of experience, competence and adequate access to finance and infrastructure, education and training are basic in terms of motivation and possibilities for young people to start their own business projects. An inclusive and integrated education, and should pay special attention to facilitate equal access to students from different socioeconomic backgrounds. Considering also that the knowledge of foreign languages will facilitate and enhance your chances of success. But apart from the technical expertise from any profession, it takes additional training to learn how a business works. It is important to see what measures are working in Europe and they could be applied in all Member States as an example of good practice. Any measure is good to give job opportunities, this is why I support this proposal.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft report has several objectives. First, put at the center of the game the preservation of European cultural heritage material (sites, real estate ...) but also intangible (oral traditions, customs ...). This draft report therefore examines the problems of financing, legal bases and the digitisation of this heritage. I am voting for the adoption of the text.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Youth unemployment is one of the main challenges facing Europe at the moment, when the rate of non-employment of young people is on average 22%, reaching 50% in some Member States. I firmly believe that, in order to increase the employability of young people, their endowment with key skills and fully useful knowledge in the labour market, such as the spirit of initiative, has become a priority. Indeed, the gap between the education received and the demands of the labour market is one of the main causes of youth unemployment. In this respect, I believe that the promotion of entrepreneurship must be done mainly at institutional level, through education, so that pupils and students gain the necessary knowledge in advance for good adaptation in the labour market and become competitive in the professional environment. Cultivating entrepreneurship is undoubtedly an effective way to fight social exclusion and stimulate the economy, while fostering social cohesion and the spirit of innovation. The Commission must therefore encourage Member States to include entrepreneurship education in the school and university curriculum. That is why I voted in favour of the Report on the promotion of entrepreneurship in young people through education and training.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Summarises very important initiatives to support young entrepreneurs. At all levels of education, it considers it necessary to provide a systemic set of key competences. The report targets the coordination and effective use of existing EU programmes. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the report because, while entrepreneurship is a path of development and job creation, it is a very limited route. The guidance and emphasis placed by the PPE Group on this proposal reveal how the figure of the entrepreneur is entrusted, as if he were a panacea for the dramatic employment problem in Europe, the prognosis of which is hopeless. Entrepreneurship is used as well as a wildcard that allows governments to evade their responsibility to create the necessary conditions to ensure access to employment or resources that guarantee a dignified life for all people. The responsibility of the Administration is transferred to the individual, promoting individual competition ("helping itself") in a market that tends to deregulation and, therefore, abuse. This report clearly prevails the individual entrepreneurship over cooperative, which is reduced to some testimonial statement, despite suggestions made by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs to give it more relevance in the job creation strategy. We believe that the neoliberal individualistic approach leads to atomization and chronicles precariousness, in the face of collective and cooperative resolution of social problems.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I abstained in this report because, while I recognise an improvement over the initial text, it remains extraordinarily undefined to a correct assessment of youth entrepreneurship and the parameters for carrying it out: occupation created, impact on the labour market, target audience, impact on the pension system...

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. In view of Europe's youth unemployment situation, such reports focusing on the important aspects of education and learning need to be promoted in order to achieve a higher rate of occupation in the EU. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as with youth unemployment appallingly high in many areas of our Union it is important that we provide action as well as rhetoric for all of our young people. Entrepreneurship education at all levels can be a highly effective tool for motivating young people, allowing them to develop their decision-making, further career development and aid them in setting up sustainable business ventures that suit their abilities. The report promotes an approach that supports young people in their creativity, ability to cope with risk, management of failure and promotes responsible behaviour; key competences that are needed by all individuals for personal fulfilment and development, active citizenship, social inclusion and employment.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'As a liberal, I think it is of the utmost importance that the government creates opportunities for young people. This crisis is hitting young people very hard in their search for work. If the European Union can facilitate young people's search for entrepreneurship, we must take this opportunity with both hands. I therefore voted with conviction for this agenda.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We are directly opposed to the idea that young entrepreneurship can be the lifeline for youth unemployment. The report considers that youth unemployment is a consequence of the lack of training for entrepreneurship, arguing that young people must be formatted from an early age to want to be future entrepreneurs, regardless of other dreams and aspirations they may have. It hides, as is customary whenever it is spoken of in young entrepreneurship, what should be the role of governments in promoting full employment and pushes to the back of young people the individual responsibility to learn to be an entrepreneur in order to achieve a future.  Omit that it is not enough to know how to be an entrepreneur, since without financing do not open businesses, nor are jobs created. Once again, the European Parliament is presenting this panacea, which is only aimed at deepening the sea of precariousness and instability in which more and more young people live.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report calls for increased cooperation between Member States and entrepreneurs to raise awareness of entrepreneurship through a coordinated approach in the education system. It is important in this report that the Erasmus programme should promote young entrepreneurship. In itself, this motion is worthy of support.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 To promote development and growth it is essential to support youth entrepreneurship with cultural, legal and economic tools. First and second level education is crucial to enable young people to acquire the skills they need to enter the world of work or start a business. University education is also important, as it allows research, innovation and creativity activities to be developed as a basis for building the businesses of the future. Entrepreneurship education must be encouraged at all levels in order to convince young people to start and build their own businesses, but at the same time we must ensure that they have the necessary tools to face all the challenges involved in starting up a business. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report ‘Promoting youth entrepreneurship competences in education and training’. The struggle to increase the rate of employment within the youth society seems to be a significant issue that requires prioritization. In order to help boosting the economy of European Union, it is essential to create the sufficient conditions, which will encourage young people to enter the entrepreneurship area.  With respect to the above, I find the substance of this report very promising. It does not only emphasise the need for the constant development of entrepreneurial skills, which can be achieved by providing conditions for effective education and training, but also provides the necessary guidance on how to achieve these targets on both international as well as national level. Moreover, focusing on the development of the entrepreneurial skills at all levels of education is absolutely crucial. This approach may help young people to become creative and responsible at the very young age, and therefore broaden their mind-sets, which is exactly what Europe needs.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Entrepreneurship education at all levels can be a highly effective tool for motivating young people, and in their decision-making re career development and setting up their own sustainable business ventures. This is particularly relevant for young people pursuing career paths in the cultural industries. The report promotes an approach that supports young people in their creativity, ability to cope with risk, management of failure and responsible behaviour; key competences that are needed by all individuals for personal fulfilment and development, active citizenship, social inclusion and employment. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the promotion of entrepreneurship among young people through education and training. I welcome the proposals made in this report aimed at encouraging the Commission to better cooperation and the exchange of best practices between Member States which have already integrated entrepreneurship education into curricula and have made better progress in promoting young people's entrepreneurship and the Member States that are still at the beginning of this process. I appreciate the Commission's call on the Commission to publish, by the end of 2017, a best practice guide for the transmission of entrepreneurial skills and support for youth entrepreneurship in the Member States to be presented to the European Parliament, as well as a report on this subject including the results of this initiative in the evaluation of its own funding measures.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: In writing. The European unemployment situation requires clear measures and requires, among other things, ambitious labour market reforms. Taking into account the evolution of our society in this area, the report seeks to give concrete solutions to the challenges facing European youth: promoting entrepreneurship among young people, flexibility, lifelong learning, flexibility of career path, mobility, continuing education or mastering new digital tools. I would therefore like to congratulate my colleague Michaela Oojdrov for this excellent report, especially since she has managed to highlight the importance of educating young men and women without resorting to the use of ambiguous words. That is why I wanted to give him my full support.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. To effectively support youth entrepreneurship we need to invest in business culture, teach it to our young people. Every freelancer creates and attempts. This culture must be passed on to citizens in order to be ready to cope with the competitive market environment. Today, when we are experiencing a difficult economic crisis, choices have been limited, our young people are leaving because they cannot find a way out, they do not find a job. We must now give them the resources to be able to create their own work, to create their own profession.  Invest in their ideas and assets.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which promotes young people's entrepreneurship through education and training. The economic crisis has highlighted the problem of youth unemployment, in particular the fact that young people have great difficulty in applying to the labour market after leaving school. In many cases, the reason is the lack of previous practical experience. Therefore, the concept of so-called entrepreneurship education is important as one of the tools for promoting youth employment.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report highlights the great value of entrepreneurship education and formulates recommendations for improving the teaching of entrepreneurial skills at all levels of the education system, as well as promoting education in the Member States and subsequently monitoring its quality. I think that it is precisely the lack of education and awareness in this area that makes young people who would otherwise like to start a business dare not dare to do so, or will not reach the end of their business plan. As rapporteur for the Committee on Employment, which gave its opinion on the draft report, I proposed, through it, to call on the Member States, for example, to provide micro-fragmentation to innovative young people, but also to simplify the regulatory framework for social enterprises, which create employment opportunities for disadvantaged young people and young people who are the most distant from the labour market. By supporting them, as well as by promoting business culture overall, we can contribute to the success of young people in the business trajectory and thus, of course, to reducing their unemployment. I therefore supported the report and am very glad that most of my proposals on it have been adopted.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report treats young entrepreneurship as if it were the lifeline for youth unemployment. The report considers that youth unemployment is a consequence of the lack of training for entrepreneurship, arguing that young people must be formatted from an early age to want to be future entrepreneurs, regardless of other dreams and aspirations they may have. It hides, as is customary whenever it is spoken of in young entrepreneurship, what should be the role of governments in promoting full employment and pushes to the back of young people the individual responsibility to learn to be an entrepreneur in order to achieve a future. He also hides that it is not enough to know how to be an entrepreneur, since without financing they do not open businesses, nor are jobs created. Once again, the European Parliament is going to contribute to spreading the idea of reorganizing work into increasingly isolated, individual and unprotected models, this time proposing that this idea be disseminated to young people from an early age. We voted against it.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the Report of the Shojdrove MEC on promoting youth entrepreneurship through education and training. Developing entrepreneurial skills and mindsets during education gives young people greater opportunities for later employment. All of this is also important for their personal development. Although we know that SMEs are the main source of new jobs in the EU, national education systems are not adapting quickly enough to changes in the labour market. Youth unemployment fell by around 500,000 between February 2014 and February 2015, but there were still more than 4.5 million unemployed young people in the EU at the end of this period. I therefore join the report's call for practical entrepreneurial skills, risk-taking and planning skills to be taught at all levels of education, and to promote motivation, initiative and a sense of social responsibility. Modules on the basics of finance, economics and the business environment should be included in the school's school plans. Member States should promote entrepreneurial skills for young people, including by providing quality traineeships, as proposed in the Council Recommendation on a quality framework for traineeships. However, I would also stress the importance of erasmus+, as there are more than one person who chooses to own a business among those who have been involved in academic exchanges abroad in the past.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, this is a slightly different topic, but I supported this report because the fact is that we are aware that there is no integrated approach to cultural heritage, and we know that the European Union has the cultural heritage resources available through creative Europe programmes, Horizon 2020, through the European Regional Fund and others. However, work needs to be done on cooperation, coordination of all cultural heritage directorates involved at European Union level in order to improve coordination, but also to result in what is currently missing, which is a database with examples of best practice and excellence in this area. Documents of all actions and all events, as well as all data on the development of the policy of preservation of cultural heritage would facilitate the possibility of cooperation of all interested parties. I point this out because I myself come from a city, from the city of Dubrovnik, which is famous for its historical buildings, for its rich cultural heritage, and this is perhaps an opportunity to note that Dubrovnik is a candidate for European this year (the President took the word MPs.)

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, an integrated approach to cultural heritage in Europe cannot exist without the return of legacy archaeological treasures. During the Second World War, Nazi occupation troops looted the archaeological treasures of my homeland of Greece. In fact, the list of associated archaeological treasures is contained both in the special volume issued in 1946 by the Greek Ministry of Education and in the corresponding special report prepared by the British Ministry of War. We therefore demand the immediate return of the archaeological treasures looted by the Nazis of Greece. In my speech yesterday I called for the Commission to intervene on this issue and for the implementation of Directive 93/7/EEC on the return of pruning archaeological treasures. Commissioner Tibor Navracsics replied that the issue is bilateral and that it must be resolved transnationally. He solemnly acknowledged in this way that the question of the return to Greece of nazi-looted archaeological treasures is real, that it remains open and that it must be solved. However, instead of implementing the directive, the Commission is treating itself as another Pontius Pilate. The Commission must assume its responsibilities.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, I am pleased that today the report on a holistic approach to cultural heritage is supported, which definitely, in addition to the historical role and role of preserving the traditions and identity of European peoples, has a strong economic role and helps strengthen tourism, crafts and medium and small business.  Many cultural goods across Europe are waiting for the public to be restored and revealed. In Croatia, huge cultural values such as Salona, Šibenik fortresses, castles in Zagorje can become an important element of economic development and job creation through reconstruction. European funds can be combined and invested in cultural heritage restoration and development projects. As shadow rapporteur for this report in the Committee on Regional Development, I asked the Commission to encourage Member States to invest EU funds in cultural goods and in education and skills development, as well as in promoting and encouraging entrepreneurship in culture and innovation.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Europe's cultural heritage has huge economic and strategic potential. Proof of this is the fact that Europe is one of the main tourist destinations in the world and attracts millions of tourists every year. I argue that we need to stimulate the potential of the Council of Europe's European cultural routes because it will help develop sustainable cultural tourism.  At the same time, we also have to deal with a number of challenges in the sector. One of them is the gradual disappearance of traditional skills and crafts. They are part of our identity and are an essential element of Europe's cultural heritage. It is our duty to preserve them and pass them on to generations to come. In this order of thought, I think it is extremely important to increase the knowledge of our material and intangible cultural heritage, which is often associated with regional and local culture. In this regard, I call on the Commission to continue to support cultural and creative industries and to establish and organise a European Year of Cultural Heritage.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The European Parliament has today voted on the report on an integrated cultural heritage strategy for Europe. Cultural heritage issues are important, but funding should be made at national, not supranational, level. Since the report was characterised by a conviction to the contrary, I chose to vote 'no'.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported this report because its objective has been to highlight the undervalued role of European cultural heritage as a source of social innovation for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. With regard to the ec's communication on this subject, I would particularly like to stress that this report highlights the importance of a comprehensive perspective, improving cooperation between different policy areas, as well as increasing funds to preserve European heritage through existing programmes such as Creative Europe, eHorizonte 2020, Europe for Citizens , etc. and its integration into the EC investment plan. Also, on a socialist initiative, a European Year of Cultural Heritage (preferably in 2018) is insisted on and drastic cuts in heritage protection in certain countries are criticized.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report follows up on the European Commission Communication on an integrated approach to European cultural heritage, which aims to analyse the economic and social impact of European cultural heritage and contribute to the development of a multidisciplinary strategic approach with which the EU can complement national and regional programmes in the Member States. Since the report points to the importance of European cultural heritage and the need to enhance its conservation, promoting the maintenance and creation of rights-based jobs, while urging the Commission to promote new participatory models that include communities in the preservation and preservation of cultural heritage, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. France has a rich national heritage that must be preserved at all costs. The motion for a resolution put to the vote of the European Parliament aims to strengthen the preservation of European cultural heritage, whether material (furniture, real estate and submarine) or intangible (oral traditions, performing arts, rituals etc.). Although she speaks of an integrated European approach, she stresses that cultural heritage is naturally heterogeneous, reflecting the diversity and cultural and linguistic pluralism of the Member States.   The motion for a resolution examines issues relating to financing, legal bases and the digitisation of heritage, highlighting its importance and links with regional development, social cohesion, agriculture, the environment, education, tourism and the labour market.   As this proposal is positive for French cultural heritage, I voted for this draft resolution. However, I will be careful not to make it a mere pretext for further integration, with no real benefit for the enhancement of our identity.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Culture cannot be imposed by Europe, or by spending taxpayers’ money. I voted against this report.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to promote an integrated approach to Europe's cultural heritage. Two perspectives should be taken into account in any public policy in the field of cultural heritage: that cultural heritage can be an important source of employment and income, which should be taken into account in particular in the current economic context, and that its cultural value remains a fundamental value of cultural heritage. An ideal integrated strategy for cultural heritage should combine the urgent need for growth and employment with the perception that cultural heritage is a long-term resource that requires a sustainable development plan.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This report encourages the preservation of the material and intangible heritage of our Old Continent. I voted for it that the Eurocrats seem to want to make the past a clean slate to build their Europe, ideological and disembodied...

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Following the European Commission's communication on an integrated approach to European cultural heritage, the Parliamentary Committee on Culture and Education has made several recommendations. In particular, the true economic and strategic potential of cultural heritage is highlighted in this report. It contributes to job creation as well as the development of innovative products, services and processes. Cultural tourism, to give just one example, is an essential sector for the resumption of growth and employment. Similarly, cultural heritage is a valuable contribution to several of the key initiatives of the Europe 2020 strategy.  I approved this report which highlights the role of Europe's cultural heritage as a strategic resource for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft report entitled "Towards an integrated approach to European cultural heritage" has various objectives such as the preservation of material European cultural heritage (sites, real estate, etc.) but also intangible, such as oral traditions, customs... It also provides an analysis of issues related to financing, legal bases and the digitisation of heritage. So I voted for it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I find the Diaconu report acceptable and balanced especially when it analyses the prospects offered by the economic potential of culture and the strengthening of specific programmes aimed at enhancing the values and common heritage of Europe and our territories; For these reasons, I supported the text with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report in response to the European Commission Communication 'Towards an integrated approach to European cultural heritage'.  As the report denounces, the economic and strategic potential of European cultural heritage as a source of social innovation for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth is undervalued. It is therefore necessary to develop a comprehensive perspective, improving cooperation between different policy areas, increasing funds to preserve European heritage through existing programmes such as Creative Europe, Horizon 2020 or Europe for Citizens and effectively integrating them into the Investment Plan for Europe. We demand from my political group the proclamation of a European year dedicated to cultural heritage, which could perfectly embody the Union's renewed commitment to that heritage. Finally, we denounce again through this report the drastic and deplorable cuts in the protection of heritage carried out by certain governments of the Union, including infamy of Spain.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report on an integrated approach to, preserving and developing Europe's cultural heritage. Culture and cultural heritage are common resources and common goods and values that no one can enjoy in their exclusive rights, and the European Parliament therefore asks the Commission to set up a single EU portal for material and intangible cultural heritage and to pool information on all EU programmes that finance cultural heritage, and to support research, research and pilot measures, in particular to analyse the impact of cultural heritage enhancement processes. Parliament urges the Member States to take initiatives relating to the development of training for cultural heritage staff and researchers on management and preservation, as the cultural heritage area is capable of creating highly skilled jobs.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. The cultural heritage is one of the pillars of European culture and of our common heritage left behind for future generations, and its main value comes from its cultural value. An integrated approach to cultural heritage is needed if we are to achieve cultural dialogue and mutual understanding. Such an approach can lead to increased economic, social and territorial cohesion, while at the same time contributing to the achievement of the objectives set out in the Europe 2020 strategy. Cultural heritage contributes to the creation of new innovative jobs, products, services and processes and can also serve as a source of creative ideas, thereby fuelling the economy. Cultural heritage plays a key role in a number of europe 2020 priority objectives, and the European Parliament therefore calls for a more prominent acknowledgement of the role of European cultural heritage as a strategic resource for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth in the interim review of the strategy. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the report on a holistic approach to cultural heritage in Europe, which aims to highlight the undervalued role of European cultural heritage as a source of social innovation for smart and sustainable growth, addressing challenges such as lack of funding, technological change and globalisation, the influx of tourism, trade in cultural goods, etc. I believe that we all need to expand and increase awareness and education in relation to the values of Europe's cultural heritage and its protection. The importance of education and research, the development of quality traineeships, the support of mobility, the preservation of traditional skills and handicrafts are some of the measures that can be effectively approached to preserve Europe's cultural heritage and understand its importance for the life of our citizens.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non—legislative report because it seeks to use cultural heritage to further the EU´s goals. For example, it states that cultural heritage promotes European culture and values, that European culture is important for European identity, and also supports a common European cultural heritage and strengthening of community in the EU. It also looks to influence national education policy, where the EU has absolutely no competence. Only elected and accountable national governments have the right to decide how to spend taxpayers’ money, create culture policy and change education policy, not unelected and unaccountable bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this text because I think that the Union must try to develop an integrated approach to Europe's cultural heritage in order to allow its harmonious development that has a positive impact on the territory in economic and non-economic terms.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cultural heritage, both material and intangible, in its various historical, artistic and landscape aspects, is a great resource for development for the European Union. It must be regarded as a non-renewable resource, to be protected and promoted consistently and whose authenticity must be protected. The Commission must support what is already in place through various programmes (Creative Europe, Horizon 2020, Erasmus, Europe for Citizens), funding (European Structural and Investment Funds) and actions such as the European Capitals of Culture, European Heritage Days and the European Heritage Label, and propose a plan by the Union and the Member States to support culture and research through improved cooperation between strategic sectors dealing with cultural heritage , reporting to Parliament on the results of this closer cooperation, and designating, preferably for 2018, a European Year of Cultural Heritage, with an adequate budget, with the aim, among other things, of spreading and strengthening awareness and education among future generations to respect the values of Europe's cultural heritage and its protection, and to present to Parliament a draft programme for the European Year no later than 2016.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. France has a rich national heritage, which should be preserved with all the necessary means.  The motion for a resolution put to the vote of the European Parliament aims to strengthen the preservation of European cultural heritage, whether material (furniture, real estate and submarine) or intangible (oral traditions, performing arts, rituals, etc.). Although she speaks of an integrated European approach, she stresses that cultural heritage is naturally heterogeneous, reflecting the diversity and cultural and linguistic pluralism of the Member States.  The motion for a resolution examines issues relating to financing, legal bases and the digitisation of heritage, highlighting its importance and links with regional development, social cohesion, agriculture, the environment, education, tourism, and the labour market.  I find this proposal positive for French cultural heritage. That is why I voted for this draft resolution.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cultural heritage is one of the pillars of European culture and is our shared heritage that we leave to future generations. At the same time, any cultural heritage policy should take into account two perspectives: the first takes into account cultural heritage which can constitute a significant source of employment and income, and for the second the main value of cultural heritage remains its cultural value. It must also be borne in mind that the economic potential of cultural heritage is enormous and we can give culture an important place on the public agenda. Culture could also play an important role in the EU's external relations, being seen as an advantage that Europe has. I voted in favour of the Report entitled 'Towards an integrated approach to European cultural heritage' because it presents a number of welcome recommendations in terms of the training, skills and mobility of cultural heritage professionals and stresses the importance of access of young heritage professionals to the culture job market.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution because it calls emphatically and rightly for much more attention to be paid to Europe's cultural heritage. Many passages can be supported, from the economic potential of culture to the financing of specific programmes.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported this report because its objective has been to highlight the undervalued role of European cultural heritage as a source of social innovation for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. With regard to the EC's communication on this subject, I would particularly like to stress that this report highlights the importance of a comprehensive perspective, improving cooperation between different policy areas, as well as increasing funds to preserve European heritage through existing programmes such as Creative Europe, Horizon 2020, Europe for Citizens , etc. and its integration into the EC investment plan.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reflection and debate in plenary, I voted today in favour of the report on the European Parliament's motion for a resolution towards an integrated approach to cultural heritage for Europe. Achieving cultural dialogue and mutual understanding between nations and their traditions is one of the aims that can most lead to the strengthening of social, economic and territorial cohesion. In particular, I would like to join those who believe that it is essential to develop a truly democratic and participatory debate for europe's heritage, including that of religious and ethnic minorities. I am also referring to cultural heritage sites that contain different or contested pasts. I agree with those who believe that the processes of reconciliation should not result in the suppression of the historical conscience of communities. The Member States must be invited to reflect on the ethics and methods of presenting cultural heritage and to take account of the diversity of interpretations.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Culture is something that cannot and should not be imposed, leat of all by the EU through the medium of spending taxpayers’ money. Hence I voted against this report.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the scope of an integrated approach towards the domain of cultural heritage. Moreover, establishing cooperation and coordination among DGs within European Commission is necessary and setting up a single EU portal dedicated to cultural heritage. In addition, cooperation between local communities and private sector in activities will definitely enhance cultural heritage as well. Therefore, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the report, namely the enhancement of Europe's cultural heritage in an integrated way, both with regard to governance and the raising and use of funds, is certainly laudable.
