However, the text put to the vote presents critical issues on which it is not possible to postpone: the Juncker plan as a key reference point for the economic chapter, a public-private partnership in which aspects of corporate social responsibility and fundamental rights are not made essential, the fact that the negative impact assessment on aspects of cultural heritage has no effect on the continuation of work on dossiers , or, again, the lack of insurance about the processing of data concentrated in very few hands. I therefore voted against the report.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the broad adoption of my colleague Mircea Diaconu's report on an integrated approach to European cultural heritage.  After the serious and recent attack on the archaeological site of Palmyra, it is more necessary than ever to stress the importance of preserving and promoting our cultural heritage, a cornerstone of our European identity.  With this in mind, it is crucial to sustain European subsidies and the contributions of our institutions to the preservation of our heritage. Mr Diaconu's report is in line with this logic, notably by calling for the establishment of a European year for cultural heritage and the creation of a single European portal centralising information on funding available for cultural heritage under European programmes. I can only welcome and support these proposals.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this draft report because it focuses on the preservation of Europe's material but also intangible cultural heritage, such as oral traditions and customs. It also allows us to examine the financing problems of the schemes associated with this.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution voted on, which follows on from the Commission's communication of the same name last July, urges the Commission to protect and enhance Europe's diverse cultural heritage, in the awareness of the importance and strategic potential, not only but also in economic terms, for the EU as well as for individual States, of this common heritage: both the "material" heritage (architectural, landscape) and the immaterial (linguistic, literary, musical... ). On the one hand, these objectives of protection and enhancement must be integrated, across the board, into all Union policies, promoting collaboration and synergies between those responsible for the various policy areas (education, tourism, environment, employment, social cohesion, regional development, taxation); This applies, in particular, to the various aspects related to European cultural tourism, an important engine for growth, employment and local economic development, especially for SMEs. On the other hand, further and specific funding strategies need to be adopted, including by strengthening the principle of multiple funding – which allows for the complementary use of various funds within the same large-scale project – and by promoting new governance models and public/private partnerships.  Useful will be the establishment of a single EU portal dedicated to cultural heritage, and also containing information on all relevant funding programmes. For these reasons, I voted in favour of

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I agree with the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism that Europe is one of the main tourist destinations because of its rich cultural, artistic religious and historical heritage. It is particularly important that Europe's cultural tourism accounts for 40% of total tourism. I must stress that Cyprus, an EU Member State, has been culturally mutilated for 41 years because of the Turkish occupation. I would also point out that in occupied Cyprus, which accounts for about 40%, its cultural and religious heritage, which is also a European heritage, was captured and destroyed. Cyprus' religious and cultural treasures are in the hands of smugglers and, unfortunately, despite our interventions, and the EU is raising its hands high. I call on the European Commission to put an end by all means to this huge cultural crime against Cyprus and the whole of the EU.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution on an integrated approach to cultural heritage for Europe. Cultural, material and intangible heritage plays a significant role in promoting the values, culture and identities of Europeans. The EP considers it essential to use the resources available to support, enhance and promote Europe's cultural heritage. To this end, with this resolution, the European Parliament calls for the establishment of a European Year of Cultural Heritage (possibly in 2018), the creation of a regulatory framework for the protection and enhancement of monuments, archaeology and historical landscapes, a single dedicated portal collecting data from EU cultural heritage funding programmes, the promotion of public-private partnerships and the increase in the benchmark from EUR 5 million to EUR 10 million in relation to projects on cultural heritage in the framework of the small-scale infrastructure action, in line with the UNESCO Convention.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report not only because I agree with the idea of better protecting culture in Europe, but above all because of the way in which it is proposed to achieve this objective: reducing bureaucracy, simplifying decision-making, creating a portal dedicated solely and exclusively to Europe's cultural heritage, structuring a database with information on how to find, among the wide range of opportunities that culture offers in Europe , the site that best suits its interests, including through comments and reviews, establish a European year dedicated to cultural heritage and so on. I hope that these words will be ed by concrete action. The citizens are not asking for action, but for action, and above all promptly.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report because it seeks to use cultural heritage to further the EU’s goals. For example it states that cultural heritage promotes European culture and values; that European culture is important for European identity; and supports a common European cultural heritage and strengthen a sense of community in the EU. It also looks to influence national education policy, where the EU has absolutely no competence. Only elected and accountable national governments have the right to decide how to spend taxpayers’ money, create culture policy and change education policy, not unelected and unaccountable bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cultural heritage, as well as an invaluable source of identity for European citizens, is to be considered a valuable long-term economic resource and the main vehicle for the development of the tertiary sector market. In particular, cultural tourism, which accounts for 40% of European tourism, is a fundamental economic sector in potential terms of growth and employment, the development of which should be further strengthened with the use of new technologies and whose protection should form an essential prerogative, through the design of sustainable forms of tourism that will ensure these benefits in the decades to come. The control of cultural heritage is the responsibility of several Directorates-General of the European Commission and, therefore, I agree that the only way to exploit the synergies of these independent actors is the coordination and integrated organisation of activities aimed at enhancing this invaluable heritage. In order to achieve this, I support the establishment of a single Eu ropean Union portal dedicated to cultural heritage, collecting information from all Community programmes for the financing of cultural heritage, a database with examples of good practice and excellence in the field of cultural heritage, news and links on political developments, actions and historical events relating to cultural heritage.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report follows up on the European Commission Communication on an integrated approach to European cultural heritage, which aims to analyse the economic and social impact of European cultural heritage and contribute to the development of a multidisciplinary strategic approach with which the EU can complement national and regional programmes in the Member States. Since the report points to the importance of European cultural heritage and the need to enhance its conservation, promoting the maintenance and creation of rights-based jobs, while urging the Commission to promote new participatory models that include communities in the preservation and preservation of cultural heritage, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because I believe that Europe's immense cultural heritage has opportunities and challenges ahead of it. In fact, while cultural heritage and tourism could feed the European economy through the development of new jobs, innovative products and services, this heritage must be protected. In particular, I agree with the possibility of developing participatory governance models for the cultural heritage sector that value it as a shared resource at all regional, national and European local levels. As shadow rapporteur for the Committee on Regional Development, I would like to reiterate that, important as they are, small projects and interventions must not, in any way, exclude medium-large ones. We have examples of artistic and cultural heritage to recover and enhance for which substantial resources are needed. The Structural Funds are the only means, not only so as not to disperse this heritage, but above all to stimulate further investment and private capital.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the report, which targets the European Year of Cultural Heritage, and calls for the creation of a single EU portal summarising the possibilities for support for cultural heritage, news, links and events related to developments. This would give local communities, including traditional national minorities, a huge chance to preserve and promote their cultural heritage. Furthermore, we must not forget that culture and cultural heritage are a common resource that is of common good and value to Europe and has therefore earned attention. Moreover, cultural heritage can be a significant source of jobs and income, which is also an important aspect in the current economic circumstances.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report since cultural heritage is a significant source of jobs and revenues, which are crucial points to be considered in the present economic context, and because the main value of cultural heritage remains its cultural value. It also proposes alternative governance models to better involve local communities, civil society and the private sector in both the preservation and promotion activities related to cultural heritage and digitisation of cultural heritage. I agree with making the running of cultural heritage more of a societal endeavour rather than just a state remit and that we should find ways and means by which to help beneficiaries find easier access to funding for cultural heritage initiatives.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that it is clear the role that cultural heritage plays in the Union's external relations through political dialogue and cooperation with third countries, and I believe that the Member States, the Commission and the Council must relaunch cultural diplomacy through interdisciplinary research projects on the conservation of cultural heritage involving both the Member States of the European Union and countries outside the Union.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe's cultural heritage has enormous social and economic potential, so the time has come to put culture really at the heart of the EU's political agenda. New and effective synergies must be created around Europe's cultural heritage by using a single information and policy platform, increasing funding, encouraging the preservation and enhancement of cultural heritage, including through EU programmes. The designation of a European Year of Cultural Heritage may also be an important opportunity to raise awareness that cultural heritage is a source of wealth, social innovation for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report proposes the establishment of a single European portal dedicated to cultural heritage in order to better coordinate work between the services of the European institutions. The organisation of this portal could revolve around funding opportunities for cultural heritage, a database with examples of good practice, relevant information on political advances, actions and events related to cultural heritage. Considering that this report defends Europe's cultural heritage and paves the way for new opportunities for local authorities and the private sector in terms of tourism, I voted in favour of the text.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the integrated approach to European cultural heritage. Our heritage is one of the richest and most important in the world. It is essential to support and strengthen cooperation between the various Directorates-General of the Commission in order to make better use of the European funds made available.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of this report is to underline the importance of Europe's cultural heritage, understood as material (architectural, landscape) and immaterial (languages, traditions, music), as a fundamental factor for the preservation of European culture and history, as well as for regional and local realities and for safeguarding the values linked to European identity. I voted in favour of this report in order to call on the European Commission to enhance cultural heritage by providing for appropriate subsidy strategies and to strengthen the principle of multiple funding that allows the complementary use of various European funds within the same project. The report also points out that cultural heritage is an important economic potential, as it contributes to the creation of jobs, products, services and new innovative processes.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for an integrated approach to European cultural heritage. This heritage is a rich and diverse mosaic of cultural and creative expressions including the natural sites built and archaeological, museums, monuments and works of art, historic cities, literary, musical and audiovisual works, as well as the knowledge, practices and traditions of European citizens. We have inherited it from previous generations and we have a duty to bequeath it to future generations. This is far from the case in the world: today, terrorists are savagely demolishing with explosives and buldozers heritage pieces representing other cultures but belonging to a universal heritage that we all share. In such a troubled time, I felt it was essential to promote the inclusion of cultural heritage on the political agenda and to encourage Member States to preserve our heritage, but also that of other cultures and civilizations through international cooperation.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Before being a bureaucratic machine and an antechamber of globalism, Europe is a community of civilizations, peoples, identities, languages and traditions. The common soil on which nations have grown is precious for the vitality and future of European countries. The protection of our heritage and heritage must be ensured and promoted. I therefore support Mr Diaconu's report which continues this need for cultural preservation, which is important at a time when Europe is undergoing dramatic social changes and when waves of migration are reaching our territories regularly.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Calls for the return of cultural goods illegally removed from the territory of a Member State, bypassing the return of those that have been legally removed but under special circumstances (Parthenon marbles, Victory of Samothrace, etc.). It draws attention to the presence of cultural heritage sites incorporating a different or controversial past, and stresses that reconciliation processes should not lead to a suppression of the historical consciousness of communities while at the same time calling on Member States to reflect on the ethics and methods of presenting cultural heritage and to take into account the diversity of interpretations (FYROM).

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Culture and cultural heritage are both shared resources and common assets and values, which cannot be used exclusively, and their full potential for sustainable human, social and economic development is yet to be fully recognised and properly exploited, both at EU strategies and the POST-2015 DEVELOPMENT GOALS of the United Nations. Cultural heritage is naturally heterogeneous, reflecting cultural and linguistic diversity and pluralism, and greater dissemination and dissemination of this heritage is important. I agree with the creation of a single portal as well as with the specific funding, studies, research actions and pilot measures to preserve and honour this same heritage.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it focuses on the preservation of Europe's cultural heritage.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union needs a single portal dedicated to cultural heritage, offering citizens of the Member States clear and comprehensible information from all European Union programmes that finance cultural heritage. One step to bring cultural heritage into the awareness of the citizens of the Member States would be the European Year of Cultural Heritage. In future, we must pay close attention to renovation work, because their poor quality implementation has in several cases significantly damaged and changed the cultural value of the building in question. The European Commission must find a way to involve local communities, civil society and the private sector more in the process of protecting cultural heritage. Any public policy on cultural heritage should therefore take into account two perspectives. Firstly, that cultural heritage can be an important source of employment and income, which are considered essential in the current economic context, and secondly, that its cultural value remains the main value of cultural heritage.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this resolution, which calls for much more attention to Europe's cultural heritage and rightly so. Many passages can be supported, from the economic potential of culture to the financing of specific programmes.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report because it calls for the return of cultural goods that have been illegally removed from the territory of a Member State but ignores the request for the return of those that have been legally removed but under special circumstances (Parthenon marbles, Victory of Samothrace, etc.). It draws attention to the presence of cultural heritage sites incorporating a different or controversial past and stresses that reconciliation processes should not lead to a suppression of the historical consciousness of communities, while calling on Member States to reflect on ethics and methods of presenting cultural heritage and to take into account the diversity of interpretations (Fyrom).

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to state my support for the proposal of designating, preferably in 2018, a European Year of Cultural Heritage to disseminate and increase awareness and education in respect of the values of the European cultural heritage and its protection. I am confident that, through this report, we will be able to highlight the undervalued role of the Europe’s cultural heritage as a source of social innovation for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, tackle the challenges such as lack of finances, technological change and globalization, influx of tourism, trafficking of cultural goods and so on; that we will seize the opportunities such as innovation in conservation, digitization and online accessibility, creation of open networks and reaching wider and more diverse audiences, and strengthen policy cooperation on all levels, all that towards achieving an integrated approach on the European level. Cultural heritage is one of the pillars of the European culture and needs to be preserved and fostered through an integrated and coordinated policy in order to preserve it for future generations, as well as to realize its potential as a source of sustainable jobs and growth.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I am firm believer that preserving and promoting our cultural heritage is an important part of our political and institutional activity.  Both the Commission and the Council indicated the need to have an integrated approach towards the domain of cultural heritage, and consequently it is important to enhance the cooperation and coordination among themselves in this area.  This report calls for setting up of a single EU portal dedicated to cultural heritage as well as a better involvement of local communities and the private sector in the preservation and promotion activities related to cultural heritage. I see this as an opportunity especially for those national minorities, such the Hungarian minority in Romania and Slovakia, to help them protect and preserve their traditions, culture and language.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the report, I believe that an integrated approach to the field of cultural heritage is necessary, because it is known at the level of the European institutions that cultural heritage issues fall within the competence of several Directorates-General of the European Commission at the same time. Their work is therefore complementary and it is therefore vital that they improve cooperation in this respect and coordinate their activities in the field of cultural heritage. In addition, European funding for cultural heritage is provided under a number of EU programmes. Some of these: Creative Europe, Horizon 2020, European Fund for Rural Development, European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, etc. It is therefore important to better convey information to potential beneficiaries. The European Year of Cultural Heritage could be a perfect manifestation of the renewed EU commitment to this cultural heritage. With proper planning, such an initiative could give a major boost to the cultural heritage sector and highlight its enormous potential. I welcome the fact that the report also makes specific recommendations on the training, skills and knowledge and mobility of cultural heritage professionals, as well as on their access to the cultural labour market for such young professionals.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported this report because its objective has been to highlight the undervalued role of European cultural heritage as a source of social innovation for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. With regard to the EC's communication on this subject, I would particularly like to stress that this report highlights the importance of a comprehensive perspective, improving cooperation between different policy areas, as well as increasing funds to preserve European heritage through existing programmes such as Creative Europe, Horizon 2020, Europe for Citizens , etc. and its integration into the EC investment plan.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported this report because its objective has been to highlight the undervalued role of European cultural heritage as a source of social innovation for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. With regard to the EC's communication on this subject, I would particularly like to stress that this report highlights the importance of a comprehensive perspective, improving cooperation between different policy areas, as well as increasing funds to preserve European heritage through existing programmes such as Creative Europe, Horizon 2020, Europe for Citizens , etc. and its integration into the EC investment plan.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. Europe largely holds the majority of sites of cultural interest: our cultural heritage is a wealth that needs to be valued in a more strategic way, and I therefore consider the text presented by the Committee on Culture, Youth, Education, the Media and Technology, which makes very specific proposals for the new attention of the European institutions in this area, to be very useful and timely. I would particularly like to stress the objective of better coordination of the use of the Structural Funds for these objectives: in times of financial constraints, it is essential to ensure better use of available public resources, especially in sectors at risk such as culture.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution towards an integrated approach to cultural heritage for Europe, as I believe that the Cultural and Linguistic Diversity of the Union must be supported in order to promote the growth of the cultural and creative sectors. Although expertise in the restoration, conservation and accessibility of cultural heritage is primarily a national responsibility, Article 167 TFEU stresses that the EU promotes the development of Member States' culture.  I am therefore of the opinion that it is necessary, through a cultural dialogue, to define a European Year of Cultural Heritage; in such a way that future generations know respect for and protection of values; the creation of a single EU portal bringing together information from all eu cultural heritage funding programmes. I also believe that cultural heritage promotes economic growth with new jobs, innovative products and services; promoting the growth of tourism. To this end, it is necessary to improve the organisation of the fight against the theft, smuggling and illicit trafficking of cultural goods inside and outside the Union, bearing in mind that cultural heritage is the most concrete testimony to our history and has inestimable value for every people.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the 'Report on the road to an integrated approach to Europe's cultural heritage', because, as a cultural politician, I warmly welcome a common strategy for preserving our European cultural assets and I would like to see more EU commitment here.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. We need a new integrated approach to the protection of Europe's common cultural heritage. It is a question of promoting an increased appreciation of the economic and social value of Europe's cultural heritage.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report given I strongly agree that any public policy in the field of cultural heritage should take into account two perspectives: that cultural heritage can be a significant source of jobs and revenues and that the main value of cultural heritage remains its cultural value.  We need to start highlighting opportunities offered by an integrated approach to address contemporary challenges through sensitive interpretation, encouraging the use of cultural heritage as an educational tool to deal with societal issues in order to combat hatred and division and bring the people of Europe closer together.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: In writing. Cultural heritage is a central component of our European identity. I am pleased to vote today in favour of this report, which aims to promote an integrated approach to cultural heritage at European level in order to reach its full social, economic and political potential. The report also points to the importance of the contributions made by the European institutions to help Member States preserve and promote heritage. It proposes the establishment of a European Year for Cultural Heritage and the creation of a single European portal that centraliss information on funding available in this sector at European level.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Diaconu report on the approach to an integrated cultural policy for Europe. The report gives account of the different types of cultural heritage and demands strong support from the Commission, including by requesting the necessary funds to take over a Europe with plural cultural heritage. Some of our group's amendments had been integrated into the report and were intended to define culture as a common good, and reinforced the Commission's call for it to promote the funds necessary to make this an effective reality and not a toast to the sun. In addition, this section has a comprehensive approach to the employment of qualified persons and the positions generated around wealth.

name: Γιώργος Γραμματικάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I would like to express my disappointment that, neither in the Europe 2020 strategy, nor in the Juncker Investment Plan for Europe, there is no clear reference to culture or cultural heritage. It is time to upgrade the position of culture on the political agenda and assess its true value in terms of economic growth and employment. It is worth noting that cultural heritage touches on many areas of public policy, such as those relating to regional development, social cohesion, agriculture, maritime affairs, the environment, tourism, education, the digital agenda, external relations, customs cooperation, and research and innovation. It is therefore of the enormous importance to make proper use of the resources available to support, strengthen and promote cultural heritage on the basis of an integrated and holistic approach.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report argues that any public policy in the field of cultural heritage should take into account two perspectives: that cultural heritage can be a significant source of jobs and revenues and that the main value of cultural heritage remains its cultural value. It also focuses on the urgent need to take into account the links between cultural heritage - and culture in general - and other policy areas. I strongly support this approach as I believe that, beyond the economic potential of cultural heritage, we must focus on highlighting opportunities offered by an integrated approach to address contemporary challenges through sensitive interpretation, encouraging the use of cultural heritage as an educational tool to deal with societal issues in order to combat hatred and division and bring the people of Europe closer together.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted favourably on the resolution towards an integrated approach to cultural heritage in Europe. I truly believe that the EU should aim to have an integrated approach towards the domain of cultural heritage. Thus the European funding programmes should be presented easier, with as less as possible technocratic obstacles, in order to better communicate information towards potential beneficiaries. Nonetheless, I really look favourably upon the notion stressed in the resolution about the connection between culture and economy. As suppose, there is a great potential in the cultural heritage, hence the EU should appreciate it and evaluate the advantages the culture carries, which could increase the growth of the economy, such as the creation of job places. Therefore, the EU should take into account the culture as a long-term resource and prepare yet follow reasonable its development plan.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported this report because its objective has been to highlight the undervalued role of European cultural heritage as a source of social innovation for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. With regard to the EC's communication on this subject, I would particularly like to stress that this report highlights the importance of a comprehensive perspective, improving cooperation between different policy areas, as well as increasing funds to preserve European heritage through existing programmes such as Creative Europe, Horizon 2020, Europe for Citizens , etc. and its integration into the EC investment plan.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was very happy to support my colleague´s report on an integrated approach to cultural heritage for Europe. Although largely a Member State competence there are a range of EU supportive measures including significant EU funding from programmes such as Creative Europe, the European Regional Development Fund or Horizon 2020. Although faced with the challenges of globalisation and reduced funding there is huge potential for cultural heritage to contribute to growth and job creation. The report’s proposals to have 2018 designated the European year of Cultural Heritage and to set up of a single EU portal to collect information from all the EU programmes funding cultural heritage will raise awareness and provide a more integrated and supportive approach for those working in the area.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because we need an integrated approach in the domain of cultural heritage. I am very much in favour of the idea of setting up a single EU portal dedicated to cultural heritage, which could be structured around funding opportunities for cultural heritage and a database with examples of best practices and excellence from the field. This is an important report which explores the need to promote cultural heritage through a common approach.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report because it rightly argues that our policy on cultural heritage should take into account two main perspectives. Firstly, cultural heritage can act as a significant source of jobs and revenue. However, the main value of cultural heritage remains its cultural value. Beyond any economic potential of cultural heritage, we need to focus on highlighting the opportunities that the effective use of cultural heritage can have as an educational tool to deal with social problems.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report because it seeks to use cultural heritage to further the EU’s goals. For example it states that cultural heritage promotes European culture and values; that European culture is important for European identity; and supports a common European cultural heritage and strengthen a sense of community in the EU. It also looks to influence national education policy, where the EU has absolutely no competence. Only elected and accountable national governments have the right to decide how to spend taxpayers’ money, create culture policy and change education policy, not unelected and unaccountable bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The huge diversity of Europe’s cultural diversity is one of our strengths and can act as a catalyst for social improvement and economic growth. Whilst this report calls for an integrated approach to cultural heritage, it is vital that that approach is ever mindful of the need to respect diversity.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Diaconu report on the approach to an integrated cultural policy for Europe. The report gives account of the different types of cultural heritage and demands strong support from the Commission, including by requesting the necessary funds to take over a Europe with plural cultural heritage. Some of our group's amendments had been integrated into the report and were intended to define culture as a common good, and reinforced the Commission's call for it to promote the funds necessary to make this an effective reality and not a toast to the sun. In addition, this section has a comprehensive approach to the employment of qualified persons and the positions generated around wealth.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Resolution from the European Parliament: to meet a holistic approach to cultural heritage in Europe, because it is essential to protect in the best possible way the invaluable value of the tangible and intangible cultural heritage of the European Union. In this context, more efficient and efficient European programmes and funds should be ensured in order to preserve and exploit Europe's cultural heritage sustainably.  Access to such funds is often too complicated and complex and it is therefore in the common interest to simplify such procedures for the benefit of end-users and competent institutions. It is also important to pay the necessary attention to the digitisation of cultural heritage and to enable the training, upskilling and mobility of people working professionally in the cultural sector. Cultural heritage represents a great potential for regional development and tourism, and therefore I am inclined to launch an initiative of annual reward of the "region of culture".

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Mircea Diaconu's report on European cultural heritage. This text proposes concrete ways to strengthen the effectiveness of cultural heritage management in the European Union and highlights the source of jobs and growth it represents for the territories. The report also recalls the challenges this heritage faces, particularly in the fight against trafficking and the destruction of cultural heritage. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which aims to strengthen European cooperation and coordination in the management of European cultural heritage because it is fundamental to protect and promote our cultural heritage. In particular, the report proposes the establishment of a single European portal.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. European cultural heritage is one of the most diverse in the world and needs to be made more aware and promoted. However, I am abstaining from voting here, because of the demands for increases in resources and tendencies not to preserve diversity, but to make adjustments.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal. The report calls for the establishment of a single portal dedicated to cultural heritage and accessible to all actors in the sector for research into existing EU funding. It is essential to use the resources available to support, enhance and promote cultural heritage, on the basis of an integrated approach, taking into account the cultural, socio-economic, educational, environmental and scientific components.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft report entitled "Towards an integrated approach to European cultural heritage" has various objectives such as the preservation of European cultural heritage material (sites, historic buildings, etc.) but also intangible, such as oral traditions, customs... It also provides an analysis of issues related to financing, legal bases and the digitisation of heritage. So I voted for it.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support this report as I agree that, beyond the economic potential of cultural heritage, we must focus on highlighting opportunities offered by an integrated approach to address contemporary challenges through sensitive interpretation, encouraging the use of cultural heritage as an educational tool to deal with societal issues in order to combat hatred and division and bring the people of Europe closer together.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The own-initiative report entitled 'Towards an integrated approach to cultural heritage for Europe' had many good points in its text, which I supported, which is why I voted in favour of this report. For example, I welcomed the proposal for new models of governance for our cultural heritage in order to allow the use of alternative funding and governance models, such as the involvement of local communities, civil society participation and public-private partnerships. Personally, I would prefer the involvement of local communities and civil society to ensure that cultural heritage does not serve profit, but citizens. Moreover, the report stressed that cultural heritage contributes to innovative jobs, products, services and practices and can be a source of creative ideas, supporting the new economy while having little impact on the environment, but only if it is managed appropriately. Moreover, I fully agree that it is necessary to increase the level of digitisation, preservation and accessibility of cultural heritage on the Internet, in particular the European film heritage, as this will help to reach new audiences and improve access to and use of digital cultural heritage. I consider this to be a sensible objective that will lead to the accessibility of cultural heritage to the younger generation and ultimately lead to the cementing of European identity.

name: Etelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The report follows the Commission Communication on cultural heritage in Europe. It is essential to support the establishment of a European Year of Cultural Heritage, in order to promote national and regional programs. Also through the Cultural heritage, there is a positive economic and social impact in the regions. Furthermore, smaller cultural institutions will be able to profit from financial support and will be more visible. By supporting this report, the European Parliament will be able to emphasise these points. This is why I voted in favour.

name: Andrew Lewer (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ On behalf of the British Conservatives, I would like to underline our support for the broad principles, and many achievable proposals, contained in Mr Diaconu’s report. The overarching aim of protecting and promoting the cultural heritage of EU Member States, whilst boosting jobs and local economies through sustainable tourism, is one we share. We also believe that exchanging best practice between EU countries – be that through national governments, local authorities or NGOs – can provide genuine EU added value in this area. However, culture and the protection of cultural heritage are not areas of EU competence and they should remain that way. A number of national programmes in the UK are already achieving, or can achieve, the aims of this text. On principle, therefore, UK MEPs followed our abstention on the report in committee with a vote in favour of this largely balanced text, whilst opposing key references to the existence, or the promotion, of a ‘common European culture’ or ‘values’ that could lead to competence creep. An effective, integrated approach to cultural heritage in the EU can, and must, recognise the diverse cultures and traditions of its individual Member States, and be built soundly on the principles of subsidiarity.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I consider the Diacon report on an integrated approach to cultural heritage in Europe to be important and well prepared. This is a good reason to congratulate the rapporteur. The EU's guiding idea – unity in diversity – is reflected in it. Variety is first and foremost a tradition and culture that becomes our common heritage. Equality of all national, regional and heritage cultures is our common task. In a Union of countries with varying economic and financial potential, proposing certain standards and ways of financing Community support measures is a very important step towards the practical implementation of this principle of unity and diversity. To emphasise the importance of the common values and cultural contribution of each Member State serves to stabilise and strengthen the Union. Popularising best practices in this area will make it possible not to disappear from the memory of cultural heritage, despite clear globalisation trends and budgets' tendency to cut and save.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported this report because its objective has been to highlight the undervalued role of European cultural heritage as a source of social innovation for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. With regard to the EC's communication on this subject, I would particularly like to stress that this report highlights the importance of a comprehensive perspective, improving cooperation between different policy areas, as well as increasing funds to preserve European heritage through existing programmes such as Creative Europe, Horizon 2020, Europe for Citizens , etc. and its integration into the EC investment plan. Also, on a socialist initiative, a European Year of Cultural Heritage (preferably in 2018) is insisted on and drastic cuts in heritage protection in certain countries are criticized.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report follows up on the European Commission Communication on an integrated approach to European cultural heritage, which aims to analyse the economic and social impact of European cultural heritage and contribute to the development of a multidisciplinary strategic approach with which the EU can complement national and regional programmes in the Member States. Since the report points to the importance of European cultural heritage and the need to enhance its conservation, promoting the maintenance and creation of rights-based jobs, while urging the Commission to promote new participatory models that include communities in the preservation and preservation of cultural heritage, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The european cultural heritage as a whole is undoubted and invaluable, being one of the most precious assets of all Europeans. All the European institutions have agreed that an integrated approach to European cultural heritage needs to be addressed in practical terms, one of the objectives that the report aims to achieve. Among the proposals put forward, I consider the idea of creating a single European Union portal dedicated to material and intangible cultural heritage and bringing together information from all EU programmes funding this heritage. At present, this information and, above all, access to finance are too dispersed and technical, preventing effective use. By agreeing with this and other proposals included in this initiative, I voted in favour.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I supported the report on the pursuit of an integrated approach to cultural heritage in Europe. Greater cooperation between Member States in promoting a common cultural heritage is very important for building a common Europe, dialogue and understanding. In particular, now that there is an increased influx of migrants, learning about the culture and cultural heritage of different countries helps to facilitate intercultural dialogue, greater understanding and respect for other cultures.  I therefore fully support the report's recommendations for a new, integrated approach to cultural heritage. In this context, I would like to draw attention to the recommendation to introduce inter-cultural heritage pathways at different levels of education, which will allow us to learn about the common cultural heritage and the values of cultural diversity at different stages of education.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this report, which aims to promote European identity and European values, calls for greater funding for cultural heritage and for a greater role for the EU in cultural heritage. But member states are better able to take care of their own cultural sites than Brussels officials.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament adopted a resolution supporting a significant part of the measures set out in the specific report of the Committee on Culture and reaffirmed the importance of the overall concept of the report. The EP is aware of the importance of cultural heritage as a value landmark, a means of individual and collective identification, as well as its role as a catalyst for economic progress. I myself believe that the proper use of available resources to support, improve and promote the preservation of Europe's cultural heritage on the basis of an integrated approach is a matter of paramount importance. Such an approach is not only a necessity for achieving sustainable cultural dialogue and mutual understanding, but is also a prerequisite for enhanced social, economic and territorial cohesion. Moreover, this can lead to the establishment of a single European cultural and value area, without prejudice to the integrity and specificity of individual national identities. MEPs strongly support the idea of creating a single EU portal dedicated to tangible and intangible heritage, sharing information on the state, funding opportunities, and existing policies in the specific area. With our approval, we also benefit from the initiative to define a European Year of Cultural Heritage, which would undoubtedly contribute to the promotion and more responsible attitude towards historical monuments of culture.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Europe is very rich in heritage of cultural heritage after a centuries-long history. At the moment, each country protects it as it can, or sometimes does not protect at all. A unified concept will help preserve and leave future generations with our masterpieces. Support!

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The protection of Europe's cultural heritage requires coordinated action by the EU institutions, in particular the Commission and the member states' authorities and institutions concerned. Measures must be directed towards the prevention, protection and preservation of cultural heritage, its documentation and restoration, so as to preserve the important cultural values of our countries and regions for future generations. The role of cultural heritage as an important economic potential, space for scientific research, regional development and tourism with an impact on employment must be emphasised.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this draft report examining the financial and legal issues related to European cultural heritage. This very comprehensive text understands the material side of cultural heritage, such as sites or real estate, as well as the intangible side, oral traditions, customs... By protecting the 'European cultural heritage' it is also the French heritage that we protect.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report, which believes that, with regard to the cultural heritage, an integrated approach is necessary if one wishes to achieve cultural dialogue and mutual understanding; is convinced that such an approach can lead to enhanced social, economic and territorial cohesion, while also contributing to the fulfilment of the goals set in the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report 'Towards an integrated approach to cultural heritage for Europe'. In line with the objectives of the European Agenda for Culture, this text sets out the EU's approach to its heritage in the various policy areas in order to help safeguard and enhance the intrinsic and social value of cultural heritage. This heritage is to be regarded as a valuable resource for economic growth, employment and social cohesion.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 I fully agree that cultural heritage is a long-term asset whose role is to create value and contribute to knowledge development and economic growth by promoting tourism and creating jobs. It is clear that both tangible and intangible cultural heritage plays an important role in the creation, protection and promotion of European culture and European values and national, regional, local and individual identities. I also join in expressing concern about the state of protection, restaurant, preservation and promotion policies, which are of great importance for European identity. I also supported an increase in financial expenditure in this area. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The implementation of projects for the enhancement of cultural heritage has a positive influence on economic activity and, in general, on the entrepreneurial capacity of small and medium-sized enterprises. In particular, I welcome the proposal in the report to establish a single portal dedicated to cultural heritage, which will be accessible by all operators in the sector, with the aim of facilitating research into existing European funding. In agreement with the approach and aims of the text, I have decided to support it with a vote in favour.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report advocating an integrated approach to European cultural heritage because, to this day, it is not entirely clear what our cultural heritage is, but that there are different definitions and visions. If we want to protect and strengthen it, we must approach this issue from a comprehensive point of view and take steps to open up new opportunities in this sector, which has enormous economic potential.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Even if you want to expand cooperation in tourism, there are also some points that are not worth supporting. In 2018, the European Year of Cultural Heritage is to be launched and given sufficient budget to raise awareness of Europe's cultural heritage. In my opinion, it is a waste of resources and therefore to be rejected.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report on the management of Europe's cultural heritage is a missed opportunity. It certainly contains some interesting recommendations on facilitating access to European funds for cultural actors or digitising heritage. But the total lack of questioning on the impact of austerity policies and issues of access to culture in the Member States is particularly edifying. The "integrated" vision of European cultural heritage is to strengthen the weight of the European Commission and to increase European appreciation of the "special characteristics of national minorities" and "religious and ethnic minorities". In the end, the rapporteur's overall vision boils down to "maximum encouragement of private support for cultural heritage projects" and a new model of "governance" that emphasizes public-private partnerships, the rapporteur's only alternative to the reduction of state funding for culture. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. France has a rich national heritage, which should be preserved with all the necessary means.  The motion for a resolution put to the vote of the European Parliament aims to strengthen the preservation of European cultural heritage, whether material (furniture, real estate and submarine) or intangible (oral traditions, performing arts, rituals, etc.). Although she speaks of an integrated European approach, she stresses that cultural heritage is naturally heterogeneous, reflecting the diversity and cultural and linguistic pluralism of the Member States.  The motion for a resolution examines issues relating to financing, legal bases and the digitisation of heritage, highlighting its importance and links with regional development, social cohesion, agriculture, the environment, education, tourism and the labour market.  I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Culture and cultural heritage are both shared resources and common assets and values, which cannot be used exclusively, and their full potential for sustainable human, social and economic development is yet to be fully recognised and properly exploited, both at EU strategies and the POST-2015 DEVELOPMENT GOALS of the United Nations.  The various impacts of culture on societies need to be taken into account in the decision-making process. It is very important to use the resources available to support, value and promote cultural heritage on the basis of an integrated approach, taking into account cultural, economic, social, historical, educational, environmental and scientific components. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report because it organises a funding structure for the preservation and visibility of cultural heritage and encourages involvement of local communities in the private sector to increase tourism.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Building a culture of mutual respect, establishing relationships between equal men in rights and duties, creating a more harmonious society, is a fundamental necessity for humanity. While globalization has unquestionably fostered more trade and progress, it is our duty to combat the danger of uniformity of our cultures. Culture is a vehicle for openness and an engine of democracies acting against nationalist retreat, racist temptation and exclusions fueled by the current economic and financial, climate and food crises. I firmly believe that every people has its own message to deliver to the world. Every people, every human being has, through its culture, its positive identity, the means to bring to humanity the genius of its imagination and creativity. As the rapporteur put it very well, "our cultural heritage is a silent witness to our long history, our creativity and our struggle". Cultural creation most of the time draws or expresses a vision, a commitment, a bias. Whether it is a relevant or impertinent bias, what matters is that it is the exercise of a right including the right to denounce.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE)
text: in writing. I would like to stress the importance of the adoption of the 'Towards an integrated approach to European cultural heritage' report, on which I voted in favour. It is a call for the European Union to support and promote cultural heritage, including religious heritage. I would particularly like to underline the support this report gives to the European Cultural Routes recognised by the Council of Europe. Moreover, I think it is well the emphasis that the report places on the tourism relevance of Europe's cultural heritage.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report towards integrated approach to cultural heritage, which, I believe, is one of the pillars of the European culture and needs to be preserved and fostered through an integrated and coordinated policy in order to preserve it for future generations, as well as to realise its potential as a source of sustainable jobs and growth.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report deals with tangible, intangible and digital cultural heritage. It states that cultural heritage issues fall within the competence of several Directorates-General of the European Commission at the same time and urges their cooperation and the coordination of their cultural heritage activities. It also points out that European funding for cultural heritage is also provided under a number of EU programmes, information on funding opportunities is scattered across a wide range of websites, in strong jargon, and translations only exist in some of the official languages of the European Union. The report therefore calls for the creation of a single EU portal dedicated to cultural heritage, which would gather information on all EU programmes supporting cultural heritage in one place. It points out that the European Year of Cultural Heritage could be a perfect manifestation of the renewed EU commitment to this cultural heritage, that the initiative could give a major boost to the cultural heritage sector and highlight its huge potential. In order to achieve a meaningful result, it considers it necessary that the European Year of Cultural Heritage should have an adequate budget and that the activities organised within it should be accompanied by multiple actions at Member State level.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report defending the safeguarding of European heritage, both material and intangible, and highlighting the issues of funding, legal bases and digitisation, we support this initiative.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report focuses on an integrated approach in the field of European cultural heritage. I would point out that the promotion of culture, cultural diversity and intercultural dialogue plays a key role and catalyst for cooperation between Member States. The enhancement of European cultural and linguistic diversity, the promotion of European cultural heritage and the strengthening of the competitiveness of cultural areas aim to foster sustainable and inclusive growth. I endorse the rapporteur's recommendation for direct and accessible communication with potential beneficiaries, specifically through a single platform for sharing information and best practices in the EU, as well as a preferred channel for the dissemination of existing European funding lines for cultural heritage and a database of material and intangible cultural goods. I advocate the promotion of cultural tourism in island, coastal and mountainous regions, which offer unspoilt nature and landscapes, local culture and crafts, which contributes to the diversification of the economy and the fixing of the population, avoiding the depopulation and deterioration of places of cultural interest, as well as the disappearance of traditions and traditional culture.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft report entitled "Towards an integrated approach to European cultural heritage" has various objectives, such as the preservation of material European cultural heritage (sites, real estate, etc.) but also intangible, such as oral traditions, customs... It also provides an analysis of issues related to financing, legal bases and the digitisation of heritage. So I voted for it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report argues that any public policy in the field of cultural heritage should take into account two perspectives: that cultural heritage can be a significant source of jobs and revenues and that the main value of cultural heritage remains its cultural value. It also focuses on the urgent need to take into account the links between cultural heritage - and culture in general – and other policy areas. I strongly support this approach as I believe that, beyond the economic potential of cultural heritage, we must focus on highlighting opportunities offered by an integrated approach to address contemporary challenges through sensitive interpretation, encouraging the use of cultural heritage as an educational tool to deal with societal issues in order to combat hatred and division and bring the people of Europe closer together.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which deals with European cultural heritage. In particular, it proposes the creation of a single portal to facilitate access to information for project owners and enable them to benefit from European programmes. This will protect our heritage, which is a source of jobs and growth for Europe, especially through tourism.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I would like to stress the need for an integrated approach to Europe's cultural heritage, both material (architectural, landscape) and immaterial (such as languages, traditions, music and practices also linked to religious heritage) as a fundamental factor for the preservation of European culture and history, as well as regional and local realities, and for the preservation of the founding values of the European identity. er to spread awareness and education in the values of Europe's cultural heritage and the need for its protection, the resolution – which I strongly supported and voted for – rightly calls on the European Commission to establish, preferably in 2018, the European Year of Cultural Heritage.  The Commission is also asked to provide for appropriate funding strategies which, in addition to strengthening programmes and mechanisms already provided for in Community legislation, will establish a dedicated single EU portal for all Community programmes. Last but not least, the resolution underlines the strategic potential of Europe's cultural heritage as a source of creative ideas and innovative jobs, products, services and processes. In short, European cultural tourism is also an important engine for growth, sustainable local development and employment.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Preserving Europe's cultural heritage is our responsibility for future generations. Especially today, when the value of our traditions and cultural heritage is under attack every day, we cannot afford to lose our treasures because of forgetting and neglect. I therefore welcome the report, which targets the European Year of Cultural Heritage. I think that in the course of such a year they would have the chance to highlight the value of a traditionally diverse Europe, our particular European identity from the interactions of the peoples who have lived here together for centuries. That is what needs to be strengthened today, that is what the future must preserve for our survival.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that was built on the latest policy documents issued in relation to the theme of cultural heritage and resumes the key points of the public debate around this topic.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported by vote the report of my colleague Mircea Diaconu because I am convinced that the cultural component must be the basis of any economic and social development. We cannot evolve as states or as individuals without knowing our history, without harnessing and preserving the most impressive monuments, cathedrals, castles, all these works of art that define our civilization, our way of life and our way of thinking.  European cultural heritage is naturally heterogeneous, reflects cultural and linguistic diversity and European pluralism, and its effects are manifested on regional development, social cohesion, agriculture, maritime affairs, the environment, tourism, education, digital agenda, external relations, customs cooperation, research, innovation. In this respect, today's report sets out how important it is that the financial and human resources available are used to support, strengthen and promote cultural heritage on the basis of an integrated approach, while taking into account cultural, economic, social, historical, educational and environmental components.  I also believe that the proposal for a firm employment report by Member States, the EU and the international community in prevention, protection, documentation and restoration activities in situations where the cultural heritage of the EU or third countries is intentionally threatened and damaged is absolutely beneficial for the integration and preservation of European cultural heritage.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. - The European Year of Cultural Heritage will be launched in 2018 and will have a sufficient budget to raise awareness of Europe's cultural heritage. Otherwise, this is a complete waste of resources. In principle, the report contains a good idea, but it is questionable which projects receive the funding. That is why I abstained.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Preserving cultural heritage while exploiting its economic potential is important. The report addresses the main challenges in the area of cultural heritage and their possible solutions.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report.  Cultural heritage plays an important role in the creation, preservation and promotion of European culture and national, regional, local and personal identity and the identity of modern European peoples. Europe's cultural heritage must be protected and strengthened, as it helps to strengthen development and improve people's quality of life. In this context, various programmes should be implemented and sufficient resources should be made available.  I support the proposal for 2018 to be declared the European Year of Heritage and to provide adequate funding.  It should be noted that the funding threshold for cultural projects must be increased and aligned with the ceiling for UNESCO projects. Private sector support for cultural heritage projects needs to be promoted as much as possible. Increased funding must be provided for studies, research and other related measures.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is often the case that culture is seen as a sector detached from the economy and is often itself among the first budget items to suffer the consequences of cuts in public spending by states. On the contrary, I believe that it must become one of the main drivers of European economic development. Europe's cultural heritage must be valued and preserved so that it can be passed on to future generations and known to the whole world. Let us remember that culture is our greatest wealth and an integral part of our identity.

name: Ева Паунова (PPE)
text: in writing. – I am proud of the huge cultural heritage that Bulgaria and Europe possess and consider its reverence, preservation and development to be my duty. Europe's cultural heritage is of fundamental importance. It lies at the heart of our European identity. Cultural heritage, in addition to a testament to Europe's glorious history, is an excellent tool for economic and social development and the creation of many new jobs. I voted in favour of the report on an integrated approach to cultural heritage because it covers all aspects affecting cultural heritage. I warmly welcome the proposal to create a common European portal dedicated to tangible and intangible cultural heritage, and I am of the opinion that the financing of cultural heritage needs to be increased, because by investing in the past we will create numerous key and long-term dividends economically, socially and externally.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the creation of a single EZ portal dedicated to cultural heritage, which would serve to inform funding opportunities for cultural heritage, be a base with examples of best practices in the field of cultural heritage, offer news on activities and events and links on the development of cultural heritage related policies. I also support the proposal for a European Year dedicated to cultural heritage, which could increase knowledge of cultural heritage. Their realisation will also require better involvement of local communities and the private sector in cultural heritage conservation and promotion activities, so that the visibility of many areas and regions and their development of tourism can also be improved. That is why I supported the report.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ While, for example, in France, the United Kingdom and Austria, the cultural heritage sector contributes billions of euros to society, in some Member States the culture sector is perceived as an unnecessary cost of too much money without significant effect.  It is a short-sighted policy that does not recognize the potential of a particular castle, manula, fortress, church, etc. whose restoration would also have an impact on the increased arrival of tourists, and thus on regional development, job creation, but also the preservation of traditional crafts and the promotion of indigenous cuisine of the region and certainly rural development.  It should help EU Member States, especially those that do not achieve the desired and good results in this sector, in developing an analysis of the performance of cultural treasure management and further strengthening administrative capacities through additional education and exchange of experience, as well as co-financing the implementation of the renovation of such facilities.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report promotes the preservation and protection of the heritage of European countries. He is interested in both material and intangible heritage. It is a pity, however, that he is making a large part of the propaganda in favour of a so-called "European identity" instead of respecting the diversity and differences between peoples, which make up the richness of Europe's cultural heritage. Despite this reservation, I consider the text to be generally positive and I therefore speak in favour.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. —As the cradle of modern Western civilization, the countries of the European Union have inherited exceptional cultural heritage that, however unique, is deeply intertwined and carries enormous potential that is still only sporadically used. No heritage is or should be for sale, escaping the cautious use of its economic potential.  Only the living heritage that we actively and sustainably pass on is a heritage that will not be forgotten and has a future. I strongly support a report advocating a holistic approach to European cultural heritage, in particular in terms of creating a single cultural heritage portal that should facilitate access to information on funding opportunities from common funds, facilitate the finding of partners, but also open up space for the promotion of cultural projects.  As an example of good practice, which can only benefit from the practical implementation of the proposed holistic approach, can serve the project "The Best in Heritage" implemented by the Croatian "European Heritage Association" with the aim of promoting the best European heritage projects.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Culture is undoubtedly the most important intangible resource for our continent. Europe is and must continue to be a world-class cultural power. In order to continue to be so, it is essential to equip ourselves with the most suitable instruments and a more integrated approach. The report calls for the establishment of a single portal dedicated to cultural heritage and accessible to all actors in the sector for research into existing EU funding. It also calls for the designation, possibly in 2018, of a European Year dedicated to cultural heritage. Lastly, it called for the financing ceiling under the Structural Funds to be raised to 5 million (for small-scale infrastructure projects for the conservation of Europe's cultural heritage) to 10 million under the UNESCO Convention. I could only give my full support to such a proposal.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Cultural heritage is a common resource and a common good. It can be exposed to over-exploitation and underfunding, resulting in neglect, destruction and sometimes oblivion. It is therefore our common responsibility to ensure that heritage is cared for, while its protection is primarily the responsibility of national, regional and local authorities. Despite references to 'European culture', the report is balanced and also refers to national and regional cultures. The report describes the instruments available at EU level, complementing national and regional programmes. In addition, it sets out measures to strengthen political cooperation at different levels and projects designed to support heritage management. That is why I supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The Union is now full of an immense cultural heritage. The diversity of cultures and heritages is a wealth of the Union and the Member States that must be preserved. Many European programmes are now dedicated to the preservation and promotion of this heritage.  In this context, the European Parliament has adopted a text which stresses the need to develop an integrated approach to European cultural heritage. The text underlines the need for greater European cooperation and coordination in the management of Europe's cultural heritage. I am pleased to have voted in favour of this report which will encourage Member States to consider their policy of managing and promoting cultural heritage from a global and European perspective. As an elected official from the South-West of France, a region with a rich historical heritage, I am particularly sensitive to it.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. – (PT) I voted in favour of understanding that the maintenance and preservation of cultural heritage must be gained from a comprehensive and integrated vision, which will not only create the conditions for increasing mobility and the exchange of good practice, but also to continue to maintain Europe as a top destination in the context of cultural tourism.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. Victim of the barbarity of those who want an end to a people, as evidenced by the recent attacks by IS on the ancient city of Palmyra, culture is a strong testimony to our past but also to our history, our roots, our identities and our common future within the framework of the European project. It is for this reason that Parliament voted this lunchtime on a resolution to draw the full potential of Europe's cultural heritage, which deserves to be valued and preserved. In practice, cultural matters currently depend on several directorates-general within the European Commission and its funding is available through several complementary programmes. The aim is to simplify this fragmented operation by proposing a number of solutions to the main obstacles that prevent it from reaching its full potential. These new legal, financial and technical perspectives should make its operation more efficient. It is also urgent to consider the economic potential and political importance of cultural heritage. It is about giving culture the place it deserves in our political agenda so that it can make a real contribution to growth and job creation.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In addition to its intrinsic value, cultural heritage can be a source of employment and income, crucial aspects in the current economic climate. A sustainable development plan for this resource is needed once and for all.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report in response to the European Commission communication 'Towards an integrated approach to European cultural heritage'.  As the report denounces, the economic and strategic potential of European cultural heritage as a source of social innovation for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth is undervalued.
