It is therefore necessary to develop a comprehensive perspective, improving cooperation between different policy areas, increasing funds to preserve European heritage through existing programmes such as Creative Europe, Horizon 2020 or Europe for Citizens, and effectively integrating them into the Investment Plan for Europe. We demand from my political group the proclamation of a European year dedicated to cultural heritage, which could perfectly embody the Union's renewed commitment to that heritage. Finally, we denounce again through this report the drastic and deplorable cuts in the protection of heritage carried out by certain governments of the Union, including infamy of Spain.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which advocates an integrated approach to European cultural heritage. The text adopted yesterday highlights in particular the importance of European subsidies and the contributions made by the European institutions to help Member States preserve and promote cultural heritage in order to reach full social, economic and political potential.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 At the level of the European institutions, policies aimed at cultural heritage are the responsibility of several Directorates-General of the European Commission and, consequently, it would be extremely advantageous to have an integrated approach to cultural heritage (understood as a complex reality and composed of various components: cultural, economic, sociai, historical, educational, environmental and scientific), as well as a strengthening of cooperation and coordination in this area.  For these reasons, I generally agree with this report, which calls for the creation of a single EU portal dedicated to cultural heritage, which is able to aggregate information on funding opportunities in this area, has a database with examples of good practice/excellence in the field of cultural heritage, as well as the promotion of cultural actions and events. I also support the idea of creating a European year dedicated to cultural heritage, as such a project could certainly boost and show the real potential of this sector. Finally, I believe that we should also promote greater participation and involvement of local and private sector communities in these areas, in order to give greater visibility to the many areas and regions with a relevant cultural, historical and heritage heritage.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of creating a single portal for cultural heritage, where all cultural experts can consult on relevant Eu ropean Union funding. As a member of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, I hope that a European Year dedicated to Cultural Heritage will be designated, possibly in 2018. As provided for in the UNESCO Convention, I agree with the call for the financing ceiling for the Structural Funds to be raised from EUR 5 million to EUR 10 million so that culture and tourism play a decisive role in Europe's growth and job creation.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because the text rightly calls for much more attention to be paid to Europe's cultural heritage.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Diaconu report on the approach to an integrated cultural policy for Europe. The report gives account of the different types of cultural heritage and demands strong support from the Commission, including by requesting the necessary funds to take over a Europe with plural cultural heritage. Some of our group's amendments had been integrated into the report and were intended to define culture as a common good, and reinforced the Commission's call for it to promote the funds necessary to make this an effective reality and not a toast to the sun. In addition, this section has a comprehensive approach to the employment of qualified persons and the positions generated around wealth.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report follows up on the European Commission Communication on an integrated approach to European cultural heritage, which aims to analyse the economic and social impact of European cultural heritage and contribute to the development of a multidisciplinary strategic approach with which the EU can complement national and regional programmes in the Member States. Since the report points to the importance of European cultural heritage and the need to enhance its conservation, promoting the maintenance and creation of rights-based jobs, while urging the Commission to promote new participatory models that include communities in the preservation and preservation of cultural heritage, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The terms 'culture' and 'economy'' seem to belong to two completely different areas, but in reality the cultural heritage sector has enormous economic potential. It is a shared resource and a common good. I therefore felt that it was appropriate to vote in favour of an integrated approach, as it can lead to the strengthening of social, economic and territorial cohesion, while also contributing to the achievement of the objectives set out in the Europe 2020 strategy. The report sets out the instruments available at European level, complementing national and regional programmes, to protect and improve the intrinsic and social value of cultural heritage and thus strengthen its contribution to economic growth and job creation. I am convinced that an important step has been taken towards strengthening political cooperation at various levels and new models of European governance.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. To be European is also to recognise and value difference and diversity.  The valorization and promotion of material and intangible cultural heritage is a factor of great importance for European integration. It is also a way to deepen knowledge and the consequent appreciation of local specificities. It may also be a decisive factor for a greater differentiation of Europe as a tourist destination. It must therefore deserve an integrated and integrative approach from the Commission, the Council and the Member States, capable of taking advantage of Europe's immense cultural potential. The report under consideration aims, above all, to respond to the needs and anides expressed by those who deal with this phenomenon on a daily basis and who experience difficulties both in accessing information and in access to finance. That is why these proposals are therefore coming at a good time, which calls for concrete measures to address these difficulties. The revision of governance models is another measure that can make a difference. The cultural phenomenon is not, and thanka far, immune to new models of organization, which is why they deserve to be taken into account in particular.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as it calls for more EU funding and it also calls on the EU to take a greater role in cultural heritage, which I am completely against.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I greatly appreciate the time and effort that has gone into this report. I strongly support this approach as I believe that we must focus on highlighting the opportunities offered by an integrated approach to address the contemporary challenges through sensitive interpretation, and encourage the use of cultural heritage as an educational tool to deal with societal issues which can combat hate and division, which may bring the people of Europe closer together. The report argues that two perspectives be taken into account in the development of any public policy in the field of cultural heritage. The first perspective is that it can be a significant source of jobs and revenue(s) and the second perspective is that, notwithstanding the economic potential, the main value of cultural heritage remains its cultural value. It also focuses on the urgent need to take into account the links between cultural heritage, culture in general and other policy areas.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that the promotion of culture in the EU is an important part of its policy and the development of an integrated approach to it also has a positive contribution to Slovakia, as confirmed by Košice as The European Capital of Culture. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution because cultural heritage is one of the pillars of European culture, it witnesses our rich history, but also our common message to future generations. Under cultural heritage we understand material cultural things – movable and immovable, intangible, such as oral traditions, rituals, customs... cultural heritage, an integrated approach is therefore needed to protect it. Cultural heritage can be an important source of employment and income, which are considered essential in the current economic context, and secondly, its cultural value remains the main value of cultural heritage. An ideal integrated strategy for cultural heritage should take both sides into account and combine the need for immediate growth and employment with an understanding of cultural heritage as a long-term resource that requires a sustainable development plan.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Cultural heritage reflects cultural and linguistic diversity and pluralism and affects many areas (regional development, social cohesion, tourism, education, research, innovation...). The resources of this heritage are long-term goods that are important for value creation and contribute to the development of skills and economic growth by promoting tourism and creating jobs. The report clearly shows the importance of using the available resources to support, strengthen and promote cultural heritage through an integrated approach, and that cultural, economic, social, historical, educational, environmental and scientific components should also be taken into account. As is often the case with regard to the conservation and development of cultural heritage, I therefore support the Commission's initiative to reconsider the assessment of the five million euros earmarked for regional operational programmes. I also welcome the development of tools for alternative and more participatory governance models in this area, which strengthen the links between local, regional, national and European plans. Cultural heritage is one of the pillars of European culture and our common legacy for future generations. The report points out that all public policies in this area should take into account two aspects – firstly, it is an important source of jobs and income and, secondly, that the greatest value of cultural heritage is its cultural value. I supported this report for the reasons described.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support the report because Europe's cultural heritage is one of the largest and most important in the world and of utmost importance to world civilization. Therefore, it needs to be preserved for generations to come and should also be among the higher places on the Europeans' list of priorities. In order to take good care of Europe's cultural heritage and to maintain and develop it in the best possible way, an integrated approach to all European cultural heritage is needed.  Of course, this approach must be the same for all Member States in order to care for cultural heritage in an equal and balanced manner. This would make it easier to understand the financial resources invested in preserving Europe's cultural heritage, development strategies and relevant events. Also, embracing the unison approach at local levels and with the help of the private sector would make cultural heritage more involved in the progress of tourism and the visibility of many regions and spaces in need of such tourism development.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report argues that any public policy in the field of cultural heritage should take into account two perspectives: that cultural heritage can be a significant source of jobs and revenues and that the main value of cultural heritage remains its cultural value. It also focuses on the urgent need to take into account the links between cultural heritage - and culture in general – and other policy areas. I strongly support this approach as I believe that, beyond the economic potential of cultural heritage, we must focus on highlighting opportunities offered by an integrated approach to address contemporary challenges through sensitive interpretation, encouraging the use of cultural heritage as an educational tool to deal with societal issues in order to combat hatred and division and bring the people of Europe closer together.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal as, in accordance with the principles of subsidiarity, I do not consider it appropriate for the European Union to address the subject of cultural heritage.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the path towards an integrated approach to cultural heritage in Europe. Cultural heritage is of paramount importance to every nation and country, not only from the point of view of the identity of the country, but also from the point of view of cultural tourism as an economic activity. Many countries are under-exploiting their cultural heritage as an opportunity to become recognisable as a cultural tourist destination. We also do little to devote ourselves to local cultural heritage, which is why it is often doomed. Local communities also play a major role here, which must start discovering and recognising the importance and preservation of the cultural heritage of their place in their environment. In Slovenia, for example, we have seen numerous construction interventions in the past, which have destroyed several archaeological finds. Archaeological and cultural heritage must be protected permanently in order to prevent the harmful behaviour of irresponsible individuals.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the road to an integrated approach to cultural heritage for Europe. This is not an effort to manage the care, use or promotion of cultural heritage from one centre, but an effort to facilitate the use of cultural heritage, which has enormous economic potential. On the contrary, the report rightly states that local governments need to be more involved in governance and use. There is also talk of the sustainable use of cultural heritage, which needs to be properly cared for so that future generations can also use it. Therefore, everything cannot be subject only to the economic aspect. As cultural heritage care is addressed by a number of Union institutions that use a number of different forms of funding, simplification of the system and simplification are required for those using these instruments at national level.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 This exhibition can potentially upgrade the tourist product of Cyprus by projecting it in a more integrated and organized way and highlighting its role in the cultural heritage of Europe. There is no doubt that the relationship between cultural heritage and tourism is of mutual benefit. At the same time, however, we must not forget that cultural heritage and ancient monuments belong to every people. The people are also responsible for managing and exploiting this inheritance as well as their potential profit. Unfortunately, this approach is absent from the report. An important omission is also the absence of any reference to the need to respect the specificities of each state and people in terms of the protection and management of their cultural heritage. Unfortunately, the report pays particular attention only to the concept of economic management of cultural heritage and to the development of a common European identity. That is why we have abstained.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Calls for the return of cultural goods illegally removed from the territory of a Member State, bypassing the return of those that have been legally removed but under special circumstances (Parthenon marbles, Victory of Samothrace, etc.). It draws attention to the presence of cultural heritage sites incorporating a different or controversial past, and stresses that reconciliation processes should not lead to a suppression of the historical consciousness of communities while at the same time calling on Member States to reflect on the ethics and methods of presenting cultural heritage and to take into account the diversity of interpretations (FYROM).

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Our cultural heritage represents a rich and diverse mosaic of our inheritance from previous generations and our legacy for those to come.  It is an important resource for economic growth, employment and social cohesion, offering the potential to revitalise urban and rural areas and promote sustainable tourism. To better preserve, foster and realise the potential of our European heritage, we need an integrated and coordinated approach to culture heritage based on improved coordination and communication between different policy areas, better access to information and increased funding opportunities through EU programmes (i:e. Erasmus, European Capitals of Culture). The report also recommends designating 2018 as the European Year on Culture Heritage. While I support this initiative, I also believe we must see cultural heritage in a broader context, particularly with regards to tourism. As the two themes go hand-in-hand a European Year on Cultural Heritage and Tourism will surely raise awareness to Europe’s touristic, historical and cultural diversity. Nonetheless, I support the elements in this report and view its adoption as a way forward in the promotion of an integrated policy, one that not only preserves our heritage but also realizes its potential as a source of sustainable jobs and growth.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report: the valorisation of the European cultural heritage is now at a crossroad, facing on the one side reduced public investment and one the other an enormous potential in terms of modernisation, diversification of the audience and increase of tourism. Maintaining its cultural heritage is a State competence, but there is a European dimension supported by EU funding. This report sets out a series of recommendations to improve the promotion of cultural heritage throughout the EU, for instance by setting up a EU portal gathering all information on funding opportunities and examples of good practices. Lastly the cultural heritage provides great opportunities for innovation, research and high-skilled jobs creation if we encourage the digitisation of the sector.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒The report highlights in a good and balanced way the fact that the protection of cultural heritage is primarily a matter for national, regional and local authorities and that in this sense the European Union must respect the principle of subsidiarity.  However, it was clearly emphasised that the aim is to review the available information on the economic and social impacts of cultural heritage as well as to explore the challenges and opportunities in the sector. I strongly support the presentation of tools available at EU level, complementing national and regional programmes, in order to protect cultural heritage values and strengthen their contribution to economic growth and job creation.  I believe that the principle of Union added value positively strengthens the cooperation policy at different levels of this area as well as projects developed with the aim of supporting new models of cultural heritage management.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. The report for an integrated approach to cultural heritage for Europe calls for the creation of a single EU portal dedicated to cultural heritage that could provide access to funding for cultural heritage, which I supported. The portal will contain databases with examples of best practices and excellence in the field of cultural heritage and relevant references, as well as news and links on cultural policy development related to heritage, activities and events. Better involvement of the private sector and public institutions in activities for the conservation and development of cultural heritage would improve certain regions and their visibility while improving the development of tourism.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Diaconu report on the approach to an integrated cultural policy for Europe. The report gives account of the different types of cultural heritage and demands strong support from the Commission, including by requesting the necessary funds to take over a Europe with plural cultural heritage. Some of our group's amendments had been integrated into the report and were intended to define culture as a common good, and reinforced the Commission's call for it to promote the funds necessary to make this an effective reality and not a toast to the sun. In addition, this section has a comprehensive approach to the employment of qualified persons and the positions generated around wealth.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Europe’s history is long and so demonstrated by the large amounts of monuments and buildings that make up the European heritage. Therefore, it is important to rehabilitate and preserve it, because European history is told through our cultural heritage. They are also an economic potential, as they help promoting cultural tourist routes, which are currently already 40% of European tourism, and that brings quality jobs. I give my support to this proposal because we should help the sector to step forward, to digital innovation, to make accessible heritage to people with reduced mobility and for cross—cooperation plans with the gastronomic and rural heritage of each European region.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft report has several objectives. First, to put at the centre of the game the preservation of European cultural heritage material (sites, real estate ...) but also intangible (oral traditions, customs ...). This draft report examines the problems of financing, legal bases and the digitisation of this heritage. I therefore vote FOR the adoption of this text.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe's cultural heritage is our common wealth, the legacy that previous generations of Europeans have left us and which, in turn, we will leave to future generations. This is a valuable resource for economic growth and job creation and is a factor in social cohesion. That is why our cultural heritage and the way in which we preserve it determine sown Europe's place in the world and the attraction that this continent exerts on those who live, live or travel here.  In the face of other sectors that are given more importance, cultural heritage may be subject to more challenges. Although there are many European funding opportunities for these sectors, most of the time the information is not always passed on to beneficiaries. In this respect, this report proposes the creation of an EU-wide cultural heritage portal to collect information from all EU funding programmes. Moreover, this report supports the digitisation of cultural heritage as a way of protecting our past and as a tool that can provide many opportunities for research and, by implication, economic development. I therefore voted in favour of the Report 'Towards an integrated approach to European cultural heritage'.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In July 2014, the European Commission presented a communication entitled 'Towards an integrated approach to European cultural heritage'. This document outlines the Union's approach to heritage in different policy areas and mentions the instruments available at EU level that complement national and regional programmes to help protect and increase the intrinsic and social value of European cultural heritage. The aim of the Communication is to help Member States and stakeholders make full use of the considerable support available under EU instruments and to move towards a more integrated approach at national and EU level, eventually turning Europe into a heritage-based innovation laboratory. The European Parliament resolution underlines the need for an integrated approach to European cultural heritage, which will lead to the strengthening and promotion of that heritage, and proposes, inter alia, the creation of a single portal at European level including information from all EU programmes to finance European cultural heritage. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Diaconu report on the approach to an integrated cultural policy for Europe. The report gives account of the different types of cultural heritage and demands strong support from the Commission, including by requesting the necessary funds to take over a Europe with plural cultural heritage. Some of our group's amendments had been integrated into the report and were intended to define culture as a common good, and reinforced the Commission's call for it to promote the funds necessary to make this an effective reality and not a toast to the sun. In addition, this section has a comprehensive approach to the employment of qualified persons and the positions generated around wealth.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which was built on the latest policy documents issued in relation to the theme of cultural heritage and resumes the key points of the public debate around this topic. Both the European Commission’s Communication and the conclusions of the last two Council Presidencies indicate the need to have an integrated approach towards the domain of cultural heritage.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this very important report on an integrated approach to cultural heritage for Europe. The text highlights the importance of EU funding and European institutions' contributions to Member States in order to preserve and promote cultural heritage, while putting forward solutions to reach its full social, economic and environmental potential. I particularly welcome this report in this time of crisis of European culture and identity, and I strongly support some of the proposals contained in the text, such as the designation of a European Year for Cultural Heritage and the creation of a single EU Portal with all sorts of information on European funding available for cultural heritage through European programmes.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. A comprehensive approach to European cultural heritage is needed. There are a number of tools and institutions responsible for promoting this heritage, so it is necessary to strengthen the cooperation and coordination of all these tools and institutions in order to be more effective in an area of great importance to Europe. This report is moving forward in this regard, so I have considered it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report argues that public policy should account for both economic aspect of culture in promoting growth and tourism. It argues that the monetisation of culture cannot be allowed to effect the fact that ultimately cultural heritage must retain its cultural values and involve the whole of society. I strongly support this approach, which is particularly relevant to Wales with our strong cultural identity. I believe that, beyond the economic potential of cultural heritage, we must focus on the opportunities offered by an integrated approach to addressing contemporary challenges through sensitive interpretation, encouraging the use of cultural heritage as an educational tool to deal with societal issues in order to combat hatred and division and bring the people of Europe closer together.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We do not intend to make room for the commercialization of cultural heritage and the defense of public-private partnerships.  We welcome some proposals such as the creation of a single EU portal dedicated to cultural heritage, bringing together information from all EU funding programmes geared towards cultural heritage, raising the ceiling of EUR 5 million for small-scale infrastructure investment projects, the creation of a policy framework for the historical and property environment , which contains a regulatory framework for archaeological and historical monuments and landscapes. We do not follow the meaning of the designation "Heritage of the European Union" attributed from a mere location of the heritage elements concerned, since, as we know, the "European" heritage is a debtor of many cultures and could also be claimed by others geographically outside the European continent. This designation is based on the development of the fallacy of the existence of a unique European identity and culture, in "European" values, entering a particularly sensitive area over which we have serious reservations.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Even if you want to expand cooperation in tourism, there are also some points that are not worth supporting. In 2018, the European Year of Cultural Heritage is to be launched and given sufficient budget to raise awareness of Europe's cultural heritage. In my opinion, it is a waste of resources and therefore to be rejected.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cultural heritage is without a doubt one of the greatest resources for European territory. However, a number of obstacles and inefficiencies damage the cultural sector and prevent its economic potential from being fully exploited. In order to overcome these difficulties, funding for the protection of artistic property must be adapted to the needs of maintenance and restoration, but above all it is essential that there is serious quality control with regard to these operations. Another important theme is the enhancement of the artistic heritage through a digitization that respects the past and that makes the culture as inclusive as possible. In order to meet these challenges, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on 'Towards an integrated approach to Europe's cultural heritage'. The report has little idea of what the European heritage is. Europe is a Europe in diversity. The common roots lie in the Roman-Christian-Jewish heritage. If the report then states that "the religious historical heritage, which includes architecture and music, regardless of the faith it has produced, must be preserved on the basis of its cultural value," it does not preserve that heritage, but destroys it. Today's Europe is inconceivable without the faith that produced it. In this respect, the report is not only nihilistic, but even hostile to European heritage. This is also reflected in the report's call for support for the 'cultural activities of migrant groups'. The authors want to reshape European culture in their own way. This has nothing to do with tradition, but rather with the wishful thinking of history-forgotten and history-blind EU parliamentarians. They want to abolish our culture. They just call it different.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report argues that any public policy in the field of cultural heritage should take into account two perspectives: that cultural heritage can be a significant source of jobs and revenues and that the main value of cultural heritage remains its cultural value. It also focuses on the urgent need to take into account the links between cultural heritage – and culture in general – and other policy areas. I strongly support this approach as I believe that, beyond the economic potential of cultural heritage, we must focus on highlighting opportunities offered by an integrated approach to address contemporary challenges through sensitive interpretation, encouraging the use of cultural heritage as an educational tool to deal with societal issues in order to combat hatred and division and bring the people of Europe closer together.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I come from Transylvania, a region that boasts a rich cultural heritage that fully reflects the multiculturalism specific to life here and which we have a duty to protect. This is just one of the reasons why I welcome my colleague Mircea Diaconu's approach in his report on European cultural heritage. I voted for the Report on an integrated approach to cultural heritage, which is comprehensive and comprehensive. I appreciate the fact that the report also highlights the importance of the SME sector in this area.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This report points to the particular importance and value of cultural heritage as a common good and resource. The EC was also asked to create a single EU portal on tangible and intangible cultural heritage, bringing together information from all EU programmes funding cultural heritage and focusing on three main aspects: a database of tangible and intangible resources, opportunities to finance cultural heritage, data on the state of European cultural heritage and data relevant to the preservation of that heritage. calls for support through targeted funding, analysis, research and pilot actions, as well as the consolidation of the newly introduced multi-source funding principle, which allows for the complementary use of different European funds in the same large-scale project. The issue of increasing the financial outlay for small infrastructure projects to the level of funding received by UNESCO projects has also been raised. Member States were also asked to consider the application of tax credits for restaurant work and to initiate dialogue with cultural industry representatives. All this is aimed at increasing the level of attention to cultural heritage, which is an important element of the European tradition, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I supported this initiative. I come from a country with a great cultural heritage whose foundations and values have affected the Western world and, of course, Europe. Our culture is the roots and history of every country, every people. Its great monuments, its unique cultural goods. We are obliged to preserve, protect and highlight this wealth. We must therefore support any action that safeguards our culture. After all, we only benefit as a Union from supporting and promote it.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The area of culture is not covered by Community policy. That's a good thing. While remaining the responsibility of state governments, various local governments, culture is better protected in its diversity and originality. It is good, however, that Parliament, the Committee on Culture, takes up both cultural heritage and the activity of contemporary artists quite regularly. Recently, at my request, we have analysed the situation in Syria and Iraq, where extremely valuable monuments have been destroyed. The act of aggression took place not by the way, not as a result of side-effects, of war, but because of the monuments themselves. This is an extraordinary act of vandalism. Today we have a report on european heritage in the first place. Good report, preceded by an interesting debate in committee. I would like to emphasise its value and thank the rapporteur.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report sets out the direction of Member States in the area of access to cultural heritage. It emphasises the value of cultural heritage as well as the shared responsibility of the Member States for its maintenance and protection. It seeks, within the limits of its powers, to set cultural heritage objectives and possible means to strengthen cooperation between Member States, in particular as regards the exchange of best practices as well as the avoidance of a negligent approach to the protection of cultural heritage. Given that the Slovak Republic also has gaps in the area of cultural heritage protection in some cases, as confirmed by recent examples from the Slovak environment, I gave my voice to the report.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We are opposed to parts of the report advocating the commercialisation of cultural heritage and the defence of public-private partnerships.  Some proposals such as the creation of a single EU portal dedicated to cultural heritage, bringing together information on all EU funding programmes geared towards cultural heritage, raising the ceiling of EUR 5 million for small-scale infrastructure investment projects, creating a policy framework for the historic environment—property heritage , which contains a regulatory framework for monuments and archaeological and historical landscapes, are recommendations that we follow.  We do not follow - and ask ourselves about - the meaning of the designation 'Heritage of the European Union', attributed from a mere location of the heritage elements concerned, since, as we know, the "European" heritage is a debtor of many cultures and could also be claimed by others geographically outside the European continent. Moreover, we believe that this designation is based on the development of the fallacy of the existence of a unique European identity and culture, based on "European" values, entering a particularly sensitive area: that of history, which can serve to feed processes of rewriting history, laundering it. We abstained.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the Diacon report on an integrated approach to cultural heritage for Europe. Cultural heritage is one of the cornerstones of European culture and represents our common legacy for future generations. It has great potential for the sustainable development of individuals, society and the economy, but this potential has not yet been properly exploited at EU level. While cultural heritage policies are primarily a national competence, there is also a clear European dimension, which is addressed in the context of a number of EU policies. I agree with the rapporteur, who says that policies in this area should take into account two aspects: that this can be an important source of jobs and income, for example through tourism, and that the greatest value of cultural heritage remains its cultural value. We need stronger links between local, regional, national and European cultural heritage plans, cooperation with the cultural and creative industries, networks of tourism operators, partnerships between private and public actors and NGOs. Above all, information on funding opportunities from EU programmes in areas related to cultural heritage – such as local and regional development, cultural cooperation, research, education, support for SMEs, civil society and tourism – needs to be collected in one place.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is with great satisfaction that we voted in favour and supported the adoption of the Boylan report. This report follows on from an ICE initiative, which has been signed by almost two million people, which is an important achievement for us, as the GUE/NGL Group. This is particularly important for the almost two million people who have reiterated that public water is a human right, as has already been established by the UN, and it is essential that it has now been established that the European Union must recognise this and that states must guarantee this right. This is an important result, which we hope will kick-start the referendum voted on by 27 million people in Italy at last, which is still waiting to be implemented.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we are pleased that the citizens' water initiative, backed by almost two million Europeans, has been launched. However, we cannot fail to show our deep embarrassment at the attitude of the EPP Group for having wanted to boycott the success of this initiative. On the other hand, we are not surprised by this attitude either, because their behavior shows the fear they have in the face of certain cases of alleged corruption that are coming out in certain town halls, some of them in my land, in Asturias. Perhaps there are too many interests that your public office has around and behind water management. Fortunately, today is not a good day for the honourable Members and it is good for those of us in favour of defending the common good. A first step has been taken today, but we won't stop here. Because we are committed to making institutions transparent, so that citizens have the guarantee and real democratic control over a common good essential for life, such as water.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, as one of the instigators and a strong supporter of the Citizens’ Initiative in the European Parliament over the last two terms, I am really pleased today to see that this Parliament has supported this European Citizens’ Initiative and has asked the Commission to come forward with a legislative proposal that would recognize universal access to, and the human right to, water. Furthermore, this resolution stresses that, by no means, should the Commission promote the privatisation of water, and the important words here are ‘by no means’. However, as a strong supporter of subsidiarity, I do not want to open the door and give the Commission the right to decide what is included and what is excluded from trade agreements in terms of public services. That right of decision is for Member States only, and in our efforts to achieve certain outcomes – namely to exclude water from trade agreements – we need to be careful. As I said, if we give the Commission the right to include we also give them the right to exclude and I do not want that. That decision is for Member States only.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: - Mr. President, when the European Commission declared the European Year of Citizens in 2013, it confirmed the democratic potential of the European Parliament, the only directly elected body of the European Union. This also recognises the importance of communication between citizens and institutions. A move away from the practice of merely lowering the decisions of institutions to the public has been announced and the placement of citizens at the very heart of the European Union's political agenda has been announced. Therefore, the aim was to further strengthen the awareness of european union citizens about community affiliation, rights, but also obligations, as well as the impact they must maintain on their daily lives. That's why citizens took the European Citizens' Initiative seriously. The European public used the opportunity to direct the Commission with one million of its signatures to propose laws within its competence, and today we decided on the first such democratic step forward. The human right to access drinking water was today kept in the European Parliament as the public's right to warn high politics about the low passions of those who would turn life's unique goods – water, fertile soil, hydrocarbons – into increasingly scaries. I have supported and will support such initiatives.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, this initiative is a very successful European citizens' initiative that has generated great public interest across member states with an impressive number of more than 1 600 000 signatures, and later continued the number of signatures and reached almost 1.9 million, or almost 2 million signatures. However, I abstained from voting on this initiative and regret that within the excellent initiative there was, I personally recognize, and also my European People's Party club, unnecessary and undue ideological guidelines. I am in favour of subsidiarity, I am in favour of Member States deciding on water as a resource that needs to remain a public good and I agree with that. In the report there are a number of details with which we disagree, since it is a delicate resource, which among other things is owned by few countries, and my country Croatia or our country Croatia ranks as much as third in the amount of water. Therefore, I am in the case for water as a human right, but in a way that Member States still have the right to decide.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Right2Water is the first citizens' initiative to have gathered almost two million signatures from European citizens. I am very pleased that he has also managed to overcome the legislative conditions imposed by the Treaty. What are people asking us? The people who voted for us want to be heard, it's normal to do that and want to and they demand the right to clean water. I therefore call on the European Commission to respect the wishes of the nearly two million people and to come up with a draft directive in which it recognises the human right to water and the full integration of universal access to water and sanitation into the Union's policies.  Also, let us not forget that the Member States also have very important obligations: they must require water suppliers to indicate the physico-chemical characteristics of water on water bills, to approve urban plans that have been drawn up according to the water resources in those places, and also to develop immediate actions to sanitize toxic substances in drinking water and to remove them.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, I consider the citizens' initiative Right to Water to be extremely important not because it is the first citizens' initiative of this type, but because it draws attention to water as a common good, but also to water as a human right. Member States' duty is to protect water sources from privatisation and pollution. Also make sure that water, drinking water, is accessible to all our citizens. Because I believe that this initiative has succeeded in covering these basic segments that I am also privately advocating in my personal and political life, I supported this report.  I also think it is important that it is recognised that particular attention should be paid to low-income populations, to populations living in rural areas and regions that are not developed. Water must not be allowed to become a source of enrichment or illegal profits for state or private service providers. Water pollution needs to be addressed urgently and citizens have insight into water quality. From an ecological point of view, quality water management becomes a priority in the coming decades, as water is important for economic development, energy stability and agricultural production and that there is no life without water.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. Today, the European Parliament voted on the follow-up to a citizens' initiative on the right to water. It is an important subject – the right to water is to be regarded as a human right. The EU and its Member States have a duty to ensure a good water supply for all citizens. Unfortunately, the report contained far-reaching left-wing ideological wordings calling for far-reaching market restrictions and a ban on profits from water-dealing activities. I therefore chose to support an alternative text from my group, the EPP.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that water is not a commercial good but a public good. The right to water and sanitation is a human right and yet only in the EU more than one million people do not have access to safe and clean drinking water and 2% of the population does not have sanitation services either. In the rest of the world, many millions of people suffer from this inhumane situation. The Commission's response to citizens is disappointing. The Commission does not respond to their demands, which call for new action and the submission of a legislative proposal for the implementation of the human right to water and sanitation as essential public services for all, as recognized by the United Nations. We Socialists defend the right of all people to water and sanitation, which must be incorporated into the Framework Directive; we are committed to a model of public ownership and control of management, based on water as an undisputed right and not as a commodity; and we oppose any attempt to privatize this public good, as well as supply cuts to citizens without financial resources.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Right2Water European Citizens' Initiative, the approval of which is a step forward in ensure that access to safe water and sanitation is not a source of speculation and business.  This initiative comes to Parliament thanks to the intensive and important work carried out by social movements across the continent and which includes something that we consider to be a fundamental right: access to water and sanitation. Water must always be public and, as a basic resource, be in the hands of States and public authorities. We cannot allow it to be marketed with something so fundamental to life, and that is why we voted for the European Commission to legislate against privatisations, following what Europe's social movements mark.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The passing of the report is a victory for the Right2Water campaigners. It calls on the EU Commission to enshrine the human right to water in legislation, to not promote privatisation of water services (including as part of Troika demands) and to ensure that water services are not included in the TTIP Agreement. There are many references in the text which make it very clear that the EU must stay out of Member States’ decisions on how they organise their water services and that the Commission should remain neutral on the issue which they haven't been to date.  Disappointingly but not surprisingly, Fine Gael and the Unionists were the only Irish MEPs to not vote in favour of this report. Having failed to remove the most progressive elements of the report and seemingly content to have EU interference in Ireland’s water services they showed their contempt for the Right2Water campaign. The report as a whole is a massive victory for the human right to water and a step in the right direction for Irish citizens.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The European Citizens' Initiative on the right to water was the first successful example of such a democratic instrument. Citizens can thereby ask the European Commission to propose legislation. However, as the previous proposal did not take sufficient account of the demands of the citizens' initiative, I support the resolution on the revision of the legislative proposals and the EU Water Framework Directive (WRR). Water supply is to be exempted from trade agreements.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The debate on the right to water was initiated following an ICE (European Citizens' Initiative) which received 1.6 million signatures. It comes at a time when the water market is being liberalized. However, it would be dangerous to use the pretext of a right to water to legitimise mass immigration to European countries. Measures to prevent the creation of a "water refugee" status should have been mentioned in this report. The proposal calls for everyone's access to water. It advocates the exclusion of water-related services from free trade agreements and the recognition of the responsibility of chemical and intensive agriculture for water pollution. For these reasons, I voted for this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe in a lot of the principles contained in this report. The right to water is a fundamental human right, and water should be a primary focus of foreign aid. I deplore the lack of access to clean, running water in so much of the world. The report does support the principle of subsidiarity in various areas. It is an own-initiative report and it covers matters beyond the scope of the Citizens’ Initiative. For example, it includes commentary on the issue of fracking. Such matters should not be for determination at European level. For those reasons I reluctantly abstained.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to step up the implementation of the Right2water Initiative for European citizens. The European Citizens' Initiative allows EU citizens who have collected one million signatures in at least a quarter of EU countries to ask the Commission to propose legislation on issues of concern to them. At the end of 2013, the eu citizens' first initiative, the Right to Water, which collected almost 1.9 million people, was the first eu citizens' initiative to raise the rights of the eu's citizens. the right of all residents to water and sanitation, as well as to prevent the liberalisation of water services. I support the calls for the Commission to update the EU Framework Water Directive and to propose other legislation that would allow the recognition of the right to water at an affordable price as one of fundamental human rights. It is also important to stress the duty of EU countries to ensure that, regardless of the supplier, all residents have access to safe drinking water and quality sanitation services.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Although a number of grievances against the Commission were suppressed during the vote, and although I fear that the Commission will soon impose 'water refugees' on us, I still support this European Citizens' Initiative on access to safe drinking water, which is so precious and essential to life. The fear of the citizens behind this initiative is legitimate: the increasing liberalisation of the water market. Fortunately, this text provides for the exclusion of water from free trade agreements.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Denouncing the European Commission's lack of ambition for the European Citizens' Initiative "Right2Water", the report of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety regrets the lack of new elements and formal political commitments despite the deep concerns of citizens. Indeed, it should be remembered that, unlike a simple commodity, water is a public good essential to life and human dignity. This is why the following key points are highlighted by the report: - water cuts are a violation of human rights; - water companies cannot be privatised; - water quality is a priority; - Member States and regional authorities should embark on a genuine social agreement to ensure the availability, stability and safe management of this resource; - the framework guidelines on water and those relating to drinking water must be implemented; - much greater financial resources are also needed in developing countries; - the Commission is called upon to make the renewal of ageing drinking water systems a priority of the investment plan for Europe. I supported that report.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to make a legislative proposal following the European Citizens' Initiative, which has gathered 1.6 million signatures to make water a human right to ensure a safe and potable water supply for all. This is the first time that an ICE has become a report (remember the one on the ban on animal experimentation, which has simply been abandoned...) and this should be welcomed. Nevertheless, while the Commission promotes, through austerity policy, the privatisation and liberalisation of public water services, this report echoes the principles of the ICE by calling for the exclusion of water-related services from free trade agreements. So I decided to vote for this text.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I found the Boylan report shareable. I believe that the Commission's follow-up to the citizens' initiative 'Water is a right' is unsatisfactory. It is necessary to reiterate and demand that water and sanitation services should not be subject to forced privatisation and imposed on Member States by mechanisms such as the troika or the European Semester; I also believe it is imperative that these goods and services are not included in trade agreements with third countries, as an example at TTIP, first of all we must protect our citizens and our territories. In view of the above, I wanted to support the text with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that water is not a commercial good but a public good. The right to water and sanitation is a human right and yet only in the EU more than one million people do not have access to safe and clean drinking water and 2% of the population does not have sanitation services either. In the rest of the world, many millions of people suffer from this inhumane situation. The Commission's response to citizens is disappointing. The Commission does not respond to their demands, which call for new action and the submission of a legislative proposal for the implementation of the human right to water and sanitation as essential public services for all, as recognized by the United Nations. We Socialists defend the right of all people to water and sanitation, which must be incorporated into the Framework Directive; we are committed to a model of public ownership and control of management, based on water as an undisputed right and not as a commodity; and we oppose any attempt to privatize this public good, as well as supply cuts to citizens without financial resources.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on the European Parliament's report on the follow-up of the European Citizens' Initiative (ECI) Right2Water. As the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe declared that access to water must be recognised as one of the fundamental human rights, as it is essential for life on earth and water is a resource that humanity must share, the European Parliament is of the opinion that the European Citizens' Initiative is an exceptional democratic mechanism that can help bring european and national social and civil society movements closer together and promote participatory democracy at EU level. The Commission is strongly urged to implement the ECI Regulation effectively and to further address all administrative obstacles faced by citizens in providing or supporting the ESAs. The Commission must take into account the main objective of the Right2Water ECI, to present legislative proposals and, where appropriate, to a revision of the Water Framework Directive, recognising the human right to water and the fact that water must be accessible to all. Parliament believes that failure by the Commission to do so will lose citizens' confidence in the European citizens' initiative as an instrument of participatory democracy, and it should therefore be in the Commission's particular interest to continue this initiative.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. - Despite criticism that the proposed report on the treatment of the European citizens' initiative 'Right to water' goes beyond the powers of the European Parliament to the EU Member States to decide on the privatisation of water resources and that most such issues should be left to the rules of the internal market, I supported the report. I believe that the right to water must remain universal and that the public interest must in any case prevail in the supply of water to private. The citizens' initiative 'Right to water' is the first initiative of its kind to be considered under the new rules. The nearly 1.9 million signatures collected is proof that the public is aware of the importance of conserving water resources, their accessibility and also that water resources must not become subject to full liberalisation. Already, the UN, in its resolution on human rights to water and sanity, points out that the human right to water and sanity means that everyone has the right to safe, physical and affordable and adequate and quality water. It is the EU's job to put this provision into practice in all respects. As regards ownership of or management of water resources, it is necessary to establish conditions which, whether publicly or private, will allow equal access for customers and adequate modernisation of the infrastructure.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ In April 2014, the EC issued an official response that only partially met the requirements of the initiative's initiators and signatories. The Commission agreed that water management should, as a rule, be the responsibility of the local authorities closest to citizens, that water is not a market product and that water and sanitation should be exempted from the Concessions Directive.  While positive, the Commission avoided committing to propose laws that would designate access to drinking water as a human right and gave no guarantee that the right to water and related services would be protected from further liberalisation and trade agreements such as TTIP. That is why I support this report and hope that the Commission's treatment of this citizens' initiative will not diminish the potential of this EU democracy tool.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The passing of the report is a victory for the Right2Water campaigners. It calls on the EU Commission to enshrine the human right to water in legislation, to not promote privatisation of water services (including as part of Troika demands) and to ensure that water services are not included in the TTIP agreement.  Crucially, as rapporteur, I ensured that there are many references in the text which make it very clear that the EU must stay out of Member States’ decision on how they organise their water services and that the Commission should remain neutral on the issue which they have not been to date.  Disappointingly but not surprisingly, Fine Gael and the Unionists were the only Irish MEPs to not vote in favour of this report. Having failed to remove the most progressive elements of the report and seemingly content to have EU interference in Ireland’s water services they showed their contempt for the Right2Water campaign. Whilst I tried to remove some ambiguous wording in Para92 Fine Gael’s group blocked the vote on the removal. The report as a whole is a massive victory for the human right to water and a step in the right direction for Irish citizens.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this text because I believe that the European Citizens' Initiative is a single democratic instrument with important potential to help reduce the gap between European and national social and civil society movements and to promote participatory democracy at EU level. That is why I believe it is important to support this type of initiative, especially when they are concerned with such an important subject, such as the right of access to water resources.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Citizens' Initiative promoted by the Right2Water campaign has reached 1.9 million signatures, the first ICE to reach this important threshold of accessions, a sign of how strong the European people feel about public and common ownership of water and the right of everyone to have access to it. Without water there is no life and the possibility of access to water resources – together with the hygienic and sanitary quality and the adequate consistency of the same – is one of the most important and delicate issues not only in the history of humanity but also in the most recent events.  The defence of public water must be an opportunity to relaunch – including culturally – the vision of human life and dignity as intangible, overcoming the neoliberal vision that treats man and his activities as any commodity. Effective follow-up to the ECI of the Right2Water campaign is a duty to the citizens, whose will has been clearly and unequivocally expressed, and it is necessary to prevent a dangerous and serious impact-making drift such as the privatisation of Europe's water services and resources. At the heart of the EU's partnerships must be the defence of access to the commons and the human right to water, today more than ever a universal common good.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The European citizens' initiative "Right2Water" has received the support of almost 1.9 million Europeans. This instrument in the Lisbon Treaty has been used to reduce the influence of European technocrats who are responsible for the privatisation of the water sector because of the austerity measures they impose on the Member States. This increases inequalities in access to safe drinking water. The motion for a resolution put to the vote of Parliament supports these European citizens, reminding the Commission to do what is necessary. In addition, the proposal stresses that water is not a product like any other and therefore cannot be integrated into free trade agreements with the United States. That is why I voted for this motion for a resolution.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Currently, 748 million people do not have sustainable access to safe drinking water, and a third of the world's population does not have access to basic sanitation services. This is regrettable and illustrates the polarity between regions. Drinking water must be made available to all European citizens. Water and its processing must be a priority for the EU. I voted in favour of the Report entitled Monitoring the European Citizens' Initiative 'Right2Water' because access to water must be a fundamental human right, and the institutions of the European Union and the Member States must take all necessary measures to ensure that all citizens have access to water and sanitation services.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. The report rightly complains that the Commission's follow-up to the ECI 'Water is a right' is unsatisfactory, since it is limited to a communication that goes no further than reiterating existing commitments. Let's add: that ICE is a lark mirror we have always supported, easy prophets. On the substance, in order to give a real follow-up to the ECI, the report expects, among other things, that water and sanitation will not be subject to forced privatisations imposed on Member States by troika or European Semester, nor will they be included in trade agreements with third countries (such as TTIP) and in the Services Directive. In this respect, there is also evidence that the privatisation of basic services implemented in the 1990s in developing countries has, among other things, hindered the achievement of the Millennium Development Goals in the field of water and health services (recital N). This is essentially the mortary US-IMF (government) method, now applied in the eurozone and, massively, in Greece, of which the alternative resolution of the PPE and ECR (em. 1) is a supporter, beyond the sweetened formulae of façade.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that water is not a commercial good but a public good. The right to water and sanitation is a human right and yet only in the EU more than one million people do not have access to safe and clean drinking water and 2% of the population does not have sanitation services either. In the rest of the world, many millions of people suffer from this inhumane situation. The Commission's response to citizens is disappointing. The Commission does not respond to their demands, which call for new action and the submission of a legislative proposal for the implementation of the human right to water and sanitation as essential public services for all, as recognized by the United Nations. We Socialists defend the right of all people to water and sanitation, which must be incorporated into the Framework Directive; we are committed to a model of public ownership and control of management, based on water as an undisputed right and not as a commodity; and we oppose any attempt to privatize this public good, as well as supply cuts to citizens without financial resources.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the citizens' initiative "Water, a human right". Nearly two million European citizens have signed this petition calling for the recognition of access to water as a fundamental right. It is essential that water is not considered a mere commodity. Everyone, any social background, must have access to water. That is why I believe that water is a public good that must be managed by public authorities. At the same time, I welcome the millions of European citizens who have carried their message through this citizens' initiative.

name: Enrique Calvet Chambon (ALDE)
text: in writing. I enthusiastically agree to consider access to safe and quality water as a fundamental human right and, therefore, to remove the "water" product from levels of marketing and speculation. Secondly, because I have a lot of sympathy for the first ICE that comes to effective results.  It is true that it has achieved few support (compared to the European electoral census), but the first steps are always hard and opens a first door to this participation system. But one thing is ice (European Citizens' Initiative), with its clear and enforceable objective, and another the initiative of Parliament that has been voted on. The latter touches on other aspects that have nothing to do with ICE and presents, ideologically and conminatoryly, as consubstantiations to the right to water. For example, it seemed that it was mandatory and unppealable for water management and its various facets to be public, which merits much greater analysis. Some demands go against my convictions. An unnecessary chapter on the nature of an ICE was also introduced which is objectively wrong and dangerously transforms the concept and operability of the instrument, which will need to be refined. Therefore, I have decided to abstain.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the resolution on the 'Water is a right' initiative. Access to drinking water and sanitation is essential for life, and the proper management of water resources is a key role in ensuring sustainable water use. Improving the supply of drinking water and sanitation is an efficient way to pursue key objectives such as poverty eradication and to promote social equality, public health, food security and economic growth. Water is not an exchange product but an essential public good for human life and dignity, and therefore the privatisation of water companies under any procedure for coordinating the EU's economic strategy must be avoided. It is essential to support this European Citizens' Initiative (ECI), which has already received enormous support with almost two million signatories, as it is an excellent opportunity to enable the EU institutions to re-engage citizens in their political action, as well as to promote participatory democracy at EU level.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The passing of the report is a victory for the Right2Water campaigners. It calls on the EU Commission to enshrine the human right to water in legislation, to not promote privatisation of water services (including as part of Troika demands) and to ensure that water services are not included in the TTIP agreement. Crucially, I ensured that there are many references in the text making it very clear that the EU must stay out of Member States’ decisions on how they organise their water services, and that the Commission should remain neutral on the issue which they have not been to date.  Disappointingly but not surprisingly, Fine Gael and the Unionists were the only Irish MEPs to not vote in favour of this report. Having failed to remove the most progressive elements of the report and seemingly content to have EU interference in Ireland’s water services they showed their contempt for the Right2Water campaign. Whilst I tried to remove some ambiguous wording in Para92, Fine Gael’s group blocked the vote on the removal. The report as a whole is a massive victory for the human right to water and a step in the right direction for Irish citizens.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I support some of the worthy principles contained in this report. The right to water is a fundamental human right, and water should be a primary focus of foreign aid. I deplore the lack of access to clean, running water in so much of the world. The report does support the principle of subsidiarity in various areas. It is an own-initiative report and it covers matters beyond the scope of the Citizens’ Initiative. For example, it includes commentary on the issue of fracking. Such matters should not be for determination at European level. Accordingly, I abstained.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am strongly convinced that access to a basic water requirement must be a fundamental human right that is not questionable, implicitly and explicitly recognized by international law. I therefore voted in favour of this report, in the hope that it will respond positively to all the requests made by the signatories of the 'Right2Water' citizens' initiative, which has reached almost 1.9 million signatures.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: In writing. I abstained on the final vote of this report, because the rapporteur went far beyond what the Citizens' Initiative advocated.  I am of the opinion, when it comes to dealing with this issue, to respect the position of the citizens, and I do not support the fact that the rapporteur allows herself to interpret the text of the petition. The resolution does not, in fact, take up the spirit of the initiative at all.  However, I share the aim of this initiative, which is to make water a human right in its own right, and sincerely regret that, in this noble struggle, the rapporteur has taken the side of making it a national partisan issue. This is not the European spirit and I hope that in the future we will be able to listen to the citizens, and that their positions will no longer be diverted from their primary meaning.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this proposal because it raises the following points, which I believe are important, including the principle of ICE and all criticism of the Commission; The principle of a right to water; excluding water-related services from free trade agreements; The need to help developing countries access water; all reminders to subsidiarity, and there are many; recognition of the responsibility of chemical and intensive agriculture in water pollution.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It was very important to carry this text through Parliament, to affirm that water and sanitation are public goods we must safeguard from private profit seekers. I voted in favour of this text, steered by my Dublin colleague, Lynn Boylan, so that we can move towards rules that will prevent the commodification of water. We want to safeguard water provision from market rules and any obligations under international trade agreements, and stand opposed to their privatisation. These are amongst the most essential services all citizens require, so the production, distribution and treatment of water and sanitation must be excluded from international trade liberalisation. Parliament’s position criticises the European Commission’s inaction on foot of a European Citizens’ Initiative calling for EU legislation to ensure that all citizens have access to clean drinking water and sanitation. Back in December 2013, the Citizens’ initiative on the Right to Water was the first ever procedure of this kind to meet the requirement of at least one million EU citizens’ signatures from at least a quarter of the EU Member States in one year. The Commission’s official response has failed to meet the citizens’ demands or even to make any substantive commitments to secure universal access to water and sanitation.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We recognise the international human right to access water and sanitation as a basic human right, as confirmed by a resolution of the UN General Council We believe that the right to water must guarantee everyone adequate, safe, accessible and affordable water for domestic and personal use. We therefore urge the Commission to commit itself to the Sustainable Development Goals and the international process for the preparation of the 2015 Development Agenda, in order to ensure that future objectives move within the framework of respect for rights, including the right to water.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote against the report on the follow-up to the European Citizens' Initiative 'Right2Water'. The measure calls for the recognition and application of the right to water and sanitation, a permanent exclusion of water and sanitation from internal market rules and the full integration of universal access to water and sanitation into EU development policies. The GROUP of the European People's Party, which voted against the report in committee, considered the content of this report to be insufficient and not in line with its prerogatives.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on this own-initiative report by the committee, as I believe that it addresses in a partial and incomplete way the problems relating to the right to water and health services for European citizens. In fact, the specific requests made in the ECI were not given due attention, it was limited to reiterating existing commitments and no comprehensive conclusion was reached, which could reconcile the differing views on this issue. In addition, in the text of Mr De Clercq's report, i.e. in the text of the report by Mr De Clercq, Mr Boylan, president-in-Law of the Council. On the contrary, I believe that the interaction between the public and private sectors is an innovative solution that benefits the economy as a whole, as water companies and responsible public authorities can work together to improve water services. Another reason why I think it is appropriate to abstain is the fact that the amendments proposed in the alternative motion for a resolution by the PPE and ECR were not adopted. Despite this, I did not consider it appropriate to vote against it so as not to be misunderstood about the universality of access to water.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The human right to water and sanitation is essential to fully enjoy life and all other human rights. Everyone should be able to access water in quality and quantity conditions (as well as basic sanitation). I regret that more than one million in the EU do not have regular access to clean water, with an estimated 10 million citizens without access to sanitation.
