For all these reasons, the vote against this report was excluded. However, the right to water cannot mean that water services should be free of charge. Tariffs should cover the resource and operational costs of the service, but should also allow companies to invest in infrastructure, improving the service provided to citizens. Although water is a public good, the choice of how to manage water services is subject to the principle of subsidiarity and falls within the competence of national and local authorities, reflecting the diversity of European traditions and models. The inclination of the Report by a model which contradicts this view thus prevents my vote in favour, so I abstain from the final vote, after it was not possible, in the specialty, to purge the most collectivist points of the Report.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats has tabled an alternative resolution on the own-initiative report 'Follow-up to the European Citizens' Initiative on the right to water', which addressed the basic demands of the citizens' initiative, such as.B: 'Water is not a commodity but a human right', 'Water is a public good'. Therefore, access to water and basic sanitation must be guaranteed for all citizens. In addition, the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats has worked to ensure that local authorities can decide for themselves how they want to ensure water supply to their citizens. The report also went too far on many other points. In today's vote, we were able to remove from the text the preference for public-public partnership over the public-private partnership in the water supply. This gave me the opportunity not to vote against the resolution, but to abstain.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. I welcome the Eu ropean Citizenship Initiative for the Right to Water because it is a democratic instrument for the active participation of the European population. Mr Boylan's report highlights the importance of the primary good of water and its use, which must also be guaranteed to the most disadvantaged and vulnerable populations with regard to the supply of drinking water and the provision of sanitation. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the right to water is indisputable and undeniable in any way. The Community's objective is to improve transparency and ensure the quality and efficiency of water services by promoting better management of water services in such a way as to strengthen public health, food safety and economic growth standards. I believe that the administration of water services should remain the responsibility of the individual States, which retain the power to decide on the allocation and management of the water good on the basis of respect for the principle of subsidiarity, according to which the local authorities closest to the citizens are responsible for the provision of water services.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Right2Water European Citizens' Initiative, the approval of which is a step forward in ensure that access to safe water and sanitation is not a source of speculation and business.  This initiative comes to Parliament thanks to the intensive and important work carried out by social movements across the continent and which includes something that we consider to be a fundamental right: access to water and sanitation. Water must always be public and, as a basic resource, be in the hands of States and public authorities. We cannot allow it to be marketed with something so fundamental to life, and that is why we voted for the European Commission to legislate against privatisations, following what Europe's social movements mark.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution first of all because I believe that the European Citizens' Initiative is an important democratic instrument for promoting participatory democracy at European level; it is also because, I regard access to water and sanitation as a human right and a fundamental value for all European citizens, which must be protected at all levels of European, local, national and European governance. The vast majority of European citizens believe that water is not a commodity, but a common good. It is right that Parliament, Europe's largest democratic institution, should listen to the voice of the citizens and give concrete answers on sensitive and sensitive issues that affect us all and the sustainability of our future.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the European Citizens’ Initiative which is a new mechanism for participatory democracy in the EU. Having a positive vote for the Right2Water was of paramount importance, particularly since this report recognises that water is not a commercial product. It states that water is a human right. I am in favour of excluding water and sanitation services from the internal market. I share the views highlighted in this report and I support the call for access to water to be treated as a basic human right.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that Member States and local and regional authorities must move towards a genuine social agreement on water in order to guarantee the availability, stability and safe management of the resource, in particular by adopting policies such as the establishment of solidarity funds on water and other social action mechanisms, in order to support people who cannot afford access to water supply and sanitation services , so as to meet the security of supply requirements and not to jeopardise the human right to water.  I believe that all Member States must introduce mechanisms for social action, such as those already in place in some countries of the Union, in order to ensure the supply of drinking water to citizens facing real difficulties.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report follows the European Citizens' Initiative Right2Water, in which European citizens called on the European Commission to take initiatives on the issue of water as a human right. This clearly ideological report ignores the different national modes of water management, production and distribution, since it proposes to take this sector out of the rules of the internal market and favours public initiatives over private ones. Together with my colleagues from the EPP and CRE group, I had tabled an alternative resolution to respond to citizens' call for access to safe drinking water and to allow public authorities to freely choose whether to manage, public and private, these water-related services. A series of targeted amendments had also been tabled to improve the text, including the need for the European Commission to propose a legislative framework on water reuse at European level, particularly in the agricultural sector. Having lost the vote on the alternative resolution but won a number of key amendments incorporating some of our demands, I decided to finally abstain in the vote of this report.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The Citizens' Initiative on "Water, a Human Right" affirms that access to water and sanitation services is a human right, and calls on the Commission to take measures to ensure the exercise of this right in practice. This European Citizens' Initiative (ICE) is the first to have gathered a sufficient number of signatures for the Commission to propose European legislation on the issue. This is a victory for the citizens of Europe, who have, thanks to this procedure, taken full advantage of this opportunity to participate very concretely in decision-making at European level. However, the European Commission's first response is insufficient. The executive must therefore, in accordance with its competences, submit a new legislative proposal following the demands of the initiative to guarantee access to water and sanitation services.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. Right2Water is the first European Citizens' Initiative (ICE). It has garnered the support of 1.6 million citizens. I think it is important to support these initiatives that enable European citizens to be the builders of the Europe of tomorrow. However, I abstained on the vote. Water is not a commercial good like any other, but for all that the public authorities must have a choice of how they wish to organize its management. In this sense, we proposed an alternative resolution which was unfortunately rejected. On the other hand, the BOYLAN report on the European citizens' initiative Right2Water pushes for a total and definitive exclusion of water services from the rules of the internal market, making a false presentation of responsibilities between public authorities and operator. It also makes biased use of the concept of "remunicipalisation" and defends an exclusive public management method at the expense of the free choice of public authorities.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 The N-VA believes that water is a public good and that the government should play a crucial role in water policy and management. Developing a long-term vision is crucial.  However, this does not mean that the private sector cannot play any role in this. In Flanders, too, water management and policy in the broad sense of the word is based on a mix between public and private players.  The N-VA also stresses that, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, Member States have the right to decide for themselves to use different water supply management systems. The resolution adopted by the European Parliament today is not in line with our position on several fundamental points. The N-VA delegation therefore voted against the resolution.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Parliament was speaking today on the ENVI Committee's follow-up to the European Citizens' Initiative "Right to Water". Although I strongly support the general philosophy of the report, I, as chair of the Public Services Intergroup, expressed a small divergence on the restriction of the freedom of choice of public authorities (particularly local and regional) in terms of how water is managed and its sanitation. Indeed, by exclusively promoting public-public partnerships, the report, in its first version, did not take into account the diversity and richness of the management methods in force in the Member States (direct, in house, entrusted to a public operator, or to a social and cooperative economy organisation, delegated to a private company - with real supervision and control of the public authorities). I have thereby supported an amendment reminding us that it is not for the European Union to impose a single way of management; in terms of implementing the principle of subsidiarity, the most extreme vigilance is required. I welcome the adoption of this report, which underlines the importance of ICE, the new tool of European democracy, an effective counter-power and a useful lever for political action.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The Citizens' Initiative is a scheme that allows one million citizens in at least a quarter of the Member States to ask the Commission to propose legislation in areas within its competence. The aim of the "water, one human right" initiative was to ensure that EU governments provided all citizens with safe drinking water and adequate sanitation. I share the objective of this citizens' initiative and I particularly support the call to make the right to water and sanitation as recognized by the United Nations a separate human right. I also support the inclusion of these rights in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. However, other provisions of this report have led me to abstain on the final vote. In particular, I consider that the provisions on the provision of drinking water are the responsibility of the Member States and not those of the EU. Other policy provisions on austerity and the troika seemed irrelevant to me. I have also had difficulties with certain provisions against trade agreements and in favour of an outright ban on all private water management initiatives.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. European countries are subject to the policies of forced liberalisation orchestrated by the European Commission. The supply of drinking water is not necessarily immune to these impulses of openness to competition from the networks. That is why the citizens' initiative is a strong act to affirm our opposition to the marketing, as a simple product, of water. On the other hand, drinking water is a challenge and an object of conflict in some poor countries, improving access to water is a mission that allows the development of these countries and a certain geopolitical stability. For these different reasons, I have decided to support this initiative.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against, because the Union needs even more decisive steps, immediate action and not half-measures. Unfortunately, this report belongs to the latter category. It is moving in the right direction, but it is not enough.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. This is an issue that we have followed closely in the Committee on Petitions, of which I am Vice-President. The objectives of the European citizens' initiative 'Right2Water' are set with regard to ensuring universal access to water and sanitation, un liberalised water service and management and, consequently, an increase in the EU's effort to achieve these objectives. The Commission's response contains some positive statements, such as that water is not a commercial product, that water management, in general, should be the responsibility of local authorities, for being closer to citizens, but the Commission did not commit much more because, perhaps, the report may present some controversial parts , in general those relating to water pricing (water banks and water share), trade agreements, the exclusion of water management from internal market rules and public-private cooperation.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The problem with the European Citizens' Initiative, at present, is the European Commission's lack of ambition to follow up successful initiatives, such as ICE Right 2 Water, which has garnered almost two million signatures. Ice needs to be improved so that it doesn't disappear. We have a serious problem: there is a big gap between what is happening in the European institutions and what is the perception of the EU among its citizens. Unfortunately, this motion does not meet the demands made by ice organisers that water and health services should be excluded from internal market rules, liberalisation and free trade agreements. However, this motion contains many positive elements, for example some of the amendments we have proposed, which emphasise that access to basic water needs must be a fundamental human right that is not questionable, which must be recognised by international law and through which governments and local communities are called on to commit themselves to allowing a minimum share of water for all. Finally, Parliament's final position, which called on the Commission to ensure the legally binding exclusion of water, sanitation and waste water services from the ongoing negotiations for TTIP, is certainly positive. I voted in favour.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The European Citizens' Initiative is an important instrument for participatory democracy that should be safeguarded, and it is gratifying that the Right2Water initiative was the first of its kind to meet the criteria for a citizens' initiative. I welcome the initiative's main objective of ensuring that access to water and sanitation is a human right. That is why I voted in favour of the alternative resolution, which focused in a balanced and constructive way on just that. Unfortunately, the main resolution chose to extend its focus to a number of areas which had very little to do with the main issue of the initiative and which expressed, to say the least, illiberal values, which I could not support. That is why I chose to abstain in the final vote.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I consider water to be a public good. The right to water and sanitation is a human right and yet only in the EU more than one million people do not have access to safe and clean drinking water and 2% of the population does not have sanitation services either. In the rest of the world, many millions of people suffer from this inhumane situation. The Commission's response to citizens is disappointing. The Commission does not respond to their demands, which call for new action and the submission of a legislative proposal for the implementation of the human right to water and sanitation as essential public services for all, as recognized by the United Nations. We Socialists defend the right of all people to water and sanitation, which must be incorporated into the Framework Directive.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report because it criticises the excessive liberalisation of the water market.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Since 2012, a European Citizens' Initiative has been available to the citizens of the Member States of the European Union. With this mechanism, the European Commission wants to increase public interest in European issues and improve participatory democracy in legislative processes in the European Union. The initiative in question is the first successful initiative of its kind with more than 1.6 million signatures. The European Commission has published its response to the initiative in question and has made it clear that water is not a commercial product and that the provision of water services is the responsibility of the local authorities closest to the citizens and, last but not least, that water and sanitation services should be excluded from the Concessions Directive. Despite the above, the European Commission has not been clear about the fundamental requirement for signatories to commit to creating legislation that would recognise the human right to water. The European Commission has also given no binding guarantees that it will exclude water and sanitation services from trade agreements such as TTIP and that it will prevent further liberalisation of water and sanitation services.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of the report. The Commission's follow-up to the ECI 'Water is a right' is unsatisfactory, having confined itself to a communication that does not go beyond reiterating existing commitments.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the follow-up to the European Citizens' Initiative 'Right2Water' because the Union needs even more decisive steps, it needs immediate action and not half-measures. Unfortunately, this report belongs to the latter category because it may be moving in the right direction, but it is not enough.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is highly disappointing that the response given by the Commission is insufficient, does not address in a proper manner the issues raised by the European Citizens Initiative organisers and does not present fresh ideas and measures that may help to achieve the goals. I therefore welcome the fact that the report addresses in detail the demands presented by the organisers of the ECI Right2Water. In particular, I agree on the idea that the European Commission should propose legislation implementing the human right to water and sanitation as recognised by the United Nations. Water is a basic human right and should be accessible and affordable to all. I believe that EU should remain neutral in relation to national decisions governing the ownership regime of water undertakings and thus by no means to promote their privatisation. We must push for a full integration of universal access to water and sanitation in the EU development policies.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In agreement with the reporter, I object to the points in the Commission's reply which do not provide assurances for the exclusion of water and sanitation services from trade agreements such as the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership and the fact that there is no guarantee to prevent further liberalisation of water and sanitation services. In my opinion, the uniqueness of the natural monopoly on water and water supply and its insufficiency in human life and health give rise to legitimate concerns about the growing trend of renationalisation of water services in Europe. Due to the natural monopoly on water supply, the vast majority of water suppliers are water utilities both in Europe and globally, which means that considerable expertise and experience can be relied on. We must continue to bear this practice in mind.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on the follow-up report on the European citizens' initiative 'Right2water', o'either because of the GUE group's appropriation of the citizen initiative and because the perspectives set out in the final report are irresponsible if it cannot be completed. In this regard, it should be recalled that competences remain part of the Member States, not the European Union.  While the initiative has been mismanagement, I can only welcome it, even more so when I have agreed on several of its intermediate points, especially those on the implementation of watershed hydrological plans that respect the DMA and its objectives of ensuring quality and ecological objectives. In this regard, I would like to draw the Commission's attention, once again, to the hydrological plan of the Ebro basin recently presented by the Spanish State, following its first devastating report, and to stress again that, in our view, it still does not meet the objectives of the DMA and its objectives of quality and guarantee of ecological flows.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that water is not a commercial good but a public good. The right to water and sanitation is a human right and yet only in the EU more than one million people do not have access to safe and clean drinking water and 2% of the population does not have sanitation services either. In the rest of the world, many millions of people suffer from this inhumane situation. The Commission's response to citizens is disappointing. The Commission does not respond to their demands, which call for new action and the submission of a legislative proposal for the implementation of the human right to water and sanitation as essential public services for all, as recognized by the United Nations. We Socialists defend the right of all people to water and sanitation, which must be incorporated into the Framework Directive; we are committed to a model of public ownership and control of management, based on water as an undisputed right and not as a commodity; and we oppose any attempt to privatize this public good, as well as supply cuts to citizens without financial resources.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 Water is not a commercial good but a public good; that is why I voted in favour of this report. The right to water and sanitation is a human right and yet only in the EU more than one million people do not have access to safe and clean drinking water and 2% of the population does not have sanitation services either. In the rest of the world, many millions of people suffer from this inhumane situation. The Commission's response to citizens is disappointing. The Commission does not respond to their demands, which call for new action and the submission of a legislative proposal for the implementation of the human right to water and sanitation as essential public services for all, as recognized by the United Nations. We Socialists defend the right of all people to water and sanitation, which must be incorporated into the Framework Directive; we are committed to a model of public ownership and control of management, based on water as an undisputed right and not as a commodity; and we oppose any attempt to privatize this public good, as well as supply cuts to citizens without economic resources.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I welcome the achievement of almost 2 million signatures for the citizenship initiative on the right to water. The instrument launched by the Treaty of Lisbon was designed precisely to give a tangible sign of closeness to active citizens, and we should therefore welcome the great work of mobilisation and the result achieved. What is more, there is also satisfaction with the substance of the proposal, which touches on public interests of the utmost importance to our communities. The protection of access to water is indeed a crucial issue for modern European society, so effective and far-sighted action by the Commission will be needed to meet these demands.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported and voted in favour of the EP resolution following the 'Right2Water' European Citizens' Initiative, because I believe that water is a human right and a public utility, and as such not subject to privatisation or market laws, but available to the needs of citizens at affordable prices. As demonstrated by the referendum held in Italy, citizens strenuously defend the nature of water as a public good. I therefore share its concern about water poverty, which affects almost 1 million EU citizens, and the call to avoid interruptions in water services and water supplies for those citizens in greatest difficulty. Austerity policies and an excessively mercantilistic worldview risk transforming water from a public good to a product of the market, violating European culture and the demands of our citizens. I also welcome the fact that this report is a direct expression of a civic initiative, which has collected almost 2 million signatures in the defence of water as an inalienable public good. I therefore support the rapporteur's call for the Commission to follow up the will of the citizens by presenting a legislative proposal which will intervene, within the limits of its competences, on the subject of public water.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. Water is and remains a human right. That is why I voted today in favour of the 'Report on the follow-up to the European Citizens' Initiative on the right to water'. Our drinking water must be protected in the long term from privatisation, sell-off and speculation – this is also the declared will of more than 1.6 million citizens in Europe.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Citizens' Initiative (ECI) is a new participatory democracy mechanism that has been allowing EU citizens to directly influence and shape the political agenda since 2012. The Citizens' Initiative 'Right to Water', known as 'Right2Water', legalised with nearly two million signatures from citizens from all EU countries, has become the first success of this 'mass petition'. In view of this fact, we could expect an appropriate response from the European Commission. Instead, we got a rather vague response, devoid of ambition. In particular, the Commission has not put forward any legislative proposal that would be crucial to the Right2Water initiative. In response, the European Parliament has put its own initiative to the report and encourages the Commission to fulfil its obligations. However, we are witnessing an attempt to weaken this report and to present an alternative settlement in which all the key elements voted in the ENVI Committee are missing. The European Citizens' Initiative aims to show citizens that the EU is willing to get involved in their affairs, which are important to them. We must remember that showing the unity of the European institutions on such obvious matters as universal access to water is important not only from the point of view of the legislative procedure, but also from a purely moral perspective.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I am campaigning for a fundamental right to water. In a motion for a resolution on the proposal of the left-wing groups, we have taken up essential basic demands of a European citizens' initiative on this subject (e.B. 'Water is not a commodity but a human right' and 'water is a public good'). Access to water and basic sanitation must be guaranteed for all citizens. At the same time, municipalities should be able to decide for themselves how to ensure the water supply.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU dedicates a quarter of its global humanitarian funding to water, hygiene and sanitation. This is laudable, but not enough. 750 million people in the world still do not have access to safe drinking water. This kills more children than AIDS, malaria and smallpox combined. It is a situation that 1.6 million engaged European citizens could not accept. That is why they launched their own initiative to ask the European Commission to do better, and I join their voices in doing so. I voted in favour of the Boylan report, because I want to join them in calling for efficient and decisive action to ensure that all people enjoy the right to water and sanitation, that water supply and management are not subject to internal market rules and that water services are excluded from liberalisation. Water should be the turf of life, not the turf of profit. I urge the Commission not to fail 1.6 million EU citizens who are counting on it to make this a reality.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. We all agree that the right to water is a fundamental human right and that much can still be done to improve access to this basic good. For example, water conduction losses need to be reduced, as well as improved drinking water supply and sanitation in developing countries. The report we voted on today therefore contains very positive points. However, it in turn contains very negative and unnecessary references on the role of private initiative in water management and supply. The public administration should be able to hire a private company for this task by setting a number of conditions to ensure affordable prices and supply to struggling families. The public company is not the only one that ensures compliance with these conditions. That is why, together with my colleagues in the liberal group, I abstained in the final vote.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I am glad to see that the ECI has proven a successful tool in encouraging interaction between citizens and EU policy-making, I was unable to support the report from the ENVI Committee. Of particular concern was the provision of water in relation to the internal market. The EU is supposed to ensure neutrality as regards national, regional and local choices for the provision of water services, and it is up to the Member States, and not the Commission to determine how these services should be run. As a British MEP, I am proud to say that the UK already has universal access to safe drinking water and sanitation; services which are predominately managed by private and well regulated companies. The ENVI report however emphasises the public provision of water services and neither allows for private enterprises or public-private partnerships, nor acknowledges the existing role they play in delivering high quality and affordable services across the EU and the developing world. It is for these reasons that I voted against.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. What is a European Citizens' Initiative (ECI)? It is a so-called participatory democracy mechanism, which allows at least one million citizens from at least seven Member States to ask the Commission to act in a specific area, which is of course treaty-compliant. The first ICE launched, called "One of us" was designed to prevent the European Union from funding activities resulting in the destruction of a human embryo. Despite having met all the criteria, she was scandalously not followed. Not politically correct enough, no doubt. The water initiative was given a response, but completely unsatisfactory: a communication from the Commission. That is to say, a kind of pat on the head to congratulate the kind petitioners and the assurance that the Commission does not really intend to engage on the crucial points demanded by the citizens: the exclusion of the water and sanitation sectors from the rules of the internal market (competition, subsidies) and international trade agreements. I agree with the report when it condemns the Commission's contempt for this procedure, and therefore towards the citizens, and recalls the necessary respect for the principle of subsidiarity or makes common sense proposals. In some respects, however, it goes too far. That's why I abstained.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the first European Citizens' Initiative because we firmly believe that access to water and sanitation must be universal and guaranteed for all people. Therefore, in order to prevent this essential resource for the development of life from falling into the hands of speculators, we support public management of this common good and its shield against privatization.

name: Γιώργος Γραμματικάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, in today's vote, strongly supports the first European citizens' initiative 'Right to Water'. The availability, accessibility and quality of water at affordable prices are integral components of the fundamental human right to water. It is therefore the responsibility of each Member State and of the Union to guarantee this right for every citizen.  Water is a public good and its privatisation is undoubtedly an issue of concern to millions of citizens in various countries including Greece. The European Parliament recognises these concerns and stresses that water ownership and management is the choice of the Member States and not something that can be imposed by the troika in the context of privatisation programmes.   Finally, I hope that water because of all its particular characteristics will be excluded from any EU trade agreement such as TTIP. I am sure that, otherwise, Parliament will not give its approval.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As the first ever successful ECI, I very much welcome the Right2Water initiative and the important role of the European Citizens’ Initiative in promoting participatory democracy in the EU and helping citizens engage in the European debate. The widespread public support for the initiative shows what an important issue the human right to water and sanitation is and, going forward, this must be properly reflected across all relevant EU policy areas. I am pleased to say that I voted in favour of making universal access to affordable safe water a human right and I asked the Commission to take the demands of citizens more seriously and provide a solution beyond the weak Communication it recently presented on this issue. We are sending a strong message to the Commission that we want the exclusion of water and sanitation from market rules. The Framework Directive for water is the right legal tool to ensure that water and sanitation are included in the EU legislation and in the Charter of Fundamental rights.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. On Tuesday 8 September, I abstained on the report on the European Citizens' Initiative (ECI) on the human right to water and sanitation. This is the first ever validated ICE, a tool that has been put in place to help European citizens take part in the European debate. In particular, the text calls on the European Commission to propose legislation that makes the right to water a human right and promotes the provision of water and sanitation as essential public services for all, i.e. they are not subject to the rules of the internal market and that water services are excluded from liberalisation.  While this report is undoubtedly a step forward in this area, it is nonetheless demagogic. Indeed, the text crystallizes an ideological vision, restricting the freedom of choice of public authorities in terms of management by exclusively promoting public-public partnerships. I also regret the total and definitive exclusion of water services from the rules of the internal market, which I consider contradictory or even absurd, because it thus opens the door to conflicts of interest and favouritism to the detriment of users.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. I spoke out in favour of the Boylan report because, as many citizens demand, we need to move forward to have access to water recognized as a fundamental right. We cannot be content with a simple consultation with a view to a possible revision of the legislation on the quality of drinking water. While respecting the diversity of public service management models currently under way in the Member States, Europe must guarantee this access to water in Europe, where 1 million Europeans do not have access to safe drinking water, as in the world. I also supported the exclusion of water and sanitation services from any trade agreement: water must be accessible and affordable to all, it is an imperative for the Social Democrats, whatever the Conservatives think. Finally, beyond the water issue alone, the success of the "Right2Water" citizen initiative shows how citizen mobilization for progressive values can influence the decision-making process; thanks to this tool, citizens can find another way to express their voice at the heart of European democracy, which deserves to be encouraged.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have abstained on the report on the European Citizens' Initiative Right2Water. First of all, I generally support the demands of the European Citizens’ Initiative, also the call for the right to water and sanitation should be guaranteed via its inclusion in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. However, I could not support the over-reaching demands of the resolution which included many off-topic political statements on austerity and Troika policies, against trade agreements as well as an outright ban of all private initiatives in water management.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that water is not a commercial good but a public good. The right to water and sanitation is a human right and yet only in the EU more than one million people do not have access to safe and clean drinking water and 2% of the population does not have sanitation services either. In the rest of the world, many millions of people suffer from this inhumane situation. The Commission's response to citizens is disappointing. The Commission does not respond to their demands, which call for new action and the submission of a legislative proposal for the implementation of the human right to water and sanitation as essential public services for all, as recognized by the United Nations. We Socialists defend the right of all people to water and sanitation, which must be incorporated into the Framework Directive; we are committed to a model of public ownership and control of management, based on water as an undisputed right and not as a commodity; and we oppose any attempt to privatize this public good, as well as supply cuts to citizens without financial resources.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the vote on this report and supported an alternative motion. The alternative motion for resolution that I supported respects the principle of providing Member States with the freedom to choose their water management systems. At the same time it also respectfully highlights the significance of the European Citizens’ Initiative, its role in the democratic process and supports its overall objectives. While I stand behind many fundamental aspects of the Boylan Right2Water Report I have chosen to abstain, supporting both the inclusion of water and sanitation services references in trade agreements such as TTIP and applying a progressive charge proportional to the amount of water used. Encouraging EU institutions and Member States to be obliged to ensure that all inhabitants enjoy the right to water and sanitation and also increase its efforts to achieve universal access to water and sanitation are ideals which I have always whole heartedly supported.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Access to water and sanitation is a right and must be recognised as such throughout all EU legislation. This is the first ever successful European Citizens’ Initiative and I very much welcome it. It sends a strong message to the Commission that we want the exclusion of water and sanitation from market rules. A framework directive for water is the right legal tool for ensuring that water and sanitation are covered by EU legislation and included in the Charter of Fundamental Rights.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. Right2Water is the first European citizens' initiative since the creation of this procedure. It has garnered the support of 1.6 million citizens and calls on the European Commission to propose legislation that excludes water supply and clean-up of internal market rules. I understand and welcome any major initiatives emanating from the company. However, while I share the sentiment that water is a human right, I do not believe that governments should be deprived of their right to organize water management.   That is why I supported my group's alternative resolution, which was unfortunately rejected. The proposal of rapporteur BOYLAN defends a total and definitive exclusion of water services from the rules of the internal market, which is totally unrealistic and paints a skewed picture of reality, particularly with regard to the sharing of responsibilities between public authorities and operators.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ This House often deals with important issues and few things can be more important than the right to access to water. This citizens’ initiative calls for water services to be fully excluded from internal market rules and it is vital that the Commission takes full note of today’s vote.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the first European Citizens' Initiative because we firmly believe that access to water and sanitation must be universal and guaranteed for all people. Therefore, in order to prevent this essential resource for the development of life from falling into the hands of speculators, we support public management of this common good and its shield against privatization.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution to monitor the European citizens' initiative Right2Water, because access to water is a fundamental human right for which there should be no exception, and I further oppose the privatisation of the water supply system. Water supply and sanitation services directly affect ecological and social assets and directly contribute to various segments of everyday life, such as agriculture and nutrition, and of course are a prerequisite for human well-being.  Water policy management should be based on active citizen participation and full transparency to ensure universal access to water and raising the level of health and hygiene standards at all levels. In this context, I want to mention the example of Istria, which, with its public water supply system, meets the needs of citizens and their right to water, and this has been achieved primarily thanks to the solidarity of citizens and the local and regional public sector.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. As part of the current austerity policy, there is an increasing liberalisation of the water market.  The debate on the right to water comes from an ICE (European Citizens' Initiative) which has received 1.6 million signatures. However, the right to water should not become an opportunity to accelerate immigration and create "water refugee" status. Although criticism of the Commission has been removed, this report proposes the exclusion of water from free trade agreements. It is also a certain concession that the EU has made to democracy, since this report has its origin in a public initiative. The congressman voted for it.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that water is not a commercial good but a public good. The right to water and sanitation is a human right and yet only in the EU more than one million people do not have access to safe and clean drinking water and 2% of the population does not have sanitation services either. In the rest of the world, many millions of people suffer from this inhumane situation. The Commission's response to citizens is disappointing. The Commission does not respond to their demands, which call for new action and the submission of a legislative proposal for the implementation of the human right to water and sanitation as essential public services for all, as recognized by the United Nations. We Socialists defend the right of all people to water and sanitation, which must be incorporated into the Framework Directive; we are committed to a model of public ownership and control of management, based on water as an undisputed right and not as a commodity; and we oppose any attempt to privatize this public good, as well as supply cuts to citizens without financial resources.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I abstained on my colleague Lynn Boylan's report, which followed the European Citizens' Initiative (ICE) on water. This ICE, which allows European citizens to bring a particular subject before the European institutions, was the first to reach this stage. While the subject is obviously of importance, namely the right to water, it was unfortunately hijacked by the rapporteur, who made it an unrealistic ideological text, overriding the legitimate concerns of the citizens who had carried this initiative.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Improving the supply of safe water and sanitation is an effective way to achieve goals to eradicate poverty, as well as the promotion of social equality, public health, food security and economic growth. Despite this, 748 million people lack access to safe drinking water, and one-third of the population does not have basic sanitation.  ICE Right2Water is the first to meet the minimum requirements: one million signatures and thirteen Member States. The demands of the organisers were: (1) that the EU institutions and Member States should be obliged to ensure that all inhabitants enjoy the right to water and sanitation; (2) that water and water resource management are not subject to 'internal market rules' and that water services are excluded from liberalization; 3) that the EU should increase its efforts to achieve universal access to water and sanitation. The Boylan report perfectly includes applicants' demands, while makes it clear that water has to be understood as an ecosocial asset rather than a mere element of production. That is why EH Bildu voted in favour of the report.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: in writing. – ‘Right to water’ is an initiative to provide every human with access to water and sanitation and it is the very first initiative which has met the requirements set out in the Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the Citizens’ Initiative. More than 1.9 million citizens supported the petition to bring it to the European Commission and finally to the Parliament.  According to the citizens’ opinion, internal market rules do not apply to water since it is not commodity, but a public good. Therefore it should be excluded from liberalisation. The United Nations organization recommends that a household should not spend more than 3% of its income to pay for water. I agree with the author's opinion that we should give high priority to water access and sanitation within the Official Development Assistance framework to support the sector in developing countries.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report is a fine sign that European citizens' initiatives can make a difference and must be taken seriously. He is clearly opposed to privatising the water supply and does not see water as a good for maximising profits. I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I very much welcome the Right2Water initiative and the important role of the European Citizens’ Initiative in promoting participatory democracy in the EU and helping citizens engage in the European debate. The widespread public support for the initiative shows what an important issue the human right to water and sanitation is and, going forward, this must be properly reflected across all relevant EU policy areas.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. I am in favour of direct democracy and therefore also support citizens' petitions. I also want everyone to have access to clean drinking water. However, for reasons of subsidiarity, I am opposed to this being organised at political level by the EU. So far, the water supply in our company has been properly met by the municipalities and cities – we can leave that in their hands. In France, the supply of drinking water has been largely privatised. Mostly with success. And if not, in France it is up to the French municipalities how to deal with it. That is why, together with my ALFA colleagues, I acted as follows during the vote: - We tried to keep the patronising of the EU Commission, EU interference in education and culture, and politically very left-wing positions such as state pricing out of the report. - When this was not possible, I rejected the report mainly on the grounds of subsidiarity.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 8 September 2015, we voted in plenary in Strasbourg on the report by my colleague from the faction and the ENVI Committee, Lynn Boylan, on the European citizens' initiative 'Right2Water'. The vote was very exciting this time. Until the last moment, it was not clear whether our report would be accepted by the plenary of the entire European Parliament, as both the People's party and conservative factions decided to put forward a completely different proposal. The European Citizens' Initiative is an important instrument of participatory democracy in the EU. Thanks to this instrument, one million EU citizens residing in at least one quarter of the Member States can call on the Commission to come forward with a proposal for legislation that citizens deem necessary for the implementation of the EU Treaties. Given the commission's current treatment of these citizens' initiatives, it was essential that at least the European Parliament expressed its support for EU citizens and set out sharply against the non-commission. Despite the nerve-wracking course of the vote, I can finally say that a good thing has been done. Mrs Boylan succeeded in pushing the report in almost its original version. That is, qualifying the right to clean drinking water as one of fundamental human rights and strongly rejecting any attempt to privatize free access to drinking water. I am very glad that I was able to support such a text.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today we approved the first report born as a result of a European citizens' initiative. "Water is a right" (Right2Water) is the first initiative to do so to have met the requirements set out in Regulation (EU) No 211/2011 and to have collected over 1.5 million signatures. The draft report calls, among other points, for the recognition and application of the right to water and sanitation. Although the differences between the Member States must be taken into account, we must be able to distinguish between water as a public good and the way in which the service is run. Our aim is, in fact, to ensure the most efficient service possible for our citizens. Unfortunately, we sometimes see inadequate public management, which leads to waste and disruption. On the contrary, public/private partnership, which keeps water as a public good, can ensure an efficient service without any increase in costs for citizens.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to make a legislative proposal following the European Citizens' Initiative which has gathered 1.6 million signatures to make water a human right to ensure a safe drinking water supply for all. While the Commission promotes, through austerity policy, the privatisation and liberalisation of public water services, this report echoes the principles of ice by calling for the exclusion of water-related services from free trade agreements. I voted for this text.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that water is not a commercial good but a public good. The right to water and sanitation is a human right and yet only in the EU more than one million people do not have access to safe and clean drinking water and 2% of the population does not have sanitation services either. In the rest of the world, many millions of people suffer from this inhumane situation. The Commission's response to citizens is disappointing. The Commission does not respond to their demands, which call for new action and the submission of a legislative proposal for the implementation of the human right to water and sanitation as essential public services for all, as recognized by the United Nations. We Socialists defend the right of all people to water and sanitation, which must be incorporated into the Framework Directive; we are committed to a model of public ownership and control of management, based on water as an undisputed right and not as a commodity; and we oppose any attempt to privatize this public good, as well as supply cuts to citizens without financial resources.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Right2Water European Citizens' Initiative, the approval of which is a step forward in ensure that access to safe water and sanitation is not a source of speculation and business.  This initiative comes to Parliament thanks to the intensive and important work carried out by social movements across the continent and which includes something that we consider to be a fundamental right: access to water and sanitation. Water must always be public and, as a basic resource, be in the hands of States and public authorities. We cannot allow it to be marketed with something so fundamental to life, and that is why we voted for the European Commission to legislate against privatisations, following what Europe's social movements mark.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. It goes without saying that everyone should have access to clean drinking water. It is therefore important that the state retains control over the supply of drinking water. However, this does not mean that the state must be the owner of the water suppliers. There is no objection to the supply of water being provided by private individuals, provided that the state reserves the right to regulate. I am also opposed to EU interference for reasons of subsidiarity. In France, the supply of drinking water has been largely privatised. Mostly with success. And if not, in France it is up to the French municipalities how to deal with it.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The privatisation of water sources must not be allowed, conditions must not be created where people lack water. The document will help to leave water usable for all and will also help to solve water problems in certain areas of the EU. I'm in for.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the initiative and agree that the public sector must be the guarantor of the provision of the population. Water is an important strategic raw material with a profound impact on the life, health, but also safety of the population. The governments of the Member States should guarantee the constitutional right to water and access to it. The Commission's task is to prepare the allocation of access to water and sanitation from international agreements on network industries.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report under discussion on the follow-up to the European Citizens' Initiative 'Right2Water' for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 7/9/2015 and because, true to my commitments, I continue to support the movement's fight and the citizens' European initiative on the right to water and I call on the Commission, on the one hand, to exclude water services from the ongoing negotiations on TTIP and TISA and, on the other hand, to stop promoting the privatisation of water companies, especially in countries that are in a memorandum as is the case with EYATH in Thessaloniki.  Water is a public good and access to water and sanitation is an inalienable right of every human being, as UN General Assembly Resolution 64/292 also points out.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this follow-up to the European Citizens' Initiative. This approach to ensuring a safe drinking water supply for all by creating a "right to water" is an excellent thing in an increasingly liberal sector that creates inequalities.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report. Privatisation of basic utilities in sub-Saharan Africa in the 1990s has hampered the achievement of Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) on both water and sanitation, as the focus of investors on cost recovery has, among other things, intensified inequalities in the provision of such services, at the expense of low-income households; whereas in light of the failure of water privatisation, the transfer of water services from private companies to local authorities is a growing trend in the water sector all around the world.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In favour of the resolution following the European Citizens' Initiative "water is a right". This text calls on the Commission to present legislative proposals establishing the right to water and to combat the privatisation of water services. The aim of the report is to ensure that the EU intensifies its efforts to ensure universal access to drinking water and sanitation, and to activate effective legislative instruments that make the human right to water a reality, as a vital and necessary asset for human dignity.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour and I am pleased that finally a European institution recognises that the right to water is a fundamental right. But this report, in addition to recognising the human right to water and sanitation, calls on the Commission to discourage water-ownership and hydraulic fracturing (shale gas exploration) practices and recognises that water and sanitation services are services of general interest, that water is a common good and therefore should be made available at affordable prices that respect citizens' rights to a minimum of water quality. It also includes several recommendations to the European Commission for water and sanitation services to be excluded from any international agreements, and in the case of the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) and the Agreement on Trade and Services (TISA) the imperative to establish a legally binding exclusion clause on these services. There is still much to do until this is indeed a right, but this first institutional step, following the first step taken by the citizens who have signed up to the European Citizens' Initiative, is a clear sign of the path that should be followed by the other institutions.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The defence of the right to water and sanitation has become the first European Citizens' Initiative to be processed. It is an essential issue, and from the European Parliament we need to follow up clearly to ensure that the initiative moves forward and its content meets the expectations set by the promoters. The report on this subject which we voted on, and which I supported, shows that the Commission needs to give an adequate response to this proposal and take steps to ensure this right, both in Europe and in third countries.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. If the Lisbon Treaty has given rise to an innovative democratic mechanism, it is the European Citizens' Initiative (ECI). Unfortunately, it turns out that these are all too rarely taken seriously by the European Commission. With 1.6 million signatories, the "Water and Sanitation are a Human Right" initiative was the first to meet all registration criteria, but the Commission provided the petitioners with a very minimalist official response. Faced with this anti-democratic reflex of the Brussels executive, the European Parliament has been planning a resolution to explore the steps to be given to the initiative.  It is reassuring to note that, both in substance and form, the Boylan report encourages petitioners in their approach, pointing out in particular that ICEs are an effective means of promoting participatory democracy at EU level. Better yet, it reaffirms that water is not a commodity but a common good, whose privatization cannot be ordered, and certainly not by the Troika. Finally, it calls for the exclusion of water-related services from all trade agreements (including TTIP) and other directives on the liberalisation of services. I'm voting for.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. As I am against the privatisation of water supply in the EU, support cost recovery and oppose any profit maximisation, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the EPP alternative resolution which acknowledges the importance of the European Citizen’s Initiative and the role it plays in the democratic process, recognising the right to affordable water, support for access to water for vulnerable groups and the need for investment in water services, while respecting the subsidiarity principle providing Member States with the freedom to choose their water management systems. I abstained on the Boylan report on Right2Water, while supporting many elements of the report, including applying a progressive charge proportional to the amount of water used (paragraph 92). I support keeping references to TTIP in the text even though the Commission has pointed out that no trade agreement to date has restricted Member States from regulating water services as they choose, and TTIP will be no different.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The "Right2Water" initiative is the first European Citizens' Initiative (ICE) to meet the conditions for the Citizens' Initiative and to be presented to Parliament after receiving the support of nearly 1.9 million citizens. The Commission's official response acknowledges that "water is not a commercial good" without proposing a legislative act recognizing the human right to water, which questions the very credibility of this mechanism. The report therefore calls on the Commission to provide more guarantees on the exclusion of water and sanitation services from trade agreements such as the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership. The report also calls for preventing further liberalisation of water and sanitation services, while highlighting the Commission's double play, which is so-calledly neutral and participates in the implementation of water privatisation programmes within the troika. I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. As part of the current austerity policy, there is an increasing liberalisation of the water market.  The debate on the right to water comes from an ICE (European Citizens' Initiative) which has received 1.6 million signatures. However, the right to water must not become an opportunity to speed up immigration and create "water refugee" status. Although criticism of the Commission has been removed, this report proposes the exclusion of water from free trade agreements. I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Citizens' Initiative has been available since 1 April 2012 as a new mechanism for participatory democracy. The European Commission has stated that it would like citizens to take a more active role in the European political process, and this unique instrument is designed to enable EU citizens to directly influence and shape the European political agenda. Under the rules on the European Citizens' Initiative, it needs at least one million signatures in at least seven Member States in order to be submitted. The European Citizens' Initiative "Water and sanitation are a human right! Water is not a commercial good, but a public good!', also known as 'Right2Water', collected more than 1.6 million verified signatures at the time of its presentation, which have now been joined by almost 300 000. It has managed to collect signatures from all Member States and has exceeded the minimum required in 13 Member States, and has thus become the first successful European citizens' initiative.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Access to water is a human right. In view of the scarcity of water resources, the problem of access to water will increasingly arise and will undeniably require a responsible response on the part of the policy. I am pleased that this issue has been debated in the European Parliament following the citizens' initiative 'Right2Water'. Citizens have sent a clear message that water policies must be a top priority in Europe. This issue will therefore undoubtedly remain on the European agenda and will have to be part of a broader and more comprehensive approach to optimal and responsible management of our natural resources in general.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Access to water is essential to life on earth and must be recognised as a fundamental human right to be shared by humankind. That is why, I voted today in favour of a report on the European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI) on the Human Right to Water and Sanitation. This is the first-ever successful ECI, a tool that was launched to help European citizens engage in European debate. My vote supports the demands of 2 million European citizens, that Water should never be treated as a commodity, but as a common good. Access to water and sanitation should be recognised as a human right across all relevant EU.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE)
text: Writing. I abstained today, contrary to my usual clear decisions. In principle, I support the citizens' initiative's concerns for a 'right to water' and would therefore agree. However, the renationalisations called for and a ban on private-public partnerships in this area are things that go too far for me. I was therefore unable to agree. The logical consequence of this is my abstention today.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The ECI has been in existence since 1 April 2012 as a new mechanism for participatory democracy. Such an initiative shall require at least one million signatures from at least seven Member States.  The European Citizens' Initiative Right2Water contained more than 1.6 million verified signatures at the time of submission and has since gained more than 300 000 new signatures. It managed to obtain signatures from all Member States (13 of which reached the quota) making it the first successful European citizens' initiative. Its central objectives are: • the EU institutions and the Member States are obliged to ensure that the entire population enjoys the right to water and sanitation; • water supply and water resource management should not be subject to internal market rules and water services should be excluded from liberalisation; • the EU will step up its efforts to achieve universal access to water and sanitation. Jean-Claude Juncker, the eventually winning Commission presidential candidate in the European elections in May 2014, has publicly supported the Right2Water European Citizens' Initiative. In March 2014, the European Commission issued its official response to the initiative, stating: • Water is not a commodity; • the provision of water services is usually the responsibility of local authorities, as they are closest to citizens; • water and sanitation services should be excluded from the Concession Contracts Directive.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. Water has become a key issue for our society, with current supply still scarce in many parts of the world. This very social initiative, ICE Right Watcher, is concerned with the following points. First, the creation of a "right to water." While this principle risks creating a new aspiring migrant pump, in the case of the creation of a new refugee status, it is a vital issue for individuals and the community. The exclusion of water-related services from free trade agreements, which limits the privatization of this vital sector. The need to help developing countries with access to water. Recognition of the responsibility of chemical and intensive agriculture in water pollution. Despite the fact that the text does not include any of our amendments, it seems to us to be an interesting step forward for improving the standard of living of developing countries.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 First, I would like to point out that "Right2Water" was the first successful European citizens' initiative, a mechanism for participatory democracy in which citizens have a more active role in the European political process.  I support that access to safe drinking water and sanitation is inseparable from the right to life, health and human dignity and the need to benefit from an adequate standard of living. I cannot fail to highlight the fact that almost two million people from different Member States are concerned about water supply and sanitation services, the loss of public, real or potential ownership of water services, as these services are of general interest and have the task of ensuring that the whole population has high quality water at socially acceptable prices and to minimise the negative environmental impacts of waste water. This report has voted in favour, for agreeing mainly with the foregoing, and for advocating that Member States should ensure the supply of water and sanitation as essential public services for all.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to make a legislative proposal following the European Citizens' Initiative, which has gathered 1.6 million signatures to make water a human right to ensure a safe and potable water supply for all. While the Commission promotes, through austerity policy, the privatisation and liberalisation of public water services, this report echoes the principles of ice by calling for the exclusion of water-related services from free trade agreements. So I decided to vote for this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As the first ever successful ECI, I very much welcome the Right2Water initiative and the important role of the European Citizens’ Initiative in promoting participatory democracy in the EU and helping citizens engage in the European debate. The widespread public support for the initiative shows what an important issue the human right to water and sanitation is and, going forward, this must be properly reflected across all relevant EU policy areas. I am pleased to say that I voted in favour of making universal access to affordable safe water a human right. I asked the Commission to take the demands of citizens more seriously and provide a solution beyond the weak Communication it recently presented on this issue. We are sending a strong message to the Commission that we want the exclusion of water and sanitation from market rules. The Framework Directive for water is the right legal tool to ensure that water and sanitation are included in the EU legislation and in the Charter of Fundamental rights.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of certain measures in this follow-up text of the European Citizens' Water Initiative, including one which calls on Member States to support the promotion of education and awareness campaigns in order to preserve and save water resources. However, I abstained on the final vote because I consider this report to be unbalanced: it excludes, for example, any possibility of private water management. It advocates a ban in principle on any water cut, which would lead to legitimizing all abuses in a context where there is, however, a social water tariff and measures to support the most modest households towards access to water and energy. I regret that the alternative resolution of the European right, which more closely reconciled the principles of responsibility and solidarity, while taking into account the major role of water in industrial activities, has not been adopted.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I abstained on the final vote of the report on the European Citizens' Initiative, but Right2Water is the first European citizens' initiative since the creation of this procedure (Article 11, paragraph 4, of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union). It has garnered the support of 1.6 million citizens and stresses two important aspects: (1) calls on the European Commission to propose legislation that makes the right to water and sanitation a human right and (2) promotes the provision of water and sanitation as essential public services for all, i.e. they are not subject to the rules of the internal market and that water services are excluded from liberalisation. As a reminder, following a citizens' initiative, the European Commission has three months to follow up on the procedure, through a communication.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We strongly support this resolution which, in addition to reaffirming the concept dear to us of the right to water for all citizens, calls on the European Commission to take very seriously the moments in general raised through the instrument of the European Citizens' Initiative. Indeed, there is no doubt that if the Commission does not respond diligently and new measures to the moments raised by an ECI, it will only discourage the use of this important instrument of active participation of citizens in the European decision-making procession. Furthermore, specifically, we firmly believe that water must be understood as a right accessible to all and that it cannot be sub-established under normal market rules, nor be compromised by the clauses of any international treaty. Finally, we stress the importance of the EU refraining from any indication to Member States to privatise the provision of this type of service and that it supports through its development policies the universal right to water and hygiene.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report, which has as its main objectives to ensure that all citizens enjoy the right to water and sanitation and to make sure that water supply and water resources will not be subject to internal market rules.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report on promoting youth entrepreneurship through education and training, which is a very important issue in Ireland, considering our high youth unemployment levels – which have stagnated at about 20% in the South. Entrepreneurship is an important driver of economic growth and job creation. We need to move towards a situation where enterprise, especially at a community level, is encouraged, facilitated and adequately supported. Access to finance and the absence of social welfare and tax benefit supports are huge worries for many entrepreneurs. The focus of this report is on our young people, and they face similar obstacles. Our young people are at even more of a disadvantage and it is they who have been hardest hit as a result of the economic crisis. The Youth Employment Initiative has fallen far short of what is required to address this situation in Ireland and across Europe. This report presents an opportunity for us to ensure that our young people who have good and innovative ideas for new start-ups are supported and encouraged in the best way possible.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because I do not believe that water supply in the EU should be privatised. Furthermore, there are many positive aspects to the report, which I am happy to support.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The "Water, a Human Right" initiative is the first European Citizens' Initiative (ICE) to receive the support of nearly two million citizens and to be presented to the European Parliament.  I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls for an intensification of the European Union's commitment to a universal right for access to water and sanitation. The resolution strongly stresses the need to protect water and water management from liberalisation, as access to water tends to be considered a human right.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. The citizens' initiative is in itself sensible, but this specific resolution is too restrictive in terms of efficient and sustainable management of water resources and limits the freedom of public authorities to have private sector involvement.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. " Water is not a commodity, but a public good that is essential for human life and dignity. The Commission cannot ignore the right of citizens' initiative. It must take into account the main objective of the Right2Water initiative. It must submit legislative proposals as soon as possible and, where appropriate, a revision of the Water Framework Directive in order to recognise the human right to water. The human right to water and water must be accessible to all. Access to drinking water of sufficient quality is a fundamental human right to be guaranteed by national governments. In this context, it is important to ensure that water and sanitation services are provided at affordable prices. I believe that universal access to safe drinking water and sanitation services should be included in the scope of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.

name: Demetris Papadakis (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today in plenary I expressed my support for the European Citizens’ Initiative calling for access to water and sanitation to be considered as a fundamental right. The human right to water and sanitation, as recognised by the UN, is universal, and the European Union, as a global player, should increase its efforts to make it a reality beyond Europe. The EU legislation should require governments to ensure, and to provide all citizens with, sufficient and clean drinking water and sanitation.
