Governments are obliged to ensure – by adopting legislation, policies and programmes and ensuring that they are adequately resourced and monitored – that everybody gains access to these services within an acceptable timeframe. I want to call for the permanent exclusion of water, sanitation and waste water disposal from internal market rules. There should be no chance for profit-seeking over people’s most basic need. I also consider it imperative that water is completely excluded from trade markets, as, for example, in the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) agreement. The human right to water and sanitation should be placed at the centre of legislation, policies and regulations and it should be ensured that those who do not fully enjoy this human right have access to justice.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 While considering water and access to sanitation as a universal and inalienable human right, while recognising the importance of the will expressed by more than 1.6 million people through the first successful European Citizens Initiative, known as 'Water is a right (Right2Water)', I decided to vote against it because the amendment proposed by my group was not adopted.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the first successful European citizens' initiative entitled 'Right to Water' and agree that the human right to water and communal arrangements has become a very important issue for citizens. This also results in increasing transparency in the field of water. However, I do not share the rapporteur's views, particularly on the decision-making on the possible privatisation of water services at EU level. It is the principle of subsidiarity and it is not for the EEZ to decide, but to decide in a Member State, region or municipality, which is why I abstained.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to make a legislative proposal following the European Citizens' Initiative which has gathered 1.6 million signatures to make water a human right to ensure a safe drinking water supply for all. While the Commission promotes, through austerity policy, the privatisation and liberalisation of public water services, this report echoes the principles of ice by calling for the exclusion of water-related services from free trade agreements. So I decided to vote for this text.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am very glad that this ambitious report has been approved thanks to my vote, and in particular with the key contribution of the European Social Democrats. Of particular importance is the response to the first ever European citizens' initiative, known as Right2Water, supported by almost 2 million people from all EU countries. I fully agree with the main message of the citizens' initiative, which, despite opposition pressures, has succeeded in pushing into the final resolution, namely that water is a public good, not a commodity, and that people have the right to water and the necessary sanitation. In its resolution today, Parliament asks the Commission to put in place the necessary measures to address the situation of around 1 million people and 2% of the EU population who do not have access to drinking water or to meet basic hygiene needs. I believe that water and sanitary measures should be outside market rules and should not be part of international trade agreements, including those currently in progress.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The draft report calls for the recognition and application of the right to water and sanitation; a permanent exclusion of water and sanitation from the rules of the internal market and the full integration of universal access to water and sanitation into the European Union's development policies, for example, through the promotion of public-public partnership. Together with my colleagues in the Italian delegation in the PPE, I have chosen to abstain from voting for or against this resolution, because I believe that the debate on the possible provision of water services by private individuals can and must be deepened further.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Since 1 April 2012, European citizens can directly call on the European Commission to act on a specific issue through the European Citizens' Initiative Mechanism. The first initiative to meet all the eligibility criteria was "Water and sanitation is a human right," and gathered more than 1.6 million signatures.   The European Parliament adopted the report stating that this initiative was being followed up. I preferred to abstain on this vote because I believe that this text was too ideological.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The "Right2Water" initiative was the first European citizens' initiative to meet the requirements set out in Regulation (EU) No 211/2011, having collected around 1.9 million signatures. The European Commission presented its official reply on 17 March 2014, proposing in particular: to strengthen the implementation of water quality legislation on the basis of the commitments presented in the 7th Environment Action Programme and the Water Plan; launch an EU-wide public consultation on the Drinking Water Directive with a view to improving access to quality water; stimulate innovative approaches to development assistance in this sector; promoting the sharing of good practice scans between Member States and advocating universal access to safe drinking water and sanitation as a priority area for future sustainable development goals. Despite the fact that this report contains some controversial aspects which do not properly reflect the priorities of the EPP, I cannot but welcome the mobilisation of European citizens around this initiative and underline the importance of recognising access to clean water and basic sanitation as a human right, which should remain at the heart of EU policies.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The Boylan Report is a striking example of the diversion for political purposes of a beautiful citizen's idea, in this case access to water. Indeed, in the wake of the first success of a European citizens' initiative: "water and sanitation are a human right!" ("Right2Water"), with more than 1.9 million signatures verified in thirteen Member States, the European Parliament legitimately wanted to support this tool put in place for European citizens to take part in the European debate. There is nothing to say about the form or support for the call for the right to water by its inclusion in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. On the other hand, many reservations about some of the proposals in the Boylan report explain my abstention in the final vote. Clearly, politically oriented passages on austerity policies or the outright ban on all private initiatives in the supply and management of water contrabing not only the values I defend but also the European Treaty which authorises delegations of public service missions. Take the case of Belgium, where intercommunal water management is plentiful, not often in the best interests of citizens. This is certainly not the example to follow!

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. I am pleased that the European Parliament has voted on the first ever European Citizens' Initiative entitled 'Water, a Human Right'. Thanks to this scheme, introduced by the Lisbon Treaty in 2007, it is possible to ask the European Commission to propose a law on a given subject. To be eligible, the initiative must be signed by at least one million citizens from more than seven different countries and cover a subject within the Union's competence and compatible with its values.    This initiative demonstrates the interest of citizens in European affairs, which is encouraging.  It aims to strengthen the commitments of the European institutions and Member States for access to safe drinking water for all in Europe but also to keep water and sanitation services outside the rules of the common market.  I share the report submitted to our vote on which the Commission only partially meets the expectations of the citizens who signed the initiative.  On the other hand, the report went further than the citizens' initiative, when it advocates free water for all and the strict refusal to privatation in this sector, which is why I abstained in this vote.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. Today's vote is encouraging: the European Parliament today relayed the voice of Europeans who are calling for the protection and guarantee of access to water and sanitation as fundamental rights recognised by the United Nations. The report calls for enshrining in legislation the fundamental right to water (as defined by the UN) and for the definitive exclusion of services in this sector from the rules of the internal market as well as from all ongoing trade negotiations (TTIP, AECG and TISA). A fundamental right and a service of general interest which, it should be remembered, were called into question this summer in Greece with the inclusion of this service in the list of areas for privatization under the rescue programme. The European Citizens' Initiative, by making up for the european Parliament's inability to make a legislative proposal, makes it possible to push the Commission and the Member States to take ambitious measures of general interest. Environmentalists strongly support this democratic tool. As a source of life, water is not a commodity, it is a human right: I sincerely hope that the European Commission will offer a favourable outcome to the rights of citizens and not to the interests of a few companies.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. The "Right2Water" initiative is the first European Citizens' Initiative (ICE) to meet the conditions and be presented to the European Parliament after receiving the support of nearly 1.9 million citizens.  There is no doubt that ice is a single democratic mechanism that can help foster participatory democracy at EU level, so it is important to act on it. That is why I have supported proposals to make water more affordable, accessible, non-discriminatory and qualitatively invested in the future, and also supporting improved efficiency and transparency.  Nevertheless, I abstained in the final vote because some parts of the text seemed to me to go too far, notably those on the exclusion of water-related services from the rules of the internal market and any trade agreement that the European Union is negotiating. I regret this, because many parts of the report were important.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This was the first European citizens' initiative to meet the requirements (1.9 million citizens). This is an example of participatory democracy which contributes decisively to bringing citizens closer to the European Parliament. The right to water is a fundamental human right (in availability, accessibility and acceptability of prices and quality). In the EU 28 we still find 1 million people without access to clean water and 2% of the population does not have sanitation. I am also concerned that Member States are losing public ownership of water services. Water can't help but be a public good.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that water is not a commercial good but a public good. The right to water and sanitation is a human right and yet only in the EU more than one million people do not have access to safe and clean drinking water and 2% of the population does not have sanitation services either. In the rest of the world, many millions of people suffer from this inhumane situation. The Commission's response to citizens is disappointing. The Commission does not respond to their demands, which call for new action and the submission of a legislative proposal for the implementation of the human right to water and sanitation as essential public services for all, as recognized by the United Nations. We Socialists defend the right of all people to water and sanitation, which must be incorporated into the Framework Directive; we are committed to a model of public ownership and control of management, based on water as an undisputed right and not as a commodity; and we oppose any attempt to privatize this public good, as well as supply cuts to citizens without financial resources.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. "Water, a human right" is the theme of a citizens' initiative that has just been voted on in the European Parliament to my great satisfaction. This initiative for which I had been an ambassador in my previous capacity as Secretary General of the Confederation of Christian Trade Unions of Belgium. At that time, we had collected close to two million signatures. Two million Europeans who are calling for water to be accessible to all, who are calling for water not to be a commodity.  Water is like air, we all need it to live. There is therefore no question of privatizing it. On the contrary, water must be accessible in quality and quantity for all. Prices for the first consumer tranches must be much lower than prices for large consumers.  In any case, the citizens' initiative that was supported yesterday by the European Parliament is something important. Important for humanity, but also important in terms of democratic credibility. It is now up to the European Commission to implement what is in this citizens' initiative.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I want to congratulate the European Parliament and those two million Europeans who have signed up following the citizens' initiative. A very important document has been adopted today. The first important text is the call for the Commission to come forward with legislative proposals and, if necessary, to revise the Water Framework Directive. I believe that only in this way can we properly guarantee people's right to water. Last but not least, the report stresses that water, sanitation and waste water disposal services would not be included in any trade agreements including the transatlantic trade and investment partnership agreement.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As part of the European citizens' initiative, which aims to increase participatory democracy, a citizens' initiative called "Right2Water" was organised on 17 February 2014, which I welcome, with a view to discussing the three main objectives: ensuring water and sanitation for all in the EU, global access to water and sanitation for all and liberalising water services. The Commission has also presented commitments to launch a public consultation on the Drinking Water Directive, strengthen the implementation of existing legislation in this area, improve transparency in the sector and stimulate innovative approaches to development aid in this area. This motion for a resolution sets important targets, in particular as to the full recognition of the right to water and sanitation and the full integration of universal access to water and sanitation into EU development policies, through the promotion of public-private partnerships. Without undermining the recognised merits of the initiative and the proposal, there are aspects that have not been taken into account by the rapporteur and others i disagree with regarding the liberalisation of the water sector and the observance and respect of the principle of subsidiarity as regards the management of water and sanitation systems at Member State level. As such, I have decided to abstain.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The protection of the right to water is a very important subject and for this reason it must be approached very carefully. The balance between economic needs must be carefully balanced in order to guarantee investment and provide an adequate service, and social needs. The GROUP of the European People's Party has tabled an alternative resolution and 16 amendments, seeking to improve a text which had numerous shortcomings and critical points and which, although well-intentioned, could lead to a deterioration in water services and an increase in their inefficiency. Unfortunately, the alternative resolution did not achieve a majority, so I decided to abstain on the original version.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because the report recognises that the Commission's follow-up to the European Citizens' Initiative 'Water is a right' is unsatisfactory, having confined itself to a communication that does not go beyond reiterating existing commitments.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the first European Citizens' Initiative because we firmly believe that access to water and sanitation must be universal and guaranteed for all people. Therefore, in order to prevent this essential resource for the development of life from falling into the hands of speculators, we support public management of this common good and its shield against privatization.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The first successful European citizens' initiative, signed by almost two million European citizens, concerns the right to water. This is a clear signal that citizens consider access to water to be a very serious issue and an area that cannot be subject to a purely commercial perspective. Today, more than one million Citizens of the European Union do not have access to clean drinking water and sanitation, and the situation outside the EU is even more alarming. The Commission should pay particular attention to the requirements of this citizens' initiative, so I voted in favour of this report.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Right2Water European Citizens' Initiative, the approval of which is a step forward in ensure that access to safe water and sanitation is not a source of speculation and business.  This initiative comes to Parliament thanks to the intensive and important work carried out by social movements across the continent and which includes something that we consider to be a fundamental right: access to water and sanitation. Water must always be public and, as a basic resource, be in the hands of States and public authorities. We cannot allow it to be marketed with something so fundamental to life, and that is why we voted for the European Commission to legislate against privatisations, following what Europe's social movements mark.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. After receiving the support of more than 1.9 million European citizens, the Right2Water citizens' initiative was the first to meet the requirements set out in Regulation (EU) No 211/2011 on citizens' initiatives. Especially given that there are 3.5 million people who die worldwide each year from waterborne diseases, that there are 748 million people who do not have sustainable access to clean water and that a third of the world's population does not have basic sanitation, this citizens' initiative is of particular importance. The report examining the Right2Water citizens' initiative reinforces the need for everyone to have access to clean water and basic sanitation and stresses, inter change, the importance of the European Commission maintaining the exclusion of water supply and sanitation services from the Concession Award Directive and calls on the Commission to discourage water ownership practices.  These are some of the reasons why I voted positively on this report. However, the fact that this report emphasises the explicit and organised demands of hundreds of thousands of European citizens was a fundamental element for me in my decision to vote.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as it calls for EU legislation, and it also calls on the Commission to work towards certain goals. I do not recognise the Commission as a legislature, so therefore I voted against.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As the first European Citizens’ Initiative to reach the target of more than 1 million signatures, the Right2Water initiative represents an important milestone in the history of not only the ECI but also the European project. It promoted participatory democracy in the EU and allowed its citizens to engage in European debate in a tangible and practical way.  The widespread public support for the initiative shows what an important issue the human right to water and sanitation is – and, looking ahead, this must be properly reflected across all relevant EU policy areas. I am pleased to say that I voted in favour of making access to affordable, universal and safe water a human right. We are sending a strong message to the Commission that we want the exclusion of water and sanitation from ‘market rules’ and that the Framework Directive for Water is the right legal tool to ensure that water and sanitation are covered by EU legislation and included in the Charter of Fundamental Rights.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution from the ENVI Committee, given that I support the idea of Right2Water and firmly believe that water supplies are a national asset and are particularly important in the case of the Slovak Republic, whose citizens I represent in the EU. The economic and ecological value of water will increase in the coming years, which is why it is important to ensure its supply to people, but also to protect its resources, not only from the point of view of protecting the natural environment, but also with regard to the economic structure of the providers of this commodity.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. The Right2Water Initiative is the first and most successful European citizens' initiative to set an excellent example of participatory democracy. Under the slogans "Water is a public good, not a commodity" and "Water and sanitation are a human right" the initiative has achieved 1.6 million verified signatures from all Member States, a major undertaking. In my view, it is necessary to recall the central objectives of the Initiative, which is that the EU institutions and the Member States are obliged to provide all residents with the right to water and sanitation.  Water supply and water resource management should not be subject to market rules, water services must be excluded from liberalisation and the EU needs to increase its efforts to achieve universal access to water. Unfortunately, despite the Initiative's request, the Commission gave no guarantees on how it would prevent further liberalisation of water and sanitation and the exclusion of water from trade agreements, which disappointed the organisers of the Initiative.   On the other hand, I would commend the beginning of the Commission's recognition and acceptance of public-private partnerships. Utilities in the Member States are known to have a natural monopoly in water distribution and there are a large number of technology experts in this field, enabling the development of public-private partnerships.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 With the adoption of the Treaty of Lisbon, we have given citizens the right to actively influence EU policy. The first European citizens' initiative entitled 'Right to water' asked the Commission to submit legislative proposals in the area of ownership and management of water services. It should be stressed that, in order for a citizens' initiative to be successful, at least one million signatories from at least a quarter of the Member States of the Union must sign up to it. It is therefore only regrettable that, on the basis of such an initiative, the Commission has not put forward a legislative proposal defining water as a human right. I supported the motion for a resolution because the resolution stresses that water production, distribution and purification and sanitation services must continue to be excluded from the scope of the Concessions Directive. Also because of the specific nature of water and sanitation services, such as the production, distribution and purification of water, it is essential that these services be excluded from all trade agreements. I would also like to stress in this citizens' initiative that I am glad that Slovakia has enshrine the protection of water as public wealth directly into the Constitutional Act.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Unfortunately, the right to water in European law is still not defined as a fundamental human right, and we are still witnessing worrying facts, such as the lack of access to clean water and sanitation in the EU, and the pressures of water privatisation across Europe are becoming more frequent. I certainly agree with the need for water that represents a public good to be accessible to all EU citizens. However, it is also essential that water and sanitation be excluded from any EU trade agreements currently being negotiated. I am thinking here, in particular, of the TTIP and TiSA trade agreements. I believe that the Right2Water civic initiative has been very successful, with almost 1.9 million signatures. In addition, it has managed to get the signatures of all Member States, which puts the Right2Water initiative for the first such successful initiative in the EU. However, this is only a first step in the right direction, and the EU needs to do more in this area, because it was precisely through this citizens' initiative that this citizens' initiative expressed the extremely high public interest in the permanent preservation of water as a public good and its protection in the European legal order. As I believe that free access to water is a basic right for every individual, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. 'Two million Europeans are calling on the European Commission, through the Right2Water Citizens' Initiative, to treat water as an audience rather than a private good. Parliament's Committee on the Environment adopted a resolution that embraces the citizens' initiative and calls on the Commission to oppose the privatisation of drinking water supplies.  Drinking water is not a regular commodity, but a human right. It is important for the European Parliament to make this crystal clear. The European Commission too often pushes through competition rules, trade treaties such as TTIP or in the demands for financial support to Greece towards privatisation. I am very pleased that we voted down the centre-right resolution and upheld the resolution of the Committee on the Environment. For the conservative resolution of Christian Democrats, Liberals and ECR removed criticism of plans to privatise water supplies under aid programmes to countries in financial need. It removed calls for water supplies to be excluded from competition rules for the internal market and the demand to explicitly exclude water supply from liberalisation rules in trade treaties such as TTIP, TISA and CETA. It also removed the call for water to be enacted as a human right in the European Water Directive and called for public-private cooperation.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. I am in favour of direct democracy and therefore also support citizens' petitions. I also want everyone to have access to clean drinking water. However, for reasons of subsidiarity, I am opposed to this being organised at political level by the EU. So far, the water supply in our company has been properly met by the municipalities and cities – we can leave that in their hands. In France, the supply of drinking water has been largely privatised. Mostly with success. And if not, in France it is up to the French municipalities how to deal with it. That is why, together with my ALFA colleagues, I acted as follows during the vote: - We tried to keep the patronising of the EU Commission, EU interference in education and culture, and politically very left-wing positions such as state pricing out of the report. - When this was not possible, I rejected the report mainly on the grounds of subsidiarity.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 There is no life without water and we must appreciate that we live in a region where there is relative enough of it. However, this may not be the case in the future and it is therefore necessary to proceed together in the rational and safe use of water resources. Every citizen's right of access to water must be linked to the fight against waste and degradation.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted abstention, although I welcome the first successful initiative since the European Citizens Initiative (ECI)" - "Right2Water". I share their view that access is guided by the human right. However, it is important to stress that the decision on water management concessions falls within the competence of the Member States.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As the first ever successful ECI, I very much welcome the Right2Water initiative and the important role of the European Citizens’ Initiative in promoting participatory democracy in the EU and helping citizens engage in the European debate. The widespread public support for the initiative shows what an important issue the human right to water and sanitation is and, going forward, this must be properly reflected across all relevant EU policy areas. I am pleased to say that I voted in favour of making universal access to affordable safe water a human right. I asked the Commission to take the demands of citizens more seriously and provide a solution beyond the weak Communication it recently presented on this issue. We are sending a strong message to the Commission that we want the exclusion of water and sanitation from market rules. The Framework Directive for Water is the right legal tool to ensure that water and sanitation are included in EU legislation and in the Charter of Fundamental rights.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal as I do not agree that the issue of water privatisation should be dealt with at EU level and not at Member State or lower territorial level.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The Union needs even more decisive steps, immediate action and not half-measures. Unfortunately, this report belongs to the latter category. It is moving in the right direction, but it is not enough.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 European citizens can request the Commission to submit draft legislation. They can do so in the framework of a so-called European citizens' initiative, but only on subjects where the Commission has the power to do so. The initiative requires one million signatures representing at least a quarter of the Member States of the Union. The Citizens' Initiative "Right2water" is the first example of the use of the new democratic instrument.  I agree with the rapporteur, who says that the ownership and provision of water services is clearly of concern to Europeans, and this interest cannot be ignored. I agree with the report in substance, which is why I supported my vote. The report invites the Commission to draw up a legislative proposal, together with, if necessary, a possible revision of the Water Framework Directive and the Drinking Water Directive, which would recognise universal access to water as a human right. The report underlines that Member States have a duty to ensure access to water for all, regardless of the service provider. Furthermore, Member States should ensure that service providers provide safe drinking water and better sanitation. I can also identify with the fact that the provision, distribution and management of water and sanitation services should continue to be excluded from the Concession Contracts Directive, even in its future review. Furthermore, it is important to note that water and sanitation services should be excluded from all trade agreements negotiated or to be negotiated by the Union.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Water is an essential part of human functioning not only biologically, but also economically. For these reasons, it must be regarded as a strategic resource for humanity, that is, one to which every person must be guaranteed an equal right of access.  The steps taken to achieve this objective are undoubtedly right and worthy of support. However, in achieving these objectives, states or public entities should not be regarded as merely credible and certain in ensuring access to this resource. The private sector should, directly or indirectly, e.g. through public-private partnerships, also be able to carry out its business tasks in correlation with those of the State.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Boylan report. The report includes the amendment tabled by Mr Affronte, Mr Pedicini and Mrs Evi, together with the rapporteur, Mr Boylan, which stresses that access to basic water needs must be a fundamental human right that is not implicitly and explicitly recognised by international law and calls on governments and local communities to work to provide a minimum share of water. The EP's report meets the petitioners' demands that EU legislation requires governments to sufficiently guarantee and provide all citizens with drinking water and sanitation. The report also states that water (water supply and management) must not be subject to the 'logic of the single market' and that water services are excluded from any form of liberalisation.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Clean water is one of the most basic factors that contribute to our way of living. Therefore it is not surprising that the European Citizen’s Initiative (ECI) Right2Water received over 1.6 million verified signatures, making it the first successful ECI. What is surprising, however, is the Commission’s response to the Right2Water ECI. Although the Commission made few important statements following the adoption of Right2Water, like recognizing that water is not a commercial product, the Commission failed to address the demands made by the signatories of the ECI and commit to legislation which would recognise the right to water as a human right. Acting this way, the Commission undermined not only the right to water, but the ECI mechanism as a whole. On this background, the current report addresses in more details the demands presented by the organizers of Right2Water. Mainly it calls on the Commission to propose legislation that will recognize the right to water and sanitation as a human right. I believe water must be made accessible and affordable to all. The current report backs this notion and brings back to the discussion on the Right2Water. My hope is that the Commission will not fail us the second time around.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to abstain on this report. The European citizens’ initiative Right2Water asks that all EU inhabitants enjoy the right to water and sanitation and that the EU should increase its effort to guarantee universal access to both. I support the call to include the right to water and sanitation in the Charter of Fundamental Rights and ensure a stricter enforcement of existing EU rules on water management and distribution. I am also in favour of the EIB investing more in the development of water infrastructures. However, the report as drafted also contained provisions I am not in favour of, especially the ban of all private initiatives in water management: I don't think such initiatives go against the right to water, on the contrary they would contribute to encouraging investment and innovation in this sector which in the end would be beneficial for all citizens.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. With the support of more than 1.8 million Europeans, the Right2Water European Citizens' Initiative (ICE) defends the idea that water is a common good and that access to safe drinking water is a fundamental human right. The aim of the Boylan initiative report is to reaffirm these citizens' demands, while the European Union still does not recognise that water is not a commodity like any other.  Against the will of privatization led by conservatives and neoliberals, European progressives mobilized. The report affirms the need to extract water and clean up market laws and future trade agreements. The report states that water management, as a service of general interest, is by nature public management (and can only be entrusted to the private sector temporarily, and by exception). As violations or restrictions on the human right to access water, the report also condemns unpaid water cuts and denounces austerity policies that degrade access to water for the poorest. I support this report because, after many years of fighting against the privatisation of public water services, it opposes their liberalisation and wants to put an end to the commodification of the commons in Europe.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ Right2Water is the first initiative of European citizens to meet all the formal requirements and is signed by a sufficient number of CITIZENS of the European Union (one million citizens from one quarter of the Member States).  I support the demand for the right to water as a fundamental human right, and I think it would be scandalous not to respect the will of the citizens of the European Union who, through this initiative, have clearly and unequivocally expressed their position on this issue.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. The Commission was invited to recognise the importance of this right as a public good and a fundamental value for all EU citizens. As poverty has increased in the EU since the economic and financial crisis, disconnects and interruptions in water supplies are an intolerable violation of human rights. MePs stress that Member States have a duty to provide water supplies to all, regardless of the operator. However, the operator must ensure that it provides safe drinking water and better communal regulation. As I have some concerns about the report, I abstained from the vote.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. I would have liked the final text to include the most important amendments tabled by the ENL Group: the implementation of all possible means to avoid the "water refugees" that are sure to occur. To date, the right to water already exists before the United Nations, so the transition to refugee status due to lack of water is only a matter of time. Nine amendments had been tabled in committee by FN MEPs: the public service of communities is more suitable for water, exclusion of water in free trade agreements being negotiated and subsequent, need for countries to ensure the potability of water for their own people, risks carried by the exploitation of shale gas on drinking water, need to avoid free food that is only apparent , responsibility for intensive agriculture in water pollution, the need to help developing countries to avoid "water refugees", to avoid water being a geopolitical weapon that harms civilian populations. The many votes per division have changed the original text too much. So I voted against the text.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Citizens' Right to Water Initiative is the first successful example of this democratic mechanism. The objective of this initiative is to ensure that the governments of the European Union provide all its citizens with adequate drinking water and sanitation and that these services are not subject to the rules of the common market. Access to water should, in my opinion, be a constitutional right guaranteed to all; therefore, water and sanitation services should be excluded from any trade agreements that the European Union is considering. Water is a cause of inequalities and social exclusion, it is a right closely linked to the right to the highest standard of physical and mental health, as well as the right to human life and dignity. For example, in Romania, at the end of 2013, 1.3% of urban settlements and 28.3% of rural settlements in Romania did not have water distribution networks. In these circumstances, I believe that viable and rapid solutions are needed to ensure this right for citizens, both Romanian and European, and I therefore voted in favour of the citizens' initiative 'Right to water'.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the first European Citizens' Initiative because we firmly believe that access to water and sanitation must be universal and guaranteed for all people. Therefore, in order to prevent this essential resource for the development of life from falling into the hands of speculators, we support public management of this common good and its shield against privatization.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which follows up on the measures of the European citizens' water initiative, which received massive support. This ensures that water is treated as a basic public service in the face of the desire to privatize some sectors.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on the Commission’s proposal concerning the European Citizens’ Initiative named ‘Right2Water’. I was personally in favour of the critical tone of the resolution, which underlined the Commission’s lack of clear commitment in 1) ensuring and guaranteeing the concept of water as a human right 2) excluding any type of privatisation of water management 3) confirming the principle that water management should by no means and any time lead to profit. I once again diverged from my group’s line on this particular vote, due to different views on exactly the points mentioned above. This decision was in relation to the responsibility I have towards the citizens that elected me in my constituency and gave me a clear mandate to fight for certain principles.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As the first ever successful European Citizens’ Initiative, I very much welcome the Right2Water initiative and the important role of the ECI in promoting participatory democracy in the EU and helping citizens engage in the European debate. The widespread public support for the initiative shows what an important issue the human right to water and sanitation is and, going forward, this must be properly reflected across all relevant EU policy areas. I am pleased to say that I voted in favour of making universal access to affordable safe water a human right. I asked the Commission to take the demands of citizens more seriously and provide a solution beyond the weak Communication it recently presented on this issue. By asserting that the issue of sanitary water is indissoluble from broader Human Rights, we are sending a strong message to the Commission that we want the exclusion of water and sanitation from market rules. The Framework Directive for water is the correct legal tool to ensure that water and sanitation are included in the EU legislation and in the Charter of Fundamental rights, an important step to establishing that access to sanitary water is a right, not a privilege.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of the report by my Irish colleague from the GUE/NGL, Lynn Boylan. The report criticises the Commission's response to the RIGHT to Water and Sanitation ICE, the first ICE to be adopted after collecting 1.8 million signatures in the EU. The European Commission had responded weakly, pledging only to comply with EU water legislation, improve citizens' information and establish a structured dialogue among stakeholders on transparency in the water sector. In particular, the report calls for recognition of the importance of the right to water and sanitation as well as as a public good and not as a commodity, opposes water cuts requiring Member States to immediately put an end to these situations, denies the Commission's alleged neutrality on water ownership, given the Troika's privatisation programmes, and calls for the exclusion of water from the rules of the internal market and any trade agreement, and not to promote in any way the privatisation of water-related services. It is an important report for future struggles for the defence of public services and the recognition of the commons.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We have always supported all those who have fought for the adoption of the UN resolution and who are fighting for it to be fulfilled - so that the right to clean water and sanitation is guaranteed to all, without exclusion, as an essential human right to the full enjoyment of life and all human rights. The European Citizens' Initiative "Water and Sanitation are a Human Right! Water is not a commercial good, but a public good!" which has collected more than 1.6 million signatures, has become the first initiative of its kind to be successful. The European Commission's expected response has raised the limitations of this mechanism supposedly designed to promote participatory democracy, as the Commission, in addition to not responding to the main aspirations of its applicants, has not changed EU policy. This report thus results in the effort and broad participation of the citizens of the various Member States who have been hit by the principles of ensuring the non-liberalisation of water and sanitation services, the exclusion of water services and the sanitation of trade agreements, such as the TTIP, of the non-privatisation of water services, rejecting the interests of transnational water services and the privatisation and commercialisation of this unique and irreplaceable resource.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. As I am opposed to the privatisation of water supply in the EU, to the fight against cost recovery and to reject any profit maximisation, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's resolution of 8 September 2015 on the follow-up to the European Citizens' Initiative on the right to water. I note that water is vital. Nobody can do without water. Everyone needs good and clean water. Nevertheless, water is not a human right. Otherwise, bread would also be a human right. And the roof over your head. If all this were a human right, then all this would have to be made available. And be paid. Every human being. To be clear, human rights do not stop at a border. Anyone who talks about a human right to water must also give water to every human being – into his hand, into his mouth. That's impossible. Human rights must be universal. This can only be done if they are defensive rights against interference – and not justifications for claims to provide things against the state or against other third parties. However, i found it difficult to reject it because it was a successful European citizens' initiative: more democracy and citizen participation in the EU. An outstanding and important undertaking in itself. Unfortunately, this citizens' initiative has been hijacked by the left-wing groups in the EU Parliament. In doing so, they have done democracy in the EU a disservice.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As the first ever successful ECI, I very much welcome the Right2Water initiative and the important role of the European Citizens’ Initiative in promoting participatory democracy in the EU and helping citizens engage in the European debate. The widespread public support for the initiative demonstrates the importance of this issue from a human rights perspective and this must be properly reflected across all relevant EU policy areas.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The European Citizens' Initiative is an important instrument for participatory democracy that should be safeguarded, and it is gratifying that the Right2Water initiative was the first of its kind to meet the criteria for a citizens' initiative. I welcome the initiative's main objective of ensuring that access to water and sanitation is a human right. That is why I voted in favour of the alternative resolution, which focused in a balanced and constructive way on just that. Unfortunately, the main resolution chose to extend its focus to a number of areas which had very little to do with the main issue of the initiative and which expressed, to say the least, illiberal values, which I could not support. That is why I chose to abstain in the final vote.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted for the report on the actions taken as a result of the European Citizens' Initiative (ECI) 'Right to Water' - Right2Water - although there are many statements, findings and proposals in it that I do not agree with. I voted for this report for two reasons. Firstly, the ECI is a very valuable instrument of participatory democracy, which can have a significant result in bringing EU citizens closer to the European institutions and increasing their confidence in legislative procedures. 1.9 million EU citizens have expressed their support for the Right2Water initiative, and the voice of these citizens is forcing us to respond concretely. The UN then recognises the right of each of its citizens to water and sanitation, and the EU must be at the forefront of this global movement. I find it paradoxical that in the EU of the 21st century, there are over one million citizens who do not have access to water and almost 10 million Europeans who do not have access to sanitation. I voted first of all on the alternative motion of the EPP and the ECR, and I am sorry that this much more balanced position than that of rapporteur Boylan was not successful in plenary.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Everyone has the right to life and life without drinking water is not possible. But we wouldn't have survived long without food – yet there's not much point in talking about the "right to eat." At least not until we name in one breath the conditions under which we can exercise this "right". Water and food and air are our needs. Renaming them human rights does not yet guarantee us that we will not die of thirst or hunger. These are universal human needs and their fulfilment is a matter of fundamental solidarity between peoples. If we start to forget this, this solidarity will gradually disappear. I regret that the European Citizens' Initiative Institute has degraded the Commission with its decisions for the opinion poll. This was particularly demonstrated by the One of Us initiative, which collected a record number of signatures. Nevertheless, the Commission has simply rejected its request to stop funding research in which human foetuses are slaughtered.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D)
text: in writing. This is an important vote, both in form and content. In form because, for the first time in its history, this Parliament is called upon to adopt a report which is the expression of a spontaneous initiative by the citizens of Europe; an idea that comes "from the bottom up" and that must find in Parliament listening and paying attention. In content, then, because for the first time in the European parliamentary term we are talking about water as a 'human right'. A right that is often violated, given that the numbers speak for themselves: in the world, today, at least 748 million people do not have sustainable access to drinking water; a lack that causes death and disease that could easily be eradicated.  As a human right, the management of water resources must remain public, because we cannot hand over to market logic the management of such an important primary asset, without forgetting, however, to monitor the efficiency of water management, which cannot afford waste or dysfunction. We will therefore continue to work to ensure that the right to water is truly a right for all, starting from a good basis such as this report, which I voted in favour of in the ENVI Committee and which I will vote in favour of again today.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the follow-up report given to the European Citizenship initiative "Right2Water", believing that water is essential for sustainable development, an effective means of achieving the fundamental objectives of eradicating poverty and promoting social equality, public health, food security and economic growth. The European citizens' initiative was an excellent opportunity to strengthen the human right to water and sanitation as fundamental assets to life, as well as to call for more adequate management of existing water resources, essential for the sustainable development of the planet.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We have always accompanied all those who have fought for the adoption of the UNITED NATIONS resolution and who strive to ensure that it is fulfilled - so that the right to clean water and sanitation is guaranteed to all, without exclusion, as an essential human right to the full enjoyment of life and all human rights. The European Citizens' Initiative "Water and Sanitation are a Human Right! Water is not a commercial good, but a public good!" which has collected more than 1.6 million signatures, has become the first initiative of its kind to be successful. The European Commission's expected response has laid bare the limitations of this mechanism supposedly designed to promote participatory democracy, as the Commission, in addition to not responding to the main aspirations of its applicants, has not changed EU policy. This report thus results in the effort and broad participation of the citizens of the various Member States who have been hit by the principles of ensuring the non-liberalisation of water and sanitation services, the exclusion of water services and the sanitation of trade agreements, such as the TTIP, of the non-privatisation of water services, rejecting the interests of transnational water services and the privatisation and commercialisation of this unique and irreplaceable resource.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this European Parliament resolution on the follow-up to the European Citizens' Initiative 'Water is a right' because it meets the demands of the almost 2 million signatories who want: that EU legislation requires national governments to guarantee and provide all citizens, sufficiently, with drinking water and sanitation; that drinking water supply and water management are not subject to the 'logic of the single market' and that water services are excluded from any form of liberalisation; the EU to step up its efforts to ensure universal access to drinking water and sanitation. However, I am critical of the lack of ambition of the European Commission's responses to the initiative, because I believe that we must respond positively to all the requests made by the 2 million signatories to the initiative. The special nature of water and sanitation makes it imperative to exclude water production, distribution and treatment from any trade agreement being negotiated.
