name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for debate on the Council's statement on the Council's presentation of its position on the draft general budget - fiscal year 2016 (2015/2735 (RSP)).

name: Pierre Gramegna
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I have the honour of presenting to you the Council's position on the European Union's draft budget for 2016, which was unanimously adopted by the Council on 4 September. The main objective is to support economic recovery, investment and job creation, on the one hand, and to stimulate the financing of migration policies of the Union's external action, on the other. The budget is therefore a reflection of solidarity inwards and outwards. I will give you a three-part presentation. The first will be devoted to current events, the second will take up the seven main principles that guided the Council's agreement and, finally, the third will contain the highlights. In view of the tragic events we are facing, and in view of the tens and tens of thousands of refugees who have fled the war and have put all their hopes in Europe, it is important to me to underline the support that the European Union is currently providing, in addition to the initiatives of the Member States. European aid to the current migration situation and the crisis of asylum seekers is one of the variations of this internal and external solidarity. A few figures: the two main funds in shared management are the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the ESF, which are endowed with 3.1 billion euros and 3.7 billion euros respectively for the period 2014-2020. In 2015, more than 45 national programmes were approved for just over one billion commitment appropriations. Just over $210 million in pre-financing has already been released by the Commission. In addition, the "emergency assistance" component of these two funds has helped to unlock just over $60 million.  The Council and the European Parliament jointly approved the European migration agenda in May 2015, which is based on four pillars and aims to improve the management of migration flows. We also approved amending budget number 5 for this purpose.  The European Union is finally one of the main donors in the region surrounding Syria: 855 million euros have been allocated to humanitarian aid for refugees from Syria in Lebanon, Jordan and Turkey for 2016. With regard to the relocation of refugees, commitments of EUR 150 million to Greece and Italy have been accepted in their entirety by the Council. These topics will certainly be discussed tomorrow by Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker in his State of the Union statement, where he will also highlight and outline a new package of measures in this area.  The second part will focus on the seven main principles that guided the Council's work. First, we felt it was important to address and address the problem of arrears of payment, which can be resolved by the end of 2016. The Council's position includes the necessary appropriations to implement the payment timetable agreement in 2015 and 2016.  The second major principle is that the Council has selected all the allocations planned to support the European Fund for Strategic Investments in 2016, which is a top priority.  Thirdly, the migration policy is endowed with significant appropriations, including temporary measures for Greece and Italy for the relocation of 40,000 refugees on their soils, and the Migration and Integration Asylum Fund, which will be endowed with 515 million euros, an increase of 35% in 2016 compared to 2015.  The fourth major principle is humanitarian aid. Payment credits increased by 16% in 2016 compared to 2015 to reach more than ONE billion euros.  The fifth principle: the credit cuts that have been carried out according to guidelines based on several parameters, namely a rate of progress of the projects' programmes, the past and expected rate of implementation for the projects and, finally, the predictable and realistic absorption capacity for the various programmes. The sixth guiding principle is that the budget lines adjusted by the Council are mainly those for which the Commission had proposed very strong progress. So it is to these very high numbers that we have applied downward adjustments. But if you look at the absolute increase in credit in these areas, you will find that the increases remain substantial. Seventh and final principle: in the face of political and sometimes dramatic instability around the European Union, the Council has decided to keep sufficient room for manoeuvre in the event of escalating tensions and conflicts. I'll go through reviewed very quickly the details of the Council's position, which was unanimously agreed on 4 September. The proposal covers commitment appropriations of $153.3 billion and payment appropriations of $142.1 billion. For payment credits, this is an increase of 0.6% and for commitment credits, a decrease of 5.4%. Knowing that the Commission had proposed a 5% reduction, we are therefore very close. The position we have chosen reduces the gap between commitment credits and payment credits and, therefore, the famous remains to be liquidated, and therefore reduces the risk of arrears of payment.  Let's move on to the highlights by topic. In the "competitiveness for growth and employment" category, which is at the heart of the political priorities for investment and employment, payment credits increase by 8.6% and commitment credits by 7%. To achieve the European Fund for Strategic Investments, which is a top priority, redeployments have been selected on the following points: the Horizon 2020 programme and the Mechanism for Interconnection in Europe (MIE). Funding for major infrastructure projects has also been reduced, including Galileo, ITER and Copernicus, as well as joint ventures. Despite the reductions, payment credits for Horizon 2020 increased by 9.3% (840 million) compared to 2015, to reach 9.9 billion euros, a considerable figure.  The Council has also slightly scaled down the mechanism for interconnection in Europe. However, commitment appropriations increased by 53% (760 million euros) and payment credits by 14% (203 million euros), which is very close to the Commission's proposals.  The popular Cosme and Erasmus programmes were not affected by the cuts. I would point out that the Erasmus programme will be endowed with EUR 1.8 billion in 2016, an increase of 30% over 2015.  In the "economic, social and territorial cohesion" category, credit fell very slightly by 0.45 per cent. In the "sustainable growth: natural resources" section, there was a slight reduction of 0.45 per cent in payment credits and 0.32 per cent in commitment credits compared to the Commission's proposals.  In section 3 "security and citizenship", which I have already insisted on in my first part, commitment credits increase sharply compared to 2015 (8.7%) and payment credits are up more than 15%. This increase mainly relates to actions in the field of migration, a political priority of the European Union. The Council also accepted the use of the flexibility instrument. In heading 4, the Council largely took up the Commission's proposals. Payment credits increased by 22.4% to more than 9 billion euros. I would like to point out that the Council has aligned itself with the Commission's amounts in key areas such as humanitarian aid, civil protection, macro-financial aid to third countries, the External Action Guarantee Fund and support for the Palestinians. Under heading 5 "administration" the proposal foresees a moderate reduction of 31 million which will not affect the functioning of the institutions of the European Union. The Council has not changed the administrative budget of the European Parliament, but will remain vigilant about the planned 5% reduction in staff until 2017. A meeting was decided at our budget trilogue in July so that Parliament, the Commission and the Presidency could discuss this issue together. In conclusion, Madam President, dear Members of the European Parliament, aware of the challenges ahead, particularly on the migration front, and in view of the growing conflicts around the European Union, the Council considered it essential to find a compromise, balanced and responsible, which retains some leeway to deal with the aggravations that are obvious. The budget is therefore under the sign of this internal and external solidarity, which is close to our hearts all.

name: Corina Crețu
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like first of all to thank Minister Gramegna for his presentation of the Council’s reading of our draft budget for 2016. The Commission fully shares the view that budgetary discipline and sound management is what people expect from us, but our citizens of course also expect that we attend to urgent needs in these times of many ongoing crises. President Juncker will present tomorrow, in his State of the Union speech, proposals for the refugee crisis. Furthermore, in response to recent market developments in the dairy sector, the Commission announced yesterday a comprehensive package of measures for EUR 400 million of EU funds to be used for the benefit of farmers immediately. The financial impact of the migration package and the agricultural basis will be reflected in an amending letter to be proposed in October. This amending letter will include the higher-than-expected surplus in the agricultural sector. Let me now turn to the original proposal of the Commission on which the Council reading was based. The draft budget for 2016 is a comprehensive proposal covering all political priorities: to stimulate investment, growth and jobs, through the agreement reached on the European Fund for Strategic Investments, Amending Letter No 1; to improve our capacity to meet the collective challenge of migration; to reinforce Europe in the world. Our proposal still leaves a margin of EUR 2.1 bn in commitments and EUR 1.6 bn in payments below the already tight MFF ceilings. All in all our draft budget for 2016 is a proposal for a responsible budget, a budget for the many competing needs of Europe, and a budget that has a margin for unforeseen events. Regarding payments, we have a draft budget that respects the agreed payment plan and that will bring us back to a sustainable budget for cohesion policy. The Commission welcomes the Council’s reading with regard to the 2007-2013 budget for Cohesion Policy programmes in heading 1b. However, we are concerned about the proposed cuts on a range of selected budget lines across headings, supposedly justified by low implementation rates in mid-June.  Our proposal aims at reversing the effect of payment shortages from the last years, including in headings for external actions. For many of the budgetary lines affected by the proposed cuts, the situation has radically changed since last year. We now have high implementation rates, especially under Heading 4, instead of delays, and from our point of view as a result there is no reason to reduce these budget lines. With regard to commitments, I see with satisfaction that the Council is endorsing the Commission proposal on migration. Let me stress that important actions were already taken in 2015 to address migration challenges. Twenty-three multiannual national programmes under the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund are approved, and some EUR 205 million of pre-financing has already been paid out to our Member States for both funds – EUR 122 million from the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and EUR 83 million from the Internal Security Fund. Money will now be able to flow. What we propose in 2016 is a continuation of the amending budget proposed in 2015, and more must be done in the next years. Regarding Heading 1a on growth and jobs, the Commission does not share the Council’s view on the reasons why the substantial cuts on programmes such as Horizon 2020 or the energy strand of the Connecting Europe Facility, are decoupled from political priorities like the Energy Union, or the spirit of our agreement on the financing of the European Fund for Strategic Investments.  Under Heading 4, cuts are proposed in our main programmes for the neighbourhood, pre-accession and development cooperation. Reducing the extent of our assistance in the Mediterranean will not increase security and will run contrary to the overall political goal for the economic development of this region so close to us. On administrative expenditure, for a number of years already the Commission, as well as a number of other institutions, has shown self-restraint and sound administrative management. We have continued working with limited increases in administrative expenditure. We are progressing towards our achievement of a 5% staff reduction target over five years, yet the Council’s position seems to ignore these efforts. I will just give you one example. For the Commission, if we were to undergo the Council’s proposal to cut EUR 19 million we would have to freeze 206 posts on top of a 4% staff reduction to be achieved by 2016. Likewise, cuts to administrative support expenditure, research staff and executive agencies across all the headings would be extremely harmful for the proper implementation of programmes. Let me conclude my statement with some elements regarding the process. In mid-October, the Commission will present an amending letter containing an update for agriculture and the budgetary implication of the new package on migration which President Juncker will announce tomorrow before this European Parliament.  We look forward to Parliament’s reading and trust that by the end of the conciliation period we will find a common way ahead for the 2016 budget.

name: José Manuel Fernandes
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to greet the Commissioner, the representatives of the Council, the Representative of the Council, all and all colleagues. Parliament is united in this respect. Parliament has a clear mandate and several resolutions - the last of July - adopted on this matter and we are consistent with our priorities. We defend employment, business, entrepreneurship, we defend internal solidarity and external solidarity. It is in our position, of our resolution.  This has consequences. It has consequences in terms of heading 1a, it has consequences in terms of Horizon 2020, the Connecting Europe Facility, the Youth Employment Initiative, which we want to continue. But we must not forget at this moment that, on our part, there is no minimum of hypocrisy and, as I was saying, we are consequential. We have already said this: migration, the refugee problem, must be in line with the budget. Solidarity does not live on proclamations. Solidarity is done with actions and, listening to the Council representative, it seems that the Council has not made any cuts, it seems that the Council defends the cause of migration.  Under heading 4, with instruments and programmes linked to the resolution of this problem, the Council cuts EUR 450 million in payments. Heading 4 cuts the instrument for pre-access assistance by EUR 119 million, cuts the European neighbourhood instrument by more than EUR 100 million, cuts a line of poverty support, combating poverty in the Mediterranean by EUR 50 million, cuts the Development Cooperation Instrument by EUR 143 million. By the way, the Council cuts eur 1.4 billion from the Commission's proposal. And I think that the Council representative was making a comparison perhaps with a budget of 1980 or 1990, and not with the budget of 2015, and it is good to note that, unanimously, a programming of the European Union budget - the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework - has already been adopted annually.  The Commission, in the proposal, has reduced and the Council has made further cuts to this reduction. A Council position which is unacceptable, which is incomprehensible, which is incoherent, goes against its proposals, which goes against its priorities. The Council cannot say - I am already done, but I had four minutes, Madam President - the Council cannot say that it saves the lines where there is good absorption. This is not true, because it cuts through Horizon 2020, where there is excellent absorption, because it cuts the Connecting Europe Mechanism, where there is excellent absorption, because it cuts these instruments that are needed and where there is excellent absorption and I do not understand how these proclamations are made and if you have these taken here in the heart of the chamber without a shred of shame , without at least a little bit blushing, because this, the proclamations, the speech, are not in line with the Council's proposal and the cuts that the Council has once again made.

name: Gérard Deprez
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, you said four minutes, sorry for this joke. Madam President, Mr President of the Council, Commissioner, Mr President of the Council, I share your relief, at least for 2015 and 2016 with regard to payment appropriations. Last year, we spent almost all of the budgetary authority's negotiations with the Commission trying to find a solution to the dramatic problem of payments. Now the situation is not good for 2015. It's bad but stabilized. It will improve in 2016, but it will not last. Between now and the end of the current financial outlook, you will see a surge in payment credits because, structurally, nothing has been done to avoid the situation we will find ourselves in before the end of the current financial outlook.  With regard to the 2016 budget, Mr President of the Council, we have three main priorities which I believe are common to almost all policy-makers: the need to stimulate growth, the need to deal humanisticly and effectively with the unprecedented wave of refugees seeking protection in our territory and, as you have forgotten today, but I imagine it is not voluntary. , the need to remain alert to the terrorist threats that continue and will continue to weigh on us. I will not talk much today about this third challenge, other than to remind you of the need to strengthen the human and technical resources to be made available to the Union's organs, such as Europol, Eurojust, the Eu-LISA Agency, which play a very important role in the exchange of strategic information to combat terrorism and avoid further attacks.  We consider that the means that you have provided at Council level and even at the Commission level are not sufficient to ensure optimal effectiveness for these bodies. Having said that, the major and most urgent problem we face today is the unprecedented influx of refugees seeking protection on the territory of the Union. We have been pleased to hear the statements of Mr Juncker, a number of politicians, whose guidelines we share - I am not talking about Mr Orbon - but, Mr President, budgetary resources must follow. For 2016, the Commission's draft budget does provide for an increase of EUR 169 million compared to 2015, but this will not be enough. This will be all the less than the cost of distributing or relocating refugees will skyrocket. If Mr Juncker announces tomorrow his proposal to add 120,000 relocation beneficiaries to the 40,000 already planned, it is not far from 960 million euros that will have to be mobilised to comply with the provisions of Article 18 of the regulation establishing the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund. So don't think we're going to get away with this. One last word, Madam President, and I will be done. I regret, as do my colleague José Manuel Fernandes, rapporteur, that the Council has still felt the need to reduce certain budget lines of the Horizon 2020 programme and the mechanism for interconnection in Europe, while, according to all the information in our possession, these lines are the subject of proposals - 36,000 for "Horizon 2020" for the period 2014-2015 - which unfortunately cannot be responded favourably because of the conditions you have created. I think that is a profound mistake.

name: Pierre Gramegna
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, I believe that this is not the time today to enter into a substantive discussion on the Council's proposal and on the remarks made by the two rapporteurs, Mr Fernandez and Mr Deprez, whom I thank nevertheless for their commitment and dynamism in defending the various appropriations.  I would just like to point out that the reductions made by the Council have been made in relation to the Commission's proposals, which themselves represent considerable increases on most of the points that have been mentioned. In particular, I would like to say that, for example in section IV, we have payment credits up by 22.45 per thousand per 22 per share. So when we talk about cutting, these are not cuts from the previous year's budget, but they are downward adjustments to amounts that are increasing significantly. But as I said, we are not going to go into the details of the negotiation today. I'm glad to hear that I've had lyrical flights. I, for one, felt that I had been extremely down-to-earth, but I will try to do better the next time I am with you. I would just like to point out that we will be working hand in hand with you and listening very seriously to the proposals you are going to make. I would also like to add that I am reaching out to you for frank and constructive cooperation in order to reach a compromise that will be all the more difficult to find because we know very well that other expenses are waiting for us because of worsening situations and unforeseen events. Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker will present the Commission's new package of measures on all migration issues tomorrow. This will not be done at zero rates. On agricultural policy, as the Commissioner has announced, there will also be ways to mobilise. The budget will therefore be difficult to close and I believe that the only assurance I can give you today is that we will be playing cards on the table and trying to find tenable and responsible compromises in the interests of solidarity with the outside world and investment, jobs and growth within the Union.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The draft budget for 2016 is a comprehensive proposal covering the most important policy priorities, from stimulating investment, growth and job creation, improving the collective capacity to meet migration challenges, to empowering Europe on the international stage. These are solid assumptions to meet realities and needs. For example, I consider it a good sign to increase funding for programmes related to culture and educational development, such as Creative Europe and Europe for Citizens. However, I do not share the Council's view that it recommends cuts to Horizon 2020, thus separating it from the main political priorities, such as the Energy Union project.  It is good that the Commission's proposal leaves a margin of €2.1 billion in commitments and €1.6 billion in payments below the already restrictive ceilings of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020. We are already clearly experiencing the need for financial reserves. The current migration crisis, which has engulfed the whole of Europe, is an example of this. In addition, recent protests by farmers in response to market developments in the dairy sector have resulted in the Commission granting a comprehensive package of €400 million for immediate use. It is also funds mobilised from reserves. The people of Europe need confirmation that we are also ready to deal with emergencies, especially now, at a time of many crises that are plaguing us.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. – The Council's general budget for the financial year 2016 shows an amount of EUR 142.12 billion for payments and EUR 153.27 billion for commitments. This represents a reduction of one per cent or 0.15 per cent compared to the Commission's budget. The Member States' budget, based on a general reduction target of four per cent since 2013, is characterised by sometimes massive cuts. At the same time, however, the Member States are calling for substantial increases in funding, an additional EUR 500 million alone to deal with the refugee crisis. Another 500 million in emergency aid to dairy farmers affected by the lifting of the milk quota and the Russia sanctions – in addition to the annual subsidies of 50 billion. An additional billion will be spent on building up a fund for African countries, and in general the Council's budget foresees a 22.5 per cent increase in funding for foreign policy measures, while the funds for programmes that increase competitiveness are only expected to increase by 8.6 per cent. Funding for Horizon 2020 is even being cut, a measure that is counterproductive because it is anti-growth. The Council is therefore on the brakes on the budget and, at the same time, is giving the gas to draw a striking comparison. This will not increase the credibility of the budget or ensure its sustainability.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The area of culture and education remains the responsibility of the Member States. Rightly. We should seek greater stability for proven projects, improve the length of the prospects for guaranteed funding, and improve the financing of those projects that increase our knowledge of the state of culture in Europe and its financing mechanisms.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for debate on Ska Keller's report, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on interim measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece (COM(2015)0286 - C8-0156/2015 - 2015/0125 (NLE) (A8-024/2015)).

name: Ska Keller
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, ladies and gentlemen of the European Parliament, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which we are a member of the European Commissioner of the European Commission, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for his excellent work. Representatives of the European Council and representatives of the Member States who have voluntarily joined the European Union.  You and all of us have joined forces with the idea of human rights, freedom, justice and solidarity. And it is precisely these European values that my report is about: human rights, because we are talking here about people who have fled war and persecution and are seeking protection here, about human rights for these very people. For freedom, because these people are looking for a life in peace and freedom. That is right, because refugees have rights, they are not packages that we can send criss-crossing Europe without asking what interests and desires they have. For solidarity, because all Member States are called upon to make their contribution. Solidarity is what holds us together. If one is in need, the other helps. All of us can be in a position to be in a position to show solidarity at any time.  We in Parliament – and I would like to express my thanks to our shadow rapporteurs for this – have negotiated this report in a mad time, in a few weeks' time. We in Parliament are calling for the binding distribution of 40 000 refugees, and we are saying quite clearly that this can only be the beginning. We call for the interests of refugees to be taken into account as far as possible. We as a Parliament, we have done our job.  And the Council? It is nothing short of a disgrace that the Member States have failed to agree on 40 000 places. First of all, they said that it was binding, that this is not possible, solidarity, that must be voluntary, and then they still promised that the 40 000 would come together – but it was nothing, just 32 000 came out of it. 32 000 places for refugees. We should not forget that more than twenty thousand refugees arrive in Greece every week. Nor should we forget that Lebanon is home to more than a million refugees, and Lebanon, God knows, has other problems and only four million inhabitants, while Europe has 500 million inhabitants.  A large number of these very Europeans are showing us what a rake is! The people of Hungary, Austria, France, Germany, Finland and all the other Member States are showing in practice what solidarity and empathy means. As Members and governments, we and you should not be left behind! That is why it is right that the Commission should propose another emergency allocation instrument, with 120 000, and this time Hungary will also be taken into account. This is the right step, but we cannot stop there. We finally need a permanent distribution key in the event of an emergency, and we must be able to decide and move forward when this emergency is there and not be blocked by various Member States.  However, we also need a far-reaching reform of Dublin at long last, because there is the catch: Dublin is not working, Dublin is dead. We have to come out, we finally need a fair distribution: fair for the Member States, but also fair for the refugees.  Europe is facing a major challenge, and many are even talking about a real crisis. And yes, the challenge of taking in and caring for many thousands of arriving refugees is not small. But we should never forget that the real crises are elsewhere, that the real challenge is borne by the refugees who take on this challenge. People fleeing Assad's bombs, from the terror of Da'ish, from dictatorial regimes – that is the real challenge, that is the real crisis.  And helping these people must be our job. Europe, as one of the richest regions in the world, can only fail in this task if we give ourselves a leg up, and we should not do that, we should not let it happen! Thank you very much.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, today’s debate is very timely. It concerns the positive opinion of Parliament on the first emergency relocation mechanism. However, as Members know, the Commission is adopting a new package on migration which will be officially presented to them tomorrow. As I have repeatedly said, both I personally and this Commission are committed to accelerating and enhancing our actions to face the migratory challenge, which is a European one. The proposal for the emergency relocation of persons in clear need of international protection from Italy and Greece is an important part of the measures we are already putting in place to address this unprecedented situation. Therefore, allow me to express my appreciation to our rapporteur, who has led the discussions on this complex file in a very constructive and engaging manner.  The aim of this proposal is twofold: to relieve the pressure on Italy and Greece and to ensure the dignified treatment of the persons concerned. The Commission welcomes the approach Parliament proposes to take.  The interests of the applicants should, as much as possible, match those of the Member States. The system has to be implemented in such a way as to create a win-win situation and to prevent secondary movements. This is why, in deciding which Member State an applicant should be relocated to, specific account should be taken of the qualifications and characteristics of the applicant, such as language skills and other individual indications based on family, culture or social ties which could facilitate their integration. At the same time, our aim is to have something as simple and efficient as possible in order to ensure that these persons can be relocated as quickly as possible. This will ensure the proper protection of the applicants concerned while alleviating the burden on Italy and Greece.  The Commission shares the concerns of Parliament when it comes to vulnerable persons. It is foreseen that they should be the priority in the implementation of the scheme. The special needs of asylum applicants, including their health, should be of primary concern, and the best interests of the child should always be a primary consideration.  As you are aware, the Council reached a general approach in our proposal in July. Member States, in general, made considerable efforts to show solidarity and agreed to the relocation of 40 000 persons over two years and, as a first step, to the relocation of 32 256 persons. I am confident that the Member States will update their figures by the end of this year so as to reach 40 000, in line with the commitment that they have taken. The discussions in the Council confirmed that this remains a very challenging topic, but we should be able to feel proud as soon as the results are achieved. The refugee crisis is a reality and no one can pretend that it does not concern us all.  Such results would not have been thinkable only a few months ago. Indeed, it is the first time that Member States have collectively – and not just bilaterally – agreed to relocate persons in clear need of international protection. It is now of utmost importance that we proceed quickly to the implementation of the scheme, including by the establishment of the hotspots. I am personally engaged in assuring an accelerated and effective rollout of the hotspots as soon as possible, and certainly before the decision enters into force.  The hotspot approach is not only necessary for the implementation of the relocation decision but is, more importantly, a key measure of solidarity vis—à—vis the most affected Member States that rely on the coherent mobilisation of European agencies. The European Asylum Support Office (EASO) will provide support in the processing of asylum applications and the registration of migrants. Frontex will help with the return process, while Europol and Eurojust will assist in the investigation of criminal networks.  It is crucial that we provide holistic support to Member States under pressure and ensure ownership and build trust with other Member States. The first hotspots have already been set up in Sicily, Lampedusa and Taranto. One more is going to be set up within the next few days in Piraeus in Greece. A workshop organised by the Commission, together with EASO, for the Member States on relocation and resettlement will take place on 1 October. The third relocation and resettlement forum will also take place this autumn to continue the discussion on the technical modalities.  We can all agree that the recent developments – unprecedented arrivals of migrants and asylum applicants – will require further action. Members have clearly called for a permanent relocation mechanism based on a distribution key. Parliament will this time be co-legislator on the file and I look forward to your engagement. This proposal will already build on many of the ideas put forward by this House during its debates on relocation. In this respect, I would like to thank you for your valuable contribution.  Let me underline that, more than ever, we need to work in a comprehensive way as there is no single solution. The Commission will continue and speed up the implementation of all the aspects of this common challenge, as set out in the agenda on migration.  I wish to thank Members very much for their attention and am ready to take note of their remarks and answer their questions.

name: Jeroen Lenaers
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Thank you to the Commissioner for the extensive explanation. I regret that the council's front row is empty, because I would have thought it very important, in the very run-up to all the intense debates that have taken place in the Council, to hear the Voice of the Council in this debate today. For I, and many of them, are disappointed in the result that the Council has achieved. I had really hoped - and perhaps I was a little naïve about it - that after everything that has happened last summer from Calais to Austria and from Bodrum to Budapest, we would be discussing this issue in a different atmosphere. But if there is one thing the Member States have proven, it is that a system of voluntary redistribution simply does not work. At a time when 20 000 refugees a week are arriving on an island like Lesbos, but we are unable to redistribute 16 000 refugees from Greece on a voluntary basis to other countries, then it is simply the case that voluntary action does not work. Then we must move towards a binding system, and I am pleased that this Parliament is strongly supporting it. But let us not fool ourselves: redistributing refugees is only one part of a European migration agenda. If we do nothing, if we cannot make progress on all other aspects, such as efficient return policies, better agreements with third countries, tackling people smugglers, tackling the root causes of the unrest, then we can talk about redistributing refugees for a very long time to come, but then we have done too little on the original causes.

name: Iliana Iotova
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D- Madam President, the events of the past few months have shown that we cannot make a policy only for the Mediterranean. The migratory pressure on land borders is enormous. The measures taken by the Commission are no longer current. The debate is no longer about the relocation figures because they change from day to day. Commissioner, the Dublin Regulation is no longer working. Some Member States at the external borders have stopped registering migrants because they no longer have the means or resources. The permanent and binding mechanism is more than necessary. The Commission must propose it and the Council must adopt it in the name of European solidarity. Unfortunately, the council's seat is now empty. Member States at the external borders should be given some relief and special status. They are the ones who take in the majority of migrants. Hot spots must be operational as soon as possible. We need a common strategy and measures to dismantle trafficking networks.  None of these measures can be really implemented if Europe does not actively participate in the resolution of conflicts in third countries. Europe must return to its position as a world leader. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – When you talk about a binding mechanism, would you not accept that if there is a binding mechanism putting these people into different areas it would (a) not only be the end of all national sovereignty, but (b) also be an effective amnesty for every single person who turns up on the shores of Europe? If you have a binding mechanism, all it will do is relocate people when they arrive. Are those two factors things you would agree with and think are a good thing?

name: Илияна Йотова (S&D)
text: answer a question asked by raising a blue card. – In recent days, some European politicians, including Mr Sarkozy, have suggested that border countries, including my country Bulgaria, should become a kind of sanitary belt of Europe and accept only refugees there.  If you ask me this question, you either agree with this policy or you do not know European legislation because it makes a clear distinction for refugees on the one hand and for economic immigrants. We are talking about a refugee policy and I ask you to read the laws well.

name: Helga Stevens
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – My delegation is in favour of a mandatory distribution of asylum seekers, but under three strict conditions. And those conditions are equally important to all of us.  First, measures must be taken to better monitor our external borders. I am thinking here of setting up hotspots and the associated effective return of economic migrants. Secondly, the European Commission must amend the Qualifications Directive so that EU Member States can pursue a strong activation policy.  Thirdly, the distribution of asylum seekers must be fair and therefore take into account, among other things, asylum applications already processed and historical migration flows. The current redistribution parameters do not meet this, on the contrary. These put the responsibility back on the Western European countries that have made the most efforts so far. Once again, I wonder: is this what we mean by European solidarity?

name: Angelika Mlinar
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We are facing the biggest political challenge of the next few years. In my opinion, this is still underestimated and too much seen as a technical problem. But we're not talking about numbers, we're talking about people - people like you and me, not people in a different category. It was only because politicians did not want to tackle the issue for a long time that this chaos arose. This must stop! It is therefore necessary to remind our Heads of State of five fundamental principles. Firstly, fundamental rights. At the end of the day, people are always behind the debate about categories such as migrants, refugees and asylum seekers. Every human being, whether registered or not, has fundamental human rights at all times, such as the right to dignity and the right to life. Secondly, the Peace Project Europe. It is precisely the unstable situation in the Middle East that must also remind us of the value of European integration. That is the only reason why we can live in peace, prosperity and security today. From this position of security, we can help other people. Thirdly, the construction of walls. Viktor Orban is not the only one currently building fences. Other politicians, such as David Cameron, are also building demarcations, even if they are not barbed wire. However, the past 25th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall has clearly reminded us that such demarcations merely demonstrate powerlessness and are not a real solution. The underlying causes cannot be eliminated by foreclosure. Fourthly, the power of numbers. For a serious discussion, we need serious figures. The populist numbers game with exaggerated arrival numbers and multiple counts distorts the discussion and only benefits the fear-mongers. And fifthly, a pan-European perspective. The refugee issue is a pan-European issue. The border issue must be linked to a strong security and foreign policy. Open internal borders and stable external borders also require an active common European foreign policy. The values that make Europe great play a crucial role in this: respect for human rights and humanitarian prudence. People are very helpful at the moment, but if politics continues to put its head in the sand, that will change.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, the European Union, in fact, lacks a policy to deal with the refugee issue. This absence of policy is co-responsible for the fact that more than 2,000 people have lost their lives trying to reach the European Union. The Commission's proposal to relocate 40,000 people in need of international protection from Greece and Italy to other countries is also a drop in the ocean. In Greece, which has welcomed more than 260,000 people since the beginning of the year, these figures sound like an insult, especially when you consider that the Council is proposing the relocation of only 32,000 people, deliberately ignoring the situation on the Greek islands, which are sinking under the weight of the people who arrive daily on them. We therefore need a permanent and compulsory relocation mechanism and the elimination of the first entry criterion from the Dublin Regulation. Above all, however, we need a peaceful solution in Syria and, by extension, in Iraq, because that alone can be a permanent response. These people are being forced to flee their countries and seek asylum in Europe precisely because of the wars that have broken out with co-responsibility from both Western countries and governments, on both sides of the Atlantic.

name: Judith Sargentini
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. I would like to congratulate the European Commission on tackling this refugee crisis. Before the summer, I thought, what a meagre proposition, resettle 40,000 people. What are we going to do with that? I appreciated the possibility of coming up with a distribution key, but found your geste actually limited.  Now that I have the strong impression that tomorrow the European Commission is going to come up with a broader proposal and we may have seen this summer that the ship is turning, I would like to congratulate you. In this light, I do not know how to understand that the European Council is not here now. Because actually, we have to say that we do not have a refugee crisis here, if you see how refugees arrive at the munich station and then in a few hours we arrive at a shelter with clean sheets and a hot shower, I would say: we can cope with the refugee crisis. What we have is a governance crisis! We have a governance crisis that needs to be resolved next Monday. The Ministers of Justice and home affairs will meet on 14 September and if they do not come out, I think our governance crisis will deepen. I am surprised to see that, when Angela Merkel calls for a breakaway, there are countries that do not want to participate, countries in Western Europe that look away! That countries in Central and Eastern Europe come together and point the finger at another. When I used to say to my mother: at Marietje's house they don't have to wash dishes, my mother said: that's a matter of being at Marie's house. We do it differently here!  This is a personal responsibility that we must take and I wish the European Commission a great deal of strength with that! Finally, I would like to say to you: this European Parliament is behind you from left to right.

name: Laura Ferrara
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by congratulating Mrs Keller on her good work and the other shadow rapporteurs. It is a pity, however, that this work has in fact been devalued, both from a content point of view, given that the Council has already approved its decision which completely distorts the position of the European Parliament and I refer to the obligatory relocation of migrants between Member States; to quotas and so on.  Then it was devalued from a procedural point of view because it is precisely because of the emergency procedure – which we then saw that this was not the case, we cannot speak of an emergency for a proposal that arrived in April, we are in September, and we are still discussing it – it is an emergency procedure that does not involve the European Parliament, if not with a consultation that is not binding So much so that, I repeat, the Council has already approved its decision.  Well, I would like to point out that the European Parliament is the only institution that is democratically elected by the citizens, which in fact represents the will of the European citizens. How many times have we been asked: what is Europe doing? Where is Europe? Surely we should be more timely, we should have a change to the Dublin Regulation – as we have been calling for for a long time – a distribution of migrants between Member States that is binding and compulsory among all, so that solidarity and cooperation are not only recognised on the Charter and the Treaties but are applied in practice.

name: Lorenzo Fontana
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I believe that at least three basic criteria are needed to deal pragmatically with this difficult situation. The first, which is always talked about, is to protect those fleeing war; This is certainly a fair and important principle, which we are talking about, which we are dealing with and which the Commission is also, I believe, more vigorously, certainly in the last period.  The second is repatriations; for those who are not refugees, for those who do not have the right, because it is clear that Europe cannot take on millions and millions of poor people, because it would obviously become chaos and – from this point of view, of course, we should help the border countries to identify people and see who is entitled and who is not – and then we also have to solve the root problems. , because we know that there are wars and Europe must use all its strength to be able to pacify the war situations, I am thinking first of all of Syria, but I am also thinking of Eritrea, where there has been a war for thirty years from which people have been fleeing. Because you see, there is a human right – which is not often pronounced here either – which is the right to live and die where you were born, and I think we should take that into account.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: Madam President, the plan by Commission President Unger and Commissioner Avramopoulos on migration is proof of how so-called technocrats perceive real problems. For example, they propose relocating 40,000 people within two years, when so many have entered a Greek island in the eastern Aegean in the two months of July - August alone. They are asking the Member States for binding quotas. A reply was recently received from the Prime Ministers of the United Kingdom and Hungary. Cameron said England would welcome refugees exclusively from existing camps in Syria. Orban built a fence on the Hungary-Serbia border and said his country does not discuss quotas unless the European Union's external borders are sealed first. The Greek islands and Italy are "sinking" and some, supposedly humanists, are now shedding tears for little Aylan while they have not reacted so long to the massacres of thousands of Aylans by the Islamic State and by Western-motivated dissidents in Syria. Money does not ease human suffering and does not buy peace. Simple solutions exist: - repeal of Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999 604/2013 concerning the first countries of entry; - comprehensive review of the Dublin II Treaty;  - establishment of reception facilities in Turkey, where all asylum applications will be examined;  Thanks.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE).
text: – Madam President, yes, I don't see the Council in front of you either. The first thing I wanted to do was congratulate Francisca and the wedd rapporteur on such a fast and effective work wrapped in enormous sensitivity. The second thing I want to say has already been said, but I'll dig a little deeper.  I do not like that, in order to bring forward the consultation of this Council Decision, we have taken Article 78(3) as a legislative basis because, in pureness, it steals from Parliament all its powers on the road to co-legislation.  What we want, Mr Avramopoulos, is to be able to give a ruling as soon as possible on a procedure and on a mechanism in which this Parliament actually intervenes, in the process of Article 78(2).  Going to the bottom of the matter, I want to make a personal pronouncement that has to do with the pronouncement of my political group. We are in favor of the obligatory and the permanent. We are in favour of prioritizing vulnerable people, especially children. We are in favour of reviewing Dublin as soon as possible: Dublin is unfair and obsolete, and does not face a crisis of this proportion and of this magnitude.  And finally, Madam President, I would like the preferences of asylum seekers, language, family reunification and culture to be taken into account - and Mr Avramopoulos has said.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D).
text: – I have to say that this whole subject has been reduced to a few such key expressions. However, those key terms are perceived differently from the point of view of the Member States. One of these terms is quotas. Unfortunately, we have reduced the total aid to human beings, to living people, to the expression of the quota. This is not just happening in one country, it is in the vocabulary of several politicians of the Member States of the European Union. The second significant problem or key concept is the way in which we communicate. The European Commission, the European Parliament and the Council have not found an appropriate way of communicating how to bring this topic closer to the citizens of the Member States of the European Union. That is also why very complicated situations are taking place in some countries. And the third problem is, we haven't actually done anything all summer. We have been meeting here since April, we have held a minute's silence, we have adopted a resolution and no one has checked how that resolution is being met. I would therefore ask the Commission to closely check how the conclusions of the previous resolution, including the one that we will adopt these days, are being met.

name: Jussi Halla-aho (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the image of the drowned Syrian child haunts us all and it is easy to get emotional. However, that image is not very representative. The vast majority of the asylum seekers coming to my country and many others are not Syrian children, but young men from countries like Iraq, Somalia, Western Africa and even Albania. They flee from poverty and unemployment, which is understandable, but we cannot afford this kind of immigration in these kinds of numbers.  A relocation system is bad for Europe itself, but it is also bad for the refugees of the world. Should we use our resources on the lucky ones who make it to Europe, or should we use them to improve the living conditions of the millions who will, in any case, remain in the camps? We must address the pull factors. The new government in Denmark has drastically cut the benefits paid to immigrants and tightened the rules of family reunification. These are the kinds of measures that Europe as a whole should implement without delay.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Firstly, I would like to thank the Commission, Commissioner Avramopoulos, the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for their tireless work on this very important report. It responds to a great need for new life opportunities for many refugees who have reached Italy and Greece, and who will now be able to find a new home and new life chances everywhere in europe.  I'm sorry the front chair is empty. That is where the Council should have been. Mr Tusk, who is President-in-Office of the Council, should have been here to take part in this debate. I am very, very disappointed because he does not take his leadership seriously, and I would like it to be recorded in the Minutes. I think it is important that, at this time, we now realise that it is only through joint European cooperation that we will be able to deal with the challenges of refugees. It is shameful, as I said, that the Council is absent. Now, however, we need to dense our cooperation, because the citizens who have stood in train stations in thousands, opened their homes and shown humanity, have more right to expect from us politicians. Now is the time to move from words to deeds.

name: Barbara Spinelli (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Treaties lie about who we are, we are not a beacon of civilisation, we do not have a common asylum policy, we have not been in solidarity with Greece, we are not with migrants. Let me remind you of one figure: 85% of the refugees are in the poor countries of the world. Tomorrow we will vote on the Keller report, which proposes a modest fair distribution of refugees, the Council is already emptying it.  Yesterday, Statewatch wrote: 'If Parliament does not impose binding and permanent measures on the Commission and the Council, it makes no sense to hold future European elections'. I agree! I think that Parliament will have to censure the Commission if it does not go beyond relocations and organises legal escape routes and the end of Dublin, but above all it must threaten to cut off the Council's operating funds, which is the most guilty of incompetence, the most incapable of action. (The President interrupted the speech)

name: Jean Lambert (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, the need for solidarity between Member States on issues concerning those seeking asylum has been discussed frequently in this House over the years, and we have called for solidarity to be shown. Today’s proposal gives us one way in which we can do that. Many of us in the House feel that it is not good enough for certain governments to complain about the supposed failure of other Member States and then wash their hands of the matter and step back from offering assistance, with what are, at times, pretty weak and pathetic excuses. It is clear that Greece and Italy need help. We know the situation in those countries and, as I say, the proposals offer a way forward. A couple of colleagues made reference to the British Government, and I am deeply ashamed that the British Government is not willing to follow the German example. In fact, it seems to be aligning itself more with the Danish one in relation to the matter of benefits as if, somehow, creating poverty and destitution among those who are pushed to come here is something to be proud of. I know that my country is offering support through the European Asylum Support Office and within the region, and that is important, but we could do so much more. And the public at home thinks that too. We know the conditions which lead to better integration – in terms of language, family, community, all of those things – but it is not everything and it does not mean that certain Member States with no real experience can stay inexperienced on the basis of their own prejudice and preference.

name: Diane James (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, the overwhelming surge in migration over these summer months, principally from conflict zones where EU interference was a major contributory cause, requires resolution – that is without doubt – but not resolution at any cost to provide a short—term fix. The European continent is now a magnet for this migration surge, with Italy and Greece at the forefront; we all know that. Yes, it needs addressing, but fast-track dispersal is just too high—risk given the global conflict and security situation that exists currently. Migrant well-being should not come at the cost of EU citizens’ well-being, specifically threats where potential terrorists – as we have already seen – can enter countries unhindered and unchecked and move around the continent, as will be the case with this mechanism. This is a short-term knee-jerk response to solving a problem with a quick fix rather than addressing the origins, including existing causal EU policies. That is what needs to happen.

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the most serious aspect of this indiscriminate reception policy is the proposal to institutionalise it, which is contained in this report and will have the sole result of making the ethnically homogeneous and culturally homogeneous Europe selected by centuries of history disappear forever.  Instead of intelligently providing reception and refuge centres in the countries of origin, in North Africa, far from Europe, Mrs Merkel's policies are being implemented, which is to host just under a million refugees, immigrants and carefully selected people. This is Mrs Merkel's good will – it is worth what she wants to go and choose her immigrants – and for this policy and for these results, Mrs Merkel is the first person responsible for opening europe's doors to millions of people, because it will be a message spread throughout Europe. Mrs. Merkel is responsible for creating racism again in Germany...  (The speaker was interrupted by the President)

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Madam President, the European Union and its governments, in alliance with the United States and NATO, having first set fire to Syria, North Africa and elsewhere for the sake of the interests of monopolies, are now pretending to be concerned about refugees and migration. They divide immigrants into legal and illegal, "good" refugees and "bad" immigrants for deportation and strengthen repressive mechanisms by paving the way for the criminal action of fascist racist hordes.  Dublin's 'à la carte' removal reveals that monopolies are "thirsty" for fabled workers. That is why there is no hiding the cause of refugees and migration, which is the rotten exploitative system itself, the one that breeds imperialist wars, interventions and poverty! Here and now, therefore, relief measures must be taken with funding and procedures for travel documents to the countries of destination of refugees and migrants must be implemented immediately. Imperialist interventions and operation EU NAVMED Force must be stopped. The Schengen Treaty, Europol, Frontex and the Dublin Regulation must now be abolished. Their action has proven to have turned the Mediterranean into a wet grave.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the decision formalised by the Council represents a timid step forward, which marks a partial awakening of Europe after the deafening silence of recent years. Finally, a solidarity mechanism is applied to distribute refugees among the Member States, but more could and should certainly have been done.  Firstly, the 40 000 refugees to be reallocated over the next two years, which in fact 32 000 have been identified to date, represent a drop in the ocean, according to the migratory flows recorded in recent months. That is why I hope that what the Junker Commission has said, for example the reference to 120 000 refugees to be allocated in an additional way, can finally materialise and be more sensitive within the Council. Furthermore, this cannot be based on mechanisms for voluntary membership of the Member States, but a compulsory and coercive mechanism must be found, which cannot also be limited to temporary mechanisms but must, in my view, be based on a permanent relocation system, changing the Dublin system once and for all.  That is why I hope that today's mosaic will be a piece of a mosaic in which Europe can once again become a protagonist, no longer silent and powerless, in dealing with an absolute emergency such as that of immigration. Through a policy that clearly confirms absolute solidarity with refugees, with those fleeing wars, from famine, but remaining intransigent towards economic migrants.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Three points: this decision of tomorrow is important, it is overdue, it is a sign of recognition of what countries such as Greece, Italy and other neighbouring countries have done. But it is a drop in the ocean. 40 000, that is roughly what flows to people every day, weekly in Greece.  Secondly, we know quite clearly that Dublin is dead and we need a permanent mechanism to replace Dublin. The European Parliament must be involved in this work. It cannot be the case – as has been the case up to now – that we are simply listened to, but we want to have a say, especially because we have seen what happens when we leave it to the Council: nothing comes out of it. And the big problem is that we don't have time anymore. We have good foundations. We decided on a good basis in April and we must not waste any time. We have had a summer of disappointment, where problems have not been resolved, insecurity has increased and people have become increasingly disappointed in Europe.  Thirdly, there are short-term problems: tens of thousands of people are on this Balkan route. Nobody does anything for them. They are exposed to the weather. I myself was in Idomeni and Gevgelija and saw that. The mafia is infiltrating this whole entity, and I believe, Commissioner, that you need to do something quickly and immediately. It is not a question of huge sums of money.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, I convey to this House the cry of anguish of the inhabitants of the Aegean islands. The impoverished Greece cannot stand other refugees and illegal immigrants. More than 230,000 refugees have flooded into Greece since the beginning of 2015. On Lesvos alone there are currently more than 10,000 refugees at a time when the island has only 80,000 inhabitants. In Kos the situation is explosive. In Samos, which I recently visited, but also in Chios the problems are acute. So immediate measures are needed here and now: firstly, the abolition of the Dublin III Regulation which turns Greece into a warehouse of souls; secondly, the application of the distribution clause for all refugees and illegal immigrants at European Union level and not just forty thousand as proposed by the Commission; thirdly, measures against Turkey which supports the slave trade, as hurriette revealed on 29 May 2015; , a brave increase in European Union funds to Greece, because the amounts provided are crumbs given the criticality of the situation;

name: n/a
text: Madam President, congratulations to the Commission and our rapporteur for the quality of the work that has been done. Like many of my colleagues and almost all of me, I hope in this House, I support a plan for the solidarity and equitable distribution of refugees according to the contributory capacities of the individual States.  I have three points. Firstly, as has already been said, the Dublin Mechanism, which is the institutionalisation of selfishness at the expense of the most border-exposed states, must be urgently reformed. Secondly, in terms of relocation and allocation, there is an amendment which was adopted on the initiative of our rapporteur, which stipulates that the preferences of the candidates to be relocated must be taken into account as much as possible. I think it is important because refugees are not parcels that can be dispatched mechanically. Thirdly, rather than letting the Member States, notably Greece and Italy, decide on the distribution of candidates between the different states, I believe that this task should go to the European Asylum Support Office (EASO), because that is the only way to ensure an impartial and coherent mechanism throughout the Union.

name: Ulrike Lunacek (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. First of all, thank my colleague, Ska Keller, for this report. It is really a good proposal, and I am glad that it is now also gaining a majority here. I also think it is good that Tomorrow, President Juncker will propose that another 120 000 refugees be taken in here and also distributed in the European Union. But that will not be enough. Four million people live in the refugee camps in the region, and millions are on the run in Syria itself. In other words, what we need is a system – the Dublin system no longer works, it must be replaced by a system of solidarity – legal access and a binding distribution of refugees. And you have to meet refugees on an equal footing. As many sections of the civilian population in Austria, Germany, but also in Hungary, have done in the past week, who have asked what they need and helped them to move forward. We need this: legal ways of meeting refugees on an equal footing and, quite well, opening up something like messages on the ground in order to make these legal routes possible.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I wonder what fantasy world the rapporteur lives in. She supports the idea of a binding redistribution mechanism, while at the same time wanting to renegotiate the Dublin Regulation. What are the consequences? If people have the choice to come to one of Europe's richest countries, Sweden, with huge benefits, what would make them choose any other country?  Sweden already has about 300 exclusion areas, where immigrants live in parallel societies. The rapporteur therefore sees this as a great opportunity, because it facilitates integration. How exactly is the integration of what in Sweden's case are formed no go zones, where the police avoid getting in? There are areas in Sweden where 56.2 percent of the inhabitants have a foreign background, significantly more than our neighbours. That is why we are opposed to this redistributive mechanism.

name: Vicky Maeijer (ENF).
text: – The debate on mass immigration has become a contest 'look at me being morally elevated', in which the media, politicians and other groups of people try to outslem each other. And anything to make the citizens feel guilty at home and justify the import of hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants. Because if you really want to raise your moral level, do you take in an asylum seeker yourself? That it is perhaps one of the 4,000 Terrorists of the Islamic State who have entered with these illegal immigrants is not mentioned and critical questions are out of the question.  But what are these mainly young men doing here? Why do they not help rebuild their own country? Why are the wealthy Gulf states and the safe Turkey not good enough? The answer is clear. Because there is no free house, free care and free money to get. That is why they are taking their chances on the water and the European Union is making it possible.  Instead of stopping this increase in asylum, the European Union is going to distribute illegal immigrants, and this Parliament even wants them to be able to choose a final destination in the near future. Who are you speaking for? Not on behalf of the majority of Dutch people who want to close the border and oppose taking in more refugees.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – Thank you, Madam President. Poland has no problem with immigrants. Poland has problems with immigrants who, as part of the implementation of the absurd Dublin doctrine, are kept in concentration camps and they want to escape from them – from Polish to Germany, to Austria and other countries. Why? Because there are much lower social benefits in Poland. If we abolished social benefits, then people would not come to Polish, nor to the whole of Europe, people who want to live on benefits. People who want to work are valuable. On the other hand, they are sent back to the country, and we are approached by people who do not want to work. This is an absurd policy that is flooding Europe with human rubbish. Let's be clear – human garbage that does not want to work. And America built power because it welcomed immigrants who wanted to work because they didn't give them any benefits. And we are destroying Europe. And this policy is a case of the collapse of Europe. Thank you for your attention.

name: La Présidente. –
text: I think your speaking time is largely over, Mr Korwin-Mikke, especially with this kind of talk.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE).
text: – You started your comment by saying that the debate came on time. Although you are not listening to me, you are dealing with your phone, I will tell you that this debate did not come in time, we are extremely late! At the moment, we are pretending to do something while not solving the problem, but complicating the situation further. This is basically a misguided solution. As far as the report is concerned, unfortunately, it is not timely. None of his numbers are timely. It was overwritten by the large number of refugees. The description of the situation is neither timely nor mentioning Hungary, even though my country has the largest influx of refugees in proportion to its population. What does this report propose? It is a quota of migrants who would move freely between the European Union's internal borders. They wouldn't stop where we send them, even if we wanted to send them to the right place, because they could change where they wanted to live at any time. I don't think that's the right thing to do. The correct solution, my fellow Members, is that we have once brought a regulation, and this regulation is currently in force. Our task is to comply with and enforce this regulation. If it does not work, as many have said, then let us propose to amend this Regulation. But as long as the regulation exists, it must be respected. And our borders, my fellow Members, must be protected. There is no other option, because then the security of Schengen and the European Union is at risk. And the source of the problem must be found at its roots, which is outside the European Union.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D).
text: – Hawnhekk illum qegħdin nitkellmu fuq l-Italja u l-Gre大ja, imma, il-fatt li dawk milquta, llum il-ġurnata huma l-Ungerija, l-Awstrija u l-Ġermanja yuri aktar minnatt qabel li din m'hiji issueex tal-Mediterran biss. Din m'hijiex problema li l-pajjiżi tan-naħa t'isfel tal-Ewropa biss iridu jindirizzaw. U dan ilna ngħiduh. Hija problema ta' hawk pajjiż u l-pajjiżi magħquda flimkien biss, jistgħu jibdew jindirizzaw dak li qedġ jiri. Fil-verità lanqas hija issue tal-Ewropa biss, imma hija issue globali li tirrikjedi kooperazzjoni internazzjonali biex anki jibdew ikunu indirizzati l-kunflitti li jeżistu. Illum qegħdin niddiskutu sistema, li tista' tkun il-bidu ta' politika Ewropea dwar il-migrazzjoni. Imma, minkejja dan, ikeertu mexxejja Ewropej baqgħu jirreżistu din is-sistema, u baqgħu jinsistu fuq sistema volontarja. L-istorja wrietna li mekkaniżmi volontarji i jaħdmux. Biżżejjed naraw x'ġara fil-każ tal-proġett pilota dwar ir-rilokazzjoni minn Malta, u hawnhekk l-appell tiegħi flower-mexxejja Ewropej, flower-Kunsill, allavolja mhumiex hawnhekk. L-istess dwar ir-regolamentazzjoni ta' Dublin li ilna ħafna nisimgħu li hemm bżonn ikunu riveduti, u nistaqsi kemm se ndumu nistennew ir-reviżjoni ta' dan ir-regolament li huwa falliment totali? Il-kriżi tar-refuġjati li qegħdin naraw illum i jidhirx li se tbatti fi żmien qasir. Għalhekk, hemm bżonn ta' mekkaniżmi li jaħsbu fit-tul għal dan, soluzzjonijiet Ewropej u soluzzjonijiet internazzjonali.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – The current wave of migration represents a milestone for a continent built on Christian foundations. A mass migration wave can change the shape of Europe. It is both an opportunity and a threat at the same time. However, we cannot ignore the large number of people fleeing the horrors of war – this war is waged by Islamic fundamentalists and waged on religious grounds, expelling many of their twies. However, it is clear that many people migrate here for other reasons. It is also true that we cannot and cannot accept everyone wholeheartedly. I consider it important to help all those who are in danger of life. I appeal to the countries of Central and Eastern Europe, which have their Christian roots, to prove that the values of the Gospel are not just empty words. However, it is not in our power – in the power of every country – to offer asylum to all people. I therefore consider it essential that Member States have the right to choose which refugees to accept. After all, it is the citizens of European countries who will share their neighbourhoods, their streets and their cities with them.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Mr Korwin-Mikke, they are not human garbage. This report was born because more than 800 people drowned on April 18, 2015. Mrs. Keller, thank you very much for your work. While this report was being drafted and discussed, Italy continued to recover bodies; other countries, too. They weren't human garbage. Yesterday, 7 September 2015, the representative of the Council, at an extraordinary emergency meeting with our LIBE Commission, said that the report does not have a realistic approach. The Council is not present here today. But even the number of 60 000 refugees who can be taken in has been surpassed by the reality which is unrealistic for the Council. This report calls for a common asylum system, not an emergency mechanism. What is unrealistic, Mr Avramopoulos, is to think that the Council is going to address this real problem, or to agree on a functioning asylum system that exceeds Dublin, or that all States are committed to compulsory form. Italy, Greece and other countries need real support, and we need a European defence policy in large war zones. Let everyone know that the Council expects public opinion to forget this issue.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, we hear from Germany, on the one hand, how he wants to generously accept all the refugees who come to Europe, and how these refugees can benefit the German economy. On the other hand, we hear voices from Germany after the distribution of refugees to countries where the public does not want these refugees and where they do not want to live either. To demand the distribution of refugees through mandatory quotas ignores the fact that all these refugees are heading to Germany for higher living standards, higher social benefits, ignoring the fact that in the Czech Republic and other countries no one wants these mandatory quotas. And I guarantee you that if you outvote the Czech Republic in quotas, it will only cause the vast majority of the public in the Czech Republic not to want to stay in such a European Union.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: – The hypocrisy and incompetence of the European Union and the institutions is left over on the issue of illegal immigration. You are even afraid of words: anyone who illegally crosses a country's borders is a smuggler. Don't confuse humanism with legitimacy. The Mediterranean and the Aegean have been transformed into a vast cemetery. One is the solution: the creation of "hot spots" in neighbouring countries with cooperation between the European Union and the UNHCR and an on-the-spot assessment of the refugees that the European Union and the US have created, after they have blooded half the planet.  Those who meet the criteria and need the countries of the European Union will travel legally and will not be stacked on rotten boats and rubber boats at the risk of their lives. The rest will be re-promoted to their countries of origin. In this way, the action of the slave traders stops immediately. The elements mentioned in this report have been overcome. In August alone, more than a hundred thousand illegally came to Greece. Greece of the crisis has proven its humanity and support, saving the lives of hundreds of people every day in the Aegean. But we have now reached our limit. The time has come for Europe to take responsibility.  Thanks.

name: Heinz K. Becker (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Although we are eagerly awaiting President Juncker's proposals tomorrow, I do not think that the discussion on the Keller report is untimely, because we can build on the developments that will be in the coming months. I would like to make a few points. For example, it is clear that it is not unimportant for the European Parliament to support the proposals for a binding quota system by a large majority. Secondly, that we can expect the quota numbers – fair quotas – to be respected and not to be undermined by an arbitrary choice on the part of the migrants to which country they want to go to. Furthermore, I believe that the main burden of those states also requires fair allocation. For example, it is Austria that has to bear a disproportionately greater burden than Italy, even if the public image is different.
