With respect for this report by Mrs Keller, I would also like to express my respect for the performance of the Commission, which has done a very good and committed job in recent weeks and months. I also think that the absence of the Council is almost at the level of cynicism that has also emerged in the budget cut of hundreds of millions of euros in neighbourhood aid, which I have come to light. I am sure that tomorrow everyone knows that Europe's governments are guilty of failing to implement the Commission's proposals in a targeted manner.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is time for truth for Europe. Whether or not Europe can regain coherence with its founding values on the basis of the principle of solidarity. This value is written in our treaties, we have learned this at great cost from the common history of Europeans, which has seen us refugees and migrants in their millions. My history as a migrant from my country of origin to Europe has changed precisely thanks to the encounter with this story, with a Hungarian refugee in Italy, Father Becketch. That meeting changed my life and without its unconditional reception today I probably wouldn't be here. Today's decision to adopt an initial extraordinary mechanism for the redistribution of refugees is a first step, albeit a partial one, based precisely on the principle of solidarity. Now let's go further. The principle of solidarity must become structurally the basis of the European Union's future common migration policy, our Europe, the lesson of solidarity with the refugees of so many European citizens. Let us go beyond national self-interest and try to build our own Europe, thanks to the Commission and also to the rapporteur.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the A migration of peoples of unimaginable proportions is sweeping us, millions are fleeing, some are fleeing war, others are fleeing poverty, and most are yet to come, thanks in part to our Chancellor Merkel. Our systems are collapsing. We in Europe need to rethink if we want to continue to recognise our continent, and we must help, but differently.  The new system must be called embassy asylum. Asylum applications are only to be made in our embassies, on the spot, close to home.  And the borders to the outside world are being closed. No more asylum applications on entry. Smugglers no longer deserve misery. Boats no longer capsize. Asylum grounds are much better examined at home and the procedures are becoming shorter. Incentives for poverty migrants are falling. And apart from better asylum, each country must decide for itself on an immigration law, sovereignly, without EU quotas.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Mr President, there will be a great debate tomorrow on the migration crisis. Today, if I dare say so, it is only a matter of sort of distributing 40,000 migrants who have arrived in Italy and Greece. Certainly these countries need to be helped, but they must be helped first to protect their borders, which are also Europe's external borders. They must also be helped to be able to sort between the real refugees and those who are only looking to lead an economically more favourable life than in their country of origin. They must also be helped to be able to identify possible jihadists who would mingle with these refugees. They must also be helped to return asylum seekers to a third country or to a safe country. I believe, however, that this aid cannot be the one proposed today, which is actually to offer a fantastic call for air that will not solve the problem of these 40,000 migrants but which, on the other hand, will bring in tens and hundreds of thousands more.

name: Monika Hohlmeier (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work he has First of all, now is not the time for the Member States to bash each other, it is the time for action. It is a time of crisis. Nor is it the time to go after a single Head of Government, such as Mr Orban, while suddenly being silent on other Heads of Government, such as those from Slovakia or the Czech Republic, who have made unspeakable comments. It is actually the time for Member States to act with each other rather than to act against each other. It is a time when we have to recognise that, with more than one million refugees, two million refugees, not individual Member States can act differently, but all must at least ensure minimum standards – that is, in Greece, for example, addressed to Mr Tsipras – at least for food, drink and a roof over their heads. People must not die of heat, they must be offered a bit of health care. It is now a time for us to reflect calmly on the Dublin system and perhaps to make a proposal that Cecilia Wikström and I actually made a few years ago, when we tried to get the Member States to use a crisis mechanism. Dublin normally works, but it does not work in the event of a crisis when one or two states are confronted with masses of refugees that they can no longer cope with on their own. Incidentally, we made the proposal four years ago. Perhaps it would have been better if we had accepted it at the time. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Barbara Spinelli (GUE/NGL)
text: Blue card question. Mrs Hohlmeier knows that Greece, which she accuses of not protecting enough and not protecting migrants, has been waiting all summer for the disbursement of funds that was to come from the Commission, and Commissioner Avramopoulos said this summer that the funds were not yet disbursed because there were still no hot spot or reception centres and so on, but these centres can only be built if the funds arrive. In short, my question is addressed both to Mrs Hohlmeier and to Commissioner Avramopoulos.

name: Monika Hohlmeier (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. My colleague, if Greece receives funds, it must also spend it on proper accommodation. Otherwise, the European Union will not be able to provide the appropriate funds. And secondly: food and drink, that is at least water and bread, offer at least a bit of accommodation and help the islands with the reception until we pass on. In any case, Germany accepts almost all refugees coming from Greece. Austria is also taking in refugees. Hungary has also taken in a large number of refugees. There are other states that have not done so. Therefore, please, let us work together and not always look for the culprit elsewhere.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, while for a long months the Member States represented in the Council – now absent – were discussing quotas, figures and numbers, Aylan's image alone, helpless and dead – and it was not human rubbish – on a beach outside the European Union has overwhelmed the hearts of millions of Europeans in order to stem the tragedy that has made the Mediterranean a mass grave under a sea of tears.  And yes, we need emergency mechanisms, such as this one designed by the Keller report on the basis of a consultation procedure in Article 78(3) TFEU. But much more is needed than that, because an emergency mechanism is not enough to re-emphasize 40,000 human beings , who are not rubbish – but rather need a long-term, binding mechanism capable of requiring Member States to 'retract' for the European Union as a whole to take over; a mechanism that ensures a fair and equitable distribution, and that signals to governments that they have not moved a finger and have meskinally resisted "portraying the" – because some have done so only when public opinion has pointed them out and some have not even then.  An exodus from the European Union portrays Europe, but it portrays above all the lousy state of the European Union, which is neither a shadow of what it said it was nor what it promised it would be.

name: Anders Primdahl Vistisen (ECR).
text: Mr President! There is a lot in this House about finding a European solution to the refugee crisis we are facing. However, it does not take into account at all the fact that there are already European agreements in place to ensure that situations such as those we are experiencing in Germany, Denmark, Sweden and elsewhere in Europe do not arise. We should have a common border through schengen cooperation, where migrants would have to be registered and asylum applications processed. We should have a Dublin 2 regulation that worked properly and where the first safe country was the place where the refugees were treated and given temporary residency if they needed protection.  Those mechanisms are not good, and as long as we cannot keep the agreements already concluded at European level, it is completely unrealistic to hope that new agreements can be concluded and maintained. That is why the only realistic response that the crisis looks like right now is the reintroduction of national border controls, because then individual Member States can at least get a handle on the refugee crises that have arisen throughout Europe.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the people of Europe – those in Germany, Austria, Hungary and also Sweden, for example – are writing a new page of our history. They are showing humanity and tolerance, values that unite us as Europeans. Germany is currently taking the lead, by virtue not of its economic power but of its moral status. It is time for the Member States to show solidarity and agree on a binding mechanism for sharing responsibility. The emergency relocation measure for 40 000 asylum seekers is a good step but it is not enough. We have to save lives and treat all those coming to Europe with dignity. But we cannot allow them all to stay. Every Member State should still carry out a humane and legally—certain individual assessment of all asylum seekers in accordance with our common rules within six months. Yes, citizens have legitimate concerns on how to cope with so many coming at the same time. We need to meet those fears with concrete solutions, not populism. Let us face it, the best way to deal with a new exodus in our time is to strengthen cooperation, join forces and support common institutions. It is time to reveal the true face of those who kidnap the asylum agenda, in an attempt to bring polarisation, isolation and national solutions by criticising everything and everyone without giving proposals. It is the opposite that is needed: we need more Europe. It is time to change the rhetoric. In the short-term, yes, refugees are a cost, but in the long-term Europe needs them. They are a benefit to our society. Refugees, welcome to Europe!

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D).
text: "I have heard some amazing things here in the last hour, but I would rather return to the report, this excellent report, and thank Mrs Keller for her work. I would like to say that this report has received very broad support in the LIBE Committee, which shows that it is not a question of political affiliation that we are debating here, but that our shared European values demand that we offer safer and more humane opportunities than before to those who save their lives. We need a mechanism that ensures solidarity not only with refugees, but also between Member States. I think it is particularly important that the report makes it clear that we see the current solution as a first step and we believe that a permanent and mandatory procedure for the redebuting of refugees should be built. It is also clear that assistance is needed not only Hungary, Greece and Italy, but also for all states in need. I think that Parliament, with this report, is sending a very clear signal, supporting a more effective, stronger and common European refugee policy. And I think it is now up to the leaders of the Member States to finally recognise shared responsibility after so much hesitation. After all, if this responsibility is not recognised, then they are deceithing from the basic idea of the European Union, and they are turning against it.

name: Geoffrey Van Orden (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I have compassion for those who have suffered great danger fleeing conflict and great sympathy for those people in those coastal areas of Italy and Greece who have borne the brunt of the current migration flow. We have a crisis, but I am afraid EU policy has made it worse. The Schengen open borders system has encouraged entry. The Commission plan to distribute large numbers of migrants across Europe is further incentive. Today it is 40 000, plus 120 000. How many more tomorrow? Over nine million people have left their homes in Syria. The people-traffickers are being enriched at the cost of human life. All this is happening at a time of raised threats of terrorism.  The first priority of EU policy should be the security and cohesion of our countries and the rights of our own citizens. Certainly, we need to relieve the pressure on Italy and Greece. Instead of making the problem worse we should focus on improving border security and a functioning system for the processing of migrants, including the return of those that are not genuine refugees.  We must help people fleeing persecution, but above all we must protect our democracies.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Mr President, in general, I consider this proposal to be a necessary response to the current migration crisis. I myself visited several refugee camps in southern Europe, Italy, Malta and other countries during the summer and the situation is very serious. I therefore also support that we seek some concrete solution and move from general proclamations to concrete steps. However, the European Union must not put pressure on Member States to take as many refugees as is the case in the proposal. The whole mechanism is built on volunteering. As it turned out, this mechanism is pass-through. An example is the Czech Republic, which has signed up to accept a similar number of refugees, which has been established by this mechanism. I'm sure he's not defending any responsibility. And if someone here is criticizing the Czech Republic, he should not only read the statement through the media, but should actually verify the facts about what the Prime Minister said or said, or look at the pages of the Cabinet Office, where all the documents are. I don't think the criticism is right. We really need to distinguish what anyone has said. Finally, I would like to say that populism needs to be divided and pragmatism needs to be divided. Not everyone who behaves populistally is pragmatic.

name: Anna Hedh (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I welcome the Keller proposal, even if it is too little and too late. The EU and all Member States must immediately show greater solidarity with people fleeing war and persecution. In order for us to be able to live up to the demands of human rights, all countries must assume their responsibilities. It is not sustainable for only a handful of Member States to accept refugees. A more even distribution is a must in order to create a sustainable European asylum system and for us to be able to help more people. If the redistribution is to work in practice, all Member States must actually comply with the EU legislation on asylum that they have signed up to. A redistribution under this proposal is only a first step. A permanent and binding system is needed. In the end, access to Europe must also be facilitated for those in need of protection. The Commission must urgently put forward proposals to create legal pathways to the EU. We cannot afford to wait while the refugees die on the way to Europe.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I welcome, in principle, the helpfulness shown in this report, this humanity towards these refugees, and that is why I will also vote in favour of this report, although I am unfortunately convinced that we will not, in fact, help the refugees. That is because these regulations are once again far too complicated. Europe lacks a coordinated overall approach to this area of refugees. The refugee crisis cannot be solved in the EU alone. We need a much larger approach to this. To this end, we must involve the neighbouring countries. Presumably, a coordinated concept must even be developed worldwide. This cannot happen overnight, but at some point we must take the first steps to do so.  However, it is also crucial not to set false incentives. In Germany, for example, people like to talk about a culture of welcome, which I think is wrong. We should be talking about an aid culture so that we can also help people and put that aid first and not put the wrong incentives.

name: Μιλτιάδης Κύρκος (S&D).
text: Commissioner, unfortunately the Council is not here and I fear that it is somewhere and she is shedding crocodile tears because this is not the first tragedy. The Mediterranean, from Lampedusa to the Asia Minor coast, is full of corpses.  - Does the Council deal in a meaningful way with the reception and treatment of refugees?  - Not because it simply places the burden on the backs of frontline states which, as the Commissioner is well aware, are failing to respond.  - Does the Council propose a permanent and binding mechanism?  - Not because it is left to the good will of the States, but they, with the bright exception of Germany, are unable to rise to the occasion. But even Germany could show a more European attitude, since for every 500,000 refugees, 350,000 pass through helpless Greece.  - Does the Council ensure that we don't have any more deaths?  - Not because we deal with refugees only after they reach European territory and not before.  I believe that three things are needed: immediate reinforcement of frontline states, realistically binding distribution key and legal and safe routes for refugees starting from Syria.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D).
text: Mr President, the urgent situation of the thousands of refugees who risk their lives to try to reach our continent requires a strong and common political response, a European response to the height of historical challenges which represent one of the greatest challenges to our values and our humanity.  We need these first relocation measures in favour of Italy and Greece to give substance to the solidarity we have so far sorely lacking. But, above all, we need a permanent and mandatory allocation mechanism to set all Member States on the path of sharing responsibilities. In this sense, I welcome the ambitious proposals that have recently been put forward by the German Chancellor and the President of the French Republic and which are moving decisively in the right direction. The Council of Member States must take all its responsibilities and commit itself, as the Commission is already doing. Finally, let us respond to the urgency of the situation with a dignified and solidarity collective action, because this is a matter of helping women, men and children who are just waiting for the right to live.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we all want the current emergency measures to succeed and wish to see both the suffering of migrants in overcrowded camps eased and the pressure on frontline Member States alleviated. But we are also aware that the scale of this migratory flow demands more than just dealing with the effects of catastrophes in neighbouring countries, and that thus far we have been unable to handle the problems it causes. There can be no long-lasting solution without comprehensive global measures to combat Islamist terror in the Middle East. What is also required is humanitarian assistance, safe zones close to the areas of conflict and well-targeted aid for trade and development for Africa. We must also determine what action is needed both in the European Union and in countries of origin. Our asylum system places a disproportionate weight on countries of arrival and final destination. The common European asylum system in all Member States is yet to be effectively implemented and we lack a list of safe countries that would enable us to better protect the most vulnerable, who need our help the most.

name: Soraya Post (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr We talk all the time about a refugee crisis. I would like to call the current humanitarian crisis a major political scandal, in which our Member States have clearly become coloured by xenophobic forces, which have actually managed to set the agenda through the media and also to steer the whole debate. Europe needs to think again. We must now show ourselves steady in our Constitution and the values on which it is based. We must not allow ourselves to be influenced by their debate. The need for rapid aid to Italy and Greece is not to be discussed. It is necessary. I am thinking, however, that there is enough scope to perhaps develop it to support the other countries outside the EU, such as Serbia and Macedonia. Then, of course, it is absolutely crazy, and we must tear up the Dublin Regulation. That is something we need to do in order to be able to receive a humane and legal certainty of refugees.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, it was clear at the beginning of the crisis that Greece and Italy could not be alone and could not carry the sheer gravity of this crisis, but some were closing their eyes at the time. It seems to me that even today they are closing their eyes and not aware of the fact that Europe can only jointly and on the principles of solidarity solve this huge crisis. Let us look to what Pope Francis said, after all, he called for every parish in Europe to receive at least one family. This is a good path, an indication of how solidarity and help must be created between us for those who need help. Here I want to emphasize something else. We have countries that are not members of the European Union and I mean Serbia and FYROM, i.e. Macedonia, which also suffer and have big problems because of refugees coming from war-affected areas. I think it is the duty of the European Commission and the European Union to help both Serbia and FYROM in this situation.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, we have already been dead for 2,800, according to UNHCR. Families and children crossing Europe, and what are we doing? Countries are fighting, not acting and have turned this crisis into an embarrassing auction. The right tells us not to put our emotions into this debate. Of course we put them, the outrage and shame we feel. In July, states were not even able to agree on the 40,000 refugees in relocation. We are surprised, Commissioner Avramopoulos, to tell us that the Member States have made a lot of effort, because, frankly, they have been constantly torpedoing their proposals and particularly the Spanish Government, whose attitude has been desponable. Please, a mandatory relocation mechanism already. Resettlement: UNHCR is asking us for 230,000 people. I hope that what the Commission is presenting tomorrow will be ambitious enough. A search-and-rescue operation at sea which has been requested by this European Parliament and has not yet been launched, with all the deaths we have had this summer, and enforcing human rights in countries like Hungary, which we are seeing absolutely intolerable attitudes. Act, because if you don't act, history will condemn you.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, we have a crisis, a terrible crisis with great human cost. Now is not the time for weak politicians to take panic measures based purely on emotion. We have a situation where there are war-torn countries that we helped to destroy. We have people traffickers making a fortune from dealing in these suffering people. We have deaths caused by people encouraged to travel to the EU.  So what do we need to do? Well why do we not tackle the people traffickers? Why do we not stop the root cause? Why do we not stop interfering in other people’s countries and helping their destruction? And why do we not make it clear that we will allow genuine asylum seekers but we cannot allow everyone, so there is no need or motivation for people to come en masse and risk their lives this way.  Knee-jerk surrender of our borders is not the answer to this current crisis. Calm, thought-through, strong solutions are the way forward.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: –One of the main elements of the phenomenon of so-called psychological abuse and psychological terror is that one party forces the other to feel constant remorse and guilt without clearly telling us what is wrong and what the expectations are, what are the rules. We Hungarians are now in this situation with regard to and against the European Union. We'd like to know what's expected of us, what they want. If, for a little while, the Commissioner could listen, I would ask him – and, by the way, Mrs Keller, the rapporteur – to inform hungary on the one hand and the 500 million EU citizens on the other hand whether, ultimately, it is wrong for us to try to protect the European Union's external border? So we're expected to give up all kinds of defenses? Let the expectation be clear, let it be clear what they want from Hungary.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, let me start by telling you that you are right. As I said in the beginning, the relocation scheme is only one part of the comprehensive approach as described in the agenda of migration. Ms Sargentini, Ms Wikström, this House has always had a very strong opinion about solidarity in practice. We agree. I agree with you, and we are working towards the same goal. You have mentioned the Council; allow me to be optimistic and confident that the Member States will soon take brave decisions. The challenge we are facing requires it. Mr Díaz de Mera, this House – the European Parliament – will be co-legislator for the permanent relocation mechanism. Even concerning the emergency mechanism, which – as the name itself reveals – had to be adopted urgently, the Commission did take the opinions expressed by Parliament into account. I am grateful both for the suggestions and for the support of this House. Many of you have referred to the need to revise the Dublin Regulations. I would like to stress that many of the measures that the Commission is proposing recognise in practice the need to act above what Dublin foresees. Regarding its possible revision, as I promised at the very beginning, a thorough assessment will be done in the course of 2016. Then we will decide the route to follow, the way ahead. Mr Deprez, would you agree? Indeed, EASO and liaison officers from different Member States will be fully involved in the selection procedure. Let me remind you that migration will be the main point of President Juncker’s State of the Union speech tomorrow morning, after which we will continue our discussion in detail. Allow me now to switch to Greek, since I was asked by some Greek deputies about the situation in Greece. Ms Spinelli asked me a question about the financing.  Within a short period of time the government, through a prime minister, pledged to proceed quickly with the necessary procedures.  I am pleased to inform you that these have been completed. Greece has appointed the managing authority responsible for managing the funds. You know from your experience that when money is made available in a country, there must be a managing authority. This was only communicated to us today. Greece has also requested emergency funding to meet immediate needs and this funding starts immediately. Greece is also accelerating the launch of the hot-spot in Piraeus, from where experts will rush to those islands where aid is needed. Reception areas are installed on the islands which are main gateways. Greece also called for the activation of the civil protection mechanism. I repeat that these are prerequisites, not only for Greece but for any country that needs the help of the European Union. I would like to take this opportunity to tell you that on this major and important issue of unprecedented proportions, which is perhaps the biggest crisis we have faced since the Second World War, Europe has not been apathetic. From the very first moment, as you may recall those of you who are members of the committees with which I had the honour of working at the beginning of my term of office, we made commitments and in record time on European data the Commission has completed its work and tabled the new European agenda on migration. It is up to the Member States to implement it. Today, during the debate, much has been said about the responsibility of the Member States.  The new agenda on migration is the framework. As I said a moment ago, it is only a matter of hours before you learn about a new package, in addition to what you already know, and I refer to all ten points of the action plan that we adopted and announced some time ago.  Taking the initiative, we moved quickly forward, but we were caught up, it is true, by these dramatic developments that accelerated the events. At this time, however, we must all demonstrate in practice both our solidarity and our responsibility - two basic principles governing the functioning of the Union. Solidarity is not only a moral concept; It is a concept that defines our internal functioning from the very beginning and is enshrined in the Treaty. We must prove this in practice: solidarity between us, responsibility of the Member States but also solidarity with those unfortunate people who, in their quest to escape war, the destruction of civil war, persecution, have chosen a very difficult and dangerous and, in many cases, deadly journey to reach our own great country, Europe. We will continue in one direction, on this path towards tackling the crisis, which unfortunately will not be solved overnight, but will require many efforts for many years perhaps. We'll work together. I'm not hiding that I'm personally. I am grateful to the European Parliament for supporting this policy from the very beginning, demonstrating in practice its sensitivity to the humanitarian dimension of the whole issue and its responsibility to lead us - through dialogue - to make the right decisions. Thank you again, Mrs Keller, for your excellent recommendation on dealing with this important issue.

name: Ska Keller
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I am very happy to see that there is great unity here to say that we do have a humanitarian crisis and we need to act on it, now. There are people fleeing for very good reasons – from wars, from conflict, from persecution – and let us never forget that the majority of all refugees worldwide are not here, they are in Lebanon, as I mentioned earlier, they are in Turkey, around two million refugees in Turkey alone, they are in Pakistan, they are in so many other countries, let us not forget about Chad, the refugees there, or in Kenya.  We are actually talking about a very small proportion of worldwide refugees that make their way to Europe and we, as a strong, as a rich region, need to do our share in helping those people. Those refugees are indeed human beings, they are like you and me, as has been mentioned before, and we are just lucky not to be in their shoes.  It is EU law but it is also human sense to help those people, and that is all we ask for today. People all over Europe have shown us how to do that, how to show empathy, how to show solidarity – and relocating 40 000 people from Italy and Greece is not a big task. If we fail in that small but important task, then how are we going to succeed in other tasks that lie ahead? Because we do indeed also need to look at structural problems, we need to act together on much more than just relocating 40 000. But let this measure be the start of a rights-based, fair and common asylum policy in solidarity with all Member States and in solidarity with the refugees.  Let me thank all the shadow rapporteurs and groups that have been very kind and very helpful in bringing this report through in a very speedy manner and in making this a success, and in also, together with the Commission, in this part at least, in showing the Council that they should act up, that they should bring together the 40 000, and more.

name: Preşedinte. –
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place tomorrow. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. The extraordinary process that has led to this hasty vote today is a clear example of the lack of democracy in this Europe and of the continued exploitation that the left is fuelling with regard to the issue of migration. I am very much in favour of the principle of the distribution of migrants in quotas and I am in favour of their redistribution among the Member States. This decision, however, deals with the problem of immigration in a completely superficial way: just think that Europe not only does not distinguish between economic migrants and refugees, but that in dealing with the central issue of relocation, it will not take into account the arrivals of illegal immigrants prior to its entry into force. In short, Europe will not take account of almost all the landings in 2015 and therefore does not introduce the certainty of returns. For all these reasons, I believe that Europe is once again far from the reality and needs of its citizens and, what is worse, ignores the social implications of its inefficiencies.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. – Dear Mr President, Commissioner Mogherini, I am firmly opposed to the mandatory nature of quotas and the distribution of refugees on a quota basis. This policy directly violates the sovereignty of each EU Member State, controls its own borders and decides which people it can place on its territory and which cannot.  The Commission's proposal is hypocritical because deciding which country this country should go to, not that refugee, discriminates against themselves. The standard of living is very different between member states and I do not think that you can force a refugee to stay in Bulgaria, Hungary or Romania.  The current approach is wrong because in practice the EU cannot yet clearly distinguish economic immigrants from genuine refugees. Before the summer, we talked about 40,000 refugees, today about another 120,000. And tomorrow? The quota principle of redistribution of refugees is not a solution to the refugee wave. This is a temporary measure that will only prompt even more refugees to seek asylum in the EU and addresses the consequences. The real solution to the problem must be aimed at quelling outbreaks of immigration, i.e. the EU must focus on normalising the situation in the Middle East and neutralising Islamic State.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. Europe, following the decision formalised by the Council, has taken a step forward after years of silence on the subject of migration. But the step is not enough and more must and should have been done. The migration emergency must be managed with a lasting and not temporary solution because today's migratory flow is probably the tip of the iceberg. At last, a solidarity-sharing mechanism is in place between the Member States, but at the same time Dublin III urgently needs to be reviewed.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – In the European Parliament, Brussels UKIP MEPs voted to uphold Geneva Convention on Refugees to reduce the draw factor for migrants towards Europe thus saving lives. The party also voted to stop the UK being financially liable for not agreeing to mandatory placement of migrants in the UK. The new emergency legislation which now goes to the next European Council meeting means that states in the Schengen Area can vote by qualified majority voting. Countries such as Hungary, Austria and the Czech Republic which are opposed to taking in more migrants could be forced to do so by Germany, Italy and France. Germany seeks to offload the consequences of such an ill—judged, illiterate and incoherent policy by forcing Member States to take migrants, bear the costs involved and fundamentally dig Germany out of a self—created financial, social, humanitarian and political fiasco.

name: Preşedinte. –
text: The next item is the debate on Tamás Deutsch's report, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development, on 'Investment for Employment and Growth: promoting economic cohesion, european Union" [2014/2245(INI)] (A8-0173/2015) and kerstin Westpral's report, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development, on the urban dimension of EU policies ((2014/2213(INI)) (A8-0218/2015).

name: Tamás Deutsch
text: Artist. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Dear Commissioner, Dear Colleagues, The European Commission's cohesion reports are milestones in the history of cohesion policy. This is no different with the Sixth Cohesion Report, which examines the EU's regional development policy in the light of the devastating economic and financial crisis and closely links it to achieving the europe 2020 objectives. Cohesion policy is the EU's number one investment policy, the most controlled and valued expenditure area in the EU budget, with a budget of more than EUR 350 billion for the period 2014-2020. Its effectiveness and indispensableness are particularly evident in crisis situations. After all, cohesion policy can offer a real and immediate solution, even in exceptional situations, for growth and job creation. Against this background, I would like to underline here, at the very beginning of what I have to say, that cohesion policy must continue to play an important role beyond 2020, and that economic catch-up and solidarity within the Union cannot be abandoned. In my report, there was an increased emphasis on the idea of putting an end to the recurring liquidity problems in regional development policy. We need to eliminate the very significant payment arrears. By the end of 2014, €24.8 billion in payment arrears had accumulated, undermining the effectiveness, credibility and sustainability of cohesion policy. The second idea, which was emphasised in my report, is to strengthen the original role of cohesion policy. The objective of cohesion policy, as set out in the Treaty, is to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion in all EU regions, in particular less developed regions. It is understandable that the objectives of cohesion policy have evolved over time and that the policy has become increasingly closely tied to the union's current strategy. At the same time, I believe it is important to give greater prominence to the original objective of cohesion policy, to reduce development differences and to ensure that the contribution to the union's current overall strategy remains compatible with reducing regional disparities. The third thought that I highlighted in my report is the future of cohesion policy. 2019 will be decisive, as a newly elected Parliament and a new Commission will have to cope with the final tasks of the Europe 2020 strategy, the development of a new multiannual financial framework and the creation of a framework for post-2020 cohesion policy. The debate on the cohesion policy of the future must therefore be started now. In addition to the three main ideas, I would also like to briefly address some of the defining aspects that have received increased attention in my report. I consider it important to take measures to ensure efficiency, simplification and results orientation. I would like to highlight the importance of simplification, as a significant number of irregularities result from opaque standards and requirements. Reducing the administrative burden on beneficiaries would be a huge step towards increasing efficiency. Results orientation is reinforced by thematic concentration, but the concretisation of objectives also requires the preservation of sufficient flexibility in order to provide answers tailored to the needs and problems of the regions. In my report, particular attention will be paid to the issue of unemployment, in particular youth unemployment and the ability of small and medium-sized enterprises to create jobs. Finally, I believe that the territorial dimension received little attention in the Sixth Cohesion Report, despite being an indispensable tool for strengthening economic, territorial and social cohesion. Dear colleagues, as I drafted my report, I have been able to work very constructively with the shadow rapporteurs from other political groups, with the Members who tabled the amendments – I would like to thank you for this cooperation here and now. The Sixth Cohesion Report is an excellent opportunity to give new impetus to EU cohesion policy and to draw attention to its effectiveness and usefulness. I would like to reiterate that, after 2020, EU cohesion policy must continue to play an important role and eu budgetary resources for policy should not be reduced. Only a properly funded cohesion policy can ensure eu solidarity, catch-up of less developed regions, the creation of new jobs and the development of the economy. Thanking you for your attention, I look forward to your comments with interest.

name: Kerstin Westphal
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done on this report. Three out of four people in Europe live in cities and suburbs. Cities are indeed engines of growth, and that is why they are particularly vulnerable, on the one hand to social problems, but on the other hand to environmental problems. In fact, 50% of ERDF funding will be invested in urban areas over the next few years. Good development in our urban areas is fundamental to the future of Europe. I would like to emphasise very clearly that the term 'city' must be broad. This is not just about big cities, it is also about small and medium-sized cities, and it is about all cities. But it is also about rural areas. We are not against rural areas. On the contrary, the surrounding area is important for the development of cities. The European debate on urban policy has been going on for over 20 years. I therefore very much welcome the fact that the Commission has launched an 'urban agenda'. In my report, I call for the urban dimension to become an integral part of all European policies. We need to think about cities all the time and everywhere, in all policy areas. Precisely because so many policy areas affect the lives of cities, there are also various measures and funding opportunities, which are often not coordinated. This is very often very confusing and very unhelpful for cities. That is why we want a task force within the existing structure of the Commission, such as a kind of 'one-stop shop'. This will enable us, on the one hand, to ensure greater internal coherence in all projects involving cities and externally to ensure that there is something like contact persons. For many cities, European funding and European standards are still a book with seven seals. In addition, cities need to have more say. Their opinion and expertise must be better heard in European legislation, and from the outset. Those who have to take care of the implementation in the end should also be able to have their say right from the start! What is also particularly important to me in the discussion is that a European urban agenda should not be confused with the fact that there are new requirements. I don't want any additional burdens on cities. We want a kind of "toolbox" for cities. Cities need contacts, but cities also need platforms for exchange. What we do not need are new requirements. These would be very difficult to implement in practice. That is why we want any new European legislation to look at the consequences for cities, which are often very diverse. In our report, we do not even try to emphasise any challenges or, on the other hand, to make a particularly small statement. Every city is different. Ladies and gentlemen, I think it is a great pity that the mission letter from President Juncker to the Regional Commissioner makes no mention of urban policy. In this regard, we urgently need someone in the College who explicitly makes urban policy. The Commissioners for Digital, Transport, Energy, Social Affairs – they all have ideas for cities. What we need is coordination, a person, a kind of 'Mister or Misses urban policy' in the Commission. I think it would be nice and good if that were the Regional Commissioner, Mr Creu, who will then have to be given the powers accordingly. But I think it can also be a vice-president who explicitly takes care of, organizes and coordinates urban policy. That is what our cities in Europe need!

name: Corina Crețu
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would first like to begin by thanking the rapporteurs, Mrs Westphal and Mr Deutsch, and, of course, the Committee on Regional Development, for these excellent reports, which bring to the heart two major issues for cohesion policy: the sixth report on cohesion and, of course, the urban dimension. Cohesion policy, as you know, is the European Union's main source of investment. Together with the national co-financing side, it will mobilise more than EUR 630 billion in the 2014-2020 funding period, with the aim of supporting efforts by Member States and regions to implement structural reforms and laying the foundations for a sustainable recovery.  In many Member States, particularly those facing a reduction in income and an increase in social spending, european Union funding has become the main source of public investment. We have economies in the European Union, where our funds contribute almost 85% of all public investment in these countries. Our objective now, as Mr Deutsch's report also shows, is to ensure that these funds reach people as quickly as possible and generate growth and jobs as soon as possible. In this respect, I am pleased to say that almost all cohesion policy programmes for the funding period have been adopted and the corresponding pre-financing amounts have already been transferred - there are only four operational programmes to adopt by the end of the year.  Now, sure, the key word is implementation. We must act at all levels - national and European - to ensure that these programmes are translated into quality projects capable of generating economic growth and creating new jobs. The operational programmes adopted will certainly meet this challenge, as they are results-oriented, all programmes offer a wide range of indicators and objectives that allow us to quantify expectations from our investments. These programmes must also respect a number of ex ante conditionalities, which are essential to enable Member States and regions to better exploit the potential of funds, and last but not least, these programmes have been specifically designed to contribute to the Union's most important priorities: job creation, investment and prosperity, the Digital Single Market or the Energy Union and climate change.  I assure you that we, the European Commission, will closely monitor the implementation of the new programmes. We are doing everything necessary to help Member States implement these programmes effectively at national, local and regional level in support of beneficiaries. They are the key actors in cohesion policy, which identifies, selects and implements projects financed with European money, thus making possible real changes for the better, which matter and which are seen in the daily lives of European citizens. That is why we are preparing a number of actions to support them in their day-to-day work. Of these measures, I would now like to recall only a few points: facilitating the exchange of best practices among those in charge of the implementation of cohesion policy (we have 24 000 workers with European funds in all Member States, many have already gained massive experience and I believe that this exchange of best practices is essential to move forward) , organising seminars on State aid or financial instruments or starting joint actions with the Court of Auditors with a view to improving the public procurement system. Of course, the responsibility for using these instruments lies almost exclusively with national, regional and local authorities. Like the rapporteur, Mrs Kerstin Westphal, I would also like to congratulate you on this report on the urban dimension. Like you, I sincerely believe that, just as the major challenges of society are also found in cities and functional urban areas, we can also find the right solutions there. I share your view: we need to pay more attention to this urban policy. We have already had a meeting with all the mayors of capitals in Vienna, and also a few months ago, before the holiday, we organised the biggest event in Brussels related to small and medium-sized cities, because, as you said, it is very important. Of course we are not addressing directly, but through operational programmes, basically what you say is happening: we address the problems of cities. There is also this subject of subsidiarity, you know very well that many cities and some national governments are opposed to having a separate lye, but I think it is our duty to develop this urban agenda that you were talking about.  I want to assure you that the new programmes already contain a set of innovative instruments and clear provisions to ensure massive involvement and more sustained support for urban areas, based on partnership and the principle of decentralisation. We estimate that at least EUR 80 billion from the European Regional Development Fund will be invested directly or indirectly in urban areas. Specifically, EUR 15 billion will be directly managed by cities as part of sustainable urban development strategies.  This is the first time that, with the help of the regulations that you have approved here in the European Parliament, we have this mutual confidence in providing cities directly with budgets for investment. I believe, indeed, as you say, that we can and must do more. As I was saying, we are preparing the EU's urban agenda, we want to help mobilise the potential of cities, which will become the promoters of job creation, social inclusion and sustainable development. Of course, you know very well that we are working on this to ensure better coordination of eu actions and synergies in this area. We have already established a public consultation, organised, as I said, a series of conferences and laid the foundations for an agreement from all Member States.  I am pleased to note that the Presidency of Luxembourg and also the Dutch Presidency place a great deal of emphasis on urban policy, and I would like to assure you of the European Commission's readiness to work with you on all the issues raised in both reports. As you know, the time allocated for intervention is limited, so I will end for the moment and I am definitely looking forward to the debate and dialogue with you on these issues.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. Mr President, cohesion policy is linked to the principles of the European Union and in particular to solidarity, which is a reason for the existence of the European Union itself. With a view to bridging the gap between private and public spending, cohesion policy is becoming even more urgent because of this economic crisis that we are experiencing. We call on the European Commission to create a coherent and more effective investment framework.  That is why I am focusing on two key points, Commissioner. Firstly, the close interconnection of funding with the budgetary and macroeconomic adjustment of the Member States essentially reverses the logic of solidarity on which cohesion policy was based and at the same time counters its regional character and will therefore have a negative impact on the achievement of its objectives. Instead, we propose to exclude funding. I shall end with a second point, Mr President, to say that the result of the ideological opposition of some conservative circles was the fact that we did not have a report from the Committee on Finance.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – Thank you very much, Mr President. Recent years have shown that cohesion policy implemented by the European Union has proved itself in a period of economic collapse. It mitigated the effects of the sharp decline in public investment and ensured stability for the regions through an influx of funds at a time when access to finance was hampered. Cohesion policy funds accounted for nearly 60% of public investment in the countries covered by cohesion policy during the crisis.  So if we see the regional disparities that have been widening in recent years, we must also remember that they would have been even greater had it not been for the Structural Funds. Now that the economy is starting to stabilise and grow again after the economic crisis, we must ensure that the Structural Funds are spent as efficiently and efficiently as possible. Hence my call on all Member States to implement cohesion policy smoothly at national level. In the face of such high unemployment, especially among young people, every day of delay is causing social damage. It is also important that the European Commission tackles late payments. Given that the costs of these delays hit small and medium-sized enterprises generating the majority of new jobs the most, it is legitimate to say that every day of delay worsens the situation on the European labour market. Thank you.

name: Evelyn Regner
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work EU policies and urban policy are not two shamheads that coexist. No, it is becoming increasingly important to improve the coherence of EU policies with an impact on Europe's cities. As the rapporteur, Kerstin Westphal, has already said: 72% of Europe's citizens live in cities and urban areas. Two-thirds of GDP is generated in cities: that is, three call signs for the Commission's tasks!  In view of the major economic and social, but also humanitarian, challenges facing Europe, it is important to address them where they arise, namely in Europe's cities, in urban areas. That is why it is so important to involve representatives from the cities themselves in the whole of EU policy-making.  From an employment point of view, I would like to call on the Commission to review the possibility of greater budgetary flexibility for cities, particularly with regard to public expenditure to combat unemployment, especially youth unemployment, poverty and social investment. As we can see, not all means of combating youth unemployment are being exhausted. Why not, for example, consider making these funds available directly to cities, directly for projects, instead of letting the money be sumbed more or less, as I say in Viennese?  A future EU Urban Agenda should also consider the issue of combating gender discrimination and include the promotion of equal opportunities. I am thinking of gender budgeting. As a Viennese in particular, I can tell them wonderful examples that would really be worth analysing at European level. That is why I call on the Commission to set up a network for the exchange of best practice examples on gender budgeting.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – Commissioner, the economic crisis has undeniably very serious coincidences in the cohesion of the European Union in the fields of industry, energy and research. However, in order to solve the problems, we must admit that the neoliberal measures of harsh austerity have contributed to the deindustrialisation of the South, to the deregulation of industrial relations, to the breakdown of the social state, to the sell-off of public wealth, but also to the closure of many small and medium-sized enterprises and to the large increase in unemployment, especially for young people. New policies are therefore needed in order to achieve real economic social and territorial cohesion in the Union. Measures must be promoted to boost the real economy, to promote growth and to create new quality jobs. It is important to support public investment but also to pay attention to the states most affected by the economic crisis. Many of these are mentioned in the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy and we expect them to be taken into account, because unless a development social policy is promoted immediately, then the Union will never succeed in reducing major economic, social and territorial disparities.

name: Silvia Costa
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Culture, Youth, the Media and Sport. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I must say that we all recognise today how culture and cultural heritage, cultural tourism, the cultural, creative and audiovisual industry are an asset in economic development and social cohesion, including for new quality employment. But you know – because you were in Parliament – that it was to Parliament's credit that we included these aspects in the original proposal on cohesion that contained no reference to these issues.  Today I ask you to ensure that programmes at national and regional level contain these indications and push them forward for what is also a challenge – for example, the digitalisation of cultural heritage rather than the cultural and creative industry. We have asked as a committee for a review of the EUR 5 million limit adopted by the European Commission for fixed investment projects in equipment and infrastructure for culture and tourism; many countries have objected to this and it would be good to leave more flexibility.  Another key issue is the objectives in education, education and lifelong learning, where the Structural Funds can also give a great deal to major infrastructures and also to the link between digitalisation and education. I believe that this cooperation with the Social Fund and the Structural Funds is absolutely essential.

name: Julie Girling
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteurs. For the Committee on Women’s Rights (FEMM), it is important that gender issues are treated seriously in the area of cohesion policy, because this represents a very significant slice of EU expenditure. Women are essential to the success of any regional policy.  We have focused in our report on some of the challenges facing women in the labour market. Historically, women are more adversely affected by unemployment than men. The gender pay gap should be narrowing rapidly, but it is not. Women are still struggling for equality of opportunities in science and technology, as the Vozemberg report – which we will also be voting on tomorrow – shows. This must improve. Single mothers have additional difficulties in all these areas. The FEMM opinion takes the perspective that job creation is the objective, not the activity. We voted for an opinion that proposed measures and conditions that will assist job creation.

name: Jan Olbrycht (PPE).
text: – Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. First of all, I would like to congratulate Mrs Westphal on the report, which expresses Parliament's views, but I would point out that this report ends with very specific remarks and expectations towards the Commission. In this report, the European Parliament appreciates what has already been done in the past, as well as the issues in the 'Cities of Tomorrow' report, as well as the actions on the urban dimension in 2014-2020, and appreciates that the European Commission has taken action on the 'Urban Forum', regular meetings and so on. At the same time, however, this report also makes it very clear that we expect the declarations made by the European Commission to be turned into action. This means, for example, that the issue of innovative urban activities, i.e. 0.2% RDF, will be completed.  We also expect some actions to be integrated. We have the feeling that, for example, smart cities, 'smart cities', are very much supported in the Commission, but we do not see too much how this is coordinated with issues relating to urban transport, environmental protection in cities, social issues in cities and so on. We are very much feeling the lack of coordination at European Commission level on the issue of cities. We expect it to be an urban policy in the future, but for today we need a clear and clear message, not just the declarations of some Commissioners.

name: Constanze Krehl
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for the work she has done. The new cohesion policy has started, and that is a good thing for the regions of this Union. It is also important that we give cities more support in their challenges. It is also important that regional policy should be used as efficiently as possible in order to support investment in sustainable development and the creation of good jobs. Allow me to make a slightly different comment: more than a third of the European budget is spent on cohesion policy. This is a sign of immense solidarity between the regions of the European Union. But we also need this solidarity in other situations. We need them, for example, in welcoming the many refugees who are now coming to Europe. Here, too, solidarity is needed, and solidarity cannot be a one-way street. Cohesion policy is really a good example of this. Please also follow this solidarity in other areas. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – I was wondering what makes you think that economic growth and drive can be better delivered by the ideas of EU Commissioners than by leaving the taxpayers’ money actually in the taxpayers’ hands and allowing entrepreneurs within cities to drive that growth? What evidence do you have that EU Commissioners are better at doing this than businessmen?

name: Constanze Krehl (S&D)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, I am surprised that you are asking this question, I know, because we are creating a framework that we have negotiated with the regions that we negotiated in Parliament, which we negotiated with the Committee of the Regions.  We are only creating a framework. The decision as to what actually happens in the regions is taken by the regions themselves! That is the uniqueness of this very regional policy, and I know that the regions in your Member State have also benefited very successfully in the past and will continue to benefit in the future. That is why it is a good reason to promote and support this cohesion policy here and to continue to do so in the future.

name: Andrew Lewer
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the ECR Group recognises the practical value of regional development funding and supports efforts to ensure it is spent more efficiently. This sixth report clearly calls for more to be done there. It is not a clean bill of health. I and others in the group are not wholly convinced that there is as full an understanding as there should be: this funding is not a revenue substitute, nor is it intended to be for more than a third of a century, as has been the case.  Furthermore, I do not believe that part of the agenda behind the – in other respects unobjectionable – urban policy is desirable either, especially – and I quote – ‘to improve the democratic legitimacy of the European project’. Best practice and cooperation – yes. I welcome those elements; but new layers of control towards a federal project – no.

name: Matthijs van Miltenburg
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Thank you to the rapporteurs for their excellent work. European cohesion policy is really the most important policy area for investment in our economy. These investments provide economic growth and jobs. For new jobs and for economic strength. In its sixth cohesion report, the Commission refers relatively little to the territorial approach. This mainly concerns cross-border cooperation. It is precisely in these European border regions that there are enormous opportunities, in particular for increasing labour mobility. The challenge would be to create a single real European labour market where there are still 28 different labour markets. We can therefore expect the European Commission to achieve a genuine European territorial agenda and to be reported extensively in the Seventh Cohesion Report. There is also a major role to play, when it comes to this territorial agenda, for our urban areas. These are - as Mrs Westphal quite rightly said - the engines of our economic growth. These are precisely the places where solutions are devised for social tasks. Whether, for example, smart mobility in those cities or sustainable forms of energy generation. It's being conceived in the cities.  These are also the places where European regulations, where European policies land and must be implemented. Let us therefore involve the cities better in the development of European policies. Let us therefore involve the cities in the preparation of the policy. I hope that the Commission will get a better eye on the cities in the coming years and I hope that the Commission will actually take up the challenge of shaping a real European urban agenda in terms of content. Because with a real European urban agenda, we are actually empowering European cities, and that makes a strong Europe.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, the report has positive elements and it is not the least of them to recall the importance of cohesion policy and to underline its objectives, all of which are necessary.  The question is whether the Commission and the Member States are really going to be involved in a new approach to cohesion which, instead of patching, effectively combats regional disparities, which in too many cases continue to increase. And I am not reluctant to add that the economic system and austerity policies are no strangers to this, but responsible for that trend.  The question is whether we will continue to accept the dismantling of the productive fabric in some parts of the Union. The question, of course, is the negative impact, in my opinion, that will link cohesion to macroeconomic conditionality, causing only a few regions to continue to move forward and develop. The question is whether state filters will continue to condition priorities and projects where regional and local entities, and social actors, could do better if they were integrated from the outset into the decision-making process.  I welcome the report's importance of cross-border cooperation, which the Commission and much of the Council seemed to be forgetting, when they are supposed to be the flag of Community spirit and key in cohesion policies , of course it is fundamental for my country, the Basque Country.  It is true that we can have a good dialogue with you, but this may not be the best place to trust the Council , as you have just done, because it is still defunct of this House.

name: Monika Vana
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work The report on the urban agenda is a very important signal for the appreciation of cities and takes account of the increasing importance of cities, as previous speakers have said. This is also high time, because cities are engines of social, economic and sustainable development. Now the fine words should be followed very quickly by deeds. On the one hand, as Mrs Westphal has already said, this must also be actively supported by the institutional upgrading of cities in the institutional structure, but also by greater consideration of EU policies in general for the real problems of cities. I confess that we Greens would have preferred a broader approach to the report, for example, as Mrs Regner has already mentioned, to include a gender perspective, but also to address real challenges – for example, one of the key issues facing cities, namely their financial capacity to act. Like Mrs Regner, I come from Vienna, one of the wealthiest cities in the world. Vienna, too, is feeling the effects of the Stability and Growth Pact massively and is finding it increasingly difficult to meet the active challenges, such as rising unemployment, working poor, poverty through investment.  We must look at this and see that EU policy actually supports cities and does not create new problems here the other way round. In other words, it is now the Commission's turn to take up this strong signal from the European Parliament and to bring the urban agenda to life. And we are all called upon to translate words into deeds.  (The speaker refused to answer a question about the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to make two quick comments on the reports. One concerns the urban agenda, while I welcome the reference to key demands such as the truly integrated approach to territorial development and the concrete application of the partnership principle, I would have expected a bolder report on a problem with a transnational dimension. I am talking about the regeneration of historic centres.  In view of the forecast of a population increase in cities between now and 2050, it was necessary to encourage all those actions aimed at preventing our urban centres from emptying, it was necessary to discourage the construction of new concrete monsters in peripheral areas, often poorly connected, which turn into real ghettos, with very serious social, cultural and economic consequences, but it was decided not to do so!  With regard to the sixth cohesion report: a brief but bitter consideration: it is September 2015 and almost two years after the start of the new programming, there are still regions – I am thinking of Campania, Calabria, southern Italy – whose administrations have not yet been able to present a decent operational programme. It is therefore essential to ensure that the less developed regions have the skills and competences to plan on time, or it will continue to happen that in order to avoid automatic disengagement and without taking into account the real needs of the territory, we will try to spend the billions of euros in the last six months and quickly.

name: Steeve Briois
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, Commissioner, Brussels and the Euro-gagas are constantly seeking to seize new prerogatives always at the expense of nation-states. This is the case today, in particular, with urban policy, which is not part of the Union's treaty powers. Urban policy is neither a shared competence nor a supporting jurisdiction. That is why this text should not even be discussed in plenary.  But the most worrying thing is that with a particularly careful semantics, you methodically share the dilution of nation states and thus call for the creation of real megacities. I quote from the report. It says: "In all corners of Europe, cities will compete as poles of attraction and develop their own forms of participatory citizenship to stimulate a continuous co-creation of the urban landscape and its multicultural social fabric." This is a fine example of what you might call a cat porridge. If our fellow citizens heard and read you, they would be horrified by what you are preparing behind their backs.  The metropolis that you call for will have the effect of crushing medium-sized cities and, above all, the definitive abandonment of rural areas. Worse, on the pretext of some European challenge, you are advocating the standardisation of urban planning policies within the Union, thus ignoring the geographical and territorial identities and specificities of our cities.  That is why, attached to my local identity and concerned with a balanced development of our territories, I will vote against this doomed technocratic project. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: n/a
text: question posed by raising the blue card. You said that city policy should not be the subject of our negotiations. I therefore consider that you do not consider this policy to be EU policy. But do you know that, for example, a major conference will be held next year under the auspices of the UN, that even organisations such as the United Nations are engaged in urban policy?

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, that is your thought, mine is quite different. I think it is up to the states to organize their sovereignty. In fact, I think we should be talking about arrears of payment or the difficulties that communities have in implementing operational programs.

name: Lambert van Nistelrooij (PPE).
text: – The sixth cohesion report does indeed provide building blocks for future policy, investment and solidarity. My thanks to the rapporteur. Let's look ahead. According to the EPP, what else should it do? 1. Reduction of administrative burden, local and regional projects are no longer holding. Gold plating in the Member States leads to control checks. We want more trust and shared responsibility.  2. Get rid of that big pile of $25 billion in unpaid bills. The European Commission is committed to ensuring that something like this does not happen again in a few years' time.  3. Prevent lost years from happening again as they do now in the 2014-2015 startup. With all due respect, we'll start the review too late. The upcoming review should be at least a year earlier. We should use the midterm review for the new policy and we should bring forward the seventh cohesion report a year earlier. This will strengthen the report's territorial cross-border work in Europe. 4. The cities. The European Commission has no coherent policy. Smart cities for the cities and smart specialisation for the regions are still offered separately. Finally, the EPP wants more commitment between regions and cities and the European Commission, european policy. I would like the Dutch Presidency to come forward next year not with yet another declaration on the urban agenda, but with a commitment, with a pact - a pact of Amsterdam, as it is possible - calling on the mayors and the regions to implement that agenda of renewal, of competitiveness. That is an innovation in our approach and there is room for that. Can I ask the Commissioner if that sounds like music to her ears?

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would also like to take this opportunity to avoid repeating a debate that is widely known and which is widely supported by us thanks to the work that the two rapporteurs in particular have done. I would like to make three solicitations.  The first, we are already in a full and operational urban agenda in progress. Commissioner Crețu was right to remind us that tens of billions are already committed to urban policy through cohesion policy. It would be useful, precisely because of the practicality of our debate, for the Commission to help us understand how these resources have already been planned. Towards social innovation, towards technological innovation, towards urban regeneration, towards the enormous challenges facing cities, from the environmental to the demographic? Understand where we are in programming the resources already used.  The second point is a point of order, we cannot have more Commissioners working on urban policy. Urban policy is fully in line with cohesion policy, and I would therefore also like to call for a joint initiative by Members, so that there is the one-stop shop that the rapporteur mentioned, so that a full role of cohesion policy is fully recognised, as a central policy for urban policy as well.  My third point is this: this is the first debate we have had on cohesion policy in a year of Parliament, yet we are committing around EUR 640 billion – as has been said – that is too little! We need to discuss cohesion policy more in this Parliament, it is the Commission's job, it is the task of the Conference of Group Leaders, it is the task of the REGI Committee, but we need to discuss these issues more.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Mr. President, I congratulate the rapporteurs on the well-drafted document and useful recommendations under the future cohesion policy action. In the period 2014-2020, the European Structural and Investment Funds should help Member States to launch economic activity more strongly during the exit from the economic crisis and boost jobs and economic growth through support, entrepreneurship, innovation and youth employment. Furthermore, under the European Fund for Strategic Investments, newer Member States should start preparing for future investments by implementing the necessary reforms, removing administrative barriers and joining energy, construction and IT consortia and clusters in order to avoid the possibility for the new fund to be used only by more developed countries with better projects and better references.

name: Искра Михайлова (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Mrs Westphal, Mr Deutsch, Commissioner, first of all, I would like to congratulate everyone on the successful work on these two reports, which focus on key elements of the European Union's cohesion policy. They reaffirm the role of cohesion policy in supporting economic growth and job creation, especially when we are talking about the 6th Cohesion Report and at a time of economic crisis, when cohesion policy is emerging as one of the main elements.  Secondly, the role of cohesion policy for territorial development and, in particular, urban development , a key policy element that allows us to look at the role of urban areas in their different dimensions in the future – major cities, capitals, small towns, urban surrounding regions.  But the main theme that both reports confirm is the topic of coordination. Coordination at all levels, coordination in the topic, coordination in the efforts of all levels of power and of all involved in the realization of cohesion policy.

name: Martina Michels (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work she has Much has already been said about the role of cities. I do not want to repeat that. However, I would like to add a very different aspect. While Christian-social politicians are concerned these days about the upcoming wave of travel to the Munich Oktoberfest, the Munich Citizenship also welcomes the many refugees who are arriving in their city these days.
