This too, ladies and gentlemen, shows once again that the urban dimension also includes the preservation of public places in the democratic debate. In addition to theatres and universities, these are currently also railway stations. Whether in Budapest, Vienna, Dortmund, Saalfeld or Berlin – the future of the modern integration-capable European city is discussed everywhere. From sustainable energy to digital networks, we could have gone down other paths long ago. But to do so, the adventurous policy of cutting the public purse would have to be brought to an end. No one needs, for example, so-called macroeconomic conditioning, no one needs the bureaucratic hurdles to get quickly to the funding pots in the cities and in the individual places. European exchanges on the urban dimension have long been under way. But in future we need more than good reports. I would like to thank the rapporteur for this signal in order to draw attention to the importance of the urban dimension. My group has been actively involved in this report and will be pleased to vote in favour of it.

name: Terry Reintke (Verts/ALE).
text: –  Madam President, last weekend I went to a small village in the north of Hungary and the situation I found there was devastating. On the one side, in one part of the village, there were poor families living twelve people together in small houses with only 70 square metres of living space. There was no running water, no paved roads. Three kilometres further away, there was a very different picture. There was a renovated city centre, a brand new water fountain that was, unfortunately, already closed down. This renovated city centre was funded by the European Union with EUR 160 000. This is an example of how cohesion policy can and is going wrong, because these kinds of projects have a detrimental effect on social cohesion in our societies. This situation is even more unacceptable when we know that, first of all, cohesion policy can be such a powerful tool to really change societies and to make the European Union more social, more sustainable and more democratic. Secondly, because many people in this room have worked for the last few years to develop tools in order to make cohesion policy work like this. Be it the partnership principle, be it clear investment criteria, be it the code of conduct or capacity-building measures on the local level, all these things have been developed in the Committee on Regional Development and in this Parliament. I say to my colleagues today, let us not wait until the next funding period, until the next regulation is negotiated. We have to start fighting now to make cohesion policy in the European Union an investment tool that creates a sustainable, ecological, social and democratic European Union.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, EU regional development and cohesion policy in its current form are counter-democratic and opposed to freedom. Our people do not want more central planning, rules, regulation, targets – and please, no more wasted taxpayers’ millions. People thrive when they taste true freedom. We must break down government to bring it closer to the people. Instead of regionalisation, let us have localism. We will fight against the EU-supported Greater Birmingham combined authority in the West Midlands that I represent because the people do not want the power to be centralised. The people want the power brought closer to them – true democracy – and, underneath, the fury of the people when they see this centralisation will bury this centralisation scheme in the West Midlands and we will bring forth the people’s desire for true democracy and freedom.

name: Olaf Stuger (ENF).
text: – Last year, OLAF, the European Anti-Fraud Office, received the largest number of reports of cheating with EU subsidies. In total, there were 1417 reports and an investigation revealed that around EUR 900 million had to be recovered. That's just the tip of the iceberg. But that will not please the Commission, because this money is not really intended for the development of the regions, but to keep countries happy and dependent. And that's what's needed at this time of year. Because the EU has fallen into freefall, a free fall that is best compared to the Roman Empire of 1500 years ago. The Roman Empire was ravaged by invasions from the outside, just like the EU at the moment. And in the Roman Empire there was also corruption and a lot of abuse of power. But in the end, that Roman Empire came to an end because of a lack of unity.  If we look at the EU now, that unity is there, if all goes well. However, with the great problems of today there is no unity, it is each for himself and God for all of us. So let us be honest and admit that the UNDEMOCRATIC elected administration of the EU is not in a way of overlooking, let alone solving, problems such as Greece or the refugee problem. Let us be honest and admit that far too many countries have joined. And finally, let us be honest and admit that this is a failed experiment and that it is best to abolish the EU immediately.

name: Joachim Zeller (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The Commission's cohesion report looks back at what has been achieved in cohesion policy, but it is also intended to set out the objectives for the new funding period. The sixth cohesion report makes it clear that one of the important pillars of cohesion policy – territorial and cross-border cooperation – is barely mentioned. But it is precisely territorial and cross-border cooperation that helps to overcome borders and bring people together. To this end, the new regulations on territorial cooperation and the European grouping of territorial cooperation have created wider and improved opportunities. These instruments can now also be linked to the Neighbourhood Policy, which is even more important in the current situation. I am therefore very grateful to Mr German for giving an outstanding tribute to this policy area in his report, unlike the Commission. However, the sixth cohesion report also says that cohesion policy programmes should make cities more heard. Mrs Westphal's report provides an important impetus for this. I hope that the Commission will take them up and implement them. It has been said that European policy can only be successful if it is done with the citizens, and that together. Of these, 70% live in cities.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Cohesion policy is still the European Union's main investment policy and, until now, the most effective instrument to help reduce disseuasive regional development. And it is becoming a lifeline today for eu countries in crisis, as evidenced by the European Commission's recent bold proposals to adopt specific measures in favour of Greece. Cohesion funds have succeeded in preventing a drastic collapse in public investment.  Therefore, with regard to the sixth report, I would like to emphasise that cohesion policy must fulfil its role to this day and lead to the eradication of poverty in the poorest regions of the Union. It should also be maintained at a level that guarantees effective support for infrastructure development, entrepreneurship and investment in innovation, research and development, as well as the fight against unemployment and social exclusion. If we are talking about a future European urban agenda, particular attention should be paid to the choice of objectives and priorities, as well as the ability of local authorities to finance its objectives. There is a need for maximum involvement of local and local authorities in its preparation and implementation. I therefore encourage the European Commission to support the development of platforms for the exchange of information and experience.  (The speaker refused to answer the question asked by Tibor Szanyi raising the blue card)

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, expectations of cohesion policy are high. Expectations are high as we know in cities, but let's never forget the rural parts of Europe that are also part of our identity. Of course these are the cities where the vast majority of the inhabitants live, and that is why, Madam Commissioner, I would like to especially warn you that you are really high expectations in Europe. In some ways, some countries practically almost live on cohesion policy money or certainly the biggest investments come from cohesion policy money. That is why expectations are high on the part of what the Commission will offer. And we need a new cohesion policy and we need more cohesion policy in this Parliament. And of course we need to talk about cohesion policy even when we talk about cross-border cooperation, but I also add when we talk about macro-regional strategies. And that's where we need a piece of cohesion policy. In this way we can round off the whole.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, it is true that cohesion policy - regional policy - is often attacked and is often attacked by the same people. The attacks are equal to the importance of this policy in the policies of the European Union. It is the main if not the only policy of solidarity and it is also the policy that has allowed to maintain significant levels of investment in the regions in a context of austerity policy.  That is why I believe that we must all already work towards consolidating this policy in the post-2020 perspective by drawing all the lessons from the sixth cohesion report.  In that regard, I want to say a word about cities. We must distinguish the major metropolises, which remain at the heart of the networks of globalization and are always attractive, from urban areas in difficulty, which, in turn, are lagging far behind in development. It is clear that the categorisation of regions, as we have thought so far, will be worth reviewing with reflections on the new post-2020 cohesion programmes.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF).
text: – This European Union cohesion policy aims to transcend regional differences within the European Union, so that these regions will grow together economically, socially and territorially. At least that's the theory. Now practice. In the quiet summer months, the European Central Bank carried out a study showing that euro design has made countries, and therefore regions in the euro area, much further apart in recent years. Whether it concerns the level of education, technological development, labour market participation or productivity. If you look at the European Commission's regional competitive index, you will see time and time again how much this continent is becoming more divided. Billions and billions are being thrown into it through regional investment policy to bring together, which cannot be reconciled. I myself come from the Member State of Belgium, where years of financial injections in the Wallonia region have not brought the Flemings and the Walloons closer together. Contrary. You are now going to try to do the same thing between regions in 28 Member States. You only do with your ever closer Union ideology, but I know better from experience. We, like our group, are opting for sovereignty and independence.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Creu, cities must be smarter, better connected and more open. Europe needs cities that promote the use of information and communication technologies, and drive action to reduce energy dependence and achieve more efficient energy consumption, as well as drive transport infrastructures that reduce traffic, improve air quality and make cities cleaner and safer. Further progress is needed on this path and greater coordination between the many existing programmes at European level to achieve better cities in the future. And, in this sense, regional development funds must play an essential role in the Union's policies, as it is the European Union's main investment policy. Growth must therefore be boosted and imbalances corrected through the use of these funds, with particular emphasis on employment, youth and small and medium-sized enterprises, which will help to restore productive fabric in Europe. Mr Deutsch's report provides a very good basis for the medium-term review of the period 2014-2020, as well as for the future configuration of the next multiannual financial framework. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – The Member rightly referred to the effort we need to make here to strengthen cohesion. Among other things, he stressed, which is also discussed in the report in question, that the settlement of climate change and energy dependency should also be on the agenda. I ask you respectfully, if a government, especially in the country of the rapporteur, Tamás Deutsch, imposes special taxes on environmentally friendly technologies, how compatible do you consider this to be compatible with the desired objectives?

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: "blue card" response. – Well, perhaps that question should be rather addressed to Mr Deutsch.  In any event, I believe that it is not incompatible at all that, from this Parliament and, moreover, in conjunction with the European Commission, every effort is made precisely to avoid these energy units, which only undermine so many aspects, not only in economic matters, but also in environmental matters.  This is a challenge facing the European Union and it is a challenge that we will all have to face, regardless of whether a particular Government of a particular Member State acts by applying procedures such as those you explain.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, commissioner, I would like to thank the rapporteurs for their contributions, which are very balanced and very interesting, and I would like to speak in particular on the cohesion aspect. The response that has been totally inadequate in recent years, provided by the European Union during the first years of the crisis, as we know, has led to a dramatic fall in investment in Europe and, in this context, the main source of investment that has made it possible to mitigate the austerity choices has been cohesion policy, which is still the main source of support for European recovery.  We must, however, find solutions to improve the effectiveness of this policy, especially with regard to the problem of certain countries, certain regions, relating to the non-absorption of funds that have created difficulties, especially in cases where these funds have not been used; they were late, because it was not possible for the stakeholders to guarantee the percentage of cofinancing. Of course, it is also very important to increase administrative capacity – I do not deny this at all!  There is therefore an urgent need to ensure that cofinancing is allocated to the calculation of the deficit in order to release as many resources as possible, to feed the recovery in a healthy way through investment and not through the current deficit and, at the same time, to allow cohesion policy funds to be spent on the territories. Alongside this, I would also like to remind you of the dramatic issue of the 2014-2015 funds for those regions that, having only had the programme approved in 2015, have to use the two-year funds in one, with the risk that these resources will end up being decommitted.

name: Mirosław Piotrowski (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Parliament's report on investment for growth and jobs in the European Union, in its forties, states that additional solutions should be sought to improve the performance of young people's employment. I understand that this raises the prospect of suggesting concrete solutions for the European Commission. That is why, taking this opportunity, I would like to draw attention to the east of the Union, my country, Poland. Its border regions, including Lublin, are affected by the serious problem of unemployment. People leave from there, heading to western countries of the Union. Although they are educated at many good universities in Lublin, the situation forces them to emigrate.  A new impetus may be the European Commission's support for the E40 waterway project. This would stimulate youth employment and, according to the report, support their integration into the local labour market. In addition, it would stimulate cross-border cooperation, as referred to in paragraph 54 of this report today.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to tell the Commissioner that, despite what some people in the UK say, Wales is a huge beneficiary of EU funds and is a huge supporter of EU regional funds.  I would also like to thank the two rapporteurs. I am pleased that both reports highlight new opportunities in the current structural funds programme, for example, the opportunity to create synergies between different cohesion policy funds and between cohesion policy funds and other programmes. I hope that the Member States and regions will take this opportunity. I also hope that they are using the new tools available to them which will have an impact on the geographical areas, for example, integrated territorial investments and the community-led local development initiatives. By adopting a bottom-up approach, by using a change of planning across an area, and by using a number of funds together, I believe that cohesion policy funds can make an even bigger difference in the future. I would ask the Commission and Commissioner to monitor the use of these new tools to make sure that they are being used and that they are effective.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! Today's cohesion policy is a new reality and a new challenge for local and regional authorities. It is also a new principle for the allocation of European funds, a thematic concentration designed and designated by the Union, which does not always converge on the real needs of the region. The mere fact of shifting financial support from infrastructure development to innovation in terms of volumes limits the ability of the poorest regions to expand their basic facilities, which are high-speed roads.  I would also point out that for the poorest regions, such as my region, Podkarpatta, in a low-competitiveness Poland, the subsidising nature of cohesion policy is very important, and regional funds should not be used to fund and guarantee new Commission initiatives, as was the case with the Connecting Europe Fund. I would also like to thank the Commissioner here for her initiatives, for the various opinions that you have been giving recently on the need to step up the development of the Carpathians region. I am referring here to the Carpathian strategy, the macro-regional strategy for the region. I believe that these are very important words that you are speaking in many places, and you can count on the support of many Members in this House, because we believe that the macro-regional strategy for the Carpathians region is absolutely justified and that there should be no obstacles to its development. Thank you very much.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking both rapporteurs for their really high-quality reports. I will comment on the report on the urban dimension of EU policies, which I fully support, because it brings new challenges and objectives not only for local and regional, but also for national and European policy. Since I myself live in the 250,000-year-old city of Košice in the east of Slovakia, I know the problems of the city personally, which are associated with unemployment, serious problems in transport, lack of amenities and public services, up to the reduction of the quality of life of citizens. But we must admit that, even in times of crisis, it was the cities that demonstrated their capacity for economic and social development. Therefore, although the European Union does not have explicit competence in the area of urban development, various initiatives by the European Union can have both direct and indirect impacts on urban and urban development. Therefore, the Urban Agenda should be a joint effort of the Commission, the Member States and other stakeholders to ensure the coordinated and efficient development of cities and urban areas, including in the implementation of the Structural Funds.

name: Amjad Bashir (ECR).
text: – Madam President, amongst the positive aspects in this report, such as the calls for simplification, more focus on SMEs and results-based policymaking, the assessment of the previous cohesion policy programming period paints a somewhat more negative picture. The backlog in payments as well as the consistently high error rate we have seen in cohesion spending amount to nothing more than an administrative mess. Therefore, I am surprised to see the finger being pointed at inadequate funding.  The reality is that we have an over-complex system that is not accessible to the end user and remains vulnerable to fraud. Moving forward, what we need to see is increased efficiency, increased simplicity and increased accountability on how our taxpayers’ money is spent – not an increase in funding, as some in this House may like to suggest.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, thanks to the contributions of both reports, Parliament has the opportunity to renew its full support for the cohesion policy, which we must constantly remind us of the added value of, but to some, I who come from a remote region overseas: investment in infrastructure, support for business, innovation and social integration.  While the crisis we are going through continues to drain its cohorts of unemployed and dangerously reduce public investment, cohesion policy is a real safety net. But the very good report of our colleague, Tamus Deutsch, also highlights how the budgetary problem of late payments is a poison that paralyzes the implementation of many projects. This is a major issue which the Council must now resolve as soon as possible because the very credibility of the Union is at stake. Macroeconomic conditionality is another area of concern. At a time when troubled Member States are being asked to pursue policies of serious budgetary or even austerity, this measure is a double punishment for regions that would be unfairly punished for decisions taken at national level. Therefore, let us keep such measures that fuel the fantasies of those who are fighting the European project.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Respected Commissioner Crețu, cohesion policy is currently the main investment instrument of the European Union. Its significance is also greater when it is known that the fundamental objectives are to reduce regional disparities, strengthen economic, social and territorial cohesion between member states' regions and create jobs. During the financial crisis, cohesion policy proved to be a key instrument for maintaining investments. It was one of the main sources of public investment. I would like to thank the rapporteurs and all those who contributed to the content of the second report – a set of guidelines for the continuation of cohesion policy implementation, burdened with difficulties with disbursements and a delayed start. It is worth knowing that Croatia, as the youngest member of the European Union, is increasingly actively and efficiently participating in the withdrawal of significant funds available. The best evidence of this is the projects of pelješac bridge and the new railway Gradec – Sveti Ivan Žabno. It is the first railway in Croatia built after 1967. 72% of our citizens live in urban areas and this line will better connect the urban areas of the three counties, which is one of the goals of the report.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, we are discussing cohesion policy, we are taking stock of last programming, we are misling ourselves with what is going on, but often, as in the case of the crisis in Greece, we question everything, we are correcting course. The objectives of cohesion investments are strategic, but it is important to understand what obstacles often prevent them from being achieved. If there are regions that cannot spend the money, if there are regions that have only needed one programming cycle to grow and others, such as my own, which are in the same position as less developed regions for 25 years now, that is, since cohesion policy was born.  When regional policy is being carried out, we must listen to the territories and the regional administrations are calling for measures to overcome them, they are asking to be helped in what is the most difficult obstacle for them, cofinancing. The measures approved last week set a precedent for starting a concrete comparison and a clear distinction between current and investment expenditure by clearly splitting cofinancing from the calculation of the deficit. This is a road that must be assessed.

name: Georgi Pirinski (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I suggest that the Commissioner take on board three central points of the Deutsch report. Firstly, that cohesion policy has an incontestable role as the principal policy for reducing disparities. Secondly, that it should be at the core of the investment policy of the European Union in the sense of being an integral and leading part of the overall investment drive that the Commissioner is currently trying to generate. Thirdly, that there is the need for a new dynamic to the debate on cohesion policy in the longer run, in connection with the termination of the Europe 2020 strategy and the movement towards a new multiannual financial framework. You have these three pillars, or points, on which to build a very strong position in the College and we wholly support you in your efforts to that end.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – I congratulate my colleague Tamás on his excellent report. With a budget of more than €350 billion for the period 2014-2020, cohesion policy was the European Union's main investment instrument. In my Country, too, cohesion policy, although under-utilised, is practically the only major investment resource. In recent years, cohesion has significantly mitigated the negative effects of the crisis, creating hundreds of thousands of new jobs and businesses. However, we are facing some challenges, problems such as backlogs of payments, major structural delays in the implementation of the new programming period and low absorption of funds in some Member States. But all of this is shable. Finally, I would like to stress that promoting the integration of young people into the labour market must remain a priority for cohesion policy and that, without effective cooperation between educational institutions and labour market actors, it will not be possible to eliminate the high unemployment rate of young graduates in the European Union.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the reports highlight the essential importance of territorial development going beyond traditional administrative boundaries in the common search for a solution to economic, social, environmental and demographic challenges. It is clear to everyone, with the migrant crisis of these days, that the geographical map and the geopolitical map no longer have anything in common.  On the other hand, it is well known how difficult it is to overcome their national borders and voluntarily to face the challenges coming from the territories of individual States in Europe, but I am convinced that every effort must be made to give the European institutions a central role in those possible forms of spatial planning or in those cases where the solution can only come from a European approach.  I am in favour of developing a negotiated and fully participatory model of town planning in which, by means of a clear multi-level governance model, we can involve everyone involved, up to the individual citizen, in order to solve today's main economic, social and environmental challenges. I therefore agree with the reports and the call for greater synergies between the European public and private national investment programmes, in order to better bring the programmes into account in the current social and economic phenomena.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, cohesion policy is crucial for the development of the European Union and economic prosperity, especially at a time when Europe is being hit by the economic crisis, because this will allow for a reduction in imbalances, a reduction in the difference between north and south, between the divergences between the hard core of the euro area and the region. This means, of course, that there must be a reduction in red tape, administrative burden and, above all, an ease of absorption of funds. I would like to address the issue of co-financing. In order to do so, there must be public investment. But countries that have been put into a memorandum or even budgetary adjustment programmes must reduce deficits and therefore cannot make public investments. To overcome this, public investment should not be counted against deficits. Finally, it is unacceptable that the NSRF in Greece, in order to be implemented, has now been linked, by a decision of 12 July of the Heads of State of the euro area, to the implementation of the Memorandum. This is unacceptable because this condition does not apply anywhere. Thanks.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, the Union's economic, social and regional cohesion policies are proving to be very little effective in practice. Disparities between regions have increased over the last decade and the same applies to social inequalities within the Member States. The cause is the austerity imposed by the dominant political forces on the Union and on the states. However, there is also an insufficient scale of EU funds allocated to cohesion policies. The EUR 350 billion, which will be allocated in the seven years 2014-2020, is minimal considering that the Union's Gross Domestic Product in the same period will exceed EUR 100 trillion. Cohesion policies therefore absorb only 3% of EU GDP. This must be drastically increased if there is to be convergence and not divergence, while at the same time allowing the economically weaker Member States to finance public investment without their public deficit being accounted for.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – Of course, cohesion policy plays an important and decisive role in reducing disparities between regions. Somewhere, this has proved to be more, somewhere less successful, but I would point to something else that may not have been warned enough today. The previous perspective has already been financial, and it also shows that there is also a high risk of errors, for fraud, for irregularities, in the absorption of these funds. I think it is right that the Commission should pay further attention here, particularly in the control work, that it actually also helps Member States to draw down these funds and, of course, also to draw up, if necessary, appropriate manuals, appropriate assistance in order to reduce the risks of also administrative problems. I am thinking here, in particular, of the area of public procurement, the area and the issue of State aid, and something that is not directly linked to cohesion rules, but that their support and simplification is necessary for successful absorption.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. Dear! I would like to stress once again what the previous previous ers mentioned in this House today. Cohesion policy is Europe's main investment policy, which in recent years has significantly mitigated the effects of the reduction in public investment in times of crisis. We have already entered a new programming period and we are facing new challenges that require an ambitious approach. At the moment, increasing the efficiency of spending funds must be a priority, especially in the weakest and poorest regions. I agree with the rapporteur that, in order to do this, we need to strengthen administrative capacity, especially at local level. Cohesion policy instruments and programmes must be easily accessible to our citizens, which will only be achieved if we work together to achieve maximum transparency and, above all, simplification of the rules. Furthermore, we must strive to maintain sustainable development between regions. We also need the right balance on the city line and the adjacent areas. In my opinion, we need to build polycentric structures.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D).
text: – Well, I wanted to raise two important points in my opinion. The first point is that cohesion policy cannot focus too much on big cities. EU policies and measures should support entire urban areas of a functional nature, which, after all, include not only large cities, but also municipalities and towns. There is another important point. It is often the case that in large cities people live anonymously. I therefore think that through the Union we should support various social, initiatives and local and civic projects. I therefore think it would be worth thinking about whether EU funds could not, at least in part and at least symbolically, support the local budgets that people want to adopt directly. Thank you.

name: Corina Crețu
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for your valuable contribution to this debate, it was very interesting for me to listen to the opinion of the expert committees and the political groups and you, personally.  With regard to the interventions on Mr Deutsch's report on the Sixth Cohesion Report, I fully agree that we must do everything in our power to ensure that european-funded programmes allow the states and member states of the region to generate growth and jobs. This year is a vital year and, on the other hand, next year will be the first year in which we will be able to see the concrete results of the regulations and legislation that you have adopted here with regard to the use of European funds in the period 2014-2020.  I wanted to tell you, ladies and gentlemen, that in the last ten months, in fact in my ten months in office - since I took office as Commissioner for Regional Policy - I have visited 20 Member States and met with dozens of representatives of national, regional and local authorities, as well as with you personally, in committees or in other meetings. I have visited dozens of successful projects and met beneficiaries who have had success stories in the implementation of European funds. We have seen concretely and, you know very well, taking you to your regions, to your countries, you know very well what the impact of European funds is, as you said here: newly created jobs, improving roads, infrastructure, water, canals, Internet connections, that successful programme on the energy efficiency of public and private buildings. In the last 40 years, since the Regional Development Fund has been in place, with the help of European funds, entire regions have developed enormously with a clear impact on the lives of the people there.  That is why I want to tell you that it is quite difficult for me to understand why this cohesion policy is so under attack, because I understand - because I have been part of the European Parliament for eight years - I understand the differences between political groups, but I want to tell you that, in my opinion, cohesion policy has no political colour, and I think we should join forces to make it more effective and to see exactly how the funds are implemented.  I think we should be very proud of these successes, but, of course, learn from the mistakes of the past, so that in the current programming period we can achieve much better results. To ensure that European funds are easily accessible to beneficiaries, simplification has been a high element of yours here, being a key element for cohesion policy. We have decided to set up a high-level working group, which will make concrete proposals from next year in terms of both the current and post-2020 programmes. On the other hand, this is also where the issue of fraud has been raised, and we need to find the exact balance between the need to simplify and the need to have very strict control over the way European money is used. There are programmes where 30 signatures are needed and this is not a requirement of the European Union. It is simply a measure taken by local authorities. The first meeting of the Working Party on Simplification will take place on 22 October and, in this respect, I am also relying and relying in particular on your contribution and experience as Members of the European Parliament. Another aspect we are working on is the preparation of the next programming period. By the end of this year, we will present a report that will assess how Member States have complied with the requirements imposed by the Partnership Agreements. This information will be particularly relevant for future strategies and, as I said, the European Parliament is a reliable partner. I would like to tell you a few things, for example, about migration, another subject raised by some of you. We have, of course, all seen the terrible images of immigrants seeking in Europe the peace, safety and well-being lost in their countries of origin, whether Syria or Libya or Eritrea. We are currently looking at how these funds and the Union's policies could contribute to the social integration of these immigrants, but I would like to tell you that we are already contributing, to a great extent, to social integration through the Regional Development Fund. I have visited, for example, the suburbs of Berlin, I have visited the suburbs of Paris, there are many communities that, through European money, have managed to integrate, to find a job. In the Netherlands, for example, we have a very nice example: a single Jordanian mother who managed to bring traditional Jordanian products and place them with The Help of European Funds on the Dutch and behold, now this mother with five children, who left for a better economic situation, manages to live alone and take care of the future of children in the Netherlands. Therefore, the challenges posed by the migration phenomenon can also be addressed and working with Member States in territorial cooperation actions, through the Interreg Programmes and macro-regional strategies.  I agree with Mr van Nistelrooij that, at this time, this cross-border cooperation between regions is gaining much greater importance. I am pleased to invite all of you who are interested to come from today in a week to Luxembourg, where it will be the 25th anniversary of cross-border cooperation. I think it's a very important topic at the moment. Last week there were many members of the European Parliament in Greece. I would like to say a few words: I enjoyed being in the REGI Committee last week. I believe that we have a duty to do everything in our power to support Greece, and I would like to thank the members of the REGI once again, for understanding the need for the Commission to adopt the measures proposed for this country as a matter of urgency and have decided to adopt them on the basis of the simplified procedure, so that EUR 35 billion ends up being invested in Greece as soon as possible. You know, Greece is one of the countries where investments from European funds account for 75-80% of public investment. Another high topic is youth unemployment. It is a challenge that must remain a priority: over 26 million European citizens really do not have a job and, thanks to the Youth Initiative and the Youth Employment Initiative, which we have fought together here in the European Parliament and which was likely to be adopted by the determination of the European Parliament, many young people will find work in the coming years. With regard to Mrs Westphal's report on the urban dimension, I understand that Parliament expects an even more active role from the Commission in promoting the urban agenda, but there are also separate opinions, whereby it is practically considered an undemocratic practice. I believe that the European Union must support cities in preparing and implementing their policies. Most of the challenges we face come from cities and urban areas, but that's where solutions come from. I want to tell you and assure you that, as a Commissioner from the country with the largest rural dimension in the European Union, the country I know very well, it is, I believe, my duty to defend the rural dimension as well. In a way, I agree with you that there is somehow a contradiction in terms between urban concentration and the need for urban concentration that we have in the legislation adopted by you and the fact that we are not succeeding in a better correlation with rural areas. We have proposed to Commissioner Hogen to see, we will also have a conference on this in October, to what extent we can contribute to rural development with our funds. Urban-rural will be a conference in Ireland that will allow us to see and analyse, on the basis of the legislation that you have drawn up, how we can, however, pay more attention to rural regions. I would also like to add that the Riga Declaration on the setting of the urban agenda, adopted last June by all Member States, with the participation of the European Parliament, the Commission, the Committee of the Regions and the European Economic and Social Committee, is a cornerstone, and I look forward to the Amsterdam Declaration, and I said, including in my opening word , that I appreciate the importance that the Dutch Presidency attaches to the urban dimension, and I assure you that we will continue to work on this with Parliament, with the Council, with the Committee of the Regions. I know time is limited. I take advantage of the fact that I only have one minute speech left and I would like to add a few more words. As I said, zero tolerance to fraud. We need to ensure the balance between simplification and control. Cross-border cooperation - I hope to have the opportunity, colleagues, to come here and talk about regional policy. As I was saying at one point, I think we need to make a great coalition to defend this policy, which has changed people's lives for the better. I know, as I was saying, that there are political reasons, but there are undeniable reasons: thousands of kilometres of infrastructure, schools, hospitals, tens of thousands of jobs. The thematic concentrations that you asked me about yourself have established here: science, technology, SMEs: So I think we need to think about where Europe would have been if all the Member States had started using these funds 40 years ago, when this regional development fund was established. You are right - disparities, social inequalities have deepened. But what would the European Union have been and what would these regions have looked like if it had not even been these investments? Let's see Greece, take pictures, photos, what Greece looked like before entering the European Union and what it looks like now. It was the last century. So let us not underestimate the importance that European funds have had in our countries, in our regions and for our citizens. Thank you very much and I rely with all my heart on your support.

name: Tamás Deutsch
text: Artist. – First of all, I would like to thank all the contributors for their valuable thoughts in enriching the exchange of views. Nearly a year of work will end with tomorrow's vote, it was a joint work, the result is shared. When the European Commission prepared its sixth cohesion report, it was the opinion of the profession that it had put a valuable document on the European Parliament's table. Without wishing to praise the European Parliament and my fellow Members on our merits, this joint work has been able to prepare a better parliamentary report than the European Commission's report. This parliamentary report, in which there is complete agreement between the factions, showed the results of cohesion policy, showed the serious problems of cohesion policy and clearly showed what needs to be done. Therefore, the most important conclusion from today's exchange of views is that it is time to act. We no longer need to talk about these issues, but the Commission must act, national governments must act, regional local decision-makers must act. And obviously the point of this action is to allocate cohesion resources to local developments as quickly as possible, with as little red tape as possible. Of course, we, the European Parliament, the Committee on Regional Development, the Members, must also act. We must act in terms of doing our job, monitoring the work of the European Commission, encouraging it to act as quickly and efficiently as possible. Let us carry out legislative work that can further support the effectiveness of cohesion policy, the mid-term review work of the seven-year budget cycle and the preparation of the post-2020 cohesion policy. Ladies and gentlemen, I trust that this agreement, this joint work, will show the result of the vote.

name: Kerstin Westphal
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Thank you for the last word that is being said here today on the subject. It is good, and it has been fun, that so much attention has actually been paid to the cities of Europe today. Incidentally, this fulfils one of the objectives of the report: urban policy comes into the minds, into the minds of Brussels and Strasbourg, and sustainability is indeed required. It is sometimes helpful to the colleague who has already left, who is so afraid of strengthening cities, I can only say. This also applies to the report, to the city report, and many of the questions it has raised have been answered.  Personally, I look forward to continuing to work with the Urban Agenda. And I am really very excited about the commission's concrete proposals, indeed, they will come. At this point, ladies and gentlemen, I would particularly like to thank my shadow rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs. It was not only a lot of fun, but it was very concrete. We have written a lot into the report and it would not look the way it looks today. The same thing for me is that we must give cities less ballast and much more scope for action. Our cities are central spaces in our society, and they play a crucial role in the future.  This is particularly true right now. Cities face great challenges in helping the many people who come to us out of fear, hardship, suffering and fear for their lives. We must not leave the cities in the rain here! They need our help, they need European help! That is why I keep saying and calling for a good future for cities, and we must find them. The Urban Agenda should only be a first step.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. – I regret that my fellow Member Deutsch's report on EU development policy 2007-2013 makes no mention of orban's government's public procurement system, systemic over-pricing, government abuses and suspected corruption cases. Today, nothing would be built in Hungary without the European Union, with 95% of public investment being made from EU funds. While the Hungarian government is in its grip, the government is enriching nearby oligarchs, blames Brussels for all its blunders. While six Hungary seven regions of The New Year are disadvantaged, some of the Prime Minister's family members are winning billions in public contracts to modernise street lighting, for example. Under the Orban government, Hungary is not developing because EU catch-up resources simply do not reach the Hungarian people, to Hungarian businesses. Most recently, the Hungarian Government announced that it would spend EU funds for the next seven years until 2017, i.e. in just two years. Fidesz would therefore, admittedly, run into the 2018 elections by handing out EU funds.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The next item is the report by Eduard Kukan, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on the evaluation of the European Year of Active Ageing and Intergenerational Solidarity 2012 (2014/2255(INI)) (A8-0241/2015).

name: Eduard Kukan
text: Rapporteur. – The essence of my report is to assess the European Year 2012 objectively and realistically. However, the subject of Active Ageing and Intergenerational Solidarity is not only a timeless one, but also an extremely important issue in today's demographic development in Europe. The report therefore looks not only at 2012, but also focuses on a number of concrete recommendations on how to continue promoting active ageing and intergenerational solidarity. I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs from the other political groups for their very good and effective cooperation in drafting this report.  The European Union is facing unprecedented demographic, social and structural changes. The ageing of europe's population is a reality and it is high time to tackle this reality. Older people are an active asset to their families, peers, communities and nations. They therefore deserve to create a favourable environment for full-fledged operation. And in this sense, the ageing of the population must be seen as an opportunity and not a disaster. It must be acknowledged that the 2012 targets have been partially met. Best results have been achieved in awareness-raising initiatives and events. The concrete positive benefits of the European Year are the EU Pact on Demographic Change and the Active Ageing Index, the development of national policies, strategies and comprehensive programmes aimed at active ageing. We also need the Commission to adopt an EU strategy on demographic change to coordinate EU action in order to maximise benefits for European citizens, the economy and job creation, as well as for the protection of the human rights of the elderly in all European Union policies. We must not be relieved here. Criticism is directed against the late approval of the European Year and against the low budget. Because both of these things have made it difficult to run smoothly this year and that's a shame. There is a need to further strengthen the coordination triangle, which consists of all levels of decision-making, including EU, national, regional and local levels, civil society and the private sector, including sectors that provide innovative goods and services to promote independent living. We also need proper statistics on the situation of seniors and on demographics. In this report, we call on the Commission to do so. We are concerned about unemployment among over-50s and the rising long-term unemployment rate, as well as the growing not only disparities between Member States, but also between regions. The second part of the report focuses on concrete recommendations to improve active ageing and intergenerational solidarity. I would like to mention that we must combat discrimination. Older workers often continue to be subjected to discrimination based on age, stereotypes and obstacles. I would also like to mention that volunteering has added value, and I am disappointed that the Grundtvig programme supporting older volunteers has been interrupted. Ladies and gentlemen, active ageing brings new social needs requiring investment in a variety of public services and in the area of health and care for the elderly. It also opens up economic opportunities arising from public and consumer spending, coupled with an ageing population, and from specific products, services, innovative solutions and needs that create new jobs. We have a lot of work to do, so the initiatives mentioned need to be followed up with concrete political decisions.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I wish to thank Mr Kukan for his report. It reflects, usefully and insightfully, the achievements of the follow-up to the 2012 European Year for Active Ageing. Firstly, the European Year 2012 has contributed towards firmly establishing active ageing on the European agenda and on many national policy agendas. It is now widely recognised that active ageing is key to preserving solid welfare systems and strong solidarity between the generations in our own ageing societies. Secondly, the European Year 2012 left an important legacy in the form of the guiding principles for active ageing and solidarity between the generations, and in the form of the Active Ageing Index, a tool to measure untapped potential and the successes or failures of our active ageing policies.  The Commission is committed to promoting active ageing, and it does this in various ways. Many of them are referred to in the report. Let me mention some of them. First, in the context of the European Semester, the Commission calls on the Member States most concerned to take measures that will raise the labour force participation of older workers. Indeed, this is a success story. The employment rate of older workers has increased even through the crisis.  Secondly, the importance of promoting independent living in old age has been highlighted in a joint report of the Commission services and the Social Protection Committee on adequate social protection for long-term care needs in an ageing society. This report included proposals for future activities in the areas of long-term care. They should address the lack of good empirical evidence – a precondition for closer cooperation and mutual learning among Member States, as well as for any policy initiatives at the European level.  Thirdly, the Commission has launched a joint project with the OECD on measuring the adequacy of social protection against long-term care needs. It should develop a methodology for cross-country comparisons of the extent of social protection against long-term care needs. Fourthly, the Commission started a new project with the European Network of National Human Rights Institutions to promote greater respect for the human rights of people in long-term care. Specific measures to support active and healthy ageing are being developed with parts of the business community in the context of the European Innovation Partnership on active and healthy ageing. Active ageing also became a higher priority in the new funding instruments, such as the European Social Fund.  The European Year was a milestone, but your report, Mr Kukan and dear Members of Parliament, is also a timely reminder that we must continue to build on these achievements of the European Year, and that we must not relent in our efforts to promote active ageing.

name: David Casa
text: F'isem the PPE group. – Sinjura President, l-ewwel nett irrid nibda jien ukoll billi nirringrazzja lir-rapporteur tagťna lis-Sur Kukan li llum gťandna dan ir-rapport quddiemna li jiena ngťid huwa rapport importantťafna gťaliex jitkellem dwar il-popolazzjoni tal-Unjoni Ewropea illi qiegťda tgťix aktar u hija aktar b'saťťitha u din hija xi żaża pożittiva, but mill-band l-oťra, l-anzjanità ťafna drabi tiżi kkunsidrata bťala theddida lis-soèjetà, l-aktar minťabba l-impatt li tťalli fuq is-sigurtà so-jali , u gťaldaqstant dan il-fenomenu qiegťed iqajjem ťafna mistoqsijiet: kif nistgťu, pereżempju, ngťinu lin-nies sabiex, jibqgťu attivi u indipendenti anke meta jkunu qegťdin jikbru fl-età?  Li bniedem jikber fl-età m'gťandux jiżi meqjus bťala piż. Gťandna nťarsu lejn l-anzjanità attiva b'mod σollistiku. Anzjani jistgťu jkunu partes-so-jetà active fis-soèjetà tagťna kemm bťala kontributuri attivi u kemm bťala benefiťjarji tas-soèjetà, f'ambjent xieraq u bi stil ta' ťajja san, nies ta' ertu età, jitilgťu fażilment iżommu l-impjieg tagťhom b'effett pożittiv fuq id-dťul pubbliku.
