name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Dear Rapporteur, I thank you wholeheartedly for your well-prepared report and our close cooperation. Indeed, the European Year for Intergenerational Solidarity and Active Ageing has been important for our people, as it has given impetus to both solidarity between generations and the further formulation of active ageing policies in the Member States. This has reaffirmed that older people are certainly not a burden on the economy and society, but an asset, first of all, because of their experience, because of their achievements, because of their knowledge. Qualifications, experience, wisdom, loyalty to the employer are those great values, so we need to encourage employers to accept and retain older workers in the labour market, to help them improve their qualifications and to adapt their working conditions. Member States must also ensure the sustainability of pension systems while guaranteeing people an adequate income in retirement so that they can live both with dignity and proactively. Unfortunately, poverty among older people has increased in some EU countries over the last five years, endangering the proper nutrition, health of those people, and finally facing energy poverty. Some appropriate solutions are therefore needed, both at European Union level and at national level. At the same time, Member States must strengthen quality public infrastructure for older people – I mean day centres, home assistance, quality inpatient care and care services, finally adapted public transport system. And for certain, we really need to use the European Union's Structural Funds. Honourable Commissioner, I appeal to you to examine the problem of unemployment among people over 50, and the Commission, together with the Member States, local authorities, the social partners, must analyse the causes of unemployment among older people and propose concrete measures to increase their employment. And to conclude, it is certainly unreasonable to link the retirement age solely to the increase in life expectancy. The situation of the European Union's labour market must be assessed and, finally, the physical ability of a person to remain on the labour market for as long as possible. Is there no risk that, by reducing the number of pensioners, moving away from retirement age, will we only increase the ranks of the unemployed? I wish you a good joint job for our older generation.

name: Arne Gericke
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, Commissioner Thyssen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I too would like to thank Mr Kukan for the report. I think we can say with good reason that the European Year for Active Ageing and Solidarity between generations has been a great success throughout Europe, despite some concerns. Countless associations, institutions and churches have taken part in the actions. The logo was present throughout Europe. And I think a lot of the impulses that have been initiated are sustainable, they still reverberate to this day. In the report on the European Year, the European Parliament insisted on taking the solidarity of generations into the title, in addition to active ageing. One cannot discuss one without the other. Families in particular are the place of a lived solidarity between generations. Mothers in particular make active ageing possible, and they deserve special thanks in this context. But in Germany, they often end up with a minimum pension. I want to achieve a European family strategy so that mothers, but also parents as a whole, can enjoy their age with dignity. For 2016, I would like to make it the European Year against Violence – a wish. I hope that this proposal will have your support here.

name: Ivo Vajgl
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, – First of all, I would like to thank my colleague Eduardo Kukan for his very engaged approach to this report, which will certainly draw a great deal of attention, particularly to those to whom the report relates. But it's going to affect every one of us sooner or later. Your speech, Commissioner, has also been encouraging and I thank you for it. We know that regulating the situation of older people under the principle of subsidiarity is the responsibility of the States, so do we have something to say at Community level? No doubt- yes! The report warns that the fundamental objective of improving the situation of the elderly and disabled is not just to prolong their ability and will to participate in the work process. But it is about having the opportunity to be active, integrated into society, considered and healthy. We expect the Commission to put forward a sensible and achievable strategy to respond to demographic change and the ageing of europe's population. A healthy and productive intergenerational relationship also includes adequate pensions and secure pension funds. It must not be the case that, in times of crisis, these funds and pensions are a reserve to cover budgetary losses, and it is therefore essential to ensure independent supervision of the management of pension funds. The report calls for intergenerational solidarity, a systematic help to those older people who are no longer able to do so without help, such as the elderly with dementia. Finally: with this report, we draw attention to the importance of accepting the United Nations Convention on the Protection of the Rights of the Elderly worldwide. The Alde Group fully supports the report.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, there are certainly many aspects in which we agree with this report, not least because a number of amendments have emerged. We believe, yes, that the increase in average life expectancy is an achievement of civilization and a factor of social progress and should not be seen as a burden on society. Now, what the expression "active ageing" should mean is, not that people have to work late, but that older people should not be abandoned, as is currently the case in so many countries. But first, they must be able to actively participate in social life, they must be able to exercise their citizenship and, in order for this to happen, they must necessarily have access to decent pensions, which guarantee them independence, and to public services, including public health services, which guarantee them quality of life, an indispensable condition for them to actively participate in their communities.  We do not agree that the ageing population should lead to what is here called a reform of social security systems. We know what this means in practice: raising the retirement age and privatising Social Security, benefiting banks and insurers. What is required for the sustainability of social security reform is the strengthening of public social security systems, which must be supportive and universal, which means that those who have the most and who profit the most have to contribute more to them and that unemployment and precarious jobs, decapitalization factors of social security systems, must be fought and eliminated.

name: Tatjana Ždanoka
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I also want to congratulate Eduard Kukan for the report, which – pointing out that the 2012 European Year succeeded in its goal of mobilising the relevant actors around the topic – considers that these initiatives need to be followed now by concrete action. The high unemployment among people over the age of 50 is an extremely worrying phenomenon. Yes, Commissioner Thyssen, I agree that the employment rate for elderly people has risen somewhat but it is not yet satisfactory, and therefore we call on the Commission to address the problem of reintegrating dismissed middle-aged workers, using the new European financial instruments. I also agree that linking a retirement age to average life expectancy only is the wrong approach. The actual unemployment rates among the population of pre-retirement age should be taken into account before changing the mandatory retirement age.

name: Dominique Martin
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, let us welcome from the outset the responsiveness of our institution, which in 2015 assesses the European year 2012 on active ageing, three years after the implementation of a scheme which still cost five million euros for uncertain results, in the words of Eduard Kukan, the rapporteur of this evaluation.  What hinders us above all in this system is your willingness to consider our elders as a raw material that should be exploited and profitable to produce wealth, what you call the seniors' economy, by hiding behind the usual shock argument of single thought, that of age discrimination, this time around.  On the contrary, we believe that our elders have the right to enjoy the few years they have left, to take time, to take the time to travel and discover the world they have shaped, to take care of their families and grandchildren; we believe that they have the right to finally live for themselves and for themselves.  However, only one point is our approval, that of not losing the knowledge and know-how of our elders, which it would be intelligent and essential to pass on effectively to the new generations.

name: Thomas Mann (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In November 2010, the European Parliament adopted my report on intergenerational justice by a clear majority. For the first time, concrete measures for young and older people were put together at European level into an overall package. This includes the European Youth Guarantee. Member States could undertake to offer every young person a job, apprenticeship or other training after unemployment of a maximum of four months. It has become an important tool for dealing with the consequences of the economic, financial and social crisis. The report by my colleague, Mr Kukan, shows that it helps to prevent a lost generation.  Another building block was the proposal to create a European Year of Active Ageing, which the European Commission proclaimed in 2012. Among other things, older workers should be able to enter the labour market for longer if they so wish. A large number of events have impressively demonstrated that older people are not a burden, but a gain for society because of their experience and knowledge. A small downside: the budget of EUR 5 million was too small to meet the great interest of the citizens.  Some points are still awaiting implementation: intergenerational balance sheets for mapping cash flows between vintages and, of course, the European Pact 50plus to increase the employment rate of workers over fifty years of age. These and other instruments will further advance the idea of intergenerational justice.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I too would like to thank the rapporteur. With the demands in his report, we are strengthening the positive role of the elderly. In fact, these initiatives must now also be followed by concrete action in all areas of life. It is important that we keep people in active employment until they retire, otherwise we will create even more poverty in Europe. The role of the social partners is also very important here. In order for older workers to be able to keep their jobs or even get a new one, we need changed jobs with good health and safety, part-time opportunities and lifelong learning. What is important for the S&D Group is that the report makes it clear that the retirement age is not linked to the development of life expectancy. This often only results in a reduction in the pension for the individual employee. What is more important is that everything is done to ensure that workers can actually work healthily in their working lives until they retire.

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, the resolution we are debating today on 'the European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity 2012' brings to light both the comical and the sad side of how the European Union works and how we MEPs often fall into traps. The year 2015 is coming to an end, with youth unemployment soaring and we, instead of 'emptying their seats', as we would quite simply say, are now wondering whether our guidelines for raising the age limits have succeeded. I wonder what solidarity we're talking about? This is not solidarity either with the elderly who are forced every two years to add an extra year until they receive their pension, nor with young people whose unemployment exceeds 20%. It is not, therefore, a question of solidarity, but of punishment for both the new and the previous generations. This is yet another contradictory policy that forces weary people to seek work up to their 70s, at a time when millions of young people are being denied the chance to take their lives into their own hands. That is why I propose that we vote against this report.

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, let me begin by thanking and congratulating Minister Kukan for the excellence of his report which he presented to us a few minutes ago.  French demographer Alfred Sauvy wrote: "The ageing of the population will be the most important social fact of the second half of the 20th century." In a century, we have seen a near doubling of life expectancy. It was therefore simple to infer that the so-called active ageing of the population would be one of the major challenges of our 21st century. But since that observation, what is the Member States' record in this area? It is up to us to decide whether this ageing population should be an opportunity or a burden on our society. To properly accompany aging can, I am convinced, be a real generator of economic growth. It can also be, through intergenerational exchange, a pillar of social cohesion on our continent. Demographic ageing is also a responsibility; a society is often judged by the way it treats its seniors.  In most Member States, the answer to unemployment among the over-50s is based on mathematical arrangements with published rates. Pension systems are sometimes totally outdated. The gap between the supply and demand for geriatric infrastructure is stark, particularly in rural areas. The autonomy of seniors, on the other hand, is despised. How can we also explain the near absence of pharmaceutical research for patients over the age of 70? The European Union therefore has a great responsibility in this area. We call on the European Commission to study the case of each member country and to provide it with clear recommendations in these urgent areas, including the dissemination of best practices.  (The speaker agrees to answer a question "blue card" (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – The Member has really, very well listed the problems, the actions, the progress made to some extent on this issue. However, let me ask you whether you, and more broadly your party, could identify with the idea that all these things that we are drafting here should be sum up and that a true European Charter for the Elderly should be born.

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE)
text: "blue card" answer. I have no objection to this proposal and I think that we could, without any problems, join forces to study its feasibility in a cross-party way.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is no doubt that a great and valuable human capital poses a demand for quality of life and well-being in respect of which public policies must reorient the priorities of their agenda. For this reason, the choices of the European institutions must be more incisive in order to achieve the objectives.  It therefore seems to me necessary to share the need to review active labour and training policies for the promotion of other areas of good employment and quality work, using and transferring competence and knowledge to the new generations, rethinking local development models, rebalancing attention to recover lifestyles within a new socio-economic vision of rural inland areas , to give back protagonism to the elderly. The issue of well-being also needs other keys to reading, we need to promote policies for the regeneration of human capital within the framework of a redevelopment of the places of life. So a new humanism for an even more modern idea of sustainable and inclusive development.

name: n/a
text: Thank you very much, Madam President. Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Dear! I am very pleased to be able to refer to the excellent and very important report by Eduard Kukan, which talks about the importance of recognising active ageing as a very important challenge in Europe. It is important for improving the quality of life of seniorcitizens, but also for building a competitive, prosperous and sustainable Europe. An appropriate policy in this area, common to the European Union, is one of our important tasks. It is very important that seniorcitizens are independent, that they are economically independent, and therefore, among those tasks that are already mentioned as already more detailed in the report, it is right to emphasise the prevention of digital exclusion and the prevention of falling out of the labour market of people over the age of 50. I am also pleased that the report takes into account one of the most important problems in the European Union, the 39% pension gap. The fact that the average European woman receives a pension almost forty percent lower than the average European is our shame, and this undoubtedly contributes to the fact that older women are much more likely than older men to be poor and suffer poverty.  The report also rightly emphasises the importance of social enterprises developing services for the elderly and rightly calls for the work on the European Commission document on the accessibility of older people to transport and housing services and products based on information and communication technologies to be accelerated. I think that universal design here can be helpful and the wider introduction of common European legislation in this area would certainly help in terms of accessibility and mobility of those who already have some health problems. The actions of the European Commission are also important. These are recommendations to Member States in the framework of the European Semester in the fields of employment, pensions, social inclusion and long-term care for the elderly. This is important for the right direction and appreciation of senior policy in the European Union. Thank you.

name: Marju Lauristin (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I wish to draw attention to one very important part of this active ageing, namely coping on the digital single market and coping in a digital society. More and more services are moving online. More and more jobs are digitalised. However, among people over 55, only 20% have enough skills to cope in this new situation, according to the European digital scoreboard, and 41% of people over 55 have never been on the Internet. At the same time, we see that business is being overwhelmed with new prospects for the silver economy, but this is only good for 50% of people over 55. This is connected with problems of training, retraining and having special schemes, and it should be a focal point if we also want to bring the ageing population on board in digital Europe.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – First of all, congratulations to Mr Kukan on his excellent report. I am pleased that at least some of the objectives we have set ourselves during the year of active ageing have been achieved. Of course, we still have a long way to go, as ageing is becoming a real challenge for the whole of the Union. Personally, I think it is necessary to recognise the potential of older people and their experiences, as they have a valuable impact on all social sides, including the economy. However, in the face of all the challenges of an ageing society, I would like to highlight the problems associated with ensuring the stability of pension systems. It is true that pension systems are regulated by each country in their own way. Many countries, including my country Slovenia, use the so-called Pay as You Go system, where young people pay for the elderly. It is right that the creation of pension systems is still in the hands of the Member States, but these systems are becoming so unsustainable that this is becoming a problem for the whole of Europe. I therefore, of course, think that europe as a whole should be more involved in surveillance and also in the recommendations on how Member States should design their systems, all with a view to making these stable in the long term and that we have decent pensions guaranteed.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I was proud to hold a European Year event in Bedford, in my constituency, with Britain’s Age UK, about the importance of staying warm, and to take part in exercise programmes called ‘Fit as a fiddle’ in Luton and in Ipswich. I congratulate all involved. But is not the real ‘fiddle’ the claim that we believe in inter-generational solidarity when, in fact, that solidarity is tragically breaking down? How can British pensioners heat their homes when two million of them – paid the lowest pensions as a proportion of GDP of all European countries except Latvia – live in poverty, and when the pre-election promise to cap their social care costs has been cruelly broken less than three months on? Sadly, British pensioners are simply some of the worst victims of cuts in welfare levels, which the Commission Report on Ageing says will decline Europe-wide by a further 2% this year. That Greek pensioner who collapsed on the floor because he could not collect his pension is symbolic of how older people are being treated across our continent. We should think twice before telling them to stay active. Let us start by telling them how they are supposed to survive.

name: Verónica Lope Fontagné (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, increasing life expectancy is one of humanity's great achievements, but in turn increases social needs and pressure on public services. It must therefore be seen as one of the great challenges of the 21st century taking into account the differences between European regions.  In my region, Aragon, as well as in other Spanish regions, there are very aging municipalities that are joined by low population density and high dispersion, which hinders and makes public services more difficult and more important and threatens their survival. The excess cost in services such as education or health becomes five times that of the capital, so an improvement in territorial vertebration or existing infrastructures will help to fix the population, protect its survival and promote active ageing, regardless of where it is living.  We need to take these factors into account so that all the elderly can enjoy lifelong learning or new technologies in order to work, increase their participation in society and ultimately improve their well-being.

name: Lambert van Nistelrooij (PPE).
text: I am pleased that Mr Kukan's report looks back to 2012. I remember that moment. It was an active ageing, said the Commission, and then we also looked at it from Age Europe, the umbrella of the organisations and from the intergroup, and said: you can only do that by adding solidarity between the generations. I am still glad that this happened then, because without a change in policy, we see it in the care sector alone, one in four young people should be working in the care sector. That's the challenge. There's another way. It's got to be different.  The second point is that in Europe, many people are retiring. Two retired and one younger one back. This gives unique opportunities, both for the younger generation and for the elderly. So as such, I think it has been a very positive approach and, above all - I look at the Commissioner - that we should continue to do so. We have that partnership. We've put a lot of projects behind that. In view of THE EU 2020, can I expect the Commission to take it up and continue it during this period?

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE).
text: – Thank you very much, Madam President. The ageing of the European population is a fact, and statistics only confirm this trend. This situation therefore requires a change in the approach to older people, not only by raising awareness of their contribution to society and solidarity between generations, but also by taking concrete action and financial resources to ensure that this group is as active as possible in society and to use their knowledge and skills. I am pleased that the European Commission has recognised that the Polish in the field of senior policy in the framework of the European Year of Active Ageing and Intergenerational Solidarity was one of the largest. From here I would like to pay tribute to the creators and listeners of third-century universities, of which there are more than five hundred and twenty in Poland, because they become a platform for the activity of thousands of older people and enable them to realize challenges that they have not had a chance to face before. Thank you very much.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, active ageing and intergenerational solidarity are issues discussed at length during the European Year 2012. Some objectives of the European Year, such as raising public awareness of people's optimal quality of life during ageing, have been achieved. However, there are some outstanding issues. Firstly, there should be an increase in funding for social security systems and public infrastructure for the elderly, such as nursing homes. Particular emphasis should also be placed on sparsely populated and island regions, such as the Aegean islands, which have fewer means and infrastructure to promote active demand, as well as more generally for regions with demographic handicaps. In addition, the problem of unemployment among people over the age of 50 should be addressed and the discrimination and obstacles faced by these people in their job search should be stopped. Finally, particular attention should be paid to pension schemes and pension rights in order to ensure a decent life for older people.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, Europe must assume that funding programmes that promote active ageing is an investment.  There is knowledge that is only acquired in the professional exercise and there is no progress without experience. In addition, the increase in life expectancy and the percentage of older people with specific skills, skills and needs has led to a new volunteering and the silver economy, which is already a source of employment and innovation.  In short, society and the economy are rediscovering the value of the elderly. We need to combat stereotypes, we need politicians and citizens aware that addressing demographic change and its consequences rightly is the key to the future.  There are plenty of accountants who call spending programmes for a citizen like the European one, which in 2050 will have an average age of 50 years.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE).
text: – I am grateful to my colleague Kukan for an excellent report and I welcome the results of the European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations, which has not only brought about a shift in consciousness.  Attitudes towards the elderly will be an increasingly important indicator of the quality of European culture and policy. It is not just a political project, it is a social and cultural project, a paradigm shift. Active ageing and solidarity between generations are essential for a more inclusive Europe and for achieving the objectives of thrise Europe 2020. It is important that we maintain and encourage the process. Initiatives taken in the context of the European Year must be upgraded and made into a strong political commitment, which must be followed by concrete actions. However, it will also be necessary to address the other side of the demographic problem and, despite the refugee crisis, to address the issue of active reovening of the European population. If the young generation is outnumbered, it will be difficult, heavily burdened, to provide desirable solidarity. The long-term strategic objective must be to balance the European demographic pyramid.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, there was, of course, much good in Mr Kukan's report. Of course, I'm afraid I can't support her.  Neither of us is against pensioners, and certainly not against intergenerational solidarity. It bothers me, however, that it was known between the lines that a colleague would not mind an increased retirement, and with that I have a fundamental problem. Raising the average age and ageing population cannot be used as an argument for raising the retirement age. Citizens have spent at least four decades at work before retirement and deserve to be rewarded for their work, earned values and effort. We must also remember that they have contributed to the social system all their lives. Personally, I believe that we should rather focus on how to ensure that citizens of retirement age live to life, that is, on appropriate health care and good social conditions, and that they have decent rest conditions. That is, sufficient pension, housing and care. We should also consider whether some professions, such as miners, would be worth considering introducing a Europe-wide limit on the possibility of early retirement.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to stress, first of all, Mr Kukan's good work and his excellent work in an exceptional report, to which I have been able to contribute some amendments.  I would like to highlight one important fact: it seems to me that Europe is gradually facing a serious challenge, which is called the 'demographic decline', which already affects several European regions, including my own region, Galicia, due to low birth rate, population decline and high population dispersion. And these facts are aggravated in rural areas.  A few years ago, a European network of demographic change regions was created, with more than forty regions. It seeks to raise awareness of the problems posed by this demographic decline for the European Union and its economic, social and territorial cohesion.  This is a very serious problem that is on the rise and that we are not all aware of yet. I am therefore very pleased that this Kukan report will meet this serious challenge and ask the European Commission to examine this issue and to draw up a communication with possible solutions at three levels: at European level, at state level and at regional level.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Madam President, the well-to-do wrapper of active ageing hides the well-thought-out strategy of the monopolies of the European Union and its governments for the total demolition of public social security, health and welfare systems. The fund needs an experienced workforce to work until old age, with working-rubber relationships, with hunger wages, supplementing some poor-school allowance that will be baptized a pension. Health becomes the individual responsibility of the elderly who will have to strive for independent living while they have paid a lifetime for insurance contributions. At the same time, you want to feed your new golden silver economy of companies that sell so-called healthy aging services. This is the capitalist system you serve and it's bankrupt. It leads to the barbarity of working until your death. Hands off social security! The workers, the people, must oppose their own power and alliance against these plans, on the road to overthrowing this rotten capitalist system that cannot be healed.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Ageing the population is an element of progress, that is not a problem. And we must invest in this evolution, which is a view that the Commission shares with you. Ageing of the population and the associated challenges will increase in the coming years. Because we know that the baby boom cohort is reaching retirement age and we must now use the momentum of the European Year to step up our efforts and improve the quality of life of older people in all respects; Parliament's report indicates the right direction for this, for which thanks.  Attention has been drawn to the special position of the unemployed among the older population group. I can tell you that in the coming weeks we will be putting forward an initiative to combat long-term unemployment. Long-term unemployment is also a problem among the older part of the population. They are having a hard time getting back to work, and I hope that this initiative will certainly benefit them as well. At least I believe in that.  There has also been talk of pensions. Pensions must not only be sustainable, in the financial sense of the word, namely that governments can still pay them, but they must also be adequate and they must reach a decent level. That is, a level at which people can continue to have a decent standard of living, even when they leave the labour market. But to achieve this, more people will have to work, more people will have to work and people will also have to work longer and we also know that this is not easy. This has an impact on the organisation of work. This has an impact on the workability of work. We will also look at this together with the social partners, because we must ensure working conditions and safety and health at work in order to make this possible. Skills have been talked about. People need to keep the necessary skills to keep working. We must pay particular attention to this. Lifelong learning, skilling, reskilling, that's something that's definitely going to be addressed in the skills agenda that we're going to be proposing in 2016. And in doing so, we will pay particular attention to the group of older workers or older people in society.  As far as the question of a strategy is concerned, I can reply that, in line with its previous strategic communications between 2006 and 2009, the Commission has certainly made a serious contribution over the last 15 years to raising awareness of the challenges posed by an ageing population, thus helping Member States to be prepared for them. Demographic change is something that has been mainstreamed in the Commission's policy in various cases. We support adapting to demographic change in areas such as social policy, employment, education, transport, ICT, research, but also in the context of economic, fiscal and regional policy. And adjusting policies in a democracy does indeed require change; this remains an integral part of our Europe 2020 strategy and is also clearly present in country specific recommandations. We will make sure that that attention does not slacken. Initiatives such as the White Paper on Pensions, a 2012 initiative, or the social investment package launched in 2013, offer prospects and guidance for the future to policy makers on how best to address the challenges. I am convinced that the strategic orientations we find in them remain valid. The priority now is that these strategic orientations are properly implemented and properly addressed in each of our policy areas. That requires constant attention. This requires a concentration on this problem. That also requires a kind of cultural change. But if we continue to work on that, Then I am sure we will succeed. Today's report by Rapporteur Kukan gives a very good idea for this, and I would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs and all those who have contributed to this report and debate.

name: Eduard Kukan
text: Rapporteur. – I would like to thank all my colleagues who took part in the debate for their contributions. This debate has confirmed that the issue of active ageing is an agenda that affects us all, regardless of political parties or other matters, and that this is therefore another reason to deal with it as seriously as possible and to ensure that seniors are truly dignified and on an equal status as all the other components of our society. In the isolated voice that claimed that this report is just a fig leaf to try to keep people in employment for as long as possible, I want to say that there is nothing like this in this report, and if they have read it between the lines, they have a very lush imagination. I have emphasised this many times when we have spoken about this issue. Commissioner Tisen's final word showed that the European Commission deals in detail, very analytically, very specifically with regard to individual aspects of this issue, and that it has a certain perspective or a certain strategy for the future on how to deal with all these important issues. I would like to say that it is here that the Commission and Parliament can cooperate very well, very closely, so that the situation of our senior citizens is changed as soon as possible so that they feel normal equal citizens of the European Union.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I recognise the issues impacting an ageing population, and the need to plan for that. Nevertheless, this debate refers to the year 2012 and is somewhat out of date. This matter was debated fully (at least by the standards of this Chamber). I am astonished that a Citizens’ Initiative signed by 1.9 million people is afforded no debate time and catch-the-eye only, whilst this report receives a full debate. We need to recall that citizens should always be a priority. On the matter at hand, medical training within the member states is vital. Importing medical professionals, often from developing countries, leads to considerable lack of resources in those countries. We need to step up efforts to train more home-grown medical professionals.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Year of Active Ageing was undoubtedly a legitimate initiative to raise awareness of the problem of ageing.  For some Member States, it has also been an important impetus to address the topic of active ageing and preparation for old age. The list of national projects presented in the report itself shows this very clearly. Another plus is the start of work on the establishment of a Pan-European Agreement on Demographic Change. The Commission should provide funding for this initiative as it will be an important grassroots movement in this policy.  Unfortunately, in summing up the European Year of Active Ageing, we are also coming to less positive conclusions. The mere fact that only 4.5 000 people have officially been officially involved in his initiatives shows little interest in the subject. If we add to this the low participation of social organisations and the private sector in this year's celebrations, it is legitimate to say that it has served only the Union and its Member States. It seems that not all actors still sufficiently recognise the importance of the problem of ageing populations. Finally, I would like to point out that it is a mistake not to continue the Grundtvig programme, which promotes volunteering for older people. If we want to activate the elderly, it is these initiatives that should be supported.

name: Marek Plura (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Eduard Kukek's report on the European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations rightly emphasises that the European Union needs an integrated strategy to respond to demographic change. This applies not only to issues such as the efficiency of pension systems or the need for health services. The new demographic situation requires innovative solutions, including the equalisation of age-related fitness deficits using new technologies and the introduction of more flexible forms of employment. An important dimension is the quality of life of older people, the promotion of their active participation in all dimensions of social and economic life and the taking of actions conducive to cooperation, understanding and mutual respect between representatives of different generations. Awareness of the huge contribution of older people to social and economic life is still low. Older people are a significant group of consumers, stimulating the development of sectors such as tourism and health, care and rehabilitation services, as well as stable, loyal employees with expertise and experience.  I believe that it is of great importance to make employers aware of the potential of older workers and to disseminate good practices in terms of m.in use of it, m.in. in the education of young people in the workplace. The elderly are also a huge number of volunteers and people caring for dependent persons and helping young families reconcile work and childcare. Without their support and commitment, it is difficult to achieve the objective of rebuilding Europe's economy and social capital.

name: Preşedinte. –

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, the fisheries agreement between the European Union and Guinea-Bissau can be considered one of the most important in force today. It is one of the few fisheries agreements in the European Union that allows access to mixed fisheries. The country has enormous wealth in resources, but is considered one of the least advanced countries. It is estimated that two thirds of families live below the poverty line. Its gross domestic product per capita is one of the lowest in the world. Its economy depends heavily on agriculture, in particular cashew. Artisanal fishing, including subsistence fishing, ensures the survival of thousands of fishermen.  Although it signed the first fisheries agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Guinea-Bissau 35 years ago, the results achieved so far, by sectoral comparison, are clamorously scarce. 3/4 of the approximately 1,500 vessels registered in 2009 were canoe-type, made from tree trunks.  We consider a more detailed assessment and consideration of this agreement, its history and future prospects necessary. Considering the role and competences of the European Parliament in this area, we consider it appropriate and necessary to approve a non-legislative resolution on this agreement. The agreement should promote a more effective and sustainable development of the Guinean fisheries sector, as well as related industries and activities, in particular small-scale fishing, which contribute significantly to food security and sovereignty and local livelihoods, increasing the added value in the country and contributing to improving the quality of life of the population , as a result of the exploitation of its natural resources.  Mechanisms should be set up for greater transparency, accountability and participation of the local population, in particular fishing communities practising small-scale artisanal fishing, including the possible revision and increase of the component of the agreement for sectoral support, alongside the creation of others and better conditions to increase and ensure that the positive repercussions of this agreement fall , preferably in local communities.  Persistent and lasting efforts are needed to produce positive results and, in line with, as examples of areas to be supported, institutional capacity building, vocational training, artisanal fishing, a greater focus on gender policies, with a recognition and appreciation of the role of women, distribution, marketing of fish, conservation, first processing.  As with other countries in the region, it is considered necessary to improve the quantity and reliability of catch information in general on the state of conservation of fisheries resources, in addition to support for the development of own capacities by Guinea-Bissau. Finally, we stress that this Parliament must be immediately and fully informed, at all stages, of the procedures relating to the Protocol or its renewal. It is proposed to report annually to Parliament and the Council on the results of the multiannual sectoral programme referred to in Article 3 of the Protocol and on compliance with the requirement for declarations of catches.

name: Peter van Dalen
text: Rapporteur. Commissioner, please note that you can be there today.  I present my report on the council's draft decision on the conclusion of a Protocol between the European Union and the Republic of Cape Verde establishing fishing opportunities and financial consideration; In addition to a draft legislative resolution, I have also tabled a non-legislative resolution. It is precisely because of this that Parliament can say more than just yes or no to the fisheries agreement. I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs, the European Commission, and certainly the secretariat of our Fisheries Committee for cooperation.  Unfortunately, Cape Verde is not a highly developed country. It ranks 131st on the UN Development Index, which has a total of 187 countries. The economy is growing a bit, especially tourism. It is a regret that just last week the archipelago was hit by a major hurricane for the first time in more than a hundred years. Fortunately, the damage from this hurricane was not so great. But what you do see is increased uncertainty. Are such storms more likely to occur, does that possibly have to do with climate change? As far as the draft legislative resolution is concerned, I recommend that Parliament approve the new protocol. I think that is advantageous, both for the European Union and for our fishermen who use it. But it is also important for Cape Verde to get economic returns from the fisheries stocks in their waters. Fortunately, Mr Ponga, on behalf of the Committee on Development, and Mr Fernandes, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, also came to this finding; thanks to both rapporteurs for their opinions.  The European Union concluded a fisheries partnership agreement with Cape Verde in 1990 and six protocols have been implemented since then. So we are now dealing with the seventh protocol, which has a duration of four years. The total amount involved in the agreement is EUR 3.3 million and can be roughly divided into EUR 1 million to compensate for access to the waters, eur 1 million for sectoral support and 1.2 million compensations from ship owners.  Compared to the previous protocol, the amount of sectoral aid in particular has increased enormously. It has even doubled, and that means more projects for better monitoring of fisheries and also combating illegal fishing.  In addition, there are projects for increased safety for local fishermen in particular and for the training and training of these people, and I also think it is positive to report that European ship owners are also going to contribute more to the quotas they use. Then the sharks. That is an issue for which I have tabled a non-legislative resolution. Because the catch of sharks has increased sharply in these waters off Cape Verde, even doubled. 1700 tonnes in 2008, 3300 tonnes in 2012. This worrying development has led to three measures being included in this Protocol. 1. The number of longliners is reduced from 35 to 30, and these are the fishermen and the fishing methods that bring out many sharks.  2. Shark catches are tracked and thresholds of 1500 and 2000 tonnes are built in, after which management measures can be taken. 3. There will be an investigation into the life of the sharks in that area there.  Of course, I know that this is a sensitive issue, and these measures in the protocol are a first step, but I think the thresholds built into these measures are quite low. They'll be made quickly. I think it is important for this Parliament that we keep our finger on the pulse by following developments closely, and I ask the Commission to do the same. There is a real need to take steps, because sharks are a vulnerable fish stock and should not be overfished. They are part of God's creation and vital in the ecosystem. That is why I am asking you to support my amendment which will make this text a little more.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, a special greeting to Commissioner Vella. The second half of the 20th century was paradigmatic in terms of the management of the seas and oceans. The visionary United Nations International Law of the Sea was agreed, based on values as relevant as the precautionary principle, peace-building, resource sharing, the protection of biodiversity, sustainable development, the ecosystem vision, the idea of an ocean.  But we also witnessed, and despite the law, the excess of fishing and the collapse of wild springs. Associated with the decline of resources in traditional fishing grounds, some industrial fleets, many of them European, migrated to the high seas and the deep sea. European countries have developed from the largest distant fishing fleets, have established fisheries agreements with many ACP countries. It should be noted that the International Law of the Sea provides that countries that do not use their renewable marine resources should make them available to third countries. Cooperation agreements for the fisheries area are thus ambassadors of the European Union for maritime issues. But fishing agreements cannot be a leak forward in order to recover the ecological footprint we leave behind. They must be ambassadors for sustainable development cooperation and good fishing practice. Unlike others, European fleets today comply with legal frameworks based on environmental accountability, based on better scientific knowledge and ecosystem approximation. Fishing agreements are now better prepared today than 40, 30, 20, 10, or even 5 years ago. They address issues such as identifying living springs, respect for workers' rights, stimulating local fisheries sectors and respect for environmental constraints. In the event of failure – and there are failures – the different legal regimes of European countries tend, by very recent provisions, to be increasingly inflexible and efficient. For example, I would remind you that one of the European governments increased the maximum penalties to EUR 11 million for non-compliance. I am convinced that the fisheries agreement with Madagascar, of which I am rapporteur, can help to improve the conditions of a country with enormous difficulties while benefiting European fleets. This partnership agreement is based on the rules laid down by the relevant fisheries organisations and includes fishing opportunities for 94 vessels. More than 15,000 tonnes of fish are expected to be caught in the waters of madagascar's Exclusive Economic Zone and, in return for its use of this area, the European Union will finance Madagascar and its fishing sector, in particular for more than EUR 6 million over four years. In the case of the Cape Verde agreement, in which I am shadow rapporteur, I am concerned about the level of uncertainty of the impact of fisheries on shark populations, as my colleague van Dalen has already said, but I welcome the provisions of the agreement to study this subject in detail. The amendments to the report reinforce these aspects and will have my support. Although I am not directly responsible for the Guinea-Bissau report, I think we will have to take particular care in monitoring this agreement. The political instability of this country is worrying and this agreement should be another factor of rapprochement with local authorities and development communities, particularly fishing communities. It is therefore important to monitor these agreements by the Commission, ensuring that negligence and corruption are escaping. At first, I think it is necessary to invest in inadequate infrastructure, which runs the risk of being scorned or out of step with outdated infrastructure. These are important issues. But smaller, when compared to the major problems of international fisheries. Abuse of labour, illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, including the use of flags of convenience and the use of technologies not assessed from an environmental point of view, are gaps that have to be addressed. I applaud the efforts made by the European Commission, but I stress, with the same wisdom that has been used so far, we need to go much further.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, it is a pleasure to be here for this joint debate on the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreements and the associated Protocols with Madagascar, Guinea-Bissau and Cape Verde. I welcome this opportunity to discuss these protocols with you, and I would like to thank, first and foremost, the rapporteurs – Mr Serrão Santos, Mr Ferreira, who was represented by Ms Senra Rodríguez, and Mr van Dalen – for their reports. I am also pleased to note that the reports adopted in the Committee on Fisheries recommend that Parliament give its assent to the three protocols we will be discussing today. I can assure you that I have taken careful note of your suggestions for improvement. Our strategy underlying fisheries agreements is to consolidate and possibly extend the network of agreements, in particular tuna agreements. These agreements will allow our fleet to rely on a real continuum of agreements in the three main regions concerned – basically the Atlantic, the Indian Ocean and the Pacific – bringing stable and consistent rules for its fishing operations. At the same time, they will ensure the sustainable use of fisheries resources. They will support effective fisheries management and they will contribute to the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) fishing, and they will help the development of local industries and guarantee good value for EU taxpayers’ money. Let me now say a few words on each of these protocols. The biggest of the three fisheries agreement, as has been mentioned, is the one with Guinea- Bissau. It is essential for the EU fleet and it is also vital for the economy of Guinea-Bissau, which is highly dependent on fisheries. Under the new protocol, the EU fleet has been able to resume its fishing activities in Guinea-Bissau after an interruption of over two years, and these fishing activities are sustainable: the stocks are considered to be in a good state and fisheries indicators such as catch levels and fishing effort have remained stable over the past years. Fishing opportunities were, in fact, slightly reduced and we took specific conservation measures. Having said this, it is clear that the situation needs to be monitored very closely. Scientific cooperation with Guinea-Bissau should also be intensified, as well as scientific cooperation at regional level. Sectoral support to Guinea-Bissau has been programmed mainly to improve the management of fisheries resources, to further reinforce control and surveillance capacities, to improve sanitary conditions and to promote artisanal fisheries. Allow me to turn now to another partner in the region, Cape Verde. Although this fisheries agreement is the smallest in financial terms, it is of strategic importance for the EU fleet because of high catch volumes and its position in the regional network of tuna agreements. As Mr van Dalen mentioned, the sustainability of shark fishing was a concern under the previous protocol. Several measures are therefore included in the new protocol to regulate shark catches by EU vessels more effectively. Firstly, the reduction in fishing opportunities for longliners is expected to reduce or at least ‘freeze’ the number of shark catches. Secondly, the protocol provides for a monitoring mechanism for shark catches and a study on the situation of sharks in Cape Verde and the wider region. We will monitor closely the implementation of these measures, which should also be seen in the wider framework of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT). The new sectoral support programme will focus on reinforcing Cape Verde’s monitoring, control and surveillance capacity through the installation of a new vessel monitoring system (VMS) and the introduction of electronic catch reporting. Let me now turn to the EU-Madagascar Protocol. This protocol is an important part of a broader network of fisheries agreements with coastal states in the south-western part of the Indian Ocean. Let me highlight just two of its key elements: first, its contribution to the development of the Malagasy domestic fishing sector, in particular its small-scale component; and, second, its provisions on sharks and the protection of the most vulnerable species. In terms of sectoral support, the protocol aims to strengthen the monitoring and control capacities of the Malagasy authorities nationally and also at the level of the south-western Indian Ocean. This should help make Madagascar one of the major regional players in the fight against IUU fishing. Here too Mr Serrão Santos raised the concern about sharks. On shark fishing, the protocol very clearly defines the scope of authorised shark fisheries. Allowable species show either stable abundance indices or slight positive trends. In addition, through its catch limits, the protocol will clearly constrain fishing mortality on sharks in Malagasy waters. With regard to protection of the most vulnerable species – and I am referring here to sharks, sea-turtles, marine mammals and seabirds – the measures in the protocol go beyond management conservation measures adopted by regional fisheries management organisations. The protocol specifically defines prohibited species in relation to capture and retention on board. On top of this, EU ship-owners have put in place best practices to decrease incidental catches and to handle vulnerable species caught incidentally in fishing gear. Let me thank you again for today’s opportunity to debate three of our fisheries agreements. I look forward to hearing your views.

name: José Manuel Fernandes
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome the signing or this proposal for new protocols, but I am going to comment specifically on the Fisheries Protocol between the European Union and the Republic of Cape Verde, since I was draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets.  I stress its compliance, compliance with legal standards, with the sustainability measures of the new fisheries common policy, both from an environmental and socio-economic point of view, thereby enabling a partnership framework for the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fisheries resources in the fisheries area of the Republic of Cape Verde.  I also consider it important to monitor and monitor, in accordance with the Protocol, and for the Commission to report annually to Parliament on additional international agreements with Cape Verde so that the European Parliament can monitor all fishing activities in the region.  I hope that this protocol will go well, to contribute to the economic development of Cape Verde and to the rapprochement between the European Union and the Republic of Cape Verde.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. Mr President, Commissioner, I fully agree with what Mr Fernandes has just said about the new protocols, on compliance with regulations and, above all, on respect for environmental issues and on the fact that, every time, a report must be made to Parliament. I will rather insist on the Madagascar agreement since I have been rapporteur on this issue. I believe that this is a win-win relationship between the European Union and Madagascar, since, on the one hand, the agreement allows Europeans to continue fishing in territorial waters and, on the other hand, it allows Madagascar above all to benefit from a whole scheme and the implementation of good practices.  I believe that this is a very interesting agreement which allows Madagascar to find itself at the heart of a system in the Indian Ocean, which is a mechanism to maintain the population of the fish in question and, above all, to evolve and take advantage of this situation.

name: Alain Cadec
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the objective of transparency and mutual interest must guide the external side of the common fisheries policy. Since the adoption of the reform of the new Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) in 2013, new fundamental principles on the external component have been set in stone. The principle of the mutual interest of the parties, sustainable governance, revision clauses in the event of human rights violations or commitments made in the fight against illegal, unreported or unregulated fishing, and also, finally, respect for the surplus, defined by the latest scientific opinions, that European vessels are allowed to fish.  The conservation and sustainable exploitation of fisheries resources is at the heart of these fisheries agreements. The CFP must promote sustainable fisheries governance at European and international level. The international presence of European industry in the countries with which we have sustainable fisheries agreements allows us to supply the European market while developing local fishing activity in third countries. The joint agreement with Guinea-Bissau is particularly important because of the diversity of species caught. The European market is the world's largest market for fish products. We import more than 70% of the fish products consumed in Europe. We must therefore enable its supply of quality products while respecting the principles of sustainable fishing in its environmental, social and economic dimensions. I would like to conclude by pointing out that Parliament wishes to be informed on a regular basis throughout the negotiation process and to be associated with the meetings of the joint committees.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Commissioner, we are facing a debate on three very important conventions in Europe's international fisheries policy and, of course, I would like to stress that these are three very important conventions for my country, Spain, and for the Spanish fleet, which depends on these conventions succeeding. But I would like to stress , I think Mr Denanot said that with these three agreements, with these three conventions, both Europe and these third countries benefit. And that is, I believe, a clear success of the objective of this fisheries policy. I wanted to focus especially on Guinea-Bissáu. Guinea-Bissau, as you have highlighted, Commissioner, suffered a coup d'eer. This convention is clearly very interesting for the European fishing fleet, but it must also contribute to the democratic stability of Guinea-Bissa-u and I believe that it will do so. I would like to highlight the good condition of the populations and the indicators of stability, and I find the non-legislative resolution which we have adopted in the committee and which is also brought here very interesting. I believe that it will bring clarity and transparency to this agreement with Guinea-Bissaeu. I hope that all three will be approved because, of course, the Spanish and all European fisheries sectors are going to benefit greatly.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I would like to support the signing of these third generation fisheries agreements with Madagascar, Cape Verde and Guinea-Bissau because the nearly EUR 20 million they will contribute to these countries contribute to developing the local fisheries industry and maintaining European industry, both in the extractive and processing sectors. In addition, they promote the most sustainable and controlled fishing practices, and are a first-rate instrument in the fight against unregulated and undeclared fishing. They also propose realistic alternatives to replace well-intentioned but impossible-to-apply proposals, such as those on shark fishing. These agreements also improve the impact of funds on local development and contribute to the stability of these countries.  The clearest example — as the Commissioner has already said - is the Agreement with Guinea-Bissa-u, which was resumed after last year's May elections, which ended the open situation with the 2012 coup d'eer. Collaboration with this country dates back to 1980. In total, the agreements offer fishing grounds and fishing opportunities to 265 vessels, which also help maintain the shipbuilding industry. European shipyards are innovating to improve ship efficiency and sustainability and incorporating technical means to prevent discards.  For these reasons, I ask you to support these proposals and encourage you to banish some stereotypes that do not respond at all to the responsibility with which our fishing industry works in the world.

name: Liadh Ní Riada
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa GUE/NGL. – A Uachtaráin, tá prionsabail agus pointí maithe sna tuarascálacha seo agus tá fiúntas ag gabháil leo. Tá sé thar a bheith tábhachtach go ndéanfaí forbairt agus infheistiú sa tionscal iascaireachta dúchasach, ach caithfear an ruaig a chuir ar an tionscal iascaireachta mídhleathach chun ár n-iascairí beaga dúchasacha a chosaint ionas gur féidir leo slí bheatha a bhaint amach. Ní féidir leis na hiascairí beaga seo dul in iomaíocht leis na trálaeir ollmhóra, mar shampla iad siúd a thagann ón Rúis nó ón Astráil nó ón tSín. Slogann siad suas tromlach cuibheasach de stoic éisc agus is fíorbheagán a fhágann siad do na hiascairí beaga úd atá ag streachailt. Ní hé go bhfuil na cabhlaigh thionsclaíocha ón Aontas Eorpach puinn níos fearr, caithfidh mé a rá. Caithfear moltaí a chur i bhfeidhm a chuirfidh cosc ar na cabhlaigh ollmhóra atá ag saothrú na stoc atá ag na tíortha atá i mbéal forbartha. Táim á rá seo mar go dtuigimid go maith an scéal in Éirinn agus an fhulaingt atá á iompar ag ár n-iascairí de dheasca an iomad solúbthachta a bheith ann maidir le trálaeir eachtrannacha a bhíonn ag iascaireacht go mídhleathach timpeall ár gcósta gan aon stró. Tá súil agam nach bhfeicfimid an rud céanna seo ag tarlú i Rinn Verde, agus i Madagascar agus gan dabht i nGuine Bissau.

name: Linnéa Engström
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Tomorrow we will take a position on fisheries agreements between the EU and Cape Verde, Madagascar and Guinea Bissau. Madagascar and Cape Verde are about tuna fishing and are relatively well designed, so we will support these agreements.  The main problem with the tuna agreements is that over the years they have come to include ever greater by-catches of sharks. Attention has been drawn to these two agreements, and there are clauses in both agreements to reduce shark by-catch. We will therefore support these agreements. As far as the Protocol with Guinea Bissau is concerned, we think it is a hasty and is quite disappointed with the way it has been produced. This so-called new protocol negotiated after the political situation stabilised in Guinea Bissau is nothing more than an old protocol. It looks exactly the same as the protocol that was suspended in 2012, when there was a military coup in Guinea Bissau.  A lot has happened over these years. New Chinese boats have been added, there have been cheating supints with false tonnage certificates, and there have been reports of illegal fishing. The Commission has been in such a hurry when it was free to negotiate again that it did not consider itself to have time to re-evaluate. Everything is based on the old evaluation from 2011. How can we make a fair assessment if we really only fish for the surplus that Guinea Bissau cannot exploit itself? That is, of course, one of the basic rules of the new external fisheries policy in the new reform. Moreover, the political situation is worrying to say the least. The government was recently dissolved, in August 2015, and there are corruption allegations that also relate to fishing licences. We will not vote in favour of the conclusion of this protocol with Guinea Bissau.

name: Raymond Finch
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, I am utterly against these resource grabs. They establish, yet again, the dominance of powerful interests over those of indigenous peoples in poor nations. Madagascar has had the EU access quotas increased by 30%, while the access fees granted to Madagascar have decreased by 20%. The resolution talks in big words about tightening monitoring, but Madagascar only has 11 police boats to cover around 5 000 kilometres of coast. These fine words mean nothing. Cape Verde is paid just EUR 3.3 million for four years of 71 EU boats plundering its seas – again, colonialist tactics to exploit a poorer nation. What is the EU? A new empire? As for Guinea-Bissau, the EU is exploiting its political instability and indirectly encouraging the move from subsistence fishing to drug smuggling. The EU should be ashamed.  Finally, regarding sharks, the south and west coasts of the UK are full of small sharks. This has nothing to do with the disgraceful practice of finning. Regulated fishing of them should be restarted.

name: Dominique Bilde
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, European fish consumption per capita currently amounts to 22 kg per year and, as a result, Europe is obliged to import 65% of the fish it consumes. This is reflected in fisheries agreements between the European Union and 21 other countries in the world, including Madagascar, so that our shipowners can fish in Malagasy waters. Efforts are being made to invest in infrastructure, support local populations and preserve biodiversity, but nothing is being done to prevent overfishing, as evidenced by the increase in European fishing quotas. Shipowners also need to be put to greater use, whereas at present it is the European taxpayer who funds Madagascar's fisheries through subsidies.  A member of the EU-Madagascar friendship group, I visited a fishing company in Nosy Be last February during a study trip, the lack of equipment was glaring.  That is why I believe that the Union should instead demand the hiring of more local fishermen and the establishment of training, promote a better fight against illegal fishing and monitor the application of the criteria requested if we really want to improve the situation on the ground.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the European Union must in any case be a leader in international for a, strengthening its presence both in international negotiations and in regional fisheries organisations and in all the world's oceans. If we do not take our place in these for a and in the oceans, other fleets far less concerned about sustainability than the European Union's fleets will do for us. However, the European Parliament is the great absentee on this issue. Negotiations are conducted by the Commission, with the blessing of the Council, and often with its back to Parliament. And this can't go on like this. The role of the European Parliament must be on an equal footing with the Council on agreements. In this area, I intend to make proposals for you very soon, Commissioner. We must be satisfied because this is the first time that there has been a section on sustainable fisheries partnership agreements in the regulation of the common fisheries policy. This is a substantial change. In the past, fisheries agreements with third countries focused almost exclusively on trade; today, with greater transparency, the focus is on partnerships, governance and cooperation, with these agreements being subject to regular evaluations. The fisheries agreements with Cape Verde, Madagascar and Guinea-Bissau, which we are voting on tomorrow, are of enormous importance. The agreement with Guinea-Bissau is a clear example that agreements can finally have a significant impact on the local economy and even on the political and social stability of the countries concerned. From the European Parliament, of course, we are clearly committed to them.

name: Ulrike Rodust (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her When we vote tomorrow on the three partnership agreements, we are literally doing so in partnership. In partnership with the contracting countries, such as Guinea-Bissau, Cape Verde and Madagascar, on the one hand, and with the Member States of the European Union on the other. What does that mean? The European Union receives a certain amount of fish, and in return the people of the contracting countries receive the appropriate money to improve their livelihoods. The European Union can only fish as much as it can grow, and only the surpluses not used by a third country. With our agreements, we call on our partners to guarantee the Cotonou Convention, in particular Article 9 on human rights, democratic principles, the rule of law and good governance. I say this also to Guinea-Bissau. If our partners do not respect this, it is possible to suspend these agreements. All of this has been the case since 2014 and is crucial for us. We too, the members of the European Union, have given new rules to our fishermen. If our trawlers do not comply with the rules of the CFP, namely to end overfishing, we can deprive them of their fishing rights for up to two years. I therefore assume that in future Europeans will fish fairly and that the terrible images in the media of how we are emptying the seas of the Third World will finally no longer have to be shown. For me, the new fisheries agreements are also an important step towards combating the causes of flight.

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the main objective of fisheries partnership agreements is to provide Members of the European Union with fishing opportunities in the waters of third countries with catch quotas within the limits of the available surplus and in compliance with the Common Fisheries Policy Regulation and the principles of good governance.  More than the economic aspect, the European Union should use these agreements to strengthen cooperation instruments and promote the development of these countries in the social and environmental fields. Such cooperation instruments should therefore focus on combating corruption of holders of public office with responsibilities in the fisheries area, and the European Union should suspend agreements where there are political changes that violate human rights or the principles of democracy. They should also implement programmes to combat unreported and unregulated illegal fishing, as well as the sustainable and responsible exploitation of local resources and their monitoring.  In summary, that fisheries partnership agreements naturally benefit the countries of the European Union, but also contribute significantly to the development of the countries with which they are concluded and are therefore to be supported and increased. The point is that they are not used as an incentive to feed what the European Union itself has been working to combat: illegal fishing and the degradation of the oceans.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, in the past fisheries agreements have seemed too often to be primarily a mechanism for exporting surplus fleet capacity from certain EU Member States. Also, in many cases, there was very little emphasis given to ensuring that local populations in third countries gained long-term benefit from the exploitation of their resources.  For those reasons and some others, I have most often in the past voted against such agreements in principle. However, one of the key improvements of the common fisheries policy was supposedly to place fisheries partnership agreements on a sounder ethical footing. They are now supposed to adhere to sustainability objectives. Nevertheless, each agreement has to be taken on its merits, and it is regrettable to say that the Guinea-Bissau Protocol is now founded on well out-of-date data, a situation that is avoidable and should have been avoided. I will be able to support the other two agreements but not the one with Guinea Bissau for that reason.

name: Marco Affronte (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, fisheries agreements are a strange phenomenon, while Parliament has very little say in these agreements: in practice, it can say yes or no. Often, they take almost for granted, pass practically everyone and are accompanied by recommendations that then remain only on paper.  Yet their impact is not at all small and should raise many concerns, there are even scientific publications on this subject that are not at all comforting. For example, with regard to the guinea-bissau agreement, which we will be voting on tomorrow, we are talking about poor knowledge about the consequences of this agreement on the marine ecosystem and the problems associated with the lack of up-to-date biological data.  With the new common fisheries policy, sustainability is our primary objective, but we often forget this when we go fishing outside where, in exchange for subsidies paid largely by European citizens and not by the fishing industry. We act like predators. The European Union must remain consistent with its principles: fisheries agreements must be fair, fair and must not put the resources of third countries at risk.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Madam President, fisheries agreements with third countries, as has already been said, are strategic for the Community fleet, including Spain and, in particular, that of my land, Galicia, which is a very important fishing region, as you know. These agreements, namely those concluded with Cape Verde, Guinea-Bissau and Madagascar, are beneficial for both sides: the European Union and the countries concerned. On the one hand, they assure the Union fleet of the continuation of economic activity through sustainable exploitation and, on the other hand, help the development of the third country's fisheries sector in many different respects. By mentioning the Agreement with Guinea-Bissáu, I would like to emphasize that it has benefited, inter alia, that part of the Spanish cephalopod fleet harmed by the exclusion of the Mauritanian Agreement.  And focusing now on the Agreement with Cape Verde, I would like to point out that it is a very important agreement for the fleets of Spain, France and Portugal. It benefits a total of 71 community ships. On the question of sharks, I would like to stress that the Protocol already lays down measures to ensure the sustainability of populations in Cape Verde, and that we will have a report next year, in accordance with the decision taken by the Joint Commission in March this year.  I will also say that the ICCAT reports, which are the body responsible for monitoring shark populations, say that both dry cleaning and dientuous marrajo, which are the two species fished in Cape Verde, are not overexploited and that biomass is well above that which guarantees maximum sustainable yield.  I believe that, in shark matters, this fishing should not be demonized as long as, logically, legal species are captured. And I'm done. I congratulate the Commission and the Commissioner on the new line now being followed by the European Commission of reaching new long-term and fisheries agreements, which gives certainty and security to the European fleet.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D).
