text: Madam President, Commissioner, the issue of fisheries agreements refers to our international fisheries strategy and our priorities, which do include the fight against illegal, undeclared and undocumented fishing. This battle determines not only the future of the resource, but also the future of our fisheries subject to unfair competition in the importation of these seafood products.  In order to meet our sustainability and development challenges, our fisheries agreements can be powerful levers, but to do so we need to be bolder in order to demand more control, strengthen scientific monitoring of species and, of course, promote development in third countries.  Of course, we must welcome, and indeed credit it to the Commission and Parliament, the very positive development of these agreements. However, the Commission too often forgets about fishing when it negotiates international trade agreements. The delegated act with the Philippines opening the floodgates to seafood without traceability or control or the agreement with Thailand, a country listed as employing enslaved fishermen on board ships, shows the urgency of reversing the terms of our trade agreements, which should integrate these environmental and social issues.  As for next year's international meetings, they must help advance our priorities and the fight against illegal fishing.

name: Werner Kuhn (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner! Ladies and gentlemen, I believe that it has become clear in the debate that it is also primarily about the people of Guinea-Bissau, Madagascar or even Cape Verde. They live there in abject poverty and are not able to use their natural resources themselves. They have small beach fishing, small beach boats and may have an income of one euro a day.  That is why these fisheries agreements, which the European Union will conclude with the developing countries, are very important in two respects. On the one hand, these are development measures, that we are advancing the fisheries sector there in Madagascar, Cape Verde and Guinea-Bissau, that they are getting economic development. And on the other hand, that the European fleet can fish there and, of course, according to the rules it has given itself: basic regulation, a ban on discards, complete monitoring and even monitoring. We have AIS, the automatic ship identification system.  In Europe, we know what is happening to our fishing fleet in the Indian Ocean. When it comes to quotas, they are not simply taken out arbitrarily, but the Indian Ocean Tuna Commission determines how many tonnes can be caught. In this respect, we also have a positive development with regard to these treaties, the fisheries agreements, including with the Republic of Madagascar. I will vote in favour tomorrow! Ultimately, it is also a question of tackling the fight against illegal fishing. If we look at the fleets of the Chinese and those of the Russian Federation, I think there is much, much more to be done than with our fleets from Spain, Portugal, Italy and France, which are there.

name: Renata Briano (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to join my fellow Members in supporting the approval of partnership agreements for sustainable fisheries, when they are indeed balanced acts between European countries and third countries and in line with the development cooperation policies pursued to date.  The aim of these treaties is to allow european Union vessels to fish in waters, in this case Guinea-Bissau, Cape Verde and Madagascar, taking into account not only scientific data and assessments, but also international commitments on the protection of endangered species and the fight against illegal fishing. With this partnership, indeed with these partnerships, with a view to solidarity and aid to developing third countries, we intend to strengthen cooperation between the European Union and the rest of the world, in order to promote a reasonable use of fisheries resources, laying the principles of transparency, better governance and non-discrimination as the basis for our negotiations.  The agreements concluded by the European Union with third countries must respect, on the one hand, the principles of sustainability of the common fisheries policy and, on the other, the human rights recognised at European and international level. That is why we must continue to monitor the situation, so that we can also review our choices if these rights are not respected.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the bilateral fisheries agreements, like the ones we are discussing right now, are beneficial features of the common fisheries policy. They are very important because they promote environmental sustainability, as on the one hand they allow the European fleet to access the surplus resources, and on the other hand they subject the vessels to the same rules of control and transparency. This not only leads to long—term resource conservation, but more than that it leads to good governance. This in itself is an added value, but I also personally appreciate the fact that the clauses concerning respect for human rights have been included in all protocols to those fisheries agreements. Considering all this, I think we can fully support them.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – We will therefore vote tomorrow on fisheries partnership agreements with guinea-bissau, Cape Verde and Madagascar. I will vote in favour of these agreements, which have been formulated in negotiations with the European Commission, as they provide mutual benefits. These fisheries partnership agreements are committed to strengthening cooperation between the European Union and these third countries. The partnership framework in place must aim to develop a sustainable fisheries policy, as you have emphasised today, dear colleagues, in the debate, and to promote the responsible exploitation of fisheries resources. It is essential that the European Union's financial contributions in these countries continue to be invested in local fisheries communities for fisheries development. In this process, Parliament's role is only to approve these agreements. However, the European Parliament should play a greater role than the yes or no decision. The idea we have heard from the rapporteurs that the European Parliament should monitor the implementation of these agreements at all stages seems to me to be useful and democratic.

name: Notis Marias (ECR).
text: Mr President, we are currently examining three fisheries agreements with Madagascar, Cape Verde and Guinea-Bisau. First of all, I agree with the reservations expressed by colleagues with regard to the Agreement on Guinea-Bisau. Let me add one more comment and ask: has Guinea-Bisau settled the issues of defining its Exclusive Economic Zone with neighbouring Senegal? We are aware of the problems that have previously arisen from the existence of a grey area of disputed waters, territorial waters between the two countries, a situation which had led to the illegal capture of fishing vessels of the Member States of the European Union fishing in the region on the basis of licences they had obtained from Senegal. So has this been settled? The matter had even gone as far as the Court of Justice of the European Union. A second issue, equally important, of course, which concerns all agreements, is to spread the economic effects in favour of the poor inhabitants of the regions.

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE).
text: Mr President, colleagues and colleagues, Commissioner Vella, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. I am taking the floor because it was said earlier that fisheries agreements are colonialism and exploitation. They used to be, they are no longer. I think that is very important to emphasise. It is true that since there has been a fishing fleet with modern vessels, with freezers on board, fishing has been global. It is fished globally, by the EU, by Asian countries, by many. For a while, it was really exploitation. It was the case that modern vessels in poor countries were emptying the coasts, and the local sector had no chance of getting on its feet. Fortunately, this is different now. In recent years, the EU has done a very good job, even if not everything is perfect. Now, in fact, only what the countries on the ground cannot fish on the ground is being fished by the EU. The money that countries receive as compensation from the EU is used to build up the sector. This is also very good for the situation on the ground. Finally, sustainable fishing is a condition for the EU for these partnership agreements. An absolute win-win situation for both sides and also for the world's fishing resources. That is why I think it is very good that we have that.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we are preparing to renew the fisheries partnership agreement with the Republic of Cape Verde, whose objectives are, among others, the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and the fight against illegal fishing, but we see that the Union's counterparts to Cape Verde are anything but sufficient for the pursuit of these objectives.  In fact, the financial compensation that the Union promises to guarantee Cape Verde is manifestly insufficient, as the Commissioner has rightly said, to ensure a fair and adequate standard of living for Cape Verdean fishing communities, to boost the fish processing sector and to enable the diversification of cape verde's economy.  Does Parliament believe that the amount of EUR 1 050 000 in four years, or otherwise said, of around EUR 22 000/month, as financial compensation for the Union's access to Cape Verde's vast fishing resources is sufficient and fair for Cape Verdeans? Ladies and gentlemen, I believe that, in fact, more than a win/win deal is a genuine European contract for the European Union.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – Of course, these agreements of the common fisheries policy have many positive components. Above all, we see both economically and socially, even downright sustainable, fisheries orientation. In fact, of course, these agreements should be directed for the benefit of both partners. And I think that in some part of the time, this can also be achieved, but of course two key elements are important. One is the data we have, i.e. that this information is current, relevant. And the other is surveillance. This control system can, of course, be an important issue, especially since the countries with which we conclude agreements are, of course, not immune to corruption, irregularities, and therefore, of course, care must be taken not to experience so-called undead fishing, which of course could also endanger fish stocks, which, of course, can be known then even in the ecosystem itself. This is also recalled in shark overfishing, but on the other hand we have good experience in European seas, especially in the overfishing of sea bass.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all the honourable Members who actively participated in this debate. It is good to note that there is substantial support from the European Parliament for these agreements. The European Union’s fisheries partnership agreements (FPAs) promote sustainability and the development of the partner countries’ fisheries sector, particularly in these developing countries, and they are not simply a transfer of money in exchange for access to fishery resources. Here I would like to make three points. Firstly, the sustainable fisheries partnership agreements are a regulated and transparent tool which allows us to frame the activity of the EU fleet in partner-country waters in full observance of the principles of sustainability, good governance and fairness. They are now being recognised as such by most of the stakeholders, including many NGOs. Secondly, our bilateral fisheries agreements are true partnerships, and the sectoral support provided to the partner countries is tailored to the individual needs of each country. Sectoral support has, for example, been used to support artisanal fisheries, to reinforce partner countries’ monitoring, control and surveillance capacity and to improve the availability and quality of scientific data. Thirdly, as implementation can sometimes be challenging, as a result of the limited administrative capacities of some of our partner countries, the Commission monitors the implementation of sectoral support closely and also provides technical support and training. Some Members had reservations in relation to Guinea-Bissau, and the Commission takes note of the nomination of a new government in that country. We remain concerned about the political and institutional situation there and we encourage all political leaders and institutions to work together to overcome the existing divergences and to find a stable solution allowing a peaceful continuation of the reconstruction and reform process. For the time being, the situation has no direct consequences for the fisheries agreement between the European Union and Guinea-Bissau. Nevertheless, it is being followed closely in order to ensure that appropriate measures are taken if necessary and, as Ms Garcia mentioned, the common fisheries policy can only contribute to economic and political stability. I would like to conclude by confirming that these agreements are beneficial to the EU fishing sector and to the partner countries, and also in terms of promoting more sustainable fishing outside the EU and strengthening the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) fishing through the introduction of better controls, monitoring, supervision, scientific research and evaluation. I would like to thank once again the rapporteurs and all of today’s speakers for this interesting debate and for Parliament’s generally positive approach to these three protocols. I am looking forward to tomorrow’s vote.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, in 2010, the European Union Fisheries Agreement with Guinea-Bissau accounted for a quarter of the total economic transfers made by the Union. As reflected in the texts of the fisheries agreements, their objective is to improve the quality of life of the population. In fact, the data state that the objectives have not been achieved.  Unfortunately, this is not different from what we see in other countries with which the European Union establishes fisheries agreements. The economic supremacy of the European Union should not be used to get the governments of these countries to give up their natural resources, but to contribute to improving the quality of life of peoples. We therefore insist on the need for these agreements to contribute to improving the living conditions of local people and supporting the development of artisanal fisheries and industry and related activities. At the same time we call on the Commission to recover, enhance and strengthen artisanal fishing in the European Union itself.

name: Peter van Dalen
text: Rapporteur. I note that there is a broad majority in Parliament to support the fisheries agreement with Cape Verde. Thank you to the colleagues.  Several other comments have been made. Firstly, several colleagues reflected on the role of the European Parliament. Some people even complained about this, because the role would be too limited. I understand that. I understand that, but that is all the more reason for me to say to these Members: support my non-legislative resolution in tomorrow's vote, because that is precisely why we are going to take a number of points and steps to strengthen the role of the EP. So add the deed to the vote tomorrow.  Another point. Some have said that the budget is too low, especially for Cape Verde. I understand that, too. I would like to say again to those members: please table amendments to the budget in order to increase the amount and to be able to pay more for, for example, the training and training of local fishermen and the improvement of their situation. I would also say that complaining is one thing, but then take action and arrange it through the budget.  Finally, the subject of sharks. It is, of course, not for nothing that a series of measures to protect the shark stock have also been announced in this Protocol; The thresholds included in it are quite low, so we know that action is needed very quickly to better protect the sharks. We can do this by strengthening Parliament's role and involvement, but also by supporting my amendment tomorrow. I have proposed a text which is simply a little sharper in order to underline Parliament's involvement in this very matter. So I ask for your support for that.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, first of all I would like to make use of everything i would like to say my satisfaction with the debate and also, again, to greet the Commissioner who accompanied us. It is important that the European Parliament gives space to this activity as important to Europe, as crucial for Europe as fisheries.  As far as this has happened here today, I believe that, and I have expectations, that the fisheries agreements with Guinea Bissau, Cape Verde and Madagascar will also be approved by the European Parliament. This is the way for me. However, I believe that the good management of living resources will have to go much further, as has been said by several colleagues. There is an urgent need to better manage European resources, fishing grounds, and sorry, including that all costs are exploited within sustainability levels. We need to reduce the pressures on habitats, we need to reduce the collateral damage of fisheries, but we must also ensure respect for human rights in the communities of the countries with which we have trade agreements, promoting them, and for the rights of workers working on our vessels. None of this should be an issue as the European legal framework already imposes it under the new Common Fisheries Policy and other European policies. Unfortunately, in the European Union there are still short-term political commitments and poor transparency of data, which undermines the sustainable benefit and security of future generations. Fishing within sustainable limits is an above all economic common sense issue. Support for the sustainable development of third countries with whom we have agreements is also good economic sense, common social sense, common sense in cooperation. Thus, I warn of the need to respect the legal basis, follow the scientific recommendations that serve as the basis for any good decision and listen to all interested parties. Only in this way can we also, at the level of marine living resources, make a better Europe.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Wednesday 9 September 2015.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the report by Wim van de Camp, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport (2015/2005(INI)) (A8-0246/2015).

name: Wim van de Camp
text: Rapporteur. First of all, I would like to thank my fellow shadow rapporteurs and all the people involved in this midterm review for their cooperation.  We have had an extensive process with 633 amendments and it really has not been easy to come up with one coherent story with the shadow rapporteurs. But we did. I would also like to thank the staff of the various political groups, in particular the EPP Group and Parliament, for their cooperation. The first comments on the White Paper were somewhat reticent. Not many new policies and no sharp choices. But it is a midterm review and therefore intended to also highlight the continuity of policy. I think that worked out well. A European Union that would present a completely new transport policy every four years is not credible. It's a midterm review and it's about implementation and continuity.  The transport sector is very important for Europe. In the Netherlands we always say: without transport, everything stands still. The transport sector has a high earning capacity and is very important for the development of the European economy; there are hundreds, thousands of people working in this transport sector, and we must not forget that. At the same time, the transport sector needs to become more sustainable. 24% of pollution in Europe is caused by the transport sector, 29% by the energy sector. Well, then you'll understand what our position is. Sustainability is not only a threat, but also an opportunity for innovation and innovation in the transport sector, which we will have to use over the next 10 to 20 years.  Then there are a few parts of the midterm review report. Unfortunately, we have seen that the modal shift, the shift from road and air to railways and inland waterways, has so far failed. That in itself is a nasty observation, because we want more clean transport in inland waterways and on the train. In the coming years, the European Union's investments in the coming years will therefore have to give priority to railways and inland waterways, whether or not in combination with maritime transport. That is a conclusion that we all share. Then there are the intelligent transport systems. We want more innovation and we also want an electronic bill of lading by 2020; it is a great challenge for us to achieve this. There are a number of proposals, for example for doubling urban transport, which have caused a great deal of controversy, but my colleagues will talk about this.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me first thank your rapporteur, Mr van de Camp, the shadow rapporteurs and indeed the European Parliament as a whole, for the really valuable cooperation in the implementation of the Transport White Paper. We have worked hard since last November with the Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN) on this report. The fact that there were over 600 amendments shows the high level of engagement by Members of Parliament on this topic and the report is of course very welcome and timely. The Commission is pleased with its general thrust and quality. Please allow me to comment on seven specific points in that report. First: the report emphasises the promotion of co-modality and effective use of all transport modes. We are fully supportive of this objective. This is why our policies aim at improving framework conditions, internalising external costs, completing missing infrastructure links, addressing interoperability issues at all levels, and establishing fair competition for all modes. Second: modern infrastructure. This is the area where the Commission has made substantial progress. The definition of TEN-T corridors and creation of the Connecting Europe Facility have been one of our main achievements in recent years. I am also convinced that transport projects can greatly benefit from EFSI, the European Fund for Strategic Investments. Third: transport sustainability. This is an area where the Commission will remain very active. I am thinking here about decarbonisation but also about actions against other environmental impacts – noise, air quality and similar. It is true that urban mobility is an area where more efforts are needed, but we have to be careful not to push solutions that are not tailored to the local specifications. Fourth: digital solutions. We agree that we need to improve travel information and provide integrated ticketing systems. However, I also share the view of many stakeholders that we cannot merely impose one solution at EU level; we should rather make the information available and let businesses come up with solutions matching customers’ needs. We will be there to develop standards and the necessary regulatory frameworks to allow value—added services to emerge. The report calls for a fifth element, which is placing people at the heart of transport policy. I could not agree more. I am personally convinced that transport should first and foremost serve the needs of society, the users, passengers and consumers of freight. This is something we will keep at the heart of all our initiatives. Sixth: social issues. The current situation is not satisfactory. The Juncker Commission attaches a lot of importance to addressing poor working conditions and skills mismatch, and avoiding social unfairness. Without a strong social agenda we will not be able to strengthen the transport internal market. I concur with the report in this respect. Seventh: more competitive and efficient transport. There are still too many barriers in Europe negatively affecting the functioning of the transport single market. We are working to gradually remove these barriers and to create a full single European transport area with high standards which can then be exported to third countries. This will enable Europe to keep its global leadership in transport.  Finally, the report underlines that one of the main weaknesses of our current policies is poor implementation. I could not agree more, Mr van de Camp. This is an area in which I hope we can cooperate closely, in particular to ensure that EU law is as clear and simple as possible and that sufficient attention is dedicated to enforcement. I look forward now to hearing Members’ detailed comments and views as regards the way forward in the White Paper. Our work is everlasting and I look forward to really cooperating with this House in a constructive and sustainable manner throughout my entire mandate.

name: Markus Pieper
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. The report provides many good indications for greater intermodal linking, for greater sustainability in the transport sector, for the upgrading of transnational transport links. In theory, all this reads very well. But, ladies and gentlemen, does the transport sector really have adequate political attention today? For many, the transport industry is obviously a milking cow in Europe. The European Union is also to regulate ever new ideas for charges, for levies, ever stricter environmental objectives, even urban transport. But this applies not only to regulation, but also to finances. Where would we stand today if oil taxes, car taxes, environmental levies in the nation states had actually been returned to investments in infrastructure and environmental protection and not misused into social systems? Transport is also a stepchild of funding in the European Commission. I am sorry to have to say that. But why did the EU Commission take the money from the extremely important Connecting Europe Facility to finance the guarantees for the EFSI? Transport is obviously also a stepchild in the Presidency of the Council. We have acute problems of border security, we have a dramatic underfunding of transnational infrastructures. And, you know, the next informal council meeting of transport ministers on 8 October is under the heading – with all these problems: 'the bicycle as a means of transport'. Ladies and gentlemen, I think that European transport policy deserves other priorities. These are excellently described in the report by Wim van de Camp. We want more sustainability, we want more competitiveness of our infrastructures and our companies, so that we do not lose in global competition!

name: Kosma Złotowski
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! The creation of a single European transport area is a task that can only be met with a precise action plan setting out the necessary objectives and stages to be achieved. The 2011 Transport White Paper aims to act as such a plan. Although only four years have passed since the adoption of this strategy, it is already clear that the achievement of the objectives will be delayed. This is particularly significant in the area of achieving overly ambitious and often detached from the economic realities of the assumptions on the move away from fossil fuels in transport. In order to avoid similar failures in other areas, we must take the opportunity to review the White Paper and clearly identify those problems that require increased efforts in such a way that European integration in the transport sector takes shape. Firstly, it is important to emphasise the particular importance of the projects that make up the trans-European transport network for the construction of a coherent Union transport network. The TEN-T project is crucial for deepening European integration in the field of transport, including increasing the transport accessibility of peripheral areas of the European Union. The construction of the TEN-T network should be a top priority of our transport policy in the coming years. Secondly, the White Paper as it stands does not sufficiently address public transport and urban mobility, as well as the involvement of modern forms of travel based on the principles of the sharing economy. I believe that such an important and strategic document, such as the White Paper, must not overlook such important topics. Thirdly and finally, the future of transport in the Union is also the future of workers and employers in this sector. It is worrying that some Member States are trying to protect their own businesses at the expense of the fundamental economic freedoms of the Union by camouflage such practices with social issues. This should not be the case, and I am pleased that the van de Camp report emphasises the importance of a balance between the free market and the protection of workers' rights. I believe that the European Commission will listen to this voice and take into account these and many other observations in this report when updating the objectives of the White Paper and their implementation in the years to come.

name: Claudia Tapardel
text: on behalf of the S&D group – Mr President, urbanisation, globalisation and demographic change in our society leads us to rethink the way the transport system works and to look at the measures proposed four years ago in the White Paper on transport. We have negotiated an ambitious agenda that will generate structural change in this system and create a genuine single European transport area. This space will have to accommodate an increasing demand for mobility and meet the needs of passengers, goods and services in the 21st century. For this reason, we brought back and put passengers at the centre of the discussion. I believe that we need to increase the quality of work in all transport sectors by setting minimum standards in the first place. In the labour market, we must use the opportunity to apply the principle of equal opportunities and make this area much more attractive to women. A transport system of the future cannot be anything other than barriers of any kind and with the use of all modes of transport in a sustainable way. That means we need both physical and digital infrastructures. All our efforts must be focused on the interconnection of border areas and peripheral regions with other regions of the Union, so that passengers, goods and services move freely and efficiently. Infrastructure investments in these areas are considered investments with a significant impact on territorial cohesion and the elimination of infrastructure development disparities between Eastern and Western Europe.  The increased urbanisation brings into question the need to improve and increase the capacity of public transport. Urban centres are at the same time the spaces where we face the negative effects of transport on a daily basis, either in the form of carbon emissions or air quality or traffic congestion. Integrated mobility services and real-time information will bring us closer to the objective of transitioning to sustainable modes of transport. Transport is a driving force of the European Union, essential for the development of related industries, such as tourism, on which the existence of connections between the infrastructure network, the efficiency of mobility, and the quality of passenger services depend.

name: Gesine Meissner
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her In fact, transport is improbably underestimated – and I see it that way – even though everyday life does not work at all without transport. Transport is the backbone of the internal market. If we think about ordering something on the Internet, we want 24-hour delivery – without transport it is not possible at all! We go shopping, want fresh goods every day, even this is not possible without transport! Waste collection is not possible without mobility, and in general mobility is one of the fundamental rights for the people of Europe, and for that too we need all means of transport. And that's why we had this metro plan as a big throw in the last period. A metro plan that connects all the cities and major centres of Europe. This TEN-T story that we have here looks great, that is precisely the European idea that we need, that people can come together, trade, if possible without borders and without traffic jams and without any other obstacles.  A very noble goal that needs money. That is why we have put more money into the budget – all quite right. And in order to have this mobility, we need all means of transport for people and for the transport of goods. We need both the railways and the road by lorry, we need the railways, we need the ships. We also need bicycles in part. Everything is necessary, and that should then meet certain criteria. It should be as clean as possible, it should be as safe as possible, it should be as accessible as possible for all people, no matter where they live and whether they have disabilities or not, and it should be as fair as possible. As fair as possible in terms of competitive conditions, but also, for example, in terms of good conditions for the profession and also in relation to passenger rights. So it's a whole bunch of what we're looking at. We now have this midterm review.  There is still a great deal to improve, and in terms of improvement we must always see that we look at all areas in a balanced way, both for users and for providers, and that we are doing this at European level. I cannot deny that we are doing the same in such a way that we can make progress, for example in the field of aviation, when Gibraltar is indeed a bone of contention. We really should find a peaceful solution between England and Spain there. For the people of Europe.

name: Merja Kyllönen
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, a big heart for mr van de Camp for his professional and constructive approach to work. This is an important document for the TRAN Committee and the outcome can be seen as a common vision of the committee's transport policy, which I hope the Commission will take firmly into account. I am still wondering whether the customer's voice is sufficiently displayed in our conference halls and tables, which decide on a transport policy that affects the mobility of all Europeans. Sometimes it seems that transport policy is only intended to safeguard the very traditional position of operators in the sector, rather than to take new measures to ensure transport services that work, are easier and even cheaper for users. It seems funny that we sometimes completely forget that the customer is number one, we even forget to invite the industrial customer of the business community to hear about the real needs of transport. We must remember that in transport infrastructure is only a small part and, in fact, much more is happening on top of that infrastructure. We need smart solutions and resource efficiency throughout the transport system. It is sad that, even in the 2010s, it will be easier for us to build a road and tunnel through huge walls than to jointly create a regulatory environment that enables interoperable user-friendly services. The most effective measures to improve the efficiency of the transport system do not require an excavator everywhere, but rather a shredded of paper. Little less conversation, little more action, please!

name: Bas Eickhout
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur and my colleague Wim van de Camp for their good cooperation. We had said beforehand that we do not want a document that is grey and that is actually a compromise, but therefore does not say anything. We want a compromise, which at the same time makes some clear points. And I think we have succeeded together and we should certainly thank Mr Van de Camp for that.  It has not become a green text on all points, but it cannot, as long as we do not have the majority. However, I do think that there are a number of points in it which are extremely important and it is also good to hear from the Commission and the Commissioner that the report is being embraced. However, there are some very clear points that need to be improved. Because if we look at the current state of transport - as Mr Van De Camp said - we are actually quite behind with that modal shift, the transition to the use of inland waterways and rail. That's not going well. And if you're going to look at reducing environmental pollution from the transport sector. That's not going well either. It is still unclear how Europe will work towards it in the longer term after 2020. There are still challenges here where we expect more from the Commission.  Also with regard to social policy, it is very important that this has been added. We all know that opening up that service market also has a social side. There is also more attention to this and the Commission is clearly invited to come forward with proposals. They have already been announced, but they are still lacking in concreteity. I think it is important that this report is clearly seen as a call to the Commission not only to embrace developments so far. It is also important to come up with new proposals so that we can say at the end of the White Paper: yes, the transport sector is really on the right track.

name: Peter Lundgren
text: On the other: The EFDD Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr A year ago, I took up this task in Parliament. Since then, I have been constantly talking about the cabotage rules and how the transport industry is experiencing very serious problems because of this particular legislation, which allows for widespread cheating on our roads. We are now proposing comprehensive measures on the part of Parliament. Now the Commission is taking up an ex post evaluation, which is very gratifying for all my fellow drivers back home in my country, Sweden, who have organised themselves into a protest movement called Here Sweden. At last, the Commission is taking the problem seriously and is prepared to change the legislation. The proposed proposal of a social law is also gratifying in order to put social dumping in order, false self-employment and ensure fair competition. We are now also calling on the Commission to take action against the illegal practices that lead to unfair competition and promote social dumping. I would like to say to my colleagues in the cars on our roads: finally something is happening to ensure that we have a level playing field on our roads.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to express here my profound disagreement on the recommendations of this report.  Under the pretext of combating global warming and road insecurity, this document is in fact aimed at strengthening, once again, the control of the European bureaucracy to the detriment of the Member States.  I deplore first of all the increase in public funds demanded in this white paper, an increase which, as always, will have to be borne by the taxpayers of the Member States and therefore, of course, by the French. I am then firmly opposed to the opening up of national rail markets imposed by the European Union to competition. Finally, it is difficult for the European Parliament to allow itself to dictate to states ever more repressive road safety standards that they will have to apply in the years to come.  For all these reasons, as you have understood, I will vote against this report.

name: Luis de Grandes Pascual (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, transport policy is a fundamental element of the internal market, the territorial cohesion of the Union and our industrial policy. Better meshing of the infrastructure network, especially cross-border infrastructure networks, greater efficiency of each mode of transport through free competition and adequate promotion of comdality is needed to reduce transport times. There are very positive elements contained in the report that we will vote on tomorrow, such as the internalisation of external costs, avoiding double taxation; the promotion of alternative fuels; the need to take action in relation to shared transport platforms; the desirability that carriers can enjoy the weekly rest at their source; the specific nature of the outermost regions, and the important role of regional airports. Mr Wim van de Camp, the rapporteur has done a magnificent job and tomorrow will be reflected in our vote, which will certainly be positive. Just a discrepancy, which is inevitable. I am Spanish and I think the mention of Gibraltar airport is unnecessary and inadequate and has never blocked air transport issues. There has always been a formula for resolving discrepancies between two partner countries such as the UK and Spain and it is the famous London Declaration. The application of the rule is suspended, as long as the contradictory parties overcome their problems through dialogue. That's the way. The UNITED Kingdom and Spain have been talking about and speaking obviously about their long-controversial issues. This is the only way, not for the Council to take decisions which are neither incumbent on it nor responsible for it in accordance with the Treaties.

name: Ismail Ertug (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. First of all, I would like to thank the protagonists, firstly the rapporteur, Mr Wim van de Camp, and our shadow rapporteur, Claudia Tapardel, for their good work. This has indeed been a very constructive and sometimes emotional debate for weeks, and we can conclude it well today. I would like to mention once again – almost four years after the White Paper that we have adopted here – that we are now on the right track with regard to the objectives that we set ourselves at the time, which were and are admittedly ambitious, but we have not yet achieved them. For example, as far as the shift from road to rail is concerned, we have not achieved this overarching objective of shifting transports over 300 kilometres to rail. We are moving here at a relatively low level. For example, between 2008 and 2011, we had an average share of goods transported by road of 76.1%, and in the period 2011-2013 it was 74.9%. This shows that, although the direction is right, it is still under-represented. We must continue to make an effort in this respect. What we need to do in the social field – I would also ask the Commission to reach out to the European Parliament and demand this in the next legislation. As far as social and safety regulations are concerned, we have repeatedly put our finger in the wound and tried to work to improve this – whether that is the various transport sectors, such as bogus self-employment or air transport pay to fly, or a systematic undermining of driving and rest periods. We must continue to work on these areas. Commissioner, thank you for your strict and correct stance on the German car toll. We need a European solution here, and we will achieve this together.

name: Jacqueline Foster (ECR).
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr van de Camp, for all of his hard work. Certainly, from our point of view –  the Conservative point of view – it is a shame that much of your original text was changed. You know that we supported a lot of it. Regrettably, it now contains several areas which my UK delegation will find difficult to support.  Firstly, the excessive concentration on further social legislation in the fields of aviation and road haulage: this would, in our view, close down the markets and is blatantly protectionist. Secondly, the unnecessary creation of a new European road safety transport agency: we do not believe that would add value. Next, the push to move forward with the Ports Directive which, as it stands, would in our view be damaging to the interests of a very successful British ports industry. Finally, I come to the reference to Gibraltar. I see that the good colleague of mine who originally put down the amendments two years ago has left. This is about a British sovereign territory which is a full member of the single market. I must say that, while Spain continues to challenge this sovereign state, there will be no movement on either the implementation – regrettably – of Single Sky or the Passenger Rights Regulation that Mr Bach has worked on. For that reason, and solely for that reason, Mr van de Camp, we cannot support the report tomorrow, but we appreciate the work you have done.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, road transport is at a time of transition waiting for the Commission's strategy.  The demands of interoperability, environmental efficiency and the need to jointly vertebrate production and distribution, among other things, require a model that is too dependent on large infrastructures and large transport companies. In this transition, it is important to place the rights and demands of workers, both dependent and autonomous, at the centre of the debate. Rest times, wages, that extra loading and unloading work are not imposed must be ensured and, above all, social dumping must be fought.  Abuse of cabotage rules and posted workers is a matter that requires stronger inspections and clear responsibility from the employer or subcontractor. It is unacceptable that the sector be liberalized for the sole purpose of eliminating the protection of national conventions and regulations. Carriers are not mere service providers; therefore, they cannot be left out of labour standards.

name: Daniela Aiuto (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that excellent work has been done on the White Paper on transport, but we will not support it as a 5-Star delegation, because we do not share the continuing support that is being given to projects such as the Turin-Lyons, despite the fact that it has been shown to be useless and harmful.  However, there are many positive elements to which we have also contributed with our amendments, including the desire to invest in increasingly energy and environmentally sustainable solutions, favouring rail rather than road transport. It is good to want to promote electric and cycling vehicles, car sharing, the optimisation of public spending, the creation of new urban mobility plans to encourage public transport, not least, commitment to safety and the fight against social dumping.  Nevertheless, I can only express my opposition to the text adopted, once again, you want to give greater powers to the European Commission to finance as a matter of priority useless works that are of interest only to the European oligarchy and to the strong powers. Keep making bad choices, so as not to admit your mistakes as you do for the euro, you have realised that it is not working, but you continue to insist on absurd policies to protect your eurozone. Do like alcoholics, who even though they know they're going to die, continue to drink cognac even at breakfast.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. Transport is the cornerstone of any economy and the internal market cannot function properly without modern transport infrastructure and networks. A full transformation of the transport sector to be energy efficient, safe, competitive, efficient and interoperable is very necessary today, especially as the latest statistics show that demand for transport services will double in the coming years. I would very much like to congratulate Mr van de Camp on his excellent report, which contains a number of important transport issues. Of course, it is not a panacea for all the ills in the transport sector, but I nevertheless believe that its recommendations provide a very good basis for the preparation of specific legislation. However, I would like to draw attention to the term 'social dumping' which has been used very often recently in committee meetings and in Parliament. We will all agree that those who provide transport services should be guaranteed adequate working conditions, including adequate remuneration, and that action should therefore be encouraged to ensure fair competition in transport. However, this time limit cannot justify for some politicians measures aimed at administratively restricting access to transport for carriers from other Member States in a given country.  On the other hand, I believe that, in view of the numerous irregularities reported, we should combat all fraud and pay attention to the introduction of better monitoring of compliance with the existing rules on the implementation of transport services in the Member States.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, let me first of all thank the rapporteur and all the shadow rapporteurs for the excellent work done. As shadow rapporteur for the original report on the 2011 White Paper on Transport, I agree with the rapporteur's position that, in order to create a single transport area that uses efficient and sustainable resources, it is first and foremost necessary to connect transport networks in all regions of the European Union and to integrate the different modes of transport. In building trans-European transport networks, account must be taken of the ever-prevailing infrastructure differences between different regions, old and new Member States, and a fundamental improvement in cross-border connections. I am very glad that the report deals with road safety issues, where it proposes the adoption of the objective of reducing the number of seriously injured road users. It also mentions the themes of improving the accessibility and accessibility of public transport, strengthening passenger rights and addressing the social conditions of transport workers. For these reasons, I will support the report and thank everyone involved once again.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, in this report the rapporteur proposes the introduction of cable cars as an inexpensive form of urban transport. The Thames Cable Car in the UK cost GBP 60 million to build, with an operational cost of GBP 6 million in the first year. With passenger numbers dropping year by year this is certainly not cost-effective.  This report also proposes a review of Directive (EU) 2015/719 on weights and dimensions. I am deeply concerned by this review, especially with respect to Recital 8 of the Directive – which provides for exemptions allowing Member States to impose restrictions for reasons related to road safety or infrastructure characteristics – which could be removed.  Yet again, this report champions the Commission’s right to interfere in the sovereignty of Member States by proposing a national road-charging scheme for passenger cars and light commercial vehicles. This is a disgrace. It also proposes that the Commission should have more powers to force through the speedy completion of the TEN-T project or, as we call it, HS2. This report is full of contradictions and is unfounded, so I urge you to vote against it.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the feeling we have when we look at the White Paper and Mr van de Camp's report is that very difficult mediation work has been done. I think, Commissioner, you can acknowledge this, and from your words we have been able to express our appreciation for a subtle work that often sees the demands of delegations with very different demands contrasted. It is a pity that sometimes, within this Parliament, what I do not think should happen at all happens, namely that, in the face of a place like this where tensions can be resolved eminently, there is a risk of bringing back some tension in one's own countries, and that is regrettable.  However, the report, in my view, has everything to support, it touches on the points that interest us, in my case a particular attention to rail transport, to its progressive liberalisation, and it works on all those elements that allow us to understand how to invest in transport, not constantly resorting to whims that Europe does not deserve, such as those of excessive attention to issues on which we are already very performing – see the ability to produce investments that respect the environmental protection – well, the ability of this report to promote that path towards investment that is useful for the mobility of goods and the mobility of people bodes well for our continent to have the development it deserves, including through transport policy.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: – Pilots who are sick and still fly, because otherwise they will not get paid. Truck drivers who have to drive day and night because they are afraid of losing their jobs. Companies that really flout all the rules, because they know that they are not being monitored. It can't be anymore, it's not allowed anymore. Europe must put an end to this.  The proposals in this report are good and I would almost say 'Thank God' the Christian Democrats are now also convinced that something must be done. So my compliments go in the direction of my colleague Wim van de Camp. Now the Juncker Commission must act. The Commissioner is expressing her political will today. I think it is now time to show ambition with concrete proposals to put an end to the social abuses in the transport sector.

name: Georges Bach (PPE).
text: Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her work and for Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to I would like to thank our coordinator, Wim van de Camp. It has managed to propose short-term, medium-term and long-term measures. I would like to confine myself to three points, due to my short speaking time. Firstly, road transport. We have known the problems and challenges for quite some time, and in order to make the areas of security, social affairs, the environment and competition a success, we do not need new laws, but – together with the Member States – a better and, above all, a harmonious, joint implementation of the laws and increased controls. I believe that an agency, a single responsible body, would also be a major improvement. As far as the railways are concerned, we must, with all the forces at our disposal, bring the fourth railway package to a successful end, so that, after 20 years of restructuring, the railways in Europe can finally fulfil their important role. And in terms of aviation, this sector is increasingly at risk of losing ground in international competition. It is important to take account of both competition security and the social aspects in order to come up with proposals for solutions as quickly as possible. Commissioner, after several years of deadlock, due to your predecessor, you are called upon to ensure that transport finally regains the status that is extremely important for the economy and jobs and which the citizens of Europe also expect.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: –  Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for being here tonight, and I would like to thank Mr van de Camp for his efforts in the balancing act that he has performed over recent months to try to get to some form of a compromise position. This will hopefully lead to a successful outcome tomorrow. The report reflects various areas of transport and emphasises its particular importance in job creation and connecting the outermost regions. Most importantly, consumers of those transport services must be at the centre of all our discussions, namely the travelling passengers and the businesses that depend on our transport infrastructure. We need to keep that to the fore in all our discussions. On the whole area of aviation, I look forward to the Commission’s package at the end of this year. It is extremely important that we recognise that our carriers are now competing on a global scale, and that needs to be addressed. The world is getting smaller, our businesses and our passengers want to travel to areas outside Europe: to Asia, the US, Australia. Our carriers need to be able to compete and we need to open dialogue, particularly with the Gulf States, that is very important. We need to start that conversation and get to some sort of aviation agreement in that area. I would like to stress that what is holding back our airlines is that they are uncompetitive on those routes. We need to address the situation.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we are still far from achieving a single European transport area, but we have indeed begun to build that path. I therefore congratulate the work of the fellow rapporteur, also the shadow rapporteurs. I welcome the references made to maritime transport and the need to strengthen the capacity of Union ports.  However, we must, without delay, put forward concrete measures to develop the real potential of motorways of the sea as an integral part of the trans-European transport network. I regret that there is a reference to the extension of THE DSCs to the entire European maritime area, without a prior opinion from the relevant international body. This measure will have serious consequences for island regions and I could not fail to make a reference here. I therefore ask the European Commission to present a strategy with clear actions for the connectivity of the islands with Europe, which should pay particular attention to the particularities of the island and outermost regions in the implementation of measures such as the global MRV system for greenhouse gas emissions.

name: Lucy Anderson (S&D).
text: – Mr President, this is a positive and forward-looking report with many key recommendations. There are a few separate votes on issues including the need for ports regulation and progressing mega-trucks as a policy aim, and also on the 4th Railway Package and the benefits of competitive tendering. I am afraid the British Labour MEPs will be voting against those points. However, in total and on balance, we very much support the report, and I welcome in particular the reinforcement of EU action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from transport by at least 60% by 2050. This is a vital statement for us to make in the run-up to the Paris summit on tackling climate change. I also especially want to highlight the focus on investment in this report. In my city of London, transport investment is not keeping up with the demands of the economy and the needs of a growing population. Across Europe, the situation is the same, and we must address this urgently. It is a big gap and we must address it consistently in the years ahead, recognising that, while the private sector has a role to play, we need substantial public funds for investment in transport.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, transport is crucial for Europe's economic development. They must be upgraded in the light of the passenger and the protection of the environment. But transport accounts for 25% of greenhouse gas emissions. It is the second largest greenhouse gas emitter sector after the energy sector. For this reason, the European Union must promote alternative transport, promote public transport, and in particular rail. In the field of road transport, infrastructure must be strengthened in order to reduce road accidents and controls must be strengthened. At the same time, the European Union must strengthen maritime transport in order for the inhabitants of island regions, especially in the Aegean, to have continuous access to the hinterland. Thanks.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, thank you to the rapporteur for his efforts.  Europe needs an integrated interoperabilible mobility system that improves the environmental and economic sustainability of transport. Saturation costs us today 1% of European GDP, and the closure of many states or the defence of their particular interests are the cause of non-compliance with many European rules which, if implemented, would radically improve the competitiveness of our economy, that of all.  Investment commitments must be fulfilled in accordance with priorities agreed and approved by all because they add value to the whole system. You have to think of all users, including those with reduced mobility issues, when talking about passenger rights. We are going to maintain the global leadership of European industry in transport technology, the future of our economy and the quality of a service that will improve our lives and our choices in the face of climate change.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, rapporteur, thank you for your report. As envi coordinator, I very much appreciated that improving energy efficiency should be one of the main priorities of European transport policy. There is an urgent need to make more efficient use of resources throughout the transport system in order to ensure a more efficient use of existing capacity. Like the rapporteur, I then lack the support and development of public transport among the ten objectives of the White Paper, which also promises to reduce the environmental emission burden. While the infrastructure to facilitate safe house-to-house mobility for public transport users, including the elderly and cyclists, would require ensuring appropriate investment, I believe that the benefits of such investments are considerable and have a good impact on employment in the Member States. I therefore support the priority approval of EU-funded infrastructure projects completing the rail network, which is part of the TEN-T core network, and projects approved under the CEF, and I call for the most effective involvement of central European countries in this network.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht Koch (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. The transport sector has a direct impact on our everyday lives, on the economy, the environment, climate, health, social aspects, tourism and much more, and its importance is so often underestimated. The measures we are taking today have a direct impact on the quality of life of our citizens of tomorrow. It is therefore essential to take stock and to define the way forward with a view to sustainable mobility and a single European transport area. Wim, thank you for your work! In some places, the report could go a little further. I am thinking here of the patchwork of toll systems. Or why do we not call for mandatory standard installation of driver assistance systems? I am particularly pleased that road safety is still seen as a priority of European transport policy. However, for all our successes, we still need concrete objectives. This includes a strategy to reduce the number of serious road injuries, as well as an EU-wide harmonised limit for blood alcohol concentrations of novice drivers and professional drivers.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would also like to thank the rapporteur, who for once got off his motorbike to offer us a comprehensive convention of good ideas for the future of transport. Some concerns: first of all, road safety. This year we have lost the battle, as the victims have increased. The crisis has aged the fleet of vehicles and ruined the infrastructure, so let us look forward, Commissioner, for the proposals you have to make to us. And I recall that both CEF and FEIE instruments are useful for infrastructure maintenance. The other security, that of passengers and workers in front of terrorists. We have already been in Madrid, unfortunately, in the vicinity and in the london stations, in Paris, hence we wish you success for the next working group with the Council and we support you in the proposals you have to make in this regard to deal with it. Transport workers, their preparation, their working conditions, even imperatively their health are essential. We wonder what has happened to make young Europeans unemployed as long as our railways, planes, boats and trucks can't find a generational spare. We look forward to your proposals, Commissioner, to make the transport professions an attractive sector for so young people unemployed. Sustainability, essentially in urban mobility, is seen by me. That is where we support the use of bicycles and also their pacification. We also point to aspects such as the tram. Finally, we need a budget, and for those who have not been able to see in the EIB a fundamental complement to the EFC, I would ask you, Commissioner, to show us that both instruments are essential to get all our projects up and running.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank honourable Members for their very valuable and very specific contributions and comments. We have taken note of all of them. Both your remarks here tonight and the report will be taken into account in the finalisation of the White Paper implementation report, which we will complete by the end of this year. But let me stress how important it is to hear that we all recognise how important transport is for growth, jobs, and for a global lead. So let me say a few additional words on the process itself. The public consultation work with stakeholders has now been completed. Since many of the implementing measures of the 2011 White Paper have only been coming on stream relatively recently, we are not in the process of doing a full evaluation but rather of taking stock of what has already been implemented, what has become obsolete and what is left to do. The political and economic landscape has, of course, evolved since 2011, but the ongoing exercise shows that the main provisions of the White Paper remain relevant and are worth implementing. I understand that Parliament is in agreement with this approach. Finally, I would like to thank once again Mr van de Camp and Parliament for having decided to take this initiative. As mentioned in my introduction, we certainly agree on the broad lines going forward. I hear a lot of calls for action. I like that. Let us now work together on the initiatives needed to make real progress.

name: Wim van de Camp
text: Rapporteur. I would like to thank the Commissioner and her staff, but certainly my colleagues, for the comments tonight. Also for the critical sounds. Mrs Foster has unfortunately already left, but I fully understand what she said this evening and we will try to take that into account in the further implementation.  The challenge will be to implement this White Paper, this midterm review. And I see it as my job to ensure that everything that we have written down and hopefully tomorrow is accepted is also carried out. As the Commissioner has already said, we must move towards a new balance of fewer rules, more sustainability, more earning capacity, but we must not forget the social aspect either. This will be a major task for the Committee on Transport over the next four years. And I repeat: the other committees cannot work without transport!

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the discussion on this item on the agenda. The vote will take place on Wednesday 9 September 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. – I welcome my colleague van de Camp's own-initiative report on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on transport. I believe that an interim reassessment of the White Paper is necessary, because the long-term goals that we set in 2011 and in many cases extend up to 2050 do not always meet the challenges of today. The aim of the interim revaluation is not to reduce the ambitious targets that we set in 2011, but to strengthen the ambition to achieve them. I agree with the reporter that it is very important not only to talk about transport as such, but also about sustainable mobility, within which we can reduce Europe's dependence on oil, grow the economy, protect our environment, create new jobs, reduce traffic jams in our cities. This will create a more livable and fun environment around us. However, this requires better use of rail and waterborne transport, while at the same time the transport of freight traffic by lorries is not negligible. I am pleased that a point in the report highlights the need to pay particular attention to supporting projects linking the trans-European transport network with infrastructure networks in neighbouring and candidate countries. It is important that we take into account future enlargement processes already. That is why I support this report.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission by Antonio Tajani, Andreas Schwab, Evelyne Gebhardt, Ms Charanzova and Reinhard Bütikofer, on behalf of the Group of the European People's Party and the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament, on further steps on new lines of action to improve the exercise of the liberal professions (O-000080/2015 - 2015/2771(RSP) B8-0569/2015).

name: Antonio Tajani
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, 4 million freelancers create 11 million jobs in Europe, with a turnover - the President intervenes - I said that 4 million freelancers in Europe create 11 million jobs, with a turnover of over EUR 500 billion. We must support this category of workers, we must solve the problems that the liberal professions encounter in accessing finance, credit, eliminating unnecessary administrative burdens and costs. We must ensure that the liberal professions can take advantage of the same opportunities as small and medium-sized enterprises, such as access to direct calls from the European Union and indirect calls from the regions. The role of the professional funds must also be assessed in order to guarantee funding to members.  A high-level group that I had created in my role as European Commissioner for Industry, drew up a series of recommendations in 2014 to support the development of the liberal professions in Europe, not only through better access to credit, but also through more training, with more information and with a focus on internationalisation. The time has now come to implement these recommendations, and the aim of the oral question I have drawn up with colleagues from various political groups is precisely to ask the new European Commission how it intends to follow up its commitments.  We expect a strong commitment from Commissioner Bieńkowska. Dear Commissioner, I can assure you that you will be able to count on the support of a large majority of this Parliament for legislative proposals, political initiatives, programmes and funding for a category that is fundamental to economic recovery and employment in Europe, a category that needs to be heard by the European institutions close to it. That is why we expect you to take a strong political initiative to ensure the development of the liberal professions, which need more freedom and less democracy, less bureaucracy, excuses.

name: Evelyne Gebhardt
text: Author. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. The liberal professions are extremely important professions and a backbone for European Union society. These professions also have a very high level of qualifications, usually in the areas of health, justice and other important security issues. That is why it is particularly important to have a high level of qualification in this area, and it is important to ensure that there are also clear rules that also give them certainty about the quality of their professions. Like my colleague Mr Tajani, I agree that we do not need excessive bureaucracy, but we need, as it were, assurance that a high quality of services in these areas can be guaranteed. That is exactly what we need.  As part of the implementation of the Professional Qualifications Directive, you are also currently undergoing an evaluation process. I know that this process is currently being examined and looked at very closely in these areas. The question you are asking yourself, and which I would also like to have answered by you, is: what is the impetus in this area, what is the point of this evaluation process from your point of view, and what are the consequences that you would like to draw out from this? Because these are things that are very preoccupying us. As I said, we want to ensure that these services are provided at the highest possible level and that consumers, patients, many people who benefit from these services can also be sure that the appropriate quality is also guaranteed.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you very much for the opportunity to stress the importance and role of the liberal professions in Europe because, as your question crucially underlines, liberal professions are first and foremost recognised for their entrepreneurial spirit. Lawyers, architects, engineers create their businesses as independent enterprises. They invest in their own assets and professional know—how, they bear the business risks and reach out for economic success. They are, of course, entrepreneurs creating jobs and providing high-quality products and services.  For this very reason, the Commission decided to make a very special commitment to the promotion of liberal professions in its Entrepreneurship 2020 Action Plan. In this context, a working group ‘Bolstering the Business of the Liberal Professions’ was set up to assess their specific needs as entrepreneurs and businesspeople, such as acquiring know—how and skills, access to markets or access to finance. This is almost the same as for the others, but we are very much focusing on those professions. This autonomous working group submitted a series of recommendations which are included in a report that will be finalised around the end of the year and which is built around five thematic blocks.  The first block is entrepreneurship, education and training, because liberal professionals need to acquire managerial and entrepreneurial skills. I would like in this place to highlight that liberal professionals can already benefit from the exchange programme Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs. The second block highlights the importance of facilitating access to finance, and from this perspective it also has to be stressed that they are offered money from programmes like COSME and Horizon 2020, and the use of the advisory services of the Enterprise Europe Network. The third block analyses access to markets. The fourth block invites representatives of the liberal professions to contribute to the reduction of their regulatory burden, which Members mentioned a few times, by identifying bottlenecks and best practices across the EU.  Finally, the working group expressed its wish to strengthen the representation and participation of the liberal professions at European level. Therefore, I decided that the liberal professions will be represented and invited to participate at in the 2015 SME Assembly which will take place in Luxembourg in November this year. This should enable liberal professions to be more directly informed about all the policies put in place. As far as the regulated professions are concerned, it should be said that the Commission is currently carrying out a transparency and mutual evaluation exercise in each Member State as a follow-up to the Professional Qualifications Directive. This is also, it has to be stressed, an exercise in very good cooperation with national authorities, and has already made it possible to identify more than 5 000 regulated professions in all sectors of activities and in all Member States.  This is particularly helpful since we know that a large majority of the liberal professions are regulated ones. The regulation of professions limits access to professions and may reduce employment opportunities. In this context, I want also to mentioned that the Commission will adopt – it is planning, but will adopt in a month, on 21 October – the Internal Market Strategy, and the key element of the strategy will be to address remaining barriers to services, and to further advance the integration of the single market in services, thus facilitating the economic activities of liberal professions.  I would be very pleased to discuss this further with Members once the Internal Market Strategy is adopted, because it is a very comprehensive document with some new points added by us.

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which Commissioner Bie-kowska, I would like to thank commissioner for her work Thank you very much for your comments on how you envisage the role of the liberal professions in the context of the European internal market. Mr Tajani has made it very clear and clear how important we, as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, attach to the liberal professions in all their variations, and that is why I am also concerned that certain rules of a consumer protection nature are now being addressed in individual infringement proceedings against different Member States. However, I agree with you that we must, of course, increase mobility in the European internal market and, in this respect, these infringement procedures also provide clarity as to whether or not these measures are admissible, and so I await with interest the decision of the European Court of Justice in these proceedings. However, Commissioner, our main interest is, of course, in ensuring that the liberal professions, by their very nature and in view of their self-government, can retain their position in a European internal market. And here you, as the Commissioner responsible for the classic part of the internal market – unlike the Digital Single Market – are, of course, the Commissioner who must also speak out in defence of the liberal professions. This is all the more true because, at various points, they are also carefully reviewing the rules that these liberal professions are subject to, and i therefore hope that in the internal market strategy that they will be presenting in a few months' time, we will also read some positives on the subject of the liberal professions.

name: Nicola Danti
