text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, in a Union that must increasingly focus on knowledge as the engine of its development, the world of professions is an important factor for growth, even if it still receives too little attention from the Community institutions. The need for greater integration of the professional world, on the basis of clear and shared rules, is also confirmed by data on internal trade in services and the lack of mobility of European professionals.  The study promoted by the Commission clearly sets out many of the guidelines on which work needs to be done. Among these, I believe that it is a priority to bet on education and training to face and overcome the challenge of international competition. It will also be important to reduce the regulatory burden and to update and complete a legal framework that must be effective and clear, in order to provide certainty and opportunities.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, from doctors to lawyers to architects, liberal professions are a great part of our lives. We need to treat them all with respect, and equally. This is why Article 59 of the revised directive is so important. By the start of next year, Member States will have to justify why some professions have national requirements that any normal person would say are simply not needed or are designed to be discriminatory against those not born or educated in that Member State. The Commission must be extremely strict when deciding what is an acceptable reason and call out those Member States that are not honouring the spirit and principles of the law. Mr President, as long as Czech engineers or accountants are faced with a bureaucratic wall when they simply want to move to Germany, there is more to be done. Not only are these professionals losing out, so too are all Germans and all EU citizens who have missed a chance for better service and more choice in their daily lives. Over—regulation of these professions is, in essence, denying these workers access to the fundamental freedoms of movement and establishment.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE).
text: Mr President, it is in my capacity, under the previous Parliament, as rapporteur on behalf of the EPP Group on the revision of the Directive on the Recognition of Professional Qualifications that I am pleased to address you this evening. In the Committee on Internal Markets, we have worked hard to try to make the Directive on the Recognition of Professional Qualifications more effective and facilitating. I will therefore focus on an issue that is particularly important to me, that of the mobility of professionals across the European Union. We know that this is one of the keys to promoting jobs, growth and trade development in general.  One of the major innovations of the revised Directive on the Recognition of Professional Qualifications was the European Professional Card, a concrete and practical instrument which was to streamline, facilitate and improve procedures for recognising professional qualifications for a range of professionals and for a number of regulated professions. Where exactly are we today, Commissioner, on the implementation of this European professional card for a number of professions that have made their interest known? A number of professions are believed to have shown interest and a consultation has been launched by the European Commission for the following professions: nurses, doctors, pharmacists, physiotherapists, engineers, mountain guides and real estate agents. Where exactly are we? What is the follow-up to this considerable creative work that had been done under the previous Parliament?

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. As early as 2003, we jointly adopted a resolution on the competition rules, the market rules for the liberal professions. At that time, too, for the simple reason that the liberal professions are the anchors of stability in our economy. However, the profession will face new challenges, especially in times of digitalisation and globalisation. But for us it is clear: free professions usually have academic training and a high level of quality of qualification. They are independent, self-responsible, unbiased and neutral, and they cannot be shaved over a groin. They provide a comprehensive service and should not be confused with the commercial professions. They provide comprehensive services for all citizens in all regions at performance-based prices. Therefore, when we talk about regulation, we have to say that, above all, we need rules that guarantee freedom, independence and security. The liberal professions do not need excessive rules. You must be able to work independently and freely.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the issue raised by this question deals with one of the most discussed, if you will, but least regulated events, as many members have said about the structure of our economic development. The role of the liberal professions has historically been well represented by the Commission's pronouncements and correctly, as the question also points out, the main needs have been pointed out on time: from the issue of simplification, to internationalisation, to access to funding.  It is precisely on this last point that I would like to point out to you that, on closer inspection of what is happening within the Union – including in my own country, for example – the entrepreneurial nature of the form in which the liberal professions often associate, is not basically recognised, is formally, but not entirely substantially so. In fact, all too often it happens that these groups of freelancers have serious difficulties in accessing forms of funding that the Union makes available in order to generate development and innovation. I would therefore ask you to pay particular attention to this particular point.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am very pleased that we are taking up this subject today, because the free professions are of great importance not only in the labour market, but also in society. In my opinion, the regulation of many professions and other regulated professions must be severely reduced and, in most cases, even abolished altogether. Unfortunately, in general, the strong corporate lobby in individual professions has a huge and effective impact on politicians in individual Member States, with the result that there is little deregulation in Europe. Yeah, I'm even watching the opposite. Excessive regulation, on the other hand, has many harmful effects – for example, they restrict access to the professions of new apprentices, which has an impact on the level of unemployment among people with education in a given profession. They also significantly increase the costs of obtaining and subsequently practising a given profession. More addition, they increase the prices of the services provided, since they restrict competition on the market of the profession concerned. This is why appropriate action is needed at Union level and then also in the Member States. I hope that this is where the European Commission's action will go.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the liberal professions make a decisive contribution to the economic development of the Member States of the Union. As we have heard, over four million self-employed people are active in the Union in important areas such as health, justice and safety. Turnover exceeds EUR 500 billion. The economic crisis, however, has also hit the self-employed. Measures are therefore needed, particularly in the area of freedom of movement, recognition of professional persons and access to sources of funding for the modernisation of their equipment. In Greece, thousands of freelancers have been financially hit by the memorandum. They are "beaten" by the Troika's tax policy and thousands of them are now unemployed, without social security, but also without even being entitled to unemployment benefit. There must therefore be social measures to support the self-employed, not only in Greece but also in the other Member States of the Union, as they have been irreparably affected by the economic crisis.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members very much for their support and for their sometimes very detailed questions. I would like to add only that the Commission fully recognises the entrepreneurial potential of the liberal professions. In this respect we will continue to pay attention to the liberal professions – as I said before – in the framework of the Entrepreneurship 2020 Action Plan.  The liberal professions will, of course, be included in our internal market strategy, with a very strong focus on modernisation, the law and regulations. We will also try to prioritise infringement cases, as mentioned by Mr Schwab. So the internal market strategy will, and should, include a number of potential actions to address barriers – mentioned by many of you – such as disproportionate professional qualification requirements or the extensive scope of reserved activities for regulated professions. The next subject is that of mutual evaluation, which, it should be stressed, covers all sectors of activity – not just the regulated professions. The objective of mutual evaluation is to assess restrictions related to qualification requirements and to remove unjustified and disproportionate barriers. On the recognition of professional qualifications, the Commission is now working very closely with Member States’ representatives to reach an agreement on the proposal for an implementing act introducing the European Professional Card (EPC) – for example, for nurses responsible for general care, pharmacists, physiotherapists and estate agents. The technical infrastructure – which was the subject of the question on EPC – and the other mechanisms in the internal market information system will be completed before January 2016, i.e. in the next few months. This was Ms Le Grip’s question. The action which will follow the mutual evaluation exercise will be announced as part of the internal market strategy. I do not want to go into detail on it here because I think we will have a lot of opportunities to discuss it at the orientation stage, after the orientation debate in the College and after adoption of the internal market strategy. I think I have responded briefly to all the questions. To sum up, I would add that there will certainly be a focus on the liberal professions in the internal market strategy. Modernisation, innovation and diminishing the rules and barriers in these sectors are very important for us, and we will be cooperating with you on this.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the discussion on this point.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the brief presentation of the report by Elissavet Vozemberg, on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, on women working in science and universities and the glass ceiling problem [2014/2251(INI)] (A8-0235/2015).

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am delighted to present, for the last time before the vote, my report on the obstacles faced by women who aspire to rise to the highest levels in the fields of research, technology, science and women who want to join boards and who seek positions of responsibility. I would like to share some thoughts with you on the subject, hoping for your support tomorrow in the vote on this important and ambitious report.  The obstacles we have been talking about have been known, for thirty years, as 'glass ceilings'. These are obstacles to the fight for equal opportunities, barriers to fair treatment that women with qualifications, competences and competences deserve when they seek, with ambition but also with honesty, to achieve the highest possible goals.  To begin with, I would like to talk about how these obstacles are born. These 'glass ceilings', these discriminations against women are due, on the one hand, to the prejudices that still exist in our society, despite the fact that we are in 2015 and we live in Europe, in an extremely ambitious society that should not normally discriminate against half the population of the continent and, on the other hand, to the family obligations that de facto take time out of the everyday life of all women. , even those who have the skills and ambitions to achieve other objectives. The result is, in fact, the under-representation of women in the science and technology sectors as well as on business boards. These are leadership positions which some women are entitled to pursue, provided, of course, that they themselves are in the necessary competitive mood and, on the other hand, that the environment leaves competition unhindered to develop. Considering some of the obstacles to women's professional development, I have classified them into some important categories. Motherhood, privilege and gift of a woman by nature, becomes an obstacle when she absorbs time that could in other circumstances be devoted to the realization of a woman's ambitions. This is an obstacle that stems to some extent from stereotypical perceptions of how much time a woman should devote to motherhood and how much time she can devote to pursuing her goals. Another category of obstacles stems from the completely anachronistic separation between women's and men's professions, at a time when so many castles have been "dropped" by women and indeed with extremely important results and achievements for science and technology. A third category is due to the gender pay gap, a problem which in many cases requires recourse to the courts to restore equality and equal access for women to specific positions in research programmes. Our report refers to motherhood, infrastructure, programmes and funding, citing above all the principles and values of the European Commission and the Member States, which should govern the efforts made by the European Research Institute and within Horizon 2020.  Ladies and gentlemen, I will end by referring to the two main parameters that can change the current situation, in family and in education. The nurturing of children and the education of adolescents and young people have the power to shape those mentalities that we need to finally recognise that half the world's population deserves exactly the same opportunities as the other half, that human beings, men and women, are equal to each other.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE).
text: – Sur President. Irridu ngħarrfu l-abilitajiet u l-kapa大itajiet ta' kulħadd, irrispettivament mill-ġeneru tagħhom billi fost oħrajn nassiguraw is-segwenti: li t-tfal, bniet u subien, jiġu introdotti għal suġetti STEM sa minn età żgħira b'mod interattiv, li jinteresshom u mhux b'modster joiiku. Edukaturi jimmotivaw flower-istudenti sabiex jiżviluppaw l-abilitajiet tagħhom irrispettivament minn sterjotipi, filwaqt li jiġu msaħħa miżuri ta' career guidance wkoll f'dan ir-rispett. Sabiex skejjel jiġu assistiti fl-akkwist ta' riżorsi meħtieġa ħalli studenti jiġu mħeġġa minn età żgħira jidħlu fi proġetti tax-xjenza ħalli hedge jitgħallmu billi jagħmlu. Irridu wkoll nisa li jkunu għamlu su大大ess f'karrieri relatati max-xjenza, jiġu inkoraġġiti jaqsmu l-esperjenza tagħhom bħala models role u mentors fejn dan g gaħdu ma jsirx, u fejn kien hemm sforzi biex dan isir irridu nsaħu dawk l-isforzi.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would also like to greet the Commissioner and also the rapporteur. As a scientist and professor in Portugal, I have seen a progressive growth in the number of women in science and i see this number progress and be accompanied by a notorious increase in the quality of university education and scientific research.  In Portugal, gender balance has been deceitful, but it is coming with unquestionable benefits. However, I recognise that this balance is not yet widespread in the institutions and that there are specific difficulties of the female gender, in particular those related to motherhood, which are not yet properly framed. It is difficult, and often seemingly impossible, to coordinate a system based on scholarships and other highly unstable work regimes with pregnancy. Tools must be created to better protect women by allowing access, especially success in the scientific career at all stages of their lives. There's still a lot of work to do. For this reason, I applaud and support this own-initiative report.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, after congratulating the rapporteur, Mrs Vosenberg, on her report, I would like to point out that, as the statistics show, even today the proportion of female researchers in enterprises reaches 19%, while there are also correspondingly low rates in the educational field. It is clear that these percentages result from discrimination against women in these workplaces, which, in turn, often lead to unequal treatment but also to gender pay gaps. This discrimination is a violation of basic human rights and must therefore be combated. In particular, the Commission should, through educational programmes and campaigns, break down all stereotypes that exist against women and encourage women to head to the scientific and academic workplace. Finally, Member States should, using the media, help to eliminate the stereotypes that still exist for both sexes. Under these conditions, the problem of gender discrimination in science and education can be reduced.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have to say that I feel very involved in this report as a fixed-term researcher, so having experienced for myself the subject we are talking about. The crystal ceiling is a very hard reality in Italian universities, harder than in other European realities.  I would like to urge you here not to remove some of the elements that determine this glass ceiling: the precariousness that has increased in universities across Europe and which is increasingly becoming the expulsion of female intelligence and passion, the competitive character that research is being sought at the expense of cooperation and, again, cuts in welfare and the possibility of choosing one's own research. , his own course of study. I believe that we must proceed simultaneously with the democratisation of research and university activity, but also restore the right to study and the right to research together with a welfare system.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE).
text: Mr President, it is my turn to congratulate our colleague Elissavet Vozemberg for the excellent report and for his very strong denunciation of this glass ceiling which European women still too often still face in scientific and technical careers, in particular. I believe it is essential that if we all come together to realize that human potential, that women's human talents are too often left out, we can make significant efforts together to break this glass ceiling and effectively combat stereotypes, stereotypes, traditional patterns and prejudices.  These are real changes in mentality that must be encouraged in families, in parents, among young girls, themselves, who are too often afraid of these technical and technological worlds. Traditional patterns are that boys are more attracted to calculus, rationality and mathematics, and girls to more literary subjects, where they are able to show their traditional feminine empathy.  All of this must be broken. There is a huge feminine potential that we need to harness for the progress of all.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, I would like to thank Mrs Elissavet Vozemberg for her report, although I cannot support all of the points mentioned. In some areas, the COMPETENCE of the EU is being exceeded. However, the report also sets some good accents when we talk about women's science and university careers. I am pleased that a majority of the House has succeeded in winning my amendment, which places particular emphasis on mothers in science and research. If we go beyond the mere concept of the gender gap in the discussion and ask about the background, we end up with families. Mothers with children are also disadvantaged in universities and in science. Children are a clear career risk, and parenting times are considered gaps in the CURRICULUM vitae. This must change, including for us here in Europe. Educational time is gainful employment and must be paid with a salary. We must finally enforce this, not to the detriment of governments, but these costs, like pensions, are borne by the general public. We also need more child-friendly universities, we need universal childcare close to mothers, close to parents.

name: Jordi Sebastià (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the work she has done and to point out, as this report points out, that the academic and scientific spheres are no exception in the inequality that exists in Europe in the face of the possibilities of employment promotion for men and women.  In this case, the situation is even more cruel because the number of women who successfully start in these areas is very large – in some areas it is greater than that of men – but the invisible glass ceiling prevents them from progressing. We face another scenario of European challenge for real equality, without which there will never be social justice.  Our amendments, accepted by the rapporteur and the committee, have only wanted to stress that, in order to avoid such discrimination, we must take above all educational measures involving men in tasks considered 'female', and especially in the education of children, which are the ones that end – as has been said – to prevent women from continuing their professional development.  If a woman takes full responsibility for family life, it is absolutely impossible for that glass ceiling to disappear due to more fees or measures we take. I am therefore very grateful that this view has been included in this report and I hope that it will challenge all the equality measures proposed from here.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, firstly, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Ms Vozemberg, and the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality (FEMM Committee) for this initiative. The draft report on women’s careers in science and university and the glass ceilings encountered is a very welcome move. It reflects well the current state of play and proposes concrete ideas to move forward. Let me share with you a few thoughts on it.  First: institutional changes. As was rightly mentioned in the report, these are very much needed to remove institutional barriers and bias. In science, men and women may have the same qualifications, but they often do not have the same chances to succeed because of persisting discrimination and stereotypes concerning the role and capacities of women. There are still practices and attitudes that produce inequalities.  Institutional changes can help on the way towards assuring that research institutions guarantee equal opportunities for both women and men at all levels. To this end, in the European Research Area, research institutions are encouraged to adopt fully—fledged gender equality plans which include a detailed account of the state of play on gender equality within the organisation, measures to address existing bias, setting targets and monitoring of progress.  With institutional changes we have moved on from women-focused programmes, which are useful initiatives but are not necessarily sustainable in the long run. Institutional changes in research organisations are today the cornerstone of the Commission’s strategy on gender equality in research. In Horizon 2020, our framework programme for research and innovation, these institutional changes are clearly pursued, but we need to do more and we need to do better. We need all Member States to engage in the same line in the context of the European Research Area. I am glad that the European Parliament is on board as its help and its role is crucial.  Second: the importance of enforcing the existing regulatory framework on gender equality. This is stated at the outset of the report, and the Commission fully agrees. It is not enough to have laws; we need effective implementation and enforcement. The Commission monitors the correct application by Member States of existing EU legislation on gender equality.  In research, we also need to address the specificities of the sector with concrete actions, both at the EU and national level. In May 2015, the Council adopted the European Research Area roadmap and called on the Member States and the Commission to implement top action priorities through action plans and strategies. Translating national equality legislation into effective action is one key priority. The roadmap also states that gaps in cross-cutting gender equality legislation at EU and national levels should be addressed. We know that national laws, strategies and incentives have a positive impact in triggering actions by research institutions. This is important, as research institutions are the ones ultimately responsible for implementing institutional changes through gender equality plans.  The Council asked for appropriate indicators to monitor the progress made at national and EU level, as does the European Parliament in its report. Again, the Commission fully agrees. The ‘She Figures 2015’ leaflet was published last July, and a full report will be published in January 2016. In this endeavour, the Commission would like to underline the need for a full collaboration from the Member States in order to produce robust indicators. Third: gender balance in decision making in research bodies and institutions. Participation of women in decision making is just as important. Women are still under-represented in decision making and the phenomenon is not self-correcting. In response to this, we see that many European states are choosing to set targets or quotas. In 2013, 18 states did so, compared to just 8 in 2008. There is a need to clearly call for improvement on the gender balance in decision making.  Before concluding, I would like to mention three important initiatives on gender equality. The first is on work-life balance. The Commission has just published, in early August, a roadmap in preparation of a broad initiative to improve work-life balance and a decision for 2016. The Commission will consider a mix of legislative and non-legislative instruments including a modern solution to the needs of today’s families. We will now start the consultation process. The European Parliament, the Member States and the social partners will have a very important role to play in this process. The second is the 2012 Commission proposal for improving gender balance on boards of listed companies. The proposal is currently supported by a majority of Member States, and once adopted by the Parliament and the Council it will pave the way for further progress on gender equality.  Thirdly, we also share Members’ concerns on the gender pay gap, which at EU level persists at 16.4%. Last year, the Commission adopted a recommendation on pay transparency aiming to assist Member States and other stakeholders in a more effective application of existing equal pay legislation. It provides a toolkit of concrete measures to tackle pay inequality and the gender pay gap.  We look forward to receiving, by the end of this year, Member States’ notifications on the national measures taken in accordance with the recommendation. We will then assess the need for possible further measures. In conclusion, both women and men are needed if Europe is to achieve its ambitions in R&I for the benefit of the whole of society. The Commission will continue to do its part, but to achieve gender equality the commitment of the European Parliament in terms of the policy and financial engagement of the Member States remains essential. The Commission will take good note of all the recommendations made in the report.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the discussion on this point.  Vote: 9 September 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – The European Union has been pursuing gender equality for some time in academic positions in science and universities. There have been positive developments in these areas in recent years, but gender equality remains a sensitive issue in the European Union. According to the 2012 She Figures publication, women account for only 10% of all rectors, and although for several consecutive years in science, the growing proportion of women has seen a promising change - the number of female researchers remains significantly lower than that of the opposite sex. Women's contribution to society must be treated and respected in the same way. Gender equality is an aspiration, while making full use of human rights by women and girls. Only in this way can we empower them and strengthen their position in the male-dominated labour market and society. Networking support networks and sharing best practices would inspire women to strive for their careers and prevent a society run by stereotypes from limiting women's access to careers in science and academy. Parliament encourages the Commission to build on existing programmes and initiatives and to develop positive campaigns, with a particular focus on the engineering and technology sector, where, despite recent results, women's participation is below average. Awareness-raising campaigns should focus on men and women, consciously or unconsciously, spreading gender stereotypes that lead women to deliberately oppose cultural and institutional barriers to scientific careers.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the short presentation of the report by Liliana Rodrigues, on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, on the empowerment of girls through education in the EU [2014/2250(INI)](A8-0206/2015)

name: Liliana Rodrigues
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank all the members who have made an open wish to this report. It was a key contribution to achieving the document we have at hand today. In fact, that's how we reached compromises and that was our best win, putting what really matters at the heart of the discussion, namely girls and young women.  I sincerely believe that education is the best way to ensure that in the future everyone has the same rights in all areas of society and life in the future. Some will argue that we are better off than we were a dozen years ago and that time will take place to balance the rights of women and men. True, we are better, but things have progressed slowly, even here, in the European institutions. However, millions of women feel, more or less implicitly, this discrimination every day. What is intended with this report is to develop a critical spirit in women and men and this is essential for the elimination of stereotypes and prejudices. This critical and autonomous thinking has to be worked on since childhood. Young people, women and educated men can change the power structure of a society, so we should not fear this change.  This report was framed in the International Women's Day, which took education as a priority and as an instrument of emancipation, as an instrument of power. Educational institutions are also those in a better position to ensure democratic education, education for gender equality, education for freedom. However, school cultures that do not meet gender equality are still maintained as the first value of democratic Europe. Research and education showed us this in all lines of curriculum studies. That is why I am most concerned that young women and girls are still discriminated against in a Europe that is said to be civilized and a lady of fundamental values that we have inherited from an unfulfilled revolution: freedom, equality and fraternity.  That is why I set two general objectives at the beginning of this work, the first being to ensure equal empowerment of girls by education, the second to comply with the Istanbul Convention when it sees education as a tool for preventing gender discrimination.  This has been five specific objectives: to create a school culture of gender equality, to critically supervise curricula and teaching materials, to ensure gender equality with regard to personal and professional decision-making, to improve the percentage of women in positions of responsibility and in senior positions and in scientific careers, as mentioned above in the previous debate , promoting equality in terms of economic independence. I think that we will all agree here on these objectives, despite our ideological differences. We must aspire to more than mere tolerance. We reject in this report the idea of tolerated and dominant tolerant dominas. We want to make Europe the place where nothing of what is different becomes strange, we want to make sure that girls are in par with boys. Without them, the idea of equality will not be possible. Even if this is a report on the empowerment of girls, it is clear to all of us, without boys and men, in this project, little or nothing will be worth it.  This report is one of all of us who understand the urgency of protecting girls and young women from a world that still kills because we are women. I am counting on the support tomorrow for this report to be voted on in favour. What is intended with this report is to protect our girls who will soon be women. We are protecting the women who will come, we are protecting the daughters of Europe.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, this report aims to completely change the image of family and society and I will not support it. Behind the enticing headline that gives the impression that this report aims to improve girls' access to education is actually a skillfully packed imposition of gender ideology in all schools of the Member States of the European Union. The report goes so far as to even prescribe curriculum content to Member States by pointing out that they place a gender perspective in sex education, although it is common knowledge that education is within their exclusive competence. This report violates numerous international conventions that guarantee the right of parents to be their children's first educators. The report is a direct attack on the right of parents and their children to respect for private and family life, as well as an attack on teachers who restrict freedom of conscience. This report has nothing to do with education, its goal is to change the overall family structure of our society and therefore I will not support it.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the European Union's mission is to promote equal opportunities. All children must have access to free and quality public education without discrimination, regardless of their State of residence. In this scenario, moving forward with measures that are protective of gender equality is increased.  The holistic approach advocated by the report is a path that will have results. It is part of a diagnosis which recognises that promoting the democratisation of education has contributed to equal opportunities, gender equality and overcoming social and cultural economic inequalities. It also lists measures capable of being firm steps towards empowering the Union with the right instruments and means.  I am convinced that the development of personality and a spirit of tolerance, solidarity and responsibility will facilitate social progress and democratic participation in society. I applaud and support this own-initiative report by Mrs Rodrigues.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, empowering girls in the European Union through education is essential in order to achieve gender equality. All Member States should contribute to the democratisation of education in order to ensure that gender equality is promoted in this way and that men and women are given equal opportunities to participate in social and economic development. In addition, awareness-raising campaigns on discrimination against women should be organised and career guidance services should be improved in order to reduce discrimination on the labour market as well. In all teaching programmes, gender rights education should be included. Any awareness-raising initiative on the issue of gender discrimination should be strengthened. Education should break down gender stereotypes and promote women in all workplaces in order to strengthen society in general.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, dialogue and good work. We also have a good result. In the FEMM Commission, Mrs Rodrigues, but also in the CULT Commission I believe that we have worked in the right direction, on the path that is never completed by gender equality, but also on the true emancipating role of education. By the way, if you want the previous point's report to succeed and have any chance, you should all enthusiastically support Mrs Rodrigues' report. If not, it will be to deceive ourselves. I had not planned to intervene in this debate, but I began to receive aggressive emails, alerting to the very serious danger that Europe, families, etc., were involved, and I realized what was really going on. This report is the evidence, the proof of 9, of urgency, of the need to move forward on the path it proposes: that of gender equity, that of the fight against stereotypes, etc. That is why I say today that I am honoured to share with Mrs Rodrigues, Mrs Ward and other colleagues the work done. Empowering means approaching a respectful equality with diversity, the real autonomy of our schoolchildren, our students to choose their professional future, to decide on their lives and on their own bodies.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: – I strongly reject ideological interference with the right of parents to raise their own children and to interfere with the competence of the Member States. I repeat my persistent reservations about the use of the ambiguous term 'gender' in the resolutions of this House. The rapporteur is also calling for the EU to accede to the Istanbul Convention. I believe that such a move would be a breach of the Treaties. The Istanbul Convention calls for the adoption of laws relating, for example, to the curriculum or criminal law. However, under the Treaties, the EU does not have the power to adopt such legislation. In a similar vein, the European Court of Justice has ruled in the past to confirm that the EU's accession to the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms would be incompatible with the treaties in force on the European Union. For these and many other reasons, I cannot support this report.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I, too, do not thank Mrs Rodrigues for this report. The European Union was a great hope for The Slovaks for democracy, freedom and pluralism of opinion. After more than a decade in the EU, many citizens are starting to ask us: And where is that democracy? We are seeing repeated efforts to oversteer the competences of the European institutions and not respect the principle of subsidiarity. They do not agree with the increasing pressure to promote gender ideology in our schools, in our families and in our society. However, millions of people across Europe say a clear 'no'. In France, Italy, Croatia, Slovakia and other European Union countries. We are obliged to hear this voice. I call on the reporters and representatives of the other EU institutions to honour the rules and principles arising from the Fundamental Treaties of the European Union. The Rodrigues report, like the Ferrara, Noichl and others report, is just a demonstration of how these principles are constantly being violated. I strongly call for us to respect the Member States in their sovereignty.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Great cinema from the left, but ultimately only a left-wing gender-gaggle. I shall vote against. Almost 90% of this report breaks the principle of subsidiarity. Education policy, I repeat, is not the eu's job. Europe's hands have lost nothing in the curriculum of our children, indeed my children. Certainly not when it comes to issues such as sex education. Transsexuals behind the teacher's desk in front of children in first grade? It would be more important to have a mother of seven, a single parent or an unemployed father who will tell the children how they are living their lives and what family means. Not peer teachers, who represent a group of an estimated six to ten thousand people in Germany. When it comes to education for girls, All I can say here is that the issue is missed. And even if I repeat, Europe has so many problems, indeed so many challenges to overcome. The last thing we need is EU sex education in our primary schools. Please stop annoying us again and again with own-initiative reports like this, beyond all our competences!

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission welcomes the report on empowering women and girls through education. This report underlines that education policies and practices are crucial in order to sensitise young people to gender equality and to combat gender stereotypes, sexism and gender-based violence from an early stage. For all these reasons, the Commission is pleased to see Parliament’s report in line with its work in this field. There are important achievements. There is now much greater awareness of gender equality as an educational issue. Women have greatly increased their participation in tertiary education; almost 60% of university graduates in the EU are women. In addition, women’s participation in previously male-dominated study subjects is now significantly higher.  Yet despite important progress in recent years gender inequalities still persist in European education systems. For example, while women are more likely to have a higher education degree, they are still under-represented in science, mathematics and engineering studies and careers in research. Women are not making labour market gains commensurate with their educational achievements. While there are many more women graduates, men still have a higher employment rate than women among recent graduates, leading to a 4% gap at EU level.  There are also strong gender imbalances in the teaching profession. Women are being under-represented in management positions, including in higher education, and men under-represented in the teaching force. Right now schools, universities and teachers are rarely assessed in terms of their gender equality policies and practices. The gender equality dimension is mainstreamed into the strategic framework for European cooperation with Member States in the field of education and training.  Last March, the education ministers met in Paris, in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks in France and Denmark, and adopted the Paris Declaration on promoting citizenship and the common values of freedom, tolerance and non-discrimination through education. Gender equality was clearly and obviously identified as one of our core EU values that education ministers committed to strengthen and promote.  The gender equality dimension is also mainstreamed into Erasmus+, our current funding programme, which offers substantial opportunities for gender-related work. The Commission shares the view that gender equality must go beyond the level of political intentions and become a reality.  The Commission also welcomes the strong emphasis on teachers. The attitudes of teachers and teacher educators are crucial in facilitating change. The Commission will continue to promote gender equality through its policies and programmes. This is reflected in the new priorities proposed for cooperation with the Member States in the context of the ET 2020 strategy framework.  Faster progress is possible. We need to move from the identification of challenges to solutions. We need active policy intervention that is sufficiently resourced, guided by evidence, with concrete and measurable targets and with tools to monitor progress. The Commission is looking forward to seeing the impact of this report and of the resolution on policy debates and on policy action around Europe.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the discussion on this point. Vote: 9 September 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Филиз Хюсменова (
text: alde), in writing. – The recommendations in the report on the emanation of girls in the EU through education correspond to the publicly announced positions of the Bulgarian liberal political party Movement for Rights and Freedoms concerning the integration of children by minority groups.  We find it essential to initiate national and supranational debates. The issues of integration and gender equality concern the whole European Union, especially given that it has around 12 million Roma and that they are the largest but poorest and least joined minority. The discussions to include addressing the problems of gender inequality in children and young people from minority backgrounds, in whose societies it manifests itself more often and to a greater extent.  We believe that education is the most important strategic priority for the integration and dignified life of minority groups and we focus on issues of access to education, early inclusion in the education system and the skillful leadership of children's society to achieve integration and prevention against gender inequality attitudes.

name: Fernando Maura Barandiarán (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Education is a fundamental tool for giving power to women, improving their economic and social status and promoting change towards a more egalitarian society. Factors such as poverty, social norms or gender stereotypes negatively influence the educational outcomes of women and girls, and contribute to the segregation of the labour market.  On the other hand, teachers' attitudes, classroom environments, or learning approaches can reproduce gender stereotypes that unconsciously influence students' personal development and educational choices. It is therefore necessary that we carry out studies and campaigns to raise awareness and training of teachers on the influence of these stereotypes, so that we can better identify and combat inequalities.  Similarly, we must stress the need to introduce sex education and health issues into schools where special emphasis is placed on equality and respect. In addition, it is important that we facilitate the continuous training of women so that they can grow professionally and avoid their stagnation or the abandonment of the labour market. To achieve this goal, it is essential to promote measures that facilitate work and family reconciliation where men and women cooperate and share the responsibilities of working and private life.
